column2: CINCINNATI, May 31 (UPI) Lee May hit two homers and Hal McRae and Tony Perez added one each to power the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-4 triumph over the Montreal Expos and give Jim Merritt his 10th victory.
Police and Fire Department investigations continued yesterday into the explosion of a tank truck carrying liquid oxygen that killed two persons in Brooklyn Saturday and injured 40.

WASHINGTON, May 31 A majority of United States Senators are reported to have signed a letter to the Administration urging that Israel be allowed to buy 125 additional jet fighter-bombers, to meet the growing threat of Soviet militancy in the Middle East. The Senators include many oponents of President Nixon's policies in Indochina.
COPENHAGEN, May 31 One European securities man to the other: "Why can't some authority decide how long the working day should be?"

Yesterday morning the State University of New York Maritime College at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx awarded diplomas to its 114th graduating class, numbering 154 men, the largest in the school's 96-year history.

Nobody can say that New York hasn't been forewarned. "This spring take a good look at Central Park south of 86th Street," says the Parks Council, a valuable civic organization, "because at no other time in the 1970's will you be able to see it intact."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 31 Bill Romano's Brand X won two races and finished second in a third to capture Thistle Class honors as 73 boats sailed with the Huntington Y.C. in the annual holiday regatta for Tri-Club Y.R.A. yachts this weekend.
PRAGUE, May 31 (Reuters) Attacks against Czechoslovakia's reform leaders of 1968 mounted today while their former leader, Alexander Dubcek, was home from Turkey visiting his gravely ill mother.
A Methodist minister described it as graphic, a Roman Catholic nun called it excellent, a Presbyterian pastor hailed it as superb, and a rabbi said nothing like it had ever been done before.

Since everybody is being so relentlessly candid I mean the authors of these books and the various people in them I may as well confess at once that I approached them absolutely gimlet-eyed with suspicion. The sheer Californiaultra-trendiness of the encounter-group, T-group, sensitivity-training (or what have you) movement is enough to sour the most bright-eyed believer in new designs for living.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 31?On the afternoon of May 6, a Wednesday, Dr. Edgar F. Shannon Jr., president of the University of Virginia, was pelted with mashmallows and that night students threatened to break into his home.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., May 31 Peace symbols crowned a sea of mortarboards and a Pomeranian scampered among the audience with a red protest band tied to his rear left leg. But Vassar graduated its seniors today (as did Smith and Mount Holyoke) in the wellbred, tranquil style that has always been expected of the elite women's colleges.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) The Army has let its hair down. It now says that reasonable sideburns and mustaches are admissible and excessively short hair is not.

By GERALD ESKENAZI Terry Sawchuk of the New York Rangers, the holder of many National Hockey League records for goaltenders and considered by many to be the sport's finest goalie, died yesterday at the age of 40 after being hospitalized for more than a month.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 Miss Joel Anne Chasis and Frederick Joseph Roll Jr., who will receive M.D. degrees from New York University on June 8, were married here today by Rabbi Edward Klein. The ceremony took place at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Winik, uncle and aunt of the bride.
The Roundabout Theater is a neighborhood playhouse that operates out of the basement of a supermarket on West 26th Street, and is marked by the ambitiousness of its repertory.
Arnold Denker, a former United States champion, won first place in the 196970 Manhattan Chess Club championship. Denker scored 8 -1 during the 11-man round-robin.
One man was wounded and three suspects were being held by the police after a running gun battle yesterday afternoon between the occupants of two cars in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

MARLBORO, Mass., May 31 Ann Seranne's and Barbara Wolferman's standard poodle Ch. Alekai Luau gained the top honor today at the Framingham District Kennel Club allbreed show and obedience trial on the Marlboro High School grounds.

STOCKHOLM, May 30 Premier Olof Palme of Sweden will begin a nine-day visit to the United States on Wednesday, and he sees his trip as an opportunity to explain "the ideas and interests this small country stands for."

CHICAGO The postman, as he usually does, rang for the third time the other day at Paul Harvey's trim, native-stone house in the exclusive Chicago suburb of River Forest. He was bringing the day's third large bag of mail most of it letters from applauding listeners of the man who is called, and on occasion calls himself, the "voice of the silent majority."

NEWARK, May 31 The runoff election campaign for Mayor that began here May 12 with the defeat of four of the six contenders is halfway over, and Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, one of the two surviving candidates, has not yet begun to seek votes actively.
ALCATRAZ ISLAND, Calif., May 31 Hundreds of Indians swarmed onto this old prison site today in a bold challenge to the Federal Government's plan to convert it into a national park.

MONTREAL, May 31 (UPI) Five bombs exploded in the wealthy suburb of Westmount today, bringing to nine the number of blasts since Frenchspeaking separatists suffered a setback in the Quebec provincial election.

Part of the natural beauty of track and field is its spontaneity and penchant for the unexpected: At any instant, in one of numerous events, an athlete may find himself motivated beyond his wildest dreams.

GABORONE, Botswana, May 28 Sixty miles upstream from the Great Victoria Falls, the Zambezi River surges with a powerful current between tree-lined banks 300 yards wide and provides this young southern African nation with her only link to her sister states of black Africa.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 31 Harmon Killebrew ended a tense battle of relief pitchers with his second home run of the game, leading off in the bottom of the 10th, to give the Minnesota Twins a 7-6 victory over the Yankees today in the finale of a three-game series at Metropolitan Stadium.
After four months on the airways, the Boeing 747 jumbo jet is drawing qualified raves from the airlines, mixed reviews from its passengers, and outright affection from its pilots.
A mother and her 4-day-old son were killed yesterday when she apparently jumped with the baby in her arms from the fifth floor of the Beth Israel Medical Center, the police reported.
TOKYO, May 31 (Reuters) More than 8,000 students and young workers staged meetings and demonstrations today in a nationwide campaign to protest the presence of American military bases in Japan.

Miss Betsy Davies Ottenberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Ottenberg of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Griffin Cherkasky, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Cherkasky of the Bronx and East Hampton, L.I.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 31 Miss Anne Janine Rosenthal was married here today to Pedro Mitro at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Milton F. Rosenthal. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue of New York.

ROME, May 31 Millions of Italian families are worrying these days whether their children will be able to take endof-term examinations as the heightened militancy of teachers unions is disrupting the state school system.
WIXOM, Mich., May 29 The older workers at the Ford auto plant here like to tell about the young kid, fresh from high school getting his first taste of work on the assembly line.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 30 Alan Pifer, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, warned foundation officials this week not to "overreact" to recent regulatory legislation and "impose on themselves a degree of cautiousness and self-censorship that goes beyond what is necessary."

Ultra-high-frequency television station WXTV, operating on Channel 41 in Paterson, N.J., had the initiative yesterday afternoon to pick up live coverage of the game, between Mexico and the Soviet Union, that opened the ...
LOS ANGELES, May 31 Candidates in the California primary elections attacked each other vigorously last week as the campaign drew to a close.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 (UPI) Bill Grabarkewitz's two-run homer off George Culver with none out in the 11th inning today lifted the Los Angeles Dodgers to an 8-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and a sweep of their three-game series.
At a special gala at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, New York vociferously, clamorously and most of all affectionately said farewell, but not goodby, to Sir Frederick Ashton.
Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday: "The Vietnam war is the single most important factor as far as the stock market is concerned."

The New York Giants completed thier second trade in less than 24 hours yesterday by acquiring Clifton McNeil, a wide receiver and all-league selection, with the San Francisco 49ers in 1968, for two high draft choices.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31 About 75 Vietcong and North Vietnamese soldiers, who seized part of the resort city of Dalat yesterday, slipped past hundreds of encircling Government troops today and escaped into the surrounding hills.
OTTAWA, May 31 The Government announced tonight that the Canadian dollar, pegged at 92.5 United States cents since 1962, would be allowed to "float freely" in the world currency market.

LOUDON, N.H., May 31 George Follmer of Arcadia, Calif., took over for his luckless teammate, Parnelli Jones, and drove his factory Mustang to victory today in the 200-mile Trans-American sedan race at Bryan Motor Sport Park in Loudon, N.H.

LOS ANGELES, May 31 Gov. Ronald Reagan, unopposed in his bid for a second-term Republican nomination, has campaigned vigorously on two money issues to be decided Tuesday in California's primary election.

Two state records, four additional meet marks and a team title that wasn't decided until the final event made the Catholic High School Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships yesterday one of the most exciting in its 42-year history.
PHILADELPHIA, May 31 A growing rebellion of students against what they describe as "the Jewish establishment" has reached into the newly created American Zionist Federation.

ROME Alberto Fontana, to give him a name, is a 30-yearold Roman, a furnace repairman by trade, who has not married and still lives with his family. He has a girl friend, but his mother keeps a close watch on all that.

WALTHAM, Mass., May 31 (AP) Prof. David Keith Hardy, director of Brandeis University's Film Theater Arts, was killed yesterday when his car struck a deer on a road in Blandford. He was 45 years old and lived in West Newton and Meredith, N.H.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Name-calling by Vice President Agnew has driven many moderate students into the arms of radical campus leaders, the chairman of the Special Commission on Campus Tensions said today.

MOSCOW, May 31 The reported arrest of Zhores A. Medvedev, a leading Soviet biologist, has set off speculation that a new chapter may be beginning in apparent effort by the Soviet authorities to silence criticism of their policies at home.

DENHAM SPRINGS, La., May 31 (UPI) Undercover agents and mounted policemen with shotguns waited until the music died before dawn today, then slipped into the "Festival of Man and Earth" to arrest about 50 long-haired youths.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 31 (UPI) Ken McMullen drove in three runs with a homer and a single and Jim Fregosi also got a homer and a single today to pace the California Angels to a 6-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.
Dr. Henry E. Marks, a specialist in internal medicine and in diabetes, died yesterday at his home, 145 East 84th Street. His age was 79 and his office was at 121 East 60th Street.
As commuters who drive know too well, it takes ingenuity, a car radio and a little bit of luck to elude the daily traffic jam into Manhattan.

MATALLA, Crete, May 27 An idyll is ending here. Harassment from Greek authorities is dispersing a hippie community that made the Roman burial caves in these soaring limestone cliffs on Crete's southern coast into a low-budget Mediterranean Shangri-la.
Gonorrhea, a disease once thought under control, is rampaging through the country, crossing socio-economic lines, making inroads into suburbia and afflicting an overwhelming proportion of youngsters.
High school students from New York and New Jersey have done well in the National Maritime Union's annual college scholarship contest.
PITTSBURGH, May 31 Steel shipments were rising sharply last week.
Mark Feldman and Lou Reich of Cambridge, Mass., led the field into the final session of the Goldman Pairs championship at the New York Hilton here last night.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 31 "The trouble with this city is that it's surrounded by more desirable places."
Three-year-old plans for a new consolidated passenger steamship terminal on the Upper West Side appear to have been whipped into acceptable, though drastically reduced, shape.
About 60 shots were exchanged early yesterday between policemen and the occupants of a Harlem apartment where the police said they found close to $1-million worth of heroin and an arsenal of weapons.
The New York Mets swept a seven-hour, 23-inning doubleheader yesterday from the Houston Astros, a team they had not beaten in 13 months until this weekend.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 31 Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, the new Prime Minister of Ceylon, today announced a 21member Cabinet that includes 17 members of her Sri Lanka Freedom party, three Trotskyites and one Communist.

Miss Victoria Wright Pierce, daughter of former General Sessions Court Judge Samuel R. Pierce and Mrs. Pierce, was married here yesterday afternoon to Denis Sirera Ransmeier, a member of this year's graduating class at Amherst College.

SAYVILLE, L.I., May 31 Bill Pagels's der Seeadler, a Raven, swept all three races among the Class A handicap craft today as the Sayville Yacht Club's annual Memorial Day weekend regatta came to a close. The only other sweep was credited to Ed Laviano's No. 289 in the Pacific Cat Class.

For about 195,000 ticketholders who attended the Royal Ballet's six-week engagement, which closed last night, this has been a season dominated by the company's guest artists, Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev.

The United Fund of Greater New York's success when it was introduced last year was due, in large measure, to the response of contributors and companies, unions and government. Among its accomplishments was

IT'S what's inside that counts in many of the new modern furniture designs that have been introduced in recent weeks. That a cube cannot be always taken at face value is emphasized by the new 31-inch box that the Charlton Company, Inc., introduced at the wholesale.

Steve Sandler of the 92d Street Y.M.H.A., the defending champion, gained the final of the National Amateur Athletic Union one-wall handball championship yesterday by defeating Bruce Davidoff, his clubmate, 21-6, 21-12, at the Municipal Courts in Coney Island.

William H. Hobson 3d, former vice president and manager of C.V. Starr Co., an insurance concern in Manila, died Saturday of cancer in Memorial Hospital. He was 36 years old and lived at 396 Oakland Beach Avenue, Rye, N.Y.

One Democratic candidate for statewide office took a quick telephone poll last Thursday conducted by calling 200 enrolled Democrats at random and then threw out the results when 124 people, or 62 per cent, said that they were undecided about how to vote for Gov-...
LOS ANGELES, May 31 Federal health officials have quietly scotched an Army plan to dump the residue of germwarfare chemical into the Arkansas River, a tributary of the Mississippi.
Two persons were accidentally killed in Queens yesterday in separate fires of unknown cause in the Rockaway Beach and Ridgewood areas, the police reported.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 26 Unemployment in this country, running in excess of 25 per cent, is combining with extremely low wages to send many Dominicans in search of illegal entry into the United States.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 (UPI) Gene Alley's homer and Al Oliver's two-run double marked a five-run third-inning outburst that knocked out Juan Marichal today and paced the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

NEWTON SQUARE, Pa. An impeccable West Highland White Terrier, Ch. De-Go Hubert owned by Mrs. Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N.J., defeated 1,217 rivals today and won best in show at the 40th annual Delaware County Kennel Club event. It was the 18th top award for the terrier who was handled by Clifford Hallmark. Henry H. Stoecker of Holmdel, N.J., judged the finals.
TOKYO, May 31 The old truism about Europe sneezing when Wall Street catches cold now applies demonstrably to Japan as well.

John J. Burns, the Democratic state chairman, urged party leaders across the state yesterday to redouble their efforts on behalf of the primary election candidacy of State Senator Basil A. Paterson for Lieutenant Governor.

LIMA, Peru, May 31 An earthquake rocked Peru this afternoon, bringing down homes and buildings and leaving dead and injured in an area spanning half the country. Some towns were reported to be in rubble.
DETROIT, May 31 Probably rarer than the whooping crane is the college president who bad mouths money.
MADRID, May 31 (AP) Generalissimo Francisco Franco, Spanish Chief of State, presided over a military parade today marking the anniversary of his victory in the civil war of 1936-39.

An off-duty policeman who was accused of shooting an offduty housing patrolman in the Bronx after an argument over a yard party was released without charge shortly after the incident Saturday pending a grand jury investigation.

Msgr. James H. Casey, pastor emeritus of St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church, Parkville Avenue, near Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn, died Saturday in Victory Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 90 years old.

PARIS, May 31 (UPI) Arthur Ashe and Cliff Richey had to struggle for victories and Mrs. Billie Jean King gained an easy triumph today as the three Americans advanced in the $100,000 French open tennis championship.
Beginning today the police will charge $50 instead of $25 for towing away cars parked illegally in midtown Manhattan. The additional $25 fine for illegal parking remains unchanged.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 31 A sociology department will be re-established at Harvard University next month after 24 years in which the field was combined with social psychology and social anthropology under the umbrella of "social relations."
The 1970 series of four free Naumburg Orchestral Concerts on the Mall in Central Park got off to a chilly start on Saturday night. Boyd Neel was the conductor and Elaine Bonazzi the soloist.

NEW CONCORD, Ohio, May 31 (UPI) President Nixon made small talk about football and surfing to put college protesters at ease in a confrontation at the Lincoln Memorial May 9, but he really wanted to help them to understand the "lessons of history," Ronald L. Ziegler, White House press secretay, said today.
MARTINSVILLE, Va., May 31 (AP) Bobby Isaac of Catawba, N.C., continued his winning streak today by taking the rain-shortened $50,000 Virginia 500 NASCAR Grand National race at Martinsville Speedway.
WASHINGTON, May 31 Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff called today for a Federal investigation of the nation's 1,200 private health insurance plans to help the consumer determine what he is buying.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 31 (UPI) The Indianapolis Motor Speedway distributed a record purse of more than $1-million tonight to the participants in the 54th annual 500-mile auto race won by Al Unser.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 31 Miss Anne C. Lynch and Edward J. Hart were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's brotherin-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph V. Keneally, who attended the couple.

The Chief Justices of the United States, present and retired, are pegged as strict and liberal constructionists on constitutional issues. But on or off the bench, Chief Justice Burger and former Chief Justice Warren are proving that neither can be so narrowly labeled because both take a broad view of the problems that threaten this country and the freedoms that can save it.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 31 The Class A yachts headed by Huey Long's 73-foot ketch, Ondine, held the first 10 fleet positions when the 25th Block Island race of the Storm Trysail Club ended today, making this 200-mile spring fixture a big-boat event for a change.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 31 Several hundred Buddhist monks and nuns of the militant An Quang faction began a 48hour hunger strike today.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 31 Gary Player, the leading South African golfer, said today that black and white golfers should be allowed to develop together in South Africa.

ATLANTA, May 31 (AP) Rico Carty drove in six runs with three homers and a single today as the Atlanta Braves routed the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-1. Jim Nash, a right-hander, gained his sixth straight victory.

HOUSTON, May 31 Miss Carol Anne Keefe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Keefe, was married at the Cenacle Chapel here today to Charles Mark Atwill, a senior at the University of Houston. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. Thomas Cemon of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

Inflation and the rising rate of reported crime have forced insurers to cancel many burglary policies and have made the companies more cautious in issuing contracts. The Federal insurance administrator, George K. Bernstein, says the problem is rampant not only in New York City and its suburbs, "but in every big city in the country."

RYE, N.Y., May 31 Cornelius Shields Jr., C. Stanley Ogilvy and Dr. George K. Brazill Jr. and Joseph F. O'Hora triumphed today in 12 -mile races on Long Island Sound as the American Yacht Club ran the season's fifth Yacht Racing Association championship regatta for a fleet of 123.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 31 (AP) The 1,500 Tufts University students who boycotted the official university commencement yesterday attended their own ceremonies today. The rites departed radically from traditional exercises.
CHICAGO, May 31 (UPI) Johnny Callison and Billy Williams backed the five-hit pitching of Ferguson Jenkins with home runs today and paced the Chicago Cubs to a 7-4 victory over the San Diego Padres.
WASHINGTON, May 31 President Nixon's muckraker in residence, Clark R. Mollenhoff, is leaving the White House staff the way he joined it with a trail of unanswered questions in his wake.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 31 Miss Lynn Ann Moloshok and Dr. Steven Marshall Green were married here this afternoon by Rabbi Jacob Shankman in the chapel of Temple Israel on Pinebrook Boulevard.
KATMANDU, Nepal, May 31 (Reuters) A British climber was killed on Annapurna I in the Himalayas yesterday after helping two companions make the first ascent of the mountain's south face.

WINCHESTER, Va., May 31 (UPI) Shirley Englehorn got a par on the first playoff hole today to beat Margie Masters by a stroke in the $15,000 O'Sullivan women's open golf tournament. The two finished the 18 holes deadlocked at 210, six under par, to force the playoff.

Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, whose Thomas Jefferson Democratic Club conducts draft counseling among other services ("two or three cases a week"), laments not only his lack of patronage but his lack of party control. "I have no control over the leaders; he says. "Every leader is an entity to himself."

Mrs. Mamie Klein Biegelman, a sister of the late Samuel Klein, founder of the S. Klein department stores, died Saturday in Mount Sinai Hospital, lived at 107 40 Queens Bouleyard, Forest Hills, Queens.
Gene Krupa, who went quietly into retirement in October of 1967, is back at his drums once again, slim, trim and tanned, leading a quartet at Plaza-9 in the Plaza Hotel.

MEMPHIS, May 31 Dave Hill had to wipe the rain from his glasses at every hole today, but despite the weather he posted the low 72-hole total of the 1970 tour as he won the Danny Thomas Memphis Classic golf tournament by one stroke with 267.
An edition of the Official Airline Guide intended for the traveler who has to plan his next move in a phone booth is blossoming out this spring at air terminals, hotels and transportation centers.

Paul O'Dwyer and Representative Richard Max McCarthy accused Representative Richard L. Ottinger in separate statements yesterday of having spent more than the law allowed in the four-way race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

WASHINGTON, May 31 A new method of measuring unemployment, which has attracted favorable attention within the Government, shows that there was actually no increase in joblessness in the United States in the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) Doubles by Luis Alcaraz and Hawk Taylor off Darold Knowles in the eighth inning drove in the tying and winning runs today as the Kansas City Royals broke Washington's four-game winning streak with a 6-5 victory.

Fred Stolle will play Ken Rosewall and Tony Roche meets Tom Okker at Madison Square Garden tonight in playoffs of the $200,000 Tennis Champions Classic. Stolle, Rosewall and Roche are Australians, and Okker is from the Netherlands.

ATLANTA, May 31 Gov. Lester Garfield Maddox, who says he is unable to find truth in any publication except the Bible, today escalated his war against this city's two largest newspapers by threatening to sue them on behalf of "all the good Christian people of Georgia they've lied to all these years."

MIAMI, May 31 Premier Fidel Castro denounced today what he described as "irresponsibility" of many Cuban workers, in a 75-minute nationally televised speech, delivered near Bayamo in Oriente Province and monitored here. He stressed that human rather than technological factors were "the weak point" hindering Cuba's economic development.

TOKYO "For a man, one cheek in three years." So runs a Japanese proverb, cautioning that a warrior can afford to wrinkle but one of his cheeks in laughter once in three years, Tadasu Iizawa, Japan's foremost living comic playwright, cited the proverb the other day to explain why...

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., May 31 President Nixon received a briefing from his leading advisers and commanders today on the operations in Cambodia and the war in Vietnam and was reportedly "encouraged" by what he heard.
SISTERSVILLE, W. Va., May 31 (UP) The nostalgic sound of steamboat whistles will be heard again in this Ohio River community Saturday when riverboat buffs stage the only known "tootenanny."

MILWAUKEE, May 31 (UPI) A double by Ted Savage with one out in the ninth inning drove in two runs today and gave the Milwaukee Brewers a 7-6 victory over the Detroit Tigers. The Brewers scored five runs in the final two innings.

PITTSBURGH, May 31 An agreement by the Black Construction Coalition, craft unions and employer groups, intended to provide construction jobs for blacks, has been criticized by the Pittsburgh Branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 31 Lucky Y Not, owned by the Sterling Ridge Farms and ridden by Mrs. Sue Mutch of Weston, Conn., captured the green working hunter title and finished as reserve champion in the regular working hunter competition today at the Fairfield-Westchester Professional Horsemen's Association horse show.
The mini-midi skirt-length issue may have split the nation's women into opposing camps and inflicted women's apparel producers with more than their usual, seasonal case of nervous exhaustion.

In his first annual report as president of Columbia University, Dr. Andrew W. Cordier said yesterday that the Morningside Heights-Harlem community in which the university is situated can become "a model for the nation" in the solution of urban ills.
LISBON, May 31 (UPI) Secretary of State William P. Rogers departed today for Washington after what he deScribed as useful and satisfactory talks with top Portuguese officials.
LONDON, May 31 Arkle, one of the foremost steeplechasers in British racing history, was destroyed by his owners today in Ireland, where the horse had been retired since 1966.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 31?The withdrawal of John M. King, Denver oil man, from Investors Overseas Services has opened the way for a European banking consortium to take over the large mutual fund organization.

The credit markets, after reaching the highest yields on record early last week and then stabilizing, face a quiet week for a change. Bond dealers hope the price gains that started last Wednesday will continue.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) Luis Aparicio and Walt Williams collected five hits apiece as the Chicago White Sox went on a 25-hit spree and buried the Boston Red Sox, 22-13, today for only their third victory in the last 15 games. The teams missed setting an American League record for most runs by one run.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 31 (Reuters) Orson Welles has been tentatively cast to play Sir Winston Churchill in a new Yugoslav war film.
ATLANTA, May 31 (AP) Jet fuel that apparently resulted in excessive engine heat was used in a propeller-driven plane that crashed here shortly after take-off yesterday, investigators said today.

Alexander Dubcek returned to Prague last weekend from his ambassadorial post in Ankara. Ostensibly, he came to see his seriously ill mother. But his return was convenient for Czechoslovakia's present rulers, who have largely liquidated the democratic gains achieved during the "Prague Spring" two years ago.
WASHINGTON, May 31 A chain of supermarkets in the Middle West, hoping to increase profits by helping customers choose the "best buys," has set up the nation's first full-scale unit-pricing system.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The Federal National Mortgage Association will return to biweekly mortgage auctions, president Oakley Hunter announced today.
TRIPOLI, Libya, June 1-- The revolutionary government of Libya has engaged the oil industry in a test of wills for enormous stakes.

PITTSBURGH, June 1--The United Steelworkers Union withdrew its opposition to a proposed takeover of Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation by Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., following a secret meeting here with James J. Ling, Texas industrialist, yesterday, it was disclosed today.
GENEVA, June 1--An I.O.S. spokesman declined today to comment on reports of renewed interest by European banks and financial institutions in acquiring a participation in the company.

The mammoth Lockheed C-5A cargo plane seems to be lining up alongside the ill-starred F-111 fighterbomber as a disastrous military investment. Air Force confirmation that a technical study of the costly new transport is under way lends substance to a report by The Armed Forces Journal that the huge plane's fatigue strength is far below contract specifications.

WASHINGTON June 1 (AP) --An ocean explorer says he will return to a reef off northern Haiti on June 15 to begin excavation of what he believes is the wreckage of the Santa Maria, Christopher Columbus's flagship in 1492.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday appointed Thomas F. Galvin, a Manhattan architect and an early Lindsay campaign worker, to head the city's Board of Standards and Appeals.
The widow of John Dewey the educator, left an estate valued between $1-million and $2-million, according to a four page, hand-written will filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

A former Black Panther whose information was used by the Brooklyn police to obtain court permission to tap Panthers' telephones testified yesterday that he actually was "infiltrating" the police while he was an informer and that the information he gave the police was false.

Walter Cronkite, news correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Turner Catledge, retired vice president of The New York Times have been named recipients of the Citizens Budget Commission Distinguished Service Award.

WASHINGTON, June 1--A Federal Communications Commission hearing examiner ruled today that an Orlando, Fla., TV station--tainted by scandal in the late 1950's and in dispute ever since--be returned to its original license holder.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, May 29--Twenty-year-old Conrad Graff, a warrant officer who is the pilot of a medical-evacuation helicopter that carries the wounded in South Vietnam and Cambodia, keeps looking at his passengers.
Soybean futures, together with soybean meal and oil, rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The most attractive commodity on the floor was soybean oil.

NEW DELHI, June 1--In another step to the left, Mrs. Indira Gandhi, the Indian Prime Minister, and her Cabinet decided today to introduce measures to prevent any individual from owning personal property worth more than $67,200 in urban areas.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1 (UPI)--Mike Storen, American Basketball Association executive became the president and general manager of the Kentucky Colonels today.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The Republican National Chairman, Representative Rogers C.B. Morton, said today that United States involvement in the Vietnam war no longer served the national interest, and he predicted that the Cambodian foray would help make it possibe to "get the hell out of there."

GENEVA, June 1 (Reuters) --The World Lutheran Federation said today that it had decided to go ahead with its plans to hold its fifth assembly next month in Brazil, despite strong criticism from a number of leading Lutherans. However, President Emilio G. Medici of Brazil will not be invited to attend.
JACKSON, Miss., June 1-- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy called on youg blacks tonight to avoid violence even in the face of provocation by the white authorities.
LONDON, June 1 (UPI)-- A British art historian said today that a 17th-century French masterpiece at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York might be a fake.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I., June 1--To such relatively mundane school courses as automotive mechanics, data processing and training as medical and dental assistants has been added a glamorous starter: the care and training of the thoroughbred race horse.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 --A blossoming black electorate and a sturdy white backlash meet head-on here tomorrow in a gubernatorial primary that could decide George C. Wallace's political future and influence this nation's next Presidential election.
After studying the autopsy reports in the death of Terry Sawchuk, the Nassau County Homicide Squad said yesterday that the contributory causes were "injuries received in an altercation."
For the first six months of this year, monthly magazines seem up or down in advertising pages depending on the category, according to figures in the May 27 issue of Magazine Industry Newsletter.

This spring, there is no particular vogue such as last season's gypsies, rich hippies and nineteen-thirties looks, and there is certainly no one right way to look.

Mac Foster served two tours of combat duty in Vietnam with the Marines. In one of 14 battles, the 27-year-old sergeant knocked out a 50-caliber machine gun with a grenade. He has been recommended for the Silver Star, as a result of that action near Chu Lai.
Alice Condodina, a member of the Jose Limon company who has turned to choreography in the last two years, presented a concert with her own dance company last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall.

PRINCE ALBERT, Saskatchewan, June 1--Ottawa's decision for the second time since World War II to let the Canadian dollar find its own level in foreign-currency dealings may prove to have important implications for the international monetary system.
From the middle of life, "a stop between open and closed," Joseph Chaikin's Open Theater reflects on our beginnings. "The Serpent" is the group's eloquent reexamination of Genesis:
Two Off Broadway performers were chosen yesterday as winners of the 26th annual Clarence Derwent Awards, given to the actor and actress for best individual supporting performances.

AUSTIN, Tex., May 31--The sizable liberal faction of the Texas Democratic party is confronted again with its longstanding dilemma--what to do in November, this time in the Senatorial race between Republican George Bush and conservative Democrat Lloyd Bentsen.

PALO ALTO, Calif., June 1-- Stanford University, to the surprise of some of its neighbors and to the irritation of others, has announced that it is considering construction of low-income housing on its plush suburban campus.
Prices on the foreign stock markets moved generally higher yesterday, continuing the advance that started last week when prices on Wall Street moved sharply upward.
MANHASSET, L.I., June 1 --Miss Lucy Lynn and James Follayttar, members of this year's graduating classes at Trinity College and Georgetown University, respectively, plan to be married in September.
COLUMBIA, Mo., June 1-- Miss Jacqueline Ann Knowlton and Alan Michael Claude were married here this evening in the chapel of Stephen College by the Rev. Kenneth L. Frerking, a Lutheran minister.

The Union Commerce Bank in Cleveland, which was taken over last year by the Parsons Group--owner of an extensive chain of banks in Michigan, Colorado, Washington, D.C., and Switzerland--published the details yesterday on a long list of transactions with other Parsons banks that it said involved "potential conflicts of interest."

The Sun Oil Company announced a price increase yesterday of 5 cents a barrel to $3.35 a barrel on its East Texas crude oil, effective immediately. Sunoco said the change was made "to meet competitive conditions in the East Texas field," and would affect production of about 12,000 barrels a day.

PARIS, June 1 (Reuters)--A spokesman for the Vietcong delegation to the peace talks here said today the announcement that Thai troops would go to Cambodia confirmed his movement's accusations that the Americans were trying to form a puppet axis of Asian mercenary forces.

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)-- Nine members of the Students for a Democratic Society pleaded guilty, today to charges of aggravated battery and mob action stemming from a demonstration last September protesting the start of the Conspiracy 7 trial.

DETROIT, June 1--Lenore Romney, a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate from Michigan and wife of George Romney. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, called today for the withdrawal of all American troops from Vietnam next year.
MANHASSET, L.I., June 1 --Miss Lucy Lynn and James Follayttar, members of this year's graduating classes at Trinity College and Georgetown University, respectively, plan to be married in September.
COLUMBIA, Mo., June 1-- Miss Jacqueline Ann Knowlton and Alan Michael Claude were married here this evening in the chapel of Stephen College by the Rev. Kenneth L. Frerking, a Lutheran minister.

The Union Commerce Bank in Cleveland, which was taken over last year by the Parsons Group--owner of an extensive chain of banks in Michigan, Colorado, Washington, D.C., and Switzerland--published the details yesterday on a long list of transactions with other Parsons banks that it said involved "potential conflicts of interest."
Richard Brown Jones, founder and president of Economic Analyst, Inc., brokers, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 71 East 77th Street. He was 71 years old.

HELSINKI, Finland, May 30 --Finland, beset by political confusion since the unexpected swing toward the right in the March general election, has settled down for the summed with a nonpolitical caretaker Government headed by the Mayor of Helsinki.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 1 (Reuters)--Spain has barred Rhodesia from the Eisenhower Trophy golf tournament in Madrid in September, the Rhodesian Golf Union said today.
TRIPOLI, Libya, June 1 (AP) --A Czechoslovak Airlines jet plane crashed today in heavy fog at Tripoli's airport. C.T.K., reported that all 13 persons aboard had been killed.
More than 5,000 employes of four breweries here authorized their union leaders yesterday to call a strike if negotiations to reach a new labor contract fail.
With an air of sweet and elegant befuddlement my wife left the Cherry Lane Theater last night vouchsafing the opinion: "Possibly there was a broader theme."

ELMONT, L.I., June 1-- Mayor Lindsay, Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary and nearly 2,000 policemen, fireman and friends attended the funeral here today of Patrolman Lawrence Stefane, who was stabbed to death Thursday.

WASHINGTON, June 1-- Senator Margaret Chase Smith spoke today of a "national sickness" pervading the land, and she denounced protesting student militants. She also attacked their critics in the Administration.

From Peru's ocean port of Chimbote, through the Callejon de Huaylas winding between two Andean ranges, to the jungle-girded city of Iquitos and in countless other communities, Sunday's earthquake traced a path of ruin and death.

JERUSALEM, June 1--An Israeli Army spokesman reported that a 9-year-old Israeli girl was killed this morning and eight other persons, including five children, were wounded when half a dozen rockets launched from Jordan landed in a schoolyard in Beisan, in the Jordan Valley.

KINGSTON, R.I., June 1 (AP) --Margaret Mead, the anthropoligist, has been named first Alumni Association Distinguished Professor at the University of Rhode Island, the college announced yesterday. She will continue teaching at Columbia and Fordham.
A four-month experimental program designed to give relief from jet noise to some communities near Kennedy International Airport was begun yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 1--Reliable sources said today that the recent arrest of Zhores A. Medvedev, a biologist, had brought protests by four of the Soviet Union's most prominent scientists, including nuclear physicists.

REDWOOD CITY, Calif., June 1 (AP)--An Orinda psychiatrist has purged himself of a contempt citation for refusing to testify about a patient, Judge Melvin Cohn of the San Mateo County Superior Court ruled today.
NEWARK, June 1 (UPI)-- A woman was charged today with shooting her policeman boyfriend to death with five shots from his service revolver as he lay in bed in her apartment.
ACCRA, Ghana, May 30-- Ghana's eight million people are happily accustoming themselves to a greater measure of genuine democracy than they have known in years.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 1-- June and a lot of 2-year-old horses were bustin' out all over at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. The occasion was a series of "baby" races, each for a gross purse of $1,000, with $500 going to the owner of each winner.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- "She's not a feminist," an associate of Margaret Chase Smith observed the other day. "She thinks the best way to establish that women are just as good as men is go about your work and not look for any privileges."
OTTAWA, June 1--Canada's new floating dollar soared between 3 and 4 cents in most money markets today.
LIMA, Peru, June 1--The Peruvian Government believes that more than 30,000 people were killed in the earthquake that devastated large areas of northern Peru yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 1--The Justice Department announced today a consent settlement with the Inland Steel Company barring reciprocal buying and selling in violation of the antitrust laws. The proposed settlement was filed simultaneously with a civil antitrust suit in Federal District Court in Chicago.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP) Accounts of peasants in the area where a group of television reporters disappeared Sunday raised a question today whether the men had been ambushed.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 2 George Corley Wallace, the voice of segregation and the South in national politics for almost a decade, was returned to office tonight by the voters of Alabama.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., June 2 (AP) Gov. Frank L. Farrar won renomination in the South Dakota primary tonight over his Republican opponent, Frank Henderson.

Swift Co. showed substantially larger earnings in the second fiscal quarter and half year ended May 2 although sales were only slightly ahead of the preceding year's periods, the report disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, June 2 Two years ago James Roose-Evans, director of the Hampstead Theater, detached himself from the new-play treadmill and launched an experimental acting unit, Stage Two, which is now offering London its first fruits in a converted veneer factory near Regents Park.
The first man-made part of a human cell, the lysosome, has been produced by two New York University scientists.

TRENTON, June 2 A former building maintenance company executive told the State Commission of Investigation today about what he said were bribes paid by the company to elminate public bidding on cleaning contracts for such state agencies as the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and the Department of Transportation.
WASHINGTON, June 2 Manufacturers' new orders declined and inventories rose substantially in April, the Commerce Department reported today.
A plaza at Fordham University's Lincoln Center campus was dedicated to Robert Moses yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, June 2 (AP) One of two brothers suspected of blowing up the Danbury police station and robbing a nearby bank of more than $26,000 has been charged with trying a second time to escape from jail.
TEL AVIV, June 2 Premier Golda Meir's coalition government has been showing signs of internal tension.
Foreign policy issues occupied the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York yesterday.

It's obvious that investor confidence was up last week. The stock market tells us so. But there was no sign of an uptick in consumer confidence. That stayed at a recession level, says Sindlinger Co., an opinion and research organization.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 2 The state's Big Six mayors will wage a major campaign this fall for greater independence through a "very substantial" restructuring of home-rule provisions at the next session of the State Legislature.

Frank L. Catapano, Democratic leader of the 38th Assembly District in Brooklyn and formerly aide to former Assembly Speaker Anthony J. Travia, died Saturday at Interboro Hospital in Brooklyn of a diabetic ailment.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 2 Arthur J. Goldberg began a three-day upstate campaign today in his quest for the Democratic nomination for Governor by chiding Governor Rockefeller for "unsound and unfair budget practices" and by pledging to consolidate or abolish state agencies grown "fat" with patronage.

Walter Krause, whose athletic goal has been to exit as a winner, fulfilled his ambition last night when the National Collegiate Athletic Association foil champion was named New York University's outstanding athlete for the 1969-70 season.

BUFFALO, June 2 Sixtytwo Buffalo policemen have been commanded to appear tomorrow in a line-up at Police Headquarters following complaints that the police attacked a man and sprayed a caustic substance on two infants in a home last April 6 in an East Side Negro neighborhood.
HANOVER, N.H., June 2 Darmouth and Connecticut scored victories over Providence and thus eliminated the Friars from the National Collegiate District I baseball championship at Rolfe Field today.

RYE, N.Y., June 2 More than 400 competitors started play in six age divisions in the United States Seniors' Golf Association's annual two-day event today, and when the opening round was finished, a familiar name was on top of one of the sections.
Metal futures prices increased yesterday in moderate trading.

The stock market closed virtually on an even keel yesterday, thanks to a brisk rally in the final half hour that wiped out earlier losses. Thus, the market continued to display an inner resilience to profit taking that both surprised and encourged Wall Street observers.
WASHINGTON, June 2 The State Department said today that the United States would provide arms and equipment to ethnic Cambodians living in Thailand who go to Cambodia for military duty.

Motorists who have been exasperated for some time by the annoying detour in the Bronx in the vicinity of the Bruckner Traffic Circle received some encouraging news yesterday from the State Department of Transportation. A new detour with fewer bends and turns is expected to be opened in about two weeks.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 2 The trial of John Norman Collins, charged with killing one college coed here and held as a suspect in a half-dozen other slayings, opened today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 The dispute between the In dians encamped on Alcatraz and the Federal Government intensified today after a series of fires destroyed a number of the old prison buildings on the island last night.

Steel production rose 2.3 per cent last week from the preceding week's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was the largest week-to-week advance in more than three months.
More than 30,000 freshmen are expected to register at the City University this September, Chancellor Albert H. Bowker reported yesterday.
M.E. Green Co., Inc., commodities brokers, has reported to the commodity exchanges with which it deals that it is unable to meet its financial obligations.
The Nassau County District Attorney decided yesterday to let a grand jury determine whether a crime had been committed in the death of Terry Sawchuk, the New York Rangers' goalie.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 2 Five political prisoners were executed last Saturday for killing two guards during an attempted escape four months ago, informed sources said today.
A pipe bomb exploded early yesterday morning outside La Stella Restaurant in Forest Hills, Queens, the scene of a police roundup four years ago of 13 reputed Mafia leaders.
There was a time when one block in Manhattan between Second and Third Avenues on 59th Street boasted one of the greatest concentrations of fine food shops in America.
WASHINGTON, June 2 A high Treasury official told Congress today that in his personal opinion the time had come to "give serious consideration" to some form of voluntary restraint on wages and prices.
CLAYTON, Ala., June 2 After voting for himself, George Corley Wallace paused on his way out of the Barbour County Courthouse today to speak to an old friend.

President Andrew W. Cordier of Columbia University evoked applause from an outdoor commencement audience of 8,000 persons on the campus yesterday when he declared that the Indochina war's 44,000 American dead, 300,000 wounded and $100-billion cost "cannot be justified" either by its character or "any conceivable result."

MIDLAND, Mich., June 2 (AP) Five members of a group calling itself "Beaver 55" entered pleas of guilty today to charges of conspiracy to willfully and maliciously damage property of the Dow Chemical Company.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 2 Jim Maver of Winged Foot celebrated his 21st wedding anniversary today by winning the 37th annual Hochster Memorial golf tournament at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.
Negotiators for Typographical Union No. 6 and The Long Island Press are scheduled to resume talks today in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract.

SAIGON, South Vietnam (AP), June 2 The United States command has completed an investigation into charges of looting lodged against American troops who captured the Cambodian town of Snoul last month. Any disciplinary action that may be taken will be carried out by the units involved, a spokesman said today.
The 102d Belmont Stakes picked up a speedball and an oddball yesterday with the addition of Delaware Chief and Hark the Lark.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 2 The financial troubles of the world youth assembly have been eased by a $28,200 gift from Britain and a promise of free air travel given by the United States, probably for as many as 100 participants.
Millions of soccer fans will be losing a lot of sleep this month, and Swedish sociologists fear families may be split up.
ATLANTA, June 2 On a rainy night in Georgia, the Braves finally beat the Mets, eight months too late for the 1969 pennant.
Sam McDowell's fastball is good enough to stop opposing batters, but he has to use some mental curves on himself.

Arthur L. Wadsworth, executive vice president and a director of the investment banking firm of Dillon, Read Co., died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 7 The Dogwoods, Roslyn, L.I., yesterday. He was 59 years old.

Representative Richard Max McCarthy said yesterday that he was the only one of the four Democrats running for the United States Senate who could preclude a November victory by James L. Buckley, the Conservative party's candidate.
The Transit Police Department's highest award for valor, the Medal of Honor, was given posthumously yesterday to a young patrolman who was slain in the Times Square area last February.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 2 Above the coffee shop in the shiny new Oakland International Airport is a row of 24 clocks telling the time at 24 points around the globe, including the Azores, Dakar and Bombay.
Two policemen and a civilian have been indicted on felony charges of possessing dangerous drugs, Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts announced yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, June 2 (UPI) England, which is defending the title, Peru and Uruguay all won today in the 1970 world soccer championship.

Many Columbia graduates of the class of '68, recalling the tumultuous spring of their last term on Morningside Heights, say they have moved to the left politically, but also have developed an antipathy for violence.

WASHINGTON "Every time I think of New York I'm consoled by the fact that it's an exception to the rules," said Wilfrid Owen, the transportation specialist and senior fellow at the Brookings Institution here.

Conferees at a general session of the American Association of Museums at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel weighed and found wanting yesterday a resolution formulated by the New York Artists Strike Against Racism, Sexism and War.
PARIS, June 2 In happier times the cream of Cambodian society used to pack its sons off to the Lycee Chasseloup Laubat, an elite French secondary school in Saigon.

TRENTON, June 2 Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark went on trial here today in Federal District Court with seven other defendants on 66 counts of conspiracy to extort $253,000 from Constrad, Inc., a company that builds sewers for Newark. Severances were granted to four other defendants.

MOSCOW President Nixon correctly estimated the advance military and diplomatic implications of his decision to order U.S. troops into Cambodia to clean out Vietnamese Communist sanctuaries and, as discussed in a previous column, enormous booty was seized while Russia and China displayed prudence in their initial reactions. However, where Nixon made a grievous miscalculation was in judging repercussions at home.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The Labor Department's Office of Federal Contract Compliance said today there was an acute lack of job opportunities for Negroes and other minority group workers on construction projects in the Newark area.

Concern over the Quality of life in America has blossomed so swiftly and so pervasively in the last few years that it is hard to imagine a time when air and water pollu tion, congestion and, indeed, the environment in general were not active social and political.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 2 Miss Dena Finn and Arnold E. Merriam were married here at noon today in the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David Finn. The ceremony was performed by the bride's granduncle, the Rev. Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. He was assisted by his son, Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) Members of the Senate Republicans and Democrats, hawks and doves ralied today around Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, in a rare display of unity.

A group of city hospital physicians called on the directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation yesterday to resign in a body unless funds were provided for "a reasonable standard of care in our municipal hospitals."

DENVER, June 2 A group of black university students made an unscheduled appearance at the annual meeting of the Southern Baptist Convention today and urged the virtually all-white assembly to "live up to the precepts of Jesus Christ" in racial relations.

WASHINGTON, June 2 Secretary of State William P. Rogers today met with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, for a renewed attempt to defuse Arab-Israeli tensions, but the two apparently made little headway toward a political or military understanding.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 2 Assemblyman Jess Unruh was nominated by California Democrats tonight to run against Gov. Ronald Reagan, who was unopposed for the Republican nomination.

The right of women to end unwanted pregnancies and the physical, emotional and economic strains they can cause has been recognized in a new New York State law which takes effect July 1. If properly implemented, this law should make legalized abortions available to the poor and near-poor just as they have always been available to the well-to-do who could travel to jurisdictions already sanctioning them.
A team at the University of Wisconsin reported yesterday the first complete synthesis of a gene the inherited, coded "message" that tells a cell how to perform a certain chemical function.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP) North Vietnamese sappers overran part of a Government fire base in the far northern part of South Vietnam today but were beaten back after inflicting heavy casualties on the South Vietnamese defenders.

ROCHESTER, N.Y. When the four students were killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State University on May 4, nearly 1,000 of the University of Rochester's 3,300 undergraduates met in a dining hall to seek a way to vent their anger and frustration.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) Thomas F. Lutz's Clover Blossom, making her second start of the year, took the lead in midstretch today then held off the late bid of Lady Jester to win the Juniata Purse at Liberty Bell Race Track by a neck.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UPI) Five young men, one identifying himself as a son of a junior college president, were held today in $1,000 bail each after they allegedly picnicked on an American flag near the Walnut Lane Golf Course.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 There is widespread doubt among the most experienced American observers in ...

The National Lead Company announced yesterday that it will increase the price of its antimony oxide by 30.5 cents to $1.38 a pound, effective immediately. The company said that move reflected higher raw material costs.

PEORIA, Ill., June 2 Miss Kathleen Michele Rothberg and J. Brian Barnett plan to be married here June 21 at the home of the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rothberg, who are also of New York.
NEWARK, June 2 Rhody A. McCoy, administrator of Brooklyn's Ocean Hill-Brownsville Experimental School District, is being considered for the job of president of strifetorn Essex County College here.

United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. won a decisive victory yesterday in New Jersey's Democratic primary, defeating a Senate candidate backed by the powerful old-line Hudson County Democratic organization to win the party's nomination for a third term.
R. Buckminster Fuller, the builder of the geodesic dome, called yesterday for, the restoration of Biblical dwellings in Jerusalem to bridge the past to the present.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) Antiwar Representatives said today they would try to amend a proposed debt ceiling increase in order to cure United States involvement in Southeast Asia.

HOUSTON, Tex., June 2 Houston, America's space headquarters, was described today by the chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, William H. Brown 3d as a "very sick city" for not providing jobs for blacks, Mexican-Americans and women.
WASHINGTON, June 2 Conversations here on the creation of a demilitarized zone between Honduras and El Salvador have entered an intensive phase.
WASHINGTON, June 2 Robert H. Finch, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today that he had dismissed Dr. Stanley F. Yolles, the Government's chief mental health official.

Sculptor, traveler, writer and feminist, Clare Consuelo Frewen Sheridan managed to shock her proper family and many proper Britons in the nineteen-twenties and thirties by her indiscretions in print and in deed.

BOSTON, June 2 The sixstate New England area was forced to reduce its electric voltage by 5 per cent as some 2,500 leaders of the electric utility industry sat down to the second day of the 38th annual Edison Electric Institute convention here. The chief topic of the day's speakers was a detailed analysis of the industry's efforts for environmental improvement.
The appointment of Dr. George W. Shea as dean of Fordham University's Liberal Arts College at Lincoln Center was announced yesterday by the Rev. Michael P. Walsh, president of the university.
LONDON, June 2 (Reuters) Britain's gold and dollar reservers rose by 3-2 million ($7.2-million) to reach 1.153billion ($2.767-billion) in May, the Government announced today.

PARIS, June 2 President Pompidou pledged continued French amity toward the Soviet Union today after France's leaders discussed the ArabIsraeli conflict and other world problems with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko.
Prices on the London stock market turned moderately easier yesterday as a four-day rally in line with the Wall Street recovery ran out of steam.
The American Stock Exchange scored its fifth consecutive advance yesterday as the list closed higher in active trading.
WASHINGTON, June 2 The building at 4500 16th Street N.W. is still known officially as the Royal Embassy of Cambodia.

As Raphael Pavia, the 44year-old bartender accused of robbing 20 banks in the last three months, was arraigned yesterday, his wife leaned over to the handcuffed prisoner and whispered, "Why did you do it?"
Negotiations on a contract for the school system's paraprofessional employes resumed last night against a background of mounting strike preparations by the United Federation of Teachers.

The adaptability of opera to the exigencies of television has long since been demonstrated, and although we do not see many operas on the TV screen nowadays it is not because the art form and the medium are incompatible.

BATAVIA, N.Y. June 2 Four Mafia members, including two who had attended the 1957 gangland gathering at Apalachin, N.Y., were arrested at lunch here today in Mancuso's Restaurant. Two men who were lunching with them also were taken into custody by the police.
MOSCOW, June 2 (AP) The Soviet Union's manned Soyuz 9 switched orbit today and suffered fouled portholes, apparently as a result of the maneuver.

As she did twenty years ago in her "declaration of conscience" against the right-wing excesses of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Senator Margaret Chase Smith is attempting to rally the country to moderation and good sense. One can only hope profoundly that it will not take four years this time for her counsel to be heeded.

Lawyers for 13 Black Panthers sought to prove yesterday in Manhattan Supreme Court that the New York County grand jury that indicted them was heavily weighted against the young, the poor and the black.
NEWCASTLE, Northern Ireland, June 2 (UPI) Bill Hyndman and Dale Morey, America's top hopes in the British Amateur golf championship, gained impressive first-round victories today.

Harry Bridges, president of Shell Canada, Ltd., will be proposed to the board of the Shell Oil Company for election as a director and executive vice president and chief operating officer of Shell Oil in the early fall.

New York department stores last month managed to push their sales to a figure slightly above the level of that in May of 1969. The city's leading stores registered a 1 per cent average gain in their downtown stores and went ahead by 2 per cent in their suburban branches.
The three corporate bond issues priced late Monday sold quickly yesterday when they were offered to investors, but the recent recovery in prices for issues already outstanding has lost some steam.

A few jokes by Joe Garagiola brightened the plodding testimony in Curt Flood's antitrust suit against baseball's reserve clause system yesterday, as three high baseball officials restated the position that the present system was necessary and fair.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 2 (Reuters) A battalion of Cambodian troops attempted today to reach the cars of eight missing television newsmen but pulled back under heavy fire.

Hitting with the precision, depth and confidence of a world champion, Rod Laver beat Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, 6-3, 6-3, 6-1, last night in the $200,000 Tennis Champions Classic at Madison Square Garden.

Does the architect who designs his own home have a fool for a client? Four architects who renovated three rooming houses in the West 90's admit to making mistakes. But they still think it's wonderful, as Peter Samton put it "to create your own life." Among the mistakes they admit to having made are:

The days of the literary salon are not over. That was clear at 6 P.M. on Monday when four large rooms of the National Arts Club overflowed with guests who came to hear the praise as well as the voice of the late John Masefield.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 2 The Camden County Prosecutor's Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation opened inquiries today into the escape of eight "dangerous" prisoners last night from the sixth-floor jail of the Camden County Courthouse Building.

John R. Bunting, a former Federal Reserve economist who now heads Philadelphia's largest bank, chided fellow economists yesterday for "notoriously bad" analysis in the last couple of years, adding that if they did not offer more imaginative solutions to economic problems they were in danger of being relegated to a role like that of a court jester.
The New York Yankees, who climbed into second place this season without much front-line pitching, got some of it from Fritz Peterson last night as they defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-2.
The Wellington Management Company announced yesterday that it plans to add an incometype mutual fund to the 11 other funds it manages.

Mrs. John A. Papps, for many years active in charitable affairs in Glen Cove, L.I., died Sunday at Hambledon, in Surrey, England, after a short illness. Mrs. Papps, the former Edith Powell, was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Powell of Glen Cove.

The devastating earthquake that has rocked a 600-mile stretch of coastline in Peru and taken the lives of unknown tens of thousands in scores of towns in the Andes is another brutal reminder that scientific energies must be directed much more intensively toward the forecasting and prevention of natural disasters.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Edwin Carroll Stein, an editor for the Voice of America, died of cancer yesterday in DeWitt Army Hospital, Fort Belvoir, Va. He was 60 years old.

Coldgas Trading, Ltd., jointly owned by the Royal DutchShell group and Mitsubishi Shoji Kaisha, Ltd., announced yesterday the signing of final documents for the shipment of $1.6-billion of natural gas over 20 years to three Japanese utilities. The deal is among the largest natural gas contracts ever signed.

The Bendix Corporation has established two new top management posts to direct its domestic and foreign operations, A.P. Fontaine, board chairman, president and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

In an agreement with 20thCentury-Fox, the Museum of Modern Art will present a series of six vintage Fox films, both silent and sound, which have not been available to the public for many years, starting next Tuesday. The opening offering is "City Girl," a 1928 silent drama directed by F.W. Murnau with Charles Farrell, Mary Duncan and David Torrence in lead roles. It will be shown at 2 P.M. and 5:30 P.M.

LIMA, Peru, June 2 Government and private radio stations were dominated today by urgent calls for doctors, medical supplies and food for northern Peru, which was devastated by an earthquake Sunday, but roads blocked by landslides kept the most seriously affected communities isolated.
Anthony A. Bliss has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Foundation for American Dance, the parent organization of the City Center Joffrey Ballet.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 Dr. Graham B. Blaine Jr., chief of psychiatry at the Harvard University Health Services here, and Mrs. Blaine have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Carson Blaine, to David G. McNellis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. McNellis of Riviera Beach, Fla.
The city Commission on Human Rights and Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday in separate actions to fight discrimination against Orthodox Jews who are denied employment because they observe their Sabbath.
Gordon D. Cates, an advertising executive, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 17 Linden Avenue, Larchmont, N.Y. He was 63 years old.
The first round of play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, contested by 98 teams Monday night at the New York Hilton, produced the usual quota of upsets.
CORONADO, Calif., June 1 (AP) Lieut, Gen. Ralph J. Mitchell, U.S.M.C., retired, an aviation commander, died here Sunday at the age of 78.

Abraham Kraditor, a lawyer and certified public accountant who was a former national commander of the Jewish War Veterans, died of a heart attack Monday after being stricken at his office, 38 Park Row. He lived at 183 Girard Street in Brooklyn, and was 74 years old.
Canada has cut its dollar loose from the United States peg of 92 cents and is letting it float upward in value. The move was a wise one for a country troubled both by inflation and unemployment.
DETROIT, June 2 The four major auto makers reported retail sales today of 267,548 United States-model cars during May 21-31 compared with 304,627 a year before.
HARRISBURG, Pa., June 2 (UPI) Six persons were arrested today following a clash between welfare recipients and state officials over a proposed 75 per cent cutback in public assistance.

The community school board elections in Manhattan last Thursday attracted a far lighter turnout of voters than the elections held previously in the other boroughs, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 2 President Rafael Caldera of Venezuela, here on a state visit, urged President Nixon today to produce "tangible deeds" in support of his public promises of changed attitude toward Latin America and he insisted on a new policy toward imports of Venezuelan petroleum.
MANILA, June 2 (UPI) A hand grenade ripped a gaping hole in the fuselage of a Philippine Air Lines passenger plane with 44 persons aboard today, killing one person and injuring 12 others.
BUENOS AIRES, June 2 (Reuters) The fate of the kidnapped former President, Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, remained unclear today in the wake of threats gainst his life and a high-level attempt to save him.

Interest rates inched lower yesterday, cautiously continuing a trend that began a week ago.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (UPI)-- Rod Laver beat Ken Rosewall, an Australian countryman, tonight to win the $30,000 Rawlings tennis classic.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 3-- Eighty-two per cent of the nation's adults oppose student strikes as a way to protest "the way things are run in this country," the Gallup Poll said today.

The London stock market closed mixed yesterday after an initial drifting tendency was followed by a moderate upward swing.

United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., who won a decisive victory in Tuesday's Democratic Senate primary election in New Jersey, showed every indication yesterday of unifying badly split Democrats in the state for the first time since 1965.

Giorgio Cavaglieri was elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects for 1970-71. He succeeds David F.M. Todd. Announcement of the organization's new officers and yearly awards were made yesterday at the group's 103d annual meeting in Delmonico's Hotel.
A $10.2-million Federal grant was awarded to New Jersey yesterday to finance the second phase of a program to revitalize Penn Central commuter service between Trenton and New York.

The art of photography, which most of us tend to take for granted as a workaday medium of visual information, has, like other branches of the fine arts, an esthetic as well as a technical and social history. In the annals of this esthetic history, the 1920's constituted a crucial decade.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) --Three federally financed studies are under way on the use of antibiotics in agriculture. The studies were ordered after a report in Britain argued that the use of drugs on animals made disease in humans harder to treat.

English chess parlance has culled some picturesque words from foreign languages. One of the most striking is the Cerman zwischenzug. This denotes a cunning intermediary, or intermezzo, play that is a surprise or even a shock to the foe.

George Wallace's nomination for the governorship of Alabama confronts President Nixon with some extremely hard choices. By placing Mr. Wallace in a favorable position to run for President again in 1972, it presents the Nixon strategists with three alternatives, none of them as attractive as dealing with a South bereft of its ablest demagogue.

The Reisinger Knockout Team Championship will continue tonight at the New York Hilton with 16 teams in contention in the fourth round. This is the premier event in the Eastern Regionals, which will end Sunday.

A dozen or so pages into Caleb Gattegno's "What We Owe Children" I was so struck by the simple, self-evident truth of his thesis that I was almost reluctant to read on for fear of anticlimax. Because if the answer to what is wrong with our system of educating children is so obvious, why has it taken so long to discover it?

"It's too good to be true." This comment by a broker summarized his opinion of the performance of the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Prices on the exchange made their sixth consecutive advance in the second heaviest trading of the year.

The periodic cicada is beginning to reappear in the state after an absence of 17 years, according to the American Museum of Natural History. Though it swarms somewhat like a locust, it is not so destructive, the museum says.

ORANGE, Calif., June 3 (UPI) --Paul Blair, Baltimore Orioles outfielder, was resting comfortably and in good condition today following surgery to correct multiple facial fractures.

Three presidents and part owners of major league baseball clubs--Frank Dale of Cincinnati, John McHale of Montreal and Bob Reynolds of the California Angels--testified yesterday that their investments would be endangered if the reserve clause system were changed.

MOSCOW, June 3--Neil A. The S.S. Kresge Company, Detroit, reported yesterday an 18.1 per cent gain in sales for the four weeks ended May 27 and a 20 per cent gain for the 17-week period.
HUNTINGDON, Pa., June 3 --The Philadelphia women's golf team, captained by Mrs. Charles Wilson, won the 64th Griscom Cup matches today by defeating teams from New York and Boston.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 3 --If President Nixon's handling of the economy, student unrest and Indochina has moved the electorate to the left, as some politicians believe it has, you couldn't prove it by the results of yesterday's primary elections. It was not a good day for liberals or for doves.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) Frank Render 2d, of Syracuse, an educational and civil leader, was chosen by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today to become Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Civil Rights.

Menasha Skulnik, the theatrical star of two worlds Yiddish comedy and the Broadway stage died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital after a short illness. He was 78 years old and lived at 535 East 86th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Ten leading Senate advocates of the sale of additional aircraft to Israel conferred for an hour today with Secretary of State William P. Rogers, and emerged expressing guarded optimism that the Administration would soon give the Israelis a favorable response.

Mike Andrews, who continued his torrid batting streak yesterday, appears too tall and gangly for a second baseman. But second basemen come in all sizes; Jackie Robinson was a muscular football-player type, while Bobby Richardson was comparatively small.

The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had cut the fair-trade price for New York on four of its refrigerator models by $5 to $15. A fairtrade price is the minimum price, determined by the manufacturer, at which a retailer may sell a product.

Barbra Streisand, the house-hater, the art nouveau, art deco and cranberry glass collector, the German Expressionist admirer, the cup-cake baker and decor maker, looked serious, spoke softly and moved swiftly through her unfurnished town house at 49 East 80th Street the other night.
ATLANTA, June 4 Tom Seaver struck out his boyhood idol, Henry Aaron, tonight, but while he was doing it, he, lost his temper and the ball game, in that order.

The United States announced yesterday a tougher bargaining position with foreign nations that restrict operations by United States airlines.
Ron Stewart and 10 Ranger teammates will attend the funeral of Terry Sawchuk today in Berkley, Mich.

The Jewish Theological Seminary of America presented its annual awards last night at the New York Hilton Hotel to nine persons active in business, civic, cultural, educational and communal affairs.
ROME, June 4 Italy, never a dull country, has seemed in recent days to verge on the chaotic.
NUKUALOFA, Tonga, June 4 This Polynesian monarchy, which has been a British protectorate for 70 years, was proclaimed an independent nation today by its king, Taufa'ahau Tupou IV.

The Police Department has brought charges against two Manhattan patrolmen, a sergeant and a lieutenant. It acted after a person arrested on a charge of first-degree robbery was allegedly released in return for a $90 bribe.

The American Stock Exchange ended in the minus column yesterday for the first time in seven sessions as profit taking in the last two hours of trading erased most of the earlier gains.

Average wage gains of hospital workers in New York City have outpaced those of most other workers in recent years, according to a survey by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A United States farm official said yesterday that agricultural exports this fiscal year will jump $400-million above previous estimates and predicted they could set new levels in 1970-71.

Ewing Kauffman, sole owner of the Kansas City Royals, said yesterday that he would pay Curt Flood $100,000 to $125,000 in salary this year if Flood were available to his baseball team, and possibly more for a long-term contract.

Assemblyman George M. Michaels, who cast the key vote to liberalize New York's abortion law, and who has been hospitalized for a week following an automobile accident, announced yesterday that he would continue as a candidate for re-election.
