WHITE PLAINS, June 4 As 50 elderly men and women looked on, Milton Goell, a 66year-old chronically ill resident of a nursing home here, was awarded a Doctorate of Education in a special ceremony today.

MONTREAL, June 4 (Canadian Press) A walkout by at least 140 employes of the St. Lawrence Seaway Authority over a job security issue had tied up 22 ships between Montreal and Kingston, Ontario, a seaway offical said today.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., June 4 Emmett J. Culligan, founder and retired chairman of Culligan, Inc., a water softening company with more than 1,000 dealerships in 85 nations, died here yesterday. He was 77 years old.
Brooklyn College yesterday awarded 4,284 degrees to the largest graduating class in its 40-year history in outdoor ceremonies at its Flatbush compus as a light rain began to fall.

Rosalyn Drexler may very well be the first Marx Sister. Her new novel, "One or Another," has no more plot than "Horse Feathers" (far less, in fact), but she has filled it up with so many sight, sound and word gags, so many sillinesses and surrealities not to mention little grinning obscenities that the reader soon begins to flinch in anticipation of the next verbal skit and to bark with relieved laughter when it works.

A Selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
A vivid debate between friends and foes of the plans to expand the Metropolitan Museum of Art took place last night at a public hearing in the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History.
The International League took away Buffalo's baseball franchise yesterday after rejecting a bid by the Bisons to keep the financially troubled team in the city.

Armour Co. had higher revenues but little change in earnings in the first half of this year compared with the 1969 period, according to results issued yesterday by Charles P. Orem, president of the nation's second largest meat packer. Swift Co. is the biggest.
Governor Rockefeller was the head cheerleader last night as the Republican party officially opened its 1970 campaign at the largest and most lucrative fund-raising dinner in its history.

TRENTON, N.J., June 4 The selection of six alternate jurors here today completed the jury for the Federal trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and seven others on 66 counts of conspiracy to extort $253,000 from Constrad, Inc., an engineering company that has done work for the City of Newark.

The Office of Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare is investigating a complaint by Puerto Rican parents on the Lower East Side that the Board of Education's redistricting plan for Manhattan schools fosters segregation.

BUFFALO, June 4 Federal, state and local authorities are investigating reports that Buffalo policemen fired shotgun pellets, wounding students on the campus of the State University here, during a disturbance last month.
Brig. Andrew S. Miller yesterday was named head of the Salvation Army's 10-county Greater New York Unified Command.

Lawrence Lachman, chairman and chief executive officer of Bloomingdale's, was elected yesterday as chairman of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York. He succeeds William S. Renchard, chairman of the Chemical Bank, who has been chairman of the New York B.B.B. since 1968.

HANOVER, N.H., June 4 Dartmouth College, behind an 18-hit attack and the six-hit pitching of Charlie Janes, routed the University of Connecticut, 12-3, today to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association District One baseball tournament final.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, June 4 T.S. Eliot's complaint that Hamlet's emotion is in, excess of his given circumstances certainly applies to Trevor Nunn's new production at Stratford's Royal Shakespeare Theater.

The city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance Benjamin Altman, used the forum of a City Council Housing Committee meeting yesterday to attack as "naive, irresponsible, ill-advised and politically motivated" a proposal for modifying rent control put forth Wednesday by 12 councilmen.
MOSCOW, June 4 Soviet authorities have ordered Zhores A. Medvedev, a biologist, detained for at least a month for psychiatric examinations, reliable sources said tonight.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 Mr. and Mrs. Palmer Shepard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ann Shepard, to Malcolm Joel Barnett, son of Mrs. Minna K. Barnett of New York and the late Dr. Sidney N. Barnett, who was chairman of the social studies department at the High School of Music and Art there. Mrs. Barnett is on the planning and program staff of New York City School District 3.

The New York Yankees completed a three-game sweep of the Kansas City Royals last night at Yankee Stadium, spoiling Jim Rooker's no-hit bid in the ninth inning, then winning the game in the 12th, 2-1, on Horace Clarke's bases-loaded sacrifice fly to center field.

DENVER, June 4 The Southern Baptist Convention, which for 125 years has preached the gospel with a drawl and functioned like the Confederacy at prayer, is increasingly turning toward a "Northern strategy."

Although seven players selected in the first round of major league baseball's two-day summer draft of free agents were catchers, the Yankees and Mets picked a pitcher and a shortstop yesterday at the Hotel Americana.
PARIS, June 4 The Pompidou Government's controversial "antiwrecker" law was passed today after a renewed outbreak of the violence at which it is aimed.

"Akokawe," the evening of African music, dance, poetry and story that opened last night at the St. Marks Playhouse as the final show of the Negro Ensemble Company's current season, means "initiation." This is not, as might be expected, a reference to any tribal ritual (although "Akokawe" draws from traditional as well as modern sources) but initiation into civilization.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 (UPI) The American Basketball Association's Pittsburgh Pipers selected Jack McMahon as their coach today. The 40year-old McMahon was a coach for eight seasons in the rival National Basketball Association. He was dismissed in the middle of last season after 2 years with the San Diego Rockets.
PARIS, June 4 A revolutionary International Center of Theater Research has been dreamed up by Peter Brook, the British stage and film director.
LUCERNE, Switzerland, June 4 (UPI) The American team won the Prix des Nations in the show jumping event today at the Lucerne equestrian competition.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Southeast Asia:

The reaction of television commentators and invited studio guests to President Nixon's speech Wednesday evening on the Indochina war ranged from succinct skepticism, sharp criticism and a degree of support to a broad conclusion that not much news had come from the White House.
The Wachovia Corporation of Winston-Salem, N.C., a holding company that owns one of the largest banks in the South, won a major battle yesterday against the Justice Department.
PHOENIX, Ariz., June 4 (AP) Arthur G. Barkley's troubles apparently began in 1963, when he lost his job as a salesmandriver for the Continental Baking Company in Phoenix.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 Earl Caldwell, a reporter for The New York Times, was or dered today to appear before United States District Judge Alfonso J. Zirpoli to show cause why he should not be held in contempt.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 Communist troops seized a village called Sethbo today and then lost it to a Cambodian counterattack in a battle only 10 miles southeast of Pnompenh, officers in the field reported. It was the closest major fighting to the Cambodian capital so far.

"The odds are growing" that the current business downturn will be classified as the nation's fifth postwar business recession the director of research for the National Bureau of Economic Research said yesterday.

Miss Luisa Turrin and Erhard Robert Fernholz were married yesterday in a civil ceremony in Pisa, Italy, where the bride is working for an advanced degree in mathematics and the bridegroom is doing research in mathematics at the Scuola Normale Superiore.
One major upset and one near-upset marked the third round of play in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship at the New York Hilton Wednesday night.

The Federal Reserve System continued to pursue a policy of gradual credit expansion in the latest two-week period, banking statistics published yesterday disclosed. Except for the important money-supply figure, all the reserve and monetary aggregates climbed and most of the sensitive short-term market rates were either unchanged or easier in the most recent statement weeks.

The inexcusable failure of the State Legislature to reform New York's antiquated and dangerous election laws at its last session threatens to create difficult problems as the primary elections approach on the 23d of this month and, beyond them, the general election for top statewide offices in November.
In this time of increasingly personal cinema, the films of Jean-Luc Godard make those of most of his contemporaries look about as original and individual as monogrammed Volkswagens.
Arthur J. Goldberg, returning yesterday from a three-day upstate vote-getting tour, predicted a "big sweep" in November:

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 4 Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam, welcomed like a visiting potentate, arrived today for a conference with the new Cambodian leaders to resolve the delicate question of Saigon's military role in this embattled country.
WASHINGTON, June 4 Eleven University of Minnesota professors told Vice President Agnew today that his public rhetoric was "driving moderates into the arms of extremists."

The appointment of Gustave L. Levy, senior partner of Goldman, Sachs Co., as general chairman of the 1970 campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York was announced yesterday by Douglas T. Yates, president of the fund.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 4 Communist troop activity was reported today in Siemreap Province, the site of the famed Angkor Wat temples, one of Asia's leading tourist attractions.
Prices on the London stock market moved narrowly yesterday in extremely quiet trading.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 4 A group of Oceanside High School seniors said today that they would boycott their graduation because Representative Allard K. Lowenstein had been refused permission by the school authorities to speak at the exercises.
The rain failed yesterday to keep away about 30 youngsters who went to Central Park to participate in opening ceremonies for a new $106,000 playground near Fifth Avenue at 62d Street.

Howard J. Samuels returned tonight from a two-day stumping tour by air in central and western New York State, convinced that while he is still the underdog, he is steadily closing the gap on Arthur J. Goldberg, front-runner in the race for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 4 A field of 11 3-year-old trotters were entered today in the $111,514,24. Dexter Cup Trot, to be staged at Roosevelt Raceway a week from Saturday. The Dexter is the first of the "big five" trotting events. The others are the Hambletonian, the Yonkers Futurity, the Kentucky Futurity, and the Colonial.
MUNICH, West Germany, June 4 (Reuters) Dr. Hjalmar H.G. Schacht, who guided Hitler's economic policies, in early years, died today in a Munich hospital. He was 93 years old.

California blocked from selling bonds for 15 months moved swiftly yesterday to take advantage of its newlyvoted 7 per cent interest rate ceiling. The state announced plans to sell $300-million of notes and bonds on June 16.

Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis, his best known fan, will undoubtedly continue to order her originals from Rome, but starting this fall, women will have a chance to buy their Valentino fashions closer to home.

Solo timpani recitals, or recitals of chamber music with timpani, are rare indeed, but there's no reason they shouldn't work. With five timpani of different sizes in front of a performer, a considerable amount of variety is available.
Charles E. Palmer, a vice president of Clairol, Inc., died here Wednesday after a heart attack. He was 46 years old and lived at 720 Milton Road, Rye, N.Y.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP) A 13-man factfinding party of members of Congress and officials arrived today. One of them said they intended to "look at the bunkers" uncovered by allied forces inside Cambodia.

JERUSALEM, June 4 Lieut. Gen. Haim Bar-Lev, the Israeli Chief of Staff, said today that Israel would be able to stand off the enemy armies and guerrilla forces on her borders in the foreseeable future despite the help the Soviet Union is providing for the Arabs.

A top official of the school system protested at a city budget hearing yesterday that the city was taking a miserly approach to the interscholastic athletic program allotting less than $1,000 annually to each of the city's 90 high schools.

The consolidation movement among Wall Street brokerage houses continued yesterday as Halle Stieglitz, Inc., announced an agreement to take over five offices of Orvis Brothers Co. in the New York area.

The Rapid-American Corporation had a net loss of $356,000 in the quarter ended April 30, in contrast to $4,380,000 earned in the corresponding three months last year, Meshulam Riklis, chairman and president, reported yesterday. Sales were $493,394,000 compared with $326,896,000.
Twelve women of Italian descent will receive American-Italian Women of Achievement Awards at the 14th annual AMITA dinner at the Biltmore tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Europe's youngest Premier, the intellectual and leftist Olof Palme of Sweden, today began a nine-day visit aimed at persuading Americans that his country's opposition to the war in Vietnam did not mean it was hostile to the United States.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 4 (AP) Emile Griffith, the former world welterweight and middleweight champion, floored Tom Bogs twice tonight on his way to gaining a decisive 10-round decision over the previously unbeaten European middleweight champion from Denmark.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 4 Ohio's Republican State Central Committee repudiated today the party's candidates for Attorney General and Treasurer.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia temporarily blocked a Senate subcommittee today from subpoenaing records of an antiwar organization that operates coffeehouses and publishes underground newspapers near military bases.
The Committee for Distribution of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., submitted to stockholders yesterday a formal proxy statement calling for election of its 10-member slate of directors.
WASHINGTON, June 4(AP) President Nixon created today a National Council on Organized Crime to coordinate strategic Federal planning.

Although it does not compare to last year's running, when previously undefeated Majestic Prince and Arts and Letters held the public interest, this year's Belmont Stakes is attracting more than mild attention. The main reason is the presence in the field of Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's Personality and High Echelon.

Advertising budget cutbacks and slow client payments have led to agency personnel parings, a tight job market and a stop to the escalation of creative salaries. At least that's what people close to the scene say.

Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6, reported yesterday that progress had been made in contract negotiations with The Long Island Press. Another bargaining session has been scheduled tentatively for today, he said.
LIMA, Peru, June 4 (UPI) Following, as made public by the United States Embassy here, are the names of Americans reported dead or missing in the aftermath of the earthquake Sunday:

Most of the nation's investors would be protected against losses in the event of brokeragehouse failures by a private insurance corporation that the securities industry has decided to establish in a rare example of industrywide cooperation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (Reuters) The Mayor of Dalat, the Central Highlands resort city that was infiltrated by Vietcong guerrillas last weekend, will be replaced, the official South Vietnamese press agency reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4 Jose Pinera, Chile's chief delegate at the United Nations, asked Secretary General Thant today to call for an emergency plenary meeting of the Economic Commission for Latin America to mobilize all possible aid to Peru in the present earthquake emergency.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 4 (AP) Branch (Big Bear) McCracken, who twice coached Indiana University to the National collegiate basketball championship, died today of a heart ailment. He was 61 years old.

BONN, June 4 Forthcoming state elections in West Germany have suddenly been transformed into a plebiscite on Chancellor Willy Brandt's East European policy and possibly on his coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats.

JERSEY CITY, June 4 Joseph H. Kenny, Surrogate of Hudson County, who had been nominated for a second fiveyear term in the Democratic primary Tuesday, died yesterday at his home, 287 Pavonia Avenue. He was 60 years old.

The Regents of the University of California are preparing for the dismissal of Miss Angela Davis, an assistant professor of philosophy with a background of black militancy and membership in the Communist party. This action will set the Regents, who are doing Governor Reagan's bidding, on a collision course not only with the faculty of the university's campus at Los Angeles but with all defenders of academic freedom.
All morning long, the speculation swirled around Belmont Park yesterday like inside information off a tout sheet.

PARIS, June 4 Cliff Richey won an argument with a linesman, lost his concentration and was beaten today in the semifinals of the French open tennis tournament by himself, the wind, bad umpiring and Zeljko Franulovic.

The national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars said yesterday that he would urge the group's national council to rescind its selection of New York City as the site of its 1972 convention because the Mayor is "doing a disservice to American youth by encouraging resistance to the draft."

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 4 Republican leaders here are seriously considering a vigorous campaign against George C. Wallace in the November general election, not in pursuit of victory but as a means of portraying him nationally as a man of diminishing political stature.

Nine hours before President Nixon delivered his interim report to the nation on Indochina, the Senate decisively turned down an effort to nullify the CooperChurch Amendment which would restrict future military activities in Cambodia. Nothing the President subsequently said in his nationwide address has lessened the need for Congressional action to curb further arbitrary moves that might extend the Southeast Asian conflict.

A committee seeking an amendment to the New York City Charter to provide a legal test of the constitutionality of the war in Indochina opened a Campaign headquarters yesterday at 650 Fifth Avenue, at 52d Street.

Mayor Lindsay was chided by a Councilman yesterday for refurbishing his office with new drapes and carpet during an austerity period. The Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., Democrat of Queens pleaded that the old drapes be used to rehabilitate a crumbling Council chamber.

L. Seton Lindsay, a former vice president of the New York Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday in Concord, N.H. He was 91 years old and lived in Bristol, N.H., and formerly in Islip, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

ATLANTA, June 4 A citizen named Maddox picketed the offices of the two major Atlanta newspapers today and said he was just doing his part to help rid the country of "Communists, anarchists and nasty people."

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) The White House announced today that the United States would increase imports of oil from Venezuela during the second half of 1970. It also indicated that an increase in Venezuelan imports may be extended beyond this year.

WASHINGTON, June 4 A life-sized, chillingly realisticlooking exhibit, designed to arouse public opinion in behalf of the release of American prisoners of war by the North Vietnamese, was installed at the Capitol today with the backing of House Speaker John W. McCormack.

Dr. Clarence B. Farrar, for 34 years editor of The American Journal of Psychiatry, who built the magazine into one of the leading periodicals in medicine, died Wednesday at his home in Toronto. He was 96 years old.
The Federal Government of Nigeria has taken two important actions to carry forward its policy of reconciliation with the Ibos and its promise to alleviate suffering in the former Biafran enclave.

The American Federation of Teachers and the American Jewish Congress, in separate statements yesterday, assailed a federally sponsored plan to set up an experimental "education voucher" system in one or two cities in the fall of 1971.
MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (AP) Bob Lutz of Lo. Angeles and Tom Gorman of Seattle moved into the semifinals today in the Northern lawn tennis championships, a warm-up event for Wimbledon.
Brooks Atkinson, retired drama critic of The New York Times; has been awarded the Actors' Fund Medal by the Actors' Fund of Amercia, Louis Lotito, president of the Fund, announced yesterday.
With the cost of money at near-record levels, one might assume that the commercial banks could improve their earnings quarter-by-quarter just by picking and choosing among prime borrowers.

MONTCLAIR. N. J., June 4 George R. Beach, former president and chairman of the board of the Provident Institution for Savings of Jersey City, who had been a trustee and alumni leader, of Columbia University, died today at his home, 167 South Mountain Avenue. He was 97 years old.
Isadore Silverman, who was in the real estate business here for 50 years, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 1050 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Plans for an "Honor America Day," scheduled as a Fourth of July rally on the grounds of the Washington Monument, were announced today by a citizens committee headed by Bob Hope, the actor, and the Rev. Billy Graham, the evangelist.

DETROIT, June 4 Miss Dorothy Jane Pratt, a doctoral candidate in political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and John David Shilling, who is studying for his Ph.D. in economics there, were married today at the Mariners' Episcopal Church. The Rev. Richard Ingalls performed the ceremony.
HARTFORD June 4 (AP) The process of buying 144 new passenger cars for the New Haven division of the Penn Central has been delayed again.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 4 Should a person openly hostile to the draft be allowed to sit on a draft board?

LOS ANGELES, June 4 Tracked air-cushioned vehicles will soon carry passengers at 150 miles an hour from Los Angeles International Airport, to the suburban San Fernando Valley, hopefully by late 1972, John A. Volpe, Secretary of Transportation, said today.
MIAMI, June 4 (UPI) Two Federal judges handed down sentences of 20 years and two years to airplane hijackers today. The man who hijacked the larger plane got the lighter sentence.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Legislation to continue protection for Negro voters in the South and to lower the voting age to 18 years was cleared by the House Rules Committee today for action on the House floor. The bill has already passed the Senate.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges disclosed plans yesterday for a far-reaching program to consolidate many key service and computer operations in central facilities.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) President Nixon today told a group of 119 high school seniors, chosen by a commission as 1970 Presidential Scholars, that despite "fears turmoil and uncertainty," this was a fortunate time to be alive.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., June 4 (AP) John P. Cahill, the 19year-old son of Gov. William T. Cahill, arrested twice this year on marijuana charges, has been hired by a state agency for the summer.

STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) Nick Shuk, the jockey, was hospitalized today after a fall before the racing program at Delaware Park. He was reported to have suffered a fractured pelvis and a possible spleen injury.
Jay Irving, originator of the comic strip "Pottsy," died Wednesday, apparently of a heart atack, in his home at 650 West End Avenue. He was 69 years old.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 4 Gerold M. Lauck, who retired in 1951 as executive vice president of N.W. Ayer Son, Inc., the advertising concern, died today in Princeton Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at Lawrenceville Road.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 (AP). Gen. Clifton B. Cates, Commandant of the Marine Corps from 1948 to 1952, died in the Naval Hospital here today after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
PITTSBURGH, June 4 The most asked question in Pittsburgh financial circles today Who will replace Richard King Melton as steward of the vast Mellon financial empire was answered today.
The prolonged trucking strike, particularly in the Middle West, combined with continuing cautious buying by consumers to hold down sales last month among seven of the country's largest retail chains.
Miss Christina Curtis and William Lee McHenry will be married next month.

WASHINGTON, June 4 President Nixon made Cambodia sound so good on the TV the other night that it almost seems a pity to leave the place. "All our military objectives have been achieved," he said, and the whole adventure was "the most successful operation of this long and difficult war."
Governor Rockefeller joined state legislative leaders and both Democratic candidates for Governor yesterday by supporting a proposal for greater autonomy for cities.
ATLANTA, June 4 C.B. King, a 46-year-old Albany, Ga., lawyer, became today the first black man in Georgia's history to qualify officially as a candidate for Governor.
WASHINGTON, June 4 White House sources said tonight that former Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge would be appointed tomorrow as an informal intermediary with the Vatican.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Despite the new political challenge posed by George C. Wallace's victory in Alabama, Nixon Administration officials say they are determined to achieve more school integration in the South next fall than has been accomplished in any previous year.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 4 C.L. Gilbert, who prefers to be called Gibby, left the golf tour last week and went home to Hollywood, Fla., while his wife gave birth to their third son. Back on the circuit today with a new club affiliation, the 29-year-old professional scored a 66 in the $150,000 Kemper open to tie 42-year-old Lionel Hebert for the first-day lead.
The stock market lost some of its resilience yesterday as it fell prey to profit taking in a share final-hour decline.
MERIDEN, Conn., June 4 (AP) An Air Force recruiting sergeant who described the Air Force as "virtually noncombatant" and called Army draftees cannon fodder has been relieved of his duties here.

NEWCASTLE, Northern Ireland, June 4 (AP) Bill Hyndman of Huntingdon Valley; Pa., was the only American to gain the quarterfinals of the British Amateur golf championship today, winning two extra-hole matches on the 6,928-yard, par71 Royal County Down course.

BILLINGS, Mont., June 4 (AP) Jeff Bennett, a stocky 150pounder from Oklahoma Christian, set a pole vault record today as he took his second straight decathlon championship in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics track and field championships.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, announced yesterday that the city's teachers had voted 3 to 1 in favor of supporting the paraprofessionals should the latter decide to strike the public school system before the end of the school year.
For the second time in two days, a major corporate executive has hit out against the country's involvement in Vietnam and its effect on the economy.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 4 Carol Reed, the former weather reporter on WCBS-TV, whose cheery sign-off, "Have a happy," became a popular American expression, died of cancer today at her home, 421 North Barry Avenue. Her age was 44.

WASHINGTON, June 4 A disgruntled 49-year-old Phoenix truck driver hijacked a Washington-bound Trans World Airlines jet with 51 passengers aboard this morning and was captured at gunpoint at Dulles International Airport tonight ...

MOSCOW Three years after the Six Day War began, Moscow's Middle East strategy is perhaps no longer based only on rearming the Arabs so they can overcome Israel while the Soviet Union and the United States warn each other to stay away. Indeed, Russia may be preparing deliberately to participate in a limited conflict, reckoning it can get away with this at little risk.
SAN JUAN, P.R., June 4 (UPI) The United States Immigration Service reported today the arrest of 13 Dominicans and one Haitian on charges of attempting to enter the United States illegally.
Rip Torn, the Broadway and Hollywood actor, was dismissed yesterday from Bruce Jay Friedman's new play, "Steambath," for allegedly failing to fulfill "all of the values of the script."

A suit that was dismissed in Federal Court two years ago because the plaintiff was out of town when the case finally came to trial 32 months after he had filed it was reinstated yesterday by the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday a broad plan for a decentralized system of "neighborhood government" throughout the city based on the creation of community boards in 62 districts.

WASHINGTON, June 4 Dr. John S. Foster Jr., the Pentagon's director of defense research and engineering, told a Senate subcommittee today that the Nixon Administration's decision to proceed with deployment of missile-defense systems and multiple missile warheads could be reversed by an agreement with the Soviet Union on strategic-arms control.
WASHINGTON, June 4 An interagency study group agreed today that the Government should make its wealth of data about household products available to the consumer.

WASHINGTON, June 4 All of the House Democrats who are competing to succeed Speaker John W. McCormack when he retires at the end of the year were challenged today to endorse a basic program of reform in House, rules and practices.
The continuing rise in New York City's relief rolls has speeded up slightly this year amid troubles in the nation's economy, but city officials say the increase still remains within budget forecasts.

On Wednesday night, the Violetta in the Metropolitan Opera's performance of the Verdi work was Pilar Lorengar. She is not an artist of strong dramatic temperament, and there was nothing tragic in her portrayal. It was a womanly characterization, very appealing, with touches of pathos now and then.

Soybean futures, together with soybean meal rose again yesterday, setting new seasonal highs on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean oil futures also rose.

Six new "Ottinger Delivers" television commercials rolled across a tiny screen in David Garth's office 14 floors above Fifth Avenue yesterday.

A 75-foot-wide pedestrian mall, forming a midblock connection from 42d to 43d streets between Fifth Avenue and The Avenue of the Americas was unveiled yesterday during dedication ceremonies of the newly renovated City University Graduate Center building.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization said today that Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe had ordered delays in the proposed dismissal of hundreds of controllers accused of taking part in the recent controller sickout.

In a three-hour match unparalleled for drama, tension and the level of quality throughout, Ken Rosewall beat Roy Emerson, 4-6, 6-1, 6-4, 4-6, 7-5, last night at Madison Square Garden and advanced to the final round of the $200,000 Tennis Champions Classic.

State Supreme Court Justice Myles J. Lane yesterday invalidated a recently enacted law that gave New York City incumbents the top line on the ballot for the June 23 primary.

On Thursday night, in her only performance of the role with the Metropolitan Opera here this season, the soprano gave a lesson in how to use one's vocal resources to best advantage.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 5 (UPI) A high official said today that Thailand had put her forces on full alert along the border with Cambodia after North Vietnamese and Vietcong units were sighted north of Tonle Sap, the great lake of Cambodia.

Eintracht Frankfurt, playing a strong game before 3,433 fans, defeated Milan of Italy, 1-0, last night in the United States Apollo Soccer Cup competition at Randalls Island.

He was 74 years old and lived at 920 Greacen Point Road, Mamaroneck, N.Y.

FRANKLIN, Ohio, June 5 (AP) Maj. Gen. Edwin Forest Harding, World War II commander of the 32d Infantry Division, which saw service in New Guinea, died at his home here today. He was 83 years old.

Furriers, who for so long have been villains in many eyes, are becoming heroes. These days, they're almost sprouting halos. Not only have most of them kissed and made up with the conservationists by avoiding endangered animals, but they're becoming do-gooders.

The professional negotiator who was hired by baseball club owners three years ago to represent them in bargaining with the players' association testified yesterday that he felt the players have "equal" bargaining strength with the owners even under the reserve system.

Criminal Court Judge Amos S. Basel said yesterday that a leading Reform Democrat had offered him "a deal" in which, if the judge would quit the Democratic primary race for Surrogate, the incumbent Surrogate would support court reforms.

Suburban libraries, grown increasingly professional and diversified in recent years, find themselves today in a state of good health that few other municipal services can claim.

PARIS, June 5 France and the Soviet Union joined today in deploring "the foreign intervention that is widening and prolonging the conflict" in Indochina.
MANCHESTER, England, June 6 (AP) Bob Lutz and Tom Gorman scored victories over South Africans today to make it an all-American final in the North of England grass championship.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 Highranking Government and corporate leaders were among approximately 1,600 persons who filled the East Liberty Presbyterian Church today at a funeral service for Richard King Mellon, the financier, who died here Wednesday at the age of 70.

GENEVA, N.Y., June 5 (AP) A narcotics raid at Hobart College early today turned into a confrontation with students who were apparently outraged over the use by the police of a young informer known as Tommy the Traveler.

Four candidates, including the appointed incumbent, Barry Salman, are seeking the Democratic nomination for the seat from the 11th Councilmanic District in the South Bronx in the June 23 Democratic primary. This is the only special election for the City Council in the coming primaries.
Edgar B. Kapp, a senior associate of Lehman Brothers, the investment banking firm, died yesterday at Long Beach (L.I.) Memoral Hospital. He was 68 years old.
Mayor Lindsay's proposed $10 auto-use tax and the 5-cent Staten Island ferry fare appear doomed, a City Hall source said yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, June 5 Mary Cottam Hatch, a staff member of the New York Public Library for 29 years, died at St. Agnes Hospital Wednesday after an illness of several months. She lived at 22 West Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale, N.Y., and was the wife of Edgun V. Wulff, an artist and illustrator.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 5 New Zealand's ombudsman, the official who inquires into complaints by the public against Government departments, began an investigation today into the aftermath of Vice President Agnew's two-day visit here last January.

The chairman of the Public Service Commission reported yesterday that the state's major utility companies had taken significant steps to increase their power supplies to meet peak summer loads, but that some "brownouts" were still likely.

The self-appointed vigilantes of the Jewish Defense League have disrupted services, marred parades, picketed museums and radio stations, defaced photographic exhibits, broken up concerts. Their leader hinted strongly that the organization took credit but could not admit it for attacks on Arab representatives in offices near the United Nations. The police have not yet identified the criminals responsible.

Billy Neal Williams, who grew up on the Oklahoma plains and wanted to be a pilot as long as he could remember, crouched behind a seat in the Boeing 727 Thursday and, with his left thumb, cocked the hammer of a revolver thrown to him from the ground seconds earlier.

He carded a four-under-par 68 for a 135 total that gave him a one-stroke lead in the $150,000 Kemper open.

Capt. James A. Lovell Jr. and John L. Swigert Jr., the Apollo 13 astronauts, walked out of the rock musical "Hair" at the Biltmore Theater here Thursday night, apparently over what they considered to be slurs directed toward the American flag.

The Bond Club of New York has elected Avery Rockefeller Jr. as president. He succeeds Robert A. Powers of Smith, Barney Co., who headed the club for the past year. Robert M. The stock market pulled back along a broad front yesterday in what Wall Street observers described as a consolidation move after the recent dramatic advance. The Dow-Jones industrial average dropped 11.50 points to 695.03.

Theodore C. Sorensen, the Democratic State Committee's designated candidate for United States Senator, said yesterday that he was not sure that organization support would help him in the June 23 primary.

THE HAGUE, June 5 (Reuters) Johan A. Pengel, former Premier of Surinam, died in hospital in Paramaribo, the capital of Surinam, today. Mr. Pengel, who was 54 years old, had been Premier from 1963 to 1969.

JACKSON, Miss., June 5 (AP)--Gov. John Bell Williams says that a state investigation showed the police acted in selfdefense in killing two young Negroes in a confrontation with students May 15 at Jackson State College.

The Eastern Regional Championships continue at the New York Hilton today with attention divided between two major events. The Federal Court of Appeals in the District of Columbia is now considering a request for an expedited appeal, if not summary reversal, of a case that concerns the civil rights of many people engaged in lawful dissent. Y., and, as I looked ahead, I concluded there must be an accident. WASHINGTON, June 6--The Defense Department is moving cautiously to reduce the size of the armed services, but Pentagon planners doubt that the force can be cut to 2.5 million men--the pre-Vietnam level-- in the immediate future.

E. Michael Keating of Wayne, Pa., for three years the leading member of the Franklin and Marshall College swimming team, was recently given the outstanding senior athlete award at the college's spring sports dinner.

CORA, Wyo.--It was mid-July, but snow still blocked the horseback approach to New Fork Canyon. As we reached the peak of a mountain well above the timber line, multiple flashes of lightning illuminated the boulders like an El Greco painting. A nearby boulder smoked after a direct hit: The horses began to buck and neigh.

NEWBURY, Mass.--The firemen's muster, one of the oldest organ ized "sports" in the United States, has thrilled spectators across the country for generations, but these days it seems that New England is doing the most to keep this fairgoers' spectacle alive.

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., June 6 (AP) -- Wace, a 5-year-old gelding, came within one-fifth of a second of tying a Finger Lakes track record today in winning the $2,300 feature race.

BERLIN, June 2--Kurt Zirzow, a member of the Burow collective farm in East Germany, told a Communist reporter that he and his colleagues had been unable to plant any summer wheat this year because of the cold and wet spring and that by the end of May only half of their potatoes were in the ground.

Miss Madeleine Anne Dean Lawrence and Elliott Hallock Johnson, a descendant of Peter Hallock, who settled Hallock's Point, L.I., in 1640, were married yesteday afternoon in the Community Church of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Chadbourne A. Spring.

MYTILENE, Lesbos--The venture to Lesbos, call it a minicruise, weaves across the broad sea boulevard of the Piraeus, past the venders of warm cheese pastries and sesame rings, past the magic signs announcing sailings to islands known to Homer and Plato as well as Onassis and past roses planted by a public relations-minded Mayor.
After several lean years that played havoc with profits, producers of fertilizer materials are showing faint smiles.

A FOUR-MAN student team from Brookline, Mass., won first place in the recent 1970 U.S. High School championship at the Hotel McAlpin, New York. Scoring 22 game points during the eight-round event, Brookline topped its nearest rivals, Bayside, queens, N.Y., and Roosevelt, Des Moines, Iowa, by a half-point.

PANGIM, Goa--Most visitors to India meet their first Goan unknowingly--when they sit down in a Bombay restaurant and give their order to the bowing, smiling maitre d'. He is probably from the tiny coastal enclave of Goa, a man trained in European civility by the Portuguese and who has reluctantly emigrated to Bombay because big-city money is available there.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 6 --Dr. Arthur M. Ross, vice president of the University of Michigan and former United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics, was found dead today in a motel in Allen Park near Detroit. His age was 54. MOSCOW--Political dissent in the Soviet Union today is a grim game of cat and mouse. The opposition is usually expressed in writing. There are few public demonstrators.

WE are weekend sailors who deped upon Long Island Sound, with its calms, its gusts and its choppy, oft-polluted waters, for our weekend cruises. The simple motions of wind and water and the euphoric detachment that comes from the act of getting one's feet off solid ground spell adventure of the highest order.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) --The words of Senator Robert F. Kennedy were heard at Arlington National Cemetery tonight. They were read by his sons and sung by a youthful chorus to joyful folk rhythms in a mass commemorating the second anniversary of his assassination.

LIMA--The Callejon de Huaylas is a steep north-south valley known as the Switzerland of Peru. Its inhabitants live on agriculture and tourism and boast such lovely Spanish-colonial centers as Yungay, Ranrahirca-- rebuilt and expanded following an earthquake there eight years ago--and other towns. There are also innumerable Indian settlements in the surrounding highlands and valleys.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 6 --Miss Ellen Foster Huntington was married here this afternoon to Robert Laurie Bryant. The Rev. Dr. Donald M. Meisel performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church. George Wallace's primary election once more raises sharply the question of that fabulously outmoded device of American politics, the Electoral College. Logically, a single party's choice for the governorship of Alabama should not be a matter of great national concern; but it is just that in the case of Mr. Wallace's victory, narrow as it was. For he is now in an ideal position to turn the Electoral College to his purposes.

A medical study of the first five manned Apollo flights has found that the 15 astronauts involved "generally adapted well to the weightless environment" during their 3,105 hours in space, but that all these men lost weight and some had minor medical problems.

MOSCOW--Genetics is the most politicized Soviet science because it impinges on the Communist system's most perplexing unsolved question-- adequate agricultural production. Any geneticist who manages to persuade the leadership he knows some sure-fire method of getting bigger and better crops inevitably acquires sponsorship at the top.

Mark Levine, an 18-yearold Brooklyn College freshman majoring in political science, won the Amateur Athletic Union national onewall handball championship yesterday by upsetting Steve Sandler of the 92d Street Y.M.H.A., 21-5, 21-11, at the Municipal Courts in Coney Island. Sandier, top-seeded and the defending champion, had also won the title in 1966 and 1967.

HONG KONG, June 6--Communist China's economic development appears to be moving ahead steadily if unevenly under a policy that aims at the best possible output from big defense-related industries but puts primary emphasis on agriculture and small rural manufactures.

Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court signed an order yesterday preventing a New York soldier from being shipped out of the country until further action by the United States Solicitor General could be taken in the case.

NEXT Sunday, Dr. Cynthia Westcott, noted plant patholgist, rose authority and author, will hold her 30th annual Rose Day at Springvale, Crotonon-Hudson, N.Y. The public is invited from 2 to 6 P.M. Honor guests will be Frank Benardella, trustee of the American Rose Society, and rose hybridist, Jack Lissemore. Members of the Westchester Rose Society and the Springvale Garden Club will serve punch and cookies.

MOSCOW, June 6 (AP)--The Soviet Olympic Committee, smarting from rejection of Moscow's bid to stage the 1976 Olympics, indicated today it would press for reform of the International Olympic Committee.

BRUSSELS, June 6--The Belgian Government has decided to develop the three national ports--Antwerp, Ghent and Zeebrugge--for handling ships of up to 125,000 tons.

JERUSALEM--Israel's "sixday war" with the Arab states on her borders is three years old now and there is no end in sight. More blood is being spilled, especially on the Suez Canal. Yet the Israelis feel reasonably secure, more so than they did before the great outburst of violence in 1967.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 6--Miss Lisa-Margaret Stevenson and Airman Alexander Campbell Sanger, U.S.A.F., a grandson of the late Mrs. Margaxet Sanger, the birth control pioneer, have become engaged.

NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, June 2--As the United States landing craft Showboat 89 unloaded food, ammunition and other supplies at this Mekong river town in Cambodia today, shopkeepers and free agents on a once sleepy street just above the landing area were doing a brisk business in items from the Showboat's earlier deliveries.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 6 --David Curtis of Marblehead, Mass., at the helm of Black Widow, won the opening race of the Pequot Yacht Club invitation Soling Class regatta on Long Island Sound today in light and tantalizing breezes.

KARACHI, Pakistan, June 6 --One hundred ninety-one Government officials, among them the civil servant most closely identified with the authoritarian regime of former President Mohammad Ayub Khan, have been dismissed following trials by special military courts. Sixty-nine others have been retired.

MANILA, June 6--President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he was in favor of an allAsian meeting on Cambodia, which the 12 Asian nations that met last month in Jakarta had proposed to Secretary General Thant of the United Nations.

MINNEAPOLIS. THE Walker Art Center's new exhi bition, "Figures/Environments," combines works by eight Americans classifiable to one degree or another as sculptors. SAIGON--The war in South Vietnam has always been a series of regional and local affairs, but it has become even more fractionalized since the allies entered Cambodia. Last week it looked more like a dozen wars than a single struggle.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 6-- Although his manslaughter conviction was overturned by the courts more than a week ago, Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, remains in prison.

WASHINGTON, June 7 It is said here of the Cabinet job that President Nixon has now transfered from Robert H. Finch to Elliott L. Richardson that whoever holds it for any length of time is bound to grow in education and to diminish in both health and welfare.

LONDON, June 7 The image-builders for the Labor and Conservative parties in the election campaign are at work in neighboring buildings on Smith Square, a treelined area not far from Westminster Abbey but a long way from Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The Re. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, General Secretary of the World Council of Churches and a Protestant leader in the ecumenical movement, was awarded an honorary doctorate of humane letters today by Catholic University of America.

MILTON, Wis., June 7 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, a frequent critic of President Nixon's war and economic policies, today called Mr. Nixon "a decent and intelligent man" and denounced personal attacks against him.
Miss Ronnie Sue Deutsch and Dr. Lloyd Richard Dropkin were married here last evening at the St. RegisSheraton Roof. Rabbi Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony.

Little deGarmo, McCaffery, Inc., billing some $9.5-million, has gotten a big shot in the arm from the Best Foods division of CPC International. The product assignment, effective July 1, is Mazola Margarine, which was backed by over $3-million in advertising in 1969.

The reform of abortion laws has thus far made barely a dent in the criminal abortion rate and has failed to produce anything resembling a revolution in medical practice or attitude in any of the five states that have had two or more years of experience with eased restrictions on legal abortions.

Representative Richard Max McCarthy, one of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator, criticized two of his opponents yesterday, charging one with excess sive campaign spending and another with gimmickry.
WESTERVILLE, Ohio, June 7 The 30-member board of trustees of Otterbein College has approved a proposal to let three students and three faculty members join the board with full voting power.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, June 8 Fighting continued today around the provincial capital of Siemreap in Cambodia. Informants said that if the city should fall, the North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops would have a major psychological victory because Siemreap is just six miles south of the historic ruins of Angkor Wat.

WASHINGTON, June 7 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States would announce "fairly soon" its decision on the sale of jet warplanes to Israel, but he strongly hinted that it would be only partly favorable.

HOUSTON, June 7 (UPI) Deron Johnson hit a three-run homer and Byron Browne drove in three runs with a homer and a triple today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 10-3 victory over the Houston Astros.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 7 Ceylon's new united front Government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike wants Communist China and Poland to release Ceylon from commitments to trade 27,000 tons of sheet rubber so that it can be sold on the open market for badly needed sterling and dollars.
WASHINGTON, June 7 One of the Government's most unusual programs a program designed to defer repayment of debts due to a Government lending agency is having a greater-than-expected success.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 7 (UPI) Jack Heidemann's double drove in two runs in the top of the eighth inning and helped 21-year-old Rich Hand gain his first major league pitching victory as the Cleveland Indians beat the California Angels; 6-4, today.
YONKERS, June 7 Max S. Wilkes, artist and teacher, died today at his home, 189 Valentine Lane. His age was 85.
According to John Jacobs, the trainer of High Echelon, the colt went into the Belmont Stakes just in time.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 7 Zim's Mr. Spoons, a 5-yearold brown gelding with an unusual name but a smart step, captured the green working hunter championship today at the Greenwich Horse Show.
The people who planned the nation's toll-roads agree that their original designs underestimated the demand that has grown for the highways.

Now we'll find out just how drunk she was when she dove into the fountain at Washington Square, and if she really did ex claim, while traveling by train through Europe, "Good God, Scott!

NEW HAVEN, June 7 In his baccalaureate address to 1,000 members of the last allmale graduating class of Yale undergraduate colleges, Yale's president, Kingman Brewster Jr., today decried such political characterization as "liberal" and "moderate."
PARIS, June 7 Mrs. Margaret Court is halfway home.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 7 John Burke Shethar, a leading yachtsman for many years and a member of the New York Stock Exchange since March 9, 1916, died today in United Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived at Milton Point, Rye, and at Hillsboro Beach, Fla.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 7 During the week some spectators asked Dick Lotz for an autograph, thinking he was Gary Player. "I didn't mind," Lotz said today after he had won the Kemper open golf tournament by two strokes with a 72-hole total of 278, holing a 55-foot putt en route.

There are few sopranos in the world could or would choose the title role of Puccini',s "Turandot" for a Metropolitan Opera debut, but Elinor Ross made her first appearance with the company on Saturday night in the spectacular part (with its triply spectacular costume) and managed the feat pretty well.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 7 (AP) Frank Fernandez's leadoff homer in the ninth inning tied the score and then Joe Rudi, a pinch-hitter, belted a three-run homer to lift the Oakland Athletics to a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
LIMA, Peru, June 7 Thousands of Indians are pouring out of their Andean settlements this weekend and moving toward valley and coastal communities.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 7 The 116th annual New York Yacht Club Regatta fell considerably short of a complete success as only 17 of the 58 handicap boats that started today managed to finish. Yesterday, none of the boats managed to finish within their allotted time.

The German-Hungarians and the New York Greek-Americans, division winners, battled to a 2-2 tie yesterday in the opener of the German-American Soccer League playoffs at Metropolitan Oval in Maspeth, Queens before about 500 fans.
WHEELUS AIR FORCE BASE, Libya, May 31 A ceremonial contingent of 52 military men is all that remains in operation at the last United States Air Force base on the African continent.
WASHINGTON, June 7 The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:
Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that "inefficient, ramshackle state government" was the single greatest factor contributing to the rapidly rising cost of living in New York State this year.
HOUSTON, June 6 On the white side of the tracks, Houston is a boom town, with new office buildings going up to complement others recently built to give the downtown area a very spic and span gleam.

Following is a weekly listing of the net asset value of closed-end investment fund shares as reported by the companies through the Association of Closed-End Investment Companies at the close of business Friday.
The police continued their investigation yesterday into the firebombing at the Woolworth store at Broadway and 44th Street on Saturday night.

FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, June 7 (AP) Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico stayed just ahead of the favored Chris Amon of New Zealand for the last 23 laps today and won the Belgian Grand Prix by one second in a BRM.

ST. LOUIS, June 7 (UPI) Vic Davalillo, pinch-hitter, delivered a record-tying two hits during a four-run seventh inning today and sparked the St. Louis Cardinals to a 10-7 victory over the San Diego Padres.
GENEVA, June 7 A constitutional amendment that would have expelled 300,000 foreign workers from Switzerand was defeated today in a nationwide referendum.
LOS ANGELES, June 7 "Too many elbows, too big a field," said Marty Liquori after he was beaten in last night's Compton invitation mile race at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.
RABBIT LAKE, Saskatchewan. Beneath the pure, cold water of Rabbit Lake, one of countless puddles on the face of northern Saskatchewan, are buried hundreds of millions of dollars worth of uranium.
LONDON, June 7 A new tower looming over Hyde Park has brought cries of outrage from Londoners and rekindled controversy about high-rise buildings in this city of intimate vistas.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 7 (Canadian Press) Canada clinched the first-round series of the North American Zone Davis Cup tennis competition against the Commonwealth Caribbean today by taking the doubles for a 3-0 lead.

BETHLEHEM, Pa. Recruiters from 100 companies last week heard a plea from a prominent educator to help reduce "the litany of macroproblems" which disturbs college students and causes them to shun business careers.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 7 (AP) Young people attacked a bank for the fourth night in a row tonight, breaking windows and knocking out street lights with stones. They tried to set the building on fire before they were dispersed by the police.
CINCINNATI, June 7 Given their choice, the Mets undoubtedly would have preferred the locusts, even swarms of them, to the Reds in Cincinnati this weekend.
The Overseas Shipholding Group has ordered two new vessels and acquired a third at a cost of about $35-million. The company was formed in January.

MOSCOW, June 7 Three musicians from the United States were among 16 cellists who survived the first elimination round in the fourth Tchaikovsky Music Competition that began last week and will continue until June 25.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 7 (AP) Dr. Paul L. Kirk, who founded the criminalistics department at the University of California in Berkeley and who was a defense witness in the Sheppard murder trial, died Friday. He was 68 years old.

MILWAUKEE, June 7 (UPI) Steve Hovley, Milwaukee Brewers' outfielder, is out of uniform and on the trading block because he refused to pay a fine for being late for a game, Marvin Milkes general manager, disclosed today.
ATLANTA, June 7 (AP) Bob Bailey rapped two home runs and Coco Laboy one today as the Montreal Expos completed a sweep of a three-game series over the Atlanta Braves, 10-1.
LOWELL, Mass., June 7 Elliot L. Richardson said today that his selection by President Nixon as the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare had been a complete surprise.

Why, do you suppose, have its admirers thought it necessary and useful to label "Tommy," an extended ballad in concert form, as a "rock opera"? The hour-long piece, which the rock group called The Who brought to the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday, could hardly qualify as opera under any except the most propagandistic definition.

PANAMA, June 7 (AP) Ismael Laguna of Panama mounted a methodical, relentless attack against Ishimatsu Suzuki and pounded out a technical knockout victory over the Japanese challenger in the 13th round to maintain his world lightweight title last night.
A permanent antiques show has been installed in New York, and, for the moment at least, it seems to be defying the slump that has hit most luxury businesses.

Unemployment is in its steepest rise since the recession of 1960. Last month the unemployment rate reached 5 per cent of the labor force up from 3.5 per cent in December. There are now 1.3 million more people out of work than five months ago.
The police used a helicopter yesterday afternoon to lift a 63-year-old woman from the rocky Hudson River shore off 250th Street after she had been injured while abandoning a foundering cabin cruiser.

PARIS, June 7 Sassafras, a colt owned by Arpad Plesch, won the $359,000 Prix du Jockey Club at Chantilly today. The race is conducted by two of the most exclusive clubs in the world the Academie Francaise and the French Jockey Club.
Someone ran a Long Island Railroad train through a brick wall last night at the Flatbush yard in Brooklyn and the police are searching for a youth who may have been responsible.

Teams headed by Edgar Kaplan of New York and Hal Fein of Eastchester, N.Y., survivors of a field of 98 teams, battled yesterday at the New York Hilton in the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship. After 48 deals of a scheduled 64, Kaplan led by 8 international match points.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) Billy Williams's tie-breaking single in the seventh inning, followed by Jim Hickman's homer, paced the Chicago Cubs today to an 8-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants. Eight home runs were hit in the game.

LONDON, June 7 (UPI) Two paintings valued at $372,000 were stolen yesterday from a house in Regent's Park. They are Gauguin's "Still Life of Apples and Grapes," whose price was put at $288,000, and Bonnard's "Les Deux Sauteuils," $84,000.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) Dr. John A. Hannah, director of the Agency for International Development, acknowledged today that the United States aid program was being used as a cover for operations of the Central Intelligence Agency in Laos.

POUND RIDGE, N.Y., June 7 Miss Joanne Gale Glickman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Glickman of New York and Pound Ridge, was married here this afternoon to Elliott Hilton Singer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Singer of Atlanta. Rabbi Alex J. Goldman performed the ceremony in the garden of her parents' home here.

WASHINGTON, June 7 The American Booksellers Association's annual convention, described by its organizers as the largest since the group was formed 70 years ago, opened today with emphasis on stimulation of business through wider advertising and more books on current events.

LOUDONVILLE, N.Y., June 7 Miss Deborah Mary, Robb and Angus Holbrook Twombly were married here this evening at the home of Mrs. Gene Robb, mother of the bride. The Rev. John H. McCombe, dean of the Hendricks Chapel at Syracuse University, performed the ceremony.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, June 7 A factory team of butterscotchbrown Ford Mustangs recorded its fourth consecutive victory today in the Trans-American championship, taking first and second places in a 180-mile race over the Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course.
Beware the baby walrus. Its affection can be overwhelming.

Edward Morgan Forster, regarded as one of the great men of English letters, wrote his last and most popular novel more than 40 years ago, but unlike others who retire to greatness, he had been heard from since.

Yiddish and the legendary Russian-Polish village of Chelm, recalled by such folklorists as Sholem Aleichmen, live. This was illustrated yesterday by the Yugntruf Ensemble, a group of Jewish high school and college students, who presented an original Yiddish musical, "Chelm Under Shtetl"("Chelm Our Village") before a packed house at the 92d Street Young Men's Hebrew Association.

WESTON, Mass., June 7 Miss Mary Devereux Goodwin, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Willard E. Goodwin of Los Angeles, was married here today to Edmund Billings Cabot, youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Dudley Cabot of Weston.

GUADALAJARA, Mexico, June 7 In a superb match that did credit to the competition, Brazil beat England, 1-0, at Jalisco Stadium today and thus became the first soccer team to win against her in the World Cup since 1962.
HINDMAN, Ky., June 7 In a decision that could have farreaching effects in Kentucky, Knott County's legislative council has voted to outlaw strip mining in the county.

DENVER, June 7 Three Vietnam veterans, active for several months in war protests in the Colorado Springs area, say they have formed an underground G.I. news service to report on "the Army's many illegal activities."

The premiere of the new local weekly series, "Positively Black," was offered yesterday afternoon on WNBC-TV (Channel 4). Its appeal and potential strength lie in the low-key presentation of the problems of blacks. The program stressed the affirmative whenever possible but let facts rather than emotionalism underscore racial abuses.

CAIRO, June 7 (UPI) France, which is maintaining a temporary embargo against arms shipments to Israel, will begin delivery of surface-to-air rockets next year to several Arab nations, the semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram said today.

The bond markets rallied last week for the first time since early spring, and then its recovery faltered. With a larger supply of new issues for sale this week, there is relatively, little hope that the advance in prices can be made to continue.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) President and Mrs. Nixon flew back to the White House from Camp David, Md., today after a weekend marked by a gathering of the Nixon and Eisenhower families to observe three graduations.

MacManus, John Adams, New York, will become the eighth name on the ColgatePalmolive Company agency list on Sept. 1 when it takes over the advertising assignments for Palmolive Soap, Palmolive Gold Deodorant Soap and Lustre-Creme Shampoo. The brands billed almost $5-million last year.

NEW CITY, N.Y., June 8--A suit by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz to halt construction of an aluminum-canmanufacturing plant in nearby Congers was put over today until June 16 in Rockland County Supreme Court.
CAIRO, June 8--The United Arab Republic has budgeted $1.2 billion for military spending and related war expenses in the fiscal year starting July 1, it was announced here today.

The Reisinger knockout team championship, a highly prized honor for four decades, was decided in the small hours of yesterday morning with a victory for Edgar Kaplan, Jeff Rubens and Leonard Harmon, all of New York, Norman Kay of Philadelphia, Monroe Ingberman of New Paltz, N.Y., and Alfred Sheinwold of Los Angeles.

New York's newest motion picture theater, the Paramount, will open on June 24 with the world premiere of "Catch--22," the World War II satire. The movie of Joseph Heller's popular novel was directed by Mike Nichols for Paramount Pictures. The film will run simultaneously at the Sutton Theater, Third Avenue and 57th Street.

A generation gap of sorts was bridged on Wall Street yesterday as Milton A. Gordon, a 61-year-old financier, and John Westergaard, a 38year-old investment research specialist, announced they had agreed to join forces.
Former Bronx Borough president Herman Badillo scored members of the Young Lords yesterday for throwing eggs and tomatoes at Puerto Rico's Gov. Luis Ferre in Sunday's Puerto Rican Day parade here.
WASHINGTON, June 8-- Earth satellites will be needed to help man husband the world's resources, keep peace with the environment and perhaps even prevent starvation, a Government report suggests.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The House of Representatives voted today to send a fact-finding mission of its own to study "all aspects of United States military involvement in Southeast Asia."

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, confronted by a new round of legal actions by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said yesterday that it was acting on the advice of its Connecticut lawyers and going ahead with its plans to merge with the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Top Defense Department officials have warned military budget planners that foreseeable pay increases over the next two years may require cuts of $6-billion or more in existing forces and programs to keep the next defense budget at or below the $71.8-billion budget request currently before Congress.

The National Fund for Medical Education has reported that American medical schools are in serious financial difficulties and that in some schools the situation is "so critical that one must be concerned about their maintenance of quality and even about their ability to survive."

WASHINGTON, June, 8--William Woestendiek, the television news editor here who was dismissed last April when his wife took a job as press secretary to the wife of Attorney General John N. Mitchell, will be named editor of The Colorado Springs Sun tomorrow.

GREAT NECK, L.I., June 8-- Dick Stockton of Garden City, L.I., seeded second, defeated Sandy Mayer of Woodmere, L.I., 6-1, 6-3, today to gain the final round of the Long Island men's tennis championship at the Great Neck Country Club.
Glancing over performance records of the mutual funds for the last 12 months, it is possible to find a number that have slid more than 50 per cent in value.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., June 8-- Seven Green Beret soldiers were killed and five wounded this morning when 20 pounds of T.N.T. exploded prematurely at their feet during a class in demolition at the John F. Kennedy Center for Military Assistance.

Seasonal highs in the July, August and September futures contracts for soybeans were attained yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Grains futures prices were irregular, however, with December wheat registering seasonal lows as local traders and commission houses sold rather heavily.
Representative Leonard Farbstein failed yesterday to prevent Barry Farber from running in November on the Liberal party line for Congress in the 19th Congressional District.

BUENOS AIRES, June 8-- The Commanders in Chief of Argentina's Army, Navy and Air Force announced today that Lieut. Gen. Juan Carlos Ongania had been deposed as President and that they were taking over the Government.
The liberation is on in women's track and field, and the 80th annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union championships is the latest example of equal opportunity.

The Federal Court of Appeals here ruled unconstitutional yesterday a section of a Federal statute that prohibits the importation of obscene materials for private use. The three-judge panel unanimously called it an infringement of rights under the First Amendment.
Dr. Benjamin Eliasoph, a physician at Mount Sinai Hospital who was a pioneer in the design of the oxygen tent, died Sunday at the hospital. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) --While sending out a followup letter of clarification, officials acknowledged today, that a letter had gone out to about 30 college deans saying that any candidate they suggested for a top Federal health job ought to be a Republican.

IOWA CITY, June 8 (AP)-- The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Big Ten Conference are conducting an investigation of the athletic department at the University of Iowa concerning the recruitment and financial assistance of athletes, Sam Fahr, chairman of the Board in Control of Athletics, revealed today.

The Hammermill Paper Company announced yesterday it planned to increase prices for its uncoated fine and printinggrade papers by $20 a ton, effective July 6. The papers are used in business communications.
BUENOS AIRES--The rule of the strongman in Latin America, once thought to be on the decline, seems more pervasive than ever.

Jazz and poetry are apt to step on each others toes when they are put on the same platform together, but a poet with the instincts of a jazz soloist showed Sunday night at Carnegie Hall that the two can swing together.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) --The Air Force said today that North American Rockwell Corporation, Los Angeles, had been the lowest bidder and had the highest rated proposal in winning a contract to develop an advanced bomber.

STOCKHOLM, June 8--The majority of the policemen who reported "sick" over the weekend returned to duty today and officials were hopeful that the looting and violence that occurred in their absence had come to an end.

JACKSON, Miss., June 8-- Mayor Russell Davis said today investigations had shown that the Jackson city police "did not fire a shot" when gunfire into a Jackson State College dormitory last month left two students dead.
CRAZY HORSE, S. Dak.-- Everything is big in the world of Korczak Ziolkowski, even the effort required to pronounce his Polish name (it is CORE--chok jule-KUFFski).

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 8--Art Al Fresco, the annual art exhibition and sale for the benefit of the Arthritis Foundation, will be held in Thomas Park here on Saturday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. In case of rain the show will be postponed until Sunday.

MILWAUKEE, June 8 (UPI)-- The Milwaukee Brewers, sparked by a leadoff homer by Tommy Harper, took an early 5-0 lead tonight and coasted to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox as Lew Krausse hurled a six-hitter.

WASHINGTON, June 8 --President Nixon was told today that nonpolitical sons and daughters of the middle class were becoming increasingly suspicious of the Administration's policies and were rapidly being pushed into the radical camp by some of the Administration's rhetoric.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP)--A Federal grant of $344,000 to develop phosphate-free laundry detergents has been awarded to the Gillette Company's Research Institute in Rockville, Md., the company announced today.
The contest for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in this state is turning into a strangely onesided affair insofar as any serious discussion of state issues is concerned.

Kenneth Kolker, senior vice president of merchandising for Abraham Straus, announced yesterday his retirement from full-time business activity after 22 years with the Brooklynbased department store chain. Mr. Kolker is 49 years old.
BATAVIA, N.Y., June 8 (AP)--One of six men arrested last Tuesday during a meeting between reputed Mafia figures and two contractors won dismissal of the charge against him today.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- A special study committee reported today that the problem of financing Senate and House campaigns had reached crisis proportions but recommended that no spending ceilings be established.

Associates of Joseph Colombo, a reputed boss of organized crime, said yesterday that he was the man behind the picket lines that have been set up nightly around Federal Bureau of Investigation headquarters here for the last month.

The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, since 1870 an independent and family-managed company, is observing its 100th anniversary with record earnings and sales for the fiscal year ended April 30, William F. Lucas, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) --President Nixon announced today a $10-million grant to Peru and plans for massive assistance to the country, which was struck by a major earthquake last week.

The New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture will benefit from a sale of paintings at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 4 East 77th Street, Thursday through June 27. Artists represented include Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Larry Rivers, Andy Warhol and Alexander Calder.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 8--A paralyzed witness, unable to move his arms or legs, was wheeled into an improvised courtroom at the Veterans Administration Hospital here today for a preliminary examination by Federal Judge George H. Barlow in the trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and seven other defendants charged with extortion.

BRISTOL, England, June 8 (Reuters)--Unseeded Jim McManus of Berkeley, Calif., gained the second round of the Wills open tennis tournament today by eliminating Ismael El Shafei of the United Arab Republic, 8-6, 1-6, 6-4.

The financial bonanza of 65,880 fans at the Yankees' Bat Day promotional extravaganza on Sunday helped take some of the bitterness out of the 12inning 4-3 defeat at the hands of the Chicago White Sox.

Charles Dickens died a century ago today--and that is greater news than the forgotten anniversaries of monarchs and generals in the world that still celebrates the kingdom of letters. Rather than by memorial services in Westminster Abbey or by Pickwickian literary toasts here, he is still receiving the only recognition dreamed of by serious writers: to have their books and ideas live.
As the World Cup soccer tournament moves toward the quarterfinals, the outcome of each game becomes more important and the game of "let's suppose" more popular.
MONTREAL, June 8--Ezzak Ruvenoff, a dance master and former star of the Imperial Russian Ballet, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 96 years old.

PAZUENGOS, Spain--The heads of the 49 families that still live in this isolated northern village--about six miles beyond maintained roads--have unanimously decided to put a "Town for Sale" sign on the homes and lands where their ancestors have lived since the 15th century. The asking price is about $335,000.

MAIDRID, June 8 (Reuters) --The South African Prime Minister, John Vorster, drove into Spain today on a threeday private visit that has puzzled diplomats. He is expected to call on Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

NEW HAVEN, June 8-- Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey, ruling on a defense claim that "massive adverse publicity" makes the selection of an impartial jury impossible, today denied for the time being a motion to postpone the trial of a Black Panther charged with murder and kidnapping.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)--Millions of American families with working mothers away from home all day had better change their way of living for the sake of their children, and for the national good, Dr. Margaret Mead advises.

A list of 44 artists whose prints have been chosen for exhibition in the United States Pavilion at the Venice Biennale was released for the first time yesterday by officials of the Smithsonian Institution's International Art Program, which sponsors participation in art programs abroad.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 8--Miss Marion Everett Watts and Allen George Swan plan to be married here July 18.
