ROME, Tuesday, June 9--The Christian Democratic party of Premier Mariano Rumor suffered a setback in Italy's nationwide elections of Sunday and yesterday, and the Communist party--strongest in the West--held its own.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Supreme Court has decided to rule on the constitutionality of referendum laws that permit a majority of the voters in a community to block the construction of low-cost housing for the poor.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8--American commanders have nearly doubled their estimate of enemy strength in Cambodia and in the sector of South Vietnam immediately north of Saigon. The re-evaluation follows the reported discovery of traces of some previously unknown and unexpectedly intricate Communist organization.
The first regular-season meeting of the New York Giants and New York Jets, scheduled for Nov. 1 at Shea Stadium, will be televised in the metropolitan area, the clubs announced jointly yesterday.
BONN, June 8--A Czechoslovak airliner on a short domestic flight was hijacked today by four young men and four young women and forced to land at Nuremberg, about 70 miles inside West Germany.
If major national magazines want to concentrate their circulation in the metropolitan markets, that's just fine with Grit, the smalltown weekly. Rural America has been its bag for 87 years.
Three local Democratic Representatives yesterday broke with political custom to endorse a primary opponent of an incumbent Democratic member of New York's House delegation.

TAYNINH, South Vietnam, June 8--United States military commanders and intelligence analysts estimate that allied forces have found only 30 per cent to 40 per cent of the enemy arms and supply stockpiles in Cambodian sanctuaries.

Everything's up to date in Kansas City, now that the Chiefs are the defending champions of the entire football world. But after the coming season their leading rusher and receiver, Mike Garrett, will be singing another tune: Going Home.
The price of certified birth and death certificates will increase by 50 cents to $2.50 Thursday, the city Health Department announced yesterday.
Col. Jane E. Wrieden, national consultant for the women's and children's services of the Salvation Army, died Sunday at her home, 3 Washington Square Village. She was 64 years old.

JERSEY CITY, June 8 (AP)-- The Hudson County grand jury indicted Freeholder Chester J. Wojtycha of Jersey City today on charges of conspiring to violate the laws in connection with the award by the Hudson County Board of Freeholders of a $57,233 contract to a surgical supply firm he headed.
HONG KONG, June 8-- Communist China denounced the United States today for what it called aggressive acts against the North Koreans.

Proponents of a methadone program for narcotics addicts in city jails filed a State Supreme Court petition yesterday in an effort to force the Lindsay administration to explain why it has not implemented such a program as provided for in legislation that the City Council passed last September over the Mayor's veto.
The Securities and Exchange Commission, contrary to the expectations of many in the mutual fund industry, has gone on record as opposing reform legislation now before the House Commerce Committee.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 8-- The Nassau County Grand Jury exonerated Ron Stewart today of any responsibility in what District Attorney William Cahn called the "tragic, senseless, bizarre" death of Terry Sawchuk.

The Board of Education has promised to "strongly recommend" that the Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration district in Brooklyn and the Intermediate School 201 complex in East Harlem be maintained as special units when they are absorbed on July 1 by new community school districts.

Paul O'Dwyer won a 30,000member union's official endorsement for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator last night, despite a fervent appeal for support by Theodore C. Sorensen, one of his three rivals in the June 23 primary.
FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 8 (UPI)--The Army is reported planning to drop all charges tomorrow against one of four officers charged in the alleged Mylai massacre.
HARWICH PORT, Mass., June 8 (AP)--Lieut. Gen. Keller E. Rockey, who commanded the Fifth Marine Division at the battle of Iow Jima, died Saturday at the age of 81.
ANCHORAGE, June 8 (AP)-- American aviation's first commercial flight to Siberia got caught in red tape, and as a result was delayed for four and a half hours.
Ken Venturi, the 1964 United States Open golf champion, failed to qualify yesterday for this year's tournament, but a University of Texas sophomore made the field.
The stock market posted a mild advance yesterday as volume of only 8.04 million shares, the lowest in a month, reflected the caution that still prevails in the investment community.

EL SEGUNDO, Calif., June 8 (AP)--Xerox Data Systems has canceled plans to build a $35million headquarters complex and has laid off 350 of its 5,500 employes, blaming the nation's economic slowdown for poor computor sales.
WASHINGTON, June 8--Dr. Wayne C. Grover, archivist of the United States from 1948 to 1965, died today of cancer at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 64 years old.
ITHACA, N.Y., June 8-- Dale R. Corson was installed today as president of Cornell University in a combined investiture and commencement ceremony before almost 10,000 people.

A new Minute Maid coffee system, designed to help solve the cost, labor and consistency problems of coffee making by restaurateurs and institutional food service managers, was announced yesterday by the CocaCola Company.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- John W. Gardner, sounding much like a political candidate, offered today a seven-point program of national conciliation to rebuild "a cohesive society despite the tensions of daily life."
Steel production last week edged down 0.4 per cent, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The National Broadcasting Company quoted a Cambodian Army spokesman yesterday as having said that a television correspondent and four cameramen had been taken to a "safe mountain hide-out" by the Vietcong.

Any day now the Loreleis of the insect world--the periodical cicadas -- are expected to emerge from their underground burrows in the New York area and drum their compelling love song to herald yet another cycle of their amazing and mysterious 17-year life span.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The Supreme Court limited today the authority of Federal judges to interfere when state judges order railroad employes to stop picketing in labor disputes.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 8 (Reuters)--Col. Muammar elQaddafi, chairman of the Libyan Revolutionary Command Council, placed a wreath on the tomb of Lebanon's unknown soldier today, then left with senior army officers for a tour of Lebanese military posts.
Mike Quarry, the undefeated younger brother of Jerry Quarry, will meet Ray Ayala of Puerto Rico in a 10-round lightheavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden on June 17.

CHICAGO, June 8--As a "humanometer" on the mezzanine of the Pick-Congress Hotel clicked off the world's current population increase at the rate of more than two a second, representatives of hundreds of academic, scientific and welfare organizations met today for the most intensive scrutiny to date of the problem of the global "population bomb."

AMMAN, Jordan, June 8 (Reuters)--Palestinian commandos kidnapped an American diplomat, Morris Draper, as he drove to a dinner party here last night and released him today, a United States Embassy spokesman announced.
MONTREAL, June 8 (UPI)-- National Hockey League players will have to use sticks with a shallower curve, the league's rules committee decided today.

Representative Shirley Chisholm joined members of a women's liberation organization yesterday in announcing a drive to raise $100,000 bail money for Joan Bird, one of the Black Panthers on trial on charges of attempted murder and conspiracy to bomb public places.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 8--Signs of affluence are easy to find in this commuter town.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The Administration probably will not oppose Congressional efforts to impose quotas on foreign imports of textiles, informed Government and industry sources disclosed today.

Arthur J. Goldberg carried his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor yesterday to the financial center of the country at Broad and Wall Streets to denounce Governor Rockefeller for his support of Nixon Administration war and fiscal policy.

JUNEAU, June 8--The Alaska Legislature in its last day yesterday authorized the state to construct a $120-million road from the Yukon River to the North Slope to avert a critical employment situation in the Fairbanks area and hasten construction of the proposed North Slope oil pipeline.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Council of the Organization of American States voted unanimously today to transfer from Santo Domingo to Washington the site of the forthcoming conference of hemisphere foreign ministers.

MOSCOW, June 8 (Reuters) An earthquake shook Kirghizia close to the Soviet border with Sinkiang in western China, destroying 5,000 houses and leaving 20,000 people homeless, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

Large figures of a different sort were the main topic at Belmont Park yesterday. On Saturday, of course, major interest centered on the $158,750 gross purse of the Belmont Stakes, and the $115,000 that went to the winner, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's High Echelon. The Monday crowd of 27,726 had a daily double payoff of $1,043.20 to think and talk about.
LUXEMBOURG, June 8-- France told its five partners in the European Economic Community today that a European free trade area could not exist together with the community.

LONDON, June 8--Twentyfour international oil-exploration groups, drawn by the Phillips Petroleum Company's oil strike in Norwegain waters of the North Sea, were awarded 30 licenses today to explore for gas and oil in 8,000 square miles of Britain's Continental Shelf.

About 300 delegates to a conference here on the ills of works of art and their possible cures, meeting here yesterday, heard a German scholar describe exhaust fumes as the chief reason for the decay of Donatello's marble St. Mark in Florence, Italy.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 8 (AP)--The 73 United States Senators who recently signed a letter urging President Nixon to sell more warplanes to Israel will he blacklisted in the Arab world, according to the Commissioner General of the Arab League's boycott of Israel office.

Interest rates, after declining slightly last week, are climbing once again. The renewal of the downward trend in bond prices resulted from the increasingly large supply of new issues scheduled for sale over the next several weeks. Since bonds offered last week failed to attract investors, yields were raised.
WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

"A Scout is brave. He has courage to face danger and to stand up for the right against the coaxings of friends or the jeers or threats of enemies, and defeat does not down him." The Boy Scout handbook.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary appealed yesterday for 2,000 more volunteers to join the auxiliary police force, which currently has a membership of 3,000.

CHICAGO, June 8 (UPI)-- United States marshals and the police tussled today with shouting supporters of Bobby Seale in the lobby of the Federal Building after members of the Chicago Seven had exhorted demonstrators to free the Black Panther national chairman "by any means necessary."

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel has asked the Army to delay work for 15 months on the Cross-Florida Barge Canal to permit a detailed study of the canal's effects on regional ecology.
Health officers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey expressed cautious optimism yesterday about holding the line against further pollution of the area's bathing beaches this summer.

BOSTON, June 8 (AP)-- Louise Day Hicks, controversial Boston City Council member, announced today that she would seek the Congressional seat of the retiring House Speaker, John W. McCormack, Democrat of Massachusetts.

A 9-month-old boy, trapped on the top floor of a building engulfed in flames, was rescued yesterday by a fireman who rushed through a curtain of fire to find the child and apply mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, the Fire Department reported.
The often-stormy pretrial hearings of 13 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places were adjourned yesterday to permit preparation and submittal by both sides of written briefs.

BUFFALO, June 8--Governor Rockefeller came here today to break ground for part of a massive state building program and stayed to search for an agreement in a dispute that has held up the program for two years.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 8--Sporadic fighting continued today at Siemreap, near the historic ruins of Angkor Wat, after Government forces retook the Siemreap airfield, a Cambodian spokesman reported.

OTTAWA, June 8--Canada's labor union leaders today firmly rejected Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's program for price-wage restraint and left the Government in a dilemma over future anti-inflation procedures.
Miss Mary Ann Chambers Swaney, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles Arthur Swaney of Winston-Salem, N.C., and Willard Bunn 3d are planning an August wedding in New York.

"The Moor's Pavane," the Jose Limon modern dance work, has been added to the schedule of the American Ballet Theater, whose engagement at the New York State Theater begins next Tuesday and runs through July 12. The Limon work will have its first performance of the season on Saturday evening, June 27.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- Whatever the deepest motives of those involved, which may be some time in emerging, the Richardson-for-Finch swap at the troubled Department of Health, Education and Welfare looks like an intelligent move by the President and maybe even for the country. This could be canceled out if the new Under Secretary of State is not chosen with care.
MADRID, June 8--Former President Charles de Gaulle of France and Generalissimo Francisco Franco of Spain met today for the first time.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 8 (AP)--The World Boxing Council has voted unanimously to support the California Athletic Commission's suspension of Ismael Laguna, the lightweight champion, the commission's executive officer, Robert Turley, said today.
NEWARK, June 8--Kenneth A. Gibson, a 38-year-old Negro engineer, continued today to pick up bipartisan support for his campaign to be Mayor of Newark.
Shipments of mobile homes, which slumped during the first quarter, rose sharply in April, the Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 8-- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

President Onganla never really regained his political grip on Argentina after the bloody rioting and popular upheaval of May and June, 1969. From then on it was mostly downhill for the shy, taciturn Army general who did not seek the presidency but came to enjoy political power and tried clumsily to build a popular base in order to retain it.

Most of the major difficulties besetting America in 1970--the Indochina war, pollution, rebellion and reaction, racism and the struggle for equality-- have provided ready material for college commencement speakers throughout the nation.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) --Clifford Davis, former Democratic Representative from Tennessee, died after a stroke here today. His age was 72.
HAWTHORNE, N.Y. June 8 (AP)--Bruce Flowers, a prominent lightweight boxer in the 1920's and 1930's, died yesterday at a nursing home here after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

CHICAGO, June 8--A joint committee of the Republicandominated Illinois General Assembly issued a report today contending that Chicago's public school system was near collapse. Democrats promptly termed the report political.
Ray R. Herrmann Jr., has been named executive vice president and general manager of the wine and spirit division of Schieffelin Co. He formerly was with National Distillers and Chemical Corporation.
One of the largest consolidation trends in Wall Street history continued to take shape yesterday with the surprise announcement that Francis I. duPont Co. and Hirsch Co. would merge July 1.
HOUSTON, June 8--The Mets took the advice of a billboard advertisement in this "Astro-everything" town and had fun tonight.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 8--A controversial proposal to spend $175,000 to rehabilitate barracks at Mitchel Field for welfare families now living in motels was defeated by Nassau County Board of Supervisors today after a lengthy, emotional meeting attended by 400 people.
"We believe that the army forces should not govern. They should be obedient to civil power."

WESTBURY, L.I., June 8-- Count Pierre de Montesson of Bouce, Normandy, the owner of Une de Mai, has accepted the invitation to have his French mare compete in the Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on July 18. The acceptance was announced by track officials today.
There are many successful anglers who return unwanted fish to the water unharmed.

An Army psychiatrist obtained an order yesterday from Federal Judge John F.X. McGohey for a hearing today at 10 A.M. at the United States Court House at Foley Square to seek the blocking of his assignment to Vietnam.

The General Cable Corporation announced yesterday that it would market a building wire to consist 70 per cent of aluminum, as an alternative to copper wire. The new product will have an aluminum core bonded to a copper sheath.

BOSTON, June 8--What would our cities look like if artists were allowed to redesign them? This question, which has sometimes led to some highly theoretical (not to say, farfetched) answers, is currently the subject of a very pragmatic exhibition. So pragmatic, indeed, that the exhibition itself, called "Project '70," is installed not at the Institute of Contemporary Art, which organized the show, but in the exhibition galleries of Boston's beautiful new City Hall.

ATLANTA, June 8 (UPI)-- Mike Ivie, 17-year-old catcher, the major leagues' top draft choice, was reported to have signed a contract in the $100,000-plus range with the San Diego Padres of the National League.
FRANKFURT, Germany, June 8 (UPI)--United States oars men added another victory at the Frankfurt international rowing regatta today.
Two major institutions of American Conservative and Reform Judaism held annual commencement ceremonies yesterday, awarding honorary degrees and ordaining 47 seminary graduates as rabbis.
GENEVA, June 8--The future of Investors Overseas Services remained clouded today with the disclosure of more board and management changes by the battered mutual-fund empire.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8 (AP)--Two members of President Nixon's 13-man factfinding team flew to Pnompenh early today for a meeting with Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 (AP)--Cassius Clay, the deposed world heavyweight boxing champion, said today he did not support an appeal filed with the United States Supreme Court to allow him to fight his successor, Joe Frazier, in Canada.

WASHINGTON, June 8--In a private letter to the White House, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has complained that a study of world military expenditures by the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency makes Amerian military outlays look high by underrating the Soviet Union's.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 8-- Intrepid looked Valiant straight in the eye today and trounced the new boat twice as the preliminary America's Cup defense trials got under way on Long Island Sound.

Two midtown Manhattan office skyscrapers with a total of nearly three million square feet of floor space will be built at a cost of $200-million with the financial aid of an American-managed overseas investment fund.
MONTREAL, June 8 (Canadian Press)--The Bank of Montreal announced today it would reduce its prime lending rate to 8 per cent from 8 per cent next Monday.

Financial figures that suggest major league baseball is teetering on the brink of economic disaster were made public yesterday during the Curt Flood antitrust trial in Federal Court here. These startling implications were imbedded in statistics produced by Dr. John Clark Jr.,...

Jack Ogden of Far Rockaway and Steve Carp of Canarsie, selected last Thursday in the major league's draft of free agents, will be the opposing pitchers today in the Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship at Yankee Stadium.
Typographical Union No. 6 and The Long Island Press reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new three-year contract retroactive to last March 31, the day after the last contract expired.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8--Declaring that Harvard University's central function was learning and scholarship, the faculty of arts and sciences refused today to suspend classes for two weeks next fall to free students for election campaign work.

The arrest of two baggage handlers at Kennedy International Airport on charges of stealing $200,000 from an airline mailbag is a reminder that cargo theft ranks second only to hijacking as a hazard to aviation security.
WAPPINGERS FALLS, N.Y., June 8 (UPI)--Barry James Holloway, a former newsman and educator, died tonight in the Wappingers Falls Nursing Home. He was 66 years old.
HONG KONG, June 8 (Reuters)--Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam has reported slow economic progress and called for efforts to meet increasing demands arising from the Indochina war.

Howard J. Samuels, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, won the support yesterday of Assemblyman Charles B. Rangel, who is seeking the nomination for The House of Representatives from Harlem.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Federal Trade Commission, which has been accused in recent years of being lax in protecting consumer interests, announced today a major reorganization of its staff to "increase the consumer's faith in the market place."
BAYONNE, N.J., June 8 --The Mayor of Bayonne has written to the President of the United States, and very respectfully has said: Enough.

Easy-on-the-hostess recipes are especially welcome when the temperature starts to rise. The curried appetizer given here can be made the day before. The casserole can be assembled early the same day and baked just prior to serving.
WASHINGTON, June 8--The Olin Corporation announced today that it would halt production of the pesticide DDT on June 30.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP)--A petition demanding $100-million from the Federal Government was received by the Supreme Court today from Auther G. Barkley of Phoenix, Ariz., the name given by a man who hijacked an airliner here last Thursday.

The first great passenger liner built primarily for cruis ing--once the Cunarder Caronia, now the Caribia of Panamanian registry--swings with the tide running through the Red Hook anchorage off the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) --The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that Weston Co. had agreed to suspend most of its securities operations until it can meet the commission's net capital and cash balance requirements.

Representative Leonard Farbstein of Manhattan, who has turned back formidable reform challengers in each Democratic Congressional primary since 1962, is facing formidable opposition from a woman this year.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., June 8--Mrs. Sven B. Karlen has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kristen Landsborough Karlen, to Jon Arlington Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Joseph of Boston and New London, N.H. The wedding will take place on Aug. 29.

BONN, June 8--Encouraged by signs of support both at home and abroad, the coalition government headed by Chancellor Willy Brandt today stepped up its "Eastern policy" of seeking better relations with Communist Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The Open Market Committee of the Federal Reserve System, while voting to continue the policy of "moderate" increases in the money supply, expressed serious concern at its March 10 meeting about the possibility that monetary policy might zigzag too widely.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Senators Harry F. Byrd and William B. Spong, both Virginia Democrats, said today that they would vote to cancel Government spending on the supersonic transport (SST). Both men had opposed SST appropriations in past years.
Stuart T. Saunders resigned yesterday as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Penn Central Transportation Company, the nation's largest railroad.

In an article with the provocative title quoted above, the Soviet weekly New Times has spelled out Moscow's deep disquiet at Communist China's recent political gains in Southeast Asia. New Times indicts Peking as partly responsible for Sihanouk's fall from power in Cambodia, and obliquely warns Hanoi that it runs the risk of "defeat and destruction" if it follows China's advice.
Most issues on the American Stock Exchange managed to make slight gains yesterday although increased selling pressure in the last two hours of trading erased some of the earlier advances.

VENICE, Italy, June 8--The defense ministers of eight countries of the North Atlantic Alliance met here today to discuss nuclear strategy in the event of conflict with the Soviet Union in Central Europe.
Prices generally sagged on the London stock market yesterday in a continuance of the downtrend that had persisted through most of last week.

Jimmie J. Ryan, president of the Community National Life Insurance Company, of Tulsa, Okla., pleaded guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to conspiring in a scheme that defrauded banks in several parts of the country.

Miss Diana Genevieve Donovan, daughter of Lieut. Gen. Stanley Donovan, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Donovan of Madrid, plans to be married there in July to Jose Ignacio del Campo y Ruiz, a student of economics at the University of Madrid.

TRENTON, June 8--Gov. William T. Cahill won a major victory tonight when the Republican majority in the Senate gave final legislative approval to his controversial measure that merges New Jersey's two public medical schools.

The Prudential Insurance Company, which recently announced plans to go into the automobile and homeowner insurance business, ran into opposition yesterday from the National Association of Insurance Agents.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) --The Supreme Court ruled today that foreign registering of a ship did not exempt the owner from paying damages to seamen injured in United States waters.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 8--One of Europe's most influential banking institutions said today a world recession would be "inescapable if inflation was not brought under control. It also criticized in uncharacteristically blunt terms the newest lines of United States monetary diplomacy. Bleakly assessing, the problems of the dollar, the Bank for International Settlements, for 40 years a central bankers' central bank, also issued a call for an American incomes policy, joining such other international bodies...

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 8--Social Welfare Minister Tran Nguon Phieu said today that the Government, after two weeks of controversy, had reversed its decision to halt the evacuation of ethnic Vietnamese from Cambodia.

GENEVA, June 8--The Swiss Government today tightened restrictions on the admission of temporary foreign workers. According to political sources, this constituted the first move by the Government to conciliate the more than half a million Swiss males who voted yesterday for a constitutional amendment that would have resulted in the expulsion of 300,000 of the 600,000 foreign workers. The amendment was defeated.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 8-- Syria reported a five-hour artillery, tank and air battle along the entire length of her front with Israel today. A Damascus military communique said that as many as 60 Israeli soldiers had been killed or wounded.

Faced by probable postal increases and advertiser resistance to high page rates, McCall's magazine will cut its rate base by a million, to 7.5 million, with the September issue. It is also planning to cut the page size to that of its sister publication, Redbook, but no date has been set for that change.

The New York Stock Exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission simultaneously announced disciplinary actions against Meyerson Co., a brokerage house with headquarters in San Francisco, and two of its top officers.

EDWARDSVILLE, Ill., June 9 (AP)--Bob Guelker, the soccer coach at Southern Illinois University in Edwardsville, was named today to coach the United States Olympic soccer team for the 1972 games in Germany.

BLOWING ROCK, N.C., June 9--Miss J. Madeleine Berry, whose great-greatgrandfather, Stephen A. Douglas, was defeated for the Presidency by Abraham Lincoln, was married here this afternoon to E. Thomas Nash. The Rev. Zack Ralston performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany.
The Curt Flood trial is scheduled to end today with Bill Veeck as the final rebuttal witness for Flood's side in Federal Court here.

WASHINGTON, June 9--The Internal Revenue Service announced today a stopgap policy dealing with the deduetibility of interest that banks pay on loans, the proceeds of which are used to buy tax-exempt securities.
BECKENHAM, England, June 9 (AP)--Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., advanced to the third round of the Kent tennis tournament today and Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego won her first-round match.

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Mayor Lindsay assailed the Nixon Administration's proposed Housing Act of 1970 today, provoking a sharp counterattack from George W. Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
The hottest team in town, the New York Yankees, took on the tough Minnesota Twins without flinching last night and scored a 5-2 victory behind the four-hit pitching of Stan Bahnsen.

Additional winners in the community school board elections held May 28 in Manhattan were announced yesterday by Dr. George H. Hallett Jr., director of the special election unit established by the Board of Elections.
A demand for large-scale training programs to alleviate the critical shortage of nurses and technicians in municipal hospitals has been made to the city' new Health and Hospitals Corporation.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 9-- Once again the race committee called out Valiant's name first in announcing the official times today in the preliminary America's Cup defense trials. This time the committee had the right order.
ISLA VISTA, Calif., June 9 --Attempts by faculty and students to maintain order in this battle-scarred college town have broken down.

Sometime after the start of yesterday's Public Schools Athletic League championship game between Far Rockaway and Canarsie in Yankee Stadium, Jack Ogden, a righthanded ace for the Seahorses, found that his fast ball wasn't working.

WASHINGTON, June 9--Sikorsky Aircraft and Pan American World Airways demonstrated today one way to beat traffic jams in the air and on the ground between Manhattan and Washington--a helicopter, which made the trip in one hour and 17 minutes.
DETROIT, June 9 (AP)-- Citing unsecured claims of about $400,000, Denny McLain, the suspended Detroit Tiger pitcher, filed today for bankruptcy.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9--Saigon's residents do not mourn the loss of the tall leafy trees that once made Saigon a city with charm, for there is too much else that is gone from their lives.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 9--Curtis Person, still just a youngster by senior golf standards, was up to his old tricks of playing like a man of 25 as he shot par today to take the first-round lead in the annual Eastern Senior Golf Association tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) --The Nixon Administration has advised the nation's police authorities that in dealing with protest demonstrations the first objective should be to keep the situation cool enough so firearms will not have to be used.
Herman W. Block, a former textile executive and a prominent figure in child care, died yesterday in his home at 12 East 86th Street. He was 98 years old.
The days when anyone could walk into an office building in New York and make his way unquestioned to any floor simply by pushing an elevator button are just about over.

Dr. Robert C. Weaver, president of Bernard M. Baruch College, told the graduating class yesterday that questioning values and institutions was commendable, but he warned that those who attack the status quo must be prepared to face the consequences of their actions.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9 (Reuters)--Fighting increased in the Fishhook region of Cambodia yesterday, a United States military spokesman said today. Four American soldiers were reported killed and 36 wounded. Vietcong and North Vietnamese losses were not known, the spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, June 9--In a six-month test program, post offices in several cities around the country--including eight in Connecticut-- will begin to accept passport applications.

One had respect and a somewhat restrained enthusiasm for the program of 10 Indian dances Karthyani presented last night at the Cubiculo. The pieces were meticulously costumed and presented, but were strangely unexciting.

GENEVA, June 9--Stock of Investors Overseas Services traded today near its record low of $2 as reports circulated that bank's interested in acquiring the distressed mutualfund company were offering little, if anything, for the shares.

WOODMERE, L. I., June 9-- Paul Harney, winner of the Massachusetts Open the last three years, said today he was not the least superstitious about qualifying for the 13th time for the United States Open Championship.

Scattered symbolic protests in the name of peace, the environment, human rights and the embattled history of Long Island University marked its 40th annual commencement exercises, held yesterday afternoon at the university's Brooklyn Center.

PARK CITY, Utah, June 9-- Voter resentments over the double crunch of inflation and rising unemployment may prove decisive in elections this fall, state political leaders said in interviews here today.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 9-- Traditions that had persisted since Aaron Burr's college days were toppled today as Princeton University held its 223d commencement.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 9--J. Russell Parsons, a former partner and director of Chubb Son, an insurance management firm, died yesterday at his home in Llewellyn Park, He was 73 years old.

ST. PAUL, June 9--Miss Robbin Lee Ridder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Ridder Jr., plans to be wed to Howard Candler Wright Jr., a fellow student she met at the University of California in Santa Barbara.

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Nearly 200 Roman Catholic priests, nuns and seminarians called upon members of Congress today to end the fighting in Southeast Asia, end repression of political dissent and act to restore confidence in the American form of government.

WASHINGTON, June 9-- Senator Edmund S. Muskie took issue today with the Nixon Administration's plan for reimbursing the states for their prefinancing of the Federal share of the cost of sewage treatment projects already completed or approved.
FORT BRAGG, N.C., June 9 (UPI)--The Army identified today the seven Green Berets who were killed yesterday in the premature explosion of TNT on a demolition training range here.

HOUSTON, June 9--Federal District Judge John V. Singleton has refused to allow the Internal Revenue Service to examine two million cashier's checks and drafts to gather evidence against a Houston physician suspected of having bank accounts in four foreign countries.

Thirty-five of the 120 parking lot employes at Kennedy International Airport were indicted yesterday in connection with what Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell called a $250,000 parking ticket racket.

HOUSTON, June 9 (Reuters) --The Shell Oil Company is making its first big venture into American real estate with an office-hotel-apartment complex in Houston that could ultimately represent investment of more than $1-billion.
HOUSTON, June 9--The Mets, who became baseball's outdoor champions last year, took another major step tonight toward winning the indoor championship this season.

WASHINGTON, June 9--In an effort to save money on defense contracts and to avoid cost overruns, the Defense Department has issued a broad policy directive that may have widespread impact on the multibillion-dollar aerospace industry.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 9-- Premier Souvanna Phouma announced today the fall of the major southeast Laotian town of Saravane to Communist-led Pathet Lao and North Vietnamese troops.
MAUN, Botswana--Much of the old Africa is gone, and what is left is disappearing fast under the wheels of tourist-filled micro-buses and the plows of land-hungry populations.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) --Members of a group of 11 Congressmen, governors and White House assistants who toured parts of South Vietnam and Cambodia at President Nixon's request reported tonight they were enthusiastic over the military success of the United States intervention in Cambodia.

"Since millions of cautious people refused to buy many items this year, there is now a built-in consumer money reservoir, greater than we can possibly imagine," Walter C. Straus, chairman and president of the J. J. Newberry Company, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
The Environmental Protection Administration announced late yesterday that the city was in a "high pollution forecast stage."

VENICE, Italy, June 9-- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has warned that, unless there is progress in the strategic-arms limitation talks with the Soviet Union in the next 12 to 18 months, the Nixon Administration will have to reconsider whether to expand and accelerate its nuclear arms program.
CHIMBOTE, Peru, June 8-- At the side of a road near here is a neatly painted sign saying "Huambacha village destroyed --we need help."
LITILE ROCK, Ark., June 9 (UPI)--Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller, Arkansas's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction, announced today that he would seek a third two-year term.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 9--A paralyzed witness, who mumbled replies from his hospital bed in the trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and seven other defendants on extortion charges, identified $240,828 worth of checks today as kickbacks from contractors who had worked for the city.

Dr. James Gallagher, who is resigning this week as chief of research and planning for the United States Office of Education, has called in a highly critical memorandum for the creation of a separate. Cabinetlevel Department of Education.
Astronauts, The President nominated Comdrs. John W. Young and Eugene A. Cernan, two of the Apollo 10 astronauts, for permanent promotion to the grade of captain in the Navy.

Dr. Howard Zinn, a long-time activist in the civil rights and peace movements, speaking yesterday at the 46th commencement of Queens College, was heard with mixed feelings when he made a bitter attack on the war in Vietnam and the "paraphernalia" and "rigamorole" of the democratic process in the United States.

DETROIT, June 9--A consumer recession is under way and "according to current indications, the 1970 recession will be the longest postwar recession," a University of Michigan consumer survey reported today.

HONG KONG, June 9--The Chinese Communists emphasized their differences with the Soviet Union today by giving an especially warm welcome to an official goodwill delegation from Rumania and lauding Rumania's resistance to foreign interference.
Mayor Lindsay has written letters of endorsement to two antiwar insurgent candidates seeking Democratic nominations for the House of Representatives in the June 23 primary election.

The former Police Academy, a five-story brick building at 5 Hubert Street, is among 122 parcels of surplus properties to be sold at public auction by the city's Department of Real Estate on June 24.

LONDON, June 9--The Treasury provided the Labor Party with campaign ammunition today with a report that Britain ran a strong surplus of $345.6-million in her first quarter trade in goods and services.

KANSAS CITY, June 9 (AP) --Charlie Metro was dismissed today as manager of the Kansas City Royals and the team's pitching coach, Bob Lemon, a former star hurler with the Cleveland Indians, was named to succeed him.
WASHINGTON, June 9--The Labor Department issued detailed guidelines today that are designed to eliminate discrimination against women in jobs paid for with Federal funds.

CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 9--Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Sperling Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Sperling, to Ens. John Herbert McAuliffe, a reserve officer on active duty with the Coast Guard at its Washington headquarters.

The New York University Medical Center announced yesterday that it expected to receive $2-million over the next five years from the Billy Rose Foundation for research and patient-care studies in two areas of surgery.

Though his voice is shallow in quality and mostly in one color, what equipment he has he uses intelligently.

CHICAGO, June 9 (Reuters) --A $3.75-million law suit was filed in Federal District Court today seeking damages on behalf of the estate of Fred Hampton. The Black Panther leader was slain in a pre-dawn police raid on his Chicago apartment six months ago.

"Business is very dull," a stockbroker remarked yesterday on Wall Street and the statistics bore out his words when the closing gong sounded on the New York Stock Exchange. Prices showed a mixed pattern.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 9--Of all the international Stratfords so far inspired to offer Shakespeare to its tourists, Ontario's Stratford, with its green parklands and handsome theater, is perhaps the prettiest. Last night, the festival's 18th annual season got started with a new production of "The Merchant of Venice" vigorously staged by Jean Gascon.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9-- Paul A. Gorman, new chairman and chief executive officer of the Penn Central Transportation Company, said today that he would seek to improve the railroad's commuter and Metroliner service but would press hard to eliminate all its longdistance passenger trains.

WASHINGTON, June 9--The Nixon Administration has decided to put the Government's credit behind the Penn Central Company and that holding company's financially troubled railroad subsidiary, the Penn Central Transportation Company.
ALBANY, June 9--Governor Rockefeller today announced a new state program for training and finding jobs for New York City residents who are inmates of state correctional institutions.
EL SEGUNDO, Calif., June 9 --The North American Rockwell Corporation has taken applications from more than 1,000 unemployed aerospace workers since last Friday.

Annual activities on the suburban debutante circuit move into high gear this week with three parties scheduled for Friday. A fourth party will be held on Monday and a fifth on June 27. But the total number of young women to be honored at the five parties, 59, is lower than in past years.

LUXEMBOURG, June 9--The six nations of the European Economic Community decided today to reassure the outside world about their international trade policies, which are causing increasing concern to nonmember countries, mainly the United States.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 9--Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, N. J., took a two-stroke lead in the 60th annual Women's Eastern Golf Association's 54-hole medal-play championship today.

MONTREAL, June 9--Jackie Gordon, the former assistant general manager of the Rangers and one of the American Hockey League's most successful executives, signed a three-year contract today to coach the Minnesota North Stars.

CAIRO, June 9 (AP)--Formations of Israeli warplanes attacked Egyptian positions on the Suez Canal for more than three hours today, killing one soldier and wounding another, the military command announced here.

LONDON, June 9--Sir Laurence Olivier is to play Nathan Detroit in "Guys and Dolls," the first musical to be presented by the National Theater.

WASHINGTON, June 9--The House Judiciary Committee approved today, 13 to 8, legislation that would immunize from antitrust prosecution existing agreements for joint publication of separately owned newspapers and would permit additional agreements under looser standards than apply to other businesses.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9-- Palestinian guerrillas battled with Jordanian forces today in and outside Amman, the capital. At one point, according to a Jordanian broadcast heard here, King Hussein escaped an attempt on his life.

ALBANY, June 9--The Court of Appeals today reversed the conviction of a man who had served two years of a maximum seven-year sentence. The court agreed with the prosecutor that the defendant had been illegally arrested.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) --President Nixon will announce tomorrow relatively modest revisions of the welfare reform proposal that ran aground in the Senate Finance Committee last month, Administration officials indicated today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) --An exhaustive examination of interlocking directorships among commercial banks was urged today by Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas and chairman of the House Banking Committee.

The Jersey Central Power Light Company announced yesterday that the future of its Longwood Valley pumped storage project is in doubt now that Jersey City has decided to withdraw from the project.

Clifford, that a merger with the Bankers National Life Insurance Company of Montclair, N. J., would be prejudicial to Bankers policyholders.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 --Seventeen years after he stood up against Joseph R. McCarthy, Nathan M. Pusey, president of Harvard University, charged today that the late Senator's "hateful technique" was now being used by radicals of the left "to destroy the universities for their own gain."
ATLANTA, June 9 (AP)--Dan Sikes of Jacksonville, Fla., shot a nine-under-par 135 over 36 holes today and led the Southeast sectional qualifying for the United States Open golf championship.
Silver futures prices rose yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange in line with increased prices received at the Government's weekly silver auction in Washington.

ROME, June 9--Leaders of the four-party partnership that governs Italy maintained today that it had been strengthened in the regional elections this week, although the conservative senior partner, the Christian Democratic party, suffered a setback.
