PARIS, June 10 A prominent South Vietnamese neutralist offered here today to form a government of "the silent majority," with no ties to either side, to lead his country out of the war.

Jerome A. Ambro, a white man running against a Negro for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, said yesterday that it was "very difficult" for him to campaign because everything he says is interpreted as racism or bigotry.
CHARLOTTE, N.C. Dr. R. Wharton Gaul is an apparently mild-mannered orthopedic surgeon, but turn the conversation to North Carolina's trash fish industry and the good doctor's restraint falls away.

NEWARK, June 10 Kenneth A. Gibson, the black candidate in next Tuesday's runoff mayoral election here, has requested Federal and state investigations of an alleged campaign plot involving a possible assassination attempt and the provocation of a racial incident this weekend. Both inquiries have already been started.
Peter H. Deitsch, a leading dealer in contemporary prints, died yesterday at the Continental Hotel in Munich, West Germany, apparently of a heart attack. He was 45 years old.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. June 10 Greeted by television cameras at every stop, Representative Richard L. Ottinger carried his campaign upstate today.

Under the Administration changes announced yesterday, George P. Shultz, reassigned, by the President from Secretary of Labor to director of the Office of Management and Budget, will direct a major share of day-today Government operations, as illustrated by solid lines in the chart, and participate in policymaking bodies, connected by broken lines.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 10 (UPI) A Federal court ruled in favor of the Black Muslims today, striking down as unconstitutional an Alabama law requiring Communists, Nazis and Muslims to register if they are in the state as lone as a day.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Robert M. Morgenthau, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said today that Investors Overseas Services had concealed $40-million to $50-million in loans to directors and other close associates that materially affected the stock of the shaky international financial empire.

Harlem Preparatory School graduated its third and largest class 83 college-bound students in a sprawling, festive commencement yesterday in the middle of a main street in the black community that gave the school its name.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 Arab guerrillas battled Jordanian soldiers today for the fourth consecutive day and held about 40 foreigners as hostages in an Amman hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, June 10 A period of cautious maneuvering began today as the three military commanders who seized power Monday sought the means to govern Argentina, a nation that has often seemed ungovernable.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) A select Senate committee announced today a summer-long series of hearings on school segregation problems in both the North and South.
August Heckscher, the Commissioner of Parks, said last night that he would not permit the digging of a shaft for a water tunnel in Central Park until full restoration of the area was guaranteed.

RUISLIP, England, June 10 (AP) A Soviet doctor and United States Air Force rescue crews worked together at sea to save the life of a Greek cabin boy and to provide emergency surgery for a British seaman, the Air Force here reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Authoritative sources said tonight that the United States Ambassador to Colombia, Jack Hood Vaughn, had resigned amid reports that he was dissatisfied with the Nixon Administration's attitude toward Latin America.

WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon made public today the outline of a revised, expanded welfare program that he hopes may prove more acceptable to Congress than the bill that stalled in the Senate six weeks ago.
Bob Moose, Pittsburgh's right-handed pitcher, got a bad case of the Willies in San Francisco's Candlestick Park yesterday.

The Kroehler Manufacturing Company, Naperville, Ill., one of the country's largest producers of furniture, announced yesterday that it was discontinuing its production of bedroom furniture in the United States due to conntinuing unprofitability. Bedroom furniture represented less than 10 per cent of Kroehler's 1969 sales of $117.5-million.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 South Vietnamese and American military planners are expected to give the South Vietnamese Army a greatly expanded role in fighting the North Vietnamese main force in the next few months.

WASHINGTON, June 10--The Justice Departmennt said today that any broadcasting company that systematically solicits commercials from companies it does business with should be denied a renewal of its broadcasting license.

BRISTOL, England, June 10 (AP) There was an upset in the $24,000 Wills open tennis tournament today, a Wimbledon tune-up, as Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., was toppled by Owen Davidson, the Australian southpaw, 6-1, 8-6, in the second round.

The International Business Machines Corporation, which for several years has been telling Wall Street that it knows how to solve most of the securities industry's problems, is now having back-office troubles of its own.
Paul O'Dwyer visited a municipal children's shelter yesterday and then denounced both the city and Federal governments for what he called their child-welfare policies.
With rising salaries pinched by increasing costs of living, proper tax planning for life insurance policies becomes more important each year.
Howard J. Samuels' campaign manager contended yesterday that Mr. Samuels would carry upstate areas "overwhelmingly" in his June 23 primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

One picked up "Bech: A Book," or "Bech: A Buch," or "Bekabook," or however it's pronounced and one groaned. One had never been a particular fan of Mr. Updike's. One had never quite been able to stomach the precociousness of his descriptive powers; the message, "Look, Ma, I'm writing," that wafted off his pages; the ultrafine sensibility that seemed to rob twigs and leaves...
Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy predicted yesterday that interest rates which in some sectors of the market posted record highs yesterday would decline moderately in the months ahead.

HOUSTON, June 10?With eager anticipation, about 200 residents of the Texas town of Alvin made the 30-minute drive to the Astrodome tonight to watch their hometown Hero, Nolan Ryan, pitch in person for the first time in two seasons.

TOPEKA, Kan. Burnett's Mound is a bulbous lump on the smooth surface of eastern Kansas, named after a Potawatomie chief whose real name Kahhegawatiangh was so unpronouncable that some white name dubbed him him Abram Burnett. In frontier Topeka, Abram was an imposing figure.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 (UPI) A Beirut spokesman said today that Lebanese troops had attacked one of the regular patrols Israel has been sending into Lebanon's frontier zone since an Arab guerrilla bazooka attack May 22 on an Israeli school bus that killed and wounded 32 children and adults.
WASHINGTON, June 10 Dr. James E. Allen Jr. of New York, who openly broke with the Nixon Administration over the Cambodian invasion, was ousted today as the Government's top education official.

The City Planning Commission has been asked to permit a developer to put up a 50Story office tower downtown in exchange for giving up control of an ancient block of buildings to be preserved as part of the South Street Seaport.

ELMIRA, N.Y., June 10 This city and Binghamton, in the state's Southern tier, were visited by Representative Richard Max McCarthy today, while in Washington his staff submitted a bill that would give Federal compensation to the widows and wives of policemen and firemen killed or injured in the line of duty.

As many as 2,000 full-time substitute teaching positions, virtually all the substitute positions remaining in the city school system, may be eliminated this fall, Board of Education sources said yesterday.

State Senator Basil A. Paterson, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, called on the Nixon Administration yesterday to sell jets to Israel "in order to maintain the balance of power in the Middle East."

BONN, June 10 A sudden rise in dollar transfers into West Germany compelled the Bundesbank today to purchase an estimated $300-million at the Frankfurt foreign-exchange market, according to usually well-informed sources.
The American Institute of Physics has named Robert H. Marks as its associate director for publishing and information activities.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) A bipartisan House group today introduced a bill that would replace the current draft law with a system allowing young men to choose between military and civilian service.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today a 1970 winter wheat crop of 1,076,445,000 bushels, a drop of 2 per cent from May and 6 per cent less than last year's production.
The Police Department, busy at all times guarding other people, took a look at its own security problem yesterday, not only at headquarters, but also in local stations.

STRATFORD, N.J., June 10 A midnight-to-dawn curfew was imposed for the second night in this small town eight miles southeast of Camden following a night of violence in which 20 persons were arrested, three policemen were injured and a police sergeant's garage apparently was firebombed.
RICHMOND, Va., June 10 Attorneys for Negro plaintiffs contended in Federal District Court here today that the city's proposed school desegregation plan was unacceptable.
Prices for several chemical and other products were given higher price tags yesterday.
A map showing how the Pacific "grew" has been published by a team of American and Soviet scientists who took part last year in drilling into the floor of that ocean.

Richard C. Grayson, president of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway Company, was elected chairman of the New Mexico and Arizona Land Company, succeeding J.E. Gilliland, it was announced yesterday following the annual meeting in St. Louis. The Frisco owns slightly more than 50 per cent of the land company's stock.

The latest bloody clash between Palestinian guerrillas and the Jordanian Army adds urgency to the fresh diplomatic initiatives that Secretary of State Rogers has promised in connection with any new arms aid to Israel.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Senior military planners here, surprised and elated by the performance of South Vietnamese military units in Cambodia, say that it may bring about a shift in the strategy for conducting the war once most American soldiers leave Vietnam.
The New York Yankees are not moving to London. They are not even being sold to anybody in London. They are not even being sold.
The city turned over a $2.6million check to the Federal Government yesterday and formally took possession of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

Eighteen Manhattan Reform Democratic District Leaders announced yesterday their endorsement of Humberto Cintron for the Democratic nomination in the 68th Assembly District, which includes East Harlem.
NEWARK, June 10 (AP) The Federal Government got a court order today to prevent the Hudson County Democratic leader, John V. Kenny, from gaining entry to a bank safedeposit box.
Specialist 4 James E. Hamerstone has been on active duty in the Army since March 24, but according to the 27-year-old reservist, no one told him about it until last Thursday.
Replacing baseball's reserve clause system gradually, to give the player more freedom, not only would do no harm but might benefit the game's management as well as the players.

WASHINGTON, June 10 A United States military attache was killed by Palestinian guerrillas at his home in Amman today and the United States Embassy came under sniper fire several times in the second day of heavy fighting between the Jordanian Army and the commandos, the State Department announced today.

A program to encourage physicians to perform abortions in their own offices or in clinics in defiance of city and state guidelines is being set in motion by the National Association for Repeal of Abortion Laws.
WASHINGTON, June 10 Anita Wells Merriam, Treasury tax adviser, died Sunday at her home here, apparently of a heart attack.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 10 The prosecution's paralyzed, bedridden witness in the trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and seven other defendants identified checks today amounting to $687,901 as contractors' kickbacks that he had cashed for the collection branch of the alleged municipal extortion conspiracy.

Combustion Engineering, Inc., announced yesterday the receipt of a $50-million contract from the Southern Company for two 850,000-kilowatt steam generators and an option for a third unit. Two operating subsidaries of Southern, the Georgia Power Company and the Alabama Power Company, will install the units on their systems with operations scheduled for 1974. Georgia Power holds the third unit option.

WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon today named George P. Shultz, the Secretary of Labor, as director of the new and powerful Office of Management and Budget. It was the second major Cabinet change in less than a week.
The printed explanations that accompany designers' fashion collections are not noted for their brevity, but George Halley managed to get his message across in two sentences.

By taking a group of pigs on a "joy ride," two doctors have made a discovery that challenges conventional scientific concepts about the spread of disease-causing bacteria from domestic animals to man.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 11 (AP) A 74year-old Buddhist monk burned himself to death in Saigon early today to protest against alleged Government persecution and to appeal for peace in Vietnam.

The State Public Service Commission charged yesterday that too many pay telephones had been out of repair "for too long a period" and ordered the New York Telephone Company to achieve the goal of fixing breakdowns, "Within four hours of detection."
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 A group of alumnae of Radcliffe College today asked the school's board of trustees to halt the impending merger of the women's college with Harvard University.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The Federal Trade Commission proposed stiffened penalties today for the manufacture and sale of clothing and household fabrics that fail to meet Federal flammability standards.
The tax increases proposed by Mayor Lindsay to balance the city's expense budget are, paradoxically, both economically risky and fiscally essential.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday in very light trading.

Dr. Yeshayahu H. Foerder, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank Leumi of Israel since 1957 and chairman of the First Israel Bank and Trust Company of New York since January, 1969, died Tuesday in Tel Aviv after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
John J. Geoghan, controller of the Power Authority of the State of New York, died Tuesday of a heart attack here. He was 55 years old and lived at 19 Stuyvesant Oval.
After a six-month search, Senator Charles E. Goodell announced the establishment yesterday of an election campaign organization that has close ties with Mayor Lindsay and Senator Jacob K. Javits.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 10 (AP) The Rev. John J. McLaughlin, associate editor of the Jesuit magazine America, formally announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat held by John O. Pastore, a Democrat.
VIENNA, June 10 Leonard Bernstein opened the Victory Party Congress of Bruno Kreisky's Austrian Socialists tonight, playing Beethoven with the Vienna Philharmonic.

Mrs. Arthur J. Goldberg, whose husband is a candidate for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, compaigned yesterday in Harlem. She was accompanied by Mrs. Basil A. Paterson, whose husband is Mr. Goldberg's running mate for Lieutenant Governor.
LONDON, June 10 (UPI) The state-owned British steel industry today announced two records.
A force of about regimental strength named Dick Gregory moved into the Village Gate on Bleecker Street Tuesday night, direct from countercommencement at Fordham University.

WASHINGTON, June 10 James D. Hodgson, the Under Secretary of Labor, who was nominated by President Nixon today to head the department, is only the second former business executive to be named Labor Secretary since 1933.

MIAMI BEACH, June 10 (AP) Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, said today that only a coalition of labor unionists, minority groups and students could turn the country away from President Nixon's "coalition of the rich."

WASHINGTON, June 10 Dr. Charles C. Edwards, the head of the Food and Drug Administration, conceded under Congressional questioning today that the artificial sweetener cyclamate should have been taken off the market sooner than it had been.

The Security New York State Corporation, an upstate bank holding company based in Rochester, announced yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had approved, without dissent, its proposed acquisition of the National Bank of Auburn, N.Y.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 10 (UPI) The Los Angeles Stars of the American Basketball Association officially became the Utah Stars today.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 10 A reconnaissance pilot who flew over Saravane yesterday after the important southern Laotian town fell to Communist forces said he saw many bodies on the airfield.

GENEVA, June 10 Bernard Cornfeld is reported to be opposed to efforts of an outside banking group to acquire control of Investors Overseas Services and has been talking of a proxy fight to regain control of the troubled mutual-fund company he founded 14 years ago.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 10 President Chung Hee Park has refused a Cambodian request for direct military assistance from South Korea but has promised non-military support a presidential spokesman said yesterday.

The Fuji Photo Film Company, Ltd., Japan's largest maker of quality color film and a leading producer of photographic materials, said yesterday it would introduce its color film products in the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The official transcript of President Nixon's latest news conference quotes Mr. Nixon as having asserted that United States forces in Cambodia had captured "rockets by the thousands and small arms ammunition by the millions."

The Carnegie Corporation yesterday announced grants totaling $935,000 to 10 universities to plan new graduate programs leading to a Doctorate of Arts degree with the aim of improving the quality of college teaching.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) The space agency said today it would launch two unmanned spacecraft toward Jupiter in 1972 and 1973 on missions of two years or longer.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 Forty-eight per cent of the American public is in favor of "freezing" prices and wages at their present level as long as the Vietnam war lasts, according to the latest Gallup Poll. Forty-one per cent are opposed and 11 per cent are undecided, the Gallup organization said today.
MOSCOW, June 10 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin reported today that the seven months of talks with Chinese Communist officials in Peking had failed to make any appreciable progress.
Process Shot, Mr. and Mrs. Sonny Weblin's fine filly who once beat the speedy Ta Wee, registered a sound triumph in the Vagrancy Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged the Army today to try to standardize National Guard firearms regulations in an effort to avoid another shooting like that at Kent State University.
MOSCOW June 10 (UPI) Andrian Nikolayev and Vitaly Sevastianov flew today through their ninth day in orbit conducting research necessary for giant orbital observatories of the future.

MILWAUKEE, June 10 (AP) "I am not responsible for any midi-length skirts purchased by my wife," Marvin Glasspiegel declared Monday in a newspaper advertisement that he later described as a protest to lowered skirt lengths.

Representatives of seven gaze-hound breeds (only the Irish wolfhound of the eligibles was missing) raced with undimmed vigor at the Greenwich Kennel Club show last Saturday, even though every now and then the rain poured down. The exhibition lasted an hour.

LORDSBURG, N.M., June 10 (UPI) Earl Grant, entertainer and organist who was best known for his instrumental version of "Ebb Tide," died with a companion in an automobile crash today in the New Mexico desert. Mr. Grant was 39 years old.

DARIEN, Conn., June 10 The engagement of Miss Linda Marie Thoman to Robert Anthony Fritz of New York has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Thoman. The bridegroom-to-be is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Fritz of Cranston, R.I.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 (AP) Robert Pelletreau, a member of the United States Embassy staff in Jordan, was among the 14 Americans and other foreigners held hostage in the Intercontinental Hotel in Amman.

The question comes up at cocktail parties these days particularly after the stock market has put in a dismal performance. The gin flows, someone gets a little downin-the-mouth and he asks: "Is another Great Depression possible?"

The American Enka Corporation has agreed in principle to acquire the International Salt Company as well as 100 per cent of the stock of Organon, Inc., in a transaction valued at about $88.5-million, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The first big shake-out of the Nixon team, which is noteworthy enough from the managerial standpoint, has stirred an unusual amount of political interest here.
Two grants for programs that would develop technical resources in art conservation were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Dr. Joshua Lederberg, a Nobel Prize winner in genetics, asked today for the establishment of a national study group on genetics research to help bring to realization a new era in medicine.

WASHINGTON, June 10 In the absence of any formal position by the American Bar Association, a committee of the bar of New York City has partially filled a conspicuous gap by testifying strongly against major portions of the proposed organized crime control act.

BONN, June 10 West Germany and Poland agreed today after four rounds of exploratory talks that they were close enough on essential political issues to start negotiating a general treaty on diplomatic relations.

Bizet's "Carmen" returned to the Metropolitan Opera repertory on Tuesday night for the first time in the 1969-70 season, bringing some singers new to their roles with the company and returning Jean Morel to the Met podium after an absence of seven years.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Usually it is the night planes that bring the men back. You see their wives at National Airport, waiting, waiting, while the clock hands crawl towards midnight, and the exhausted children doze.
Like sourdoughs looking for gold dust or nuggets, 30 policemen sifted through debris at Police Headquarters yesterday in search of fragments from the bomb that exploded there Tuesday night.

JERSEY CITY, June 10 About 200 members of the Young Puerto Rican Society staged a rock-throwing melee at City Hall here at about 10 o'clock tonight, overturned a police car and damaged two others in a disorder that grew out of a protest against alleged police brutality.
Dr. Joseph P. McMurray has resigned the presidency of Queens College to become head of the College of New Rochelle, a Roman Catholic institution for women. He will be its first nonclerical president.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 10 (UPI) Tear gas was shot into a crowd gathered in the student community of Isla Vista tonight after the police were unable to break up a sitin with mass arrests.

ATLANTA, June 10 Hosea Williams, a long-time civil rights activist, qualified today to run for Secretary of State of Georgia as a Republican. His wife qualified to run for Controller General as a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Murray Chotiner emerged from seclusion as a White House adviser for an hour this morning to provide some new insights into President Nixon, the unfolding Republican campaign and, just incidentally, himself.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10 A 7-year-old girl was found dead here in an unused refrigerator last night, and officials said they suspected she had been murdered.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 (UPI) Gen. Bartolome Blanche, Provisional President of Chile for two weeks in September, 1932, died today at the aye of 91.

SYRACUSE, June 10 To meet the ever-increasing demands of intercollegiate rowing, one must be truly dedicated to the sport. There are 451 such dedicated oarsmen ready to row on Onondaga Lake here tomorrow in the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual three-day regatta.

E.F. Hutton Co. announced yesterday that it had acquired the offices of Orvis Brothers Co. in Norfolk, Va., and Memphis, Tenn. Earlier in the week Hutton had reported the acquisition of the Orvis branches in Chicago and Washington, D.C.

WASHINGTON, June 10 In a first effort to diversify highway spending, John A. Volpe, Secretary of Transportation, urged today that 7 per cent of the highway trust fund be used for safety and beautification instead of new construction. He was immediately challenged by supporters of the trust fund on the House Public Works Committee.

Mr. and Mrs. John A. Thomas of New York and Truro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ellen Thomas, to Alexander Edward Naughton, son of Mrs. Helen Naughton of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Alexander Edward Naughton, professor of French and Italian at Stanford University.

Paul A. Gorman, head of the Penn Central Company, expressed the "hope" yesterday that the troubled transportation system "within the next few days" would have the money in hand that a group of banks has agreed to loan it with the Government's guarantee.

Miss Lucy Durr Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ransom Johnson Dunn Jr., was married at her parents' home in Birmingham, Ala., on Saturday to Winton Malcolm Blount 3d, son of Postmaster General and Mrs. Blount of Montgomery and Washington.

The appointment of Max I. Basner as supervising referee for the State Department of Motor Vehicles, new Administrative Adjudication Bureau here was announced yesterday by Commissioner Vincent L. Tofany. The bureau's five local offices will open on July 1 and will handle adjudication of most moving violations taking place within city limits.
Sol O. Lipset, vice president and account supervisor of Diener Dorskind, Inc., an advertising agency at 1501 Broadway, died Tuesday at his home, 4 Hull Street, Oceanside, L.I. He was 61 years old.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 10 (AP) Deceit, a Kentucky-bred filly owned by the Windfields Farm of E.P. Taylor of Canada, scored an easy victory, as expected, in the $24,400 Colleen Stakes at Monmouth Park today, winning by three lengths.

The bus is called the Fresh Meadows Express, and it leaves 34th Street and The Avenue of the Americas every 10 minutes during the rush-hour period. It makes three stops in midtown Manhattan and then rolls nonstop until it reaches the winding roads and garden apartments of eastern Queens.

As City Councilmen and others reviewing Mayor Lindsay's proposed $7.8-billion expense budget have found out, the city's fiscal situation is extremely serious. Costs rise alarmingly. Revenue sources shrink.

The convulsion that cost the jobs of Penn Central's board chairman Stuart T. Saunders and two key associates throws a harsh spotlight on some of the problems now plaguing American business and threatening the health of other corporations as well.

BONN, June 10 Lufthansa, the West German airline, announced today that it would propose its first dividend, a 4 per cent cash payout. Last year saw the company's best profit in its 15 years of operations.
DELANO, Calif., June 10 (UPI) The signing of the largest contract to date between the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee was announced today by Cesar Chavez, farm union leader.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 10 The Government here reported today that Laotians had joined the North Vietnamese and Vietcong military forces forces that were fighting in the Siemreap area in northwest Cambodia.

Miss Diana Davenport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Braxton Bragg Davenport of Lancaster, Pa., was married on June 3 in Athens to E. Haring Chandor, a stockbroker with Shearson, Hammill Co. The ceremony in the American Protestant Church was performed by the Rev. Dr. Otto Meinardus.

CHICAGO, June 10 (Reuters) Prof. Milton Friedman said today that he expected the Federal Reserve to cut back growth in the money supply to an annual rate of 2 to 3 per cent over the coming months to neutralize the inflationary impact of the 9 per cent average rate of the last three months.

TOKYO June 10 (AP) The Mitsui Mining and Smelting Company said today it has succeeded experimentally in eliminating carbon monoxide from auto engine exhaust by means of a low-cost catalyst with a manganese base.
Theodore C. Sorensen appeared at a rally in the garment center yesterday and called for a war against the traffic in drugs.

Encouraged by the turnout of 17,000 fans who paid at least $150,000 last Sunday to see a live telecast of the England-Brazil World Cup match played in Mexico City, the Spanish International Network will present another telecast at Madison Square Garden on Sunday.
Soybeans futures prices continued to rise sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday for a three-day gain of about 12 cents a bushel.
The London stock market resumed its downward drift yesterday. A newspaper strike added to the influences that have sharply reduced trading activity during the last week.

MEXICO CITY, June 10 (AP) Gerhard Muller, a center forward, scored three goals for the second time in the World Soccer Cup championship and led his team to a 3-1 victory over Peru today to assure the West Germans of top place in Group IV.

SYRACUSE, June 10 A college student who had just returned home for summer recess was charged today with killing his mother and wounding his father in Baldwinsville, a small hamlet northwest of here. Investigators said they had been unable to discover a motive.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The doctors in the auditorium of the New Senate Office Building wore peace buttons and smoked their pipes reflectively. Senator Harold E. Hughes, in a bright blue suit, looked down on them and said happily:
The stock market went through another sinking spell yesterday, with American Telephone trading at its lowest price in 10 years, as volume continued at an extremely slow pace.

PARIS, June 10 Roland Petit last night resigned from the directorship of the Paris Opera's Ballet. As the story goes, he did so by letter from his home rather than from his office because he had no phone in the office.

George Balanchine's celebrated dictum that there are no mothers-in-law in ballet seems hardly supported by his own "A Midsummer Night's Dream," so clearly does the master of plotless ballet tell a tangled tale.

Union representatives of newspaper pressmen and electricians held separate negotiations yesterday with the publishers of the city's four major daily newspapers in a continuation of efforts to reach contract agreements replacing those that expired last March 30.
Howard J. Samuels and Arthur J. Goldberg, the two candidates for Governor in the Democratic primary on June 23, will hold the first of two scheduled debates on Sunday.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 10 The Government has relaxed restrictions on Percy Sledge, the American Negro singer, to allow him to appear before all-white audiences.

The biggest name in French shoes comes to Fifth Avenue today. The Charles Jourdan shop, designed by a French architect with most of its Plexiglas, steel and leather interior made in France and assembled here, opens at 700 Fifth Avenue.
The city yesterday asked the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission for $9.9million to expand its methadone treatment programs to combat drug addiction.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn. "I cannot mask as a good cook," Mildred Dunnock, the actress, protested, "but I like to cook because to me it's like the theater, getting together and having fun; a great way to forget yourself.

MONTREAL, June 10 The Rangers lost some muscle in Orland Kurtenbach, finesse in Don Marshall and youth in Allan Hamilton today as the National Hockey League expanded to 14 teams by stocking the new Vancouver and Buffalo franchises.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Last Thursday, quiet, reflective George Pratt Shultz thumped his fist on a conference room desk at the Labor Department and told a group of contractors who had come to see him about a lottery plan for selecting apprentices that the meeting was over.

ABERDEEN, Md., June 10 Miss Janie Elizabeth Horan and George Pearson Smith were married twice today. The first time was in a civil ceremony at the nearby Bel Air courthouse. The second time was in a ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents on Paradise Road here, where the couple exchanged limericks instead of vows.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 10 On an afternoon more suitable for bikini-watching than yacht racing, Valiant took another step forward today in the preliminary America's Cup defense trials.
Ten years ago, things were simpler for judges and lawyers and district attorneys: A man was arrested, arraigned, indicted if a felony was involved and sent to trial.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10 Columbia clinched the team title today in the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championships as two Lion doubles pairs qualified for the final tomorrow at the University of Rochester courts.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 10 (UPI) Space agency officials are thinking about canceling next year's Apollo 15 moon mission, and possibly a second flight, to free more Saturn 5 rockets for the space station program.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., June 9 The newly reorganized John F. Kennedy Center for Military Assistance has just graduated its first class of new "ugly Americans" 39 officers who received a concerted six-week smattering of knowledge in the political and social sciences.
A variation on a favorite theme the social responsibility of advertising was played yesterday morning as the World Congress of Advertising reached the midpoint of its week-long meeting.
Miss Elaine Noel Butcher and William Joseph Garrett of Philadelphia will be married Aug. 22 in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

CAIRO, June 10 (Reuters) President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, today called on King Hussein of Jordan to do everything in his power to end the crisis between his Government and Palestinan guerrillas.
The New York Yankees, who seem to be nourishing an impossible dream of their own this season, made it two straight over the Minnesota Twins last night on a four-hitter by Mel Stottlemyre.
The city's experimental methadone program in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, which started last October, is under attack.
LONDON, June 10 In the middle of the campaign for the June 18 election the British today found themselves without their national newspapers.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 10 Gossip, malice and hypocrisy, like the poor, will always be with us, and therefore every production of Sheridan's exquisite comedy, "The School for Scandal," can hardly fail to be timely. Michael Langham's new production of the play seen for the first time at the Stratfor Festival last night is more than timely, it is welltimed.

Triangle Industries, Inc., a major fabricator of copper products, filed an antitrust action yesterday that charged five, of the nation's largest producers and refiners of copper with price fixing and conspiracy to monopolize the fabricating sector of the industry.

TOKYO, June 10 (Reuters) An American business leader made a strong plea today for prompt liberalization of Japan's trade and capital transactions at the seventh JapanUnited States business conference here.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 10 Curtis Person had a few problems on the Siwanoy Country Club course today but finished strongly to win the 10th annual Eastern Seniors Golf Association title with a 71, 75-146 for the two-day tournament.
Barry Farber was ruled off the Liberal party line yesterday in the November election for Representative in the 19th Congressional District.
Judges ready to try criminal cases before juries in Federal Court here this week have had a problem not enough jurors.

Delicate negotiations in public broadcasting appear destined to make New York's Channel 13 one of the more unusual noncommercial TV operations in the country. If no hitches develop, James Day, president of National Educational Television, will become president later this month of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, licensee of Channel 13.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Harper Row of New York and Charles E. Tuttle, a small Vermont publisher, received the John Barnes Publisher-ofthe-Year Awards tonight at the closing session of the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association. The awards named for the late founder of Barnes Noble, Inc. are made each year by secret ballot among the association's membership, which now totals 2,800 bookstores and wholesale dealers.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) The Office of Economic Opportunity announced a $1.95million grant today to encourage and train more doctors, dentists and other medical personnel to serve in poor neighborhoods.

WASHINGTON, June 10 A Harvard student who has been severely critical of the "liberal" way student radicals have been treated by colleges will become Vice President Agnew's only full-time speech writer.

The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday denounced the bombing of Police Headquarters on Tuesday night as "the work of anarchists" and warned that the city was close to an "explosion that will destroy us all."

WASHINGTON June 10 The House passed today a clean air act that went considerably beyond earlier legislation in the stringency of its antipollution standards and in the penalties imposed on industry for noncompliance.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 10?Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Kroll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Knox Kroll, to Andrew Thompson Dwyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dwyer Jr. of Syosset, L.I.
Israel Goichberg, a Yiddish poet and teacher, died Tuesday in the New York Infirmary after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 60 West 68th Street.
PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) A Federal judge issued a ruling today clearing the way for Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., to take over the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation.
PALERMO, Sicily, June 6 Scores of notorious underworld figures have been freed under a new Italian decree to protect the rights of accused persons.
The city's Board of Elections yesterday came out in support of giving th right to voter to 18-year-olds in city and state elections.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Opposition to the Nixon Administration's proposals for fighting organized crime has developed within the legal profession, only three weeks after President Nixon called upon bar organizations to help him pass his anticrime program.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 10 Gil Hanover, a $95,000 purchase as a yearling who failed in the first race of his career but since then has been unbeaten, did not fare well this morning in the post position draw for Saturday night's $111,514,24 Dexter Cup trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

Two top city housing officials, upon receiving a check yesterday for more than $53million in Federal urban-renewal funds, took pains to stress how cordial their relations were with the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development a day after the department's Secretary, George W. Romney, called Mayor Lindsay's attack on a Nixon Administration housing bill "irresponsible and inaccurate."
A group of union leaders promised strong support yesterday to Arthur J. Goldberg and hinted that other unions, now committed to Governor Rockefeller, might "soon have a change of heart."
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Navy operations on the small Puerto Rican island of Culebra were bitterly criticized today at a Congressional hearing.
The city's Board of Elections yesterday came out in support of giving th right to voter to 18-year-olds in city and state elections.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Opposition to the Nixon Administration's proposals for fighting organized crime has developed within the legal profession, only three weeks after President Nixon called upon bar organizations to help him pass his anticrime program.

WASHINGTON, June 11 A former Army intelligence officer has written in a magazine article that the American Army unit involved in the alleged Songmy massacre received conflicting intelligence information.
The World Congress of Advertising ended yesterday on the subject of society's ills its dominant theme for four days.

Irving A. Manacher, who, although sightless for 50 years, ran two of the nation's largest independent coal and fuel-oil distributing concerns, died Tuesday in his sleep at his home, 55 East End Avenue. His age was 74.
LONDON, June 11 A week before Britain's scheduled election, Prime Minister Wilson and his Labor party appear to hold a commanding lead.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 11 The office of Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that National Guard troops had been placed on alert in case of further trouble in Isla Vista, a tense community adjacent to the University of California at Santa Barbara.
BOSTON, June 11 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, announced to day his candidacy for re-election to a second term in the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, June 11 In a rebuff to President Nixon, the Senate refused today to modify proposed legislative restrictions on future American military operations in Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The popular music group Blood, Sweat and Tears will perform in three Eastern European countries this month and next, the State Department announced today. It will be the first such contemporary American musical group to be sent to Communist countries under the State Department's cultural presentations program.

A 22-year-old unemployed car washer who told the police he had a $60-a-day drug habit was arrested yesterday in Astoria, Queens, and charged with the murder of a woman teacher from Long Beach whose body was found in an abandoned lot near La Guardia Airport Saturday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 There is something new in the air on the campuses of America at the end of this university year. All the same problems and arguments remain, but the moderates are beginning to challenge the extremists of the right and left and change the tone and maybe even the direction of the student debate.

MOSCOW, June 11 (UPI) Andrian Nikoleyev and Italy Sevastianov took a break from their spaceflight duties today and played history's first chess match between space and earth, the press agency Tass reported.

ALBANY, June 11 New York State labor unions have forsaken Democrats to endorse Governor Rockefeller for reelection this year with a frequency that is embarrassing to Democrats who are supporting former Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg.

Sidney Watters Jr., the country squire from Middleburg, Va., saddled National Anthem and Attribution for yesterday's 54th running of the grueling Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park and then watched them finish one, two, respectively.
WASHINGTON, June 11 Vice President Agnew appealed to Republican Congressional candidates tonight to campaign on the record of President Nixon.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) The State Department said today that Jack Hood Vaughn, director of the Peace Corps in the Johnson and Nixon Administrations was resigning as United States Ambassador to Colombia to return to private life.

SUKHUMI, U.S.S.R. The Soviet Union, which covers one sixth of the earth's surface, is fighting the same grim battle against pollution that decreasingly engrosses the United States. Neither capitalism nor Communism has developed a successful formula for curbing man's sins against the atmosphere enveloping him and, if the ecology of this vast country has not yet been so seriously damaged as America's, the process is well under way.
Scandinavian Airlines has announced the appointment of B. John Heistein as vice president and general manager of its North American division, effective July 1.

Justice George Starke said yesterday in State Supreme Court that the police had no right to permit the use of bullhorns or other sound equipment by Italian-Americans who nightly picketed the headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here.

Glamour and investmentgrade issues came under renewed pressure yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average tumbled 9.93 points to 684.42. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange continued to limp along at a slow rate that means red ink for the operations of many brokerage houses.

NEWARK, June 11 Joseph (Joe Bayonne) Zicarelli, reputed boss of Hudson County racketeering and a leading Mafia figure, was indicted today on charges that he evaded paying income taxes on a total of $960,000 in 1967 and 1968.
Mayor Lindsay signed a bill yesterday to permit landlords to deduct from their real estate taxes three-fourths of the cost of removing or boarding over lead-based paint in their buildings.
BRISTOL, England, June 11 (UPI) Rod Laver and Mrs. Margaret Court were in top form today as they advanced in the Wills open lawn tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON, June 11 For 33 years, commissions, White House advisers and students of the Presidency have insisted, with increasing urgency, that the President of the United States does not have enough power.
WASHINGTON, June 11 The Nixon Administration is seriously considering a plan to break up the Atomic Energy Commission and remake it into an agency dealing with all forms of energy.

WASHINGTON, June 11 "You could have substituted 'transistors' for 'books' and everybody would have thought we were at a convention of electronics corporations," the vice president of a major publishing house remarked as he left a session at the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Illinois Central Railroad and the United Transportation Union signed today an 18month experimental agreement calling for new operating methods and eliminating restrictive job rules to win new business and create more jobs.
CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) Steve Reid, who bagged six birdies on the last eight holes, shot a five-under-par 66 today and took the first-round lead in the $130,000 Western open golf tournament.

A Queens patrolman was shot twice last night while trying to stop a holdup at Topsy's Restaurant 112-01 Queens Blvd.

PASADENA, Calif., June 11 (AP) Frank Silvera, the actor, director and producer who played the role of a Mexican ranch owner on television's "High Chaparral" series, was accidentally electrocuted today in his home here.

PARIS, June 11 The Saigon Government announced today that it would release next month 62 disabled war prisoners and 24 fishermen captured at sea off North Vietnam. A spokesman for Hanoi indicated that his Government would raise no obstacle to the transfer.

Adam Yarmolinsky and Nathan Glazer, two prominent Harvard University professors associated with the American Jewish Congress, took issue yesterday with the group's formal opposition to a federally sponsored plan to establish an "education voucher" system in one or two cities next year.
An urgent effort to head off a Long Island Railroad strike Sunday morning got under way here yesterday afternoon under Federal auspices.

BERLIN, June 11 Thousands of young West Berliners took to the streets today in a peaceful march to protest Allied-backed legislation to legalize the equipping of West Berlin's policeforce with machine guns and hand grenades.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The State Department said today that the Spanish Government's action in penalizing a leading opposition figure for attempting to meet with Secretary of State William P. Rogers in Madrid last month was an "internal matter" of Spain.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 11 After five days of the bloodiest fighting ever between Arab guerrillas and the Jordanian Army, King Hussein yielded tonight to the two principal commando demands by removing his uncle as Commander in Chief and dismissing the commander of the Third Armored Division, which surrounds the capital.

About one out of every six Americans plays a musical instrument, and more than one of every three American households has an amateur musician, according to a survey released yesterday by the American Music Conference.

The chancellor of the City University of New York has sounded out Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the ousted United States Commissioner of Education, about whether he might be interested in becoming president of Queens College.

Miss Elaine Barbara Schwartz and Edward Strausman were married here last evening at the St. RegisSheraton. Rabbi Jacob Polish performed the ceremony. State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Barshay assisted.
LONDON, June 11 Spin a coin and take your pick for the 42d contest for the Wightman Cup between the United States and Britain at Wimbledon tomorrow and Saturday. It could be that close.

A nightclub show of more than usual significance is winding up an engagement tomorrow at the Royal Box of the Americana Hotel, where B. B. King, the blues singer and guitarist who has provided the cutting edge for the current wide popularity of the blues, has been appearing.

TRIPOLI, Libya, June 11 (AP) Several hundred Libyans stood silently today as the United States flag came slowly down for the last time at Wheelus Air Force Base near here and a Libyan band played "The Star Spangled Banner."

Premier Olof Palme of Sweden said last night that he sensed "a kind of division in this nation and an emotionally charged atmosphere" very unlike what he knew as a college boy in Ohio or when he had visited 36 states "by the hitchhiking method."
Strolling along the remodeled but deserted piers that supplanted the teeming wharves where he worked as a young longshoreman, Paul O'Dwyer berated the Port of New York Authority yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 11 The Syrian Government announced today that it would stand by the Arab guerrillas "all the way and at all cost" in their struggle with the Jordanian authorities.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 Vietcong guerrillas shot their way through a South Vietnamese hamlet early today, killing 70 civilians in their homes, a United States military spokesman said.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) A general kissed generals at the Pentagon today as the Army handed stars to women for the first time in its 196-year history.
The parents of children at Public School 183 had worried for a long time about the inadequate opportunities for physical exercise at the school.

MEXICO CITY, June 11 (AP) The Mexican soccer team gained the World Cup quarterfinals tonight for the first time. The host nation beat Belgium, 1-0, before 112,000 fans in Aztec Stadium to tie the Soviet Union for first place in Group I.
Traffic plays tasteful rock, and if that sounds like a contradiction in terms, it is nonetheless a sign of the progress that rock has made over the last several years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 11 The police last night arrested a local representative of the Black Panther party, his wife and three other persons after, the police said, a patrolman was threatened with a shotgun.

VIENNA, June 11 Herbert von Karajan, the 62-year-old conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, plans to offer himself as a guinea pig to investigate the experience of performing and listening to music while under the influence of drugs.
Spartans Industries, Inc., one of the largest retailers in the United States, has assembled a list of about 250,000 names of confessed shoplifters and dishonest retailing employes.

Alexander Kerensky, who led the first phase of the Russian Revolution in 1917 until he was overthrown in the Bolshevik coup, died yesterday of arteriosclerotic heart disease at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 89 years of age.
Angkor, now in the hands of North Vietnamese forces, is generally regarded as the consummate masterpiece of the vanished Khmer Empire, which flourished from the 9th to the 13th century.

Continued low prices and high market freight rates along with rising operating costs were mainly responsible for the decline in first-quarter earnings of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., from the year-ago period, the company reported in London yesterday.

The designation of Secretary of Labor Shultz as President Nixon's chief aide in managing the vast Federal bureaucracy could represent a great extension in the responsibility and influence of a Cabinet officer who without question has been one of the brightest stars of this Administration.

"Take One" is the name the distributor, Universal, has given a group of student films now showing in three separate programs at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle. All the films were made within the last two years or so, and all were made by graduate or undergraduate students or (in a few cases) by nonstudents closely associated with schools.
Members of Branch 36 of the National Association of Letter Carriers voted last night by a narrow margin to delay strike action.

MARION, Ohio By the time the curtain opened not long ago on the Miss Heart of Ohio pageant in the baroque old Palace Theater here, the local Jaycees were confident that their eight months of planning had paid off.

Even for this turbulent and violent century the dimensions of Peru's natural disaster strain credibility. The Peruvian Government now believes at least 50,000 persons were killed in the earthquake that struck the lovely Callejon de Huaylas and by the Andean avalanches and floods that came after.

TOKYO, June 11 (UPI) A meeting of United States and Japanese businessmen ended today on the same note on which it began the United States group asking for a speedy relaxation of Japanese import restrictions and the Japanese pleading for patience.
MOSCOW, June 11 The Soviet Union announced today that it was increasing its military and economic aid to North Vietnam as a result of intensified fighting in Indochina.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) David A. Pine, a retired United States District Court judge who once ruled that President Harry S. Truman acted unconstitutionally, died here today at the age of 78.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., June 11 The paralyzed prosecution witness in the trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and seven other defendants on charges of extortion said here today he had withheld information from the United States Attorney because he was "afraid." Before he could tell what he feared, a defense lawyer who was cross-examining him cut..

NEWARK, June 11 Black members of the administration of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio attempted today to minimize reports of "violence and potential violence" during the Mayor's campaign for re-election against Kenneth A. Gibson, a Negro engineer.

When Robert L. Leeds Jr., chairman of Manhattan Industries, Inc., a large apparel and retail company, visited the Soviet Union last week, he could not resist taking a busman's holiday by inspecting stores and production machinery there.

HONOLULU, June 11 (AP) The crew of the charter boat Coreene-C hauled in a 15-foot, 1,805-pound Pacific blue marlin yesterday. It was reputed to be the largest fish other than a shark ever caught by rod and reel.

T. Rowe Price is getting old. At 72, he says, "I should have retired a long time ago." But he likes what he's doing and he does it well.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended June 6 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Continued work stoppages at major truck terminals throughout the country contributed to the large year to year decrease tonnage.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) A July draft call of 15,000 men was issued today by the Pentagon. It is the same as the quotas previously set for May and June.

CEDAR FALLS, Iowa, June 11 (AP) Chalmers B. (Bump) Elliott, former head football coach at the University of Michigan and a standout player for the Wolverines in the 1940's, today was named athletic director at the University of Iowa.

WASHINGTON, June 11 President Nixon assumed the direction of urgent efforts today to assure the safety of about 24 Americans held hostage by Palestinian guerrillas in two Amman hotels and of other Americans in Jordan.
COLORADO SPRINGS, June 11 (AP) John Pilch has been reelected president of the International Typographical Union by a margin of nearly 2 to 1, a tabulation of the biennial voting indicated today.

Budget cuts that would mean a smaller increase in real estate taxes and the elimination or reduction of some new taxes were proposed yesterday by Democrats on the Board of Estimate and two Democratic leaders of the City Council.

The Senate took a reassuring step toward reasserting its constitutional checks over the warmaking powers of the President yesterday in rejecting an effort to transform the Cooper-Church amendment into a virtual blank check for future military operations in Cambodia.

State Senator Basil A. Paterson, the first Negro to run for Lieutenant Governor in New York, said yesterday that he had encountered "no antiblack feeling" while campaigning around the state but that he believed his positions on issues had been obscured by "the black candidacy question."

SALISBURY, Conn., June 11 Miss Sarah Hervey Smith and David Debs Dixon, candidates for master's degrees in architecture at the University of Pennsylvania, plan to be married in St. John's Episcopal Church here on Aug. 29.
The Continental Can Company announced yesterday that it would spend $100-million to modernize and expand its paper mill in Hodge, La.
The Garden State Arts Center opened its third season Wednesday night in the home built for it by the New Jersey Highway Authority at Telegraph Hill Park on the Garden State Parkway.

Representative Shirley Chisholm told the academic world yesterday that it was burying its head in the sand while large numbers of disillusioned students were "ripe for political agitators."

CAIRO, June 11 President Gamal Abdel Nasser tonight denounced the fighting between Palestinian commandos and Jordanian troops as a "tragedy and a massacre" and said that the Arab world had a right to expect guarantees for stability in Jordan.
SYRACUSE, June 11 (AP) Dr. Frank C. Laubach, a missionary who fought illiteracy around the world, died today in a hospital here. He was 85 years old.

Telephone service in New York City, was found to have improved in some respects during the month of March but in other facets was no better than in January, when a Federal Communications Commission survey indicated that service here was the worst in the country.
SUTTON, Mass., June 11 (AP) Favored Kathy Whitworth and steady Mary Mills shared the first-round lead with fourunder-par 69's today in the $30,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association championship.

Because of Ned Rorem's estimable accomplishments as a composer, his acknowledged gift for language, and his musical involvement with theater, one looks forward to his work as a playwright.

BONN, June 11 West Germany's economics minister, Dr. Karl Schiller, said today that yesterday's mammoth dollar flow into West Germany ought to be considered "a compliment" to domestic price stability and the mark's purchasing power.

Expecting a challenge from the Chicago Sidewinders, Detroit Sparks and Arizona Road Runners, the Illinois Gizz Kids open defense of their title in the 14th annual National Wheelchair games at the Joseph Bulova School of Watchmaking in Woodside, Queens, today.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The head of the New York Stock Exchange suggested today that Congress, in seeking to curb abuses of secret foreign bank accounts, tread softly so as not to disturb legitimate transactions between American and foreign business associates.
The American Stock Exchange turned in its poorest performance of the week yesterday as the list declined in slow trading.
Money and credit are expanding at a rapid rate, banking data published yesterday showed.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
MILWAUKEE, June 11 (UPI) The Milwaukee Brewers traded Steve Hovley, an outfielder, to Oakland today for Tito Francona, an infielder, and Al Downing, a left-handed pitcher.
The Parvin-Dohrmann Company, which has been beset by a variety of investigations and management changes, announced yesterday that its newest director had resigned.

Thirty-five reputed underworld figures were arrested yesterday in eight counties in and around New York City as District Attorney Eugene Gold of Kings County announced their indictment on charges of criminal contempt.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The International Association of Chiefs of Police has distributed a report warning that some models of 1969 Ford automobiles may be a serious hazard to motorists because of mechanical failures.

Several prominent New Yorkers, including Thomas P.F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum, sent a telegram to President Nixon and Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird yesterday, urging that the Angkor temple complex on Cambodia be spared from damage or destruction during the current fighting there.

Two locals of the International Longshoremen's Association pledged their support yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's bid for re-election, and leaders of the union indicated that the full association would shortly take the same action.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 11 Delancy Smith of the Park Country Club, Snyder, N.Y., won the 59th annual women's Eastern Golf Association championship today by six strokes.

WASHINGTON, June 11 President Nixon asked Congress today to approve legislation canceling 20 Federal oil leases in the Santa Barbara Channel, where a blowout in January, 1969, polluted miles of beaches and destroyed much marine life.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 11 (UPI) Some 320 Laotian Government soldiers were killed or are missing in the fall Tuesday of Saravane, a key town at a highway junction in southern Laos, official sources said today.

While housewives on the upper floors of a tenement casually dropped garbage past his head, Howard J. Samuels explored the refuse-strewn alleys of a South Bronx slum yesterday, then proposed a way to solve the housing crisis.
New York's baseball teams reversed courses yesterday, the Yankees heading west in strength and the Mets returning home under their severest pressure of the season.
Prices of wheat futures stole the play away from soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade and shot upward while soybeans closed irregular. Other grain prices also closed mostly higher.

A retired teacher who had returned here from Central America for the funeral of his mother was beaten and killed in Greenwich Village early yesterday by two young men who allegedly used a 14-year-old runaway girl as a decoy panhandler.

Clarence R. Mease, associate executive director of the National Council of Young Men's Christian Associations of the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 54 Rose Terrace, Chatham, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The appointment of George P. Shultz to head the Government's reorganized and expanded budget and management operation has been greeted with enthusiasm by Federal officials responsible for national economic policy.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary returned from West Berlin last night and said the only way to make Police Headquarters secure from future bombing attacks was to shut it in with a "Berlin wall" something he would not do.
SIEMREAP, Cambodia, June 10 The Cambodians clustered around a truck to stare at the two dead men sprawled in back as if something could still be learned from their gray faces and cold bodies.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 11 Secretary General Thant said today that only agreement between "the two biggest powers" the United States and the Soviet Union could end the rising level of war going on in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, June 11 The incoming Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare received a stern lecture today from a former Secretary of the department on the frustrations of serving in the post.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Legislation for establishment of an "independent" agency to represent the interests of consumers before Federal courts and regulatory bodies and to test and evaluate consumer products was unanimously approved today by a House subcommittee.

Representative Richard Max McCarthy, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator, said yesterday that he was preparing legislation that would ease the effects of inflation on the unemployed and underemployed.
LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) The first major commodity exchange in the Western United States will open for trading by October, one of its founders said today.

DETROIT, June 11 (AP) Scheduled United States automobile production surged to a yearly peak of 185,461 this week, nearly even with the output of 185,660 for the comparable week last year. The previous weekly high for 1970 was 183,353.

Communist forces reportedly also opened a new attack on Siemreap, a provincial capital only four miles from the edge of the huge temple complex.
British Government bonds fell sharply on the London Stock Exchange yesterday. A spate of bearish news also brought a further decline in share prices.

Four major works by Martha Graham that have not been seen here for about 20 years, will be revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company in an engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Oct. 2 through Oct. 8.

The abrupt dismissal of Dr. James E. Allen Jr. from the key post of United States Commissioner of Education is a reflection not on his leadership capacity but on disorderly governing procedures of this Administration.

The Goodyear Tire Rubber Company, the nation's largest tire producer, which just concluded a costly labor contract, announced yesterday that it will increase tire prices by 5 to 6 per cent beginning Monday.

An experimental program in the handling of both civil and criminal litigation in Manhattan under which judges in State Supreme Court will be assigned to handle cases "from initiation to judgment" was announced yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, June 11 Cuba announced today that sugar production from the current harvest had reached a record total of 8.8 million metric tons. The previous high was a 7.9-million-ton crop in 1952.

Dr. John D. Angelides, an obstetrician and gynecologist in New York and Nassau Country for many years, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He lived at 186-21 Chelsea Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens, and was 53 years old.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 11 Miss Deborah Sue Cheney and Frederick Daniel Lazar, both of whom were graduated Monday from Cornell University, will be married July 11 in the First Presbyterian Church here.

Arthur J. Goldberg, calling for sweeping legislative reform, accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of a "cynical" abuse of executive power that he said had robbed the Legislature of its independence and creativity.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The securities industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission are racing against a Congressional deadline in an attempt to agree on an insurance system to protect investors from losses when brokerage firms go bankrupt. Persons close to the negotiations said today the odds were 50-50 that an agreement would be reached by Monday, when hearings on the issue begin in a House Commerce subcommittee.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 11 No one around Stanley Dancer's barn at Roosevelt Raceway today was able or willing to talk about which drivers would handle the Dancer Stable entry in Saturday night's $111,514.24 Dexter Cup Trot. Dancer will make the decision by 11 o'clock tomorrow morning, but until then the identities of the men who will be in the sulkies behind Nevele Rascal and Gallant Prince remain mysteries.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 The allied intervention in Cambodia has resulted in a new wave of protests by South Vietnamese against the Saigon Government.

On the small gray movie screen, Mac Foster was pummeling Cleveland Williams in a slow-motion barrage of punches. Watching the film in the Felt Forum yesterday, Foster and Jerry Quarry, opponents in next Wednesday's 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden, sat in silence.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Dr. James E. Allen Jr., who was forced to resign yesterday as the Government's chief education official, declared today that the partisan constraints placed on him by the Nixon Administration had made it impossible for him to administer the Federal education bureaucracy properly.

SYRACUSE, June 11 Varsity eights from Pennsylvania, Washington and Cornell qualified for Saturday's finals on Onondaga Lake today at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta. UTICA, N.Y., June 12 Theodore C. Sorensen wore a suit with a small hole in the seat of the trousers to this upstate city today, where he was promised support by the Oneida County Democratic organization and Mayor Dominick Assaro.

ROCHESTER, June 12 Howard J. Samuels, campaigning in Buffalo and Rochester, warned upstate voters today that an "all-Manhattan" Democratic ticket headed by Arthur J. Goldberg, his rival for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, would have no chance of defeating Governor Rockefeller.

Gaspare DiGregorio, a small garment manufacturer who was catapulted to national notoriety in 1965 as the reputed successor to Joseph (Joe Bananas) Bonanno as boss of a farflung Mafia empire, has died in the obscurity to which he retired four years ago.

The stock market took another pounding yesterday before an afternoon rally clipped its losses. The Dow-Jones industrial average, down more than 6 points at 1:30 P.M., finished at 684.21 with a decline of only 0.21 of a point.

Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin announced yesterday the fifth arrest in the continuing inquiry into the Satellite Program, which was financed by the Human Resources Administration's Youth Service Agency.
Miss Carol Anne Penelope Nickels and Robert Joseph Smith were married here yesterday morning by Dr. Richard Gambino, a leader of the New York Society for Ethical Cultural, at the society.

The Museum of American Folk Art, a small and young museum that is winning a growing following, has announced plans for expansion, a new home and a $4-million fund drive to underwrite its future.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Union today to provide equal access to their Telpak rates for all private-line customers without regard to the nature of their business.

The State Attorney General's office has charged that a decision by Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley awarding damages to a prisoner for unconstitutional solitary confinement created so much unrest at Wallkill State Prison that the warden felt the Commissioner of Corrections might be "wholly justified" shutting it down.
TOKYO, June 12 (Reuters) Japan had a deficit of $70million in its balance of international payments in May, the Finance Ministry announced today.

Mrs. Diana Hutchins Rockwell of New York, widow of James Rockwell of St. David's, Pa., was married here yesterday to Manuel R. Angulo, a partner in the law firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt Mosle here. Supreme Court Justice Matthew M. Levy performed the ceremony in his chambers.
John J. Scanlan, president of the New York Mercantile Exchange, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 60 years old and lived at 447 100th Street, Brooklyn.

The School of American Ballet gave a couple of performances on Thursday afternoon at the New York State Theater for those admirably friendly Friends of City Center. Hendrik S. Houthakker, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said here yesterday that the controversial two-price system for copper one level for American supplies and another for foreign production probably would "disappear within the next few years, and perhaps much sooner."
Prices on the London stock market closed mixed yesterday after an early decline.

Carmine Lombardozzi, an alleged Mafia lieutenant, was sentenced yesterday to two years in prison by a Federal Court judge in Brooklyn on a charge of conspiring to cash $50,000 in stolen brokerage checks.

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 12 Mary K., a war widow with three young children, lives in a bush village just east of Owerri, the last capital of the land that was Biafra.

Technicolor, Inc., the colorfilm processor, reached at least a partial understanding yesterday with Harry Saltzman, one of its largest stockholders, who has been trying to take control of the company in a proxy fight.

The Monsanto Company announced yesterday that it had raised the price of all grades of saccharin by 30 cents a pound.

DETROIT, June 12 A move by Detroit's school board to mix more white and black students in the schools here has exploded into a recall campaign against board members and a drive in the State Legislature to block the integration effort.

SYRACUSE, June 12 One of the points of interest at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's regatta finals tomorrow will be Pacific Lutheran's chances of beating Harvard again in the varsity four-oared event. Pacific who?
