A consortium of 33 major American banks announced yesterday that it had agreed to extend for a period of up to six years $250-million in loans owed by the Central Bank of the Philippines, most of which were originally scheduled to come due this year.

At first, it comes as a shock to discover that Jay Martin's new book is the first biography of Nathanael West ever written. Nearly 30 years have passed since the Sunday afternoon in December of 1940, when West died with his wife (the former Eileen McKenney and the model for "My Sister Eileen") in an automobile accident.
LANGHORNE, Pa., June 14 (UPI) Bobby Unser, speeding past his brother Al in the final moments, won his second consecutive 150-mile national championship race today at the Langhorne Speedway.

BUFFALO, June 14 The closing hours of the 13th annual Allentown Arts Festival in downtown Buffalo tonight were disrupted by clashes between rock-throwing festivalgoers and police who retailiated with tear gas.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 14 (AP) Leftist students shouted "Murderer!" today and a young woman tried to slap the president of the University of Puerto Rico, but the campus police maintained control at the university's graduation exercises.
BOSTON, June 14 Two students of public opinion have concluded that the young and the college-educated have not opposed the war in Vietnam as much as popularly supposed.

OMAHA, June 14 (AP) Don Powers, an Iowa State freshman southpaw from Brampton, Ontario, fired a six-hitter today for a 7-1 victory over Arizona. The loss eliminated the Wildcats from the College World Series.

Carl and Ruby Obert of the New York Athletic Club, the top-seeded team, gained the semifinal round of the National Amateur Athletic Union's onewall handball championship yesterday by defeating Andy Grosz and Mark Levine of Union Temple, 21-15, 21-17, at the Municipa1 Courts, Coney Island.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (UPI) Dr. Douglas A. Fessenden, retired head of the physical education department at San Francisco State University and former University of Montana football coach, died Thursday at the age of 69.

Once again a committee of distinguished citizens has looked into the financing of political campaigns in this country and found the picture deplorable. A task force of the Twentieth Century Fund, concentrating wholly on Congressional campaigning, differs little from other recent investigating bodies, though its personnel represents a wider political spectrum than is usually the case-Republican and Democrat, black and white, business and labor, experience and youth.

NEWARK, June 14 Every participant in the mayoral campaign, including the two candidates, agrees that the quality of life here will continue to reflect all aspects of urban misery no matter who wins on Tuesday.

CAIRO, June 14 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic repeated today that he "firmly rejected" reinstatement of the 1967 ceasefire agreement with Israel until Israeli troops withdrew from all occupied Arab Lands.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 14 (AP) The two-week-old Government of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, in a sharp swing away from the West, announced today, that it would recognize North Vietnam, North Korea, East Germany and the Vietcong's provisional revolutionary government of South Vietnam.
Frederic Abilgaard Fenger, a marine designer and author, died Friday in Norwell, Mass. He was 88 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 14 In a couple of weeks the Federal Government will close the books on fiscal 1970 with a deficit of $1.5-billion. But further deficits are in prospect for the following two years, and they may be much higher. The Administration says that the deficit in fiscal 1971 will be only $1.3-billion. Its estimate assumes that Congress will ...
STOCKHOLM, June 14 The bridge teams representing five countries were gathering in the Hotel Foresta here today in preparation for the 17th contest for the Bermuda Bowl beginning tomorrow.

William Turner, the head of two construction concerns here that specialized in government buildings, died at Mount Sinal Hospital Thursday of a heart attack. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.
Jean-Leon Destiny and his Afro-Haitian Dance Company offered a well-balanced professional ethnic dance program Saturday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall.

Construction is scheduled to begin soon on three new city Mitchell-Lama rental developments involving more than 1,000 middle-income apartments and a total investment of $28-million, the Housing and Development Administration announced today.

Dr. Carl Eis, assistant professor of economics at Richmond College of the City University of New York, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home, 19 Bascom Place, Willowbrook, Staten Island. He was 31 years old.

CHELTENHAM, Pa., June 14 Mrs. Karen Lynn Grossman and Oscar Brand, the balladeer, composer and motion picture documentary scriptwriter, were married here this noon by Rabbi David Wice at the Ashbourne Country Club.
Robert Allerton Parker, the author of several biographical books, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 1040 Park Avenue. He was 81 years old.

A large group of executives, editor sand authors has appealed to the book publishing industry across the country to devote next Wednesday to "positive action for peace" by allowing employes to hold assemblies or lobby for political candidates opposed to the Indochina war.
MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, June 14 (AP) The last and deciding match of the Davis Cup tennis series between Yugoslavia and Rumania was adjourned today because of darkness.
Early each June of the last 18 years, cadet hats have been sailed into the air at the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Kings Point, L.I., as the traditional end of commencement exercises.
LONDON, June 14 (UPI) An oil tanker safety guide for the world's seafarers has been issued by the International Chamber of Shipping.
DUNGIVEN, Northern Ireland, June 14 (AP) Roman Catholic youths hurled stones and bottles at policemen protecting a parade of 2,000 Protestants through this predominantly Catholic town today.
BETHPAGE, L. I, June 14 The Pitchfork Polo team of Greenwich, Conn., defeated Bethpage, 7-3, today at Bethpage State Park for the Rothmann Tournament Championship.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I. June 14 In St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon. Miss Margaret Susan Custer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merton Davis Custer, was married to Second Lieut. Jay Wallace Kaine, U.S.A. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. John Byrne.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The Labor Department said today that the nation's sharp rise in unemployment this year had been felt most by skilled white workers in the aircraft, aerospace, weapons and automobile industries in the Middle West and on the West Coast.
Corporate bond yields, which rose to record levels last week, are headed even higher.

Unseeded Sandy Mayer of Woodmere, L. L, upset secondseeded Steve Ross of Brooklyn, 6-3, 6-2, 6-0, to win the New York State men's tennis title at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens, yesterday. It was the third tournament victory for the 18-year-old Mayer this season.

TEL AVIV, June 14 (Reuters) Israeli commandos attacked an Arab guerrilla base inside Jordan today as Israeli jets began their third week of almost round-the-clock bombardment of the Egyptian front line.

The Greek-Americans routed the German-Hungarians, 4-1, yesterday before 1,200 fans at Metropolitan Oval, Queens in the second game of the German-American Soccer League playoffs, and captured the league title for the third year in a row. The first game had ended in a 2-2 deadlock.
Edward T. Fagan, a former New York Telephone Company official, died yesterday. He was 79 years old and lived at 974 East 26th , Brooklyn.

PRINCETON, June 14 Some Princetonians feel that the summer vacation will prove a particular blessing this year in restoring tidiness to that segment of Nassau Street that separates town and gown sometimes referred to as the "D.M.Z." Frequently during the 1969-70 academic year the campus.

Miss Myra Janice Goldenberg, daughter of Louis Goldenberg, president of Wildenstein Co., and Mrs. Goldenberg of Larchmont, N.Y., was married here yesterday to David Stephen Green, son of Mr, and Mrs. Joseph Green of Merrick, L.I. His father is vice president of RBS Fabrics, Ltd. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Irving Koslowe at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

Adam Walinsky, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Attorney General, charged yesterday that present state procedures for handling consumer fraud cases encouraged these practices rather than acting as a deterrent.
Don't pity the poor working girl who doesn't have $30,000 for a sable coat. She can wrap herself into a $250 rabbit skin and be every bit as warm when the blizzards come.

LOS ANGELES, June 14 On June 24, President Nixon and Congressional leaders will be handed copies of a bulky 450page document proposing answers to a question that has been bothering much of the country for generations: What should be done with the onethird of the nation's land that is still Federally owned?

BLACK LAKE, Mich., June 13 Deep in Michigan's northern woods, where the bullfrogs' croaks are so loud they make the city folk jump, the United Automobile Workers has turned a millionaire's playground into a union resort.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 14 On a two-run homer by 12-year-old Yang Fu-hsing in the last inning, the Seven Tigers recently won the right to represent Taiwan in its first defense of a world athletic championship.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 14 Edward C. Baumert 3d sailed Ariette to a 20-second Shields Class victory after 10 miles on Long Island Sound today when a fleet of 132, largest of the Yacht Racing Association championship season, raced off Larchmont Yacht Club.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 14 With the current school year drawn to a close, the Nixon Administration has shown great concern in recent days about what may occur during the next one.

WASHINGTON, June 14 The widely held notion that the recent reorganization of the Executive Office of the President will demoralize the Cabinet and create an all-powerful White House was challenged today by Murray Comarow, the architect of the reshuffle.

LONDON, June 14 The Esalen encounter group from the United States, which came here three weeks ago worried that it would get an "up-tight reception," has discovered that "it's really merrie Olde England" after all.

Hundreds of youths smashed store windows and set rubbish fires over an 11-block area of predominantly Puerto Rican East Harlem last night after an outdoor rally called to protest the arrest of a Young Lords leader.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner yesterday endorsed "wholeheartedly and unequivocally" the candidacy of Vincent A. Marchiselli, who is seeking the Democratic nomination in the 86th State Assembly District in the northeast Bronx.
LOS ANGELES, June 14 (AP) Bill Sudakis smacked a tworun pinch homer with two out in the ninth inning today, giving the Los Angeles Dodgers a 5-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
The 3,000 members of the city's auxiliary police force turned Flushing Meadow Park in Queens into a sea of blue yesterday at Police Volunteer Day.
Opposition to the Nixon Administration's proposal to authorize detention before trial of persons ruled "dangerous" has' been voted by the National Council on Crime and Delinquency.
CONCORD, Mass., June 14 Salgray's Double Talk, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hamilburg's brindle boxer, was named best in show today at the 56th annual Middlesex County Kennel Club event.

ROCHESTER, June 14 Arthur J. Goldberg and Howard J. Samuels met in their first two-man television debate here tonight. Within an hour the candidates for the Governor were angry enough to keep arguing even after the cameras were turned off.

Doing their part to keep alive idle chater about an all-New York World Series, the Mets, who used to be the party of the second part in such wishful joking, completed a three-game sweep of the Atlanta Braves with a 7-5 decision at Shea Stadium yesterday.
MONTEREY, Calif., June 14 (UPI) Ron Grable finished more than 40 seconds ahead of his nearest rival in winning the $25,000 Continental championship series race for Formula A sports cars today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 14 (AP) Jim Holt tripled to spark a four-run fourth inning and capped another four-run flurry in the eighth with a homer today as the Minnesota Twins scored a 10-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
BALTIMORE, June 14 (UPI) Dave May's two-run homer with two out in the 10th inning today gave the Baltimore Orioles a 4-2 victory over the Oakland Athletics.
PASADENA, Calif., June 14 (AP) Astronomers said today that they had used radio telescopes for the first time in a successful test of Albert Einstein's 55-year-old general relativity theory.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that 72 per cent of all eligible stock deliveries in May were processed by computers.
NEWARK, June 14 Both the incumbent, Hugh J. Addonizio, and Kenneth A. Gibson, his Negro opponent, put in a hard day today in the final, bitter campaigning for the mayoral election Tuesday.
BONN, June 14 The Social Democratic - Free Democratic coalition led by Chancellor Willy Brandt was dealt a setback today by West Germans voting for parliaments in three states.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 5 Tiny, tightly organized bands of radical right-wing and left-wing students, warring as much with each other as with the Government, are reducing higher education in Turkey to a shambles and raising the risk of new military intervention in politics.

BUENOS AIRES, June 14 Until Saturday, when he was named President of Argentina, Brig. Gen. Roberto Marcelo Levingston was nearly as unknown to most members of the armed forces as he was to the public.

MEADOW LAKE, Saskatchewan, June 6 Here in the northwestern corner of the settled part of Saskatchewan, a sawmill and a pulp mill are coming along. They will create 1,400 jobs, a veritable superboom for a town of barely 4,000 population.

KANSAS CITY, June 14 After spotting the Kansas City Royals a 2-0 lead in the first inning, the streaking New York Yankees settled down to work at Municipal Stadium today and pulled out a 3-2 victory that kept all their nice numbers alive.

MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., June 14 Miss Dianne J. Bedford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Forrest Bedford, was married at the Community Church (Congregational) here today to William T. Marsden, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Marsden. The Rev. Dr. Loral W. Pancake performed the ceremony.
Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams has urged a Queens grand jury to expand its investigation into the May 20 subway collision to include the entire subway system.
WASHINGTON, June 14 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-call votes in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

While the proposals of the Twentieth Century Fund are given small probability of Congressional approval in an election year, especially since they do not favor incumbents, headway on the television front is distinctly possible.
MIAMI, June 14 Gonzalo Roig, a composer of operettas, and popular songs, died in Havana last night, the Havana radio said this morning. He was 80 years old.

MOSCOW, June 14 The Soviet Union is experiencing a boom in natural gas and some Western experts predict that incoming decades Moscow may turn out to be the major source of this cheap, efficient, nonpolluting fuel in Europe and Asia.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 14 Miss Sonna Chalek was married at home here today to Howard Marc Schupak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schupak of Yonkers, by Rabbi Arnold Kaiman.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 The American Diabetes Association said today it saw no need to abandon accepted methods of treating diabetes despite a report from a massive study that has cast doubt on the value of oral drugs in controlling effects of the disease.

Michael Crichton spent four years at Harvard Medical School, and what does he have to show for it? Seven novels, a movie, several more manuscripts and screenplays and a fast-paced, provocative book of non-fiction on the state of the American hospital, which was published last week.
The city is investigating the possibility that some winners in the recent local school board elections may be ineligible to serve because they hold Civil Service jobs.
Le MANS, France, June 14 Porsche finally won Le Mans today and 300,000 persons cheered at the end of a very strange 24 hours.
LONDON, June 14 The state of the British economy has become the most debated issue in the election campaign.
ALBANY, June 14 Governor Rockefeller said today the State Department of Health was planning a program to detect lead poisoning in children and to remove potential sources of the poisoning.

Can the former publishing director of Harper's Bazaar, House Beautiful and Town Country find self-expression, even happiness, running a famous Fifth Avenue store? He can, responds William M. Fine, after a year as president of Bonwit Teller, and he can find a few surprises, too.
The top creative man at Rumrill-Hoyt, Eugene F. Novak, has been moved into the presidency of the agency. That means that Donald B. Miller has moved up to chairman but remains chief executive.

The heralded pole-vault duel between John Fennel, the world record-holder, and Dick Railsback of the Los Angeles Striders at the Sacramento, Calif., invitation track and field meet Saturday night fell short of expectations. Neither won the event nor were they among the leaders.
DETROIT, June 14 (UPI) Willie Horton smashed two homers and Norm Cash added a two-run clout today as the Detroit Tigers downed the California Angels, 8-4.

A funeral service for Alexander Kerensky, who led Russia in the brief interval between Czarism and Communism in 1917, was held late yesterday afternoon at Frank E. Campbell's Madison Avenue and 81st Street.
KINGSTON, N.Y., June 14 Maria Lo Pinto, a writer of Italian cook books and a lawyer, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at her country home here. She was 70 years old.
LAGOS, Nigeria Yakubu Gowon is one army general who says it with conviction: he longs for the day when he can turn over political power to a civilian government.

He had never bought a chair or devised a color scheme. Yet last year, Richard P. Hunt did what few decorators would dare. He redesigned and furnished 31 apartments at 220 West 98th Street in less than four months--a deadline most professionals would consider tight for completing even one four-room flat.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 14 An Arab commando spokesman said today that the commandos had executed two Arabs who were implicated in the rape of two American women during last week's disorders here.
MOSCOW, June 14 The twoman Soyuz 9 spaceship logged 5 million miles in earth orbit today and closed in on the space endurance record now held by the United States.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 14 The Philadelphia First team won two games today to finish undefeated with a 4-0 record in the national tournament of the United States Women's Lacrosse Association at Swarthmore College.
Eli B. Enzer, a former correspondent for United Press International, died Saturday at University Hospital of a brain tumor. He was 31 years old, and lived at 100 West 94th Street.
Bella Abzug, riding atop a sound truck, invaded the stronghold of Representative Leonard Farbstein on the Lower East Side yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 Cambodian and South Vietnamese troops fought under cover of artillery barrages and fighter-bomber attacks today to regain control of the Cambodian city of Kompong Speu and keep open a vital link to the sea.

The Sicilian Defense between A. Kurajica and Bobby Fischer during the recent Zagreb, Yugoslavia, International, was a bizarre struggle. Fischer, eight times the United States chess champion, went on to win the Zagreb event 2 points ahead of the 18-man field.
PITTSBURGH, June 14 Steel producers see a change taking place in their market mix.

Every once in a while it happens: the presentation of a film without interruptions on the home screen. On Saturday evening, Bounty paper towels had a modest word to say at the opening of Sir Laurence Olivier's 1948 film version of "Hamlet." Then, from shortly after 9 p.m. to about 11.40 p.m., there was only the Bard and not a blurb to be heard on WOR-TV (Channel 9).

The Nixon Administration has added some imaginative new features to its plan for reforming the nation's chaotic welfare system. The revisions, put forward to meet objections raised by the Senate Finance Committee, are an extension of the constructive teamwork between the White House and Capitol Hill that has been one of the most welcome aspects of this effort to make over welfare.
Amid emotional debates about soak the rich and about constitutionality, Congress decided to do little about the tax-exempt status of municipal bonds.
Last night, with a performance of Balanchine's "A Midsummer Night's Dream," the curtailed 50th season of New York City Ballet came to an end at the New York State Theater.

Two years ago, when Adele Williams, a former stylist for Gumbinner-North Advertising Agency, opened Boutique de Cuisine at 200 East 61st Street, its limited quarters suited her modest aspirations. Before long, it was obvious that she had underestimated her own potential.

NEW HAVEN, June 14 Federal Judge A. Leon Higginbotham Jr. has been elected a trustee of Yale University, the first black person to be chosen for the institution's governing board since Yale was founded in 1701.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) Hugh Royer, a perennial alsoran who had never come close to winning a professional golf tournament, overtook Bobby Nichols today and won the Western open by a stroke with a 273 total.
LONDON, June 14 Edward Heath, the leader of the Conservative party responded today to Enoch Powell's charge that an enemy within was attacking Britain.

LIMA, Peru, June 14 The flow of foreign aid arriving here in the wake of the disastrous earthquake two weeks ago has caused two pronounced political shifts. One is the sudden improvement in United States-Peruvian relations and the other is the new respect that Cuba has earned in the eyes of many people here.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 Taking the lead on the second leg of the four-legged course that circled the island in a clockwise direction, Herbert F. Schwartz won the Ensign Class event with Wenden on Long Island Sound today in the annual Captains Island regatta of the Greenwich Cove Racing Association.
BOWMANVILLE, Ontario, June 14 Dan Gurney, the new member of the McLaren racing team, picked up where the team left off last year by winning the opening Can-Am race of the 1970 season today.
Several hundred Americans of Lithuanian origin staged a commemoration and protest yesterday of Russian persecution of citizens of Baltic states over the last 30 years.
The Federal Government has started legal action against a ship radio officers' union in an effort to set aside an election of officers.
PEKING, June 14 (Agence France-Presse) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, head of the Cambodian government in exile, left here today by special train for North Korea on an official visit.
GENEVA, June 14 Tough days are ahead for the mutual fund industry in Europe as it faces both stricter national regulation and a declining sales trend.
The city Traffic Department is asking motorists to be on the lookout this morning for new directional signs guiding them from the Bruckner Circle in the Bronx to the Throgs Neck Bridge.

SAN JUAN, P. R., June 14 (AP) The United States Navy has announced a major easing of regulations for boats entering or leaving waters around Culebra Island, the controversial Navy target island off eastern Puerto Rico.

Robert J. Mangum, the New York State Commissioner of Human Rights, announced yesterday that, in a case without precedent in the 25-year history of his agency, the house of a Rochester couple would be auctioned off to collect $300 in damages stemming from a housing discrimination case.
OTTAWA, June 14 A report on marijuana has divided Canada's Cabinet.
SAG HARBOR, L. I, June 14 Whaleboats surged through Shelter Island Sound and bands marched along Main Street here this weekend as the summer season opened with the eighth annual Old Whalers Festival.

MEXICO CITY, June 14 The growing problem of smog, which is recognized as a threat to health and tourism, has generated the first official steps toward remedial action in this metropolitan area of more than 7 million people.

ATLANTA, June 14 A venture in black capitalism by two civil rights leaders who started out with a large inventory of idealism but a short supply of business experience has ended in rancor, distrust and a growing concern about the antiwhite feeling that has emerged among Southern blacks.

BIRMINGHAM, England Enoch Powell was talking about "the exploitation of what is called race" when a frail young woman in the back of the hall cried out, "By whom?" Half a dozen stewards pushed through the seats and roughly grabbed her. A well-dressed man stood up to try to protect her; without a word the stewards manhandled him and dragged him out the door. The crowd cheered.
CALGARY, Alberta A growing feeling of alienation from Ottawa and the whole eastern Establishment, coupled with economic uncertainty, have brought discontent to the Canadian prairies.
OWENSBORO, Ky., June 14 (AP) Bill Muncey piloted his Myr's Sheet Metal to first place in the second annual Kentucky Governor's Cup Regatta today on the Ohio River.

SUTTON, Mass., June 14 UPI) Shirley Englehorn, 2 onestroke loser to Kathy Whitworth for the 1967 title, forced an 18-hole playoff by tying Miss Whitworth today on the 72d hole of the 1970 Ladies Professional Golf Association championship. The playoff will be held tomorrow morning.

GENEVA, June 14 Sir Eric Wyndham White has confirmed his new role of strong man in the embattled Investors Overseas Services financial empire in a boardroom showdown with the I.O.S. founder, Bernard Cornfeld.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (UPI) Jim McGlothlin scattered six hits and drove in the Reds' first two runs with a single today as Cincinnati hammered out 18 hits for a 10-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Charles T. Stewart, vice president for public affairs for the National Assoication of Real Estate Boards, died Friday at the age of 59.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 (UPI) About 100 elderly Buddhist women and youths carrying signs reading "Americans go home" joined a funeral procession today for a 74-year-old monk who immolated himself in the cause of peace. The demonstration was peaceful.

PARIS, June 14 The luck of the Irish followed Seamus McGrath as he confounded the racing experts again today when his filly, Sweet Mimosa, a 23-1 shot, won the $262,000 Prix de Diane the French Oaks at 15-16 miles.
Television, an ever-growing factor in elections, has become an issue in the primary contest for the Democratic senatorial nomination.
VIAREGGIO, Italy, June 14 (UPI) America's 1,600-meter relay team set a meet record today in winning the final at the 24th Conseil International du Sport Militarie track and field championships.
Black policemen took a step toward narrowing the generation gap yesterday by honoring black students at a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON In the second week of our heat wave, with the intrusive sun buttering London like a toasted muffin, the British are in a mood of euphoric Philistine exhaustion, enjoying a prolonged Mediterranean siesta. Theaters and movie houses are empty.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 14, ="When Christ came the first time, God called on John the Baptist to prepare the way," said Sam Young. "This time he's raised up our denomination."

LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 14 St. Michael's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Mariana (Mimi) Van Rensselaer Griswold, a 1970 graduate of Connecticut College, to Lewis Frazer Geer, a 1970 graduate of Yale.

NEWPORT, R. I, June 14 The 175-mile yacht race that began yesterday off Oyster Bay, L. I, was in a state of flux tonight with nothing established officially except that the converted 12-Meter sloop American Eagle was the first yacht to finish.
MEXICO CITY, June 14 (UPI) West Germany and Uruguay gained overtime victories and Brazil and Italy won in regulation time today to advance to the semifinals in the World Cup soccer championships.

BUENOS AIRES, June 15 (UPI) The armed forces commanders met today with Brig. Gen. Roberto Marcelo Levingston, the man they chose to be Argentina's next President, to form a Cabinet and lay down down the ground rules for the new Government.

PARIS, June 15 Against a background of increasing anxiety in Europe over American inflation and the position of the dollar, President Nixon's chief economic adviser offered scattered bits of evidence today of progress on the American prices front.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 15 (UPI) Cambodian military spokesmen said today that the North Vietnamese had set up a command post at the Temple of Lolei outside the Angkor complex of renowned temple ruins. The Vietnamese Communists were reported to have seized control of the area a few days ago.

A crowd of 20,819, the largest wrestling turnout in the old and new Madison Square Gardens, saw the favorite, Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, succumb to Crusher Verdu of Bilboa, Spain, last night.
PARIS, June 15 The French Government has resumed its intervention in the preparation of news broadcasts, it was disclosed today following the resignation of a leading television journalist.
A national antiwar coalition of college educators announced yesterday the endorsement of 18 candidates for Congress and the initial contribution of $50,000 to their primary campaigns.

MEMPHIS, June 15 (AP) Liberals gained a narrow victory yesterday with the election of William A. Benfield Jr. as Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S. (Southern), which has nearly one million members.

NEWARK, June 15 If Kenneth Allen Gibson is elected Mayor of Newark tomorrow, he will be the third black man in recent times to win that office in a large American city. His victory, if it comes, would not surprise him at all.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Pentagon made public today a study by the Rand Corporation speculating on the possible effects of a Vietcong takeover in South Vietnam. The study found that reprisal killings could number at least 100,000 and said this figure could easily he higher.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to consider realignment of the New York City Board of Estimate along one-man, one-vote lines.
LOS ANGELES, June 15 The selection of a jury in the trial of Charles M. Manson and three women accused of killing seven persons last year will start tomorrow here in the Hall of Justice.
TEL AVIV, June 15 (Reuters) Israeli aircraft continued their concentrated bombing of Egyptian targets along the Suez Canal today, hitting fortified infantry positions, bunkers and gun emplacements.

Spokesmen for an English rock group, Ginger Baker's Air Force, said yesterday that the nine-man band had canceled its eight-week tour of the United Statese partly out of sympathy with student demonstrators in this country.
LIMA, June 15 The revolutionary military government became the second largest commercial banker here today by taking over Banco Popular del Peru. In doing so, the state ...
STOCKHOLM, June 15 The Dallas Aces began well here tonight in their attempt to win the world team title for the United States for the first time since 1954.

The capital gap between developed and underdeveloped nations remains vast and is in danger of widening in the new decade. This is the conclusion drawn by business leaders in 51 countries who were surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board.

A return "match" between Stephen Clark's Bailar and Marion Frankel's Baitman took place in the feature event at Belmont Park yesterday, with the former gaining the victory. Although the race, a turf event of seven-eighths of a mile, had 10 starters, the expectation among the 27,852 fans was that this pair would provide the principal contention.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The presidents of the nation's two leading medical association's called today for a replacement of Medicaid with a federally subsidized health insurance program.

ALBANY, June 15 Arthur J. Goldberg, employing what some staff members describe as "our new strategy," said today his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, is running a campaign that lacks a basic "sense of justice."
PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) Tim McCarver, one of two catchers for the Philadelphia Phillies injured May 2 against the San Francisco Giants, had the cast removed from his broken right hand today.

NEPTUNE, N.J., June 15 Edward Petry, founder and former president of Edward Petry Co., Inc., a New York-based radio and television station representative, died in a hospital here Friday. He was 73 years old and lived in Spring Lake.
The Board of Estimate and the City Council approved yesterday a record $7.7-billion expense budget $82-million less than the 1970-71 "austerity" budget proposed by the Mayor last month.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 15 (Reuters) A spokesman for the Palestine Red Crescent organization here said tonight that Dr. Paul Shraum, one of the Americans seized as a hostage by Palestinian commandos last week, would be released tomorrow.

The Rev. Gerardus Beekman, retired rector of St. Paul's American Church in Rome (Episcopal), and Mrs. Beekman of Cap d'Antibes, France, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sabina Catherine Beekman, to Malcolm Stevenson Forbes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Forbes of Far Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for next year.

Abraham Ber Tabachnik, a writer, literary critic and editor for the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, a wire service for the Yiddish, Hebrew and AngloJewish press, died Saturday at Bellevue Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 68 years old and lived at 266 East Broadway.
Prof. William L. Finkel, former chairman of the speech department of City College, died of a heart attack yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 473 West End Avenue.

More than a year ago. President Calvin H. Plimpton of Amherst College warned President Nixon that, while there is no magic formula for campus peace, there is no hope for a moderate consensus so long as many students feel that "the nation has no adequate plans for meeting the crises of our society."

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Faulty directions from a traffic controller, working under conditions of stress, caused a Puerto Rico airliner crash last year in which all 19 occupants were killed, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

Arthur D. Lerner, president of the Concord Insurance Company of Newark, which was declared insolvent last week, said yesterday that "active negotiations" were under way to abtain new capital or to sell the company. Concord sells mostly auto coverage to substandard risks in New Jersey.

MUNICH, West Germany, June 15 Vandals desecrated Torah scrolls and other religious objects in a synagogue here last night in the rear of a Jewish old people's home that was burned down by arsonists in February.
Danny Kaye is returning to the Broadway stage in the fall as star of a Richard Rodgers musical, "Two by Two," based on Clifford Odets's play, "The Flowering Peach."

WASHINGTON, June 15 Black students throughout the South are likely to force confrontations this fall over what they see as the fraudulent desegregation of their schools, Julian Bond, young black Georgia legislator, predicted today.
ARLINGTON, Va., June 15 (AP) Col, Charles S. Lawrence, U.S.A. retired, a survivor of the Bataan death march, died at his home in Romney, W. Va., Friday. He was 78 years old.
State Supreme Court Justice George Starke refused yesterday to bar a police departmental trial of a detective charged with selling confidential information to private agencies.

The office of the Manhattan District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan, got 28 summer helpers yesterday, each of them a second-year law student. And if tradition is repeated, at least six or seven of them will end up as assistant district attorneys following their graduation a year from now.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Army would no longer have to sell enlisted men 16 ounces of tobacco a month or buy horses and mules on the open market under a bill passed by the House today.

Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the United States Supreme Court refused to intervene in the Connecticut prosecution of eight Black Panthers charged with murder and kidnapping yesterday, the eve of a trial for one of the defendants.

KENT Ohio, June 15 (UPI) A Portage County court dismissed today an injunction that had closed Kent State University following the shooting deaths of four students by National Guard troops last month.

Exchange. The President sent to Congress the annual report on the International Educational and Cultural Exchange Program for the fiscal year 1969, as required by the Mutual Educational and Cultural Exchange Act of 1961.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 For the second time in three days, there was a decidedly anti-American flavor to the demonstrations staged today by students protesting against the Thieu Government.

GREENVILLE, N.C., June 15 Miss Judith Rae Webb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fred Webb Jr., plans to be married on Aug. 29 to Jean Edmond Lanier, a French graduate student at Cornell she met aboard the liner France three years ago.

TOKYO, June 15--The first of two weekends of protests against the United States-Japanese security treaty ended tonight after a number of tense moments but with the level of violence far below that of last year.

DENVER, June 15 George Romney tried today to persuade the nation's mayors that the Nixon Administration had committed itself to a course of "reordering national priorities" just as the mayors had been demanding.

JERUSALEM, June 15 A political crisis that had threatened to drive the National Religious party out of the governing coalition was apparently averted today when an American-born woman gave up her legal battle to have her conversion to the Jewish faith by a Reform rabbi declared legal.

LONDON, June 15 With the Wimbledon tournament only a week away, the American No. 1, Stan Smith, had a tremendous tussle with a part-time player, Bobby Wilson, before squeaking out an 8-6, 9-7 victory in the first round of the London grasscourt championships at the Queen's Club today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 15 Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J., who heads the draw, led the seeded players into the third round of the Eastern women's clay-court tennis championship today at the Orienta Beach Club.

PARIS, June 15 (Reuters) Traffic jams built up in and around Paris this morning as commuters struggled to reach work with the city's public transportation system almost completely shut down by a 24-hour strike.

The vanishing art of quality book publishing won honors yesterday from commercial publishers and a bookstore here as a counterpoint to fast, mass marketing operations that are becoming ever more prevalent in the industry.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15 A three judge Federal court ruled here today that Rhode Island's Salary Supplement Act of 1969, under which the state would have contributed up to 15 per cent to the pay of lay teachers of secular subjects in parochial schools, was unconstitutional.

ROME, June 15 At 2 A.M. today, young couples were still dancing in the Piazza Navona and packs of cars, their horns continually honking, were racing down the narrow Corso in a spontaneous outbreak of joy such as this city has not witnessed for many years.
BALTIMORE, June 15 (AP) A bases-loaded double by Roberto Pena capped a six-run Milwaukee rally in the eighth inning tonight as the Brewers downed the slumping Baltimore Orioles, 9-6.
A growing number of engines needing modification has slowed considerably the expansion of Boeing 747 service, particularly on Pan American World Airways, the heaviest 747 user.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans this fall to order a small fleet of experimental commuter rail cars that will make their own electricity with a jet engine.

The trend of automobile sales, while still lagging behind the pace set in 1969, has shown a distinct improvement in recent weeks, data compiled yesterday showed. A Federal appeals court has upheld a controversial clause in the current New York Shipping Association-International Longshoremen's Association labor agreement.

CHASKA, Minn., June 15 (UPI) The Hazeltine National Golf Club, site of the 1970 United States Open starting Thursday, reopened for play today and most of the qualifiers here set out on practice rounds.

ALBANY, June 15 The Court of Appeals upheld today the invalidation by a lower court of legislation that automatically allocated to incumbent the top line on ballots in the primary election next Tues day in New York City.

White and Roger B. Chaffee. Following the public indignation roused by this expose, NASA and its contractors promised a thorough review of the Apollo equipment and correction of weaknesses that might lead to other disasters.

Top negotiators for the city's four major daily newspapers and Mailers Union No. 6 flew to Colorado Springs yesterday to continue their contract talks at the headquarters of the parent International Typographical Union.

The Cerro Corporation has announced that C. Gordon Murphy has become the copper company's new president and chief executive officer. Mr. Murphy succeeds Robert P.
