Lufthansa, the West German traps-Atlantic airline, has named Herbert Culmann to the new post of chairman of its four-man executive board, on which he has served since 1964.
A citizen's committee that waged a vain year-long fight to prevent jet airline service to Martha's Vineyard won a legal point this week, but the jets are still flying in.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 16 (UPI) Haroon Rahim of the University of California, Los Angeles, and Pat Cramer of Miami of Florida led the way with two victories apiece in the National Collegiate Tennis championships today.

Governor Rockefeller told industrialists at a conference on the environment yesterday that their sector of society should work to strike "a balance, rather than a competition, be tween the economy and the ecology."

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Representative Joel T. Broyhill, in a formal break with the state's Republican Governor and most of the Republican organization, said today that he would work for endorsement by the party later this month of the Senate candidacy of Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., who is running as an independent.

Dr. Abraham Oppenheim, director of the adult hygiene and cancer control research bureaus of the New York City Department of Health, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness. He was 62 years lived at 70 East 10th Street.
VERONA, N.J., June 16 A light plane bound for Teterboro Airport crashed into a luxury apartment building here this evening, killing the plane's two occupants.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 16 (AP) A strike has closed the Monte Carlo Casino and spread today to some of the principal hotels and restaurants in Monaco.
TRENTON, June 16 (AP) Former Mayor Arthur J. Holland has defeated the man who ousted him four years ago, Carmen J. Armenti.
WASHINGTON, June 16 A final effort to work out a voluntary method of restraining Japanese textile exports to the United States will be made early next week, it became known today.

FARMINGTON, Conn., June 16 Miss Elizabeth Harriman Miller and John Clayson Dennis were married here this afternoon at Sevenfold, the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Danforth Miller Jr., by the Rev. Roger W. Smith of St. James Episcopal Church here.
Take heart, you dancers at debuts, you frolickers at fetes and all you beautiful people who feel at home amid the smilax. The Tatler is comine to town.

Interunion squabbling confronts the country with the dismal threat of a second postal strike. The central issue this time is the formula for union representation that the House of Representatives seals into the pro posed postal reform bill.
The 17-year-old son of State Supreme Court Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg and three of his friends were arraigned at a police station early yesterday morning after being arrested on marijuana charges.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16 (AP) Three American correspondents, captured May 7 by Communist troops in Cambodia, arrived in Saigon today, apparently in good condition after being freed by their captors.

JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla., June 16 (UPI) George N. Syvertsen, the Columbia Broadcasting System newsman who was killed May 31 near Phnom Penh, Cambodia, was eulogized today as a gentle man who did not fit the popular conception of a war correspondent.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16--Ehrenfried von Holleben, the West German Ambassador to Brazil, returned safely to his home here tonight, five days after he was kidnapped and held for the highest ransom yet demanded--40 political prisoners--in a rash of diplomatic kidnappings in Latin America.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 16 (Reuters) A United States marine private pleaded innocent today to a charge of premeditated murder of 11 children and 5 women on Feb. 19 in a hamlet near this base city.
WASHINGTON, June 16 President Nixon will embark on a more formalized "educational" campaign tomorrow to help check the rise in prices and wages, officials indicated today.
The first annual Straw Hat Awards, sponsored by the Council of Stock Theaters, were presented yesterday by Cary Grant at an informal reception held at the Faberge Townhouse, 5 West 54th Street.

TEL AVIV, June 16 The High Court in Jerusalem ordered the Government today to register as man and wife a Jewish couple who were married without the participation of clergy in a private religious ceremony.

DETROIT, June 16 Vice President Agnew called today for the resignation of the only student member of a new Presidential commission on campus unrest, but he was rebuffed by both the student and the White House.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The Selective Service Director, Curtis W. Tarr, announced today stringent new standards to be applied by draft boards to determine if young men can qualify for exemptions as conscientious objectors under yesterday's Supreme Court decision.
ASCOT, England, June 16 (Reuters) A winner for Queen Elizabeth in the fifth race today capped the opening of the four-day Royal Ascot race meeting.
The argument over whether the ball is livelier this year goes on without a definitive decision, but there's no doubt that it has been lively in June with the bases loaded.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16 A month-long investigation of State Treasurer John D. Herbert's office has upheld reports that a Herbert campaign contributor was allowed to arrange illegal loans of state funds for which the contributor's company received hundreds of dollars in fees.
Thirteen persons were slightly injured and a sewage-treatment plant near Kennedy International Airport was heavily damaged last night in an explosion apparently caused by accumulated gases.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 16 A high-ranking aide of President Chung Hee Park accused the United States today of "a breach of international faith" in planning to withdraw troops from South Korea.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 16 Dr. Hortense Powdermaker, an anthropologist and author who taught at Queens College for many years, died of a heart attack at her home here last night, after returning from a movie. She was 69 years old. Dr. Powdermaker moved here three years ago after retiring from the Queens College faculty.

LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) The long-delayed trial of four members of a nomadic clan charged with murdering actress Sharon Tate and six others began today, with each prospective juror questioned privately about the influence, if any, of pre-trial publicity.

WASHINGTON, June 16 When Richard Nixon ran for the Presidency, he promised that he would have a "small" White House staff, and after he won, he said he would run an "open" Administration with a strong Cabinet of "independent thinkers."

KOMPONG SPEU, Cambodia, June 16 South Vietnamese and Cambodian infantry and armored units drove into this provincial capital and regional military headquarters today but found that the large enemy force they had hoped to trap had vanished.
WASHINGTON, June 16 President Nixon and leaders of organized labor lost an opening skirmish today as the House insisted on taking up its own version of a sweeping postalreform-and-pay bill.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 16 Leaders of radical Arab governments have assumed an aloof position toward the Palestinian commando movement in the aftermath of last week's crisis in Jordan, according to reports reaching here.

Five farmer participants in the Fresh Air Fund's free summer vacation programs have been awarded full $700 scholarships for summer sessions of the Encampment for Citizenship, a nonprofit organization that trains teen-agers for community leadership.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The State Department has assured Government officials who signed a letter last month to Secretary of State William P. Ropers protesting the incursion into Cambodia that no "formal or informal" punishment would be taken against them, the American Foreign Service Association said today.

Rochester, following the lead of New York, San Francisco, Chicago and Atlanta, will present an international film festival. A nonprofiit group, Rochester International Film Festival, Inc., headed by Williiam V. Creighton, chairman and administrative director, and Fred Mintz, festival director, announced that the festival will run from Oct. 17 through 25.
CHICAGO, June 16 Roy White picked the Yankees up on his 170-pound frame tonight and lifted them half a game closer to the top of the American League's Eastern Division.
TRENTON, June 16 (AP) The enforcement of a court order that could have led to a ban on all construction in a four-county area in northern New Jersey was put off today for at least two months.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 (AP) Harvard University announced today the names of 13 journalists who have been selected as Nieman Fellows for 1970-71.

Paul O'Dwyer, campaigning yesterday for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in the subway complex under Times Square, called on New Yorkers to "take back control of the subway system, while we still have any rolling stock that still functions."
Kenneth A. Gibson, the Negro candidate in Newark's bitterly contested and racially divisive mayoral election, decisively defeated Hugh J. Addonizio, the white, two-term incumbent, yesterday.

Miss Jane Louise Handler and Christopher Beirn were married yesterday by Surrogate Samuel J. Silverman of New York County in his chambers. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Handler of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Kenneth Beirn of Southport, Conn.

The sports-car people seem to be awash in beer these days and they couldn't be happier, what with the brewers joining the list of nonautomotive sponsors of motor competition. The Sports Car Club of America and the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company have just completed ...
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 The election of Dr. Elazar Goelman as president of Gratz College, the oldest Hebrew teachers' college in the Western Hemisphere, was announced here today.
MOSCOW, June 16 Following is the text of a statement titled "This Is How We Live," by the Soviet author Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, protesting the detention of the biologist Zhores A. Medvedev:

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 16 John Gentile Jr. of The Patterson Club, Fairfield, Conn., won the medal by two strokes today in the qualifying round of the 51st annual Westchester County Golf Association amateur championship.

Miss Emory Graham Alexander ,and her sister, Miss Helen Campbell Alexander, were honored here last evening at a reception and a dinner dance, given by their mother, Mrs. Lloyd L. Groves of Fair Hills, Elkton, Md., Mrs. Groves is the former Miss Helen King Kleberg, the only daughter of Robert Justus Kleberg Jr. of the King Ranch in Kingsville, Tex.

On a hot June morning four years ago, Bernard Andre (Boom Boom) Geoffrion strutted about a, Madison Square Garden conference room, his muscles stretching his Seventh Avenue-chic, shimmering suit. He was on top of the world. He took care that his manicured fingernails stayed neat, and when he picked up a cup of coffee his pinky discreetly stood at attention.

Tightening state conspiracy laws to apprehend the top leaders of organized crime instead of only jailing "middle management" and men on the street was the "No. 1" recommendation yesterday by the officer who commanded the Police Department's efforts against the crime syndicate for the last two years.

Americans rightly regard the usual British election campaigns as not only more restrained but more responsible with debate at a higher level and more attention to real issues than most campaigns in this country. The campaign that ends with the election of a new House of Commons tomorrow has, unfortunately, failed to meet the expected standard.

LONDON, June 16 Edward Heath, striving to come from behind in the last days of the election campaign, charged tonight that Britain would face another devaluation if the Labor party remained in office.

NEW HAVEN, June 16 The first trial in what is expected to be a drawn-out series of trials of Black Panthers started quietly here today with an unusual assurance from the prosecutor that he had no intention of seeking the death penalty for defendant, Lonnie McLucas.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 16 The Rev. and Mrs. Edwin Harold Rian have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Edwina Rian, to Brian Joseph Hayes, son of Mrs. Joseph H. Hays of Kenilworth, Ill., and the late Mr. Hays.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle, subject to certain conditions, to acquire from the Tracy Investment Company a 37.5 per cent interest in the International Leisure Corporation, which owns and operates the International and Flamingo Hotels in Las Vegas, Nev.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 16 Miss Jamee Becker, a model and a screen and television actress, will be married July l8 to Dr. Philippe Heem Guilbert, who, under a grant from the Frendh Government, is a teaching fellow at the University of California at Los Angeles.
MIAMI, June 16 (AP) The police shot four men two Whites and two Negroes on a rooftop tonight as racial violence spread into three Negro sections of Miami.

TRENTON, June 16 The president of an engineering concern testified today that he told the Newark City Council in 1965 that his company was withdrawing from a sewer project because it was too busy, when it actually wanted to get out because of a kickback demand.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 16 The leader of the most leftist of the Arab commando movements said today that the conflict between the Jordanian Army and the Palestinians could flare into a new and bloodier crisis "within a few months or even with a week."
The credit markets, revived by record yields ranging as high as 11 per cent, sprang to life yesterday. Prices rose sharply as new issues sold swiftly.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has asked a Federal Court to appoint a receiver for the Gray Line Corporation, which owns 24 per cent of the voting shares of the contested Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.
WASHINGTON, June 16--President Nixon issued a proclamation today setting July 1 as the date of the next draft lottery drawing.
LOS ANGELES, June 16 (UPI) The 72-foot Blackfin led the 14-boat fleet at the start of the second day of the 3,571-mile Los Angeles-to-Tahiti yacht race today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Citing lack of sufficient evidence, an Army court of military review set aside today the mutiny conviction of a private who was court-martialed for his participation in the alleged "mutiny" by 27 soldiers at the Presidio stockade in San Francisco in October, 1968.

"This is Tony," says the friendly narrator of "Censorship in Denmark: A New Approach," introducing us to a pretty, oval-faced girl with long hair who looks a little like Leigh Taylor-Young at loose ends.

MOSCOW, June 16 Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia and colleagues from Japan and Malaysia flew here today and Secretary General Thant arrives tomorrow on separate but similar missions: to persuade Moscow to use its good offices to get negotiations started to end the fighting now spreading throughout Indochina.
Msgr. Louis Risha denied yesterday that he had converted church funds to his own use in Philadelphia.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 Martial law was proclaimed tonight in Istanbul after a day of rioting by militant left-wing workers over proposed changes in labor legislation.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 16 United Nations officials and an American citizens' group are planning a new worldwide fight against illicit traffic in narcotics.

The mighty Mets, shrugging aside intermittent showers as easily as they did the Cincinnati Reds, posted an 8-1 victory at Shea Stadium last night in a game that lasted a couple of minutes past midnight.

Jean Cruguet, the French jockey who has been finding it difficult to get into the winner's circle this season, scored his second double in two days at Belmont Park yesterday on mounts with interesting backgrounds.

The patients at Mount Sinai Hospital have learned to distinguish between the two doctors named Waldman. They call the bubbly hazel-eyed red-haired woman in the minidress, who's been making rounds during the last year as a senior medical student, Mrs. Dr. Waldman. The dark-haired, mustached, quiet one is Dr. Waldman.

WASHINGTON, June 16 North Vietnam has announced that it will "fight shoulder to shoulder with the fraternal peoples of Laos and Cambodia." The pledge is being viewed here as a commitment by Hanoi to merge the hostilities in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia into a single integrated Indochin amilitary theater.
The indictment of 16 persons on charges of operating a $5million-a-year bookmaking and policy business in the Bronx was announded yesterday by District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 16 The South African Government came under new pressure today to restore the passport of the country's leading playwright, Athol Fugard.
President Nixon's talk on the nation's economy will be carried live at noon today on television and radio.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The House Education and Labor Committee approved an occupational safety bill today amid warnings by Republican members that they would contest the measure when it reaches the House floor.

ATLANTA, June 16 (UPI) The management of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, Inc., announced at its annual stockholders' meeting today that it was studying three consumer-protection proposals, including unit pricing of items and dating of perishable goods.

France's potential challenger for the America's Cup arrived by freighter yesterday at the Brooklyn Army Terminal surrounded by two other 12-Meter yachts, three motorboats, nine aluminum masts, nine French crewmen, a 1958 Bentley automobile and a tight curtain of security.

Biographical profiles of persons in the news are being reprinted from The New York Times and mailed weekly to subscribers to The New York Times Biographical Edition, it was announced yesterday. The new service will include more than 1,000 biographical sketches each year.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Hamer H. Budge, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, criticized today as "materially lacking" many aspects of a securities industry plan for insuring investors against bankruptcies of brokerage firms.

TRENTON, June 16 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill signed into law today his controversial measure merging the administrations of the Rutgers Medical School and the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The recovery of the bodies of 76 miners trapped by a West Virginia explosion a year and a half ago may be delayed for up to two more years, a United States Bureau of Mines official reported today.

Maureen O'Neill, chairman of a union-organizing committee at Newsday, said yesterday that a petition had been filed with the National Labor Relations Board here by editorial employes seeking to be represented in collective bargaining by the United Automobile Workers.
ALBANY, June 16 The state's highest court ruled today the Barry Farber, New York City radio host, was the legal Liberal party candidate for Congress in the 19th Congressional District.

In an unusual tactic in labor negotiations, Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union yesterday showed a 28-minute documentary movie on the 113-day hospital strike last year in Charleston, S. C., to negotiators here for city's voluntary hospitals. The local is seeking a new contract for 22,000 workers.

A construction company yesterday threatened to take over the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater at 425 Lafayette Street unless a bill of more than $400,000 for work done on the structure is paid "within the next few days."
Silver futures rose yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange although prices received at the Government's silver auction in Washington showed a decline.
The London stock market rallied strongly yesterday following the sharp slump caused by the announcement on Monday of a widening of the British trade deficit in May. Trading, however, remained quiet.
Joseph P. Grant has been named president of the Licensing Corporation of America, as subsidiary of Kinney National Service, Inc.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 16 George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills, the 1968 champion, and one of the sectional qualifying medalists, Dave Muraskin of Rutgers, survived the opening rounds of the New Jersey State Golf Association's 69th amateur championship today over the rolling Plainfield Country Club course.
A substance widely considered to have been a key ingredient in the early evolution of life has been detected among the stars by a radio telescope atop Kitt Peak in Arizona.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Dean Rusk, the former Secretary of State, tonight broke 18 months of silence on United States foreign policy to say that he could not "throw brickbats" at President Nixon for his failure to find peace in southeast Asia because the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations had also failed.

BALTIMORE, June 16 (AP) Charles P. McCormick, businessman, educator, civic leader and author known for his "multiple management" system, died tonight in University Hospital of a heart attack. His age was 73.

WASHINGTON, June 16 A lawsuit that may cause consternation in the pharmaceutical industry will be filed against the Food and Drug Administration tomorrow in an effort to force the Government to bar useless drugs from the market.
MEXICO CITY, June 16 (UPI) The oddsmakers and the experts agreed today that it will be a Brazil-Italy final in the 1970 World Cup soccer championship.

WASHINGTON, June 16 The National Labor Relations Board extended its jurisdiction today to cover private colleges and universities. With operat ing budgets of roughly $6-billion a year, such institutions have a clear impact on interstate commerce, the board said, and will have to operate under the labor-management rules that govern other big businesses.
William J. Haight is no run-of-the-mill stock analyst. No, he's not a producer of instant research on far-flung corporate empires. Far from it.

In comparison with the meetings last year when James Forman, the black militant leader, was making the rounds in behalf of "reparations" for the evils of slavery, this spring's meetings of the major Protestant denominations have been about as tumultuous as Wednes day-evening prayer meetings.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) President Nixon announced today the formal organization of the President's Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation, which ...

CARMEL, Calif., June 16 In an ecumenical ceremony at Carmel Mission Basilica, Miss Rosemary Elton and Alexander Markowski were married this afternoon. The Rev. George McMenamin, pastor of the mission, performed the ceremony. The Rev. Peter Farmer, pastor of All Saints Episcopal Churah here, presented a homily and blessed the service.

Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that Arthur J. Goldberg had "suggested" he was injecting racism into their campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Mr. Goldberg emphatically denied the charge.

STOCKHOLM, June 16 After tonight's third-round play in the world championship here, the United States team, the title favorites, was left the only undefeated team. It had a bye round, for which it received a nominal 10 points out of 20, for a total of 41 victory points. Apparently leading with 42 points is the Brazilian team, which beat Norway tonight, 16-4. In the other match Nationalist China defeated Italy, 14-6.

About a year and a half ago, I wrote a review in this column praising Eldridge Cleaver's "Post-Prison Writings and Speeches." A howl of protest went up that would have warned Leonard Bernstein of the pitfalls of Kaffeeklatsching with the Black Panthers. Dozens of letter writers wanted to know how I could lavish such...

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A spokesman for Secretary of State William P. Rogers said, "We hope this release will be followed by the release of other American and international journalists captured in Cambodia in recent weeks."
AMMAN, Jordan, June 16 (Reuters) An American physician who was detained by Palestinian commandos in Amman Friday was released today, a spokesman at the United States Embassy said.

Herbert Kebeck, the tenant in an East Side luxury building who previously pleaded guilty to fighting with a policeman who had come to check on complaints from Mr. Kebeck's neighbors, changed his plea to not guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday.
In a meaningful match not only for the combatants but also for the heavyweight division, Mac Foster will make his Madison Square Garden debut tonight against Jerry Quarry in
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 Mr. Rhodes said today that he had "no intention of resigning" from the commission in the wake of Mr. Agnew's comments.

LONDON, June 16 No sooner had the seedings been announced for next week's Wimbledon tournament than Clark Graebner, No. 9; Tom Okker, No. 11, and Roger Taylor, No. 16, were knocked out in the second round of the London open grass court tennis championships today.
The verdict of the ballot box was a sour one for several hundred followers of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio who had gathered last night at Thomm's, a restaurant in the heavily Italian North Ward.
A patrolman was hit on the head with a bottle yesterday when he attempted to arrest a youth at the edge of a crowd of 300 students gathered outside Public School 108 in Jamaica, Queens.

BERLIN, June 16 A small group of West German leftist political extremists has served notice that it plans to set up a guerrilla organization to overthrow the parliamentary system in the state and in West Berlin.

PARIS, June 16 Tunisian Jewish merchants in the slum known as Belleville swept the glass from their shattered storefronts today and reopened for business. It was not the first time, and it would not be the last, they said.
David Geringas of the Soviet Union has won the cello prize at the international Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported last night.

VIENNA, July 16 After two months of meetings here on a possible limitation of strategic nuclear arms, United States and Soviet negotiators are edging slowly toward an agreement involving all the major categories of such weapons.

HYANNIS, Mass., June 16 As public television program managers this week were discussing ways to make their fall program schedules appealing to general audiences, other representatives of the various segments within public broadcasting have been speculating privately on the immediate and long-range future of their medium.
SEA ISLAND, Ga., June 16 J.E. Griffith Jr., a retired vice president, group division, of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, died today at his home here. He was 77 years old.

Standing on the steps of the old Subtreasury Building at Nassau and Wall Streets, Theodore C. Sorensen suggested yesterday a package of taxlaw changes that, he said, would ease the burden of the middle-income taxpayer and homeowner.

CHASKA, Minn. June 16 United States Golf Association officials prepared today to save their 70th Open championship from a washout as 150 golfers crammed hurried practice rounds into a delayed schedule.
LONDON, June 16 Viscount Thurso, wartime Air Minister and a former leader of the Liberal party, died last night at his home in Twickenham, a London suburb. He was 79 years old.

MOSCOW, June 16 Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the controversial Soviet novelist, has assailed the continued detention in a mental hospital of Zhores A. Medvedev, a biologist and an outspoken critic of the regime.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Defense Department sources revealed today that there were "about 10,000" American troops still in Cambodia. The President has pledged that all United States troops will be out by June 30.
PARIS, June 16 Elsa Triolet, the Goncourt prizewinning novelist who was the wife of Louis Aragon, the poet, died of heart failure today. Her age was 73.

John C. Lawrence, president of Agau Mines, Inc., and of the United States Antimony Corporation, said yesterday that the affiliated concerns had verified the presence of major antimony reserves on their property near Thompson Falls, Mont.

The Arnold Constable Corporation, the 145-year-old retail concern, announced yesterday that it has agreed to merge with the American International Development Corporation, a Florida operator of condominium (or jointly owned) properties, in the latest phase of a diversification program.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., June 16 Representative Richard L. Ottinger said today that he had heard "through the grapevine" that the latest Goldberg camp poll showed him overtaking Theodore C. Sorensen in the four-way Democratic senatorial primary.
"This rally came out of the blue," a Wall Street secretary declared yesterday. "On Monday, the market looked dead."

The Central Soya Company, the nation's second largest soybean processor and sixth largest producer of broilers, expects to show the highest sales and earnings in its history for the fiscal year ending August 31, a spokesman for the Ft. Wayne, Ind.-based company declared yesterday.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 16 The Indiana Democratic State Convention adopted today a resolution urging "prompt and orderly disengagement" of American forces from Southeast Asia.
Two men were killed and three others were critically injured in a fiery automobile accident on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive early yesterday morning.
TORONTO, June 16 (Canadian Press) The Toronto Stock Exchange announced today that trading in Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., had been suspened beginning today.
Adam Walinsky, a contender for the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General, vowed yesterday that he would run a "very" independent office if elected.
Bill Baird, a defensive back with the New York Jets for the last seven seasons, announced his retirement yesterday from pro football.

SYRACUSE, June 16 Mr. Samuels, making his final swing through the upstate area he hopes will provide him a heavy vote in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, told supporters that his once-confident opponent was now desperate.

Mayor Lindsay was described as doubly pleased yesterday by Monday's Supreme Court action in letting stand a state Court of Appeals ruling that the oneman, one-vote doctrine was not applicable to the Board of Estimate.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 16 (AP) The Rev. R.J. Hampton filed today for the Republican nomination for Governor, becoming the first Negro in decades to run for the state's highest office.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange made their biggest advance in almost two weeks yesterday as the list made good gains in fairly active trading.

Boxes of California table grapes bearing the safe passage stamp of the Farmworker's A.F.L.-C.I.O. union label a black Aztec eagle inset in a white circle against the background of a red flag are making their first appearance here to what seems to be a mixed reception.
German measles vaccine appears to be reducing the incidence of the disease in states where the vaccine is widely used, the National FoundationMarch of Dimes said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16 Housing starts declined slightly in May while permits for new construction increased, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A Securities and Exchange Commission examiner has recommended barring Thomas D. Ledwith, former head of the security clearance department of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company, New York, from engaging in the securities business.
House Minority Leader Gerald R. Ford and two Senators said yesterday that they had been asked by Dr. Martin Sweig to appear as his defense witnesses.
Brian Piccolo, a halfback for the Chicago Bears football team died here yesterday in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. The 26year-old athlete's death was attributed to cancer.

BERLIN, June 16 Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader, has suggested, in what could be a change of position, that the two German states exchange diplomatic representatives and apply for membership in the United Nations before establishing full international relations.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 16 Everyone connected with Columbia George, the 3-yearold pacer who will be among the leading contenders in next Saturday night's Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, would like to forget about what happened to the colt last Sunday and Monday in Canada.
Adam Clayton Powell predicted yesterday that he would "win by 3 to 1 over my nearest opponent" in his fight for renomination to the House of Representatives despite the "intrusion of outsiders."
MINEOLA, L.I., June 16 In Nassau County's four contested village elections today, challengers generally failed to oust incumbent officials seeking reelection.
ROCHESTER, June 16 A bookmaker was released from the Monroe County Penitentiary for several hours Monday to be married in his home in suburban Irondequoit.

OMAHA, June 16 (UPI) Florida State knocked Ohio University out of the College World Series tonight with a 2-0 triumph in a superb pitching battle. The Ohio starter, Ed Robbins, suffered his first loss of the season after 14 victories.

Eloise Laws, a sinuous singer sheathed in purple, did all she could to turn the cement block gymnasiumand-auditorium of a city prison into a nightclub yesterday afternoon, in a show for 500 male inmates on Rikers Island.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission reported today a net decline in nicotine and tars in cigarettes compared with previous tests in November.
PORT HURON, Mich., June 16 (AP) A valuable painting by Georges Braque, owned by the Detroit Institute of Arts, is missing here according to the police.

JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 17 A military spokesman said that Israeli forces struck deep into Syria last night to shell a military camp occupied by about 1,000 Syrian soldiers and to blow up a highway bridge.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 President Judge Vincent A. Carroll of the Philadelphia Common Pleas Court brought suit in his own court today for additional funds with which to operate the court.

WASHINGTON, June l6 A new law under which Federal courts could prohibit and punish interference with freedom of speech was proposed today by a Congressional coalition of Democrats and Republicans, both liberal and conservative.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., June 16 Three women prisoners at the Niagara County Jail here were charged today with murder in the death of a 67-year-old jail matron during what appeared to be an attempt to escape.
GENEVA, June 16 The United States and the Soviet Union today launched a campaign to win approval for their projected treaty to keep the ocean floors free of nuclear weapons.

UPPERVILLE, Va., June 16 Miss Kathryn Halliday Horkan, a granddaughter of retired Maj. Gen. George Anthony Horkan, former quartermaster general of the Army, was married this afternoon to Andrew Wilson Campbell.

A trio of trios from the 19th century made up the "Evening of Romantic Chamber Music" that was Monday night's "Sampler" at Alice Tully Hall. Two of them are among the best and most popular works in the repertory, Mendelssohn's...

Last week, when the Penn Central Company abruptly dismissed its chairman, Stuart T. Saunders, in the midst of what was (and clearly still is) a grave financial crisis, a tremor ran through the canyons of Wall Street.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 16 (AP) A New York City student was arrested at Jones Beach today, and the police said he was rolling in the sand while wrapped in an American flag.

FREEHOLD, N.J., June 16 (UPI) A grand jury indicted seven members of the Long Branch, N.J., Police Department today in connection with an alleged firehouse orgy May 18 involving the 17-year old daughter of a minister.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 16 The second of four races in the international team sailing for the Onion Patch Trophy produced another sweep of the first three places for the United States today, but again the official outcome was inconclusive.

DOVER, Del., June 16 (UPI) John Daniello, a Newcastle County councilman who ran on an anti-war platform, won the Democratic nomination for Congress today in Delaware's only statewide primary election.

MIAMI SPRINGS, Fla., June 16 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Jones have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Charlette Jones, to Ens. Vance Wiley Torbert 3d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Torbert Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J.

Almost everything went well with American Ballet Theater at the beginning of its month-long season at the New York State Theater last night. The exception was the sad absence, through injury, of its superstar, Erik Bruhn. I understand that Mr. Bruhn will not appear this season. But the Ballet Theater, now in its 30th year, is certainly big enough and old enough to stand on its own.

DENVER, June 16 After three days at the United States Conference of Mayors convention here, Mayor Lindsay has eased into a relaxed and even polite attitude toward the Nixon Administration that contrasts markedly with some of his sharp criticism earlier this month of the Federal Government's urban policies.

The American Broadcasting Company, which had substantial success this season with its 90-minute "Movie of the Week" television series, has created a new unit to make two-hour feature films for television, starting in 1971. The unit, to be called A.B.C. Circle Films, will be a subsidiary of A.B.C. Television and will be directly under Barry Diller, the network's vice president for feature films and program development and the man responsible for "Movie of the Week."

CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) The head of the United Transportation Union, the nation's largest railroad operating union, said today that the organization "will not tolerate further delay" in settling the lingering dispute over the use of firemen in diesel locomotives.

THE HAGUE, June 16 Secretary General Thant of the United Nations suggested today that the leaders of the five great powers, including ,Communist China, meet to discuss world problems. He said they should try to change from their hostile attitudes to "the building of a safe and peaceful world."

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., following the long-standing practice of the railroads and airlines, has arranged for longterm leasing for some of its badly needed generating equipment.

NEWTON, Mass., June 15 At the Massachusetts Democratic Convention last weekend a woman approached the Rev. Robert F. Drinan and told him she could not vote for him because he was a priest and belonged in a parish, not in politics.

ERIVAN, U.S.S.R. In discussing Moscow's policy toward the Middle East, many people forget that the Soviet Union is itself a Middle Eastern power. The Allied Stores Corporation, the nation's second-largest department-store chain, has found that May showed "no big turnaround" and that the current fiscal quartet's business was running at or slightly below the 3.7 per cent gain in sales during the second quarter, ended April 30.

The amendment to the Clean Air Act of 1967 approved by the House, 374 to 1, is positive recognition that national standards are essential to cut down omissions from motor vehicles and stationary (smokestack) sources of pollution. By authorizing appropriations of $775 million over the next three years, the House has nearly doubted the amount asked by the Administration.

Twice last month Linden Junior High School was closed as were all city schools to give pupils time to reflect upon the violence at Kent State University and at Jackson, Miss.
ROME, June 16 (AP) The film "Midnight Cowboy" has won two David di Donatello prizes, the Italian equivalent of Hollywood's Academy Awards, it was announced today.
KOMPONG CHHNANG, Cambodia, June 16--No one got any sleep last night in Kompong Chhnang.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Voices of the white ethnic working class rose in anger at being ignored by government and the press, anger being ridiculed by intellectuals, anger at being exploited by "right-wing reactionaries like George Wallace."

The heart of the Supreme Court's 5-to-3 ruling that men may legitimately object to military service on purely moral and ethical grounds is that it has removed the requirement of religious belief from the legal concept of the conscientious objector. The decision properly eliminates from Federal law the implication that only those who subscribe to formal religions are to be credited with a fundamental aversion to war and killing.
Manhattan business leaders were warned yesterday that the narcotics problem in industry was spreading and were urged to sharpen their detection methods.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) Maj. Charles S. Robb, son-in-law of former President Lyndon B. Johnson, is leaving the Marine Corps to study law.

MASSENA, N. Y., June 16 Representative Richard Max McCarthy came to this industrial city of 16,000 near the Canadian border today and charged that high power rates set by the State Power Authority were driving industry from this hard-pressed area.

WASHINGTON, June 16 A spokesman for the Pentagon reacted favorably today to a suggestion that its multibillion-dollar military exchange system undergo regular examination by Congress and the executive branch.
The Baltimore Orioles, who have been under pressure lately from the New York Yankees, contributed to a flurry of activity as the baseball trading deadline arrived Monday at midnight.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 16--The marriage of Miss Katharine Temple Emmet to David Fulmer True, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. True of Marietta, Ohio, took place here today at the home of Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet, mother of the bride.

MONTREAL, June 16 Delegates representing 84 countries opened an emergency session of the International Civil Aviation Organization here today to plan measures to combat the extended wave of hijackings and sabotage against airliners.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 17 (Reuters) At least eight persons were killed and 15 injured last night when a condemned 14-story apartment building collapsed and dragged down an adjacent nine-story building that was under construction.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel imposed today a virtual ban on the use of pesticides on more than 500 million acres of Federal lands, one-quarter of the land area of the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 17 Cancer cells appear to have been transformed into noncancerous cells in laboratory experiments reported here.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Air Force Secretary Robert C. Seamans Jr. suggested today that the trouble-plagued history of the C-5A supertransport airplane might have been different had the service obtained greater control over its development and production.
The recent European Zonal tournament No. 1 in Praia da Rocha was the first time Portugal was host to such an important chess event.

ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, June 16 Srichai Luangsangthong, a Thai medicine salesman, was in this neighborhood this afternoon with some time to spare, so he crossed the frontier to take his first look at Cambodia.

Good afternoon, my fellow Americans. Today I would like to share with you my thoughts on three subjects that reach into the homes and the pocketbooks of every family your job, your income and your cost of living.

RUMSON, N. J., June 17 Mr. and Mrs. George Vernon Coe Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Bruce Coe, to Charles Frederick Irish Jr., son of Mrs. Margaret Jensen Irish and Mr. Irish of Jacksonville, Fla., an architect. The wedding is planned for December.

A packed house that included many dancers turned out last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall for a program that offered three premieres by Bertram Ross and the first revival in 18 years of Martha Graham's "El Penitente.
BOSTON, June 17 Miss Roberta Shapiro and Marc E. Saperstein, graduate students at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, were married this evening at Temple Israel.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 17, (UPI) The Cambodian Parliament asked the United Nations today to send United Nations forces to protect the renowned temple ruins at Angkor if the world body cannot obtain by other means the evacuation of the area by the North Vietnamese, Vietcong and Pathet Lao forces.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee introduced a bill today designed to fix a 6 per cent maximum interest rate on all credit and loan transactions.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) The Nixon Administration urged the Supreme Court today to invalidate job tests that tend to prevent Negro workers from advancing without measuring their ability to do the job.

WPIX-TV, Channel 11, was accused yesterday of a policy of anti-black bias in the selection of talent for one of its former rock music programs, "The Clay Cole Show." The station quickly denied the allegation.
LOS ANGELES, June 17 The chore of choosing a jury in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three codefendants moved into its second day today with not a single juror yet seated.

After 112 years, rye futures will be suspended from trading next month on the Chicago Board of Trade. Beginning July 22, trades in rye futures for delivery in September and December, 1970, and May, 1971, will be permitted only for liquidation.

Robert E. Dewar has been named president and chief administrative officer of the S. S. Kresge Company, it was announced yesterday in Detroit following the annual meeting. Mr. Dewar has been executive vice president for administration and finance.
CHICAGO, June 17 Two Yankee winning streaks were snapped tonight as the club concluded a two-game visit to Comiskey Park with a 6-3 defeat at the hands of Jerry Janeski and the White Sox.

Plans for a $16-million combined public school and 420unit low-income apartment project in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn were announced yesterday by the New York City Educational Construction Fund.

WASHINGTON, June 17 The House approved and sent to President Nixon today a bill to lower the voting age from 21 to 18 in all Federal, state and local elections beginning in 1971. The measure would open the political process to about 11 million young people.

NEWARK, June 17 Mayorelect Kenneth A. Gibson declared today that under his administration Newark no longer "will be a place of fear," and he called on the "energies of all the people here black and white to build a new city."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 17 -George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills and Billie Ziobro of Ash Brook, both of whom have been involved in the pressure of title tournaments before, and Jeff Alpert of Florham Park and Wiley Williams of Warrenbrook, newcomers to the event, reached the semifinal round of the 69th New Jersey State amateur golf championship today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 17 Vietnamese Communist troops cut Cambodia's last working railway line today, capturing more than 200 tons of rice and other food supplies from a freight train about 40 miles northwest of here.

Bargaining agents for the International Typographical Union's New York Mailers' local and the city's four major daily newspapers returned from a two-day negotiating session in Colorado yesterday and expressed hope that the stalled negotiations could be revitalized.
A 38-year-old orthopedic surgeon was arrested yesterday after he fired four shots into the street from his apartment at 15 West 72d Street, according to the police.

LONDON, June 17 Two Americans made their protest against next week's controversial Wimbledon seeding by reaching the quarterfinals of the London grass-court championships today. Marty Riessen defeated the No. 7 seeded player, Stan Smith, 10-8, 6-2, on the strength of his heavily punched volleys and little Cliff Richey won, 6-2, 7-5, from Jaidip Mukerjea of India, who had knocked out 11th-seeded Tom Okker yesterday.
With Petey Anderson guiding him to a driving finish, Mrs. John A. Morris's Proudest Roman won the $31,475 National Stallion Stakes, colts and geldings division, at Belmont Park yesterday.
Representatives of taxi fleet owners and unionized drivers have been meeting to seek ways to end their contract before its expiration date and to increase fares, it was disclosed yesterday.
DETROIT, June 17 (AP) The mail-in-a-pail postal service began its 75th year of deliveries today to ships passing the city on the Detroit River.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 17 (UPI) Gov. William T. Cahill and his daughter Patricia were awarded $100,000 today in an out-of-court settlement of a suit filed in connection with the auto accident that left Miss Cahill paralyzed for several weeks last summer.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Korenblatt of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Korenblatt, to Joseph P. Norelli. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Angelo A. Norelli of Eastchester, N. Y.

Mr. and Mrs. Morris Merow of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rend Merow, to Lester J. Margareten. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Margareten of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, and Lake Mohegan, N. Y. The couple plan to be married in Novem ber.

The voters of Newark have given an encouraging demonstration of the health of the American political system. In recent years no city has reflected more alarmingly the acuteness of urban decay, corruption and racial animosity. Yet, in Newark's mayoral election, significant numbers of white voters, ignoring strident appeals to their fears and their prejudices, joined blacks in naming as head of their municipal government the best-qualified candidate, Kenneth A. Gibson.
The Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Transnation Development Corporation, which recently sought ownership of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., announced yesterday a merger plan of their own.

Last year, Congress enacted the Tax Reform Act of 1969, the most massive overhaul of tax law in the nation's history. The following article is the eighth in a series that periodically will examine the implications for personal money management of the changes that were adopted.

Representative Richard Max McCarthy, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Senator, was thwarted yesterday as he sought to climb down a steel ladder in a Fifth Avenue manhole to see what repairs and installations the New York Telephone Company was making under midtown streets.
Representatives of landlords agreed yesterday to a threeyear contract providing 25,000 doormen, elevator operators, handymen and porters with wage increases averaging 40 per cent.

Jesse Gray charged yesterday that Assemblyman Charles B. Rangel had violated the conditions of a $39,500 municipal loan by living "rent free" in a Harlem apartment house he had inherited. He demanded that Mr. Rangel turn the building over to poor people.

A new series of legal maneuvers by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, against the merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company failed to deter I.T.T. from going ahead with merger plans yesterday.

King Hussein's brave attempt to reassert his authority in Amman at an elaborately staged press conference yesterday cannot conceal a radical transformation in Jordan that must profoundly affect prospects for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

WINSTON-SALEM, N, C., June 17 Mrs. Elizabeth Christian Gray, widow of Bowman Gray Jr., who was president and board chairman of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, was married at noon today to Richard Edward Thomas Hunter of Wallingford, Conn., a master at the Choate School there.

WASHINGTON, June 17, (UPI) The total personal income of Americans declined in May for the first time in almost five years to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $793.5billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

ROCHESTER, June 17 Mr. and Mrs. Merritt C. Chandler of Rochester and of Bomoseen, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Barbey Chandler, to John Henry Strohmeier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Strohmeier of Scarsdale, N. Y., and Nonquitt, Mass. A fall wedding is planned.

The London stock market closed firm yesterday in reaction to Tuesday's rally on Wall Street
Congratulations are in order for the crew of Soyuz 9 which has broken the space-flight duration record set by this country's Gemini 7 back in December, 1965.

Diners Club, Inc., controlled by the Continental Corporation, had a loss after taxes of about $13-million in the fiscal year ended March 31 or a total of $23-million with an additional non-recurring write-off of about $10-million, the preliminary unaudited company report disclosed yesterday. Audited figures are expected before the end of July.

WASHINGTON, June 17 The Senate Armed Services committee approved today an expansion of the anti-Soviet phase of the Nixon Administration's missile defense system But it rejected a proposed start on the anti-Chinese phase, which the Administration had described as essential.

NEWARK, June 17 Hundreds of congratulatory telegrams poured into the headquarters of Mayor-Elect Kenneth A. Gibson today as residents of Newark's black neighborhoods voiced their confidence that they finally had a champion in City Hall.

BONN, June 17 Amid signs of deep political division, West Germany today marked its annual Day of National Unity, marking the 1953 uprising of East German workers against the Communist regime.

LONDON, June 17 Alexander Kerensky was buried today in a small cemetery here, an exile who yearned vainly to return one day to his Russian homeland.

WASHINGTON, June 17 Vice President Agnew praised young people today for their determination to change the governmental system and strongly endorsed their right to vote at age 18.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries showed lower earnings for the three months ended May 31 despite a new high in operating revenues for the period.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 17 (Reuters) The trial of a United States marine accused of the murder of 16 Vietnamese women and children was adjourned today because two witnesses were missing and a third was sick with malaria.

The appointment of Dr. Charles U. Walker, dean of Hamline University in St. Paul. Minn., as the fifth president of Russell Sage College, was announced yesterday by the College's board of trustees.

A sharp increase in the penalties for air and water pollution, including fines of $1,000 a day for violators, were proposed yesterday by Representative Richard L. Ottinger.

Nathan M. Voloshen, lawyer and lobbyist, pleaded guilty in Federal Court here yesterday to conspiring with an aide of House Speaker John W. McCormack to use the prestige of Mr. McCormack's Washington office to defraud agencies of the Federal Government.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 17 -John Gentile Jr. of the Patterson Club, Fairfield, Conn., the medalist, won two matches at Sunningdale Country Club today to reach the quarterfinal round of the 51st annual Westchester County Golf Association championship but Gregory Zorila of Briar Hall, the defending champion, was eliminated in the second round.
The credit markets listened to President Nixon's speech on the economy yesterday, and they found it unsurprising and disappointing.

Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the physician who developed the vaccine against polio that bears his name, and Francoise Gilot, the mistress of Pablo Picasso for 11 years and mother of two of the artist's children, plan to be married July 9.

BERLIN, June 17 (AP) Wolfgang Nordwig of East Germany surpassed the listed world pole-vault record today when he vaulted 17 feet 10 inches at a meet involving East Berlin athletes, ADN, the official East German news agency, reported.

DALLAS, June 17 (AP) Texas' abortion laws were declared unconstitutional today by a three-judge Federal panel that said the statutes infringed on the right of women to choose whether they wanted to bear children.

Mario A. Procaccino, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Mayor last year, yesterday endorsed District Attorney Robert R. Meehan of Rockland County for the party's nomination for State Attorney General.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 (AP) James L. Buckley, the Conservative party's cnadidate for the United States Senate candidate from New York, described the allied thrust into Cambodian border areas today as "a hell of a successful operation."

NORWALK, Conn., June 17 Former Representative Abner W. Sibal of Weston withdrew today from the contest for the Republican nomination: for United States Senator.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17 A Syrian military spokesman said today that two Syrian soldiers were killed and five slightly wounded in an attack by Israeli forces yesterday on the Syrian Army camp near Nebk. The town is 20 miles northeast of Damascus.

MOSCOW, June 17 (UPI) The Soyuz 9 astronauts, now in the 16th day of their recordbreaking space endurance flight, are conducting eye experiments to determine the effect of prolonged space flight on vision, Soviet specialists said today.
