MADRID, June 18--Eight months after Generalissimo Francisco Franco drastically reshuffled his Cabinet, the Spanish Government is confronted with the widest and most troublesome opposition in the 30 years since the Civil War.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Robert H. Finch, said today that Vice President Agnew's recent attack on a young member of the President's Commission on Campus Unrest had given the commission greater "legitimacy and visibility than it had before."
After trying unsuccessfully for nearly a year to find a man to head the city school system, the Board of Education now hopes to name a chancellor before the end of this month.

PORTLAND, Ore.--Doctors bury their mistakes, architects plant vines, and Portland covers them with roses. June is rose festival time in this city of 375,000 people, where green residential hills drop down to the commercial

An overnight spate of firebombings which started in Greenwich Village was climaxed early yesterday when someone pitched a molotov cocktail into the hose bed of a fire truck while firemen were battling a two-alarm tenement blaze at 8 and 10 Avenue B in the East Village.
Lowell M. Birrell, the financier, was convicted last night by a Federal Court jury of participating in a fraudulent scheme to use blank stock certificates as security for a $5,000 bank loan in 1966.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- Officials in the Nixon Administration who differ on the issue of whether the President should resort to "jawboning" to influence private price and wage decisions expressed satisfaction today with the President's message on the economy.
The 24-year-old National Basketball Association and the three-year-old American Basketball Association agreed yesterday to merge, subject to the approval of Congress.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 18 (Agence France-Presse)--A student group in this whitedominated country is demanding that blacks be represented in the government of the University College of Rhodesia when it attains university status.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- With considerable interparty jockeying, the Senate moved today to break the legislative logjam created by its protracted Cambodian debate by agreeing to hold evening sessions to consider Administration bills.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday in light trading.

Mayor Lindsay's plan to give a city agency the authority to set profit levels in rent-controlled apartment houses will almost certainly be substituted with a program placing that power with the City Council.

Adam Walinsky demanded yesterday that Attorney General Louis J. Lefkofitz investigate allegations that an upstate undercover agent for the Ontario County Sheriff's office known as "Tommy the Traveler" had incited campus violence by offering students bombs, guns and lessons in guerrilla tactics.

Mrs. Faith Burwell Kaye of New York, widow of Sidney Kaye, was married here at noon yesterday to James Stewart-Gordon, a roving editor of Reader's Digest, by Justice Stanley H. Fuld of the New York Court of Appeals.
TRENTON, June 18--An alleged extortion-money collector arrived by helicopter at a job site for a Newark water main extension in March, 1966, picked up $35,000 in cash and left the same way, a witness

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18 (UPI)--Fighting in Indochina last week killed 130 Americans and wounded 364, the United States command reported today. The number killed, an increase over the previous week, included 93 men slain in South Vietnam and 37 in Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, June 18-- Consumer prices continued to rise in May at the rate of other recent months, though less than the rate of last winter, the Labor Department reported today.
A Police Department trial of a detective charged with selling confidential information was adjourned about midnight last night after a series of highly technical legal developments.

GUILFORD, Conn., June 18-- Dr. Mary Clabaugh Wright, a leading scholar of. Chinese history and the first woman to be named a full professor at Yale University, died at her home here 'today. She was 52 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 18-- The Congressional decision to give the vote to 11 million Americans between 18 and 21 years old may have raised as many questions as it settled.

NEWARK, June l8--Senator Harrison A. Wiiliams Jr., the Democratic candidate for reelection, assailed the Nixon Administration tonight in a debate with Nelson G. Gross, the Republican candidate. It was their first confrontation of the campaign.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 18--Vietnamese Communist troops today cut the last major surface route open in Cambodia, the highway linking Pnompenh with Saigon.

WASHINGTON, June 18-- The House Appropriations Committee recommended today an appropriation of $1-billion for the construction of municipal waste treatment works for the fiscal year beginning July 1-- the last year of the program authorized in the Clean Waters Restoration Act of 1966.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 18 --Last year, Marty Liquori was the challenger who wanted a piece of the action, a place alongside Jim Ryun of the international track and field honor roll.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 18 (UPI)--Rock throwing and looting in a predominantly Negro section followed the death tonight of a black escaped convict in a gun battle with policemen.
The pace of monetary expansion moderated somewhat during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.
New American Review, the last of the mass-market paperback literary journals, is being abandoned by its publisher, the New American Library, a subsidiary of The Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles.

MONTREAL, June 18--The United States delegation to an emergency aviation conference here is pressing for a strongly worded resolution against hijacking and sabotage that will call for action by governments but stop short of sanctions.

STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, June 18--"King John," at the Royal Shakespeare Theater, launches the Royal Shakespeare Company's 23-year-old first woman director. Even without the help of a name like Buzz Goodbody, there would be no danger of ignoring her contribution.
MIAMI, Friday, June 19--A truce worked out by the police and Miami Negro leaders produced a night of relative calm in Miami after three days of racial violence.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) --President Nixon asked Congress today to overhaul and consolidate Federal welfare services and add new aid for child foster care and adoption.

A slate of 10 directors submitted by the Devon Committee and pledged to continue Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., as an operating entity emerged victorious yesterday. Earlier in the day, the Appellate Division cut more than $3-million from the price the city will have to pay for intangible assets of the company taken over in 1962.

LONDON, June 19 On the night of his triumph, Edward Heath stood at the bar of the Crook Log Hotel in Bexley, the district south of London that sent the shy, intense Conservative to Parliament in 1950. Mr. Heath listened uneasily to the first returns of the evening, surrounded by...

CHESTERTOWN, Md., June l9 Mrs. William R. McAlpin of Land's End Farm here and Norfolk, Conn., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Miss Pamela Kathleen Lawrence, to Richard Sawyer Pieters Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pieters of Andover, Mass., and East Andover, N.H.

The marriage of Mrs. Victoria Tollefson to Howard Loeb Wattenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Wattenberg of New York, took place yesterday afternoon at the home here of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Carabba, stepfather and mother of the bride. Supreme Court Justice Theodore R. Kupferman performed the ceremony.
Anybody who bought a lot of those hot new issues during their heyday in 1969 knows why they are so unpopular today. They fell out of bed along with the rest of the common stocks only more so.

Howard Cook, a public relations consultant and an associate professor at Herbert H. Lehman College, died of pulmonary tuberculosis at St. Vincent's hospital Monday. He was 40 years old and lived at 15 Charles Street.
MOSCOW, June 19 Two Soviet astronauts, Col. Andrian G. Nikolayev and Vitaly I. Sevastyanov, landed safely on the earth today after the longest manned flight in history aboard the Soyuz 9 spacecraft.

Alfred J. Scotti, chief assistant district attorney of Manhattan, scored the Police Department yesterday for having failed to finish its departmental trial of a detective accused of dishonesty before that detective's retirement, and right to a police pension, became final.
Objects and pictures that document New York's importance as a port offer challenging possibilities for the collector.

PARIS, June 19 European Common Market officials see another difficult period approaching for the British economy and warn that hard economic realities will determine whether Britain finally wins admission in the market.

A 100-year-old water main ruptured under Third Avenue and 42d Street last night, flooding the surrounding streets and basements of office towers and snarling heavy traffic over a wide area of the East Side.

CHASKA, Minn., June 19 (AP) One can detect a little bit of Ben Hogan in Ben Crenshaw, the mop-haired 18-year-old Texas schoolboy who emerged today as an amateur threat in the 70th United States Open golf championship.

Discount stores, restaurants and a leading juice producer were the major targets for the merger-minded yesterday. At the same time, two companies backed away from previously announced resort developments.
Mrs. Charles C. Bassine yesterday accused her husband, chairman of Spartans Industries, Inc., of fraud and misrepresentation in handling her finances and sued him for $6.2million.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 19 While the waterfront hummed with activity in preparation for tomorrow's start of the yacht race to Bermuda, important paper work was completed today for the most exciting of ocean competitions and for three shorter events that have served as tune-ups this week.

Twenty-five were expected but 76 appeared last Thursday at the Institute of Human Relations, 165 East 56th Street, for a "consultation" about the distaff side of the American intelligentsia's latest discovery the lower middle class.

SAN DIEGO, June 19 (AP) Mexico has held 24 men aboard two United States tuna boats prisoner for two weeks in a dispute over fishing rights, the manager of the American Tunaboat Association said today.

LONDON, June 19 Many pieces of conventional wisdom about British politics have gone down with Harold Wilson. And in those crumbled notions must lie part of the explanation for the greatest election upset here in a generation.

The defense lawyer for a plainclothes patrolman charged with lying when he denied illegal contacts with gamblers called as a witness yesterday the man who is prosecuting his client Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

Two of the top soccer clubs in the world, Racing Football Club of Argentina and A.C. Milan of Italy, attracted only 4,103 spectators to Yankee Stadium last night as the South Americans scored a 1-to-0 triumph.
WASHINGTON, June 19 Two-Vietnam veterans implicated in the killing of civilians in Songmy,Vietnam, were ordered today to stand trial before a military court on charges of murder and other offenses.

Connecticut College's 23d American Dance Festival in New London has announced the schedule for its six-week season, which is to include seven premieres. The new works listed so far are by Martha Graham, Meredith Monk James Cunningham and Lucas Hoving.

WASHINGTON, June 19 A special Federal grand jury will be convened in Jackson, Miss., on June 29 to investigate the fatal shooting of two students last month at Jackson State College, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today.

Timmy Breslin, newspaper columnist turned City Council President candidate turned novelist, has volunteered from Ireland where he is working on a new book some thoughts on the Democratic primary in New York.
"When a woman lengthens her skirts and grows her fingernails, it's a sign of crisis and economic depression. Subconsciously, she feels defensive."

The purchase by Stake Senator waldaba stewart of three dilapidated buildings in an area he proposed four months later for an urban renewal project has become the central issue in the bitter Democratic primary fights in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 19 Dr. William A. Wexler, president of B'nai B'rith, expressed confidence today that the Jewish service and charitable organization would be "fully vindicated" of charges that it had been used as a cover for some Israeli foreien-policy activities.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 19 (AP) Mrs. Jean Bredin Perkins, the wife of James A. Perkins, former president of Carnell University, died last night at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. She was 55 years old and lived at 18 Campbelton Circle.

CHASKA, Minn., June 19 Tony Jacklin continued to batter par today as the high winds that buffeted the competitors yesterday in the United States Open gulf championship vanished. As zephyrs replaced 41mile-an-hour winds at the Hazeltine National Golf Club course, the 25-year-old Englishman widened his margin to three strokes with a 36-hole aggregate of 141.

In its search for a chancellor, the Board of Education has commendably tried to find a man of the highest qualifications. Indeed, the change in the title of the office can be justified only by putting a premium on exceptional qualities of leadership which inspire the confidence and respect both of the educational bureaucracy and the community at large.
LONDON, June 19 Never a haunt of theatrical knights, the Royal Court Theater has coaxed two of them John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson into its production of David Storey's new Play, "Home."
Everyone, it seems, is trying to help the Yankeespresent Yankees, past Yankees, even players who have been rumored to be future Yankees.
Blue-chip issues led the stock market in a solid advance yesterday as the Dow-Jones indus-_ trial average, strong for the second straight day, moved ahead 7.74 points, to 720.43.

BOSTON, June 19 The New York Yankees, who are beginning to behave like the old Mets, went eight innings to night without getting a hit off Sonny Siebert of the Boston RedSox. Then, on five pitches in the ninth, their first four battern got four hits and four runs

BOSTON, June 19 Collectors who are buying vast quantities of ancient Chinese ceramics of the Tang Dynasty as well as plenty of modern fakes of them may now have a scientific technique to detect the frauds.

Transportation Secretary Joseph A. Volpe, during a visit here yesterday, rode an experimental train car, announced a $20-million grant for the Long Island railroad and said he hoped to initiate a Government test of downtown-to-downtown air service in the Northeast Corridor.

More than $700,000 in purses will be available today on a horse-racing program that includes four $100,000 events at Belmont Park, Hollywood Park, Arlington Park and Detroit Race Course, according to the Associated Press.
LONDON, June 19 When Harold Wilson was to speak outside London in the election campaign just ended, he went down to the station and took a train like anyone else. Well, almost like anyone else.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 19 New York State's new Superintendent of Banks, William T. Dentzer Jr., made his first public appearance before bankers here today and hinted broadly that he had no inclination to change dramatically the course of policy followed in the recent past.
Officials of the Board of Education said yesterday that the board had agreed in principle to grant a teacher's license to Judy Heumann, a 22 year-old polio victim who is confined to a wheel chair.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 19 A record time for the mile in tomorrow night's $30,850 Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway was deemed more than likely in discussions today around the paddock and barn areas.

LONDON, June 19 The result of the British general election took bookmakers, like everyone else, by surprise. Experienced as they are at calculating the odds they too were fooled by the public-opinion polls.

Bertram Schwartz, a lawyer, and professor of military law at the New York University Law School, died of a heart attack at his home yesterday. He was 57 years old and lived at 164-03 89th Avenue, Jamaica, Queens.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 19 (AP) Bombs exploded today at two branches of the Bank of America, shattering dozens of windows. The bombings were the latest in a series of violent acts against the nation's largest bank.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 19 Billy Ziobro of Ash Brook, trailing at one stage by six holes, rallied on the second round today to defeat Jeff Alpert of Florham Park, 3 and 1, and take the 69th New Jersey amateur golf championship.

American Ballet Theater dug into its history last night and came up with a gem. In 1942, toward the very end of his career, the great Russian choreographer Michel Fokine produced for the then very young and adventurous Ballet Theater a final version of one of his most famous ballets, "Petrouchka." During those early performances, Petrouchka was danced by Yurek Lazovsky, the Moor by Dimitri Romanoff and the Dancer by Lucia Chase.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 19 (AP) A military judge today denied a motion for the acquittal of one of four United States marines charged with murdering 16 Vietnamese women and children in Sonthang village on Feb. 16.
OTTAWA, June 19 An official commission recommended today that Canada radically relax her laws banning or restricting the use of narcotics.

Jesse Moss has a fireplace, a chandelier and old racing prints in his Fifth Avenue law office. His personal style is similarly adorned. At a news conference the other day, he described the State Racing Commissioner as "a lackey of the Jockey Club," charged that the building of Aqueduct and Belmont was "conceived in sin" and called for a "restoration of confidence" in thoroughbred racing.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 19 A series of surprise performances, including a collegiate record in the six-mile run by Bob Bertelsen of Ohio University, set the stage today for a dramatic windup to the 49th annual National Collegiate out door track and field championships.

DARIEN, Conn., June 19 The marriage of Miss Leslie Ann Martin and William Rowland Duncan 3d, who were graduated June 1 from Pembroke College and Brown University, respectively, took place here this afternoon. The Rev. H. Arthur Lane performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

If V.S. Naipaul moves effortlessly from his novelist's chair to the historian's desk in this chronicle of his native Trinidad, it is because that history is so fictional, a family story with living characters. The events are played out on the fringes of European national ambitions; the performers include mountebanks and incompe-...
CHICAGO, June 19, (UPI) A Chicago Policeman was shot to death today while sitting alone in his squad car while making out a report on the city's South Side.

The overwhelming passage by the House of a bill to modernize the postal service brings halfway to realization a major governmental reform. The wrangle over the bill's labor provisions obscured the fundamental nature of the contribution the measure can make to increasing the speed and efficiency of the mails.

ROME, June 19 A document purporting to describe recommendations by the Atlantic alliance for the transfer of American troops from West Germany to northern Italy because of Communist strength there was shown to members of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Chamber of Deputies yesterday. Today the Italian Foreign Ministry branded it a forgery.

WASHINGTON, June 19 The mutual fund industry appears to have incurred heavy liquidations of its shares in the early part of May, but then a turnaround to net sales in the second half of the month, according to figures collected by the Invest ment Company Institute.
Short-selling of stocks increased sharply in the last month, according to figures released yesterday by the New Yark Stock Exchange.

A program for party and electoral reform was outlined yesterday by Arthur J. Goldberg. At the same time, he assailed proposals for such reforms advanced three weeks ago by his opponent for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, Howard J. Samuels.
Governor Rockefeller has offered $250,000 in state matching funds if the city acquires the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater at 425 Lafayette Street, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization announced today that it had accepted the resignation of F.Lee Bailey, the Boston criminal lawyer, as its general counsel.
Out of technology can come more interesting forms of art. This was proved handsomely yesterday at a metalsmith show that opened in the Museum of Contemporary Crafts.

Samuel J. Melville, who a month ago admitted a plot to bomb eight Manhattan office buildings last fall, began a 13to-18-year prison term yesterday after being sentenced in heavily guarded Federal and state courtrooms.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 19 (AP) Communist pressure increased north of this capital today as fresh fighting was reported to have erupted on the road to the historic temples of Angkor.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The board of directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce endorsed today the economic policy of President Nixon as described in the President's speech two days ago.

Albert M. Thorne, vice president of the Oceanic Investing Company, died yesterday after a longg illness at New Rochelle (N. Y.) Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 38 Franklin Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.
Bill Freehan, Detroit Tigers' catcher, emerged as the biggest vote-getter yesterday in the first weekly release of fan balloting for the 1970 American League All-Star team.
WASHINGTON, June 19 New orders for durable goods, which have been moving erratically in recent months, rose $800-million in May, the Commerce Department estimated today.

The Cinderella-man of British politics turns out to be not Harold Wilson, winning his third straight election, but Edward Heath, one of the longest-shot victors since Harry S. Truman upset Thomas E. Dewey and the pollsters in 1948.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 The University of California's Board of Regents dismissed a Negro assistant professor of philosophy from the Los Angeles faculty today. The board said it moved because of statements she had made in four offcampus speeches.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19 (Reuters) Thailand's Premier, Thanom Kittikachorn, conferred with the principal American and South Vietnamese military commanders when he made an unexpected sevenhour visit to South Vietnam today.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 19 Surrounded by 200 friends and relatives who led lighted candles in a circle near the Jefferson Rotunda, Miss Barbara Jean Crispell and Richard Doane Johnson were married tonight on the Lawn of the University of Virginia.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., June 19 (AP) A girl was refused her diploma from Nichols Junior High School here today because she was wearing a midi-length dress.

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., June 19 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell criticized the House today for not acting on the Nixon Administration's proposed legislation aimed at curbing drug abuse and the narcotics traffic. He called it an appalling delay.
The new-issue market continued in the doldrums this week as only three companies made first public offerings of their common stock.

The American Symphony Orchestra League presented the Gold Baton Award, its highest honor, to Helen M. Thompson, manager of the New York Philharmonic, last night in Denver during its 25th national conference.

Jeremiah Titus Mahoney, a prominent lawyer and former judge who was once an allround athlete, died Thursday night at the Near York Athletic Club, where he had an apartment for the last four years. He would have been 92 years old next Tuesday.
SISOPHON, Cambodia, June 19 The flies that swarm through the tilting barracks seem to be in control of the decaying army garrison in this town in Cambodia's northwest.

CHITTAGONG, Pakistan, June 19 (AP) In a confidential report, a high-level economic committee has recommended that Pakistan devalue her rupee. It also has suggested the country defy pressure from the International Monetary Fund and continue to give bonus rates of exchanges to encourage exporters.

WASHINGTON, June 19 Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans denounced today statements made yesterday by one of his principal assistants on trade policy and he disclosed the resignation of the assistant, Kenneth N. Davis Jr.

Rents for most of the 1.3 million families in rent-controlled apartments will be raised up to 20 per cent to cover landlords' taxes, operating expenses and maintenance costs if Mayor Lindsay's computerized rent formula is approved by the City Council.
Members of the ManhattanBronx Postal Union voted yesterday to authorize a strike if a satisfatory postal reform bill is not passed by Congress.
STOCKHOLM, June 19 The United States team rested this afternoon while their rivals battled for second position in the world team championship here.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 19 John Humm of Rockville Links had a built-in rooting section today as he gained the quarterfinal round of the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club. The rooting section cost the 51year-old Humm $14 in caddie fees that remained in the familY.

WINNETKA, Ill., June 19 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Hahn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Padraig deNormandie Hahn, to Theodore A. Brennen, son of Theodore W. Brennen of Toledo, Ohio, and Mrs. Arthur E. Backus of Chicago. The wedding is planned for late October.

A recurrent theme of the Middle East debate is "no weight to conquest." President Johnson sounded that theme in 1968 and, more recently, Secretary of State Rogers maintained that any changes in the 1949 armistice lines between the Arab States and Israel "should not reflect the weight of conquest and should be confined to insubstantial alterations required for mutual security."

HARTFORD, June 19 As the Republican State Convention opened here today, the big question was not who would be nominated for the top offices but whether challengers would be able to force the holding of the first primary election in Connecticut's history.

The flow of funds into the nation's savings and loan associations improved substantially during May compared to the depressed levels of last fall and winter, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday.

Year in and year out an average of 8,000 people living on 5,000 miles of streets in Queens complain to the Overlook office of the Parks Department about trees, and the pattern of complaints is always the same.

The Senate Armed Services Committee has prudently trimmed from President Nixon's Safeguard antiballistic missile (ABM) program a small but significant proposal to begin work on a thin area defense against China. But the committee went on to endorse the bulk of a $1.5-billion Administration request to continue development of two Safeguard sites approved narrowly last year and to begin work on a third site to defend Minuteman missile bases against Soviet attack.

NEW DELHI, June 19 A three-nation task force seeking peace in Cambodia was reported today to have failed in its efforts to persuade New Delhi to endorse its approach for solving the Indochina problem.

MONTREAL, June 19 (AP) The home of Jean Louis Levesque, a financier who lives in the wealthy suburb of Outremont, was the target of a terrorist bombing today. The bombing was the 12th in the Montreal area in less than two months and the third this week.
The campaign for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator has been characterized by some politicians as four men in search of an issue.

The lawyer for three Black Panthers charged with a machine-gun attack on a Jersey City police station 18 months ago obtained subpoenas yesterday requiring a court appearance by two New York Times reporters who wrote stories about the attack.
David Pasmantier died at the Bronx Lebanon Hospital yesterday. He was 71 years old and lived at 10 Park Avenue.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 19 The Connecticut Conservation Association, a private organization, has filed a $150-million suit against four towns and cities and six companies on the state's coastline, charging them with polluting Long Island Sound and destroying ecologically important marshlands.

MIAMI, June 19 (AP) A dusk-to-dawn curfew in Negro neighborhoods was lifted today after 300 volunteer black peacemakers restored temporary calm to Miami, which has been wracked by four days of racial violence.

MANILA, June 19 (AP) A Philippine court found the commander of the United States' Clark Air Force Base and a former member of his staff guilty of contempt today and ordered them jailed for failing to produce an American airman accused of abducting a Filipino girl.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 16:
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Black Panther party announced today plans for a Revolutionary People's Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia on Labor Day, Sept. 7.
Mrs. Abraham Goldberg, mother of Bernard Goldberg, president of Schenley Industries, Inc., died at the Albert Einstein Hospital here yesterday. She was 77 years old.
Thomas K. Happel Jr., president of the Dairy division of Pet Incorporated in Johnson City, Tenn., died Monday at Memorial Hospital there, after a long illness. He was 56 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 19 The United States reached an important milestone today in the postwar development of arms technology by announcing that, it had deployed multiple warheads on some American Intercontinental missiles.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 19 (UPI) The Long Island Railroad agreed to drop charges against three commuters who refused to show their commutation tickets to a conductor in Valley Stream last January.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz says unemployment will probably climb above the 5 per cent rate recorded in May, the highest monthly figure since 1965.

Following on the heels of a Wage settlement that it is estimated will cost $70-million over the next three years, the B. F. Goodrich Tire Company announced yesterday it would charge more for its tires beginning July 1.

Only an act of God could have stopped the Mets and Tom Seaver last night and one nearly did. With the New Yorkers trouncing the Philadelphia Phils by 9-0 in the second inning, a heavy downpour halted the game.
WASHINGTON, June 19 The Federal Trade Commission moved today to outlaw the interstate shipment of unordered merchandise.

PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) The vice president and general manager of AAMCO Automatic Transmissions, Inc., of Bridgeport, Pa., denied today charges by the Federal Trade Commission that the company uses deceptive means to get repair jobs.

ALBANY, June 19 The four candidates for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator started to debate issues in a television program here today that quickly became a three-on-one atack of Representative Richard L. Ottinger's campaign spending.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 19 Heike de Leyer has been riding horses most of his 13 years, but never had entered a jumper competition until this year.

NEW HAVEN, June 19 A psychiatric report on George Sams Jr., a key prosecution witness against Bobby G. Seale in connection with the slaying of a fellow Black Panther, has found him to be stable and intelligent enough to give reliable testimony.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 19 Communist forces are said to have stepped up troop movements in southern Laos amid indications that they are stocking the region as an expanded supply base for the war in Vietnam.
"We live here, we don't want you here!" the gangling Puerto Rican youth shouted. "Get the hell out of here, we don't need you!"

WASHINGTON, June 19 President Nixon left for Camp David today to resolve what his senior associates describe as one of the most difficult decisions he has faced: Whether to approve or veto legislation lowering the voting age from 21 to 18.

The welcome mat is out for American business in three African countries now recovering from severe setbacks Nigeria, the Congo (Kinshasa) and Ghana but "Africans are determined to do their own thing" in any new ventures.

The Nixon Administration, in a reversal of plans, decided yesterday not to guarantee up to $200-million of bank loans for the financially troubled Penn Central Company and its huge railroad subsidiary, the Penn Central Transportation Company.

Even in the school for plainclothes policemen, many of the students were said to have complained about being off the street for the 30 days needed for the course and missing what they called "the nut"payoffs to the police by gamblers and narcotics pushers.

CORONA DEL MAR, Calif., June 19 Miss Susan B. Mooney, a former speech writer and legislative aide on the staff of Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut, and the Senator's son, Christopher John Dodd, plan to be wed in August.
It was raining and thundering outdoors during the New York Philharmonic Promenade concert Thursday night at Philharmonic Hall.
DARIEN, Conn., June 19 Miss Hester Kingsland Dall and Harry Mark St. John 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. St. John Jr. of Avon and Masons Island, Mystic, were married here this morning.

Ion Buzea, the Rumanian tenor who made his debut with the Metropolitan Opera earlier this season, added the role of Edgardo in "Lucia di Lammermoor" to his repertory there in Thursday night's performance of the Donizetti work.
HOLLYWOOD, June 19 (AP) Television, and movie writers have given their union's governing council the authority to call a strike against major Hollywood producers.

Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Gleboff have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Gleboff, to William Henry McDavid Jr., son of the late Mr. and. Mrs. McDavid of Garden City, L. I. The wedding is planned for fall.
FRANKLIN, Pa., Saturday, June 20 (AP)-Thousands of gallons of oil continued to feed a fire raging at a multimillion dollar oil refinery early today, but firefighters said they were making headway.
BRUSSELS, June 19 (AP) Five of Europe's largest aircraft manufacturers have agreed to cooperate to fight American competition.
A top editor at Harper Row lost his job yesterday in the midst of a dispute growing out of the publishing company's decision to halt the expansion of its fiction list.

Cathy Honey will be the strong favorite to take the 54th running of the Coaching Club American Oaks today at Belmont Park. Hastings Harcourt regards his Florida-bred filly so highly that he has paid a supplementary fee of $10,000 to put her into the important 1 mile test.

Howard J. Samuels said yesterday that his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, Arthur J. Goldberg, represented the passe liberalism of "the thirties, forties and fifties, which hasn't worked." Mr. Samuels said he, on the other hand, exemplified "the new liberalism of the seventies, which is how to make government function."

Planned Parenthood of New York City announced yesterday that a citywide abortion information and referral service would be in operation on July 1, when the state's new abortion law takes effect. The service will advise women on abortions and refer them to doctors and hospitals willing and able to perform the operations.
LONDON, June 19 More than most traditional governing parties returning to power after an interlude, the Conservative party takes office in Britain with a specific mandate for change.
SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 19 John Gentile Jr. of the Patterson Club at Fairfield, Conn. added the Westchester amateur golf championship today to the Connecticut amateur title he won last year.

PARIS, June 19 European conservatives were cheered and Socialists dismayed today at the victory of the British Tories, It was widely taken to confirm a craving by "the silent majority" for stability in a world beset by inflation, war and other frightening changes.

RICHMOND, June 19 This state's Republican hierarchy, including Gov. Linwood Holton, has spurned overtures from United States Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., a former Democrat, for their endorsement of his independent candidacy for reelection.
The flying beer can and the shattered soft-drink bottle are heard in the land sounds as American as roadside and beachfront litter piling up in summer.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mostly higher yesterday in slightly heavier trading.
WASHINGTON, June 19 President Nixon conveyed his congratulations to Edward Heath today and his "personal sympathy" to Harold Wilson, the defeated Prime Minister.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 19 Levi Smith Sr., patriarch of one of Vermont's most prominent families and retired president and chairman of the Burlington Savings Bank, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 84.
BELGRADE, Yougoslavia, June 19 A group of 96 damp but determined Indians from Uganda entered the second day of a sit-in strike in the driveway of the British Embassy here today.

EMPORIA, Kan., June 19 (AP) F. G. (Fran) Weich, an internationally known track and field coach who trained a number of Olympic athletes, died today at the University of Kansas Medical Center in Kansas City after a brief illness with leukemia. He was 74 years old.

When politicians forecast the outcome of the primary election contest in the 21st Congressional District a few months ago, the result seemed clear: an easy victory for Herman Badillo if he chose to run.
MUNSAN, South Korea, June 16 The people of Munsan are worried.
The Freeport Sulphur Company has announced that it has obtained final agreements and necessary appproval from various governments for its $120million copper project in West Irian, Indonesia.

Platinum futures rose yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange with no particular news to trigger the advance. The January contract, with 36 sales, went to $156.50 an ounce from $154.60 an ounce the day before. The October contract rose to $154.50 an ounce from $152.50 the previous day.
LOS ANGELES, June 16 "We don't have too many people," Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel remarked recently. "The trouble is that they're concentrated in the wrong places."

Business and industry representatives opposed yesterday the return of subway operations to the city, while politicians, straphangers and an 11-yearold student were highly critical of the operation of the system by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
LONDON, June 19 Champagne corks popped in some London brokerage offices today as financial markets gave Britain's new Conservative Government a huge vote of confidence.

Members of the Socialist party, one of the oldest political institutions in the country, gathered here yesterday for their national convention and immediately heard warnings that attempts on the left to form a new third party would "guarantee the re-election of Richard M. Nixon in 1972."

LONDON, June 19 The Rev. Ian Paisley, the fiery Protestant extremist and potential embarrassment to the Conservative party leadership, won a House of Commons seat from Northern Ireland today on a backlash of Protestant resentment against the Roman Catholic minority.

Twenty-five years ago there was another profound British political upset. The Conservative party led by Winston Churchill went down to defeat before the Labor party in what was described at the time as one of the most stunning election surprises in the history of democracy.

HOLMDEL, N. J., June 19 Only a few hundred dauntless fans of country and Western music made their way through the heavy rain that pelted this area last night to attend the first program in a three-night country music festival at the Garden State Arts Center. The festival is being presented through tomorrow night by WJRZ, a Hackensack radio station that specializes in country music.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 19 (AP) A secret spy satellite equipped with a television camera and X-ray sensors sped tonight toward a lonely outpost high over Southeast Asia to keep watch on the Soviet Union, Red China and North Vietnam.
LONDON, June 19 Edward Heath moved into 10 Downing Street tonight as the new Conservative party Prime Minister of Britain.

LONDON, June 19 For the London grass-court tennis championship at the Queens Club tomorrow, Rod Laver will meet John Newcombe, just as the seedings have them doing in the Wimbledon tournament, which opens next week.

BALTIMORE, June 19 Two private citizens filed suit today in an attempt to force the Justice Department to sign a draft indictment proposed by a special grand jury investigating the alleged corruption of government officials.

MADRID, June 19 The Spanish Government has begun to levy fines against opposition figures who signed a statement to Secretary of State William P. Rogers last month expressing concern over the current negotiations on United States military bases in Spain.
Dr. Leon Paul Lewithin, senior clinical assistant at St. Clare's Hospital, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 73 years old and lived at 325 East 57th Street.
A Queens soldier was granted the right yesterday to try to prove in Federal Court his claim that the war in Vietnam is unconstitutional.

LONDON, June 19 British poll takers, widely assailed for their mistaken election forecasts, excused themselves today by arguing that an unexpectedly low turnout had upset the general prediction of a strong Labor party victory.

LIMA, Peru, June 19 The Peruvian military Government tonight expelled Joseph McGowan Jr., The Associated Press bureau chief here, charging that he had insulted the Peruvian national dignity and Peruvian womanhood.
CLEVELAND, June 19 A federally financed study to determine the feasibility of reserving freeway lanes for buses and car-pool vehicles during rush hours has started here.
David Irwin, who survived a 2,000-mile trip alone across the Arctic in 1935, died Thursday after a brief illness at his home in Scotrun, Pa. He was 60 years old.

TRENTON, June 19 A bookkeeper testified today that his employers, contractors on the South Side sewer in Newark, had "apparently" issued checks to pay what the Government has called fictitious bills even before the bills were received.

BONN, June 19 Heeding a central bank warning, the West German Parliament shelved today a bill for higher tax allowances on workers income and gradual abolition of a surtax on self-employed and corporate income.
LONDON, June 19 (UPI) Harold Wilson said today that he and his wife would have a housing problem when they move out of the Prime Minister's official residence at 10 Downing Street.
WASHINGTON-"If I had ever learned to type," Elizabeth P. Hoisington mused, "I never would have made brigadier general."

ALBERT CITY, Iowa, June 19 (UPI) Seven construction workers plunged 130 feet to their death today when the scaffolding and steel girders of a grain elevator roof collapsed 15 minutes before the men were to have quit for the day.

CAIRO, June 19 An authoritative Cairo voice cautioned the Arabs today that they must not expect the Soviet Union to support them indefinitely with costly military aid if they persisted in bickering among themselves and refused to undertake decisive, coordinated action to bring an end to the drawn-out conflict with Israel.
Dr. Sydney Chapman, to many the grand old man of geophysics, died Tuesday in Boulder (Colo.) Memorial Hospital after a heart attack and stroke. He was 82 years old.

Miniaturization, which has done so much for electronics, is now being applied to the Broadway musical theater at the Pig 'n' Whistle, a twostory restaurant in what was once President Taft's town house at 36 West 48th Street.
OTTAWA, June 19 Following are excerpts from the final chapter, "The Issues Some Interim Recommendations," of a report to the Government published today by the LeDain Commission on Canada's drug laws:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 20 Saybrook garden courtyard at Yale University here was the setting today for the afternoon wedding for Miss Diane McClure and Lieut. George Penn Holsenbeck, U.S.N.R.

WASHINGTON, June 20 A significant change in the plan for direct popular election of the President, designed to promote broader support, has been advanced by two members of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., June 20 Miss Barbara Ann Brown, a junior at Jackson College of Tufts University, was married in the South Presbyterian Church here this afternoon to James David McNitt 3d, a senior at Tufts.

At the end of this absorbing textual anatomy of Thomas Hardy, J. Hillis Miller likens his author to an anthropologist structure-hunting among the Dorset tribes and presents himself as the critic in his turn structurehunting "a watcher watching the watcher watch his characters." And now the wheel comes full circle: another Dorset novelist joins the chain of spies.
ATLANTA, June 20 (AP) "Unless you have bread and a pad, please find your thing somewhere else or face a bad scene," Mayor Sam Massell has advised.

ROME, June 20 Italian newspapers today quoted Giovanni Agnelli, chairman of Fiat, as having told correspondents in Moscow that his concern was considering participation in an international consortium to assist the Soviet Union in building a big truck plant.
A 25-game basketball schedule, with 15 games at Cole Field House and clashes with three of last season's tournament teams, will be played by the University of Maryland this season.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., June 20 A Gordon setter, known on the circuit as Valor, showed his mettle in the ring at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds today when he was named the best of 1,263 dogs at the MidHudson Kennel Club show.
Forty law students from schools across the country began a summer program here last week with the Legal Aid Society to help the poor with their legal problems.

WASHINGTON The principal question raised last week by Hubert Humphrey's return to the campaign trail was how the effervescent Minnesotan had been restrained for 18 whole months from announcing that he was back in business.

While Arthur J. Goldberg and Howard J. Samuels have traveled the state for the past three months in their race for the Democratic nominations for the Democratic nomination for Governor in Tuesday's primary election, their respective headquarters in Manhattan have issued a series of "position papers" or "programs" designed to show what kind of Governor each man would be.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) A 12-man House committee left today to investigate United States involvement in Southeast Asia.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I. (UPI) A former New York Giant halfback, Dick Pesonen, has joined the Long Island Bulls of the Atlantic Coast Football League as coordinator of offense.
After 5 P.M. (New York time) today, the Federale Internationale de Football Association, the world governing soccer body, will start searching for a new World Cup.

The city's first clinic for the treatment of sickle cell anemia has been opened in the pediatric outpatient department sponsored in Brooklyn jointly by the Downstate Medical Cenner and Kings County Hospital.
LONDON, June 20 Richard Crossman, Secretary of State for Social Services in the defeated Labor Government, is to become editor of the New Statesman, a left-wing weekly magazine.
To the neighborhood kids, the van Summerns' new home in Wilton, Conn., is "Fort Apache."

Msgr. Leo G. Farley, a former Fire Department chaplain, died at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. He was 62 years old and lived in Montrose, N.Y., where he had been pastor of St. Christopher's Roman Catholic Church since 1962.

CHASKA, Minn., June 20 Before beginning the third round of the United States Open Golf championship, Dave Hill, who had moved into second place yesterday three strokes back of Tony Jacklin of England, was fined $150.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 20 Howard B. Keck's Fiddle Isle, given Bill Shoemaker's 5,959th winning ride, beat Fort Marcy by a slim neck today in the $100,000 Hollywood Park Invitation Turf Handicap.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 20 Harold Seroff of 3836 Westfield Avenue, president of the Intercontinental Funding Corporation, a division of the Intercontinental Life Insurance Company in Newark, died yesterday at the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 45.

PITTSBURGH A young man who had recently earned his master's degree in business administration and then gone to work for the Aluminum Company of America, told the chief financial officer of Alcoa the other day that the concern's cost accounting was "really out of the Dark Ages."

LONDON The political correspondents in Britain, the experts and the pollsters know now how their American equivalents felt on Nov. 3, 1948. Not since Harry Truman's surprise victory over Thomas E. Dewey have so many people been so wrong about an election.

SOME years ago, Glenn Gould's accountant brought him the good word. The young Ca nadian pianist could give up riding the concert circuit. He was delighted. Big-time public performance had brought him fame and fortune in a relatively short time, but he did not enjoy it and was delighted at the prospect of putting it behind him.

The appliance industry, as the automobile industry did a few years ago, is going compact in a big way. And, as with the big Detroit car makers, the appliance producers of the Midwest and South have apparently been spurted into making compact models by the inroads of a rising flow of imports.
Goshen is an anachronism in 1970. It is a 19th-century village 85 miles from Manhattan. The frenetic society so close by hasn't disturbed it yet.

Columbia College's 1970 student yearbook has scrapped traditional concepts of class annuals and candidly discusses sex and drug use on campus, race relations at the university, and the political protests that have racked the school for the last two years.

LOS ANGELES There was little doubt about what action the California Board of Regents would take in the Angela Davis case as its members assembled here last week for a two-day meeting. Miss Davis, a young, black Communist party member, would lose her job as acting assistant professor of philosophy at the University of California at Los Angeles.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 Extraordinary security measures have been taken at the Fairfield County Hunt Club following a telephoned threat to burn the barns at the Fairfield County horse show.

NEWARK, June 20 With the corridor outside his City Hall offices lined with cartons overflowing with pictures, awards and other personal memorabilia, Hugh J. Addonipledged the full cooperation of his administration this week to the orderly-transfer of authority to Mayor-elect Kenneth A. Gibson.
MADRID, June 20 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird strongly endorsed today the eventual entry of Spain into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

In New Jersey early this month legislative action snuffed out Rutgers University's hope that it might soon have a full four-year medical school. In California a few days earlier, voters defeated a proposed multi-million dollar bond issue designed to increase substantially the state's medical education facilities. Meanwhile, all over the United States existing medical schools are caught in a deepening financial crisis which has brought some to the edge of bankruptcy.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 There will be no Coast Guard vessel or patrol plane accompanying the NewportBermuda race yachts this year. The Cruising Club of America sponsors did not request such assistance for two reasons, said Bill Robinson, secretary of the race committee.

STRATFORD, CONN. THERE must be some mistake. For all our years "All's Well That Ends well" has been catalogued, and dismissed, as one of Shakespeare's most careless and least attractive dark comedies, not even dark enough to merit special attention in as age like our own with a taste for grotesquerie.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 20 Demands have increased here that the United States transfer to the local police, and to the courts, judicial jurisdiction over crimes committed against Okinawans by American servicemen and civilian employes of the United States Government.

In a six-month survey of more than 5,000 students at 39 randomly selected colleges and universities, two Swarthmore College psychologists have concluded that the Vietnam war has greatly changed students' attitudes toward careers, parents, religion, politics and the United States in general.

CHIHUAHUA, Mexico Two borderlinking roads that are in various stages of improvement, notably paving, are already bringing an increased number of American tourists to this capital of Mexico's largest state (of the same name). And Chihuahua, with its cathedral, many modern hotels, native products and historic shrines to revolutionary heroes, is ready for them.

DENVER Mayor Lindsay left the five day meeting of the United States Conference of Mayors here last Wednesday with a strengthened reputation in city halls around the country and his future in national politics, in the view of many Mayors, full of promise, but still several years off.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 19 Strange white specks floated over this grim, hilly city, dancing higher than the minarets. Seen from the barren countryside, they somehow seem magical and without substance, as though they were a trick of the desert sun.

ALGIERS, June 20 A fourday state visit by King Faisal of Saudi Arabia has served to underscore the determination of President Houari Boumediene of Algeria to concentrate on his country's internal problems and to avoid meddling in those of other Arab lands.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 20 (AP) Bert Campaneris drove in four runs with a double and homer today to pace the Oakland A's to an 8-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia An American official here who was defending the Nixon Administration's low level of assistance, for Cambodia said the other day: "You've got to remember that the President said we didn't come into Cambodia to save the Cambodians." The Cambodians are fast beginning to realize this.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 20 Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N.J., regained the women's Eastern clay-court tennis championship today.
MEXICO CITY, June 20(AP) A goal by Wolfgang Overath at the 27-minute mark gave West Germany a 1-0 victory today over Uruguay and third place in the 1970 World Cup soccer championship.

The qualifying requirements for dogs whose owners want to enter them in next year's Westminster Kennel Club show has been made easier through a reduction in the necessary championship points. Last year and the year before a dog needed to have won a major, or at least 3
WHAT TO DO "...3. Express your views. Write the stations, the networks, advertisers, the FCC ..." "How to Talk Back to Your Television Set," page 220.

Pen-points scratch, typewriter keys clack, wheels turn, presses roll, and out tumbles another bunch of "old reliables" Grimm, Andersen, Kipling, Lear, et al. done up as picture books in 1970 for the entertainment and edification of the youth of 1984. Anything for them to remember when they get to placard-bearing age?

In 1967, after 50 years of of intermittent debate, New York State scrapped its noisy convention system of selecting statewide candidates and adopted the primary election system, supported for so long by good government groups and newspaper editorials. The first full test of the primary law will be held on Tuesday when enrolled Democrats choose their candidates for Governor, United States Senator and lesser offices.

The hero of "Bech: A Book" is a writer in trouble. In the mid-fifties Henry Bech's first novel brought him considerable reputation, especially among the young, but after that the books got worse and worse, until a severe artistic block formed.
KINGSTON, R.J., June 20 (UPI) The dean of the University of Rhode Island Summer school says he is canceling a course on revolution, as directed by the university president, Werner A. Baum.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 20 Miss Nancy Whitney Gerry, a great-granddaughter of the late Edward H. Harriman, the railroad magnate, was married here this afternoon to Geoffrey Lewis Groat, headmaster of the Joseph Kershaw Academy in Camden, S.C.
If the liquefied natural gas (LNG) industry has its way, millions of consumers will not only be heating and cooking with LNG, they'll also be fueling their cars and freezing food with it.

ORANGE, N.J., June 20 Miss Ann Dixon Schickhaus and David Carpenter Titus were married here this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church by the Right Rev. Leland Stark, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark. The rector, the Rev. Richard H. Schoolmaster, assisted.

SALT LAKE CITY, June 20 (AP) Jeff Borowiak of the University of California, Los Angeles, defeated Roscow Tanner of Stanford, 10-8, 9-7, 7-5, for the singles title of the National Collegiate tennis championships.

HONG KONG, June 20 There is strong evidence from Communist China that Peking has gone far toward dismembering the vast, northern, crescent-shaped territory called the Inner Mongolian Autonomous Region.

IMAGINE first the ultimate jazz bar: a soulful, Sa royanesque House of Losers, buried in some impossible location like the dockside warehouse district of Manhattan. Then imagine night in the city, with the fumes of rape, murder and mayhem rising from the pavement and the blocks lengthening into miles in the eerie urban silence.
Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., may be the site of the first national collegiate lacrosse championship game in 1971.

Miss Lucy Elisabeth Schneider and John Fergus McDiarmid, 1968 graduates of Swarthmore College, were married in the Community Church of New York yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wayne Knoll, a Jesuit priest, who is studying for a doctorate in English at Harvard, as is the bride. Mr. McDiarmid is a candidate for a doctorate in English at Yale.

The Soviet Union increased its trade last year with nonCommunist countries especially developing nations much more rapidly than with other Communist countries. In line with this spurt, Soviet-American trade in 1969 had one of its sharpest rises in years.

NEWARK Right after the Tuesday night election returns showed that Kenneth A. Gibson had become the first in what promises to be a long list of black mayors here, two black youths, both of them grinning from ear to ear, pranced past a cordon of white city patrolmen drawn around City Hall in the event that a Gibson defeat might ignite another violent black rampage in the city. As

In December, 1945, President Harry S. Truman sent Gen. George C. Marshall on the most frustrating diplomatic mission in American history an attempt to bring the Chinese Nationalists and Communists into peaceful agreement. The Communists accused Marshall of aiding the Nationalists. The Nationalists rejected Marshall's suggestions for reform and negotiation and instead welcomed civil war to the finish. They lost.

DETROIT, June 20 The United Automobile Workers are willing to maintain close ties with individual A.F.L.-C.I.O. unions, but not to mend the historic break with the parent labor federation, according to Leonard Woodcock, the new U.A.W. president.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 20 (AP) A concentrated mail campaign to recruit 40,000 Roman Catholic clergymen for the antiwar movement has been announced.
Two new rivals have been added to City College's 1970 soccer schedule: The United States Merchant Marine Academy of Kings Point, L.I., and New Haven College.

The smell of charred wood and smoke was strong one recent morning in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. On a garbage-filled sidewalk a young Puerto Rican girl was berating a group of newsmen covering an outbreak of violence of the previous night.
The second annual American Kennel Club-sanctioned B. Match sponsored by the Great Dane Club of America will be held today, at the Salisbury Park East Meadow in Westbury, L.I.

A politician looks out across the country and sees voters bunched together in Congressional or election Districts. A marketing man has a much different view. To him those are all consumers out there and they live in households, each with its own buying power and life style.

Jerome Kretchmer, the head of the city's Environmental, Protection Administration, said yesterday that his agency would shortly propose regulations prohibiting the sale of leaded gasoline in the city.

Brazil and Italy, two of the most colorful and exciting teams in the tournament, will meet for the World Cup soccer championship today in a game to be shown on closed-circuit television at Madison Square Garden and the New York Coliseum. The telecast will begin at 2 P.M., live and in color via satellite with English commentary.

TEL AVIV, June 20 (Reuters) Israeli jets pounded Egyptian military targets in the Suez Canal region for the 21st consecutive day, hitting fortified positions and artillery sites, a military spokesman said here today. All planes returned safely to base, he added.

In his first starting assignment since a sore elbow put him out of action on May 22, Jerry Koosman pitched well enough to win for the New York Mets last night, but didn't. Philadelphia's Chris Short, another left-hander of note, outpitched him by holding the Mets to four hits and posted a 2-1 victory as the Phils won on a walk with the bases full.

"A wall is a wall, is a wall," but the construction industry is not an industry, not an industry, not an industry. Then what is it?. Probably this country's and this century's greatest anachronism. The innovative and the inventive have been sadly lacking and hence we have "to pay through the nose" for a large slice of our living expenses.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J. June 20 Miss Lora McNeill Elkinton and John Hamilton Miller 3d were married here this afternoon in St. John's on the Mountain Episcopal Church. The Rev. James L. Johnson performed the ceremony.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 20 (AP) Bob Clark, concerned with defending his National Collegiate Athletic Association golf title, wants no part of the pro tour.

OLD FORGE, N.Y. When you run out of nature's own lakes and the last acre of open shorefront holds a bright new summer home, what is more natural than to build some new lakes? Nothing the size of Lake Mead, because that would be out of place, and slightly grotesque in the Adirondack Forest Preserve, but, say, eight small lakes, the largest a mile long and maybe one-half to three quarters of a mile across?

ROME, June 20 A group of experts has recommended that Italy spend $20-billion over the next 15 years to fight air and water pollution and thus save much of the nation's cultural heritage that would otherwise be destroyed.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 20 A survey by the Gallup Poll indicated today that favorable opinions of Vice President Agnew outweighed the unfavorable by a 5-to-3 ratio but that only one person in five thinks of him as Presidential timber.

While the United States and the Soviet Union negotiate in Vienna on slowing down the arms race, that race, in the opinion of many experts, is in danger of escalating to a new level. This arises from the fact that both the United States and the Soviet Union have been developing MIRV's Multiple Independently Targeted Re-entry Vehicles.

WASHINGTON Twentyfour hours before President Nixon went on the air last week to discuss the national economy, the Senate Democratic Policy Committee adopted a resolution whose clauses provided a broadly accurate if partisan picture of where the economy stands:
ADEN, Southern Yemen, June 20 The adjoining Yemen Arab Republic has appealed to United Nations agencies and several countries for help because of an extreme drought that has lasted for several years.
HONG KONG, June 20 (Reuters) The Hanoi radio said today that United States aircraft and ground forces had fired on a number of North Vietnamese villages during the past week.
EUGENE, Ore., June 20 Once again, a court has ordered the removal of the Skinner Butte Cross, a 51-foot concrete cross that overlooks this university city from a hilltop park.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 20 (UPI) Introducing legislation to abolish the post of Selective Service Director, Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republican of New York, charged today to let new standards for conscientious objectors set by the director, Curtis Tarr, Discriminate against young men who have not head a college education.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 20 Construction of an unusual $155-million hydroelectric power project on Raccoon Mountain near Chattanooga will start in July, according to the Tennessee Valley Authority. A $6,353,073 contract has been let to the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company, York, Pa., for four hydraulic pump-turbine units.

Swinging a golf club just might be the most unnatural movement an athlete has to master, but hockey players, accustomed to flailing a puck with a stick, apparently have less difficulty with the game than other professionals.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 20 the Cragwood Stable's favored Ribofilio, champion 2year-old of England in 1968, finally gained his first triumph on American soil today by winning the $29,687 first section of the Longfellow Handicap at Monmouth Park.

We call it the summer solstice, and it took place yesterday. Today, in the terms of the almanac, it is summer. Now the earth begins to swing back on its trunnions, past the year's longest span of daylight and toward the equinox of autumn. The long summer days will slowly shrink, for though summer is April and May grown into June and July, it is also June and July ripening into September and October.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 20 Older delegates to the second World Food Congress reacted strongly yesterday against a co-ordinated attempt by 250 participating students and youth leaders to concentrate the debate on political issues.

The program to reform the nation's postal system, which had been moving at Pony Express pace for months, spurted last week when the House, in a 359to-24 vote, passed a sweeping reform and pay-rise bill. The measure would turn the Post Office Department into an independent Government agency operated by an 11-member commission.

WASHINGTON, June 20 The Congress, the Supreme Court, and the Director of Selective Service have now all spoken on what beliefs or convictions should relieve a man from serving in the armed forces of the United States, but the result is such a tangle of conflicting views that even a draft board of judges, saints and philosophers would scarcely know what to make of it.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 20 James D. Johnson, who opposed Senator J.W. Fulbright for re-election in 1968, is trying to amend the Arkansas Constution so that he can lead an effort to recall the Senator.

A FUNNY thing happened to the Russian Carpa thian Church on 13th Street between Second and Third Avenues on its way to becoming an Off Broadway theater: it became a movie set. Beside the entrance, on a black signboard set with white plastic letters, were the words:

Irv Kintisch, who was appointed head track coach at Columbia earlieir in the year has been elected president of the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America Coaches Association. He had served as first vice president last year.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market advanced last week in comparatively light trading.

ALONG with stock companies performing in barns and symphony orchestras playing in the open air, the historical drama-pageant is becoming entrenched as a summertime phenomenon across the United States.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 20 Joseph Pisani, a New York State Assemblyman from New Rochelle, and his son, Frank, rowed to a six-foot victory in the father-and-son doubles event in the 102d annual New York Athletic Club open regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon today. The Pisanis defeated Ed Good Jr. and Ed Good 3d of Manhasset, L.I., in the 1,000-meter event.

Christ Church, United Methodist, was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Selina (Tina) Schroeder Croll, who made her debut here in 1961, to Albert Constantine Bellas, an associate with the investment banking house of Dillon, Read Co.

WATCH HILL, R.I., June 20 The Watch Hill Chapel was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Katherine Gatch Orthwein to James McClelland Snowden Jr., who is an assistant vice president of Glore Forgan Staats, Inc., investment bankers in New York.
The Joint Distribution Committee, the American welfare agency that aids needy Jews the world over, assisted 323,000 men, women and children in 25 countries at a cost of $23,382,000 last year.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 Columbia George, bowed tendons and all, ruled the track tonight just as much as Roland Beaulieu, his New England driver, wanted him to at Roosevelt Raceway.

SEWICKLEY, Pa., June 20 Miss Sarah McKnight Willard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Willard Jr., and Charles Devens Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Devens of Milton, Mass., were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Benedict Williams, assisted by the Rev. Robert Hetherington in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church here.

In the two months since the Apollo 13 spacecraft was damaged by an explosion that aborted its moon mission and jeopardized the lives of its threeman crew, the accident has been the subject of an exhaustive investigation by a board of scientists. Last week the board issued its report: The accident was caused by human and mechanical failure, management errors by industry contractors, and gross negligence on the part of ground crews.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I The specter of legalized gambling, which has been hovering over this unsophisticated island for a dozen years, seems to have been chased away at last. The news brought cheers from those of us who love this place and want it to be left alone to go its own Yankee-independent way.
CLAREMONT, Calif., June 20 The American Association of Theological Schools has voted to accept Jewish seminaries into its membership.
MADRID, June 20 Spain's lawyers called today for a general amnesty of political prisoners and the abolition of special political courts.

ERIVAN, U.S.S.R. The most sensitive segment of the Soviet Union's ring of allies is Czechoslovakia, a country which always wanted to become a kind of East-West bridge and never could. It is therefore noteworthy that the Communist propaganda machine should have chosen Prague's ideological monthly to make a sharp attack on the "bridge-building" efforts of U.S. policy.

THE Customs Bureau has prepared a flyer en titled "An Explanation to You the Traveler," which warns of delays that visitors to this country can expect at international ports of entry during the present tourist season.
TORONTO, June 20 (AP) Almoner came from sixth place on the far turn and outbattled Franfreluche in the stretch for a three-quarter length victory in the $88,300 Queen's Plate Stakes today.
VALHALLA, N.Y., June 20 Grasslands, the Westchester County hospital, celebrated its 50th anniversary here this week with a ceremony honoring those who had worked at the hospital for 10 years or more.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 20 A small group of Indians attempted yesterday to make a citizen's arrest here of the president of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 Miss Lynn Prentice Powers and Jaromir Babicka were married here this evening in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. Edward Adkins.

MEXICO CITY, June 20 If Italy is to win the World Cup tomorrow for the first time in 32 years, its chance must rest on Felix and on desperation. Felix, the Brazilian goalkeeper, must be one of the worst goalkeepers ever to play in a World Cup soccer final. He is as unsafe, as indecisive and as worrisome to the Brazilian defense as his predecessor, Gylmar, was sound and sure.

SEASHORE gardens are sometimes invaded by that thorny stemmed vine known as cat-briar, one of the Smilax. Anyone who has tried to struggle through a cat-briar thicket knows how cruel its barbs can be, tearing flesh and clothing, so naturally it is a most unwelcome intruder.

In the intensive-care unit of a New York City hospital, Richard Messenger, magazine artist, illustrator of children's books, husband of Julie and father of two young sons, lies in a deep coma. HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 20 James E. Meighan Jr., a retired stage and radio actor, died today at his home, 29 Greenlawn Road. His age was 66.
For Ronald W. Haughton, the president of the Board of Mediation for Community Disputes, there is a special virtue in being humble.

AMMAN, Jordan There was the whisper of soft shoes on the polished floor, a shout of "His Majesty" and the little man with the worried eyes slipped into the red velvet chair. It was King Hussein Ibn Talal, monarch of Jordan, scion of an ancient Arab line, holding a palace press conference.
OTTAWA, June 20 Many Canadians, especially the young, applauded today the LeDain Commission report recommending more liberal laws on drug use. Others termed it "too permissive."

THE mysterious aloofness and quirky genius of Bob Dylan so fascinate the public imagination that the rare release of a new album by this sly, incredibly gifted artist invariably rocks the excitable psyche of pop culture with the force of a historic event.

KINSHASA, the Congo, June 20 (AP) The Congo is now hopeful that she can save her native white rhinoceros.

BORDENTOWN, N.J., June 21 Some 300 prisoners at Bordentown Reformatory refused to leave the auditorium after a movie last night. About 50 state troopers in full riot gear were dispatched to the institution, which has been affected by a statewide strike of prison guards for the last six days.
MORICHES, L.I., June 20 Bill Pagels, the Blue Jay Class national champion, took the lead today in the men's championship series of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.

MEXICO CITY The eyes of 300 million television viewers from the Soviet Union to Chile, from South Africa to northern Europe will be on Aztec Stadium here today for what most of the non-Asiatic world considers the supreme sports event of the year: the final game of the world soccer championship between Brazil and Italy.

TOKYO, June 20 (UPI) The police tightened their security measures today as opponents of the United States-Japanese security treaty planned their biggest demonstration for tomorrow to demand that the pact be scrapped.
As the slowdown in the economy squeezes thousands out of their jobs each week, a bill that would provide extended insurance protection to the unemployed is stalled on Capitol Hill.

WASHINGTON, June 20, (UPI) More than 4,000 smallbusiness men have formed joint organizations to hire and train disadvantaged jobless people under a program that has been used mostly by large corporations, Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz said Thursday.

Sam Aaron, wine merchant: Mildred Custin, former president of Bonwit Teller, and Diana Vreeland, editor in chief of Vogue recently joined some 100 civilians in this country who have received a medal they know is an honor but, in most cases, don't know quite what honor.

BEND, Ore., June 20 Two high school girls elected to make a movie with an eight millimeter camera instead of writing term papers for an honors English class this spring. Now, the local school district and five teachers are defendants in a $1-million libel suit, and the girls may yet be sued.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 Since 1963 when the An Quang Buddhists whose leader is Thich Tri Quang helped bring about the downfall of President Ngo Dinh Diem, their disapproval of all other governments here has provided continual jolts throughout the nation.
CAMDEN, N.J., June 20 The Camden Board of Education has hired the RCA Corporation as prime contractor in a joint effort to reform the entire public school system in this city of 115,000 people.

LIVONIA, Mich., June 20 (AP) Fast Hilarious took the lead at the start and fought off a charging Figonero to win the $126,000 Michigan Mile at a mile and one-eighth today in the record-equaling time of 1:47 4/5 for the Detroit Race Course.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 20 Miss Susan Elizabeth Hand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Darwin C. Hand of Old Greenwich, was married here this afternoon to Stephen Manning Robinson, son of Mrs. Claude E. Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday urged diligence and restraint in authorizing out-oftown travel expenses for city employes, "which have increased about 370 per cent since the 1966 budget."

NEWARK, June 20 The Essex County Medical Examiner's office said today that Paul N. Anderson, a bank executive killed in a car accident yesterday on his way to testify at the extortion trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio in Trenton, had died as a result of injuries suffered in the accident.
PARIS, June 20 (Reuters) A three-man Asian delegation working to bring peace to Indochina arrived here today for talks with Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann.

Ninety air travelers have been killed and 23 injured in the last 18 months in 114 incidents of hijacking, sabotage and ground attacks on aircraft.

The exacta will be put into effect at Aqueduct a week from tomorrow, the New York Racing Association announced yesterday. Exacta tickets of $2, $10 and $20 will be sold for two races the fifth and eighth.

In the dusky recesses of a Manhattan bar, Clare Conley, Jack Samson and I talked of the world of field and stream and of this month's 75th anniversary edition of the magazine they work for: Field and Stream.

CHASKA, Minn., June 20 Tony Jacklin is still leading. The 25-year-old Englishman, who was honored by Queen Elizabeth for winning the British Open last year, today was four strokes ahead after 54 holes in the United States Open golf championship with a 211 total.

PARIS In planning a trip to the French Alps recently, I faced the prospect of a four-hour layover at Orly Airport. The thought struck a dismal chord, one reminiscent of other times and other airports at which unavoidably long waits were exercises in tedium and boredom.
TOKYO, June 20 Two senior Cabinet ministers are due in Washington Monday with Japan's final proposal on the long angry dispute between the two countries over Japanese textile exports.
CHICAGO, June 20 Staked to a six-run lead in the first inning, Bill Hands hurled the Chicago Cubs to an 8-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

Twenty-six years ago, on an April night at the old Metropolitan Opera House, "Fancy Free" burst upon New York. And it has been bursting ever since; this Jerome Robbins-Leonard Bernstein ballet has become one of the best loved in the American repertory. Its joys are perennial, and never seem dimmed by cast changes or even over-familiarity.
From its small office on the fourth floor of a Manhattan office building, a special agency carefully nurtures and directs the dreams of a group of young people determined to lead a normal life.
CLEVELAND, June 20 Vice President Agnew accused eight of President Nixon's most outspoken antiwar critics tonight of prescribing surrender to achieve peace in Indochina.

Warren Cummings Cook, U.S.M.C., son of Mrs. William H. Vanderbilt of Williamstown, Mass. and John R. Cook of New York.
