WASHINGTON, June 20 Secretary of State William P. Rogers met today with Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin of the Soviet Union on possible peace moves in the Middle East.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 20 American military and diplomatic analysts believe most South Vietnamese forces will be withdrawn from Cambodia within a few days after the June 30 deadline announced by President Nixon for the pullout of all United States troops.

Millions of children every morning begin their school day by reciting the pledge to the flag, sitting through routine chores, such as attendance taking and listening to the principal's disembodied voice giving inspiration and instructions over the public address system. To many, this symbolizes order and security; others see it as a process of dehumanization.
ALGIERS, June 20 The Algerian Government is ending a multimillion-dollar program of United States aid by expelling members of the private American CARE-Medico mission, it was learned this week.

LIMA, Peru, June 20 In the bleak, cold Andean highlands of northern Peru, many Indians are still hiding their injured and orphaned, according to missionaries, three weeks after the devastating earthquake there.

MOUNT HERMON, Mass., June 20 The Memorial Chapel at the Mount Hermon School was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Deborah Jean Kiendl, daughter of Arthur H. Kiendl Jr., headmaster of the boys' preparatory school, to James Joseph McLaughlin, a law student at Boston University.

OAKLYN, N.J., June 20 Miss Linda Joyce Palmer, who was graduated last week from Susquehanna University, where she was on the dean's list, was married this morning to Mark Fulton Miller, an alumnus of the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsylvania.

For two decades the National Council of Churches has been taking liberal stands on issues like the war in Vietnam while millions of churchgoers fretted, fumed and angrily accused the ecumenical agency of being out of touch with grassroots Protestant opinion.

The New York Giants announced yesterday that Yankee Stadium had been sold out for the 1970 National Football League season. The Giants' string of home-game sellouts dates to the 1962 season and will have reached 65 straight games at the end of 1970.
COLUMBIA, S.C. As the war in Vietnam drags on, the Army is finding itself increasingly plagued by a growing struggle of another sort against dissidents in its ranks.

THE Middle Atlantic Regional Lily Group will have its seventh annual Lily Show on Saturday and next Sunday at the Pennsylvania Horticultural Society, 325 Walnut Street, Philadelphia. Hours Saturday will be from 2 to 5 P.M. and Sunday from noon to 5 P.M.
The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 67th annual match-play championship gets under way at the Essex Fells Country Club in Essex Fells, N.J., tomorrow and continues through Friday.
YONKERS, June 20 When Richard Ottinger turned his sights this spring from the House to the Senate, he left in his wake one of the most hotly contested political races in recent memory here.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 20 Miss Christine Valerie Stoehr and Jonathan F. Wells were married here today at a nuptial mass in St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. William Cullen.

A roseate tern, a beautiful local sea bird, has turned up for the first documented time in the Pacific Ocean after migrating from a breeding area on the Atlantic coast of the United States.

The Page Airways field outside of Rochester, N.Y., showed only a few lights late last Sunday night. It was a lonely place, a sad place to be on a Sunday night. Two small planes waited beyond the circle of light around the small terminal building one to take Arthur J. Goldberg to Syracuse, the other to take Howard J. Samuels to New York City.
A printing error caused more than 100 ticket holders to miss part of the first act of the Metropolitan Opera Company's first production of Pietro Mascagni's "Cavalleria Rustieana" last night.

The New York Knicks yesterday sent Nate Bowman, their backup center, and Mike Silliman, a former West Point star, to the Buffalo Braves, one of the three new National Basketball Association franchises, "for future consideration of draft choices."

The top officials of an association of 2,000 black New York City policemen yesterday challenged city and police officials to halt alleged "stationhouse brutality" against prisoners before it led to "armed confrontations" between white and black policemen.

A tall old tale is "The Derby Ram," and what a wonderful whopper of a ballad it has been for hundreds of years now! The narrator's description of the extraordinary creature met upon an ordinary market day gets broader and broader as the verses proceed: "The wool upon his back, sir,/Reached up unto the sky,/The eagles built their nests there,/For I heard the young ones cry." And on and prodigiously on:

WITH approximately 500 rodeos scheduled in the United States and Canada this season, vacationers will have more than one opportunity to relive the bold spirit of the "Old West." This 87-year-old dramatic sport still excites thousands of spectators and earns cash prizes for those rugged entrants to whom bronco busting or roping a frisky steer is just part of at day's work.

HARTFORD, June 20 United States Representatives Thomas J. Meskill and Lowell P. Weicker, who had been endorsed by state party leaders, were nominated by the Republican state Convention today to run for Governor and United States Senator, respectively, in Connecticut.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has declared that a law enacted by the 1970 Legislature removing the necessity for corroboration of testimony in antimonopoly cases gives district attorneys "another weapon in the fight against organized crime."
A new organization of environmental scientists and other concerned individuals has urged the study and control of the life balance of the Hudson River basin and nearby coastal areas.
WASHINGTON, June 20 Communist China informed the United States today that it would not be suitable at this time to set a date for the resumption of their ambassadorial talks in Warsaw.

WASHINGTON, June 20 Colleges and universities that close this fall to give students and faculty time to work in political campaigns will have to add an equal amount of time to the school year or run the risk of losing their tax-exempt status.
WASHINGTON, June 20 The new head of the National Institute of Mental Health hopes to set up within the institute a unit to deal exclusively with the mental problems of minority groups.
Howard J. Samuels said yesterday that he favored mandatory binding arbitration in public employe disputes after collective bargaining fails.

Wheeler 2d of Williamsburg, Va. The Rev. Frederick H. Arterton performed the Episcopal ceremony.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 20 The race to Bermuda, glamour event of ocean sailing, began today with 149 starters reaching into a fresh southwesterly breeze and a lump of sea capped with white in clear, crisp weather. Ahead were 679 miles of whatever the fortunes of the biennial fixture had to offer and for one yacht an immortality of sorts as the main corrected-time winner.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has announced the election of the first woman to the corporation, or board of trustees, of the school. She is Mrs. Philip F. Wagley of Baltimore, a 1947 alumna of the Cambridge, Mass., institution.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, June 21 Enemy forces struck north of Pnompenh yesterday in an apparent effort to seize the upper reaches of the Mekong River and speed the flow of troops and supplies into Cambodia.

The T-shirt has a brand-new look this summer. The classic cottonknit top an old hot-weather standby has stretched to reach anywhere from mid-calf to mid-ankle. It is the perfect beach cover-up. These easy cotton-knit dresses in every conceivable kind of stripe will be making the scene at most beaches and pools this summer.

The Rev. Robert L. Wilken, a Lutheran scholar who three years ago became the first non-Roman Catholic in the theology department of Fordham University, has been notified by university officials that his contract will be terminated at the end of the coming academic year.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) The ketch, Blackfin, held the lead today after about the first quarter of the Los Angeles-toTahiti race was completed.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP), Roy Foster's second home run of the game with one out in the eighth inning broke a tie and gave the Cleveland Indians a 2-1 victory over the Detroit Tigers today. The triumph was the seventh straight for the Indians.
The City University is proceeding with plans for a new two-year college patterned after Antioch College in Ohio, where students will alternate classroom instruction with on-thejob experience for pay.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, had accepted the network's offer of free television and radio time to reply to President Nixon's address on the economy last Wednesday.

IT will be another year before Pierre Boulez becomes music director of the New York Philhar monic, but he is currently in charge of other American organizations. WASHINGTON The galleries were packed, young people overflowing the seats and standing clustered around doorways. When Speaker John McCormack announced the vote, 224 to 183 in favor of the resolution, they broke into applause that the Speaker was unwilling to check with his gavel.
MIAMI, June 20 (AP) Court Page overtook Cincy Syd at the sixteenth pole today and scored a four-length victory in the $6,000 Summer Handicap at Tropical Park.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) Corn Off The Cob, owned by Tom Gary of Miami and ridden by the nation's leading money winning jockey, Eddie Belmonte, won the $109,500 Arlington Classic today in a drizzle by six lengths.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) For about a year now, the red, white and blue mail drops on the street corners of America have been turning blue.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20 Tennis way once the game of the kings of France and still is widely regarded as a fancypants sport for the moneyed bourgeois, not for common people. After' a five-hour debate, delegates to the Socialist party convention here yesterday rejected a move to support candidates of a new third party this year and in the 1972 Presidential elections.

Missile Belle rounded out a fine stakes week for the John A. Morris family by winning the $133,875 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park yesterday. WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) Three teen-agers who performed outstanding acts of heroism or helpfulness and a boy who drowned rescuing a friend from a rushing stream have been named as recipients of Young America medals.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 20 With one exception, all trainers among the regulars currently at Roosevelt Raceway will have space for their trotters and pacers at Yonkers Raceway during the 73night, second-half meeting that starts July 27.

WASHINGTON, June 20 No doubt it would have been more orderly to approve the eighteen-year-old vote through a constitutional amendment, but it would have taken longer, too. That is one of many good reasons why President Nixon, despite his misgivings, should sign the unusual legislation that would lower the voting age.

G. Stanley McAllister, an executive of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, a chain of department stores that includes Lord Taylor, died of a heart attack while walking on Fifth Avenue near his home yesterday. He was 70 years old and lived at 1115 Fifth Avenue.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 20 Prime Minister John Vorster returned from a three-week European tour today and said that he had found South Africa was "not as isolated as some of our enemies tried to make out."

UNITED STATES stamp collectors will be wellrepresented in displays at Philympia, London's international stamp exhibition, Sept. 18-28, at the Empire Hall, Olympia, in the Kensington section of that city.

WINNETKA, Ill., June 20 Back in 1966 when she was at Smith and he was at Amherst, Miss Gail Ann Ingersoll and Lawrence Bristol Ransom fed their personality profiles into a computer. It said they were meant for each other.

BUENOS AIRES, June 20 The kidnapping and presumed murder of Lieut. Gen. Pedro Eugenfo Aramburu, former provisional President of Argentina, have added a perplexing new dossier to the files of unsolved political crimes in this country.
ROME, June 20 (AP) Unions representing a majority of teachers in Italy's junior high schools and high schools refused today to issue final grades and examinations to more than five million pupils.

WASHINGTON Sixteen years after the Supreme Court declared school desegregation by official policy to be unconstitutional, it is now clear that there will be massive integration in the towns and rural areas of the Deep South next fall. MOSCOW, June 20 (UPI) Soviet scientists expressed satisfaction today with the Soyuz 9 space mission. They said it had demonstrated that "man with his inherent creative endeavor, preserves his characteristic qualities" under weightless conditions.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) The Celestine Dilibero entry of L'Alglon and Lion Sleeps finished one, two today in the $15,000 Bread Winners purse as the 2-1 favorites at Suffolk Downs.

DENVER, June 20(AP) The New York Jolt's heavyweight, Jasper Evans, whipped Billy Thompson of Chicago on a 10-0 decision last night in leading the Jolts to the championship of the International Boxing League.
Health and antipoverty officials in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx have urged emergency measures to halt lead poisoning discovered among children tested in that area.

NEOCLASSICISM During the first half of the 19th century, neoclassicism reigned supreme and Duncan Phyfe was its chief exponent in this country. The 1830's parlor in the Metropolitan (right) shows the style as it was. The modem black-walled room below features Italian Directoire chairs with neoclassic lines arranged around a Noguchi table. Art by Robert Indiana, James Seawright and Babe Shapiro adds a 20th-century signature.

WASHINGTON Around and around the earth the two Soviet cosmonauts sped for almost 300 orbits in the Soyuz 9 spacecraft which finally landed last Friday after a record-breaking 17 days 16 hours in space. During this longest journey man has ever made Col. Andrian G. Nikolayev and Vitaly I. Sevastyanov played chess with ground controllers, gawked at the stars, radioed an election day get-outthe-vote speech to their countrymen, and photographed the weather beneath them.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of 16 persons in New York and Florida in connection with an East Coast car theft ring that specialized in stealing expensive late model autos.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) Colin Mitchell, who commanded the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, promised his old outfit today that the ousted Labor Government's plans to scrap the regiment in November would be canceled.
DETROIT, June 20 The top bargainers for the auto industry warn that foreign competition threatens the jobs of American workers and must be considered in this year's labor contract talks.

In an upstairs room of a West 88th Street brownstone that houses the Children's Community Workshop School, organized by dissatisfied parents as an alternative to public school, an 11-year-old boy indulges his fascination with electronics by building a radio from cannibalized parts.

KEARNEY, N.J., June 20 Steve Siegel of Teaneck moved into the final of the New Jersey State men's tennis championship by beating Claude Schoenlank of New York today, 7-5, 6-2, at the Arlington Players Club. He meets Steve Ross of Brooklyn in tomorrow's final.

EASTBOURNE, England, June 20 (Reuters) Ken Rosewall of Australia won the $1,200 men's singles first prize with a 6-2, 6-1 victory over South Africa's No. 1 player Bob Hewitt, in the South of England tennis championships today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 20 A record number of blacks have switched to the Republican party in Arkansas this year to run for political office, suggesting that the state's Negroes may have virtually abandoned their traditional allegiance to the state Democratic party, at least for now.
WASHINGTON, June 20 If there is anything that should convince liberals that Communism is not joking about taking over the world, it is weeds.

Henderson, rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Newcastle.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 20 Mr. and Mrs. John F. Nash of Bethlehem, formerly of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Ann Nash, to Randall Corbin Perry, son of Mrs. Eleanor McClure Perry of Georgetown, Washington, and Wilbert R. In the spring of 1969, the Army court-martialed 27 young soldiers on mutiny charges for conducting a sit-down demononstration in protest against stockade conditions at Presidio, Calif. PARIS, June 20 (Reuters) France and Rumania have agreed to double their trade to 1.3-billion francs ($250million) a year over the next five years.

LONDON, June 20 Rod Laver beat John Newcombe, 6-4, 6-3, with ease and, in what appeared to be the most stunning upset of the season, little Winnie Shaw of Scotland led the great Mrs. Margaret Court, 6-2, 5-0, today before an incredulous crowd that couldn't believe what it was seeing in the London grass-court tennis finals at the Queens Club.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain THE First International Theater Festival of San Sebastian, which rapidly came to be known among the participants rather cynically as Festival Zero, was scheduled to last from May 4 to May 10. Henry Beers, a 43-year-old Princeton graduate with two degrees in aeronautical engineering, is looking for a job. He has a daughter headed for college in the fall, and two other children, and he is not particular whether his next job is in or out of the aerospace field.

The Penn Central Transportation Company, which operates the country's largest railroad system, told a Federal judge yesterday that it could not pay its bills and was granted its petition for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws.

The Penn Central Transportation Company, now that it is in reorganization, will operate pretty much as it has operated right along. Its own management, headed by Paul A. Gorman, chief executive officer, will continue to direct day-byday activities until the Federal court appoints trustees.

REVERE, Mass., June 21-- Miss Elena Frances Alpher, daughter of Mrs. Theodore Rubinovitz of Marblehead, was married in St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to Peter Lehman Wise. He is the son of Mrs. Hilda Lehman Wise of New York and grandson of Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman of New York and the late Governor Lehman of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Guido Pillato.

Sukarno, the deposed "lifetime" President of Indonesia, was a man of exceptional gifts who led the world's fifth most populous nation out of colonialism and inspired its widely scattered and divergent people with a sense of national unity. He deserves remembrance as the Father of his country.
SAIGON, South Vietnam china intensified on a dozen weekend of fighting since the in April. Allied forces reported that more than 220 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers had been killed.
BALTIMORE, June 21 (AP)-- Dave McNally registered his 100th career victory today as the Baltimore Orioles completed a four-game sweep of the Washington Senators, 4-2.

CHICAGO, June 21--The annual convention of the American Medical Association opened in confusion today as protest groups of blacks, consumers and the poor forced the delegates into a closed meeting guarded by private policemen.

CAIRO, June 21--Can Doris Day and Walter Winchell, Lucille Ball and Dr. Ben Casey triumph over stern-faced and daring Bulgarian intelligence agents, Soviet guerrillas, Hungarian criminal investigators and the Bolshoi Ballet?
VIENNA, June 21 (AP)--The foreign ministers of the Soviet Union and its six Warsaw Pact allies met in Budapest today for two days of talks on the projected European security conference.

SEATTLE, June 21 (AP)--A resolution urging the newspaper industry to consider the problems created by disposal of newspapers was approved yesterday by the Executive Board of the American Newspaper Guild, a union representing newspaper employes.

Behind each of the four Democratic aspirants to the Senate stands a woman--on a subway platform, on a soapbox, at a switchboard, or simply in a living room with a cup of coffee in her hand--talking and talking and talking.
LONDON, June 21 (AP)-- King Hussein of Jordan has sent his four youngest children to safety in London, but diplomatic sources today discounted any political significance in the move.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 21 (AJ)--Jay Johnstone cracked a bases-loaded double in the 10th inning today, bringing the California Angels a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

TOKYO, June 21 (AP)-- About 150,000 demonstrators, far short of the organizers' goal of a million, turned out today across the nation for the ninth day of protest against the automatic extensoin of the Japan-United States security treaty.
SAN DIEGO, June 21 (AP)-- Hal Lanier singled home the lead run in the sixth inning and started a three-run eighth with a double as the San Francisco Giants whipped the, San Diego Padres today, 7-2.

TEL AVIV, June 21 (Reuters) --Israeli aircraft today began their fourth week of intensive raids in the Suez Canal area with intermittent strikes against Egyptian targets there throughout the day, an army spokesman said here.
Summer came to the northern hemisphere at 3:43 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time yesterday, but--in the New York metropolitan area, at least-- the weather didn't match the calendar.

WASHINGTON, June 20-- Until the abrupt resignation of one of their number several weeks ago, they were known to outsiders as Haldeman's Four Horsemen--a versatile, seasoned, and aggressive quartet of White House advisers technically attached to H.R. Haldeman, President Nixon's chief of staff.

TORONTO, June 21--"That's right lovey, stand tall," cried one of the 32,000 spectators at the Woodbine race course here yesterday as the slim, erect figure in striped trousers, morning coat and gray top hat walked across the red carpet laid over the dirt track.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., June 21--The Smith Haven Mall, a new "city" within the Village of Lake Grove straddling the line between the Towns of Smithtown and Brookhaven, has a low silhouette but casts a large shadow over central Suffolk County.

The three-year contract agreed upon by spokesmen for apartment house owners and the building service union assures to tenants in cooperatives and most higher-rent apartments immunity from a crippling strike. But it leaves virtually unchanged the threat of service shutdown before the end of this month in many of the 1.3 million apartments under the 1943 rent control law.
Heated face-to-face arguments among the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator broke out yesterday during and after their next-to-last television debate of the campaign.

Rain prevented the New York Mets from registering their one millionth customer before the first day of summer by forcing postponement of yesterday's game at Shea Stadium with the Philadelphia Phillies.

CLEVELAND, June 21--The man who came to dinner here last night to arouse the passions of 1,400 listeners and nearly as many demonstrators left in the rain today without a peep and with scarcely a spectator.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 21--Tony Palafox, seeded second, and Jon Buchman, fourth, won two matches apiece to reach the fourth round of the Eastern men's clay-court tennis championship at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today. The matches were moved indoors because of rain.

CINCINNATI, June 21 (AP)-- Johnny Bench drove in four runs today with a double and his 24th homer and Wayne Simpson breezed to his 10th victory as the Cincinnati Reds beat Los Angeles, 9-3, for a split of their double-header.

ATHENS, June 21--Archeologists from the American School of Classical Studies, led by Prof. Leslie Shear of Princeton University, have unearthed in the ancient market-place of Athens the place where the trial of Socrates was held.
ATLANTA, June 21 (AP)-- Hank Aaron belted a pair of two-run wallops today, running his career homer total to 575, as the Atlanta Braves downed the Houston Astros, 6-4.

MOSCOW, June 21--The Soviet Government and the official literary establishment have marked the 60th birthday today of Aleksandr T. Tvardovsky with warm praise for his poetry but not a word about his resignation of the editorship of the liberal journal Novy Mir.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- Federal agents staged what they described as the largest nationwide narcotics raids in history last night and today, arresting 135 persons and seizing heroin and cocaine valued at about $2.5-million on the retail market.

DES MOINES, Iowa, June 21 --Colleagues have called Dave Maggard, "the hippie coach," because he practices in that famous college commune, Berkeley, and because he tells his track and field athletes that beards, beads and mustaches are fine as long as the finish line comes first.

CLEVELAND, June 21 (AP)-- Cesar Gutierrez, Detroit's shortstop, became today the first player in modern major league history to get seven consecutive hits in one game as the Tigers beat Cleveland, 9-8, in the second game of a doubleheader on Mickey Stanley's 12th-inning homer. Gutierrez had six singles and a double.

The Protestant leadership of New York City has quietly conceded defeat on a highly publicized effort to bring religious agencies and community groups together for a coordinated drive on poverty and other social problems.

WASHINGTON, June 21--A patent cooperation treaty, designed to save paperwork and expenses in patenting the same invention in a number of countries, has been concluded here, subject to ratification by the participating governments.
BOSTON, June 21--In a 4hour thriller that bore a striking resemblance to the Boston Marathon, the New York Yankees scored six runs in the 11th inning today to defeat the Red Sox, 14-10.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) --Paul W. McCracken, President Nixon's chief economic adviser, predicted today that unemployment would get worse before it got better.

Dozens of major Wall Street law firms have a lot in common--offices in the financial district, corporate giants as clients, scores of lawyers with degrees from the best schools, and not a few partners whose annual income is in six figures.

HARTFORD, June 21-- "Twenty years from now people will still be talking about the 1970 Republican convention," a tired politician said as he walked out of Bushnell Memorial Auditorium at 4 o'clock this morning.

MEXICO CITY, June 21-- Brazil, with a crushing 4-1 victory over Italy, won the ninth World Cup soccer championship today and gained permanent possession of the Jules Rimet Trophy, symbol of world supremacy in the sport.
TORONTO, June 21--A clinic here dispenses free care to young people suffering from a variety of medical problems, often connected with the use of drugs.

At the Marble Collegiate Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Alberta Ann Wangeman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank George Wangeman of New York and Quaker Hill, N.Y., was married to Ens. Charles Roberts Lamson, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Otis Floyd Lamson Jr. of Mercer Island, Wash.
Peggy Wood has been named the winner of the first annual Theater LaSalle Award, it was announced by Brother Daniel Burke, president of LaSalle College in Philadelphia.
The Administration's package of anticrime bills is loaded with provisions of doubtful constitutionality.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 21 --Souther (Chick) Whittelsey, at the helm of his Luders-16 Class sloop, Interlude, won his third straight Yatch Racing Association race today when the Indian Harbor Y.C. conducted the season's 13th regatta for Connecticut area Y.R.A. fleets based east of Rye. Interlude triumphed by 34 seconds over a 7.5-mile triangle in an 8-to 10-knot east-northeast breeze.

ALBANY, June 21--State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today that state spending had exceeded revenues by nearly $600-million a year for the last five years, with the budget balanced only by borrowing for construction.

Federal and county law enforcement officials here said yesterday that they would willingly investigate charges of brutality committed against arrested persons in station houses if they were asked by the Guardians' Association to do so.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 21 --Spindletop Showdown, the defending national high point champion, won his fourth consecutive title this season--but in a close squeak--today as the Fairfield County Horse Show closed its four-day run at the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 19--"We owe much to America and we acknowledge that debt," a Korean Government official said. "But we cannot go along with you on your plans do restrict our textile exports. For us, textile exports are almost a matter of life or death."

KATONAH, N.Y., June 21 --"This is the first time that Mozart has left me cold." The remark was going the rounds at the opening of the 25th annual Caramoor Festival here last night. It had nothing to do with the composer's opera "Idomeneo," which was being presented in the outdoor Venetian Theater, but with the weather.
WASHINGTON, June 21--The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

Maria Vogt's vague ambition to become a middleclass German housewife ended at 17 when she was kicked out of high school for refusing to say Heil Hitler. For the next three years she went to a private arts and crafts school and learned to work in precious metals. Then Germany became too unpleasant to bear and she left, first for England and later for the United States.

CHARLESTON, Va., June 20 --Five years and several billion dollars later, the Government officials who manage the Appalachian economic recovery effort initiated by President Kennedy have decided that the time has come to "reach the people."

LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) --There may be more than a quarter of a million "prisoners of conscience" in jails throughout the world, according to a report released today by the British section of Amnesty Internatinnal, an organization founded in 1961 to assist such prisoners.

GUYENCOURT, Del., June 21--The marriage of Miss Alpine Douglas Chandler to Donald James Bird took place here today at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred DuPont Chandler, grandparents of the bride. The Very Rev. John N. Peabody, Dean of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Baltimore, performed the ceremony.

HOLMDEL, N.J. June 21--To judge by the array of Nashvillebased performers who were heard at the three-day Country Music Festival that concluded last night at the Garden State Arts Center, the most popular song in Nashville nowadays is --would you believe it?--"Danny Boy." It was performed three times during the festival --sung by a trumpet player, wailed out by a steel guitarist and harmonized by a male trio.

John R. Crews, who has led the Brooklyn Republican organization for 36 years, faces a strong challenge to his leadership in tomorrow's primary, but is generally expected to win another term if he decides to seek it.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 21 (AP)--Sal Bando hit two home runs as the Oakland Athletics beat the Chicago White Sox, 6-4, to complete a double-header sweep today.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 21-- The stockade here at the Presidio of San Francisco is old and small and hidden on a fogshrouded hill in the shadow of the Golden Gate Bridge.

A doughty white Sealyham, showing all the power and determination for which the breed is known, carried off the top honors in an entry of 1,510 dogs at the 30th annual show of the Staten Island Kennel Club yesterday. He was Ch. Jenmist Dougal, owned by Mrs. Henry Sutliff Jr. of Richmond, Va.
At 10 o'clock Saturday morning the final phase of Operation Eagle in New York began.

"To Be or Not to Be-- What Kind of a Question is That?", a revue reflecting present-day Israel, will have its premiere Oct. 13 at the Barbizon-Plaza Theater. Presented by Henry Goldgran and Arthur V. Briskin, it will run for five weeks before going on a national tour.

Sharp on all four boards, Bayside High School scored 20-4 to win the Spring, 1970, Interscholastic Chess League Senior High School Team Tournament. The results: Board One, Nicholas Ocipoff, 4 1 ; Board Two, Alex Ocipoff, 5-1; Board Three, Richard Wentzler, 5-1, and Board Four, Steve Sherbel, 5 - .

Members of New Yark Typographical Union No. 6 yesterday ratified a new three-year contract with the city's four major newspapers. The vote for acceptance was 293 to 8 and was taken at the union meeting in Stuyvesant High School.

Edward Heath has selected his Cabinet largely from his own kind of British Conservative. This means that, although the Cabinet represents a large measure of continuity from previous Conservative Governments, most of the key Ministers symbolize modern Toryism. Iain Macleod, Reginald Maudling, Robert Carr, like Mr. Heath, are pragmatic, practical, flexible men, indifferent to ideology and dogma.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., June 21--Roaring over rain-slicked surfaces at an average speed of 90.55 miles an hour, Mark Donohue of Media, Pa., drove his red, white and blue Javelin to its first triumph in the Sports Car Club of America's transAmerican series.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) --The New York Athletic Club senior eight-oar shell won the third annual Triad rowing regatta over rough water on the Allegheny River today.

It's almost inevitable that Paola Davitti be compared with Emilio Pucci and she manages to smile brightly while the analogies are made. They are both from Florence, Italy; they are both fashion designers and the specialty in each case is printed silk jersey fabric.

This all too sound piece of advice is recalled by Eva Buckingham Hines on page 319 of Eleanor Clark's new novel, the first she's written in nearly 25 years. At the time Eva recalls it, she is standing on a ...

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) --Senator J.W. Fulbright called today for a 75 per cent reduction in Pentagon spending for public relations and charged the Defense Department has understated the growth of its "propaganda apparatus."
STRAHANE, Northern Ireland, June 21 (Reuters)--Policemen wielding clubs charged a crowd today after a celebration of Miss Bernadette Devlin's re-election to Parliament turned to stone-throwing.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 21--Indonesians by the tens of thousands streamed into a mansion on the outskirts of this capital today for a last look at the once-fiery politician who led them to independence.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI)--The Federal Government announced a pilot project today aimed at the voluntary eradication of wild marijuana in 20 counties of 10 Midwest states before illicit traffickers can harvest it.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 21--Marvin Kapilow sailed Lorraine to his third Etchells-22 Class Yacht Racing Association victory of the season today in the Sheldrake Yacht Club's annual regatta on Long Island Sound.
GLEN COVE, L.I., June 21-- Jack Hirsch's Dynamite, a new 45-foot Whitby built sloop, was the apparent winner of Bayside, Yacht Club's 17th annual pointno-point cruising race today.

Interest rates hit a peak early, last week and then declined in the face of an unusually large volume of new bond issues for sale. As a result, investment bankers expect yields to move down further this week.

PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria-- Here in the capital of the Rivers State is where the most difficult tests for Nigerian reunification and for reintegration of the Ibos who served Biafra will come. The signs so far are not encouraging.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP)-- Steve Carlton hurled a six-hit shutout in the opener and Joe Torre slugged a tie-breaking homer in the eighth inning of the second game today as the St. Louis Cardinals captured a doubleheader from the Chicago Cubs, 3-0, 3-2.

JERUSALEM, June 21 (AP)-- Dr. Cecil Roth, noted authority on Jewish history, died of cancer today in Hadassah Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived here and at the Oliver Cromwell Hotel in New York.
PITTSBURGH, June 21 (AP) --Firebombing and rock throwing swept the predominantly Negro Manchester district today after a 12-year-old Negro boy was shot to death.

Robert Nagy, for many years a comprimario with the Met, emerged from the relatively obscurity of Messengers, Heralds, and Faithful Companions Saturday night to sing the leading role of Canio in "Pagliacci." The promotion was on the whole a well deserved one for Mr. Nagy gave a thoughtful, intelligent performance.

MOSCOW, June 21 (UPI)--A Russian space commentator said today that the recordbreaking flight of Soyuz 9 may not have answered all the questions puzzling scientists about man's ability to endure prolonged periods in space.

Saturday afternoon, when some ninth-graders hereabout were out celebrating the end of school with picnics and littleleague games, Michael Toth was at Carnegie Recital Hall, making his New York debut. The 14-year-old pianist from Glenside, Pa., wisely avoided the most common prodigy trap by choosing comparatively uncomplicated music that overreached neither his technical equipment nor his emotional understanding.

PARIS--If ever an exhibition demonstrated the dangerous vanity of labels, it is the one currently at the Musee d'Art Moderne, under the titillating title "European Expressionism." The core of the show is provided by two generations of German--and, accessorily, Benelux--artist ...

James Earl Jones cupped his hands to his mouth and boomed: "The Alvin Theater shouts, 'Hey! Come in here, and make money!' On Broadway you're supporting marquee lights. The building makes demands on you."

Arthur J. Goldberg and Howard J. Samuels, the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Governor, met in their second and last television debate last night and quietly and politely restated the positions they have tried to develop in the last three months.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21--Reliable military sources disclosed today that United States fighter-bombers and gunships, which have been restricted to flying a maximum of 21.7 miles into Cambodia in support of ground operations, have been ranging much deeper into northeast Cambodia for nearly two months in raids on new enemy infiltration routes.

STRATFORD, Conn.--In some respects "Othello" is the simplest and most direct of Shakespeare's tragedies. The action, as even the unfriendly Dr. Johnson noticed, is almost classic in its continuous thrust, and the two main characters, Othello, a man of stupid nobility, and Iago, a creature of blind malevolence, travel their predestined course of doom, needing no more motivation than the slender, but allpowerful, excuse of a purloined handkerchief.
WASHINGTON, June 21-- Doctors who treat more than a million adults with mild diabetes face a problem this summer that most cannot solve independently.

Richard Max McCarthy, one of the four candidates for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, was shaving in his hotel room last Friday before a night of speeches. Someone asked whether there were any issues that were not being discussed in this campaign.
MUNICH, West Germany-- Munich is growing as it never did before. There are 1.3 million people here, and last year the new arrivals outnumbered those departing by nearly 50,000.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- Serious grievances are mounting in the coal industry, increasing the likelihood of a disruption of the nation's critically short supply of coal--a factor in the power brownouts forecast for this summer.

CHASKA, Minn., June 21-- Tony Jacklin won the United States Open golf championship today and became the first Englishman to do so in 50 years. "I'm proud to be an Englishman," said the smiling 25-yearold British Open titleholder after sinking a 35-foot putt for a birdie that gave him a sevenstroke margin.
FORT DIX, N.J.--"Mice were observed in the dishwashing area."

One of the most peculiar "farms" in America is not to be found under God's blue sky but in a rather dark and humid basement in Chinatown. And the man responsible for the harvest, along with a crew of eight, is a smiling, well-tailored, wellmanicured and obviously prosperous gentleman named C.P. Liu.

LOS ANGELES, June 21 (AP) --More than 220,000 pounds of relief supplies donated for Peruvian earthquake victims sat in an airport hangar here today as volunteer workers sought for transportation to deliver it.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 21--A 21-year-old marine was convicted of premeditated murder today in the fatal shooting of 12 Vietnamese civilians during a patrol on Feb. 19. He was sentenced to life imprisonment at hard labor.

The board of directors of National Educational Television will submit its views on a consolidation of N.E.T. and WNDT with the board of Channel 13 at a meeting on Wednesday. The N.E.T. board met on Saturday.

The state's Attorney General declared yesterday that he would sue the state's Public Service Commission if it approved a telephone rate increase "without some restoration of service to which the people are entitled."
The Mount Sinai School of Medicine has won a state grant to train prospective building superintendents in housing maintenance, on the ground that good housing is basic to good health.

The practice of sniffing chemical solvents for "kicks" has stopped the hearts of and killed at least 110 American youths in the last decade, and deaths as a result of the practice are rising sharply, a medical study shows.

J. Peter Grace, president and chief executive of W.R. Grace Co., a major chemical producer, has informed the Federal Reserve that--under protest--he plans to resign "promptly" as a director of Marine Midland Banks, Inc.

Miss Lesly Ellen Spitzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel J. Spitzer of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married here yesterday to Jonathan Franklin Wise, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Wise, also of New Rochelle.
ADEN, Southern Yemen, June 21--Saudi Arabia has sent a consignment of food to the neighboring republic of Yemen to tide her over a severe famine, according to the Sana radio.
A limited future for container feeder ships in United States waters is being predicted by an official Government study.

ROME, June 21--Pope Paul VI today proclaimed the first Croat saint, a 14th-century martyr in the Holy Land, and deplored in a eulogy what he called the modern world's preference for "fashion" over faith.
In death, James Parris has succeeded in getting what he was unable to get in almost 43 years of life--attention. But whether it will give him an identity remains in doubt.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) --The conduct of Vice President Agnew has been disgraceful, divisive and damaging, Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, said today.

KENNEBUNK, Me., June 21--Miss Alexis Droggitis and Stephen O. Muskie, son of Senator and Mrs. Edmund S. Muskie, were married this afternoon on the lawn of the Muskies' summer home here, near the Webhannet Golf Club, where the reception was held afterward.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 21 --Three Iranians seeking political asylum in Iraq today hijacked an Iranian airliner with 91 passengers aboard on a flight from Teheran to Abadan and forced the pilot to fly to Baghdad.

STOCKHOLM, June 21-- Barring a combination of circumstances about as likely as the chance of receiving a 13-card suit, the United States, represented by the Dallas Aces, will play in the final of the 1970 world championship beginning here Wednesday.

NANCY, France, June 21-- This rebellious provincial center of eastern France handed the Government an electoral defeat today as Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber, secretary general of the Radical Socialist party, took a commanding lead in a by-election for a seat in the National Assembly.

The State Department of Motor Vehicles has established a new hearing and adjudication division with Robert J. Hogan of Schenectady, former assistant executive director of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, as its director.

A grant to assist the nation's first college-degree program to train a new category of health professionals, the physician's assistant, will be announced today by the Commonwealth Fund, a locally based philanthropic foundation.

The chairman of the New York City Human Rights Commission apologized yesterday for having "innocently and inadvertently" used the word "Polacks" to refer to PolishAmericans during a television discussion.
MOSCOW, June 21--Twenty persons were reported today to have been arrested in Leningrad in what the Soviet authorities have called an attempt to seize a Soviet airliner.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 21 (Reuters)--A 12-man select committee from the United States House of Representatives and Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee arrived in Saigon today on separate aircraft for visits to South Vietnam.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 21--Emmet John Hughes, a journalist, author and former Presidential adviser, will join the faculty of Rutgers University in September as a professor of political science in the Eagleton Institute of Politics.

Governor Rockefeller and the two candidates for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, wearing the traditional yarmulke, participated yesterday in the dedication of a Brooklyn campus of the Lubovitcher Movement, the worldwide Orthodox Hasidic organization.

Willard L. Neeley Sr., an art representative, died Saturday night at Meadowbrook Hospital, East Meadow, L.I. He was badly burned last Sunday by charcoal lighting fluid at a barbecue in Sea Cliff, L.I. Mr. Neeley, who was 47 years old, lived in Sea Cliff and formerly in Pound Ridge., N.Y.

LIMA, Peru, June 21--The revolutionary Peruvian military Government is preparing four basic economic laws that will be the most radical measures taken in Latin America since the Castro take-over in Cuba.
PITTSBURGH, June 21-- Steel users have been consuming metal as fast as it has been coming in.
EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 21--As Bob Murphy, his orange shirt and blue slacks raindrenched, walked onto the patio of the Wheatley Hills Golf Club today, he was handed a telegram.

Dr. Abraham L. Umansky, an orthopedic surgeon at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 92 Verdun Avenue, New Rochelle, N.Y.
The police warned motorists yesterday to avoid the area around Third Avenue and 42d Street today because repaving of the intersection damaged when a water main broke Friday night was not completed.

President Nixon's request for legislation to cancel oil drilling leases off Santa Barbara and create a marine sanctuary there should help redeem the Interior Department, the proposal's originator, for having allowed the worst offshore oil spill in the country's history. And it may serve as a precedent elsewhere.
After receiving tens of millions of tons of foreign food grains over the years, India has now embarked on a program to become self-sufficient in food production by 1974.
ZANDVOORT, The Netherlands, June 21 (AP)--Jochen Rindt of Austria drove a Lotus to victory today in the Dutch Grand Prix, which was marred by the fatal crash of Piers Courage of Britain.
MONZA, Italy, June 21 (Reuters)--Mike Walker of Britain, driving a 5,000 cc McLaren, won the two-heat, 205-mile Grand Prix of Monza today with an aggregate time of 1 hour 1 minute 6.1 seconds.
The first Englishman to hold the British and United States Open golf championships concurrently is a 25year-old perfectionist whose main problem on the tournament tour is boredom.
WASHINGTON, June 21--By what appears to be a classic process, the United States may be slipping into erecting a major new "non-tariff barrier" to trade.
TORONTO, June 21--A committee of securities industry leaders has embraced the essential arguments of Canada's leftish economic nationalists with respect to the undesirability of foreign ownership.

CLEVELAND, June 21--Dr. Austin S. Weisberger, chairman of the department of medicine at the Case Western Reserve School of Medicine and University Hospitals of Cleveland since 1965, died of a heart attack while driving in San Mateo, Calif., Saturday.

LONDON, June 21--It would be absurd not to pick Rod Laver and highly, disputable to favor Mrs. Billie Jean King over Mrs. Margaret Court as play opens tomorrow in one of the world's great sport spectacles on the lawns of the All-England Lawn Tennis club at Wimbledon.

MONTREAL, June 21 (AP)-- The police seized more than 650 pounds of dynamite and arrested six persons in the Montreal suburb of Laval and the Laurentian city of Prevost, 30 miles north of Montreal, today.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- The National Council of Churches, a federation of Protestant and Eastern Orthodox denominations, agreed here today to call a National Ecumenical Consultation that would include Roman Catholics, Southern Baptists and other evangelical churches.

LONDON--A young man writes from America. In his last year at a college in the Middle West he did some parttime teaching. He had an experience that he still cannot altogether understand, that he cannot forget.
PARIS, June 21--The horses in the Grand Steeplechase de Paris were applauded four times today by 35,000 cheerful fans at Auteuil race course.

WASHINGTON, June 21-- High United States officials said today that the number of sorties flown by Soviet pilots over the United Arab Republic had dropped substantially since May 14 and that current flights were confined mainly to training missions.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22-- The 13 justices of the Federal District Court here will draw lots tomorrow to decide which one of them will act as the judge in charge of the reorganization proceedings of the Penn Central Transportation Company.

CHICAGO, June 22--Two urologists from the University of Michigan Medical Center said today that a short course of oxyphenbutazone, an anti-inflamatory drug, helped to reduce pain and tenderness from a condition called acute epididymitis.
The Four Seasons Equity Corporation announced yesterday that it would cease the development of additional nursing centers because of "a serious liquidity problem."
A Federal court jury convicted a real estate operator yesterday in a scheme involving the fraudulent pledging of life insurance policies as collateral for bank loans in six states.

A policeman who called a news conference a week ago to protest what he called departmental harassment because of his long hair, said he had been "treated like a criminal" yesterday at a departmental hearing.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--President Nixon said today that the United States would vigorously oppose any attempts by foreign nations to restrict the operations of United States airlines.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the constitutionality of Federal construction grants to church-related colleges and universities.
Jackie Gleason obtained a divorce from his wife of 34 years yesterday, ending a marital case that had set a legal precedent in divorce litigation in the state.
DOVER, N.H., June 22-- Schuyler Merritt Meyer, a lawyer and former New York State legislator, died at a nursing home here yesterday. He was 84 years old, and lived in Hanover.
