Appeals from the Department's ruling of last November to that effect could then take their long and tortuous course without harm to man or beast.

W.A. Swanberg, the biographer of Hearst, Pulitzer and Dreiser, has rejected an honorary doctorate from Northwestern University because of his "strong opposition to American militarism," which he charged was subsidizing the university.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- President Nixon's approval today of the 18-year-old vote came at a time when there was strong interest in many states in lowering the voting age. In several states campaigns to extend the franchise are nearing a referendum.
The financial markets weathered the shock of the Penn Central's filing under the bankruptcy laws with little difficulty yesterday.
And so it goes in fashion: Alexander's announced yesterday that it is dropping out of the haute couture copies competition.
At Yankee Stadium last night, there were bats and balls and homemade signs, popcorn, peanuts and hot dogs, youthful fans, moms and dads and an assortment of dignitaries.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 22-- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy expressed concern about the United States balance of trade here today and called for a corporate response to the Administration's proposal to defer taxes on export profits.

"Political insanity" seems to be peculiarly endemic in Russia. Nearly 150 years ago Czar Nicholas I detected the disease in Russia's first modern political philosopher, Pyotr Y. Chaadayev; the evidence of his "insanity" was his enunciation of the rule that "the chief think we owe to our country is truth." Czar Nicholas forbade Chaadayev to write or speak publicly and sent a physician to examine him each week.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
The Corning Glass Works, the first major company to issue half-year results, reported yesterday lower earnings for the 24 weeks ended June 14 despite record sales for the period.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 22 --A North Korean agent was killed early today when a group of two or three Communist infiltrators accidentally detonated a bomb that they attempted to mount on a gate at the National Cemetery here, the Government announced.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 22--Nepenthe, Grundoon, Congere and Warrior, participants in the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race, were dismasted last night and were proceeding to United States ports this morning, according to a report received here today from the United States Coast Guard in Boston.

Reacting sharply to a statement by the Massachusetts Division of Fish and Game that it and other utilities with dams on the Connecticut River are being uncooperative in providing facilities for upstream passage of shad and Atlantic salmon, the Holyoke (Mass.) Water Power Company says that the accusation is unjustified and inaccurate.

Athol Fugard, the South African playwright held virtually captive in his own country, has written some fine plays, but certainly none better than the amazing "Boesman and Lena," which opened last night at the Circle in the Square, and instantly became the best-acted play in New York.

The broadcast industry, urged by President Nixon two months ago to "get the message across" to young people that drug use is "weakening the character" of the United States, has attempted to keep the dangers of narcotics abuse in front of its listeners in diverse ways.

It was a toss-up at Palisades Amusement Park yesterday whether Sister Mary Rosaire of Staten Island, several hundred policemen and policewomen from all over the city, or several thousand orphans from the metropolitan area had a better time.
HOUSTON, June 22 (Reuters)--The astronaut corps is about to lose another of its charter members, sources close to the space program said today.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- President Nixon's national television address on the economy was a good example of why there is a widespread impression that the nation is failing to come to grips with its major problems, that its leaders instead fall back on high-level public relations and gimmickry.
GENEVA, June 22--Marvin H. Hoffman, formerly a member of Arthur Andersen Co., auditors for Investors Overseas Services, has been appointed financial vice president of I.O.S., it was announced today.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 22--Arthur Ashe led most of the Americans into the second round of the Wimbledon open tennis championship today by destroying Graham Stilwell of Britain on the center court in a match that had enormous possibilities but turned out to be a dud.

Abraham Straus and Ohrbach's, two of New York's largest retailers will operate a major new shopping center in the Rego Park section of Queens, containing large stores of each company. The opening is set for late 1972.
The Controller of the Currency, William B. Camp, has warned banks against engaging in transactions with J.P. Morgan Co., Ltd., a concern not affiliated with the New York bank with a similar name.

WASHINGTON, June 22--A Federal judge said in a report here today that a grand jury had charged a Baltimore contractor with "seeking to obtain the assistance of members" of Congress in connection with an underground garage project here.

On a broad front, prices of American Stock Exchange issues moved lower yesterday in moderately active trading. At the close stocks declining totaled 542, well outnumbering the 195 that advanced. Some 233 issues remained unchanged from last Friday's quotations.
To most of the staff of the city's Criminal Court yesterday, it looked like one more mammoth problem to add to all the rest.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--College freshmen are virtually assured of student draft deferments next fall but the Selective Service System says that the deferments could be short lived.
The four candidates in day's primary contest for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, all bonetired but each exuding confidence, wound up their campaigns yesterday.

CAIRO, June 22--A man with an Albanian passport, said to be a resident of the United States, hijacked an airliner over the eastern Mediterranean today and forced the pilot at pistol point to fly to Cairo.
Steel production edged 0.3 per cent higher last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
PRINCE FREDERICK, Md., June 22 (AP)--Benjamin Parran Sr., agriculturist and cattle breeder, died yesterday after a long illness at Calvert County Hospital. His age was 72.
The Federal Bureau of the Census asked the city yesterday to help recruit 750 to 1,000 census canvassers to work in slum areas here, where the response to mailed census forms has been slow.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- The Democratic National Committee asked the Federal Communications Commissions today to guarantee opponents of a President's policies free network television time to respond to his televised advocacy of those policies.

TORONTO, June 22--Canadian banks, acting virtually in unison, said today they would lower their interest rates on business loans, mortgages and savings accounts. The move was a sign that Ottawa had modified its tight-credit policy because of the sharp rise in unemployment this spring.

JERUSALEM, June 22--Premier Golda Meir rejected today the recent Egyptian suggestion for a temporary cease-fire in the Middle East and warned that if Russian pilots flew combat missions near the Suez Canal, Israel would have "no alternative" but to fight them.
A convicted gambler testified in State Supreme Court yesterday that he had paid the police 500 a month in protection money.

ROME, June 22--The Government decreed emergency measures tonight to assure end-of-term and graduation examinations for more than three million students despite a boycott by high school teachers unions.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 22--Dick Stockton of Gar den City and Sandy Mayer of Woodmere scored victories in the Eastern men's clay-court tennis championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 22--Bernadette Devlin, the 23-year-old Ulster Member of Parliament and Roman Catholic civil rights leader, lost her appeal today against a six-month prison sentence for her part in the riots between Catholics and Protestants in Londonderry last August.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- As the roll-call moved inexorably forward to overwhelming passage today, Robert Carlyle Byrd rested comfortably in his back-row Senate seat, one hand to his mouth, and savored the dimensions of his victory.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 22-- The game that made Brazil the undisputed soccer champion of the world ended in Mexico City yesterday afternoon. The joyous outpouring of national pride that followed in Brazil went on all night and will probably end only after the team returns tomorrow.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22 (UPI)--United States troop strength in South Vietnam is at its lowest point in nearly 40 months, American military spokesmen said today.
ROME, June 22--The Minister of Tourism and Entertainment, Giuseppe Lupis, flew to New York today to start a drive for more American visitors to a country that already seems overrun by them.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- President Nixon resolved a political dilemma today by signing into law a historic measure lowering the voting age from 21 to 18--and then immediately calling for a court challenge to decide if it is constitutional.

David La. Cole, an impartial arbitrator selected jointly by the major league baseball owners and the Major League Players Association, has directed the clubs to pay $82,420 in additional World Series shares to the four teams that finished second in their divisions in 1969.

Wells Fargo Co., parent company of the Wells Fargo Bank, has announced that it has revised the terms of a proposed Wells Fargo mortgage investors' offering through an amendment filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Fred Silverman was promoted yesterday to vice president of programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System. He succeeds Michael H. Dann, who resigned over the weekend to become vice president of the Children's Television Workshop and assistant to its president, Mrs. Joan Ganz Cooney, producer of "Sesame Street."
If a person wants to operate a serpent farm to make snakebite remedies, the city intends to charge him $35 instead of $25 for a permit.

The city's Health and Hospital Corporation, which takes over operation of the 18 municipal hospitals on July 1, cannot provide a budget for "a decent and professionally satisfactory standard of health care," according to a study made for the New School for Social Research.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced here yesterday that he would introduce a bill in the Senate today that would give company shareholders a greater say on social issues.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 22--Secretary General Thant gave an indication today of a new Initiative by the United States State Department that he believed might help to break the deadlock in the Middle East conflict.

Continuing inflation and unemployment have led the State Department of Social Services to estimate a 21 per cent rise in spending on relief grants, along with a 7 per cent increase in statewide welfare recipients for the fiscal year that started April 1.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22--The nine-year-old program of spraying chemical defoliants and herbicides to strip the cover from enemy-controlled base areas in South Vietnam and to kill rice crops in such regions has been suspended, American military sources disclosed today. They said the program was stopped without announcement nearly two months ago.
Edmund H.H. Caddy, former dean of the New York Law School, died of cancer Sunday at Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 544 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.

ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP)-- Americans are uninformed, ineffective critics of their political institutions and complainers about government who take no steps to make it better, a former Cabinet member said today.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 22 (AP)--The Syracuse Chiefs, the first-place team in the International League, whipped the parent New York Yankees, 3-1, tonight in an exhibition game before 9,475 fans.

AACHEN, Germany, June 22 (AP)--William Steinkraus of the United States Equestrian Team guided Snowbound to first place today in a difficult jumping test over 12 obstacles and 14 jumps at the Aachen International Horse Show.
Soybeans futures continued to occupy the main stage on the floor of the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday with the new crop options again setting highs for the season.

A three-judge Federal court ruled yesterday that Nassau County could not prosecute opponents of the war in Indochina who displayed buttons showing a peace symbol superimposed on a representation of the American flag.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) --A Southern Senator's objection tonight struck down a $150-million appropriation intended to soothe the strains of integration for 994 Southern school districts.

Two police cars were set afire and a third was reported damaged last night when a large crowd gathered outside an upper Manhattan police station after a young girl was taken into custody following a dispute among teen-agers.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- A spokesman at the Library of Congress said today that at least 35 countries in addition to the United States, 13 of them Communist, now allowed voting at age 18.

Dr. Robert C. Weaver, the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, resigned as president of Bernard M. Baruch College last night, citing the "uncertainty and inadequacy of financing from the city and state" and the growing frustration of his job.

CAIRO, June 22--The Premier of Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, called tonight for total Arab unity to support the cause of the Palestinians against Israel, declaring that if Arab rulers failed to join the struggle, "the masses must press for this even by revolution."
BIG STONE GAP, Va., June 22--A small Negro congregation has merged with a larger white congregation in this "Trail of the Lonesome Pine" country.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 22 --Australia will double her economic aid to Cambodia but she will not send arms or troops, the Government decided tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) --The Justice Department sought divestiture by the American Steamship Company of one of two competing Great Lakes steamship companies purchased by American last year.

PORTLAND, Me., June 22-- (UPI) The luxury ferry Prince of Fundy completed her maiden round-trip voyage this weekend between this city and Yarmouth, N. S., with a delegation of officials from Maine and Canada aboard.
The day before the primary election was a time for encouraging words at the headquarters of the Democratic gubernatorial and senatorial candidates.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The Supreme Court let stand today a 1967 deportation order against Carlo Gambino, 67-yearold reputed "boss of all bosses" of the six Mafia families in the New York-New Jersey area.
Overseas National Airways, the Cunard Line and the Rotterdam Dockyard Company have reached agreement on the building of a second 17,000-ton cruise ship.

The financially threatened New York Shakespeare Festival has decided to present its dusk-to-dawn production of the "Henry VI" trilogy and "Richard III" on Saturday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.

Mrs. Barbara Jacquet of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Pamela Jacquet, to Haywood H. Davis Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Howard Davis of Norfolk, Va. The future bride is the daughter also of Illinois Jacquet, the jazz saxophonist, of St. Albans, Queens.
A design of six cannonballs stacked as a triangle was selected yesterday as New York State's symbol to mark the 200th anniversary of the Revolutionary War, beginning in 1975.

CHICAGO, June 22--By substituting an experimental merit system "founded upon principles of education and learning" for the traditional initiation rites of basic combat training, two Army doctors are challenging the theory that it is necessary to "break" a recruit to make him into a well-disciplined soldier.

Ogden Phipps's Reviewer shattered a track record of 13 years standing when he won the $28,200 Nassau County at Belmont Park yesterday. Under a sound ride by Braulio Baeza, Reviewer raced the mile and an eighth in 1:46 4/5, eclipsing the standrd of 1:47 1/5 set by Gallant Man under 121 pounds in September, 1957.

Subway riders in Brooklyn were delayed up to two and a half hours yesterday when a BMT express train did a "split," and its rear portion somehow ended up on a separate set of rails. No injuries were reported in the accident, which occurred at the 86th Street station.
ARROW IN THE BLUE. By Arthur Koestler, 416 pages. The Danube Edition: Macmillan $7.95.

Two of the 20 Soviet citizens who were reported implicated in an air hijacking attempt in Leningrad last week were among 27 Riga Jews who had signed a petition to Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin last year requesting permission to emigrate to Israel.

ARLINGTON, Va., June 22 --Mrs. Barbara Bellin, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Bellin of East Orange, N.J., and the late Mr. Bellin, was married here this morning to Martin Stuart Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Michael Kahn of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Municipal Magistrate Francis E. Thomas Jr. performed the ceremony in his office.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn. June 22 (UPI)--The longest strike in the history of Union Carbide's atomic energy facilities here ended last night when members of the Atomic Trades and Labor Council ratified a new contract by a vote of 2,007 to 787.

TOKYO, June 22--The Japanese Government today declared its intention of continuing its security treaty with the United States, which expires tonight. The expected cries of protest were relatively muted.

Arlene Francis, the actress, and William R. Hudgins, president of the Freedom National Bank, will be guests of honor at the 10th annual "Evening of Elegance" at the Boat Basin Rotunda, 79th Street at the Hudson River, on Friday night.

DELLROY, Ohio, June 22-- Henry Ernest Perry, area manager for international sales in the power generation division of the Babcock Wilcox Company, New York manufacturers of power plants, drowned Friday, apparently after suffering a heart attack while sailing on a lake near Massilon. He was 56 years old and lived at 43 Gordonhurst Avenue, Upper Montclair, N.J.

A Federal appeals court ordered a hearing yesterday to determine whether a New York State law enacted after campus violence last year had "coerced colleges to adopt disciplinary codes embodying a 'hard-line' attitude toward student protesters."

The Columbia Broadcasting System set a precedent last night by offering free time over the company's television and radio networks as a regular practice to whatever principal political party was not in occupancy of the White House.
JERUSALEM, Tuesday, June 23--Israeli troops penetrated into Egypt last night, mortared an Egyptian Army center and destroyed two armored troop carriers, a military spokesman said today.

Interest rates continued to move downward yesterday, keeping intact the recovery that began a week ago prior to President Nixon's economic address. This trend toward lower yields was seen most clearly yesterday in the competitive sale of $60-million of Boston Edison Company 30year bonds--an issue that Wall Street underwriters priced to yield 9.20 per cent.

Paper ballots are being used today in a score of upstate counties, adding a confusing element to a primary in which Democrats pick their candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General and United States Senator.

TRENTON, June 22--The Government's key witness in the extortion trial of Hugh J. Addonizio was granted formal immunity from prosecution today at the request of the Department of Justice so that he would testify.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 22-- President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra of Ecuador assumed dictatorial powers today, ending a night of Government confusion and student riots.

Link-Temco-Vought, Inc., the troubled conglomerate concern whose control of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation has been challenged by the Justice Department, is expected to get three seats on the steel company's board later this week.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., June 22 (AP)--The police said the rock 'n' roll band leader Chubby Checker and three other men were arrested at the United States border early today on drug charges.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 22--Units of two American battalions reportedly pulled out of Cambodia today from border regions where they had been searching for enemy facilities.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) --Three natural gas pipeline companies have been authorized by the Federal Power Commission to spend an estimated $29-million, or about $9.5-million each, on separate programs to expand the Ellisburg, Pa., gas storage facilities.

BECKLEY, W. Va., June 22 --Far from Broadway, in the mountains of Appalachia, a new chapter in outdoor theater and an image of the mountain man far different from the comic stereotype of cartoons was created here Saturday night with the premiere of "Hatfields McCoys."
The Joint Legislative Committee on Crime is expected to renew its inquiry soon into one of the most sensitive and rumor-ridden area of politics-- how a lawyer gets to be a judge.

TRENTON, June 22--Acting under a controversial new law, a real estate developer and 12 black apartment seekers filed suit today against zoning ordinances that they charged excluded Negroes and other lowincome minority groups from a suburban community.

A building superintendent in the Bronx was arrested last night after the police found two of his five children living alone in one of two apartments he apparently maintained, and found all five children with marks indicating they had been beaten.

Fewer than a million of the state's 3.6 million enrolled Democrats are expected to vote today to elect their party's candidates for Governor and United States Senator in the first full test of the 1967 New York primary election law.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) --The price of the most expensive Government building ever --a new headquarters for the Federal Bureau of Investigation --has gone up by $5-million. Meanwhile, all that is visible at the site is a massive hole.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Senator William Proximire, Ralph Nader, and a host of other advocates of consumer interests chronicled today deceptive and threatening methods used by some creditors to collect debts that may or may not have been owed to them.

A number of questions have been raised by some insiders at the General Dynamics Corporation and Wall Street observers regarding the company's 1969 financial report and its recent comments about the income statement.
YONKERS, June 22--Keith Drake, candidate for the Democratic nomination in the 25th Congessional District, today clarified his position on Nixon Administration policies in Southeast Asia.

NORTH CALDWELL, N.J., June 22--Jerry Swon of Fairmont, an amateur, carded a two-under-par 36, 33--69 today at the Green Brook Country Club and led 62 qualifiers into the 50th New Jersey open championship.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 22 (UPI)--Harry Lang, who wrote of the rise of the American labor movement and of life on New York's Lower East Side, died today of pneumonia at the age of 81.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- The chief defense counsel for two former poverty workers charged in Federal Court today that the Government had made "gross misstatements of fact" before the grand jury that indicted the two for contempt of Congress.

Evidence supporting a new theory to explain the extraordinary speed and precision with which enzymes catalyze biological reactions is being reported today at a symposium in Riga, Soviet Latvia, by an American biochemist.
The Theater Guild will present "Bech," a play by Eric Ambler and Leonard Spigelgass based on John Updike's recently published "Bech: A Book," on Broadway in September.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 22-- William (Buddy) Gilmour, who was refused a license to drive at New York's standardbred tracks in January of 1967, was granted a license tonight by the New York State Harness Racing Commission.
The Dutch airline KLM is investigating a complaint that some of the crew and most of the passengers on a recent student charter flight to Europe were smoking marijuana and hashish.

Frank Robinson, the batter, did better against Cal Koonce, the last Boston pitcher, than Frank Robinson, the fielder, did against Ken Brett, the first Boston pitcher, and that's why the Baltimore Orioles beat the Red Sox, 9-8, last night.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 22 (AP)--A military spokesman said today that enemy forces were quitting Kompong Thom, a provincial capital 80 miles north of Pnompenh. But it was thought that the North Vietnamese there might be taking a breather before making another attack.

The trade that Wall street had been watching for yesterday--the opening in Penn Central common stock--took place at the final bell and it was a whopper. Pennsy's stock plunged 4 5/8 points to 6 on a mammoth transaction of 450,000 shares. Two years ago, this issue sold at a peak price of 86 .

PARIS, June 22--Against a sober background of anxiety over the dollar, caused by the troubles of the Penn Central Transportation Company, a new device was announced today to help American companies raise funds in Europe.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 22 (AP)--Jose Manuel Ibar, known as Urtain, retained his European heavyweight championship by outpointing the German challenger, Jurgen Blin in a sensational fight tonight.

CHICAGO, June 22--Roman Caholic doctors fought today to have the American Medical Association sidetrack a recommendation of its board of trustees that would favor the repeal of all laws limiting abortions.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- Following is the text of the statement made by President Nixon today as he signed legislation extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 and lowering the minimum voting age to 18:
KOMPONG SPEU, Cambodia, June 22--A Cambodian Army officer declared here today that "the population now has more fear of the South Vietnamese than of the Vietcong."
WASHINGTON, June 22-- The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional New York City's system of denying jury trials to persons accused of crimes that carry sentences of up to one year in prison.

The Urban Arts Corps, an integrated group of professional performers between the ages of 16 and 25, will present "But Never Jam Today" at the Mount Morris Amphi Theater, 122d Street near Lenox Avenue, on Friday at 8:30 P.M. Admission is free.

A secretary to House Speaker John W. McCormack testified yesterday that she had been told by Dr. Martin Sweig, Mr. McCormack's chief aide, to take orders from Nathan M. Voloshen because "it would be the same as doing it for the Speaker."
A 23-acre tract of woodland on the Palisades has been leased by Columbia University for ecology field trips.
ROME, June 22--The United States and Italy signed today a new air transport agreement that awarded new routes to carriers of the two countries.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans reported "some progress" today in the first round of talks on the sensitive textile import question between himself and Kiichi Miyazawa, Japanese Minister of Trade and Industry.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 22 --Margaret Dixon, managing editor of The Baton Rouge Morning Advocate and reporter of the Louisiana political scene from the days of Huey P. Long through the current legislative session, died of cancer last night. She was 62 years old.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 22-- The 34-year-old mother of three children won a $500,000 settlement today from a hospital and three doctors fro brain damage she suffered during a six-hour open heart operation.

BLITAR, Indonesia, June 22 (Reuters)-- More than 50,000 mourners joined weeping relatives as former President Sukarno, the founder of modern Indonesia, was lowered into his grave with full state honors today.

The contract covering 22,000 workers in New York City voluntary hospitals expires next Tuesday, with every present sign pointing to a strike. That is an unconscionable prospect, both because it would endanger the lives of the sick and because the preponderance of Negroes and Puerto Ricans among the workers would aggravate racial tensions.
One place where two can Mill live as cheaply as one, if only for a matter of hours, is a theater that is selling "twofers."

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Much of the soft coal industry was crippled today by wildcat strikes as roving pickets protested the policies of their union and a closed-door meeting here on mine safety by Government and coal industry officials.
David Schwartz, president of Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapels, inc., died of a heart attack Sunday at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 64 years old and lived at 81 La Salle Drive, Yonkers.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 22 (UPI)--The California Assembly passed a bill today that prohibits schools from busing children for racial integration or any other purpose without their parents' consent.

PENN VALLEY, Pa., June 22--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dorrance Jr. of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Ellen Dorrance, to Frank Alfred Craven, son of Mrs. Frank Tempest Craven of Yardley and the late Mr. Craven.

DETROIT, July 22--A major component of General Motors Corporation's new mini car will be made in Europe. The car, the Vega 2300, which may be in production by the end of the month, will carry a manual transmission made in West Germany and imported into the United States.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP)-- Mayor Kevin H. White announced today that despite his defeat at the state Democratic convention, he would enter the primary election with three other candidates for the gubernatorial nomination.

STOCKHOLM, June 22-- The United States players crushed their nearest rivals, Nationalist China, or Taiwan, in the 12th round of the world championship qualifying stage here this afternoon, thus removing the faint mathematical chance that they would not reach the final and also throwing wide open the race for the crucial second position.

Refused to grant permission to Cassius Clay to go to Canada for a title fight with Joe Frazier. The former heavyweight boxing champion is appealing a conviction for refusing to submit to induction into the armed forces (unnumbered, Clay v. United States).

TURIN, Italy, June 22 (Reuters)--Prof. Robert Triffin of Yale University said here today that the creation of a European reserve currency would allow European central banks to substitute their own currencies for the United States dollar in foreign exchange dealings.

When a candidate wants to feel the pulse of his electorate; a manufacturer of a new product, the pulse of a housewife, or an ad agency, the pulse of a consumer, they usually end up in the hands of a woman like Mrs. Chezna Copeland and the women who work for her. Professional pulse-feelers all.

Gustave Tassell never did make baby dresses, which is perhaps why he latched on to the midi length so avidly. Back in December, when most designers were still equivocating, he came out strongly for below-the-knee hemlines for spring. Knees were banished by the time he showed his summer clothes two months later.

The marriage of Miss Ingrid Junker to Roger Royce Conant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Royce Conant of Pelham, N.Y., took place yesterday in the medieval Oddernes Church near Kristiansand, Norway. The Rev. John Nilsen officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arne Johan Junker of Kristiansand.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Mrs. Annis Chaikin Sorensen, the mother of Theodore C. Sorensen, a Democratic candidate for the Senate nomination from New York, died in a hospital here today of cancer. She was 81 years old, and lived in Lincoln, Neb. Her husband, C. A. Sorensen, a former Attorney General of Nebraska, died in 1959.
Nearly 1,000 persons attended a rally against narcotics abuse yesterday in front of the Federal Hall Memorial, in the heart of the financial district.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) --Leaders of seven college student groups protesting American involvement in Southeast Asia today announced coordination of their lobbying effort and plans to assist "peace and new priorities" candidates for Congress.

BONN, June 22--Foreign Minister Walter Scheel, the leader of the small Free Democratic party, received a vote of confidence, 240 to 100, and two minutes of applause and cheering at the party's annual convention here today after having delivered a defense of his policy of middle-of-the-road liberalism.

ALBANY, June 22 (AP)--A strike by Teamsters Union truck drivers has halted delivery of Ford Motor Company vehicles in parts of several Northeastern states, a spokesman for Automobile Transport, Inc., in nearby Selkirk, said today.

TORONTO, June 22--Great Canadian Oil Sands, Ltd., the Sun Oil Company subsidiary that is extracting synthetic crude oil from the sands of northern Alberta, estimated today that it lost $9-million in the first half of 1970, compared with a loss of $16.2-million for the same period a year earlier.

Jack Dempsey will celebrate his 75th birthday tomorrow but a warm-up anniversary party was tossed for him in Madison Square Garden last week just before the Quarry-Foster fight. The Garden gala was significant in two respects because it provided a two-way glimpse of the old heavyweight champion of the world. Both were impressive and one was awesome to the point of being frightening.

WASHINGTON, June 22--Administration sources conceded today that a plan to rescue the Penn Central with $200-million in Federally guaranteed loans had been abruptly abandoned when the White House decided that its political risks were too large.
In a sharp reversal yesterday, the London stock market lost a good part of the large gains it had made on Friday in reaction to the Conservatives' election victory. Trading was quiet.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., the conglomerate, is holding discussions concerning the possible acquisition of a stock interest in Societe Generale Immobiliari, one of the largest real-estate and construction companies in Italy.
The American bishop of the Roman Catholic Church have received permission from the Vatican to make a series of changes designed to speed the granting of annulments of marriages involving Catholics.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--President Nixon discussed student unrest for an hour and a half today with the presidents of 19 colleges and universities.

Jazz in some of its longerestablished aspects entered the "Tally Hall Sampler" series at Alice Tally Hall on Sunday night. The World's Greatest Jazz Band, Maxine Sullivan, the Teddy Wilson Trio and a septet led by Zoot Sims played a program that went all the way back to "Tin Roof Blues" and came up to a recent composition by Bud Freeman called "That D Minor Thing."

BILLINGS, Mont., June 22 --The engagement of Miss Janet Ruth Hurly to Brian O'Donoghue White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross O'Donoghue White of New Canaan, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. John T. Hurly.

TRINIDAD, Colo., June 18 --Through the peculiar processes of American politics, the Model Cities Program, designed to attack urban blight in large metropolitan areas, has found its way into this remote coal mining town of fewer than 10,000 people.
The book, "A World in Flames," was written on the kitchen table while the children were in school.

Richard Burton, whose portrayal of Henry VIII in "Anne of the 1000 Days" proved unsuccessful in the competition for best actor honors in the recent Academy Award sweepstakes, will return to the screen in "Raid on Rommel," a World War II adventure that goes before the cameras in Mexico on Monday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I. June 22-- The president of the Suffolk County Cartmen's Association and his partner in two carting concerns were indicted today on charges of having used threats of violence and death against a competitor to retrieve business the latter had won away from them.
The Singer Company announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to acquire for stock the Besco Organization, a California independent real estate developer.
LONDON, June 22--British tourist officials, who have been attracting young American travelers with the theme "London is a nonstop party," are hoping that the party may soon be over.

TORONTO, Tuesday, June 23--William M. Kunstler, the trial lawyer for the Chicago Seven, was beaten and knocked down by a group of rightists last night when he tried to deliver a speech. He apparently was not seriously hurt.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 22-- Is an athletic department accountable to the rest of the University? How far does this jurisdiction go in its relationship to the student athlete?

WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)--Serious reported crime in the United States increased 13 per cent during the first quarter of this year, compared to the like quarter in 1969 despite the Nixon Administration's heavy emphasis on "law and order."

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 22--Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick May have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Hartwick May, to Edward Watson Birkford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Davidson Bickford of Bethlehem, Pa.
HORSHAM, Pa., June 22 (AP)--Mrs. Judy Rankin of Midland, Tex., who trailed by seven strokes, carded a five-underpar 68 today and won the $25,000 George Washington golf tournament by one stroke.

WASHINGTON, June 22-- Gerard C. Smith, chief United States negotiator at the talks with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms, conferred with Secretary of State William P. Rogers after arriving from Vienna today for consultations.
WASHINGTON, June 22-- President Nixon vetoed a bill today for construction and modernization of medical facilities.

In the first test of New York State's new challenge primary law for the selection of gubernatorial candidates, Democrats will go to the polls today to choose between Arthur J. Goldberg and Howard J. Samuels. Members of that party will also choose nominees for Lieutenant Governor, Attorney General and United States Senator. Democrats, as well as Republicans and members of the Conservative party, will make selections in nomination races for Congress and other offices.

Prize money totaling $200,000 will be awarded in the world Grand Prix of tennis and a year-end Masters tournament among the Prix leaders, according to an announcement yesterday by Pepsi-Cola, the sponsor in conjunction with the International Lawn Tennis Federation.
MONTREAL, June 22--Eight persons were arrested over the weekend in connection with a number of recent bombings in Montreal.

Miss Judith Ellen Seldel, an editor with the Twentieth Century Fund, and Leon Irwin Jacobson, a lawyer with Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison, plan to be married on Aug. 30.

The New York Stock Exchange provided yesterday the following list of bonds that will be traded with the letter "Q" preceding the basic ticker Symbol, designating a company in receivership or bankruptcy proceedings.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 22--The Rev. Dr. John Legare O'Hear, rector of Christ Church Christians Hundred (Episcopal), and Mrs. O'Hear have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Berwick O'Hear, to Robert Silliman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Harper Silliman of Hagley, Montchanin.
If you bought Electronic Data Systems at 150, you may, have been horrified several weeks ago when the stock dropped to 70 in just two days.

It may seem as if the entire world is on a low-calorie diet, but there are still enough people who eat cookies and cake to make baking a rewarding task. And for those people, here are two recipes that would be good served with coffee or a tall glass of homemade lemonade.
CHICAGO, June 22-- The New York Mets and Chicago Cubs resumed hostilities today before 24,867 persons in Wrigley Field and the Mets took Round One with a 9-5 victory.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 22--Prime Minister John Vorster has come home from his European tour with reassuring words contending that this country is not so much a social outcast after all.
BOSTON, June 22--Maj. Gen. William Henry Harrison Jr., former Adjutant General of Massachusetts, died here on Saturday. He was 73 years old and lived in the city's Roxbury section.

John P. Lightcap, the public address announcer at Shea Stadium, died at Memorial Hospital yesterday of lung cancer. He was 53 years old, and lived at 227-50 112th Avenue, in, Queens Village, Queens. Mr. Lightcap had announced the first three Mets games this year before entering the hospital.

CHICAGO, June 23 A team of United States Public Health Service researchers reported today that they had developed an improved culture medium in which to grow the bacterium that causes gonorrhea and that they now could infect an animal the chimpanzee to study the commonest form of venereal disease.

OTTAWA, June 23 Repre- sentatives of the United States and Canada took first steps to- day to coordinate a joint plan to end pollution of the interna- tional waters of the Great Lakes and the St. Lawrence River.
Sales of new cars in the nation rose 16.7 per cent in the June 11-20 period, based primarily on a record performance by the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest auto maker.

Creation of a Youth Conservation Corps that would provide useful employment in national parks and forests echoes the New Deal's Civilian Conservation Corps, which lasted from 1933 to 1942 and became one of President Roosevelt's most popular domestic recovery programs. Designed mainly to bring relief to the young unemployed, the C.C.C. brought lasting benefits to the nation through soil erosion control, forest fire-fighting and reforestation.
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) A test case of the new Federal voting rights law was filed today in the Federal District Court here.

Growing worry over the ramifications of the move by the Penn Central Transportation Company for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws probably was the cause of the decline yesterday in prices on the American Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Negotiations on textiles between the United States and Japan stalled today but further talks were scheduled for tomorrow.

A special committee of the American Bar Association has recommended strict changes in the 46-year-old Canons of Judicial Ethics to prevent conflicts of interest by judges in municipal, state and Federal courts.

Gilbert, the onetime multimillionaire convicted on Federal and state charges of swindling and looting corporate accounts, testified yesterday that "a lobbyist" for House Minority Leader Gerald R. Ford Jr. sent him to Nathan M. Voloshen for help in getting a suspended sentence in a New York state court.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today refused to allow Michigan Consolidated Gas Company to engage in any more financing of homebuilding in Michigan.
Out Chicago way, the Alberto-Culver folk are testing a new toothpaste. At the moment it's called Excitement and the company is saying very little about it.
WASHINGTON, June 23 One bright October day in 1963, President Kennedy Called Representative Wayne N. Aspinall to the White House. "Wayne," said the President, "I'd like to have that wilderness bill."

Virtually complete returns showed early today that suburban Democrats were almost evenly divided in their gubernatorial preferences, with Arthur J. Goldberg winning the narrowest of victories over his rival, Howard J. Samuels.

One by one the operas in the Metropolitan repertory are making their last stands and Monday night it was the turn of "Aida" to be heard for the final time at the Met this season.

The American Broadcasting Company and National Broadcasting Company, in response to the Columbia Broadcasting System's offer of free time to critics of White House policies, stated yesterday that they believed they could give fairer television coverage by making case-by-case judgments.

A sweeping realignment of air routes in and out of New York will be put into effect at one minute past midnight tonight by the Federal Aviation Administration.
LONDON, June 23 Secre- tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that South Viet- namese forces would be free to operate anywhere in Cambodia after June 30.

Textile markets continued to reflect weakness and caution in buying by trade outlets and consumers, the American Enka Corporation explained in reporting yesterday lower earnings for the three and six months ended June 14.

A Bronx gambler testified yesterday that he had paid various units in the New York Police Department $1,650 a month for protection from arrest.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Senate Banking Committee took up bank holding company legislation today in closed session.

The stock market gave way yesterday to a new set of anxieties with fears of corporate liquidity the culprit this time as prices tumbled along a broad front. The Dow-Jones industrial average plummeted 18 points, falling steadily through the session, to finish at 698.11.

Efforts to restore Congressional responsibility in the warmaking process and to limit Presidential expansion of the war in Indochina have been unwisely weakened by the latest modification of the Cooper-Church amendment in the Senate.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 19 It is 20 years since the North Korean onslaught across the 38th Parallel on June 25, 1950. But there is no real peace in Korea today, and the Government of South Korea still remains in great doubt that it could withstand another such attack on its own.

CHICAGO, June 23 It may have been the lively baseball, the age of Aquarius or simply the fact that, when the Mets play the Chicago Cubs, strange things happen. But in a 3 hour fantasy today before 28,118 persons in Wrigley Field, the Mets scored two runs in the ninth inning and two in the 10th to subdue their archrivals, 12-10.

Graduate students at the City University will have to pay a $50 general fee instead of $18 and $10 more in instructional charges for each credit under a new fee structure detailed yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.

TRENTON, June 23 The prosecution's key witness in the extortion trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark testified here today that Anthony (Tony Boy) Boiardo, a reputed Mafia operator, who is also on trial, had been introduced to him as "the real boss of Newark."

Roy White, who helped out during the New York postal emergency last winter, will start an emergency of his own today when the Yankees return to the Stadium with a double-header against the Cleveland Indians.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The Supreme Court extended its one-man, one-vote doctrine today to hold that persons who do not pay real estate taxes cannot be barred from voting on proposed general obligation bond issues.
CHICAGO, June 23 Ed Kranepool, the last of the original New York Mets, was sent to the minor leagues tonight and his place on the roster was taken by a 23-year-old rookie named Ken Singleton.
Short-term interest rates as well as long-term bond yields declined, once again yesterday.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 Air observations of the Newport-to-Bermuda race course made between 4 and 6 P.M. today indicated that of the yachts bearing down on the new turning mark at Argus Tower, the 48-foot Class C sloop Carina, appeared to be faring best in the over-all picture.

The transitive verb "demoralize," meaning to corrupt the morals of, to deprave, is pure American. Indeed, its purity traces to Noah Webster, the 19th century American lexicographer, who coined it his only improvisation.
BELGRADE, June 23 (Reuters) A group of 14 students have gone on a hunger strike at Belgrade's School of Philosophy over what they call "the plight of miners and other hungry people in Yugoslavia."

DULCE, N.M. The Jicarilla Apache Indians here, as well as other Indian tribes, had long had a fondness for Johnny Cash, the country folk singer, who has used his national television appearances to sing and talk about Indians who have had their lands taken from them by force.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) Tony Jacklin, winner of the United States Open golf championship, arrived in London from the United States today and immediately drove north to Lincolnshire to keep a six-month-old promise.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 23 Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Taylor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Lee Taylor, to Timothy H. Avery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert, A. Avery of Burbank, Calif.
BRASILIA, Brazil, June 23 (UPI) A crowd of more than 5,000 greeted the Brazilian soccer team at Brasilia Airport today when the team returned home after winning the World Cup.
WASHINGTON, June 23 United States international monetary reserve assets declined in May, mainly because of another large drop in for- eign-currency holdings, the Treasury disclosed today.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 23 On the platform of a Lehigh University auditorium here Dr. Frederick M. Fowkes, head of the university chemistry department, held up a test tube containing a thimbleful of "water." As an audience of eminent chemists and physicists watched, he tilted the tube and the liquid rolled about thickly.
Truck drivers for Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., resumed deliveries in "dangerous slum areas" yesterday after the bakery company agreed to put two men on each truck as a deterrent against holdups.
The Rev. Billy Graham, who opens a five-day crusade tonight at Shea Stadium, deplores widespread identification of patriotism with the political right.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (AP) Evonne Goolagong says no one seems to pronounce her name right. But Wimbledon tennis buffs are calling her a champion of the future.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 23 Steve Ross of Brooklyn and Steve Siegel of Teaneck, N.J., won two matches apiece to gain the quarterfinals of the Eastern men's clay court tennis championship today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved cautiously higher yesterday on the strength of favorable company results and hopes of an early announcement of policies by the new Conservative Government.
CIMARRON, N.M. Jiggs Porter refuses to live on daylight saving time. His watch is always an hour behind and if he had his way, that hour would be years.
The A. P. food store at 1211 Madison Avenue, between 87th and 88th Streets, will be closed from 9 A.M. to noon tomorrow for a final accounting of the loss of its foremost asset a human life.

BRUSSELS, June 23 What amounts to a censure of American corporate activity in Europe, one of the severest yet made by an official body, has been produced in a secret report by the Executive Commission of the European Economic Community.
Now that Bill Singer has shed his infectious hepatitis, the Los Angeles Dodgers have developed a case of infectious winning.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 23 Mr. and Mrs. Allan Edwin Shore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marylu Shore, to John Lewis Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Simon of Bayonne, N.J.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Navy announced today that it was making a long-delayed contract award of $2.1billion to Litton Industries to build 30 destroyers over the next eight years.
George W. Naumburg, retired banker and philanthropist, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 778 Park Avenue.

Leo Ritter, the furrier, doesn't believe in being a fashion dictator. He's very accommodating about lengths, for instance. Although he's showing a lot of boot-top hemlines, a number of his new coats are just below the knee and others several inches above.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 23 (AP) The 12-Meter yacht, France, the French contender for the America's Cup, has arrived at Newport along with two other yachts owned by the same syndicate.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 23 The Southampton College Scholarship Endowment Fund and the East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Society's civic projects will benefit from an island safari on Friday, Saturday and Sunday when Robert D.L. Gardiner will be host on Gardiners Island.
GENEVA, June 23 A United Nations organ today postponed until January a decision on whether to advance $10-million toward an $80-million addition to United Nations Headquarters in New York.
CHICAGO, June 23 The American Medical Association gave lukewarm support today to the concept of national health insurance but asked that doctors rather than the Government monitor such a system.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) The House Commerce Committee approved a $35-million authorization bill today for activities of the Public Broadcasting Corporation in fiscal 1971. The corporation provides programing and other support for educational radio and television stations.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 23 Long Island's invasion by red and blue polka-dotted gypsy moth caterpillars today was extended to the Suffolk County Legislature, which greeted the hairy brown creatures with revulsion and a resolution to eradicate them.

CHICAGO, June 23 At least 760 campuses about 30 per cent of all colleges and universities in the country played some role last month in the first national student strike in American history, a private research group reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Army dismissed criminal charges today against a brigadier general and two other officers implicated in an alleged cover-up of the Songmy incident.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The Federal Reserve Board, moving rapidly after the Penn Central Transportation Company filed for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act on Sunday, acted today to help assure that banks would have enough funds to meet calls upon them by their creditworthy corporate borrowers.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 23 Rupert Campbell Thompson Jr., who was a top executive officer for 11 years of Textron, Inc., the country's first industrial conglomerate, died today of cancer in Jane Brown Hospital here. He was 64 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Following are the members of the Public Land Law Review Commission. The chairman is Representative Wayne N. Aspinall, Democrat of Colorado.

The good idea called "Tully Hall Sampler," a mixed grill of programs presented by the Metropolitan Opera Studio, came to an end Monday night with a concert of "20th Century Romanticism from France." Three of the studio's young singers soprano Colette Boky, tenor Melvin Brown and Gene Boucher offered a shrewdly balanced menu of solo selections that ran from the zoological camp of Poulenc to the sensuous seriousness of Debussy.

VENICE, Italy, June 23 On the second day of the official critics opening of the 35th Venice Biennale, carpenters were still working to get the showrooms in order, and artists were still waiting for power sources for their works.
LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP) Widgeon, a Cal 40 yacht skippered by Milton Stratford of San Diego, took over the handicap lead today in the 3,571mile Los Angeles-Tahiti transPacific yacht race.

The engagement of Miss Jean Rappy to Richard Aaron Marks has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Rappy of New York, parents of the future bride. Mr. Marks is the son of Mrs. Jules Epstein, also of New York, and the late Henry Marks.
PRAGUE, June 23 (Reuters) Former Premier Oldrich Cernik, one of the leading reformers of 1968, resigned as Minister of Technical and Investment Development today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 The National Commission on Product Safety, concluding a two-year, $2-million investigation, urged Congress today to authorize mandatory Federal safety standards for products used by householders and their families.

AACHEN, West Germany, June 23, (AP) Bill Steinkraus, Neal Shapiro and Frank Chapot of the United States failed to place in the second qualification round today for the jumping prize at the Aachen international horse show, but Steinkraus and Kathy Kusner won earlier events.
ONTARIO, Calif., June 23 (AP) Qualifying for the first California 500 auto race will be held Saturday and Sunday, Aug. 29 and 30, the Ontario Motor Speedway announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (Reu- ters) Secretary of State William P. Rogers has cautioned his advisers to pay attention to the legal implications of United States actions in future international crises.

NEWARK, June 23 A move to change the form of Newark's city government from a Mayor-Council back to a fivemember commission has been started by Anthony Imperiale, a white militant Councilman who lost out in his bid to become Mayor in the May 12 election.
LONDON, June 23 Prince Charles won a Cambridge bachelor's degree with honors today, the first university degree to be earned by an heir to the British crown.

As Jack Sharkey approached Jack Dempsey in the middle of the ring, they mockingly assumed fighting poses, laughed at their private joke and embraced. It happened at Madison Square Garden a week ago when the fight mob jumped the gun in paying public tribute to Dempsey on his 75th birthday, which actually is today.
GUILFORD, Conn., June 23 Robert C. La Borde, who invented and manufactured wiretap devices, died at his home here last night. He was 69 years old and lived at 1045 Long Hill Road.

A plaque honoring John D. Rockefeller 3d for his "inspiration and leadership" in the conception and building of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts was dedicated here yesterday with Governor Rockefeller and other notables in the arts and in government attending.

"The Man in the Middle," a study of three Metropolitan area working-class families who find their cherished values of God, country, family and hard work insufficient in a time of swift sociological change, was presented last night on WNBCTV.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission issued guidelines today for the offering and sale of shares in mutual funds and open-end investment companies to investors outside the United States.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 Arthur Ashe reached the third round of the All-England tennis championships today but it took all his feline touch on stroke and volley to blunt the thunderbolts from Nikki Pilic's service in an enthralling four-set battle that raged over 2 hours 45 minutes.
Representative Richard L. Ottinger, helped by an energetic and expensively mounted campaign, won the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York yesterday.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 23 University professors and business leaders are reported to have been jailed by the military here following the assumption of "supreme powers" by President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra yesterday.
STANTON, Del., June 23 (AP) After six straight favorites had disappointed their backers, Augustus B. Gay's Flutter Away came to the rescue with a victory in the seventh race at Delaware Park today.

Frank Reilly has been appointed president of Wallachs, the New York-based chain of 25 men's and women's apparel stores, effective Aug. 1. The chain has units here and in Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and Florida.
Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia was named yesterday to handle the reorganization of the Penn Central Transporta- tion Company under the bankruptcy laws.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 23 Miss Mary Kathleen Cronkite and Mark Robert Stewart were married here Saturday at noon in the meadow of Overbrook Farm, the country estate of Arthur Altschul, the financier, by the Rev. Gerald Deaton of the Covina (Calif.) Christian Church.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 State Auditor Roger Cloud, Republican nominee for Governor of Ohio, defended his role in a Statehouse scandal today and got a vote of confidence from the Republican State Central Committee.

Mayor Lindsay's first press secretary has depicted Mr. Lindsay as less than candid with the public, concerned with his public image, petulant and a poor administrator surrounded by young, power-hungry aides.
The two key figures in the politically explosive abortionreform struggle in the 1970 Legislature one a Republican the other a Democrat were defeated in party primary elections yesterday.
POTOMAC, Md., June 23 Miss Diane Lloyd and Peter Emmet Yaeger will be married Aug. 30 in Washington.

The Rudy Perez Dance Theater is a company of choreographers Mr. Perez, Barbara Roan and Anthony La Giglia each with a personal style but one that has some family resemblance to the others. Mr. Perez is slightly more sobersided, Miss Roan has a winning kookiness and Mr. La Giglia is the ebullient and flip observer of incongruities. Each offered a premiere last night at the Cubiculo.

Around the city, candidates were backed up early this morning, waiting to go on television. Columbia Broadcasting System newsmen were, first, fidgeting, and then just plain annoyed. Only Paul O'Dwyer, a defeated Senatorial candidate, stood by calmly.

AMMAN, Jordan, June 23 A new United States proposal for a Middle East settlement calls for Israel and the Arab countries to accept renewed contacts with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring of Sweden, the United Nations envoy, but makes no mention of direct or indirect talks between the parties in the conflict.
LONDON, June 23 Prime Minister Heath's new Govern- ment faced its first test of will power today when dock workers called the first official national dock strike since 1926.

The Schering Corporation and Plough, Inc., two large pharmaceutical producers, announced yesterday plans to merge into a new company to be named Schering-Plough Corporation. The market value of the two companies, based on yesterday's closing prices on the Big Board, aggregated $131.9-million.

Norman Katz, an unsuccessful candidate for the State Assembly in the Democratic primary in Brooklyn, was arrested last night for allegedly electioneering too close to a polling place in violation of the law.
WASHINGTON, June 23 The Congress moved rapidly forward on several fronts today to help keep th Penn-Central Railroad running and to try to prevent similar problems on other lines.
A half hour after the primary day balloting started at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Maurice J. O'Rourke was at Public School 194 in Harlem to check on reported trouble there with voting machines.
The longest and richest jumping event on the New York Racing Association's spring calendar, the $39,025 Grand National Handicap Steeplechase, was won by Lake Delaware at Belmont Park yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) President Nixon plans to deliver a summation on the Cambodian aspect of the Indochina war during a week or more to be spent largely at the western White House at San Clemente, Calif.

Antony Tudor's ballet "Jardin aux Lilas" is more than 30 years old, yet its beauty and poignancy remain undimmed. First produced by the Ballet Rambert in London during the late thirties, it was introduced by the American Ballet Theater during its inaugural season in 1940. It wears its years lightly, because it is a work of genius and insight.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 23 Roscoe Turner, one of the most flamboyant and successful pilots of the scarf-and-goggles era of the nineteen-thirties, died in an Indianapolis hospital today after a two-month illness. He was 74 years old.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 23 Enemy forces attacked Prek Tameak, a town on the Mekong River 20 miles north of Pnompenh last night but were repulsed by Cambodian troops after a night of fighting.

The distinguished record of public service Arthur J. Goldberg brought to the contest for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, plus his stranglehold on organization support, gave him a hard-won victory in yesterday's statewide primary. The loser, Howard J. Samuels, earned respect for the intensity of his campaign, but he could not triumph over the solidity of the Goldberg record as Supreme Court Justice, Secretary of Labor and Ambassador to the United Nations.
When Yvonne Stamper was growing up on a wheat farm 100 miles east of Spokane, Wash., she would pore through the Sears, Roebuck and Montgomery Ward catalogues and see only the models.

FLORENCE, S.C., June 23 Representative John L. McMillan, the dean of South Carolina's Congressional delegation, won convincing renomination over a Negro physician in today's Democratic runoff primary in the Sixth District.
POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., June 23 (AP) Governor Rockefeller, casting the 34th vote in his home district in today's primary, said he expected "a very tough race" in his bid for re-election in the fall.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 23 Two former champions were eliminated as the first round the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 67th annual championship was completed today.
MOSCOW, June 23 (Ap) Lev Alexandrovich Zenkevich, a prominent Soviet oceanographer, died in Moscow last Saturday at the age of 81, Pravda reported today.

The struggle over which city, if any, will have a major exposition in 1976 when the nation celebrates its 200th birthday heightened yesterday as the executive committee of the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission began two days of closed hearings here to listen to further pleas from Philadelphia, Boston and Miami. The three cities are competing for the honor and the accompanying economic rewards.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, moved today to make it easier for shareholders to influence corporate decisions affecting environmental and social problems.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 23 President Chung Hee Park said today that the continued presence of American troops in South Korea was "absolutely necessary" until this country has built up its own capability to defend itself against Communist aggression.

President Nixon has served the nation well in his handling of the combined Congressional action to extend the Voting Rights Act and lower the voting age to eighteen. He did not let his belief that an age qualification fixed by the Federal Government would require a constitutional amendment get in the way of his signing the legislation and thus clearing the way for the courts to resolve that question.

LANCASTER, Pa., June 23 Eastern college basketball officials are threatening to withhold their services for the 19701971 season unless agreement is reached on a new fee scale with the Eastern College Basketball Association.
The question of who took a bath in the shares of the Penn Central Company continues to intrigue Wall Street. The answer appears to include a number of big holders.

The State Commissioner of Education ruled yesterday that students did not have the constitutional right to remain seated as a protest while their classmates rose to recite the Pledge of Allegiance.

The move by the Penn Central Transportation Company for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws spread its ripples across Wall Street yesterday as the stock of the Chrysler Corporation fell to a new low after a delayed opening following rumors of major liquidity problems at the auto maker.

Arthur J. Goldberg won a close victory over Howard J. Samuels yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Governor as State Senator Basil A. Paterson and Adam Walinsky easily won the party's nominations for Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General.

"George M!," the hit musical that recounted highlights in the career of George M. Cohan, will be televised as a 90-minute special on the National Broadcasting Company network Saturday Sept. 12, at 7:30 P.M. Joel Grey, who created the role on Broadway and won a Tony Award for his performances as the cocky tunesmith, will star in the television version.

The appointment of Frederick P. Rose as chairman of the 1970-71 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York was announced yesterday by George H. Heyman Jr., president of the organization.
About 2,000 people awaiting the arrival of Mae West and Raquel Welch jammed the area of the Criterion Theater last night for the premiere of "Myra Breckinridge."

Operators of most 1971 model automobiles, soon to reach the market, will be paying as much as they are now, or more, for less efficient gasoline.
