Soybean futures prices leaped ahead yesterday in active trading, following news that the Commodity Credit Corporation had advanced the selling price of number one yellow soybeans for September by one cent a bushel. This follows an increase of 2 cents a bushel last week by the Government agency.

BALTIMORE, June 23 A Fed- eral District Court judge has ordered expunged from court records a special grand jury report that charged a contractor here and his concern with conspiracy to corrupt Congres- sional figures in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 23 Nixon Administration forces acted today to bring to an end the protracted Senate debate on Cambodia in the hope of keeping the Democrats from focusing further political attention on the war issue.
WASHINGTON, June 23 Treasury bill rates declined sharply at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 23 (AP) G.A. Sacks's Evening Bag came from last place to post a three-quarter-length victory in the $12,000 Green Superintendents Pursue at Monmouth Park today.

Coney Island residents who are being ousted from an urbanrenewal site and are demanding suitable replacement housing held 12 city employes prisoner yesterday until the Commissioner of Relocation agreed to transfer two of his workers from the area.
Representatives Adam Clayton Powell and Leonard Farbstein were defeated for renomination yesterday in upsets in the Democratic primary election.

GORI, U.S.S.R. This Georgian town of 45,000 is the only place in the Soviet Union that still boasts a Stalin Avenue leading past a Stalin Museum into a Stalin Square dominated by a bronze statue of Stalin.

WASHINGTON, June 23?A Congressional commission, after a massive five-year study, recommended today that the one-third of the nation's land that is federally owned be largely retained by the Government, but that major changes be made in its management and use.

About the only way you can tell it's Election Day in New York is that the bars are closed. Maybe it's the Puritan's revenge. The only thing worse than politicians with booze is politicians without booze, but anyway, Election Day passes in New York with most people grumbling about the "political system" and less than a third of the eligible voters even going to the polls.

At least 27 youthful members of the Jewish Defense League brought routine import-export business to a sudden stop yesterday afternoon when they stormed through offices of the Amtorg Trading Corporation in retaliation for recent arrests of Jews in the Soviet Union.

JERUSALEM, June 23 Israeli military sources asserted today that since the ArabIsraeli war of June, 1967, Syria had impressively increased her military inventory, almost doubling the number of tanks at her disposal.
There should be many Brian Augers. The British organistpianist and his group, The Trinity, are playing through tonight at Ungano's, 210 West 70th Street, and doing some marvelous things.
MEXICO CITY, June 23 (UPI) The International Federation of Football Associations suspended Rhodesia for two years today by approving an Algerian proposal backed by all black African members.

TOKYO, Wednesday, June 24 Rallies, brief wildcat strikes and scattered acts of violence by militant radicals erupted across Japan yesterday in protest against the security treaty with the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) Labor Secretary George P. Shultz will leave his present job at the end of this month without having fulfilled his plans to open 30 new Job Corps centers by July 1.

Corporate executives whose industries have been under fire as major polluters, turned in progress reports yesterday. In every instance they hinted that more time was needed, primarily to develop better technologies to clean the environment.
Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, announced several changes in the top management of the company yesterday.
For more than two weeks we fled westward in the midst of a massive migration of guerrilla troops and Cambodian peasants.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 23 Dr. and Mrs. George Smith Jr.'s Columbia George encountered no problems en route to his victory in last Saturday's Commodore Pace, in which he easily defeated Truluck, Most Happy Fella and other 3-yearolds at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Frank J. Wilson, former chief of the Secret Service, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital. His age was 83. During his tenure as head of the Secret Service from 1936 to 1947, Mr. Wilson's crackdown on counterfeiting cut losses from about $1.5-million a year to about $50,000 a year.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 (Reuters) President Roberto Marcelo Levingston today af- firmed that his Government was aiming at a return to constitu- tional rule but he indicated that elections were still far off.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 (Reuters) President Roberto Marcelo Levingston today af- firmed that his Government was aiming at a return to constitu- tional rule but he indicated that elections were still far off.
CINCINNATI, June 24-Mrs. Annette Wurlitzer Knoop died here yesterday in her suburban home in nearby Clermont County.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)--A group of prominent citizens headed by a former Democratic Secretary, of State and a onetime Republican Vice-Presidential nominee announced today the formation of a committee to back President Nixon's proposal to expand the antiballistic missile system.

JERUSALEM, June 24--Heavy fighting broke out tonight on the Syrian-Israeli cease-fire line in the occupied Golan heights, and both sides were reported to have exchanged shellfire for three hours and 15 minutes.
James Day was officially recommended last night to be president of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation in a consolidation of the activities of Channel 13 and National Educational Television.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Nationalization of the nation's railroads is "the alternative" to giving troubled carriers a Government guarantee of bank borrowings for working capital, John A. Volpe, Secretary of Transportation, said today.

GENEVA, June 24-Hal W. Vaughan, former United States Foreign Service Officer, has been promoted to senior vice president of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the principal sales subsidiary in the I.O.S. Mutual-fund complex, it was announced today.
LOS ANGELES, June 24 Charles M. Manson, who is accused of slaying seven persons here last year, instructed his attorney today to stand mute and not to question prospective jurors for his trial.

Special to The New York Times STOCKHOLM, June 24-The United States, represented by the Dallas Aces, recovered from a poor start in the world championship final here today and led Nationalist China, or Taiwan, 25-15, at the halfway stage in the match. This is a substantial lead, but not necessarily a decisive one.

President Nixon's doctrine of military self-sufficiency in Asia is receiving short shrift in Seoul. The South Korean Government objects vociferously to a reported plan for the gradual withdrawal of 64,000 American troops and airmen still stationed in that country seventeen years after the Panmuniom armistice.

WASHINGTON, June 24Sargent Shriver today accepted the leadership of a committee to promote the election of Democrats to Congress this fall, thereby formally ending his unannounced candidacy for Governor of Maryland.

BOULDER, Colo., June 24 (AP) In a light municipal turnout, a resolution urging "prompt withdrawal of all United States military personnel from Southeast Asia in a manner consistent with their safety" was defeated yesterday by a 4,960 to4.401 vote.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jnne 24 James D. Maver Jr., and Walter Ulltich of Winged Foot won the Westchester County Golf Association's British Victory Cup tournament today when Maver sank an 18-foot downhill putt for a birdie-4 on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff at Round Hill Club.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24 A controversial bill that would give President Nguyen Van Thieu extraordinary economic powers for five months was passed by the National Assembly today and sent to the Senate.

SUFFERN, N. Y., June 24--Rockland County District Attorney Robert R. Meehan, 39 years old, who was defeated by Adam Walinsky in the Democratic primary for Attorney General, was admitted to a hospital today in what was described as a state of exhaustion.

An annual Miss Venus beauty contest, to select potential film stars, was announced yesterday by Dino De Laurentiis, the Italian movie producer, and Robert Oliver, president of the newly organized Miss Venus International, Ltd., and a former director of the Miss Universe pageant. The contests are slated to be held in two cities, here and abroad, with the first scheduled for next spring in a city yet to be selected.

The City Center Jeffray Ballet will present four new productions, including two works by Todd Bolender, in its fall season. The six-week engagement at the City Center will run from Sept. 29 through Nov. 8.
The stock market, burdened by fears of corporate liquidity, posted another loss yesterday after a mid-session rally failed to hold.

WASHINGTON, June 24President Nixon has invited leaders from 40 newspapers and broadcasting networks to a five-and-a-half-hour private briefing Friday at the Presidential compound in San Clemente, Calif.

ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 24 Two Long Island players, one from New Jersey and one from Westchester reached the semifinal round of the 67th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.
PARIS, June 24 An Irish 49-1 shot, Herring Gull, won the Prix des Drags steeplechase over 2 5/8 miles at Auteuil today.

Contract negotiations between the drug and hospital union and the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York have reached a stalemate, with both sides expressing concern about the possibility of a strike next Wednesday.

Soybeans futures which had been hitting new highs recently fell back yesterday and closed at lower prices for the day after advancing early in the session. Soybean oil and meal futures also closed lower.

A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that the State Legislature and the voters, not the Federal courts, had the power to lower the voting age in New York State, and he dismissed a suit challenging the present minimum age for the franchise of 21 years.

Some of her conclusions are rather startling: Gentlemen no longer prefer blondes. (They like brunettes better.) Their ideal woman is "plumpish" rather than skinny-as-a-fashion-model. And they're becoming more tolerant about considering marriage with an unwed mother.

Governor Rockefeller super seded District Attorney Willard C. Best of Ontario County yesterday and ordered a special grand jury inquiry into recent student disorders on the campus of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, June 24--Rennie C. Davis, the radical leader, met today with organizers of Honor America Day and charged that their planned celebration July 4 was "designed to show a phony consensus for Richard Nixon's foreign and domestic policies."
WASHINGTON, June 24--Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans announced today that negotiations with Japan for voluntary restrictions on exports of textiles to the United States had failed.
DALLAS, June 24-A cenotaph, or empty tomb, was dedicated today to the memory of President Kennedy in brief ceremonies held 200 yards from the site of his assassination Nov. 22, 1963.

Dolly Madison Industries, Inc., which recently sold its ice cream and furniture manufacturing businesses, filed a petition in the U.S. District Court in Philadelphia yesterday for a reorganization under the Chapter X provisions of the Bankruptcy Act. The company, listed on the over-the-counter market, reported a "severe cash shortage."

Thomas J. Donovan of New York and Mrs. Hocace W. Dietrich of Brick House Farm, Ellicott City, Md., and Key Biscayne, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Paul Donovan, to Justin Edward Beals of Washington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs.. Justin Beals of Hillside, Prince George County, Mr.

With the primary election out of the way, Republican campaign strategists yesterday were counting on picking up three Congressional seats from the Democrats this fall, and New York City appeared to be virtually certain of sending the first Puerto Rican to the House of Representatives.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 24 (P) The new leftist government decided today to ask the United States Peace Corps to leave the country.
The London Stock Exchange continued on a roller-coaster course yesterday as prices dipped sharply.

A Federal judge approved yesterday an $82.5-million offer by five major drug companies to settle damage suits brought against them by 66 states, cities, counties and druggists and thousands of individual consumers who charged the companies with fixing high prices on tetracycline and other "wonder drugs."
The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston sharply criticized yesterday Congressional attempts to use the Federal Reserve System to force more money into the housing market.

Mayor Lindsay asked the Federal Government yesterday to transfer Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn to the city for use as a general aviation airport. The 1,100-acre Naval Reserve facility will soon be vacated by the Navy.

CRANFORD, N. J., June 24 Superior Court Judge Harry V. Osborne Jr. and Mrs. Osborne have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Wallace Osborne, to Pierre A. Orsoni of Montmorency, France. A Wedding next month is planned.
WASHINGTON, June 24 President Nixon conferred today with his chief delegate to the talks on the limitation of strategic arms to discuss details of a formal proposal to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 24--President Nixon's men who understand such things keep advising us not to worry about the way prices keep rising. For months now they have had him reassuring us that the worst is over and that prices will settle down contentedly somewhere and stay there.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24 The Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race begaa to end in the predawn darkness today when Windward Passage completed the course as first to finish. By midafternoon, with only a small part of the 149 starters over the St. David's Light finish line, a pattern of performance was forming.

VIENNA, June 24 Alexander Dubcek, the discredited leader of the Czechoslovak reforms of 1968, has been dismissed from his post as Ambassador to Turkey, according to an announcement today by the official Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 Mr. and Mrs. Julian C. Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Louise Smith, to Charles Merrill Ambler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambler of Jenkintown, Pa.

Leaders of the Democratic majority in the City Council yesterday proposed smaller rent increases for most tenants than had been requested by Mayor Lindsay as part of his plan for a vast revision of the city's 27year-old rent control law.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Following is the text of the Gulf of Tonkin resolution on military action in Indochina, which the Senate voted today to repeal: To promote the maintemaintenance of international peace and security in southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Judge John Lewis Smith Jr. of Federal District Court refused today defense moves to broaden the scope of the contempt-of-Congress trial of Alan and Margaret McSurely.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 24 (AP) D. Havemeyer McConville's No Back Talk scored an upset today to win the $22,400 Tyro Stakes at Monmouth Park by a neck from Brazen Brother, whose rider's foul claim was denied.
The handling of baggage was suspended yesterday at the East Side and West Side Airlines Terminals when 50 baggage handlers called in sick, apparently as a result of a labor dispute.

An 18-man accounting board began meeting here yesterday to determine the final form of controversial new principles governing mergers and acquisitions. The board was reported "scrabbling hard" to find areas for compromise among its various factions.

Assemblyman Andrew Stein, Democrat-Liberal of Manhattan, charged officials at the Sheridan Rehabilitation Center yesterday with criminal negligence in the death of a 19-yearold narcotics patient at the state facility June 4.
Dr. E. Sterling Nichol, a pioneer in cardiology and founder of the Miami Heart Institute, died yesterday of leukemia. He was 73 years old.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 24 (UPI)--The President of the American Baptists Association urged yesterday that Americans forget partisan arguments over the Vietnam war and pray that divine providence bring America victory.
A. Lightfoot Walker has been elected chairman of the board of the City Investing Company.
LOS ANGELES, June 24 (UPI) The leaders in the Los Angeles-to-Tahiti yacht race neared the halfway point today in the longest scheduled ocean race in the world.
LONDON, June 24 The Labor party's executive body, meeting today for the first time since the election, warned the new Conservative party Government against resuming the sale of arms to South Africa.
Income tax deductions for gifts to charity begin with some basic homework, or at least complications of the new tax law make it seem more necessary than ever to do some figuring.

There is something fundamentally wrong with an entertainment package--call it "Myra Breckinridge" or whatever you will--that has the luscious Raquel Welch strutting around mannishly, wearing dresses like a uniform. Worse still, a million-dollar doll named Mae West ambles in for a few scenes, including one song, and generally cools it on the sidelines.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., and the Eastman Kodak Company introduced yesterday a new flash cube that requires no battery or external power source when used in a new line of cameras. Spokesmen for the two companies indicated both the flash sources, to be marketed as Magicubes, and the new cameras, designated the Instamatic X line, will he available immediately in retail outlets.

Auden writes that "biographies of writers, whether written by others or themselves, are always superfluous and usually in bad taste" because "a writer is a maker, not a man of action." Mr. Auden is right, of course; and his words should be stamped, like a medical warning, on the spines of
When the Cincinnati Reds played professional baseball's first night game at Crosley Field on May 24, 1935, President Roosevelt turned on the lights by pushing a button in the White House.

BALTIMORE, June 24--George Beall, the United States Attorney for Maryland, said today that he would continue the investigation that led to charges that a prominent Baltimore contractor, Victory H. Frenkil, had conspired to defraud the Federal Government.

A young Puerto Rican tapped on the restaurant window until Jack Dempsey turned and waved. Then the young man carefully took a cigarette out of his mouth and struck a classic boxing pose.

A series of 14 free Hispanic band concerts will be presented in parks in Manhattan and the Bronx from July 7 and through Aug. 20, it was announced yesterday by City Recreation Commissioner Joseph Halper.

BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 24 Bob Shields of Alpine, who used a cart because of a 15stitch gash in his left leg, scored a 32, 33-65 and took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association tournament today.

WASHINGTON, June 24Twenty years have passed since President Harry S. Truman led the country into what he skittishly called a "police action" in Korea, and the controversy thus raised about a President's power to make war still haunts this capital.

MOSCOW, June 24--Soviet musicians dominated the results of the fourth international Tchaikovsky Music Competition, which ended early this morning with the announcement of winners in the violin and piano contests.

A group of Brooklyn Republicans attempting to unseat John R. Crews, their county leader for 36 years, picked up strength in Tuesday's primary but apparently lack enough votes on the county executive committee to achieve their objective.
The lawyer for a New York policeman accused of lying about his connections with gamblers sought yesterday to discredit the testimony of a key prosecution witness.

For some years now, part of the American Ballet Theater's papularity has been tied to Erik Bruhn's coattails and this is unhealthy. Mr. Bruhn's injury and consequent very sad absence this season-it is hoped that he will be fit for the forthcoming European tour-may, in one sense, be a blessing in what is traditionally known as disguise.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (Reuters) Foreign intelligence reports said here today that Soviet pilots in Egypt were flying combat missions south of the Suez Canal and had challenged Israeli jets that crossed the Gulf of Suez.

Prices of American Stock Exchange shares plunged again yesterday for the third successive trading session, and the drop was accompanied by increased activity. Volume increased to 4,050,235 shares, well above the 3.14 million shares moving on Tuesday. The index closed at 20.42, down 0.21.

Comedy, near-tragedy and plain old-fashioned baseball heroics consumed a long afternoon at Yankee Stadium yesterday, where the New York Yankees and Cleveland Indians split a double-header before a crowd of 31,925 and Bobby Murcer hit four straight home runs for the Yankees.
Six persons were arrested for criminal trespass yesterday during a sit-in at Babies Hospital, part of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
George Bennett, president of Bennett Public Relations, Inc., died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 1059 Brighton Street, Union, N. J.
Ruby Keeler, the dancing star of stage and films, is returning to Broadway in November as star of Vincent Youmans's 1925 musical hit, "No, No, Nanette," after an absence of 41 years.

CINCINNATI, June 24 (UPI) Jack R. Howard, president of the E. W. Scripps Company, announced an agreement today to sell Scripps stock in The Cincinnati Enquirer to Francis L. Dale, president and publisher of The Enquirer.

WASHINGTON, June 24-The Food and Drug Administration today completed the legal requirements for removing from the market 48 combination antibiotic drugs that were ruled ineffective more than a year ago after a major study.
MOSCOW, June 24 Mikhail A. Sholokhov, the Nobel Prize novelist, today rebuked Soviet poets who look for things to criticize and who are willing to recite their poems in the Capitol in Washington.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 19 South Korea has undergone a profound political and economic transformation in the 20 years since the North Korean Communists launched their attack across the 38th Parallel on June 25, 1950.

Charles B. Rangel, who defeated Representative Adam Clayton Powell in the Democratic primary, showed up for the start of the 1965 civil rights march from Selma, Ala., dressed in city clothes dark suit, white shirt with cufflinks, raincoat and hatappropriate for the brief,
Dr. Robert L. Ketter, a 41year-old civil engineer who was formerly vice president of the State University of New York at Buffalo, was named president of the institution yesterday, effective July 1.

ROME June 24 The Societa Generale Immobiliare, Italy's largest real estate corporation, announced today that Gulf Western Industries, Inc., had acquired 15 million shares, representing 10.5 per cent of its common stock.
If you want Robert Zollner's advice don't take anybody's advice on the stock market.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation asked the Government today to delay for two more years the 1973 deadline for installing inflatable safety air bags on new cars.
With an eye to a multi-million-dollar gate, a serious attempt is under way to match Joe Frazier against Cassius Clay in Detroit or Seattle on Sept. 22.
KITTERY Me., June 24 (AP) Four construction workers plunged nearly 100 feet to their deaths today when the staging on the under side of a bridge from Kittery to Portsmouth, N. H., collapsed.

CHICAGO, June 24 Two Canadian physicians reported today that by conducting an educational program among physicians at the Montreal General Hospital they had almost halved the incidence of adverse reactions among patients receiving the heart medicine digitalis.

Panic, like some higher forms of grief and joy, is such an exquisite emotion that nature denies its casual recollection to all except psychotics, a few artists and an occasional, pre-existential hero like Yossarian, the mad bombardier of Joseph Heller's World War II novel, "Catch22."

Dr. Frank Stanton may have solved one problem and raised some others by his agreement to let the opposition party have free television time on the Columbia Broadcasting System to reply to Presidential pronouncements.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 24Six Middle Atlantic states formed today an anticrime compact directed chiefly against interstate traffic in narcotics.

ALGIERS. June 24 (AP)--President Houari Boumediene of Algeria told the world's major oil-exporting nations today to bypass the international oil companies and deal directly with the governments of the consumer countries.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Disputing President Nixon's assessment of the economy, the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that recession was an economic fact and "the rhetoric of a radiant tomorrow does not alter it."
The Metropolitan Opera's seventh and final "La Traviata" of tho season Tuesday night had a new Alfredo, Ion Buzea, who sang the role of the first time with the company.

WASHINGTON, June 24The 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution, which the Senate voted to repeal today, was conceived in crisis and haste as a demonstration of national unity. It came to be depicted-at least by Johnson Administration officials-as a declaration of Congressional authority for the American involvement in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon is to leave Sunday on a threeday trip to Peru to take money and relief supplies from private United States groups to help the victims of that country's earthquake of May 31.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Books, microscopes, footballs, helmets and even whole buildings are disappearing from Southern schools that are desegregating, only to reappear in new, all-white "segregation academies," four young civil rights lawyers said today.
Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that there has been a serious deterioration in the over-all profitability of member firms.

SENECA FALLS, N. Y., June 24-Robert W. Root, professor of comparative literature at Eisenhower College here, died of a heart ailment last Thursday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 55 years old and lived on Cayuga Lake Boulevard.

Magnavox will be leaving Kenyon Eckhardt with the intention of farming out the various functions of a fullservice agency to independent companies, according to a memo circulated yesterday at the agency.

George E. McDonald, president of Mailers Unit No. 6, said yesterday that contract negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City were broken off late in the afternoon because of a lack of movement.

MANSFIELD, Pa., June 24 (UPI) Tom McMillen, 6-foot11-inch high school basketball star sought by 250 colleges, picked the University of North Carolina because of its academic, as well as athletic standards, his coach said today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission went to court yesterday to close what it contends is a legal loophole that enables the shares of privately owned companies to be issued publicly without registration.

Operations of the Diamond International Corporation in the 12 and 24 weeks ended June 21 resulted in lower sales and earnings, reflecting in part the continued lower levels of residential construction, William H. Walters, chairman, reported yesterday.

A detective who retired last week before the completion of his Police Department trial on charges of selling confidential information was arrested yesterday in a private East Side hospital and ordered transferred to Bellevue Hospital's psychiatric ward for observation.

BUFFALO, June 24-Joseph F. Crangle, the Erie County Democratic chairman, whose statewide advocacy of Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor was surprisingly rebuffed in his home county yesterday, denied today any permanent damage to the candidate or himself.
The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and the Citizen Watch Company, Ltd., of Tokyo have established a new watch manufacturing company-the BulovaCitizen Company, Ltd. in Tokyo.
The international master D. Minic of Yugoslavia finished in first place during the recent European Zonal Tourney No. 1 in Prais de Rocha, Portugal by the Sonneborn-Berger tie-breaking system.
TEANECK, N. J., June 24Chaim Brisman, an actor, director and sculptor, died of cancer today at Englewood Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 143 Voorheos Street.

The regular political machines can draw little comfort from the results of the Congressional primaries in and around New York. The voters displayed a remarkable ability-especially in those districts where multiple names were on the ballot-to zero in on the candidates who held forth a hope for reform leadership, for liberal approaches in impacted areas where racial difficulties are omnipresent, for new efforts to end the war and reorder priorities.
CHICAGO, June 24 The new president of the American Medical Association called today for doctors of medicine to practice medicine.

Arthur J. Goldberg opened his campaign against Governor Rockefeller yesterday by linking the Republican incumbent to President Nixon and Vice President Agnew-a link that is essential to the Goldberg campaign strategy of rebuilding the traditional Democratic coalition of liberals, working people and minority groups.

LONDON, June 24-The Maharaja of Jaipur, former ruler of a state in India with more than three million people, died today during a polo match at Cirencester, Gloucestershire, about 90 miles from London. His age was 58.

Luckily for the country the end-product of five years of work by the Public Land Law Review Commission is a report, not yet a piece of legislation. As a study, curiously outmoded in tone, it can be read, pondered and put on the shelf. As an omnibus bill for the reform of American land policy, it would call for alarm signals from every conservation group in the land.
Bond prices rose and interest rates declined again yesterday as investors continued to worry about corporate liquidity, the stock market and the health of the economy.
The Danforth Foundation of St. Louis announced yesterday that it was granting $15-million, with no strings attached, for the general support of Washington University and its medical school.

Russell G. Oswald, chairman of the New York State Parole Board, testified yesterday that ha had rebuked the office of the Speaker of the House of Representatives for having asked him for the release of a prisoner who was "at least on the fringe of organized crime" and "closely involve" with a Mafia leader.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)--The Internal Revenue Service said today that some of its employes had discovered ways to cheat the Government for their own gain by Feeding false information into computers used to process income tax returns.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The American Bar Association's Board of Governors will meet in a special session next month to decide whether the association should oppose controversial portions of President Nixon's proposed anticrime legislation.

MARION, Mass., June 24The engagement of Miss Meredith Wickenden to M. Edwin Birkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Birkins of Glen Head, L. I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James W. Wickenden.

NORWALK, Conn., June 24 Charles W. Lippitt, vice president and secretary of Joseph P. Day Realty, Inc., in New York, and a retired colonel in the Army Reserve, died Monday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Wilton.

With a well-researched dossier on his Republican opponent but without the immediate endorsement of two of his three primary election rivals, Representative Richard L. Ottinger went to work yesterday as the Democratic nominee for Senator from New York.
DENVER, June 24-Vice President Agnew said here tonight that the lengthy Senate debate over the President's war-making powers proved that the Senate was "not suited to crisis response."

CLEVELAND, June 24 United States golf professionals responded with a challenge and a smile today to Gary Player's remarks that they were not the best in the world end that he could pick a team that would beat them.
WASHINGTON, June 24 The Senate voted today in favor of repeal of the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution, once interpreted as the statutory equivalent of a declaration of war in Vietnam.
The crack of the bat at Shea Stadium gave way last night to the age-old call to repent as the Rev. Billy Graham opened a five-day evangelistic crusade here.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) E. Washington Rhodes, publisher, lawyer and a longtime leader of the black community of Philadelphia, died today. He was 74 years old.

The National Broadcasting Company television network has canceled its weekly series on ecology, "In Which We Live," less than two months after its publicized premiere.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June .24 The United States, which has promised $7.9-million in arms aid to Cambodia for this fiscal year, has stepped up its shipments to this country in the last several days.
A state appeals court ruled yesterday that a landlordtenant lease with a "no dog" clause was binding despite a tenant's assertion that a dog was needed for protection.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24Highly placed Lebanese informants said today that the latest United States proposals for peace in the Middle East called for the creation of a 12-mile demilitarized zone on each bank of the Suez Canal and for a three-month cease-fire between Israel and her Arab neighbors.

The New York Library announced yesterday the acquisition of a hitherto unknown manuscript by Mark Twain, possibly the last he ever wrote, in which he related how he had allegedly been swindled by a young Englishman and his female secretary.
ATHENS, June 24 Church and state in Greece have joined forces to curb a small colony of foreign nudists on the fashionable Aegean island of Myconos.

CLEARWATER, Fla., June 24 (AP) Robert Lehmann, the owner of the Kentucky Derby winner, Dust Commander, said today the colt had returned to the track and would run in the $100,000 Monmouth Invitation on Aug. 8.
One of the joys of pregnancy is not, generally speaking, the clothes. In fact, it's a point of pride among most expectant mothers to stay out of maternity clothes as long as they can.

WASHINGTON, June 24 The selective service system announced today elaborate preparations intended to insure complete randomness in the draft lottery next week.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 24 (UPI) North Korea today marked the 20th anniversary of the beginning of the Korean war by offering to sign a nonaggression pact with South Korea and take other steps leading to eventual reunification of the country. The condition was that all American forces be withdrawn first from the peninsula.
BAYONNE, N.J., June 24Msgr. Daniel O'Reilly, pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church since 1950, died today in St. Francis Hospital, Jersey City, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Brazil has proposed that the Organization of American States formally exclude terrorists from the right of political asylum as a way of combating the extended wave of kidnappings of and attacks on foreign diplomats and government officials in Latin America.

The C. F. I. Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the Crane Company, announced yesterday that C. Clay Crawford, a 52-year-old vice president, had been elected president and chief operating officer, succeeding Frederick A. Fielder.
Advertising People Against the War is a new group that has created newspaper and television advertising that can be used by local groups.
WASHINGTON, June 24Industrial wholesale prices rose by one-tenth of 1 per cent in June, the smallest amount in a year, the Department of Labor reported today.
Six of the 150 members of the State Assembly went to defeat Tuesday in the rash of primaries for the Legislature across the state that involved the four major parties.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 24-What the All-England tennis championships at Wimbledon needed today was an explosion to set it on fire.

Livingston L. Wingate, executive director of the New York Urban League and Mrs. Wingato of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Elizabeth Wingato, to Lieut. (j.g.) Frederick Eugene Jones, U.S.N. He is the son of Mrs. Elbert Jones of Conemaugh, Pa., and the late Mr. Jones.
GASTONIA, N.C., June 24 (AP) Diane McKinney, 17 years old, of Gastonia says that she is staying in a place called "Hijackers Hotel" in Cuba and wants to come home.

LONDON, June 24-Among London's lesser debts to the Aldwych Theater is the discovery that Dion Boucicault was not only the most famous hack of the Victorian stage but also the author of several notably good plays. The salvage work, which began with the revival of "The Shaughraun," continues with Ronald Eyre's production of "London Assurance," which opens the Royal Shakespeare Company's new season.
WASHINGTON, June 24President Nixon has "significant support" among college educators for sending United States troops into Cambodia, professors said at a news conference here today.

The City Planning Commission yesterday approved a revised proposal for financing the construction of the Waterside Housing Development, a 1,470-apartment, mixed-income project to be built on a platform over the East River. Plans have been stalled since 1967 by financial problems.

Mayor Lindsay was asked by the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday to grant subway policemen "hazardous-duty" pay, because of findings that because of steel dust "it is more hazardous to work in the city subways that it is to work in a coal mine."

The head of the Jewish Defense League charged yesterday that the United States Department and Soviet representatives had acted in collusion to promote severe charges against 28 league members arrested Tuesday at the offices of the Amtorg Trading Corporation, a Soviet Government trade agency.

VILLANOVA, Pa., June 24 -Mr. and Mrs. Philip Tremaine Tryon of Villanova, formerly of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Victoria Tryon, to Howard Gerald Lepow. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Lepow of New York. A wedding in the fall is planned.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 24-Can a 5-foot8-inch 148-pound athlete find success and happiness in the decathlon, track and field's most versatile and physically demanding event?
UNION, N.J., June 24-John Roll of 21 Carpenter Place, formerly a general manager of the Elizabeth plant of the Singer Manufacturing Company, died yesterday at his home. His age was 68.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I. A stiff breeze that slanted against Hay Beach from the east failed to die, as it often does along the sea coast at sunset, making it difficult to cast our big salt-water streamers.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 A Federal judge granted an antistrike injunction today against thousands of dissident members of the United Mine Workers of America who quit the western Pennsylvania coal mines Monday in a dispute with their union leaders over enforcement of Federal safety laws.

MOSCOW, June 24 The chief designer of the Soyuz 9 craft said today that the first tests of the two astronauts, Col, Andrian G. Nikolayev and Vitaly I. Sevastyanov, had shown that man could work in space "for at least a month."

Arthur J. Goldberg won the Democratic gubernatorial nomination because the areas he carried tended to vote more heavily than those areas won by his opponent, Howard J. Samuels, according to an analysis of assembly districts and sample election districts throughout the state.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 24 (AP) A young marine who testified he had never kills danyone, even an enemy in combat, was acquitted today of charges of having taken part in the slaying of 16 Vietnamese women and children on a patrol in February.

The following dispatch is the third in a series by Richard Dudman, chief Washington correspondent of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, who has returned home after being held prisoner by the Vietnamese Communists for six weeks and then being released with two other American newsmen.

CHICAGO, June 24 (UPI)Chief United States District Court Judge Edwin A. Robson ruled today that the transcript of a Federal grand jury investigation into the shooting deaths of two Black Panther party leaders could be examined by a Criminal Court judge, Joseph A Power.

Mrs. Marianne O'Brien Reynolds of Miami and New York, second of the four wives of the late Richard J. Reynolds, the tobacco heir, plans to remarry on July 30. Her bridegroom will be Lee Meyers, a public relations man, also of Miami.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 29 -Charles J. Colgan, executive vice president and general counsel of the United Tanker Corporation in New York, died in a hospital here today after an illness of several months. He was 52 years old and lived at 29 Langdon Avenue, Ardsley-on-Hudson.

Another A. P. food store manager was shot to death yesterday in an attempted holdup in Brooklyn that took place only a few hours after the police arrested two suspects in the fatal shooting of an A. P. manager in Manhattan Saturday.
In recent days you have heard from the President on the state of the nation's economy. It is on the same matter that I ask your attention.

WASHINGTON, June 24 Despite pollution, pesticides and the large-scale burning of coal and oil, the amount of oxygen in the earth's atmosphere seems to have remained essentially constant over the last 60 years
Miss Linda Louise Hoff, a senior at Boston University, and Roy Albert White, who is studying for a master's degree at the university's School of Theology, will be married next autumn.

WASHINGTON, June 24Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that the Treasury was studying "in depth" the adoption of a value-added tax, mainly as a means of helping the nation's trade balance.
Unity Hall continued her unbeaten ways yesterday by taking the $31,000 National Stallion Stakes, filly division, by 3 lengths at Belmont Park.
WASHINGTON, June 24 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today a new program of purchase of Government backed mortgages from Savings and loan associations and mutual savines banks.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 24--A benefit performance of "All's Well That Ends Well," with Eva LeGallienne, will be given Friday evening at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater to aid the Alcoholism Council of Southern Connecticut.

TRENTON, June 24-The State Commission of Investigation heard testimony today that building maintenance companies hired a man with alleged ties with organized crime to minimize competition while at the same time "reparations" were paid by a firm that took a contract from another.

WASHINGTON, June 24 A study by the Urban Institute shows that inflation has created a financial crisis for public housing authorities in major cities across the country and that the trend is expected to continue.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell, who lost the Democratic primary by a 203-vote margin to Assemblyman Charles Rangel in Harlem's 18th Congressional District on Tuesday, asked for a recount yesterday.

TRENTON, June 24-The Government's key witness in the extortion trial of Hugh J. Addonizio testified here today that he had raised cash for a New Jersey kickback at the headquarters in New York of Abraham D. Beame, Frank D. O'Connor and Mario A. Procaccino in the 1965 mayoral campaign there.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) Lieut Charles R. Saxbe, a Marine officer, wrote to his father, Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio, "If this war doesn't end soon, I see an underground develop ment that would seek to disrupt the country with arson, sabotage and assassination."

CHICAGO, June 24 The New York Mets made it four in a row over the Chicago Cubs today by winning a doubleheader and swept into first place in the National League's Eastern Division something they did not manage last year until Sept. 10.

Mrs. Joanne Smitherman, mother of five and head of the Bronx Council for Welfare Rights, has been fasting since Moaday to dramatize what she calls the lack of clothing for welfare children who want to go to summer camp.
Alexander Kerensky, the Russian revolutionary leader, left his estate of 15,000 to $30,000 to a son in London, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court.

OTTAWA, June 25 The Government declared today that Canadian foreign policy in the nineteen-seventies must diligently pursue national aims and interests, including the protection of Canada's independence and cultural identity when dealing with the United States.
Abortion law reform, long overdue and finally enacted at the last session of the State Legislature, emerged as an ugly and divisive campaign issue in some primary contests.

WASHINGTON, June 25 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the wek ended June 20 was above the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period affected by work stoppages throughout the country was considerably below the volume in the like period last year.

Miss Ulla Maria Lehtokoski and Jeffrey David Holzman were married here yesterday afternoon in the home of Mrs. Louis Klein Jr., the bridegroom's sister. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, performed the ceremony.

JERUSALEM, June 25 Premier Golda Meir plans to make a "political statement" in the Knesset, or parliament, Monday, when she is expected to give some indication of Israel's attitude toward the United States peace initiative.

The staggered work schedule program to ease peak-hour pressures on mass transit serving the Manhattan financial district, introduced April 1 for 50,000 commuters, is working out to the satisfaction of its co-sponsors.

Miss Ann Bancroft Dickinson and Stephen Chittenden Turner were married yesterday in St. John's Anglican Church, Christiansted, St. Croix, the Virgin Islands. The Very Rev. Dean Francis Sayre of the Washington Cathedral performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Stephen Gow of St. John's Church. A reception was given at the Beach Hotel of St. Croix.

Everybody seems to be denouncing the pollsters these days for not calling the outcome of the British election, but they should be thanked for their failure. For the more the pollsters fail, the more the democratic process is likely to succeed.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 25 (AP) A Paine College student, Edward Sapp Jr., has been arrested on charges of creating a public disturbance and misuse of a flag in connection with an incident shortly before a riot broke out that left six dead and 60 injured in Augusta.

JERSEY CITY, June 25 Walter H. Waggoner, a reporter for The New York Times, today answered a subpoena to testify in Superior Court about a story he had written on the machine-gunning of a police station here, but he refused to name police sources he had quoted in the story.

STOCKHOLM, June 25 The United States captured the world team championship here this afternoon, winning the final with something to spare against the young team representing Nationalist China, or Taiwan.

ORVIETO, Italy, June 25 In a valley north of this ancient hill town, work started today for a railroad that by 1975 will whisk travelers from Rome to Florence in an hour and 25 minutes at an average speed of 115 miles per hour.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 Jim Burnes, an A.B.C. News correspondent, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 42 years old.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that Arnold Bernhard, a leading figure in the mutual fund industry, had violated provisions of four Federal securities laws in the operation of his fund management company.

In these days of equal opportunity it was only natural that the success of the Texas Boys Choir should inspire the formation of a 'Texas Girls' Choir. Now an eight-year-old institution, the latter stopped here Wednesday night to give a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on its way to a European tour.

When Joseph Okpaku, an established author, playwright and editor at the age of 27, considered starting a black publishing house, he was encouraged by announcements from the publishing industry that it would be delighted to help black entrepreneurs.
ALONG THE MEKONG RIVER, opposite Prek Tameak, June 25 "If it rains, we will be fighting the Vietcong," predicted Cpl. Koe Vong.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 25 Henrique Carlos Malta Galvao, who called world attention to his campaign against the Salazar regime of Portugal in 1961 by seizing a luxury liner in the Caribbean, died today, after a long illness, in Sao Paulo.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 25 (AP) Valiant, the America's Cup contender, was undamaged after running aground off her berth last night at the Newport Shipyard.

Back in the glory days of Murderers' Row, two Yankee musclemen, Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, hit more home runs between them during the 1927 season than did 14 of the 15 other teams in the big leagues. They established the home run as the Yankee trademark and the Bronx Bombers boisterously blasted their way to championship after championship.

Alma Mabrey Talley, a writer, movie critic and crossword puzzle expert, died of a stroke yesterday at French Hospital at the age of 72. She was the wife of Victor W. Talley, retired Sunday picture editor of The New York Times, and lived at 100 Central Park South.

The Distrigas Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to build a $60-million deep-water terminal on Staten Island to receive and redistribute liquefied natural gas from Algeria. Jacek Makowski, the concern's president, said the terminal would be a 40-acre tract on the southwest shore of Staten Island.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 25 If additionnal evidence were needed to emphasize how much the synthetic rubber surface at Roosevelt Raceway "moves up" a standardbred, it was supplied tonight by Peter Wood, a 6year-old trotting gelding.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 25 (AP) Thousands of coal miners picked up their tools and returned to the mines in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio today as a United States Senator announced an investigation into their charges that Federal mine safety legislation was not being enforced.

"I would doubt that more than 20 per cent of the goods sold in stores today are affected by the computer. In the seventies, that figure should rise to between 90 per cent and 95 per cent of all merchandise," said Edward S. Donnell, president and new chief executive officer of Montgomery Ward, Chicago.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 25 As South Koreans observed the 20th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean war today, President Chung Hee Park called on his nation to continue to build up its strength in order to crush any new Communist aggression.
In heavy trading, futures prices of the major agricultural commodities shot upward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. In many cases, the trading was the most active so far this year.
CLEVELAND, June 25 Larry Hinson took the first-round lead today in the $150,000 Cleveland open with a 65 while Dave Hill equaled the current tour record of 29 for nine holes.

Mrs. Verta Mae Grosvenor is a woman of commanding presence, imposing height and black skin. She is an author, a musician and a mother whose daughter recently had a book of poems ("Poems by Kali") published.

The little three-car turbinepowered train that negotiates the twists, turns and tricky roadbed between here and Boston and on better stretches zips at speeds up to 105 miles an hour will have an expanded weekend service starting today.
WASHINGTON, June 25 A New York correspondent for Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, will be expelled from the United States for what sources here described today as improper activities.

WASHINGTON, June 25 The United States today formally announced the launching of a broadly based diplomatic campaign in the Middle East to encourage Israel and the Arab countries to "stop shooting and start talking" under United Nations auspices.

LEE, Mass., June 25 A fledgling dance company from North Carolina as well as the New York City Ballet's Patricia McBride and Edward Villella opened the 38th Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here this afternoon.

GENEVA, June 25 The Soviet Ministry of Culture has been asked to reconsider its refusal to permit David Oistrakh to play at the Gstaad Music Festival organized by Yehudi Menuhin. The reason for the ministry's refusal is its contention that Mr. Menuhin "supports the Zionist aggressors" in the Middle East.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indicated.

The attempt by Democratic leaders in the City Council to put their own distinctive imprint on reform of the rent control law has resulted in a legislative hodge-podge that is likely to prove impossible for tenants, landlords or the city to live with.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 25 A Liberal Roman Catholic priest who opposes the war in Indochina won the Republican nomination for the United States Senate tonight, becoming the first priest ever to run for the Senate.

The Federal Communications Commission issued an order yesterday barring the three major televisibn networks from owning cable television systems. It also forbade television broadcasters from owning cable TV systems in their local broadcasting areas and set three years for them to eliminate any existing cross-ownerships.
It is a curiosity among theatergoers that the unfinished work at times evokes a stronger emotive response than the thoroughly polished piece.

Twenty-three-year-old Leon Botstein, who was a student until a year ago, yesterday was named president of Franconia College, a small experimental school in northern New Hampshire, making him what is thought to be the youngest college head in the country.

BURLINGTON, Vt., June 25 A joint Federal-state conference on pollution in Lake Champlain ordered today that the International Paper Company and the State of New York, identified as the two major polluters of the lake, take prompt steps to improve the situation.

One man was killed and three others were injured yesterday afternoon as part of a building that was being renovated collapsed and crashed through a protective sidewalk tunnel at 255 West 14th Street, near Eighth, Avenue. Two of those injured were pedestrians.

Governor Rockefeller will appoint two lawyers from Rochester to act as special prosecutors in an inquiry he has ordered on student disorders on the Hobart College campus in Geneva and the activities of a police undercover agent known as "Tommy the Traveler."

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) A Congressional watchdog report charging that United States inspectors allowed filthy, rat-ridden meat packing plants to stay in production has brought a demand from Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff for an investigation of the Agriculture Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 25 The United States has assured the United Nations of its concern that the temples and monuments at Angkor in Cambodia are not damaged, but it has not guaranteed the safety of the temples if the enemy should use them for military purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 25--In his memoirs, Pierre Salinger tells about an old man who met him at the airport when he returned to California in 1964 to run for the Senate. The man, a stranger, pressed a Kennedy half-dollar into his hand and said "If you carry it with you all the time you can't lose."

MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 (AP) Rod Carew, the Minnesota Twins' All-Star second baseman and leading batter in the American League, lay in a hospital bed last night as his teammates beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-2.
Jazz reached a nadir of popularity last year, according to George Wein, producer of the Newport Jazz Festival.

The threat of a strike by 25,000 apartment house workers was revived yesterday when spokesmen for landlords of rent-controlled buildings declared that they would cut their employes' salaries if the City Council failed to approve adequate rent increases.

ATLANTA, June 25 A Federal district judge ordered today a temporary halt to the Army's prosecution of a soldier accused of murdering Vietnamese civilians at Songymy.

JERUSALEM, June 25 Israel's jets bombed Syrian military camps on the outskirts of Damascus today and shot down a Syrian MIG-21 as an intense exchange of fire broke out for the second day along the ceasefire line, a military spokesman said.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced the appointment yesterday of Wilfred N. Horne, a former newspaperman and city administrator, as deputy commissioner in charge of press relations for the Police Department, a $26,320-a-year position.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25 While other yachts were being blasted by knockdown winds and shattering seas, the Newport-to-Bermuda race still was in progress for half tee 149 starters. Richard S. Nye's Class C. sloop Carina, from Greenwich, Conn., meanwhile had a serene trouble-free passage and was confirmed as the main winner today.

ALGIERS, June 25 (UPI) Algeria and Libya led a drive today to cut the refining and marketing role of American and other international oil companies in the 10 nations that produce half of the world's petroleum.
OXFORD, Miss., June 25 (AP) Jeanette Jennings of Hattlesburg has become the first full-time Negro faculty member at the University of Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, June 25 The text of a report prepared by a grand jury in Baltimore and now expunged from Federal Court records lists 45 "overtacts" through which a Baltimore contractor allegedly sought to defraud the United States Government.

Officials of the city's voluntary hospitals sought assurances yesterday from the state that the hospitals would be reimbursed for higher labor costs that might result from a new contract covering more than 22,000 service, maintenance, clerical and other nonprofessional employes.
MOSCOW, June 25 (Reuters) The Soviet government and the Communist party announced today that last year's sweeping and costly program to bring in the harvest would be repeated.
WASHINGTON, June 24 One hundred executives from almost as many national corporations flew from New York to the capital today in a move to bring an end to the Vietnam war.

Never having been able to work up a great surge of enthusiasm for Picasso's linoleum cuts ("linocut" seems now to be the accepted abbreviation), I was happy to discover that the exhibition that opened Wednesday at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle affords a very pleasant experience.
WASHINGTON, June 25 The Federal Trade Commission in a unanimous decision that may set a precedent in antitrust law, ordered the Bendix Corporation today to divest itself of the Fram Corporation.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 25 Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Mendell have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Jean Mendell, to Kenneth Winston Starr. He is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. William Douglas Starr of San Antonio, Tex. A wedding in August is planned.
Simon Wassermann a Philadelphia architect, died at Episcopal Hospital there Wednesday. He was 75 years old.

Miss Myrta Hargen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hargen of San Juan, P.R., was married here yesterday afternoon to Rory O'Dwyer, whose father, Paul O'Dwyer, was defeated in his bid for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York in Tuesday's primary.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell of Harlem contended yesterday that he won the Democratic primary election in the 18th Congressional District on Tuesday by some 2,000 votes.

Two State Supreme Court justices acted yesterday to assure that their orders prevailed over those of three other judges of the same court, whose actions had helped a Westchester County contractor avoid appearing before a New York County grand jury.
TOKYO, June 25 The Japanese Government issued a statement today saying it would do its utmost to settle the textile dispute with the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 25 Congress approved today the $50-million in additional funds requested by President Nixon to provide summer jobs for youths.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Elliot L. Richardson, the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, took a tough stand against Southern school segregation today and expressed willingness to terminate Federal aid.

PARIS, June 2 The Vietnam peace talks remained blocked today as each side accused the other of aggression and of rigid refusal to heed the other's proposals.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 The generation that will provide the nation's leaders in another decade or so sent some representatives to town this week, and they dropped a few hints about their character and hopes.

Since it opened its doors 116 years ago, McSorley's Old Ale House has served only beer and ale and only to men. But yesterday a Federal judge male ruled that the sawdust-floored haven was just another "public place" that must admit any customer who comes in, even a woman.

WASHINGTON, June 25 The House voted 279 to 98 today to override President Nixon's veto of the $2.79-billion bill for construction and modernization of medical facilities, 27 more votes than the two-thirds majority required.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., June 25 (AP) Robert Lister Macneil, the Macneil of Barra, an American who had been chief of the Scottish clan Neil since 1915 died here yesterday. He was 80 years old.

NEW HAVEN, June 25 The arduous effort to assemble a jury to hear the first of a series of trials of Black Panthers charged in connection with the slaying of a party member was stalled again here today.

ABERDEEN, Md., June 25 Mrs. Rosalie Hunter Thompson of Havre de Grace, widow of Andrew A. Thompson Jr., was married here Saturday to Josiah Van Kirk Thompson of Greenwich, her late husband's brother, near Bridgeton, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Aerospace Industries Association forecast today a 12 per cent decline in employment in the aviation and space manufacturing industry by September, from totals of a year ago.

Assemblyman Edward Stevenson, Bronx Democrat, charged yesterday that he was the victim of "hanky panky" at the Board of Elections and demanded a recount of votes cast Tuesday in the 78th Assembly District.
The Consolidated Foods Corporation, based in Chicago, again will be headed by two top executives instead of one, as has been the case since last December.
Forty-four basketball players have been invited by the United States Olympic Committee to paticipate in a three-week training program July 5 through 26 at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs.

WASHINGTON, June 25 Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of New York, returned to the House today after winning his party's nomination for the United States Senate and promptly went on the attack against his Republican-Liberal opponent, Senator Charles E. Goodell.
A detective charged with conspiring to receive a $5,000 illegal payment from Montgomery Ward submitted his retirement papers to the Police Department yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters) The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today approved the nomination of ambasadors to Venezuela and Niger but held up a controversial appointment to the United States embassy in South Africa.

Bernard S. French 3d has been named to the new post of executive vice president of the RobitshekSchneider Company, outerwear manufacturer, a division of Hart Schaffner Marx.

For the fourth day in a row more stocks declined than advanced on the American Stock Exchange. However the downtrend slowed noticeably, Yesterday declining issues totaled 467 compared with 683 on Wednesday, and advancing issues totaled 287 compared with 144.

Carl J. Austrian, the lawyer who directed the recovery of more than $100-million in savings for 400,000 New Yorkers who thought they had lost all when the Bank of United States closed in the Depression, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a long illness. The Rev. Arthur Blessitt arrived in Manhattan yesterday with a message of salvation and what was probably the only pneumatic-tired cross ever to be trundled across the George Washington Bridge.

ATLANTA, June 25 (UPI) Lester G. Maddox Jr., the eldest son of the Georgia Governor, pleaded guilty today to a charge of attempted burglary, his second such offense in five years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 (UPI) United States combat deaths in Indochina last week were at their lowest level since the end of March, but the number of wounded was nearly double that of the previous week, the United States command reported today.

CHICAGO, June 25 The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education proposed today that 230 to 280 new, two-year community colleges be established in the United States by 1980. The proposal would put one community college within commuting distance of 95 per cent of all Americans.

The National Committee of Black Churchmen issued a Black Declaration of Independence yesterday. It urged the black community throughout America not to participate in annual Fourth of July activities but to celebrate its own Black Liberation Day this Sunday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 Rather than risk criticism for mixing pleasure with business, Secretary of Commerce Maurice Hubert Stans called off a jaguar hunt in South America in April. Judging by the criticism he has received, Mr. Stans might well have canceled a few other items.
Members of Mailers Union No. 6 at The Daily News stopped work and held a union meeting for about an hour last night, delaying distribution of the first edition of the paper.

BUENOS AIRES, June 25 A business court judge has charged three foreign meat-packing companies under the antimonopolies law with manipulating prices at the Buenos Aires central cattle market.
BANGKOK, Thailand, June 25 (AP) Premier Thanom Kittikachorn told a cheering Parliament today that Thailand would send her army into Cambodia if necessary.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., June 25 Lloyd Monroe, who has yet to make his mark in the paying ranks, took over the lead in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship today with 134 at the half-way point of the 72-hole tournament.
DALLAS, June 25 (UPI) Gary Allen Deeds was sentenced to a four-year prison term yesterday by a Dallas jury that found him guilty of burning an American flag.

AREA A "I think the fishing in this area has improved," said John Falkiewicz in Surf City. "Kingfish are being taken on the beach about two dozen a man, using bloodworms mostly." Other fishermen reported an occasional striped bass hanging around "if they were lucky." Summer flounder (fluke) were also being caught at the extreme ends of the bay, from Beach Haven to Barnegat.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 25 President Nixon will deliver his final report on the American operations in Cambodia next Tuesday.
A checked swing at a breaking pitch, resulting in a soft pop-up, ended Bobby Murcer's bid to become the first majorleague player to hit five consecutive home runs.
WASHINGTON, June 25 Both exports and imports rose to record levels in May and the export surplus increased to $334-million from $202-million in April, the Department of Commerce reported today.

TRENTON, June 25 The prosecution's key witness in the conspiracy-extortion trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark named and pointed to Mr. Addonizio today as a man to whom he had paid $3,000 in bribes in 1968.

JERSEY CITY, June 25 Suddenly, in the stale, sweaty fragrance of Bufano's Gym today, the noise stopped. The other fighters ignored the bags they were punching, or rolled up their ropes. Sonny Liston was in the ring, and the dozen other fighters and three dozen spectators were watching him.
The city's Board of Health voted yesterday to permit abortions in clinics as well as in hospitals, but only if stringent standards are met.
The Senate has repealed the Tonkin Gulf resolution with the same haste and confusion of purpose that attended its adoption six years ago.
Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks declined last month by 3.9 per cent from the April level to $4.25-trillion, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 25 An injury to Jeff Bannister, the early leader, and career-best performances in eight events helped John Warkentin of Fresno, Calif., win his first national Amateur Athletic Union decathlon championship today.
QUITO, Ecuador, June 25 The Ecuadorian Government yesterday banned outgoing news dispatches by cable without notice.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 Ted Ashley, chairman of Warner Bros., confirmed today rumors that the company would transfer "major elements" of its New York headquarters operations to its Burbank, Calif., studios.
NEW DELHI, June 25 Foreign Minister Dinesh Singh offered his resignation tonight following a sweeping Cabinet shuffle ordered by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi.

Talley Industries, Inc., diversified industrial producer and makers of products for the aerospace industry, yesterday reported a sharp decline in earnings to $2,711,951, or 43 cents a share, for the fiscal year ended March 31, from the previous year's net of $12,342,562, or $1.99 a share.
Naples, Italy Franco Zurlo 188 pounds, Italy, outpointed Enzo Farinelli, 118 , Italy, 15 rounds; Zurlo retained European bantamweight title.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 25 A group of 500 Puerto Ricans protesting alleged police discrimination marched on City Hall tonight but disbanded peacefully after talks with Mayor Louis De Pascale and Police Chief George Crimmins produced a series of concessions.

BELLEVILLE, Ill., June 25 (AP) President Nixon said today that he planned no political campaign speeches in 1970. He said that he felt he could best serve Republican candidates by making "as good a record as possible in Washington."
Members of a Congressional committee opened four days of hearings here yesterday on heroin traffic in New York City and heard pleas for Federal action to cut off the supply of the drug at its source.

The parents of Tom McMillen, the year's most sought after high school basketball star, have expressed strong objections to their son's plans to attend the University of North Carolina. As a result, the 6foot-11-inch athlete may not go there although he signed an agreement to that effect Wednesday.

SAO PAULO, Brazil June 25 (AP) The government has authorized the destruction of coffee plants in an area fourfifths the size of Texas, if necessary, to try to avoid a major catastrophe in this nation's most important product.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a $422-million, four-year program of research to develop systems for reuse of solid waste materials.

Two young Puerto Ricans one advocating violent revolution, the other calling for peaceful change confronted each other yesterday in an emotional, ideological duel before the graduating class of Benjamin Franklin High School.

MOSCOW Exactly twenty years ago, June 25, 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea and the United States became involved in its first unpopular Asian campaign, an involvement which has not yet ended because a four-star general commands the thousands of troops still committed to protecting the South. The story of the conflict itself is painfully well known.
CHICAGO, June 25--The American Medical Association voted for the first time in its 123-year history today to allow doctors to perform abortions for social and economic reasons, as well as medical.
The United States Weather Bureau issued this forecast at 8 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island South Shore and nearby coastal waters.

State Supreme Court Justice J. Courtney McGroarty ruled yesterday that Local School Board 14 could not dismiss the district superintendent or delegate authority to mini-boards in the Williamsburg-Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

MARSEILLES, France, June 25 (AP) French and Italian police, working in cooperation with United States narcotics agents and Turkish and Lebanese police, have seized a shipment of 343 pounds of morphine base.

Six inspectors in the city's Department of Air Resources were indicted yesterday on charges that they had falsely denied having told a fellow inspector that they had either received bribes or had been able to get bribes if they wanted.
Activities. The President flew to St. Louis to address the Jaycees and then flew to his home in San Clemente, Calif., where he planned to spend a week of work and relaxation.

Jerome S. Gore has been elected president of Hart Schaffner Marx, Chicago, succeeding John D. Gray, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Gore was formerly executive vice president.

Hayden, Stone, Inc., a major securities house, disclosed yesterday that it was taking steps to raise $7.8-million in additional capital in the second major capital infusion for the concern in the last four months.

WASHINGTON, June 25 The Secretary of Transportation, John A. Volpe, said here today that he was unable to say "with any degree of certainty" that the Penn Central Transportation Company "can or can not meet its payrolls."

Jorge Velasquez, the calm Panamanian, showed his competence as a grass rider by winning both turf races in which he participated at Belmont Park yesterday. One of these events was the feature on the card, a purse named the Citizens Budget Commission, which attracted a field of eight older horses.
WASHINGTON, Friday, June 26 (AP) The Senate, working past midnight to clean up a legislative backlog caused by the Cambodian debate, passed a $4.8-billion education bill early today.
Prices on the London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday after a quiet trading session.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) The Chicago Cubs purchased Milt Pappas, a right-handed pitcher, from the Atlanta Braves today for "considerably more than" the waver price of $20,000.
Miss Madeleine Francoise Rudel and Jeffrey Steven Grant plan to be married in December.

Secretary of State Rogers shed little light on the new American peace initiative for the Middle East yesterday, but it is evident that a major effort is under way to get the Arabs and the Israelis "to stop shooting and start talking."
WASHINGTON, June 25 The Senate agreed today to end its prolonged debate on Cambodia Tuesday and voting then on the Cooper-Church amendment to restrict future military activities in Cambodia.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 25 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Essex County will meet Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham in the 36-hole final of the 67th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tomorrow.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 The long established names of Arthur Ashe, Stan Smith, Dennis Ralston and Marty Riessen reached the fourth round of the All-England tennis championships today, here just as they were supposed to do, along with a fifth American who advanced on the finest victory of his career.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25 Militant Arab governments and Arab guerrilla groups denounced today Washington's plea to "stop shooting and start talking about peace" in the Middle East.

CHICAGO, June 25 A panel of physicians urged doctors today to be more cautious in writing prescriptions for pregnant women and newborn infants. Some drugs, they said, can damage the unborn child and the effects of many other medications in these situations are largely unknown.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer, after two years of campus turmoil, resigned today as president of Stanford University.
The Penn Central's financial troubles are making investors much more credit conscious as they buy bonds.
Clifford Zieger, a retired Eastern Airline pilot who had flown more than 30,000 hours, died Wednesday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 63 years old.

The Penn Central "crisis" produced scarcely a ripple in the nation's money markets, banking data published yesterday showed. The pace of monetary expansion ap peared to be more moderate than was characteristic in late May and early June.

WASHINGTON, June 25 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to issue a ruling explaining the obligation of urban school systems in the South and in the North to bus students to eliminate racial imbalance.

Governor Rockefeller and his Democratic opponent, Arthur J. Goldberg, played political attack and counterattack for the first time yesterday. The Governor charged that Mr. Goldberg "supported the war policies" of President Johnson, and the Democrat charged that Mr. Rockefeller supported President Nixon's "enlargement of the Indochina war."

A New York policeman yesterday denied charges that he had lied to a Bronx grand jury about meeting with gamblers to receive bribes.

The Magnavox Company, which is splitting with Kenyon Eckhardt, yesterday announced that Lois Holland Callaway will take over the creation of the advertising for its consumer electric products.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 25 The Cambodian Government issued a "general mobilization" decree today, requiring every citizen between the ages of 18 and 60 to perform either military duty or some "service of national interest."
