The infant offspring of the snootiest fashion concerns are doing nicely, though many of them are not yet a year old. They're proving that a designer's name packs a wallop even when the designer steps into a lower price bracket.

The wide-ranging bloc of cable television regulations and proposals issued Wednesday by the Federal Communications Commission have prompted favorable responses from the cable TV industry and silence from commercial television sources.
Joseph J. O'Hara, a senior account executive with Southern Outdoor Markets of New York, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home at 1660 East 8th Street, Brooklyn. He was 38 years old.

PARIS, June 26 Fortyfour French priests have resigned en masse, declaring that "while faithful to the Gospel" they can "no longer in conscience accept a great many of the present structures of the Church."
Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, moved into the New York City hospital negotiations yesterday at the direction of Governor Rockefeller.
Corn Off the Cob and Terlago, 3-year-olds who were unplaced in the Kentucky Derby, are the top weights for today's $123,200 Hollywood Derby at Hollywood Park.
The Treasury announced yesterday plans to sell $2.5-billion of tax anticipation bills maturing next March.

McSorley's Old Ale House, whose 116-year-old practice of turning away women with a variety of hoots, clangs and whistles was held on Thursday to be illegal, will be able to keep on barring women, at least until Tuesday.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 26 The goat cart that pulled Porgy to international fame brought him home to Charleston this week for the first time since the musical had its premiere 35 years ago.

VIENNA, June 26 Alexander Dubcek was expelled from the Czechoslovak Communist party today, the Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K. reported. The expulsion was decided by a majority vote of the party's Central Committee, which met in Hradcany Castle in Prague.
TANTOYUCA, Mexico, June 18 To the twang of country guitars, a quartet of singers wearing straw hats and red kerchiefs improvised verses of political tribute.
The index of help-wanted ads in metropolitan newspapers dropped sharply again in May, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Harry S. Dent, a special counsel to President Nixon, denied today that he was attempting to solicit business for his brother's housing company in South Carolina when he wrote letters on White House stationery to Negroes in the state.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26 A missile damaged an Italian jetliner flying near Damascus, Syria, today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) The Transportation Department awarded today two sets of contracts, one to produce a safer car and the other to eliminate drunken drivers from the highway.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Senate Finance Committee approved today a House-passed bill to raise the temporary national debt ceiling to $395-billion.

ATLANTA, June 26 (AP) Gov. Lester G. Maddox removed his ban on sales of two Atlanta newspapers at the state Capitol today.

EL CAJON, Calif., June 27 (AP) The defending champion, Jane Bastanchury, and her Arizona State teammate, Cathy Gaughan, will meet for the National Women's Intercollegiate golf title in tomorrow's 36-hole final after winning their matches today.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 26 Patrick E. Haggerty's Bay Bea, from Dallas, succeeded Thomas J. Watson Jr.'s Palawan of Greenwich, Conn., as the runner-up in Class B today in one of the final bits of business associated with the Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race.

BALTIMORE, June 26 (AP) The Social Security Administration announced today that it would temporarily continue to reimburse physicians and other suppliers of medical services under the existing levels under part B of Medicare, which is due to be changed July 1.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday a $480,000 grant to clean and maintain equipment on 19 private bus lines in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

BALTIMORE, June 26 Federal Judge Roszel C. Thomsen asked The New York Times today to divulge voluntarily the source of its article concerning a secret grand jury report charging a Baltimore contractor with trying to defraud the United States Government.
TRENTON, June 26 One of the co-defendants of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark pleaded guilty in Federal court today to a charge of incometax evasion.

As Governor Rockefeller and Arthur J. Goldberg square off for their gubernatorial contest, the central problem facing the state is epitomized in the budget New York City has just adopted to pay for streetcleaning, public safety, schools, welfare and other municipal services in the next twelve months.
The National Education Association, in recent Senate testimony, has cut through the statistical fog that long obscured the truth about school desegregation in many Southern districts.

HARTFORD, June 26 The Democratic state convention opened tonight with United States Representative Emilio Q. (Mim) Daddario as the sole candidate for Governor and four men battling for the seat of Senator Thomas J. Dodd.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., June 26 (AP) The appointment of Dr. Charles Edwin Bishop, 49 years old, of Chapel Hill, N.C., to be the first chancellor of the University of Maryland at College Park was approved today by the Board of Regents.

ATHENS, June 26 The Greek military-backed regime announced today the compulsory retirement of 12 major generals, bringing to 60 the number of senior officers retired in the last semiannal review of armed forces personnel.

The North American Rockwell Corporation expects to add about 15,000 workers at it's Los Angeles plant as a direct result of the recent award of the contract for the B-1 bomber, Willard F. Rockwell Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said in an interview here yesterday.

A Trans World Airlines Boeing 747 developed a fire in one of its engines after landing at John F. Kennedy International Airport yesterday, and a dozen passengers were slightly injured as they fled from the jumbo jet.

ALGIERS, June 26 Algeria has launched an ambitious fouryear economic expansion program that President Houari Boumediene says will enable the former French-ruled country to turn the page once and for all on the heritage of underdevelopment left by colonialism.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) Dr. Borden S. Veeder, a widely known pediatrician, died Wednesday of infirmities at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 86 years old.

The stock market sagged again yesterday following an abortive attempt at a rally during the early trading. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was not heavy, concluding a week of generally spiritless activity.

AUGUSTA, Ga., June 26 The Nixon Administration will begin filing desegregation suits against recalcitrant Southern school districts next week unless local and state officials can work out acceptable plans to end discrimination in the public schools next fall, a top Justice Department official said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 (AP) Speakers commemorating the signing of the United Nations Charter here 25 years ago pleaded today for peace in Indochina, a settlement in the Middle East and general acceptance of postwar European borders.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The post Office Department announced today plans to spend $43.3-million to renovate the Morgan Postal Station in Manhattan, which was damaged by fire in December, 1967.
Neither a sore back nor a sore throat could keep Frank Robinson from playing last night, and neither Joe Coleman nor Joe Grzenda could keep Robinson from hitting grand-slam homers.

RUMFORD, R.I., June 26 Ed Tutwiler of Indianapolis carded an even par 69 today and held a two-stroke lead in the ninth annual Northeast amateur invitation golf tournament at the Wannamoisett Country Club.
Two gunmen wounded a secretary during a holdup in a bank in lower Manhattan yesterday and then escaped with more than $4,000.
PALO ALTO, Calif., June 26 Richard W. Lyman, provost at Stanford University, was named acting president of the school tonight, effective Sept. 1, when Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer will formally step down.

WHITE PLAINS, June 26 The school year in Westchester County, marked as in many other places by protest on the left, has closed on a note of concern among school administrators about activity on the right.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Defense Department today rejected as incomplete and unacceptable a list of prisoners of war compiled by a peace group in New York and described by Hanai as a complete list of the Americans it holds.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed steady in quiet trading yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, June 26 The prestigious Conference of Major Superiors of Men made its debut this week in the arena of social action after 13 years of strictly fraternal, private annual gatherings.

GENEVA, June 26 Secretary General U Thant appealed to the governing council of the United Nations Development Program today to pledge $10million immediately toward the construction of the proposed $80-million extension to United Nations Headquarters in New York.
A 64-year-old Brooklyn principal was beaten in his office yesterday by five men who gained admission by posing as newsmen.
HARTFORD, June 26 In this capital city these days most of the talk is of politics.

Blue Cross of Greater New York has decided to extend its coverage for abortions performed in hospitals to include single women and dependent children after the state's new abortion law takes effect Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, June 26 A United States District Court jury today found Alan and Margaret McSurely, former civil rights and antipoverty activists, guilty on two counts each of contempt of Congress.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday toured eight sites that have been proposed for state-subsidized housing, insisting reelection politics was not his motive, but beaming at some high praise offered along the way by the Democratic Minority Leader of the State Senate, Joseph Zaretzki.
NEWARK, June 26 A settlement was reached today on charges brought against a white landlord who had been accused of excluding a tenant because she was not black.

MOSCOW, June 27 A Leningrad Jew, in a letter to the Soviet Prosecutor General, has protested the detention of eight Jews in connection with an alleged hijacking plot in which 12 other persons are being held.
Cleveland, June 26 A twohour thunderstorm washed out play in the second-round of the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament today and forced a postponement until tomorrow.

PARIS, June 26 Jean-Paul Sartre has been thumbing his nose at the French Government, intellectually speaking, for more than a month. For some time the Government did not react, but today Mr. Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir, his long-time companion, were arrested briefly.

CHICAGO, June 26 Truck drivers and terminal workers in the Chicago area have overwhelmingly rejected a proposed new settlement of their 78-day combination strike and lockout, thus continuing their threat to upset a national master freight truck settlement reached April 2, it was announced today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam June 26 (AP) The United States Command announced today that a United States Navy escort plane attacked gun positions deep inside North Vietnam yesterday after the guns had fired on a reconnaissance aircraft the Navy plane was escorting.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The United States refused today to consider the speech by President Gamal Abdel Nasser in Libya yesterday as the final word on the American peace plan.

The National O.T.C. Clearing Corporation yesterday confirmed that it was negotiating a merger with the National Association of Securities Dealers to form a key link in the N.A.S.D.'s plan to create a national clearing system for unlisted securities.

Nearly 200 new and used 1970 Chevrolets, about half the automobile inventory of Prince Chevrolet, Inc., of Brooklyn, were offered at an auction yesterday at its showroom at 5323 18th Avenue, in the Bensonhurst section. The retail value of the 200 cars was estimated at $500,000. A total of 103 was auctioned for $344,000.

The "Jazz in the Garden" series at the Museum of Modern Art took a turn for the gospel Thursday night, with the first local appearance in several years of the Stars of Faith. While the five-voice, Philadelphia-based ensemble (a sixth member was ill) may not generate as much raw excitement as some other gospel groups, there is an exhilarating freedom to its work, a joyful spirit fired by more than average musicality.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., June 26 Mr. and Mrs. Valda L. Adams Jr. have announced that their daughter, Miss Belinda Antoinette Adams, and Donald Dill Eddy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Eddy of Miami, will be married in the Community Church here on July 18.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The State Department confirmed today that a Soviet correspondent for Pravda in New York, Boris M. Orekhov, was being expelled because of "nonjournalistic activity hostile to the interests of the United States."

WASHINGTON, June 26 An "emergency" housing bill with potentially major implications for home building and for the financial markets headed to a Senate-House conference today after passage last night by the House of Representatives.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 26 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of the Essex County Country Club won the 67th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) Gordon B. Thomas of Toledo, Ohio, was elected president of the United States Jaycees today after 24 ballots.

An accountant who prepared tax returns for foreign musicians and opera singers was convicted late Thursday by a Federal Court jury of having made false statements in their tax forms and of having given illegal gratuities to Internal Revenue Service employes.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 (UPI) Another change in the winds provided the Los Angeles-toTahiti yacht race with its third leader in three days today as Widgeon took a slight lead on the 12th day.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Post Office Department officials warned today that, unless airlines take adequate precautions against mail theft at airports, they will face stiff fines ranging up to $1,000 for for each piece of mail that is stolen.

STOCKHOLM, June 26 Six young Dallas experts, Jim Jacoby, Bob Wolff, Bill Eisenberg, Bob Goldman, Mike Lawrence and Bob Hamman, received their world championship trophies here this afternoon from Princess Christina of Sweden.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26 Syria reported shooting down 11 Israeli planes today.

PACIFIC BEACH, Calif., June 26 Capt. Cathie Lydia Jo Kerns, U.S.A., was married at Christ Lutheran Church here this evening to Jay Charles Wegrzyn, a former Air Force captain, who is a real estate broker in Monterey. The Rev. Lawrence Yoder performed the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, June 26 The Interstate Commerce Commission opened an investigation today of two railroads in a move that could have possible implications in the Penn Central case.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 26 Returning to the scene of one of his most embarrassing experiences in track and field, George Frenn won his first national Amateur Athletic Union outdoor championship in the hammer throw tonight.
AACHEN, West Germany, June 26 (AP) West Germany won the Prize of the Nations jumping competition of the Aachen international horse show today, with Britain second and the United States third.

Goodrich Company and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company were barred yesterday from using any rights attached to the shares of Rubberfabriek Vredestein, N.V., that they had acquired earlier this year. LUBBOCK, Tex., June 26 (AP) The 10th annual Coaches All-America football game tomorrow night as expected to be a high-scoring duel of two powerful offenses, with the West rating a slight edge over the East on the strong passing arm of Dennis Shaw of San Diego State.
LONDON, June 26 (UPI) Mrs. Marilyn Wills Gayer, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, died yesterday five months after her wedding. She was 22 years old.

BRUSSELS, June 26 The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community, in an effort to spur establishment of European-based multinational companies, has submitted a plan to the six member states that would facilitate mergers across frontiers.

The official canvass of the votes in the 18th Congressional District began yesterday as Representative Adam Clayton Powell charged that Tuesday's Democratic primary was fraudulent and should be held over again. The Harlem Representative called the election "the biggest scandal I have ever seen." "Here in New York City we have been confronted with a major scandal a Black Teapot Dome," he said.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 26 The engagement of Miss Louisa Ogden Dixon to Samuel E. Walker has been announced here by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul R.B. Dixon. The wedding will take place on Aug. 22 in Omaha.

MIAMI BEACH, June 26 Miss Cheri Rosenbluth who sings in nightclubs and on television as Cheri Royce, and Ezra Millstein, owner and president of Advertising, Research, Marketing, Inc., in Miami, were married this afternoon in the Plaza Hotel.
BRUSSELS, June 19 The universe of international organizations includes behemoths like the United Nations but admits some very junior partners as well.

In a world where peace seems increasingly elusive, the quiet success of the Organization of American States in resolving the "soccer war" between El Salvador and Honduras should not go unnoticed. The Foreign Ministers of the five Central American nations, acting for the O.A.S., worked out an agreement for a demilitarized zone on the disputed border.
PINEHURST, N.C., June 26 (AP) Thomas C. Robbins, winner of several major senior golf championships in the 1950's died of cancer at a Pinehurst hospital today at the age of 77.

George E. McDonald, president of Mailers Union No. 6, said yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, mediator in the newspaper dispute, had informed him by telephone that he would cut short a European vacation and return to help resolve the union's differences with the Publishers Association of New York City.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The first harpy flew out of Pandora's box today following the Nixon Administration's endorsement of import quotas on textiles. The rubber foot wear industry, asserting that it was far more damaged by imports than textiles, demanded that the Administration and the Congress "examine the need for quotas." Previously, the industry had been interested only in preserving a relatively high tariff.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 26 Confronted by a flood of insurance policy cancellations, the State of New Jersey today declared a 90-day emergency moratorium on the termination of all homeowner and automobile insurance policies and other lines of personal coverage.

MOUNTAINDALE, N.Y., June 26 A summer-long series of "Bach to Rock" concerts that its promoters say will attract 50,000 patrons a day will open in this tiny Sullivan County community on Tuesday, July 7.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 26 (UPI) The Thomas Dooley Medical Foundation, an American charitable group, is closing its hospital facilities on Khong Island in the Mekong River on the Laos-Cambodia border because of Communist operations in the area, military sources said today.
The Police Department will begin Tuesday a departmental trial of a detective charged with conspiring with Lieut. Watkins T. Parry to receive an illegal $5,000 gratuity from Montgomery Ward, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy declined by eight-tenths of 1 per cent in May, the Commerce Department reported today.
OTTAWA, June 26 The Supreme Court of Canada upheld today the new Federal law requiring a motorist to give a sample of his breath to the police if asked.
A suspended New York patrolman said yesterday that he had not seen a Bronx gambler give one of his fellow policemen a bribe when the police raided the gambler's apartment in 1968.

Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc., a major operator and builder of nursing homes and child-care centers, filed yesterday in the United States District Court in Oklahoma City for a petition to reorganize the troubled company under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 26 Miss Bernadette Devlin, 23-year-old Member of Parliament and volatile civil-rights leader, went to prison tonight for riotous behavior during vio- lence between Roman Catholics and Protestants last summer. WASHINGTON, June 26 The Senate today redefined once again the proposed amendment to limit Presidential authority to conduct military operations in Cambodia.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) Walter J. Hickel, Secretary of the Interior, proposed today an environmental bill of rights because "we have polluted the American dream."

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The National Education Association has asked the Supreme Court to overturn a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in a school desegregation case involving the Charlotte-Mecklenburg County, N.C., Board of Education.

The spring meeting at Belmont Park will end today with the Saranac Handicap serving as the feature on the nine-race program. To the great vocal majority of local fans, the de nouement is a happy occasion, for from Monday on through Aug. 1 the thoroughbred activity will swtich to the more popular Aqueduct.

MARION, Mass., June 26 Mr. and Mrs. William Shaw have announced the engagement of Mrs. Shaw's daughter, Miss Brenda Marsh Johnson, to John Howard Dick. He is the son of Albert Blake Dick 3d of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mrs. John S. Wyper, the former Elisabeth York, of West Hartford, Conn. Miss Johnson is the daughter also of Orlan A. Johnson of Gates Mills, Ohio.

GENEVA, June 26 Investors Overseas Services announced today that loans and other financial arrangements made in favor of insiders and other persons associated with the giant mutual-fund complex had been nearly halved in the last five months.

The Columbia Daily Spectator, an undergraduate daily that has taken strong stands on political issues and candidates, is being investigated by Internal Revenue Service agents to see if its tax-exempt status is legal.

DULUTH, Minn., June 26 (UPI) The Minnesota State Democrat-Farmer-Labor party helped Hubert H. Humphrey along the comeback trail today, but adopted a peace plank very close to that advocated by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy two years ago.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) The Government filed suit against Calhoun County School District 1 in South Carolina today for operating a segregated school system.

The City Council headed early today toward approving a major revision of the city's 27year-old Rent control law that would raise rents Aug. 1 by 8 to 15 per cent for most fam- lies living in controlled apartments.

NEW HAVEN, June 26 Miss Kathy Lou Bowman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton F. Bowman of Denver, was married today to Henry Luther Loomis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther Loomis of New York and Sharon, Conn. The civil ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace George Longyear. There were no attendants.

CLEVELAND, June 26 Specialists in Jewish intergroup relations called today for immediate formation of a coalition of black, labor, academic, religious and white ethnic minority groups to cope with the divisiveness and social ills that confront the nation.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., June 26 Pat Schwab, the 37-year-old professional from Crestmont, put together final rounds of 66 and 70 to win the 72-hole New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship today with a 272 over the par-71 Hendricks Field course.
The new-issue market stumbled through another period of lower prices and weak trading activity this week, with only one company managing to negotiate a successful fully-registered offering.

Harold Harlow Corbin, a defense lawyer who represented many figures of the underworld and public life for more than a half century, died at his apartment yesterday after a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived at 530 Park Avenue.

Marc Sinclaire, the hairdresser, has moved up in the world. Physically, that is. He has left his underground stand at the Charles of the Ritz salon and moved into sunny, airy quarters of his own on the second floor of the town house at 115 East 55th Street. Although Mr.
Futures prices of agricultural products continued to occupy the commodities markets limelight yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 A spokesman for the Honor America Day Committee said today that the morning program for the group's July 4 celebration in Washington had been completed and would not include anything, demanded yesterday, by Rennie C. Davis, the radical leader.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Nixon Administration, which last month argued in favor of Federal tax-exempt status for segregated Southern private schools, appeared today to have backed away from that position.

RICHMOND, June 26 (AP) A Federal judge rejected a Government proposal today for desegregating Richmond schools on the neighborhood school principle and took under advisement a plan, put forth by Negro leaders, relying heavily on school busing.
A house painter was held without bail yesterday on a charge that he had killed his three-year-old son by forcing water down the child's throat, causing him to drown.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Nixon Administration prodded the Senate today to act on welfare reform and signed a $2.3-million contract with Vermont for a partial test of the proposed family assistance measure.

WASHINGTON, June 26 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today reiterated Washington's plan to continue American bombing raids inside Cambodia after the June 30 deadline for the withdrawal of American troops here.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 26 A company charged with pollution here has leveled the same charge against City Hall in what is growing into a full-blown ecological war.

Miss Susan Beaven Selden and Robert James Egan were married here yesterday afternoon at St. John's-in-theVillage Episcopal Church by the Rev. Charles Howard Graf and the Rev. John Mulhearn. A reception was given at the River Club.

James Day, president of National Educational Television, protested yesterday the exclusion of public television from President Nixon's televised conversation with feature correspondents from the three major commercial networks. The program will be broadcast Wednesday night.

After a shortlived effort to rise yesterday, prices on the American Stock, Exchange resumed their downward course, taking the index down 0.15 to 20.22, its lowest level since May 27. On that date the index stood at 19.96.

MONTREAL, June 26 The Expos walloped three home runs in Jarry Park tonight and brought the New York Mets down to earth, 6-5. The defeat ended a five-game winning streak that the Mets had run up against the Cubs in Chicago this week.
Earnings of the General Instrument Corporation soared 41 per cent in the first fiscal quarter on a sales gain of 8 per cent, shareholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting in Newark.

The Billy Rose Foundation has given a grant of $250,000, to be allotted over a five-year period at $50,000 a year, to the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Charles Wohlstetter, foundation director.
LONDON, June 26 The Soviet bloc gave a new indication today that it was willing to discuss with the North Atlantic alliance a reduction of forces in Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Irving Trust Company of New York, as trustee of a $16.9-million Government-guaranteed loan to the former New York Central Railroad, took the first step today to get the Treasury to make good on the guarantee.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. It was students versus mothers here the other evening and the students won.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26 Scattered fighting was reported at several points within 35 miles of this capital today, but elsewhere in Cambodia military activity remained generally low for the third consecutive day.
LOS ANGELES, June 26 (UPI) The prosection announced today that it would demand the death penalty for Charles Manson and his three female codefendants accused of seven killings.

LONDON, June 26 "American forces have warned Cambodian rice field workers that they are in danger of being hit if they run for cover or 'look suspicious' when U.S. helicopters fly over them, qualified sources said...."

Henry H. Dreifus, city planning official and reform Democratic leader in Brooklyn, died Thursday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn of a heart attack. He was 50 years old and lived at 636 Brooklyn Avenue in the borough.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 26 (AP) Lanny Wadkins of Wake Forest held a two-stroke lead after 45 holes when rain suspended play in the 73d National Collegiate Athletic Association university-division golf tournament at the Ohio State course.
WASHINGTON, June 26 "My politics are children," Dr. Edward Frank Zigler said today upon being sworn in as the first director of the Office of Child Development.

MOSCOW, June 26 The Soviet Union was reported today to have shown renewed interest in recent weeks in reaching a negotiated settlement of the Middle East crisis. Reliable diplomatic sources said that, in conversations in Western capitals, the Russians had underlined the seriousness of the situation and the need for a settlement.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 26 President Nixon told a closed-door meeting of editors and executives from major news organizations today that he had chosen the course of orderly withdrawal from South Vietnam to reinforce America's role in world affairs and thus secure a "lasting peace."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 One Australian expatriate beat another today as Bob (Nails) Carmichael finally set Wimbledon alight by crushing Bob Hewitt in straight sets to reach the quarterfinals of the All-England tennis championships, along with John Newcombe, Tony Roche and Ken Rosewall, Australians who live in their homeland some of the time.
BALTIMORE, June 26 Bob Foster will defend his world light-heavyweight title tomorrow night against an unusual challenger. Mark Tessman, a 23-year-old Texan.

MINEOLA, L.I, June 26 Mrs. Mary-Rose Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Mackay of Locust Valley and grandaughter of the late Clarence H. Mackay, who was board chairman of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company, was married this morning to William T. Heisig of Locust Valley.

MINEOLA, L.I, June 26 Mrs. Mary-Rose Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Mackay of Locust Valley and grandaughter of the late Clarence H. Mackay, who was board chairman of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company, was married this morning to William T. Heisig of Locust Valley.

The summer-long pop music series at Wollman Rink in Central Park, the Schaefer Music Festival, began on Thursday night with what was, on the surface, a sure-fire program Ray Charles and his orchestra and the Raelets, his quarter of girl singers.

CLEVELAND, June 23 Fire House No. 9, in Cleveland's East Side ghetto, has all the earmarks of a police station. Squad cars are parked in the driveway. Armed policemen stand guard. They have been on duty since firemen were shot at a few weeks ago.
TACOMA, Wash., June 26 (AP) The Washington State Athletic Commission refused today to grant Cassius Clay a boxing license to fight the heavyweight champion, Joe Frazier, in the state.

Dr. Martin Sweig, then an aide to House Speaker John W. McCormack, accompanied a client of Nathan M. Voloshen to a meeting with the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission at which the client sought to have trading of his company's stock resumed, it was testified yesterday.
JERUSALEM, Saturday, June 27 Israeli and Syrian forces fought with tanks, artillery and jets yesterday in the Golan area as the biggest Middle Eastern battle since 1967 went into its third day.

The Bali Company, a leading producer of foundations and lingerie, announced that it had completed a refunding of $9.1million of short and long-term debt with three major New York banks and had arranged through other sources for an additional $3-million of working capital.
PARIS, June 26 Herbert von Karajan has resigned from the Orchestra de Paris effective in 1971.

LONGMEADOW, Mass., June 26 Mr. and Mrs. Albert Schwartz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Ann Schwartz, to Robert Kanof Tendler. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Max Tendler of Washington.

I've seen elaborate wreaths by the plaque which commemorates the six million Jewish dead. I've seen dramatic flower arrangements, and streamers with gilt letters proclaiming sorrow. Since my afternoon walks take me past there, on Riverside Promenade at 83d Street, I've gotten used to it. But a couple of weeks ago I came on something different.

WASHINGTON, June 26 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended June 23:
MOSCOW, June 26 (UPI) A three-man team from the United States has scaled Mount Elbrus, highest peak in the Caucasus, and planted the American flag atop it, an expedition members said to day.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 26 It was last Aug. 2 that Nevele Pride won the Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:07 2-5, setting a world record for 14-16 miles at that gait over a half-mile track.
Mrs. Esther Abelson, an early leader of the suffragette movement in Rhode Island, died Thursday night of a heart attack at her home, 25 Tudor City Place. She was 79 years old.

The State Tax Department, which prefers to collect money rather than refund it, is now facing the sad job of returning hundreds of dollars to people all over the world who have heard that they might become a millionaire through a $3 lottery ticket.

CHICAGO, June 26 Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., charged here today that three former computer operators for the company obtained and sold without authorization its confidential customer list of about 2 million names and addresses.
The New York Stock Exchange has received its first application for membership from a securities concern owned and controlled by blacks.
Dreams of European vacations have turned into nightmares this summer for countless travelers because of illegal practices by some travel agents and airlines.

CHICAGO, June 26 A special Cook County prosecutor was appointed today to impanel a special grand jury and reopen an investigation into the slaying of two Black Panther party members in a predawn police raid here last December.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 26 Barney Ward piloted Cat Bird to victory after a jumpoff in the open jumper class tonight at the Middlesex County Horse show.

KINSHASA, the Congo, June 25 Newcomers to this dusty capital, recalling the violence that marked the early years of the Congo's independence, still sometimes ask with concern whether it is safe to walk about town.

BAY SHORE, L.I., June 26 Miss Elizabeth Anne Ryan and Frederic J. Torphy were married at noon today in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church by the Rev. James K. Bogert, who also celebrated the nuptial mass. There was a reception at the Southward Ho Country Club.

Hermann B. Deutsch, a columnist for The New Orleans States-Item, died Thursday in New York on his way to Polyclinic Hospital after suffering a heart attack at a board meeting of the Channing Fund, an investment group at 285 Park Avenue. He was 81 years old and lived in New Orleans.

William M. Tendy, assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District, told members of the House Select Committee on Crime yesterday that about 15 Mafia figures were responsible for almost 85 per cent of the heroin being brought illegally into the East Coast.
Completion of a $94.1-million refinancing agreement between Peru and a consortium of 11 American banks was announced yesterday by Manufacturers Hanover Trust, the leading bank in the group.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Vice President Agnew signed a clean politics pledge in behalf of the Republican party today. The pledge is incorporated in the 1970 Fair Campaign Practices Code.

Senator Charles E. Goodell declared yesterday that he would campaign for the reelection of Governor Rockefeller but that he would not campaign directly against Arthur J. Goldberg, the Governor's Democratic-Liberal opponent.
Arthur J. Goldberg called yesterday for television debates with Governor Rockefeller and said that "Rockefeller's going to get the surprise of his life if he concentrates on state issues."
NEW HAVEN, June 26 Federal authorities charged the wife of a Black Panther leader in Bridgeport today with illegal possession of firearms.

OURAY, Colo. Even though U.S. 550, the Million Dollar Highway, has been widened and improved so that it is no longer a terror to flatlanders, it is still a breathtaking way to go from Durango, near the New Mexico border, north into Colorado's alpine country around Silverton and on up to mountainous Ouray and Uncompahgre National Forest.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 27 Dr. Leona Baumgartner, visiting professor of social medicine at the Harvard Medical School and former Health Commissioner of the City of New York, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Alexander D. Langmuir. The bridegroom, for many years chief epidemiologist of the Communicable Disease Service of the Public Health Service in Atlanta, will join the Harvard Medical School faculty in August as a visiting professor of epidemiology.
LINCOLN, Neb., June 27 The Church of the Brethren overwhelmingly approved today an official church position endorsing nonviolent draft resistance as an acceptable option for draft-age young men.
LOS ANGELES, June 27 (AP) Mir, skippered by George A. O'Brien of Vancouver, British Columbia, recaptured the lead this morning in the Los Angeles-to-Tahiti yacht race.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 27 Capping a meet of upsets, Howell Michael beat Marty Liquori in the mile and John Smith surprised Lee Evans in the 440-yard dash tonight at the National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 27 The Spreckels Organ Pavilion in Balboa Park here was the scene for the morning wedding of Miss Susan Taylor White and LeGrand Snowden Redfield. The Rev. Joseph Sandren of the Mission Hills Congregational Church performed the ceremony. A reception was given at the Del Coronada Hotel here.

Madison, Conn., June 27 Miss Delozier Davidson who received a B.A. degree from Briarcliff College this month, was married here this afternoon to William Benson Wigton, a 1970 graduate of Lynchburg College in Virginia.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) After 27 months, the income surtax will expire at midnight Tuesday, adding about a dollar to the weekly take-home pay of the average worker.

WATERTOWN, Conn., June 27 Christ Episcopal Church was the scene this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Barbara Webster Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cook Campbell of Watertown, to William Kemp Bigelow Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bigelow of New Vernon, N.J., and Dorset, Vt. The Rev. Jackson W. Foley performed the ceremony.

BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., June 27 Miss Nancy Ellen Booth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McLaughlin Booth of Birmingham, Mich., was married here this afternoon to Peer Eiler Wedvick Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wedrick of Haworth, N.J., and New York.

The line of Interstate 70 in the Rocky Mountains west of Denver cuts through a ridge called the Hogback. On the initiative of Colorado conservation and civic groups, it is being turned into an attractive showplace of the geology of the region.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia They're cutting the low branches off all the trees in Pnompenh these days in order to give the Government defenders a clearer line of fire if the Communists attack. This is as good an indication as any of how bad things have become in Cambodia as the deadline for American troop withdrawal approaches.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 The great Rod Laver was beaten at Wimbledon today, his streak of 31 victories over 10 years broken.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27 Tony D'Ambrosio Jr., a 16-year-old senior at Iona Prep in New Rochell, N.Y., had the best strategy and the best mount tonight and won the Gambler's choice class in the open jumper division at the Middlesex County horse show.

DAN BERRIGAN Jesuit priest, prize-winning poet and napalmer of draft files-is on the dam. He was convicted with eight other Christian resisters, including his priest-brother Philip Berrigan, for destroying Selective Service records snatched two years ago from Local Board 33 at Catonsville, Md. But after the Supreme Court refused to review the case,he failed to surrender himself for imprisonment on April 9.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) Volume in hail insurance on crops has more than tripled since World War II but lately has shown signs of leveling off because of tighter acreage restrictions and lower prices for major crops, the Agriculture Department has reported.

The Board of Elections declared yesterday that State Assemblyman Charles B. Rangel was the official winner over Representative Adam Clayton Powell in last Tuesday's Democratic primary contest in the 18th Congressional District.

MARGARETVILLE, N.Y., June 27 Miss Cynthia Meeker Holthusen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. John Holthusen of Sea Girt, N.J. was married here today to Roswell Randall Sanford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford of Margaretville.

EVERY gardener who has a little unused space to spare can help conserve our vanishing wildflowers by propagating them from seed. The difficulties vary with the species, but the dedicated dirt gardener will surely see them as challenges rather than obstacles.

MILWAUKEE, June 27 (AP) Gene Brabender scattered five hits today and the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Oakland Athletics, 3-1, for their third straight victory.

RUTHERFORD, Calif., June 27 After the small family wedding this afternoon in Holy Family Roman Catholic Church of Miss Paula Helene Sullivan and Thomas Crowley Escher, a large reception took place at Beaulieu, the estate of the bride's family in the heart of California's wine country. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Mark Hurley.

HOUSTON, June 27 (UPI) Tony Perez drove in two runs with a pair of singles and Jim Merritt pitched a perfect game for six innings tonight, leading the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-2 triumph over the Houston Astros.

BUDAPEST, June 27 (AP) The Warsaw Pact governments, in a memorandum handed to Western governments by Hungarian diplomats and published today, have proposed the early preparation of a European EastWest security conference, with the United States and Canada also attending.

More than 100 years ago, America conceived the land grant colleges to open higher education to the children of the middle class. Then came the twoyear junior, or community, calleges as enrollments increased and spread into the lower classes. Now the community colleges are being asked to handle most of the burden created by extension of higher education to even the poor and deprived.

WASHINGTON, June 27 A Congressional watchdog Committee recommended today that South Vietnam promptly devalue its currency to dampen inflation, curb corruption and protect the morale and morals of Americans fighting and working in that country.

Stout of White Plains, who was assisted by the pastor, the Rev. George R. Bailey.

Only once in this century has the city approached this experience-in two depression years, 1933 and 1934 (aside from the nationwide World War II shutdown of residential construction).

Silent Screen made his way to the winner's circle yesterday, for the first time since last February. JERUSALEM Israel maintained a cautious silence last week about the new and still unpublished United States peace initiatives for the Middle East. Premier Golda Meir promised a "political statement" in Parliament tomorrow, but she may not disclose Israel's true reaction to the plan. Many observers believe that Israel has kept quiet in the hope that the Arab nations would shoot down Secretary of State William P. Rogers's proposals and save Israel the trouble.

WASHINGTON, June 27 The Nixon Administration believes that the use of South Vietnamese and Thai combat troops and air forces in Cambodia, combined with a limited supply of United States weapons and continued bombing of Communist supply lines, will save the regime of Premier Lon Nol in Pnompenh.

Underhill 3d. Family Court Judge Har old Felix performed the ceremony.

VANCOUVER, B.C. THERE are those who say there is an architecture of confrontation and that it has been built at Simon Fraser University. CLEVELAND, June 28 Bruce Devlin made it two victories in a row for foreign golf professionals today. In Denver, on Fifteenth Street between Arapahoe and Curtis, a huge, bearded miner cast in bronze, one hand resting on a pick and the other holding a nugget, reminds passers-by of the Western city's gold-rush beginnings. Several blocks away, the genuine gold-leaf dome of the State Capitol glistens against an azure sky to attest to the success of the earliest prospectors.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 As American troops continued their withdrawal from Cambodia, scheduled to be completed by Tuesday, a slight increase in enemy activity was reported throughout South Vietnam in the last 48 hours.

COPENHAGEN, June 26 Denmark is approaching the formal opening Tuesday of negotiations for membership in the European Economic Community with a greater degree of confidence than any of her fellow applicants.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 As American soldiers near the end of their two-month incursion into suspected North Vietnamese and Vietcong sanctuaries in Cambodia and return to South Vietnam, the course of the war in Southeast Asia appears vastly more complicated and uncertain than before the incursion began.
Arthur J. Goldberg; the Democratic candidate for Governor, scoffed yesterday at Governor Rockefeller's description of himself as a "strong peace candidate."

MINNEAPOLIS, June 28 A team of Mayo Clinic researchers has found "a reassuringly low incidence" of recurrent seizures, or epilepsy, in a follow-up study of 381 children who had been treated as infants for convulsions associated with a high fever.

MONTREAL, June, 28 Dave Marshall of the Mets and Rusty Staub of the Expos both cracked home runs over the right-field fence in the eighth inning today, but Staub's came with a man on base and that was enough to lift the Expos to a 3-2 victory over New York.
ROME, June 28 More than- 1,000 Roman Catholic traditionalists from various European countries publicly prayed in Latin today in a sedate protest against what they termed the "Montini mass."

Seventy films from the archives of the Cinematheque Francaise in Paris will be shown from July 29 through Sept. 3 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art under the joint sponsorship of the museum and the City Center of Music and Drama.

TOKYO, June 28 To the countries of East and Southeast Asia, President Nixon's Guam doctrine has an appealing ring, and Asian lip service to the doctrine is enthusiastic.

Miss Johanna Sebastian Rosenthal, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Rosenthal of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married here yesterday to Dr. Wallace Brand Mendelson, son of Prof. and Mrs. Wallace Mendelson of Austin, Tex. The ceremony at the Plaza was performed by Rabbi David J. Seligson, cousin of the bride.

CAIRO, June 28 President Gamal Abdel Nasser is expected to fly to the Soviet Union this week for consultations on the military and po- litical aspects of a settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict, but officials here said they had no information about such a trip.

MIAMI BEACH, June 25 Tens of thousands of vacationers were on the beaches here this morning, engaged in the No. 1 American holiday activity sunbathing. The ocean water that crashed onto the South Florida beaches in fivefoot waves was clear.
DETROIT, June 28 Detroit's police commissioner has ordered his men to get some college education before promotion.
BALTIMORE, June 28 (AP) Philip L. Poe, president of the Maryland Pennsylvania Railroad died on Friday at his home. He was 91 years old.
David Humphreys, a landscape painter, died in Paris on Thursday after a short illness. He was 69 years old, and lived here and in Dorset, Vt.

RUMFORD, R.I., June 28 Alan Miller of Pensacola, Fla., shattered the tournament record by seven strokes as he ran away from the field in the ninth annual Northeast amateur invitation golf event with a total of 280 today.

HARTFORD, June 28 Twenty-four years ago, John M. Bailey seized control of the Connecticut Democratic party by winning the gubernatorial nomination for a white-haired poet named Wilbert Snow at a turbulent convention at the Bushnell Memorial Hall in Hartford.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 South Vietnamese voted today for city and provincial councilmen in an election that has centered on domestic concerns but that may play an important role in the future of national politics.
CLEVELAND, June 28 Signs of a willingness by railroads in the Great Lakes area to share dry bulk traffic with steamship operators were reported here last week.
TORONTO, June 28 An ambitious but somewhat vague plan for delivering natural gas from Alaska to Canada and the United States was announced over the weekend by the Alberta Gas Trunk Line Co., Ltd.

PARIS, June 28 Earl A. Scheib, auto painting executive of Beverly Hills, Calif., paid a large, undisclosed sum of money last Friday for a classy Irish colt, Roll of Honour. He recovered most of his investment today when the horse won the first prize of $173,000 in the Grand Prix de Paris, run over 1 mile 7 furlongs at Longchamp.

A coalition of youth gangs and political activists calling itself the Think Lincoln Committee held a rally in the South Bronx yesterday afternoon to protest conditions in Lincoln Hospital and to charge the police with "brutally beating up" people at a similar rally on Saturday.
MILWAUKEE, June 28 Radicals from a wide spectrum of organizations gathered here this weekend to plan new strategies to end the war in Southeast Asia.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 28 Two fresh enemy infantry regiments are making their way from North Vietnam through Laos toward the northernmost province of South Vietnam, according to highranking American and Vietnamese military men. But they insist they are not worried by this development.
WASHINGTON, June 28 President Nixon's promised "new approach" to foreign aid in the Seventies is evoking stiff opposition in Congress even before its official unveiling.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 27 "We don't have a dictatorship we have a revolutionary Government that is going to restructure Ecuador's social and economic life," Finance Minister Luis Gomez Izquierdo said the other day.

Thousands of young men and women homosexuals from all over the Northeast marched from Greenwich Village to the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday, proclaiming "the new strength and pride of the gay people."
CASTLE ROCK, Colo., June 28 (AP) Mario Andretti overcame extreme heat today and won the $60,000 Rocky Mountain 150-mile auto race at Continental Divide Raceways.

WASHINGTON, June 28 Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, proposed today that the United States initiate a graduated cease-fire in Vietnam in an attempt to improve the climate for a negotiated peace.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 28 Miss Barbara Ann Tashjian, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Haig Tashjian of Leonia, was married at the St. Thomas Armenian Apostolic Church here today to William Saunders Weismann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dudley Weismann of Schenectady. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arnak Kasparian; who was assisted by the Rev. Levon Arakelian.
BOSTON, June 28 The Youth Caucus endorsed today for Congress a Roman Catholic priest, a black lawyer and a former school teacher in three Massachusetts Congressional districts.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 28 (UPI) Mary Mills of Laurel, Miss., won a sudden-death playoff on the second hole to take the $20,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association's Immke Buick open today.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) A Federal-state relations office has been created within the President's Committee on Consumer Interests, Mrs. Virginia H. Knauer, committee chairman, announced today.

Miss Vivian Claire Diamant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Diamant of New York, was married here last evening to Albert Cabasso, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Cabasso of Geneva.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 The California Legislature is about to propose a state constitutional amendment designed to permit direct appropriations of public funds for private colleges and universities.

Charles H. Prange, a former alloy company president, died Saturday at Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Hospital of a heart ailment. He was 78 years old, and lived at 10 Park Avenue, New York. Mr. Prange joined with a brother-in-law, Heiner W. Erdle, in 1928, to form Austenal Laboratories, Inc., producer of stainless steel denture plates.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange is scheduled to meet in special session this afternoon to vote on a new commission rate schedule which will he submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission tomorrow.

Three members of the militant Jewish Defense League, including its chairman, Rabbi Meir Kahane, were arrested outside a police station in Brooklyn last night for allegedly hurling bottles at policemen who attempted to disperse a crowd of the league's followers.

HEWLETT, L.I., June 28 In a garden ceremony at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Finck, the bride's uncle and aunt, Miss Jane Konheim of New York and Mondi Elimelech of Tel Aviv were married this afternoon by Rabbi Judah Cahn of the Metropolitan Synagogue of New York.

When Nate Bowman and Henri Phipps were students at Wichita State in the early nineteen-sixties, they led very different lives. Mr. Bowman, a star athlete, was busy dunking shots for the basketball team. Mr. Phipps, an engineering student, was busy designing furniture.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., June 28 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Bradley Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elise Burns Bradley, to William Mairs Duryea Jr., a member of the New York Stock Exchange and a partner of the New York securities firm of H. Hentz Co. in New York. A September wedding is planned.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 Steel producers are revising their 1970 forecasts upward.

The overwhelming rejection by Chicago truck drivers of a contract that would have given them pay increases of more than 40 per cent over a 45-month period is a blow to the Nixon Administration's hopes for wageprice stability through the President's new brand of "jawboning."

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., June 28 A national organization of black journalists was founded today at Lincoln University here and adopted a program to support a colleague who has been cited for contempt of court.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) A bill that would require companies in basic industries to give advance notice to the President of any proposed price increase will be introduced tomorrow by Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn. The bill would require a 60-day waiting period before any price increase could take effect.

CHICAGO, June 28 (UPI) Bill Melton's 14th homer of the season provided the Chicago White Sox with an 11-10 triumph today after the Minnesota Twins had given Manager Bill Rigney the 1,000 victory of his career by winning the opener, 9-1, with the help of two homers by Harmon Killebrew, his l9th and 20th.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 28--The Government of the Ryukyus over the weekend gave official approval to the aluminum Company of America's application for a multimilliondollar investment on the island The action came on the heels of a similar bid by a group of five Japanese aluminum producers which, with their Government's backing, have been bitterly opposing a "backdoor entry" of the American concern.
A special $1.7-million state program designed to provide additional summer jobs for disadvantaged youth was announced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

Suppliers of low-sulphur fuel oil needed to meet air-pollution controls report that they probably will be able to fill only 80 to 90 per cent of the demand on the East Coast next winter, according to the city's Environmental Protection Administration.
BARABOO, Wis. By the time the long Northern twilight falls over central Wisconsin these days there are few places left in the three sprawling campgrounds at Devils Lake State Park.

In foreign policy, Edward Heath's personal priority has long been clear. He would like to go down in history as the Prime Minister who took Britain into the European Common Market. He believes this step would provide the best guarantee for future prosperity and a meaningful international political role for Britain.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 Gilbert E. Jones, chairman of the board of the I.B.M. World Trade Corporation, and Mrs. Jones have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leila Haven Jones, to Jonathan Scranton Linen, son of James A. Linen 3d, chairman of the executive committee of Time Inc., and Mrs. Linen and nephew of William Warren Scranton,former Governor of Pennsylvania.
JACKSON, Miss., June 28 (AP) A special Federal grand jury will be empaneled here tomorrow to investigate the disorders in which two young Ne- groes were killed last month at Jackson State College.

PARIS, June 28 Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber, the journalist, author and secretary general of the Radical Socialist party, was elected a Deputy in the National Assembly today in Lorraine, in eastern France. His victory was regarded as a provincial revolt against Paris.

CINCINNATI, June 28 The N.A.A.C.P. said today that its part in the fight to defeat the nomination of Judge Clement F. Haynesworth Jr. to the Supreme Court was one of "its most noteworthy achievements" of 1969.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 Secretary of State William P. Rogers conferred for 90 minutes here today with Rumania's Foreign Minister, Corneliu Manescu, who will meet tomorrow morning with President Nixon at the Western White House at San Clemente, Calif.
The New York Yankees continued to reconstruct pieces of their glorious past while splitting a doubleheader with the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
PARIS, June 28 Pierre Mac Orlan, the French novelist and poet, died last night at the age of 88 after a heart attack at his home at St.-Cyr-surMorin.

TENAFLY, N.J., June 28 The marriage of Miss Debra Ruth Piche, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Cole Piche, to Angus McDonell Coffey took place in the Presbyterian Church here tonight. The bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Onolee McDonell Coffey of Englewood and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Thomas Coffey of New York.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 28 Miss Mary Ellen Palmer and Second Lieut. David William McDermott, U.S.A.F., were married here today in the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Holy Trinity. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert McCormick.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 (UPI) Don McMahon shut off the slumping Atlanta Braves for two innings in each game of a double-header today as the San Francisco Giants won the opener, 6-4, in 10 innings and the second game, 4-3.

PESCARA, Italy, June 28--Buses and trucks barricading streets, smashed store windows and overturned burned-out cars have transformed this Adriatic beach city into a guerrilla landscape.

SAIGON, June 29 (AP) As the last American combat troops withdrew from Cambodia today, Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops renewed their assault on the Cambodian munitions depot at Longvek, 23 miles north of Pnompenh, and shelled Cambodian troop positions with mortars in the Siemreap-Angkor area in the northwest.

DETROIT, June 29 Two Negroes, reportedly part of a small extremist group, were charged today with attempting to murder Detroit policemen.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The Federal Communications Commission ruled today, by a 4-to-3 vote, that Alabama's educational television system was free to drop the black-oriented programming of the National Educational Television Network as a matter of "taste or judgment."
Vincent D. McDonnell, chairman of the State Mediation Board, met separately yesterday with both sides in the critical hospital dispute in an effort to avert a walkout tomorrow morning.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 29 The British Army announced a stepup in security measures today as Roman Catholic-Protestant feelings in Belfast became increasingly bitter.
Dean Witter Co., the big investment banking and brokerage firm, announced yesterday a loss for its third fiscal quarter ended May 31 and a profit for the nine-month period.

CORNWALL, N.Y., June 29 Gerald C. Stowe, the curator of the museum at the United States Military Academy at West Point and an authority on the American Revolution, was found dead outside his home here today. The coroner ruled Mr. Stowe's death a suicide, according to the State Police.

WASHINGTON, June 29 A high-level study group, appointed a year ago to advise the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare on what to do about the Medicaid program, has concluded there must be sweeping changes in the entire American health care system.

Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy says she believes "everything Ted said" about the events surrounding the accident on Chappaquiddick Island last summer that involved her husband, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, and took the life of a young secretary, Mary Jo Kopechne.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Parents for Peace urged President Nixon today to end the war in Southeast Asia swiftly or, the group warned, the nation will face "irreparable" harm to society.
LONDON, June 29 Mrs. Jeremy Thorpe, wife of the leader of the Liberal party, was killed in an automobile accident in Basingstoke today. She was 32 years old.
The formation of a new trade association for the port's tug and barge industry has been announced by Thomas E. Moran, chairman of the new group.

A special, reduced-size facsimile of page one of yesterdays's New York Times was sent to the United Nations pavilion of Expo '70 in Osaka, Japan, via communications satellite and a telenews system developed by The Asahi Shimbum, the Tokyo newspaper.

HUARAS, Peru, June 29 Mrs. Richard M. Nixon strolled through the streets of this earthquake-stricken Peruvian community today to accept gifts of flowers from children, look at the damage, and chat with survivors.

LUXEMBOURG, June 29 The European Economic Community and Israel signed a fiveyear preferential trade agreement today that Foreign Minister Abba Eban said had significance beyond its economic content in providing the basis for deeper political relationships.

Robert Macht has been elected vice president of the Southeast Bancorporation, Inc., effective Aug. 1. He recently resigned as chairman of the board of Jordan Marsh-Florida and as executive vice president of the parent company, Allied Stores Corporation. He has been a member of the board of the bank holding company.
WASHINGTON, June 29 The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the issue of school busing to achieve integration, but it did not say whether its ruling would come before schools open in the fall.

JERUSALEM, June 29 Premier Golda Meir said today that she saw no reason to change Israel's present diplomatic and military policies. She thus appeared to reject that latest United States peace initiative in the Middle East.

MOSCOW, June 29 The Foreign Ministry today advised William Cole, Moscow correspondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, to leave the Soviet Union because he had "engaged in activities incompatible with the status of a foreign journalist."
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 29 James W. Cameron, a traffic manager for the Union Carbide Corporation, died at Community Hospital here Saturday. He was 42 year old and lived in Yorktown Heights.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29 (AP) President Nixon nominated Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg today, to another five-year term as chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Justice William O. Douglas declared today that a worker may have a constitutional right to be a "conscientious objector" against union membership.
Stock prices observed a bearmarket tradition yesterday. They sagged on "Blue Monday." Glamour and rail issues were hit hardest.
