After five down-drifting days last week, stocks on the American Stock Exchange could find little impetus yesterday to rise. As a result the index closed at 20.13, down .09.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 29 The loneliness of the long-distance runner is no more for Frank Shorter, whose only record at Yale, he says, was for second-place finishes.

TRENTON, June 29 The lawyer defending Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark, who is on trial here with five other defendants for extortion and conspiracy, took the prosecution's key witness today through an extended cross-examination.

STOCKHOLM, June 29 European pairs dominated the standings after the first day play in the world pair championship here. With 48 deals completed of a scheduled 288, the leaders were Arne Persson and Einar Pyk of Stockholm, 4,568, a 61 per cent score; Niels Henriksen and Peter Lund of Arhus, Denmark, 4,450; Giuseppe Saulino and Mario Zanasi of La Spezia, Italy, 4,391, and Jean Besse and John Collings of Geneva, 4,357.

Trans World Airlines said yesterday that an engine fire that erupted during the landing of a T.W.A. Boeing 747 jetliner here Friday night was caused by an accumulation of fuel in the engine's tailpipe. The fuel was pumped into the tailpipe after the engine's air compressor "stalled" during the landing, it was said.
Penn Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn was the scene of street fighting on Sunday night as Hasidic Jews and blacks threw bottles and insults at one another until the police took control.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin told the United States Court of Appeals today that he did not intend to suspend sales of DDT until he had decided whether to cancel various uses of the pesticide.

WASHINGTON, June 29 In a confidential report to the President, a special White House panel recommends urgent Administration assistance for millions of blue-collar workers, described as economically trapped, socially scorned and "overripe for a political response to the pressing needs they feel so keenly."

BONN, June 29 Chancellor Willy Brandt suggested today that Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader, had given a sign that East and West Germany could proceed now to a third, meaningful round of talks about settling some of the differences that have kept them separated and hostile for the last quarter of a century.

Archbishop Iakovos, the Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America, declared yesterday that his church must be granted more autonomy by the Ecumenical Patriarchate in Istanbul if it is to thrive in an American context.

CINCINNATI, June 29 Following are excerpts from the keynote address of Bishop Stephen G. Spottswood, chairman of the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, at the association's annual convention here today:

The lawyer for a Bronx policeman charged with lying about his dealings with gamblers accused the police and prosecution yesterday of granting policy operators immunity from arrest in return for testifying against his client.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 29 The Iranian Government is in the midst of a campaign to attract back home intellectuals and other highly qualified Iranians who are abroad for political reasons.

Judge William Mertens of the City Civil Court and Mrs. Mertens have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Patricia Ann Mertens, to Stephen Ross Beckwith, son of Mrs. Robert E. Beckwith of Glenview, Ill., and the late Mr. Beckwith.

A House committee released testimony yesterday in which the Air Force suggested that the best solution to its $600million dispute with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation over the C-5A cargo jet might be for the Government to pay up to half the company's claim.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The United States Court of Military Review has reversed the mutiny convictions of two more men involved in the protest by prisoners at the Army's San Francisco Presidio stockade, the Pentagon said today.
LONDON, June 29 If Edward Heath had not become Prime Minister of Britain, in his own view, he "really could have done well" as a conductor.
The current heavily advertised premium war involving savings banks is making comparison shoppers out of depositors.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 29 We all make mistakes, errors of judgment, failures in perception. Yesterday afternoon in a bus on the way to the first performance of "The Devil's Disciple" given by the American Shakespeare Festival Theater, I fell into a very natural error.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 29 The Lutheran Church in America overwhelmingly approved tonight the ordination of women to the ministry.

WASHINGTON, June 29 President Nixon's venture into Cambodia is ending with proclamations of unprecedented military gain, but it was launched for the broader purpose of rescuing Cambodia from sudden Communist domination and that purpose is still unrealized.

Robert Streicher and Peggy Cicierska collaborated on a program of dances Sunday night at the Cubiculo. Both are accomplished technicians who developed their dances out of a secure base of craftsmanship. Neither, however, managed to rise far above the admiration that one reserves for sheer skill.
JUAREZ, Mexico, June 29 (AP) Members of two wellknown American families Roosevelt and Rockefeller were granted divorces today in this Mexican border town.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 29 American Airlines has been awarded the right to apply for three flights a week to Australia under a new agreement between the Australian and United States Governments on air services across the southern Pacific.

A sharp drop in nationwide construction contracts in May caused the Dodge index of construction contract value to dive to 170 from 203 in April, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

Dr. Vaughan C. Mason, an obstetrician, who was installed a month ago as president of the New York County Medical Society, died at Sydenham Hospital yesterday morning after a brief illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 28 Priscilla Avenue in Yonkers.
The National Hockey League awarded yesterday the starcrossed Oakland Seals to Charles O. Finley, the controversial, owner of the Oakland Athletics baseball team.
There's more than enough noise to cause headaches in the lower floors of the American and Statler Hilton Hotels. And the flashing and blinking psychedelic lights can easily create dizziness.

A 29-year-old Brooklyn man being sought by the police for the murders of three narcotics pushers last Wednesday night walked into a police station in the Bedford-Styvesant section last night and surrendered.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The Federal Reserve Board adopted a new rule today requiring that subordinated notes or debentures issued by banks to raise funds have a maturity of at least seven years and a minimum denomination of $500 if they are to be exempt from interest rate ceiling under Regulation Q.

LOS ANGELES, June 29 Legal arguments in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women moved from the judge's chambers to open court today following a protest by the District Attorney's office.

John F. Donato, a public relations man, testified yesterday that Nathan M. Voloshen gave him the use of the office of House Speaker John W. McCormack, and that he, Mr. Donato, in turn, arranged for his employer, the Sperry Gyroscope Company, to engage Voloshen with a monthly retainer of $1,250.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate approved tonight a bill raising the temporary national debt ceiling to $395billion, opening the way for the Government to borrow money it said it needed to pay its bills.

Consolidated Edison's nuclear power generating plant at Indian Point, which is capable of meeting the electrical needs of 260,000 families, will be out of service for the rest of the summer, the utility company announced yesterday.
CINCINNATI, June 29 The Nixon Administration was denounced as anti-Negro here tonight by the chairman of the board of the racially moderate National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Evidently divided, the Supreme Court called today for a new round of argument on efforts to prosecute 11 New York Negroes on charges of plotting to paralyze and overthrow the state government.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The income tax surcharge ends at midnight tomorrow.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29 President Nixon conferred with Secretary Rogers today amid recurring reports that the Administration was preparing to take new diplomatic steps to add life to the Paris peace negotiations.

Miss Clare Bowen Buck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Orton Buck of New York, was married here yesterday to David Morrison Dalva, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Dalva of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald C. McFerren at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Bob Hope, the comedian, who is national co-chairman of Honor America Day, forecast this morning that the July 4 celebration in Washington would attract "the biggest crowd that has even gathered for any show," estimating that more than 400,000 persons would come for the day's events.
WASHINGTON, June 29 The National Endowment for the Arts announced today that it would soon make $2-million in grants to support and encourage selected arts groups across the nation.

WASHINGTON, June 29 An organization of black contractors announced today that it would oppose the choice of Malcolm R. Lovell Jr., the Department of Labor's manpower administrator, to replace Arnold R. Weber as Assistant Secretary of Labor when Mr. Weber joins the staff of the Office of Management and Budget.

A day after the New York Shakespeare Festival's 11hour marathon presentation of "The Chronicles of King Henry V" and "Richard III" in Central Park, Mayor Lindsay agreed to submit a budget modification to the Board of Estimate for the purchase of the festival's Public Theater at 425 Lafayette Street.
Officials of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission who retained a Columbia University sociologist to study some facets of the addiction problem have done an evaluation of his evaluation.
LONDON, June 29 (AP) A London bank owned by the Soviet Government struck a bargain with British labor today and granted its employes a wage increase.
ALGONA, Iowa Cheryl Browne, who jokingly calls herself "the girl who came to dinner," came to this small northwest Iowa town over the weekend to let the locals get a glimpse of royalty, Iowa style.

JERSEY CITY, June 29 In a bloody sacrifice that evoked more sympathy for the loser than prestige for the winner, Sonny Liston was awarded a 10th-round knockout at the Jersey City Armory tonight when Chuck Wepner was determined unfit to continue after nine rounds.

When Arthur J. Goldberg and Howard J. Samuels were still battling for the Democratic nomination for Governor, someone asked Governor Rockefeller who he thought had the best chance of beating him in November. Mr. Rockefeller answered: "Dick Nixon."
BUFFALO, June 29, (AP) The Buffalo Bills signed today their No. 1 draft choice, Al Cowlings of the University of Southern California.

Sir David Owen, head of the International Planned Parenthood Federation and a former administrator of the United Nations development program, died of a heart attack yesterday in a London hospital. He was 65 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29 The last United States ground combat troops in Cambodia scrambled back into the Central Highlands of South Vietnam this evening, ending two months of operations in Cambodia that, at the peak, had seen 18,000 American troops attacking Communist base and supply areas across the border.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 Secretary of State William P. Rogers warned North Vietnam today that it could not again count on a safe haven in Cambodia despite the withdrawal of United States ground combat forces from that country.
Prices drifted down in very quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

A case that embroiled five State Supreme Court justices in angry clashes last week ended yesterday with the central figure a Westchester contractor wanted by a New York County grand jury as a material witness in a bid-rigging case fined $250 for contempt, but he was released from a $100,000 bail obligation imposed last Thursday.

With the Fourth of July celebration coming up, Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary warned the public yesterday of the dangers of fireworks and at the same time called upon every member of the force to prevent the illegal sale of the explosives.
WESTBURY, L.I. June 29 Lyon, a 6-year-old bay from Sweden, was the first horse chosen today for the $125,000 Roosevelt International, the world's richest invitation trot.
BADEN, Austria, June 29 Consumer-protection experts opened an international conference in this garden spa today amid growing anxiety that they were failing to reach the needs or the poor.
How do you get the two best-known iconoclasts in the accounting profession on the same side?
PRINCETON, N.J., June 29 Eric Kahler, a cultural historian who had taught at universities here and abroad, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 1 Evelyn Place.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Navajo Indians won a major victory today in a fight to prove title to 40 million acres of Western land.

FIRE SUPPORT BASE EUNICE, South Vietnam, June 28 Twenty-one-yearold S. Sgt. Stanley Zeager of Rocky River, Ohio one of the more than 30,000 American soldiers sent to Cambodia is back in Vietnam and glad of it.
WASHINGTON, June 29 The Senate rebuffed a Republican attempt today to force an immediate vote on the so-called end-the-war amendment, which has become the rallying point for Senate doves.
Because Ernie Austin, a movie actor about to become a stage manager, has a brother-in-law who is a Colombian there is a new shop on Ninth Avenue between 57th and 58th Streets called Macramania.
MOSCOW, June 29 (UPI) A Soviet conservationist has said that the great Kuznetsk coal mines are devouring fertile lands, poisoning the air and polluting the water.

WASHINGTON, June 29 Improper landing procedures were blamed by the National Transportation Safety Board today for the crash-landing in San Francisco Bay Nov. 22, 1968, of a Japan Airlines DC-8 airliner.

It took Cushman Wakefield, Inc., just one week to find a new merger partner. A week ago, it was announced that the Allied Maintenance Corporation and Cushman Wakefield had ended merger talks "because of tax considerations that appear insoluble."

Liza Minnelli, who starred in her first television special last night, on the National Broadcasting Company, is so engaging and willing a performer that one feels positively caddish in finding her program less than memorable. Rarely have more energy, enthusiasm and production skill gone into a TV special with such meager results.
ST. LOUIS After the Cardinals won a recent game with a timely hit by their Spanish-speaking second baseman, Julian Javier, several jubilant fans were walking past a vacant building near the stadium.

Emile Grifith, former middleweight and welterweight champion, started two weeks of training at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum yesterday. He sparred two rounds apiece with Henry Castro, a middleweight, and Miguel Barreto, a welterweight, in preparation for his July 15 Garden bout with Dick Tiger.

The New York Stock Exchange has abandoned plans for any further volume discounts on commission rates and would restrict the rate increases on most small transactions to 50 per cent under a plan to be submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The city's two top public welfare chiefs have declared that the rise in New York City's relief rolls during the nineteen-sixties had been paralleled by similar rises in Los Angeles and some other urban centers. They sought to rebut crisicism of administration here.

TORONTO, June 29 The Bank of Nova Scotia, a leading Canadian bank, said today that "the sudden movement of United States troops into Cambodia" intensified pressures on the Canadian dollar and forced Ottawa's May 31 decision to let the dollar float freely in the foreign-exchange market.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Selective Service officials began today stuffing 730 plastic capsules with dates and numbers that will determine the 1971 draft sequence of hundreds of thousands of youths with 19th birthdays this year.

WASHINGTON, June 29 American ground troops are out of Cambodia on schedule. That is all to the good and emphasizes, rather than diminishes, the need for the Senate to pass the Cooper-Church amendment on Tuesday.
JACKSON, Miss., June 29 A Federal judge impaneled a special grand jury today to investigate the shooting of Negroes at Jackson State College last month by members of the State Highway Patrol.
Forty-two years ago, on July 9, 1928, a young Cornell graduate joined the National City Company, the investment banking affiliate of the National City Bank, as an $80-a-month mail clerk.

ATHENS, June 29 Premier George Papadopoulos today enlarged and shuffled the Cabinet of his army-backed regime in a move that was viewed here as technical rather than political, as the appointees have predom- inantly nonmilitary back- grounds.

A group of business men from Philadelphia and Washington, incorporated under the name of Bob Foster, Inc., and representing the lightheavyweight boxing champion, announced yesterday they had filed a statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking registration of 100,000 shares of common stock to be offered for public sale at $4 a share.

Physicians who perform abortions under the new state law that goes into effect tomorrow will issue a death certificate for the fetus, a spokesman for the city's Health Services Administration confirmed yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 29 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic arrived today for talks with Soviet leaders that are expected to shed some light on the possibilities of a political settlement of the Middle East conflict.

When Casey Stengel was managing the Brooklyn Dodgers many eons ago, his right fielder was Hack Wilson, a tremendous home-run hitter. But the short, wideshouldered Hack was then completing the process of drinking his way out of the league. On this particular day he was playing in Philadelphia's band box park, Baker Bowl, and it was to be a rugged afternoon.
Premier Golda Meir's low-key response to the new American peace initiative keeps alive the opportunity for quiet diplomacy to break the dangerous Middle East impasse.
With one eye on the weather, traders bought heavily on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, sending new-crop corn and soybeans futures soaring again to new highs for the season.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) The Senate Appropriations Committee voted to double funds available for the food stamp program in the next 12 months, to a total of $1.25billion.
The Flintkote Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices from 10 per cent to 20 per cent above current market prices on all gypsum wallboard and lath products.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Senate passage by voice vote completed Congressional action today on a bill that includes an emergency $50-million appropriation to provide summer jobs for disadvantaged youths.
Bond prices climbed again yesterday, nudging interest rates down still further from the peaks reached two weeks ago.

CAIRO, June 29 President Nasser's talks in Moscow are expected to be decisive to the course of the Arab-Israeli conflict, either to pursue efforts for a political settlement or to increase military steps to compel the Israelis to withdraw.
PARIS, June 29 (AP) Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of the Salk polio vaccine, and Francoise Gilot, former mistress of Pablo Picasso, were married today in suburban Neuilly.

WASHINGTON, June 29 In the third such case against a major steel company in little more than a year, the Justice Department brought suit today against the Republic Steel Corporation for engaging in allegedly illegal reciprocal business arrangements.
MUTTONTOWN, L.I. June 29 Mr. and Mrs. Dan G. Kramer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Dean Kramer, to Charles Seymour 3d.
Willie McCovey, the San Francisco slugger, has regained the lead over Richie Allen of St. Louis in the voting for first baseman on the National League All-Star team.
Steel production showed a slight gain of 0.1 per cent last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., June 29 Seven men were arrested by Suffolk County police today on charges of fraud involving the cashing of welfare checks.
ST. PAUL, June 29 Minnesota's 77-year-old abortion law was upheld as constitutional today in its first court test.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (UPI) A police officer and a youth reportedly wearing a black nationalist uniform were wounded today when a gunbattle broke out at what the authorities called a black nationalist recruiting headquarters on the city's East Side.
Young Rubicam will be getting the assignment to advertise the installmentform encyclopedias that are being published by Marshall Cavendish, Ltd., the British concern.

A.C. Nielsen Company reported yesterday in an unaudited statement for the nine months ended May 31, a record profit of $5,564,852, or $1.05 a share. This compares with $4, 924,055, or 93 cents a share, for the comparable 1969 period. Sales of services also reached a record of $78,921,221, up 7.8 per cent from $73,179,480 a year earlier.
IOWA CITY, June 29 Golf and industry merged today for a pro-amateur tournament deep in the corn-belt country that cost more than $100,000 to produce.

Just down the road from Jamaica, Queens, where Lou Carnesecca coached St. John's basketball teams for the last five seasons, the little man issued his first practice-drill orders yesterday in preparation for a new season. But this time Carnesecca was conducting workouts for 34 young men hopeful of playing professional basketball next winter.

SARATOGA, Calif., June 29 Miss Kitty Susan Stark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Stark of New York, was married here this evening to Lee Nicholas Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Price of Bangkok, Thailand. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Roger Herst at the Villa Montalvo.

When Dr. Nunzio Rini, a retired surgeon, and his wife, a dermatologist, went shopping at a Grand Union supermarket at 4768 Broadway the other day they discovered that the store had made available to them what some food retailers regard as the wave of the future unit pricing.

NEW DELHI, June 29 The old-guard faction of the Congress party, led by opponents of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, called today for a national democratic front to "save India" from dictatorship and Communism.

The surtax on personal and corporate income expires tonight. It deserves an obituary notice, since it will certainly be missed especially when the Nixon Administration calculates the deficit that is looming for the fiscal year 1971, which starts tomorrow, and for fiscal 1972 as well.

LONDON, June 29 In his first week at the Foreign Office, Sir Alec Douglas-Home has seen the top 50 or so people in the department. Every one of them worked for him the last time he was Foreign Secretary, seven years ago.
LONDON, June 29 Harold Wilson was re-elected leader of the Labor party today despite unhappiness at the election upset June 18 that threw the party out of power.
National Educational Television and New York's Channel 13 announced yesterday that they would merge into a single broadcasting organization, the Educational Broadcasting Corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 29 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

The debut of the Exacta, a bomb scare and a dead heat for first in the $36,700 Tremont Stakes turned racing's switch from Belmont to Aqueduct into a waiting game yesterday for 37,792 horseplayers and one detective.
DES MOINES, Iowa, June 29 (AP) Iowa's fourth dynamite bombing in less than two months damaged the Harvey Ingham Hall of Science at Drake University early today.
NEW ORLEANS, June 29 Mrs. Frederick Urbin Gallaty has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Maureen Anne Gallaty.

Commissioner Pete Rozelle and Ernie Wheelwright of the New Orleans Saints met yesterday is the commissioner's New York office to discuss the ownership, of a Metairie, La., night club in which the player has an interest. There was no announcement as to the result of the discussion.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 29 Here, in the cradle of trotting, where since 1838 harness racing has been a way of life, the Grand Circuit moved into Historic Track today for the 58th time since 1873. This touring school of juvenile and sophomore standardbreds annually provides a common meeting ground for the big-city gamblers and the blue-jeaned townfolk.
STOCKHOLM, June 29 (UPI) Sweden will open a permanent diplomatic mission in Hanoi next month to handle increased relations with North Vietnam, the Government announced today.

Richard J. Blakinger has resigned as president and a director of the Hamilton Watch Company, and Arthur B. Sinkler has been named to perform the duties of the office until he is formally elected on July 9. The latter will continue as chairman of the board.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Senate Commerce Committee voted today to open the Federal courts to a broad range of class action suits by consumers against unfair business practices.
THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President issued his statement on United States policy in Cambodia.
DETROIT, June 30 The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had abandoned its minicar design in favor of a new design, but that its introduction would be delayed until 1972.

Cruz Azul, the soccer champion of Mexico in the 1968-69 season, blanked the New York Greek-Americans, 1-0, at Gaelic Park, the Bronx, last night, in the first of the two-game, totalgoal series of the Central and North American playoffs.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, June 30 (UPI) Dartmouth and Pennsylvania lead a contingent of 10 American crews competing in the annual fourday Henley royal regatta opening tomorrow.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 Liberty Bell race track had its biggest thoroughbred daily double today when Market Beat ($42.60) and Bob's Doria ($44.60) triumphed for a $2,110.60 payoff.

WASHINGTON, June 30--With President Nixon placing renewed emphasis on diplomatic efforts to end the Vietnam war, the State Department today indicated more flexibility in the United States' approach to the formation of a coalition Government in Saigon.
West Germany's coalition has survived one crucial test since its recent setbacks in three state elections, but the longer-run political outlook in Bonn remains unpromising.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 The last American advisers and support troops withdrew from Cambodia today, 63 days after major allied operations began against North Vietnamese and Vietcong sanctuaries.
CINCINNATI, June 30--Roy Wilkins urged Negroes today to reject again those ideas being put forth that advocate a separation of the races.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Congressional action and inac- tion are threatening to add more than $7-billion to the budget deficit for the fiscal year that begins tomorrow a new official tally disclosed today.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation announced yesterday it will negotiate with the Equitable Life Assurance Society past the June 30 takedown date established in an agreement made in December, 1968, for a contemplated $25million loan.
A New York policeman was found guilty yesterday of lying to a Bronx grand jury about his meetings with policy gamblers to collect protection money from them.
WASHINGTON, June 30 Manufacturers' inventories held stable in May while new orders rose, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Justice Department accused five textile companies today of conspiring with wholesale and retail dealers to eliminate competition in the retail sale of trademarked bedding. In five suits filed in United States District Court in New York, the Justice Department said each concern conspired with its wholesalers and retailers, but not with each other, to stabilize retail prices of prime-line sheets and pillowcases.

The State Commission of Investigation disclosed yesterday that it had investigated the State Public Service Commission's supervision of electric and gas utilities last year and had, in effect, found its work inadequate in holding down costs.

At midyear the United States economy is sliding into a recession. Unemployment, which reached 5 per cent of the labor force in May, almost certainly climbed higher in June. With hundreds of thousands of young people entering the job market at a time when employers are laying off workers, unemployment will go higher this summer and threatens to hit 6 per cent by the end of the year.

CHATTANOOGA, June 30 The Times Printing Company, which publishes The Chattanooga Times, filed a $21-million countersuit today against The Chattanooga News-Free Press Company and its publisher, Roy McDonald.

Negotiations between broadcast licensees and community groups seeking programing responsive to community needs and the elimination of discriminatory hiring practices will become routine "in the foreseeable future," it was predicted yesterday by the Rev. Everett C., Parker, director of the Office of Communication of the United Church of Christ.
CINCINNATI, June 30--With more dirt in the stands than on the field, the Cincinnati Reds opened their new but unfinished $45-million Riverfront Stadium tonight.
LUXEMBOURG, June 30 A process that could alter the structure of Europe began today as Britain, Ireland, Denmark and Norway opened negotiations to join the European Economic Community.
Fires broke out shortly after 7 o'clock last evening in three F.W. Woolworth stores in Manhattan. No one was reported injured.
LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) Two Republican members of the John Birch Society were elected tonight to fill unexpired terms in Southern California Congressional districts.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters) The United States Treasury said today that it received from the West German central bank a deposit of $32million in mixed claims awards and a mutual security loan repayment of $ll.7-million

WESTON, Conn., June 30 Mrs. Elizabeth Morris Marjoribanks, widow of the Rev. George Marjoribanks, was married here this afternoon to John Clement Bair. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed by the Rev. Albert Campbell at the home of the bride's twin, DuBois S. Morris Jr.

Mark Harner, an unseeded player from Clifton, N.J., was on his way to a possible upset of top-seeded John Peckskamp of Cincinnati when rain halted their match at the start of competition yesterday in the 18-years-and-under section of the North Atlantic junior tennis championships at Columbia's Baker Field courts.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The House voted today to authorize $3.1-billion over the next three years to help state and local policemen fight crime. Cities with high crime rates would get first priority.

A university official testified here yesterday that House Speaker John W. McCormack had personally asked him to admit the son of a convicted labor racketeer during a conversation in which a Federal official held out the possibility of increasing the university's Federal research contract.

For all five trading days last week and Monday and yesterday of this week issues on the American Stock Exchange have been caught in a broad decline. Yesterday, however, most prices tended to be lower by only fractions of a point. The index closed at 20.06, down 0.07.

NEW HAVEN, June 30 The defense asked today to have Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, brought here from prison in California to testify in behalf of Lonnie McLucas, a Panther on trial in connection with the kidnapping and murder of a fellow party member.
A Department of Justice request to enjoin the Greyhound Corporation from exercising control over Armour Co., the meat-packing company, was denied yesterday by a Federal judge in Chicago.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 30 Forty American trucks were driven today from South Vietnam to Cambodia the most publicized gift of United States aid to Cambodia so far. The trucks carried about 1,000 Vietnamese soldiers of Cambodian descent as well as supplies.
WASHINGTON, June 30--The Senate, moving to reassert the war-making powers of Congress, today adopted the long-debated Cooper-Church amendment to limit Presidential action in Cambodia.

GENEVA, June 30 (Reuters) The United States today formally proposed the inclusion of toxins in a British draft convention to outlaw biological weapons now before the 25-nation Geneva disarmament conference.

BELFAST; Northern Ireland, June 30 The British Home Secretary, Reginald Maudling, began a two-day visit here today and, giving little comfort to Northern Ireland's restive Roman Catholic minority, stressed that his first concern was the restoration of law and order.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 30 Eight years after Carmine Abbatiello and Rex Pick, a pacer, team up, Abbatiello is still going strong. Rex Pick is, well, just going.

DETROIT, June 30 The New York Yankees flew here today to open a three-game series against the Detroit Tigers, but their eyes were fixed firmly on the main event the return of Denny McLain to the major leagues tomorrow night.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Following is the text, as amended, of the amendment to the foreign military sales bill offered by Senators Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, and John Sherman Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, adopted today by the Senate:
LONDON, June 30 "Les Poseuses," a small painting by Georges Seurat, founder of the French neoimpressionist school, was auctioned today at Christie's for $1,033,200.

Like most of the 60,000 teachers in the city school system, Stephen Ware, a 27-year-old fourth-grade instructor at public School 41 in Greenwich Village, cleaned out and straightened up his classroom yesterday.
DALLAS, June 30 (UPI)--The Texas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association got Gene Moore, a 6-foot-9-inch center, from the Kentucky Colonels today, but the price proved high.

God is black He really is! That, I suppose, is the thinking, or at least the nub of the thinking, in Bruce Jay Friedman's new comedy, "Steambath," which opened last night at the Truck and Warehouse Theater.

DETROIT, June 30 The president of the American Library Association called today for "more vigorous responses" to what he characterized as a growing threat to intellectual freedom stemming from "hysterical charges and counter charges."
The International Business Machines Corporation introduced yesterday a new family of computers the IBM System/370, but insisted that it was not a fourth generation.
GLEN COVE, L.I., June 30 Nicholas R. Jones, a former New York lawyer, died at the Montclair Nursing Home here tonight. He was 90 years old and lived in Glen Cove.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 (UPI) Two former participants in the America's Cup races joined three American yachts and a French 12Meter off Newport today as the contenders prepared for trials to pick a defender and challenger for the coveted trophy.

MOSCOW, June 30 President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union tonight joined in advocating a peaceful settlement of tensions in the Middle East.
Silver futures prices rose yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange despite a drop in the prices at the Government's auction in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters)--The Organization of American States today formally condemned terrorism, political kidnapping and extortion as crimes against humanity and the principles of international relations.
Edward K. Hamilton, who has held key economic posts with the Federal Government, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to succeed Frederick O'R. Hayes as head of the Budget Bureau.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Selective Service System will hold its second draft lottery tomorrow amid indications that the random selection process is finally functioning smothly.

HANCOCK, Mass., June 30 One of the most exquisite and least familiar forms of 19-century American religious art the so-called "Spirit" drawings of the Shakers is currently the subject of an unusual exhibition in the handsomely restored Brick Dwelling of the Hancock Shaker Village. The exhibition marks the 10th anniversary of the establishment of the Hancock Shaker Village as a public historical museum.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 30 Jonathan G. Ford of the Riverside (Conn.)) Yacht Club won both races by comfortable margins today and took a 2-point lead for the 19th annual Long Island Sound men's sailing championship and the Commodore Hipkins Trophy. The one race remaining in the round-robin series will be sailed tomorrow.

Theodore W. Kheel, mediator in the continuing newspaper dispute, met yesterday with negotiators for Mailers Union No. 6 and representatives of The New York Times, The Daily News, The New York Post and The Long Island Press in a new effort to resolve their protracted dispute.
Isaac Liberman has resigned as chairman of Arnold Constable, Inc., the Fifth Avenuebased retail chain announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Following is the 76-19 vote by which the Senate overrode today President Nixon's veto of hospital construction legislation:

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 30 George M. Perkins, director of network radio programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., died yesterday at United Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 128 Betsy Brown Road.
Perhaps the gloom over rising wage costs and sliding profits has been overdone. That's the line the Argus Research Corporation is taking in its Weekly Staff Report, just out.
DEAL, N.J., June 30 Once again the Philadelphia junior girls intercity team proved too strong for either New York or Boston, as it won the Mrs. Frank Enos Trophy for the fourth straight year today.
Faulkner, Dawkins Sullivan, one of Wall Street's topranked institutional brokerage houses, will initiate a major cost-cutting program today in response to sluggish conditions in the stock market.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 30 A victory here for women's rights was viewed today as a threat to the Lutheran unity movement.

WASHINGTON June 30 The Nixon Administration has proposed for the Supreme Court's consideration a school desegregation plan for Charlotte, N.C., that would prescribe a Northern-style "de facto" pattern for the Southern city.

The next couple of weekends should be among the season's best in motor racing, with major events scheduled by all the principal sanctioning organizations. Michigan International Speedway will run an unusual Twin 200's double-header Saturday for United States Auto Club cars.

The Philadelphia Eagles are expected today to sign John Carlos, the sprinter, to a contract and thus begin the conversion of a great athlete from one sport to another. Carlos, winner of two Olympic medals and a world record-holder, will not have much time since the contract

MADRID, June 30 The Spanish Cortes, or Parliament, met in secret session today for the first time in its history to hear a report that criticized one member of the Cabinet and two former members in a huge financial scandal.

The Seafarers International Union and eight of its officers and employes were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of conspiring to contribute $750,000 to Republican and Democratic political campaigns in 1968.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y., June 30--The state's decision to acquire the Lake Awosting portion of the Minnewaska resort area and the Shawangunk Mountain escarpment for park purposes was hailed today as "one of New York State's finest conservationist victories."

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Senate voted 76 to 19 today to override President Nixon's veto of the three-year, $2.79-billion authorization bill extending the Hill-Burton program of construction and modernization of medical facilities.

The nations' most liberal abortion law goes into effect in New York State today amid controversy and confusion over how many women will seek abortions, how an abortion can be obtained, how much it will cost and whether the hospitals will be able and willing to meet the demand.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, July 1 A weary Senate voted early today to revamp the nation's postal system and give postal workers an 8 per cent pay rise, retroactive to April 16.
LONDON, June 30 He moves and speaks gently. Slight, balding and immaculately tailored, Anthony Barber is the archetype civil servant and Conservative party official.

Public accounting is a curious profession. Above all else, an accountant wants his imprimatur to be taken as a mark of credibility an assurance to creditors, investors and the general public that a company's affairs have been fairly and properly reported in accordance with "generally accepted accounting principles."
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today a sharp cut in the world coffee crop for the 1970-71 season.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) An increase in the prices of two types of extra reinforcing steel was announced today by Jones McKnight Steel, Inc.

The Mill Factors Corporation, an insolvent finance company that was once considered a "Tiffany" of its industry, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell substantially all of its assets to James Talcott, Inc., and then liquidate.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The main point of President Nixon's final report on the Cambodian operation today was that he has proved himself a man of his word who ought now to be trusted by his people at home and taken seriously by his adversaries abroad.

LA JOLLA, Calif., June 30 Miss Rowena McGill, daughter of Dr. William James McGill, chancellor of the University of California at San Diego, who will assume the presidency of Columbia University, was married here on Saturday to Thomas B. Springer.

WASHINGTON, June 30 Following is the text of a telegram from Leonard Garment, special consultant to President Nixon, to Bishop Stephen G. Spottswood, chairman of the Board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, replying to a speech by Bishop Spottswood last night that was critical of the Administration's racial policies:

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Extensive changes costing $10-million to $15-million will be made to Apollo spacecraft before men can be sent to the moon again, the National Aeronotics and Space Administration said today.

CAIRO, June 30 The United Arab Republic reported today that its antiaircraft forces along the Suez Canal had shot down four Isaeli fighter-bombers, including two, supersonic Phantoms, and that three Israeli pilots had been captured.

The placid trees around Central Park's Sheep Meadow and the brilliantly lit skyscrapers in the background scarcely suggested the wilds of Scotland, but last night Donizetti's music was soaring through the area to tell an audience of many thousands that Lucy of Lammermoor was going mad because her love for Edgar of Ravenswood had been thwarted.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Creation of a commission to study and recommend the first major overhauling of the nation's bankruptcy laws in 32 years was approved today by the House.

FALLSBURGH, N.Y., June 30 The head of the largest Jewish Orthodox rabbinic body in the Western Hemisphere called upon Jewish welfare funds and federations today to establish 10 Jewish colleges in major cities to arrest the decline of Jewish cultural and spiritual life.

MINEOLA, L.I., June 30 Joseph Colombo, the reputed Mafia leader who helped organize yesterday's protest in New York against linking Italians with criminality, was arrested today on a charge of refusing to answer questions about organized crime.
NEW LONDON, Conn., June 30 Rear Adm. John S. Thompson became superintendent of the United States Coast Guard Academy in a formal ceremony today.
ATTARD, Malta, June 30 Experts attending a conference here on problems of the sea have been calling fervently for international controls on radioactive wastes.
HONG KONG, June 30 The withdrawal of United States troops from Cambodia prompted no immediate plaudits from the Communist countries in Asia.

A hearing examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission has ruled that 12 investment company management concerns violated the antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws bg selling shares in the Douglas Aircraft Company after being tipped off by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc.

STOCKHOLM, June 30 The United States representatives fought their way back into contention in the fourth session of the world pair championship here tonight after starting slowly in the earlier sessions.
In baseball, the best relief pitchers are those who "throw strikes," as the managers like to say.
The Glass Container Manufacturers Institute announced a nationwide program yesterday to buy used bottles, at a penny a pound, and re-use them in the manufacture of new ones.
The city's private nonprofit hospitals made two new pay offers to their 25,000 nonprofessional employes yesterday, but the union representing the workers rejected both offers as inadequate.
SANTIAGO, Chile, June 30 (AP) Northern Chile is under a state of emergency as a result of student riots that spread throughout the country from Santiago, the capital.

Loew's Theatres, Inc., which will become Loew's Corporation at the fiscal year-end, achieved record operating earnings for the three and nine months ended May 31 before taking into account its losses from securities transactions.

RICHMOND, June 30 (AP) Reynolds International, Inc., a subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company of Richmond and Vereinigte AluminiumWerke of Bonn, West Germany, announced today plans for construction of a jointly owned alumina plant near Stade, West Germany.

BADEN, Austria, June 30 Asian and African housewives, angered over maggots in chocolates, filthy milk containers and rotted meat, are stepping up pressure against fraudulent practices and uniting in militant consumer groups, an international meeting of consumer-affairs specialists here was told today.

MONTREAL, June 30 The International Civil Aviation Organization urgently called on all countries today to unite behind a strong security program to protect planes and passengers from hijackers, saboteurs and armed attackers.

Kenneth Robinson found being an honor student rather lonely. He says he felt alienated from people his own age until he met Stanley Crump, who is mentally retarded. Stanley, the son of Kenneth's family pediatrician, proved loyal, free of prejudice and not ashamed of expressing his feelings in a hug.
Prices closed higher on the London Stock Exchange yesterday after a quiet start.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The head of the United Mine Workers has appealed to President Nixon to enforce the mine safety laws and end what he called "deliberate footdragging" by the Interior Department and its Bureau of Mines.

NEWARK, June 30 Kenneth A. Gibson, who will be sworn in as Newark's first black Mayor tomorrow, named a white policeman today to the post of Police Director, one of the most sensitive positions in this city, where racial tensions were heightened by the bitter mayoral race.
MANILA, June 30 (UPI) A move was under way today to establish an Asian currency to spur inter-regional trade and reduce dependence on the United States dollar and other currencies.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today adopted the Cooper-Church amendment to restrict future United States military operations in Cambodia:
The exacta, in only its second day as part of the betting program of the New York Racing Association, registered a big-number return yesterday in one of the feature races at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, June 30 H LeVan Richards, a prominent tennis official for many years until his retirement in 1965 died today in George Washington Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived in Falls Church, Va.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., June 30 Richard A. Wright, vice president and account executive at Carl Byoir Associates, a public relations firm, died at a hospital today after suffering a heart attack while visiting friends here. He was 57 years old and lived at 52-40 39th Drive, Woodside, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The new schedule of sales commissions that the New York Stock Exchange formally proposed today to the Government would add $520-million annually to the gross revenues of brokers, according to the exchange's estimates.
A note of discontent was injected yesterday into the nontitle 10-round bout between Emile Griffith of New York and Dick Tiger of Nigeria, scheduled for Madison Square Garden on July 15.

TRENTON, June 30 The key witness in the extortion trial here of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and five other defendants testified today that a man he referred to only as "Mr. Hagan" had made arrangements for him to visit the campaign headquarters of Abraham D. Beame in the 1965 New York mayoral campaign.

The most important result of the American "incursion" into Cambodia which ended yesterday is not the dubious military achievement claimed by the President in his lengthy report from San Clemente but the political reaction on Capitol Hill as reflected in Senate passage of the Cooper-Church amendment.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., June 30 Benjamin Ludlow Jr., orchestra leader, composer and choral director, known as Ben Ludlow, and Mrs. Martha Lohrke von Glahn of Oyster Bay were married here this evening in St. John's Episcopal Church.

DETROIT, June 30 While everybody was talking about Denny McLain tonight, the Detroit Tigers hit three home runs in one inning, made five double plays and ground out a 5-3 victory over the New York Yankees.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30 President Nixon today announced the "successful" completion of the American incur- sion in Cambodia, ruled out the use of American troops there in the future and suggested that the country's defense would be left largely to the Cambodians and their Asian allies.

Miss Judith Nancy Heineman, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Florentine of the Bronx and Miami and the late Bertram Heineman, was married last night to Joseph Shuldiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Shuldiner of Crompond, N.Y. Rabbi Edward Heisler performed the ceremony at the International Hotel of Jamaica, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters) Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, today opposed extending United States participation in the International Coffee Agreement, charging that Brazil had violated it.

With the premiere of its production of Jose Limon's 1954 work, "The Traitor," last night at the State Theater, American Ballet Theater took another step in carrying forward its renewed policy of including moderndance pieces in the repertory.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Association of American Railroads said today that the Federal Government must come up with more than $1-billion a year in new railway subsidies or face "an ever increasing number of bankruptcies." The association cited the Penn Central's recent filing for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws.

There is no sign, just a symbol and a bell at the side of the entrance to the loft building at 36 West 22d Street. The motif the palm of a hand with four fingers raised within a circle and cross peace symbol is the mark of the women's liberation movement, whose communications center is housed on the second floor.
TOKYO, June 30 (UPI)--Japan's over-all balance of payments for May registered a deficit of $78-million, the Finance Ministry said today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The Newspaper Preservation Act won formal clearance today for early House action, and its sponsors forecast House approval. A similar bill has been passed by the Senate.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The House, heading toward another big desegregation fight with the Senate, voted today to stand by its proposed ban on forced school busing and its attempt to legalize court-rejected freedomof-choice school integration plans.

MOSCOW If the position of Soviet Jews is not so bad as the West imagines, it is surely not so good as the regime pretends. Were the Government suddenly to grant them permission to leave, the great majority would probably remain; but it is not a happy community.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan has asked the state's highest court for an emergency order to halt what he called the "chaotic" and "uncertain" situation created in the New York City Criminal Court by a United States Supreme Court ruling on jury trials.

Two and a half years ago, teachers spoke of Interme diate School 201 in East Harlem as "a jungle." An air of bedlam prevailed at the modern, windowiess school, and teachers brandished yardsticks to discipline children who got out of control in the classrooms and corridors.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 30 Two city policemen were shot early this morning in the predominantly Negro West End after responding to a small fire in a store. City officials contended that the fire had been "staged deliberately" to lure the police into the sniping.

Mayor Lindsay's Subway Service Watchdog Commission said that "bad engineering and poor maintenance" were responsible for the collision May 20 between two subway trains in Queens. Two persons died and about 70 were injured in the collision.

LIMA, Peru, June 30 Mrs. Richard M. Nixon's goodwill trip to earthquakestricken Peru ended today. Before boarding the Presidential jet she spent her final hours in Lima at a hospital visiting children who had evacuated from the main earthquake zone.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 Ken Rosewall beat Tony Roche in four enthralling sets today, John Newcombe came out of the abyss to lick Roy Emerson in five and, if anything is sure in tennis, Rosewall will face Roger Taylor and Newcombe will meet Andres Gimeno in the Wimbledon tennis semifinals on Thursday.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Jean Martin to the Rev. Robert H. Buche, pastor of Trinity Presbyterian Church here, took place in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church yesterday. The Rev. Robert C. Martin Jr., cousin of the bride, performed the Presbyterian ceremony.
ATHENS, June 30 Lieut Gen. Demetrios Patilis, retired Second Deputy Premier of Greece, died in an Athens military hospital today of a cerebral hemorrahage. He was 57 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Penn Central Transportation Company closed its books last night with approximately $35-million in its depository banks and expects no problem with its payrolls of $20million a week "for the foreseeable future." This reassurance was given Congress today by the company's executive vice president for finance, Jonathan O'Herron.

GOSHEN, N.Y., June 30 Billy Haughton drove A.C.'s Orion to victory in the E.H. Harriman Challenge Cup No. 45 and Stanley Dancer guided Keystone Memento to the top prize in the Debutante Stake No. 24. But the real hero of today's Grand Circuit harness racing matinee at the 133-year-old Historic Track was a 55-year-old man who never even had been on a sulky.
An embargo on all deliveries by truck within the city was threatened yesterday unless Mayor Lindsay and the Police Department took steps to give drivers more protection against assault and robbery.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 30 (UPI) President Nixon announced today that he had reluctantly permitted the extension of a $120-million school milk program he had criticized as outmoded and of little help to the poor.
Shrugging off protests by the brewing, laundry and dairy industries, the Board of Estimate yesterday voted an across-theboard increase of 75 per cent in water rates.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (UPI) A three-judge Federal panel reversed today a decision given in Pittsburgh last Thursday that ordered thousands of striking coal miners in western Pennsylvania back to work.

The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, threatened with dissolution by a financial deficit last April, has named Douglas Blair Turnbaugh chairman of the Dance Theater Foundation, Inc., a nonprofit tax-exempt corporation that will seek sustaining funds for the interracial modern-dance troupe.

The quality of mercy is not strained. It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven upon the undeserving noggin of Denny McLain. The suspension of the great Detroit Tiger pitcher will come to a kindly end tonight and he will return from exile to pitch against the New York Yankees before a sellout crowd in Tiger Stadium and millions of curious televiewers.

Mrs. Virginia Beck Smith, the wife of Dr. Vincent E. Smith, a philosophy professor at Sarah Lawrence College, died Monday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens. She had suffered a fractured skull in a fall at her home, 179-05 Croydon Road, Jamaica Estates, earlier in the day.

GLENCOE, Ill., June 30 Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Bernstein have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheilah Bernstein, to Dr. Elliott George Gross, a neurologist. He is the son of Mrs. Max Gross of Long Beach, L.I., and the late Mr. Gross.

Corporations are continuing to flock to the bond market to borrow money and so far the rush has not stopped the decline in interest rates that began two weeks ago. Yields kept moving downward yesterday.

GENEVA, June 30 The United States was victorious today in its campaign to have a United Nations agency speed its decision on whether to advance $10-million toward construction of the proposed $80-million extension to the United Nations headquarters in New York.

There is a feeling among some black performers, and they've reported it to the City Commission on Human Rights, that there's been a slackening in the effort to use minority group people in commercials. The commission, according to a spokesman, is looking into the matter, but so far has come up with no substantiation.
The stock market closed out its June quarter yesterday with mixed readings in the popular indicators and pronounced weakness in I.B.M., Wall Street's most famous growth stock.

JACKSON, Miss., June 30 The Federal Government officially ended today negotiations over desegregation with school districts in the South, 16 years and 1 month after the Supreme Court ruled that racial discrimination in the classroom was unconstitutional.
The city has vastly expanded its use of private consulting contracts, which are awarded without competitive bidding and are usually unknown to the public.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 30 The 29-member executive council of the State A.F.L.C.I.O. recommended by a 2-to-1 margin today that the organization's state convention, meeting Sept. 2 to 4, endorse Governor Rockefeller for re-election.
Jonathan Kaplan has a can of film and a good deal of hope. B. William Kostecke has a can of beer and a good deal of money. August Heckscher had "a vague dream" and a good deal of park space.

Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey said yesterday that he was willing to consider increasing auto tolls on Hudson River crossings if a satisfactory plan was devised to use the added revenues for mass-transit projects.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Mrs. Felicia Warburg Sarnoff, former wife of Robert W. Sarnoff, board chairman and president of the RCA Corporation, will be married here this morning. Only members of the families will attend the ceremony.

On a typically busy Friday recently, 9,451 passengers passed through the customs gates at Kennedy International Airport, where a stepped-up baggage inspection system designed to stem the flow of narcotics has been in effect since early June.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that Fifth Avenue would be closed to all but crosstown traffic from 42d to 57th Street for four successive Saturdays beginning July 11.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, told the Senate tonight that an organization calling itself the National Socialist White People's party the former American Nazi party was urging the assassination of several dovish members of the Senate.
Miss Jane Gottlieb and Jordan R. Lefko will be married in August.
The Washington Senators are not going to go anywhere in the American League Eastern Division, but they are certainly raising hob with the so-called contenders.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 30 (AP) The National Assembly gave an informal vote of confidence today to the Premier Prince Souvanna Phouma. The vote followed reports of increasing rightist pressure because of recent North Vietnamese advances in southern Laos.

TORONTO, June 30 The new management of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., told shareholders today that the worst of the company's troubles were behind it and that it is now looking for new partners who can infuse capital and managerial talent.
BAYONNE, N.J., June 30 There will be no moratorium on the drafting of men from this city into the armed forces.

The election of Herman Badillo for the Democratic nomination in the new 21st (Triborough) Congressional District was challenged in Supreme Court yesterday by Peter F. Vallone, Mr. Badillo's closet rival in the June 23 primary.

METROPOLITAN NEW YORK ITS GEOLOGIG SETTING at 2 P.M. tomorrow and "Animals of Northeastern United States" at 2 P.M. Tuesday at the American Museum of Natural History. For children 8 years and older and adults. Free. 873-1300.
Federal Judge Walter R. Mansfield granted permission yesterday to McSorley's Old Ale House to continue denying entry to women, as it has for more than a century.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Nixon Administration, stung by an accusation that it was anti-Negro, responded sharply today, labeling the charge as unfair and disheartening.
WASHINGTON, June 30 The Czechoslovak Embassy's scientific affairs officer has defected to the United States, reportedly upon receiving orders to return home after 18 months in Washington.
LONDON, June 30 Representatives of Japan, Norway and the Soviet Union, the three main whaling countries, have agreed here to maintain the present catch limit of 2,700 whale units for the Antarctic.

WASHINGTON, June 30 The Nixon Administration announced a modest increase today in the level of permitted meat imports in the year 1970 as a whole, but with some rollback in the second half from first-half levels.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 Another dispute over public spending to help parochial schools loomed today as the million-member National Education Association opened its 108th annual convention.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 30 (AP)--The Audley Farm Stable's Charles Elliott, a $15,000 claim two races ago, scored a six-length victory in the $12,000 Homestead Country Club Allowance Purse at Monmouth Park today.
James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, strongly urged President Nixon yesterday to announce that no draftee would have to fight in Vietnam after April 1.

BERLIN, Md.--His name is Charlie Brown. He has mischievous little eyes, chatters a blue streak and is an expert pickpocket. He wears a honey-brown coat of the world's rarest mink and, because he is so appealing and mildmannered for his breed, he has been allowed to keep it. Charlie is a 3-year-old Kojah mink.

ROME, June 30 The Roman Curia, the administrative arm of the Vatican that has been controlled by Italians for centuries, has become a genuinely multinational body as part of the updating of the Roman Catholic Church initiated by Pope John XXIII.

Alexander's Inc., one of New York's largest retail chains, announced yesterday that its plans for a new store at 96th Street and Broadway had been defeated by zoning problems and community opposition, and that it was dropping the project.

TORONTO, July 1 Bernard Cornfield charged today that the new management of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., had "deceitfully" caused him to lose his seat on the board of directors of the mutual fund and financial empire he founded.

BONN, July 1 Further opposition to Chancellor Willy Brandt's policy of rapprochement with Eastern Europe was stirred today after a newspaper published the last installment of what it termed as the secret text of a draft treaty with the Soviet Union.
Jack De Lon, a Broadway actor and singer, died Sunday in St. John's Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived at 35-13 76th Street in Queens.

The Air Lines Pilots Association, which threatened last year to stop flying into jet airports that the organization contended lacked adequate equipment for coping with crashes and fires, has reported that 23 of the 27 fields specified had already installed or ordered such equipment.
DETROIT, July 1 Denny McLain acknowledged tonight that he was "overwhelmed" by the standing ovations accorded him in Tiger Stadium.

DETROIT, July 1 Almost half of the nation's 92,000 elementary schools lack adequate library facilities because they cannot afford to hire trained personnel, the American library Association was told today.

A revision of the City Charter to give the Board of Estimate authority over the award of all of the city's management consultant contracts of $10,000 or more was urged separately yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame and City Council President Sanford D. Garelik.

The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that, effective Aug. 1, it would put into effect price increases ranging from one-fifth of a cent each for copies produced on the Xerox 2400 to an increase of $5 in the monthly-use charge for the models 914 and 720.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 1 John M. Knight, holder of a number of patents on automobile seats and railroad car equipment, died at a nursing home in Neptune yesterday. He was 90 years old and lived here at 1007 Fifth Avenue.

President Nixon will make a mistake if he interprets the Senate's narrow rejection of an arms embargo against Greece as a signal for full-scale resumption of military aid to the Athens junta. Some Senators probably voted against Senator Hartke's ban on arms sales only because they were unwilling to tie the President's hands on a security matter, not because they wanted to help entrench the Papadopoulos regime.

WASHINGTON, July 1 The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered formal proceedings today against Gregory Sons, a New York Stock Exchange member firm that is now in liquidation, and against two of the firm's officials.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Stepping from his fourthfloor office in the Pentagon yesterday, Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. greeted one of his superiors in the corridor with a cheerful "Hi, Boss." The senior officer returned the greeting and flashed an ironic grin. Today, as he as

ALBANY, July 1 (AP) The Court of Appeals held today that truth could not be used as absolute defense in libel and invasion of privacy cases that involved the Publication of material that courts had ordered to be secret.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 Cheryl Toussaint of the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn won the 440-yard event in the United States of America girls track and field championship at the University of California, Los Angeles, today. Running despite an inflamed tendon, Miss Toussaint led from gun to wire and won by 12 yards in 54.4 seconds.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 1 Sperry Butler, a partner in the law firm of Albertson, Simmons Butler, died today at New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived at 40 Lord Kitchener Road.

BONN, July 1 Fulfilling a two-week-old announcement, West Germany's central bank today raised minimum reserve requirements by 15 per cent, thus taking 3-billion marks (about $808-million) out of circulation.

BERGEN, West Germany, July 1 (AP) Three hundred Jews, former inmates of the Nazi Bergen-Belsen death camp, commemorated the 25th anniversary of their liberation today with a "procession of silence" beside mass graves of many of the camp's 50,000 victims.

Q. Mr. President, in your report on the Cambodian operation yesterday, you said you were going to emphasize the route of negotiated settlement again. A. Have you had any signal from Hanoi that they are more willing to talk than they have in the past and, B. Do you have any new proposals to put to them to make a negotiated settlement more attractive?

TRENTON, July 1 Paul W. Rigo, the prosecution's key witness in the extortion trial here of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, told defense lawyers today of the tangled state of his personal and corporate finances.

HONG KONG, July 1 (AP) North Vietnam charged today that the United States, despite the withdrawal of its ground troops from Cambodia, was prolonging the war in Southeast Asia by aiding anti-Communist forces.
BADEN, Austria, July 1 Shortly before dusk, Miss Mitsuko Tabuse walked along the Ringstrasse and stopped at one of the half a dozen wooden stalls selling fruits and vegetables.
A woman who witnessed a bank robbery in Queens yesterday followed the suspects in her car and told the police where they were hiding. Three suspects were arrested.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 1 The death this afternoon of one of two policemen who was shot by snipers shortly after midnight Monday while protecting firemen at a blaze produced new tensions in this racially polarized city of 45,000.
The motorist began subsidizing the straphanger in New York yesterday.

LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) Ray Patterson, the Swedish-based American boxer and younger brother of Floyd Patterson, the former world heavy weight champion, has has been knocked out of a fight with Danny McAlinden of Britain by an insect bite.

ALBANY, July 1 The State Conservation Department reported today that, on the basis of laboratory data received relative to mercury contamination of fish, it is advising fishermen not to eat fish taken from the St. Lawrence River.
Scores of abortions were performed in hospitals throughout the state yesterday on the day a new state law the nation's most liberal on abortions went into effect.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters) A Nicaraguan truce observer was killed today along the troubled border between Honduras and El Salvador, officials of the Organization of American States here said.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission accused the Coca-Cola Company today of tricking its customers in a Big Name Bingo promotional game last year.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 1 The Lutheran Church in America radically altered today its traditional concept of confirmation and first communion.
DALLAS, July 1 (Reuters) Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., has reduced its bank debt by more than $35-million, James J. Ling, president, said today.
The Lindsay administration agreed yesterday not to cancel the union dues checkoff of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association if the union held off any strike action until April 1, 1973.
Tenants of 400,000 apartments in the city that are not under rent control face increases of 6 to 12 per cent under an order issued yesterday by the Rent Guidelines Board.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 1--The British Home Secretary, Reginald Maudling, took a determinedly optimistic view of Northern Ireland's sectarian troubles today and called the tense situation "a mixture of danger and hope."
WASHINGTON, July 1 The General Accounting Office issued today a report to Congress that was sharply critical of the financial management of the Smithsonian Institution.
ST. LOUIS, July 1 Arthur B. Baer, former president and executive committee chairman of the Stix, Baer Fuller department stores, died today in a hospital, apparently of a stroke. He was 75 years old.

The city's new Parking Violations Bureau got off to a sputtering start yesterday with State Controller Arthur Levitt narrowly escaping a $25 summons and embarrassed city officials and meter maids having trouble finding cars to ticket.

WASHINGTON, July 1 Following are excerpts from a statement by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, counselor to the President, on the Administration's welfare program, delivered today before representatives of business at a briefing arranged by the Urban Coalition Action Council:

LONDON, July 1 (Reuters) Sir Laurence Dunne, who as London's Chief Magistrate refused to extradite Gerhard Eisler to the United States, died yesterday while on a fishing vacation at Stockbridge. He was 76 years old.
BONN, July 1 (Reuters) Informed sources said that the Finance Committee of the West German Cabinet agreed today on a budget for 1971 of 100.1 billion deutsche marks, or $25.2-billion.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 1 Vicki Lynn Miles, a Negro who was elected last month as governor of Oklahoma Girls State, has been passed over by officials of the American Legion Auxiliary in choosing delegates to Girls Nation.
St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Wendy King Norris to Cpl. Richard Hooker Wilmer 4th, who is serving with the Marine Corps at Quantico, Va.
PARIS, July 1 Drug addiction in France will be treated from now on as a medical rather than a penal matter, under legal changes voted by Parliament before its adjournment for the summer.

The State Public Service Commission approved a $104.9-million rate increase for the New York Telephone Company yesterday and at the same time said it would order the utility to make refunds to customers on an interim increase granted last February.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 It will be Mrs. Margaret Court against Mr. Billie Jean King for the women's title at Wimbledon on Friday, just as everybody knew all along.
PHIADELPHIA, July 1 Mike Manganello moved into a firstplace riding tie today with Marty Fromin by winning three races at Liberty Bell race track. Each has 19 victories.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) Justice Department lawyers celebrated their agency's 100th birthday today with a plea by a former employe of the department, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, to put fair administration of justice above winning cases.
WASHINGTON, July 1 A coalition of peace groups petitioned Congress today to act to end research on and production of chemical and biological weapons.

John McGuire, 47 years old, longtime city policeman, was charged with murder last night in the shooting of his estranged wife, Dolores, at her home in Valley Stream, the Nassau County police said.
