SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 2 (UPI) Democrats refused tonight to approve Gov. Ronald Reagan's $6.59-billion compromise budget and sent California into a third day without a program to spend tax money.
The F.W. Woolworth Company reported yesterday that consolidated sales in the 26 weeks ended June 27 rose 14.2 per cent, to a record $1,086,723,047 compared with $951,185,075 in the 1969 period.
CHATTANOOGA, July 2 "I'm astride The Southern Strategy," said Senator Albert Gore, "aid he's a real bucking bronco."
PARIS One way to be immortal in France is to wear the sword of the French Academy. The other way is to appear in a cartoon by the country's foremost political cartoonist, who signs his work TIM.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 2 Premier Lon No1 asserted today on his own behalf and on that of Deputy Premier Sisowath Sirik Matak that they jointly have full power to make all governmental decisions during the war emergency.
Helen Comstock, an author and authority on antiques and wife of Helmut Siber, the artist, died Wednesday at her home in South Peacham, Vt., after a long illness. She was 77 years old.

FORT BENNING, Ga. The Stars and Stripes, almost immobile in the still and heavy heat, shades many of the doorways; the houses, Mediterranean-style and nondescript assembly-line, glisten with care. When a newcomer arrives, women in shorts and minis, prim prints and pants, cross their generous and groomed lawns, under an awning of trees, with welcoming casseroles and cakes.
Paul O'Dwyer yesterday announced his endorsement of Arthur J. Goldberg and Richard L. Ottinger.
Straddling his chair in front of a television set, Robert Gellerman, age 11, watches critically as the close-up image of a hand his own approximates the art of violin vibrato.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission adopted today a new schedule of fees for its services. The new fees are designed to pay the commission's way in full for the first time. They include annual permit fees on both broadcasting and cable TV operations.
Glamour stocks, once the dramatic high-fliers of Wall Street, came down with a thud yesterday, while the rest of the market held to a fairly even keel. Numerous glamour issues sold at 1970 lows.
June 26, 1970 I have reviewed the mat ter of consultant contracts as you requested on receipt of the Controller's letter of June 5.
LONDON, July 2 (UPI) Princess Anne saw it first today: the ordeal of Earl Mountbatten of Burma.

DETROIT, July 2 For the third time in a month, Horace Clarke broke up a no-hitter in the ninth inning when he singled with one down off Joe Niekro tonight as the Detroit Tigers defeated the New York Yankees, 5-0.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 2 Bud Gilmour returned tonight to the Roosevelt Raceway paddock, where he had been banned for 3 years, and began shaking hands.
BILLINGS, Mont., July 2 The gun buffs, who are thick as jack rabbits in the Big Sky country, have undertaken to make things difficult for Senator Mike Mansfield as he runs for re-election this year.
STOCKHOLM, July 2 Two young Austrian players, Fritz Babsch and Peter Manhardt of Vienna, became clear favorites to win the 1970 world pair championship at the end of play here tonight.

Former Detective Michael Martin, who retired from the Police Department last month before the completion of his departmental trial on charges of stealing and selling confidential police information, appeared in Criminal Court yesterday to face prosecution for the same alleged offense.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 2 A few months ago Jackie D., a 6-year-old boy with big brown eyes, was so bad that his mother was at her wit's end.
New York City's municipal hospitals reported that they performed 49 abortions yesterday, the second day of operations under a new state law allowing terminations of pregnancy by choice.

After placing their full garbage cans in the street to protest erratic collections in the past and a proposed reduction of the official collection schedule in the future, residents of a Queens neighborhood had their garbage collected immediately last night.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange were very firm yesterday. Rank Organisation led industrial stocks into higher ground. Plessey recovered from recent dullness. I.C.I., Courtaulds, Beechams and Glaxo also advanced.
LONDON, July 2 Britain's new Government put tax cuts and labor-union reform at the head of its program today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Senate met for eight seconds today, the secondshortest session on record, and then adjourned for the July 4 holiday weekend.

TRENTON, July 2 The prosecution's key witness in the extortion conspiracy trial here of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and five other defendants testified today that Newark might have to spend extra "millions of dollars" on sewage treatment because inferior pipe was installed in 1965 as part of a kickback scheme.
Soybean futures prices advanced sharply in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but prices eased towards the close under profit taking.

ALBANY, July 2 Telephone service in New York City and its suburbs is getting better, but it will not improve substantially until late this year, according to the chairman of the Public Service Commission, Joseph C. Swidler.

DETROIT, July 2 A committee of the American Library Association has held that records of books withdrawn from libraries must be considered confidential and should not be yielded to investigative agencies without a court order.
WASHINGTON, July 2 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the latest week ended June 27 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., July 2 (AP) Donna Caponi, the defending champion, and Carol Mann took different routes to arrive at the same spot today two-under-par 69 and shared the first round lead as the United States Women's Open golf championship.

OSLO, Norway The Norwegian Government, feeling these days rather like the cat that's got the cream, is planning greater participation in exploring and exploiting an apparently enormous supply of offshore oil.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) A Federal district judge dismissed today a case in which a 33-year-old Air Force veteran contended his skin color had changed from black to white as a result of treatment at a Veterans Administration hospital here.
PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) Pennsylvania's Supreme Court says that it is legal under state law to desecrate the American flag "if the desecration takes place at a political demonstration."

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) The Boston Patriots and Harvard University announced today "substantial agreement" for the use of Harvard Stadium by the National Football League club for its seven home games in 1970.

Denny McLain always did have more brass than a trombone factory. If this quality led him into trouble, it also helped make him the great pitcher he still is. That was a rather remarkable exhibitionhe gave the night before last when he returned from exile for his first appearance of a season that is approaching the halfway mark.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 (AP) Earl D. Craig Jr., a Negro active in the New Democratic Coalition, announced today that he would challenge Hubert H. Humphrey for the Democratic nomination for the Senate in the Sept. 15 primary if he can raise $20,000 in campaign funds in the next two weeks.
The long decline of stock prices on the American Stock Exchange continued for the ninth session in a row yesterday. The index slumped to 19.95, down 0.09 from Wednesday's level.
CAMDEN, J.J., July 2 A 38-year-old man in jail awaiting trial on one homicide charge was charged today with six more murders in Camden between February and September, 1969.

Some of the dangerous consequences of American chemical proficiency engaged both the legislative and judicial branches of government this week with no better than a fifty-fifty outcome for the country.
MOSCOW, July 2 Diplomatic sources said today that Communist China had agreed to accept a new Soviet Ambassador in Peking.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Reviving a civil rights weapon that was largely abandoned nearly a year ago, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare threatened three segregated Southern school districts today with loss of Federal funds unless they dismantled dual systems for blacks and whites.

The Interstate Commerce Commission announced yesterday that it had instituted a full investigation into "all phases" of the operations, accounts and financial transactions of the Penn Central Transportation Company and its affiliates.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 The Lutheran Church in America spoke out today for fair treatment of homosexuals.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 2 Thai fighter-bombers launched their first air strikes in Cambodia yesterday, informed sources here said today.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 2 Mr. and Mrs. William F. Prigge of Westport, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Stefanie Prigge, to George Forest Kramer, son of Mrs. Rozanne E. Kramer of Santa Fe, N.M., and adopted son of Clarence J. Kramer of Washington, D.C.
Pleasant Valley demonstrated a definite liking for the turf yesterday, as she scampered to victory in the feature race at Aqueduct. The 3-year-old filly,

Commissioner of Investigation Robert K. Ruskin, citing a case where two policemen allegedly extorted money from a man with a woman in a parked car, called yesterday for the repeal or modification of state laws that he said sometimes "foster corruption."

WASHINGTON, July 2 President Nixon's televised interview on the Southeast Asian conflict won from Congress today praise for his designation of a new peace negotiator, some Democratic resentment in the Senate and a new Republican peace proposal in the House.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 2 The mood of the chalk players at Historic Track today matched the weather dark, dreary and threatening.

Charging that fraud and irregularity weer involved in his loss of the Democratic party's nomination for re-election last week, Representative Adam Clayton Powell on Thursday, filed suit to force the holding of a new primary election in the 18th Congressional District.
New York City has received a $532,000 grant to demonstrate how motor vehicles that give off relatively small amounts of pollution perform under urban driving conditions.
The great Independence Day rush from New York began last night with the usual jamups on highways and huge crowds at the city's bus, rail and air terminals.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 2 Even as President Nixon has talked to the nation about Indochina, he and his senior associates here have become increasingly preoccupied and alarmed by the volatile situation in the Middle East.

When 17-year old Theodore Rosenberg was arrested with three friends on a drug charge last month, his father, State Supreme Court Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg, called a fellow judge out of bed to go to the precinct and arraign the four.
PARIS, July 2 President Pompidou warned Israel today that time was working against her and issued a pressing appeal for a Middle East settlement through concerted action by the Big Four powers.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 At long last, Ken Rosewall is in another Wimbledon tennis final. Sixteen years after he first made it, the 35-year-old Australian snapped Roger Taylor's amazing upset streak today and will meet a countryman, John Newcombe, Saturday for the All-England singles championship.

A witness testified yesterday that Police Department detectives had requested a 10 per cent "reward" after the recovery of $100,000 worth of electronic equipment that had been stolen from a Montgomery Ward truck terminal here.
WASHINGTON, July 2 Communities should not collect stocks of restricted pesticides for disposal without Federal guidance, the National Conference on Pesticide Problems has warned.
The Treasury, wasting little time to borrow more money as the Government's new fiscal year got under way, sold $2.5billion of bills yesterday.
The Federal Aviation Administration has awarded a $36,000 contract to American Airlines to explore the feasibility of building a small floating STOLport in the Hudson River off Manhattan.
STOCKHOLM, July 2 (AP) Bo Jansson, 33 years old, of Sweden, and the Swedish team won the world military modern pentathlon championships today.
The Commonwealth United Corporation had an estimated net loss last year of about $61million, including extraordinary losses and losses from discontinued operations, it was reported last night.
Mailers stopped work at The Daily News last night to hold a shop meeting, delaying the printing and distribution of the first edition of the paper.

The Metropolitan Opera is not exactly a band of strolling players these summer weeks, but it does move from one place to another to entertain different communities, and there was a singular appropriateness about its presentation of "Pagliacci" in Brooklyn's Prospect Park on Wednesday night.

The warnings of "brownouts" ahead for the New York metropolitan area have given ample notice of the unsatisfactory margin of reserve electric power available for the summer months. Now the bad news that Consolidated Edison's nuclear power plant at Indian Point will be out of commission until September must further intensify public concern.
CINCINNATI, July 2 Directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People proposed today a comprehensive restructuring of higher education to attack the causes of campus unrest.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 2 (Reuters) The Rev. Ian Paisley, the Protestant Unionist extremist, was suspended from the Parliament today after heated exchanges with the Speaker.

CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., July 2 (UPI) Mario Andretti, former U.S.A.C. driving champion, escaped injury today when his turbo-charged Ford Hawk crashed and burned after the qualifying trials for Saturday's 200-mile race at the Michigan International Speedway.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has filed suit against airlines using Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports to require improvement of noise-abatement devices on jet aircraft.

A state mediator yesterday opened intensive bargaining sessions between the Transit Authority and a union representing subway supervisors in an effort to avert a threatened rule-book slowdown, chiefly over pay isues.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) A twin-engine air freight transport carrying at least two canisters of radioactive material crashed into a Potomac River lagoon today, killing its two-man crew.

In 1917 the Grand Duchess Olga, eldest daughter of the Czar, escaped from Russia. She went to Queen Marie of Rumania, where she found solace with a "blond Rudolph Valentino" who passed as a Byzantine Prince. They moved to Berlin, where the Grand Duchess won notoriety for the excesses of her salon.

Deep in Central Park, "The Wars of the Roses" are getting bloodier. Joseph Papp's besieged, beleaguered and all but bereft New York Shakespeare Festival is presenting at the Delacorte Theater Shakespeare's "Henry VI, Parts I, II III" combined ...
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 The war dogs, too, are out of Cambodia.

ATLANTA, July 2 A Federal judge ruled today that a soldier accused of atrocities at Songmy could not be tried by court-martial until a three-man civilian judicial panel had decided on the legality of the Vietnam war and the constitutionality of the Army's Uniform Code of Military Justice.

John Adikes, chairman of the board of the Jamaica Savings Bank, died yesterday in Jamaica Hospital in Queens after a brief illness. He was 75 years old, and lived at 84-36 Wareham Road, Jamaica Estates.

ALBANY, July 2 (AP) Damage at 18 of the State University of New York's 26 stateoperated colleges and centers totaled $518,500 in the 1869-70 academic year, according to a report released today. It put most of the blame on student radicals.
RICHMOND Ind., June 30 State Route 227 is a slender ribbon of blacktop meandering through the fields of soybeans, oats and knee-high corn north of this city of 44,000.
WASHINGTON, July 2 Consumer installment credit rose $415-million in May, the most since February but still well below the monthly average of recent years.

PARIS, July 2 The flow of dollars into Germany, a sign of both weakness of the dollar and strength of the mark, slowed to a trickle today, but an air of nervousness lingered over the exchange markets.

SAIGON, South Vietnam July 2 The first contingent of Cambodian troops to be trained in South Vietnam is being instructed at Lamson infantry training center near Nhatrang in central Vietnam South Vietnamese military sources said here today.
NEW DELHI Computers, the wonder machines from the West, in a quiet and unobtrusive way, appear to have ushered in an economic and social revolution in this tradition-bound and ancient country.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Station WXUR in suburban Philadelphia, which has been in legal difficulty for four years because of its ardently right-wing political broadcasts, lost its license today by a unanimous order of the Federal Communications Commission.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 (Reuters) Four hijackers overwhelmed by troops in an airport assault here yesterday were trying to force the release of 40 political prisoners, the Brazilian Government said today.
Organized landlords urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to veto the new rent control program approved by the City Council last Saturday.

ALBANY, July 2 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller today named Justice T. Paul Kane of Cobbleskill to preside over an extraordinary term of State Supreme Court for an investigation of a confrontation betweeen the police and 150 students and faculty members of Hobart and William Smith Colleges.
More than 2,000 children in The Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Town program will be leaving this week for free vacations at the homes of families in 12 Eastern Seaboard states.

FORT-LAMY, Chad, July 2 (Agence France Presse) France today began the phased withdrawal of some of her 3,500 troops from this north central African nation, which has been torn by guerrilla war for years.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said tonight that it would reopen bidding on a contested $50-million satellite project that was awarded this spring to the General Electric Company.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 The Phils reversed a disturbing home field trend against the New York Mets tonight and reduced New York's lead in the Eastern Division of the National League to microscopic dimensions by handing the Mets their first double-Header loss of the season.

During the last nine years, the West Side Orchestral Concerts Association has brought dozens of outdoor programs to Riverside Park. A shortage of funds trimmed this summer's schedule to two, but at least the weatherman cooperated and goodly crowds turned out at 103d Street, both for the opening concert on June 24 and the final one on Wednesday.

Princess Luciana Pignatelli, European fashion coordinator for Eve of Roma, and Burt Simm Avedon, president of the Boston-based cosmetics concern, were married on Wednesday in a civil ceremony in California, where the bridegroom's parents make their home.

NEW HAVEN, July 2 A middle-aged white man being considered to sit on the jury here for the first of a series of trials of Black Panthers was having difficulty the other afternoon with the precept that a Black Panther or any other person must be presumed innocent until proved guilty.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 2 (AP) Yale University, Pennsylvania's four without coxswain and a schoolboy crew from Absecon, N.J., kept United States hopes alive in the Royal Henley Regatta today after the Penn and Dartmouth College heavyweight eights lost to English opponents in the Grand Challenge Cup.

House Speaker John W. McCormack told a Federal judge and jury here yesterday that he had been unaware that persons he regarded as friends were misusing his office for the benefit of commercial clients.
ALBANY, July 2 (AP) Physicians who perform abortions on Medicaid patients will be paid fees ranging from $64 to $220, the State Health Department announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reuters) Firebombs were tossed at, four Latin-American embassies here early today, soon after the Organization of American States approved funds for a special study of terrorism.

DETROIT, July 2 New-car sales last month made their strongest showing of the year, with the four manufacturers today reporting dealer deliveries of 799,791 American-type cars against 798,057 sold last June.
KIEV, U.S.S.R., July 2 (AP) A 22-year-old Kiev student ran the 800 meters in 1 minute 45.5 seconds today, the best time for the distance this year.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) General Motors Corporation has agreed to pay $50,000 in lieu of civil penalty claims for manufacturing certain 1970 model Chevrolets and Buicks with backup lights that violate Federal safety standards, the Transportation Department said today.
Mayor Lindsay will submit the budget modification to the Board of Estimate for the purchase of the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater on July 23, instead of next Thursday.
Plans have been announced for the Broadway production of two musicals and one drama in the new season.
Closing quotations for stock issues not traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday:

CHICAGO, July 2 Poor, despised Chicago. How desperately it has struggled to escape its reputation, and how impossibly. From the Fort Dearborn massacre, through the St. Valentine's Day massacre, up to the present day, the name Chicago has conjured up bleeding images of violence that assure the city an immortality of the sort previously awarded Tombstone, Ariz., and Sodom.
A lone star rode the windy darkness above the Jones Beach Theater on Wednesday night and remained fixed over "The Sound of Music." No wonder. The sound and sight of the show were simply stunning.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2 The latest Soviet proposals on the Middle East accept the concept that Arab governments will have to curb guerrilla activity against Israel when a state of peace is attained, diplomatic sources said here today.

FALLSBURGH, N.Y., July 2 Five hundred Orthodox rabbis listened with mixed feelings as two graduate students both Orthodox chided them for their failure to provide answers to religious and social problems.

WASHINGTON, July 2 Sponsors of Honor America Day sought today to show that the July 4 celebration would be nonpolitical, neutral on the war and an occasion at which longhaired youths and "hard hat" patriots would feel welcome.
PARIS, July 2 President Pompidou criticized President Nixon today and declared that peace could not come to Indochina until the Americans made up their minds to get out.
PEKING, July 2 (Agence France-Presse) Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia was given a triumphal welcome today when he returned to Peking from a 17day official visit to North Korea.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 2 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the police could not expect politica demonstrations "to be conducted like prayer meetings."
Two spokesmen for the Black Panther party announced yesterday that their group would not take part in the United Nations World Youth Assembly opening next Thursday.
MILAN, Italy, July 2 (AP) Sandro Mazzinghi of Italy, former world junior middleweight boxing champion, knocked out Harold Richardson of Newark in the fifth round of a scheduled 10-rounder tonight.
An investigation into the conduct of a State Supreme Court Justice, Michael M. D'Auria of Nassau County, was ordered yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

LONDON One who has completed a lengthy trip through four republics and three autonomous subrepublics of the Soviet Union feels entitled to reword Lincoln Steffens: "I have seen the future and it works the hardest possible way."
Several Canadian producers have increased their prices for wood pulp as of July 1, it was announced yesterday. The action seemed to follow similar moves by United States
The city's summer antipoverty program starts Monday with more than $30-million available to serve 1.5 million disadvantaged children and adults.
The Milo Electronics Corporation, listed on the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that it plans to file a Chapter XI petition for arrangement under the Bankruptcy Act.

John Bateman, baseball's perennially overweight catcher, set two personal records last spring by being fined $800 for weighing too much and then sweating off 35 pounds to get down to Manager Gene Mauch's prescribed limit.

ALBANY, July 2 The State Court of Appeals ruled today that a recent United States Supreme Court decision guaranteeing the right to a jury trial to persons accused of crimes punishable by more than six months in prison does not apply to trials begun before the decision was handed down on June 22.
BADEN, Austria, July 2 International efforts to link the growing consumer movement with the fight against pollution met a harsh response today from African and Asian nations.
Four doctors, a former union official and two other persons were arrested here yesterday on charges of stealing thousands of dollars from an insurance company.

MOSCOW, July 2 Communist party leader Leonid I. Brezhnev told the party's Central Committee today that investments in the nations agriculture would be increased by 70 per cent in the 1971-75 five year plan.

When Tommy Stagg and the Majority, a smooth, tightly organized rock quartet, finishes a set at the Riverboat and the young dancers who have been shifting and pumping through mutual solo routines drift off the floor, Sy Oliver's nine-piece band takes the stand and an older group of dancers step out to do an older, close-contact form of dancing.

Supporters of international scientific cooperation have won another important victory. The decision in Washington and Moscow to permit American scientists to work at Serpukhov site of the world's largest nuclear accelerator and to have Soviet scientists do research at Batavia, Ill. where an even larger atom smasher is being built is a major step forward. The secrets of the atomic nucleus which these giant ...

GUATEMALA, July 2 Col. Carlos Arana Osorio, who was sworn in yesterday as President, was his country's military attache in Washington in 1966 when he read that 15 members of a Guatemalan Army had been killed in an ambush by leftwing guerrillas.
The Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America voted overwhelmingly yesterday to permit the substitution of English and other vernacular languages for Greek in its liturgies.

LONG BEACH, L. I., July 3 An increasing number of the hundreds of thousands of people who flock to beaches in the metropolitan area on weekends seeking sunshine and salt air are finding signs reading "Residents Only."
Five Negro clergymen in the metropolitan area will make a 10-day visit to Moscow next month as guests of the Russian Orthodox Church.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 The Lebanese press today criticized President Nixon's remarks Wednesday night in Al Anwar, a pro-Egyptian daily, described them as "the dynamite that has blown up the bridges that Secretary Rogers and his aides had spent months to build."
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 3 Grand Circuit time, a five-day week offered here annually to harness racing fans, was concluded this overcast, humid afternoon at the 133-year-old Historic Track.

A Russian doctor has been struck by the similarities between the bureaucracy-enmeshed Soviet physician and his American counterpart who spends much of his time filling out forms for research grants from private and public agencies.

The Chemical Bank announced yesterday the formal opening of an international bank in London that it has formed in partnership with three other major banking institutions Baring Brothers Co., Ltd., London, Credit Suisse, Zurich, and the Northern Trust Company, Chicago.

BARCELONA, Spain, Saturday, July 4 A chartered British airliner with 112 aboard, including 105 vacationers going to the Costa Brava resort area of Spain, was believed to have crashed in the sea off the coastal village of Mataro, 18 miles northeast of here, last night.
CAIRO, July 3 Egyptians reacted with indignation and apprehension today to a remark by President Nixon that the Arabs still aspired "to drive Israel into the sea."

CINCINNATI, July 3 Delegates to the N.A.A.C.P.'s 61st annual convention expressed today their "strongest possible opposition to the attempt by the United States Justice Department" to require Earl Caldwell, a reporter for The New York Times, to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Black Panther party in San Francisco.

BABYLON, L. I., July 3 A fleet of 202 yachts, the largest turnout in recent years, started today, in the annual Fourth of July weekend regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club. A southerly wind that veered to the east gave the skippers a fullsail breeze throughout the afternoon.
Three companies managed to make first public offerings of their stock this week in another period of desultory market activity.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (UPI) George D. Fischer, president of the National Education Association, warned today of "a conspiracy" against public education and urged teachers to form a political group to combat it.
ROME, July 3 Portugal recalled her Ambassador to the Vatican today in protest against an audience that Pope Paul VI granted to three leaders of liberation movements in Portugal's African territories.

GENEVA, July 3 A group of scientists, sociologists and theologians recommended today a wide discussion of questions arising from new birth-control methods in view of what it called the "worldwide need for population control."

When a baseball team finds itself locked in a losing streak, however modest, nothing seems to go right. That was the case last night when the New York Yankees lost to the Washington Senators, 4-3, before 14,795 fans.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 Chi Cheng lowered the world record for the 220-yard dash to 22.6 seconds today in the trial heats of the women's national A.A.U. championships at the University of California, Los Angeles. She was aided by a tailwind of 1.9 meters per second, onetenth under the allowable maximum.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) The Nixon Administration defended its health policies and budget today, calling reports of a low Federal health priority untrue.

Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, accused the Nixon Administration yesterday of a "too-little, too-late approach" to the problem of supplying summer jobs for the nation's youth.
STOCKHOLM, July 3 Two Italian pairs chased after an Austrian partnership in the world pair championship here tonight, with the American representatives virtually out of contention.

No abortions were performed yesterday in most city hospitals, elective surgery being postponed until Monday so that surgeons and other members of the hospitals' staffs could observe the Independence Day holiday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 (UPI) Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, United States military commander in Vietnam, underwent successful surgery in Japan today for the removal of his gall bladder. The surgery had been delayed until now so he could direct the recent United States operation in Cambodia.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 3 (AP) More than three months after hijacking a United States munitions ship to Cambodia, Clyde W. McKay Jr. and Alvin L. Glatkowski wish they were anywhere but in Cambodia.
GUATEMALA, July 3 (AP) The Fourth of July in Guatamala is Marimba Day.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 3 (AP) The United States is expected to be among the top three in the free-style competition and could be one of the surprise teams in the Greco Roman events of the world amateur wrestling championships that start tomorrow.
Norman Singer will remain as chief executive officer of City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Richard M. Clurman, center board chairman.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 3 Dr. Henry Guze, a psychoanalyst and adjunct professor of anthropology at Drew University, died Wednesday of cardiac arrest at Mountainside Hospital here. He was 51 years old.
The city, which faces thousands of lawsuits filed by disgruntled citizens each year, now has to contend with one brought by a member of its own Law Depertment.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 3 The treason trial of Prince Norodom Sihanouk opened here today without the defendant's presence or anyone to testify on his behalf.

Charlie's troubles in the New York Legislature began the day he went out and kissed a baby race horse. "Somebody should let these horses know we need them," the State Assemblyman declared. "They are everything the New York Racing Association says they are: noble, courageous, graceful, faster even than a cheetah."

WASHINGTON A guest at Hillandale during the recent Opera Ball studied the stuffed giraffe head and its 8-foot-long neck, which are mounted directly under the tail of the unfortunate creature on the wall in the sun room.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 3 (AP) Herbert Allen's Distinctive scored a final-stride victory by a nose over Tearing Around in the $27,775 Rumson Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 3 Miss Elisabeth Sterry Ellis, a descendant of Myles Standish, was married here this afternoon to Joseph Interlandi Pirri. The Rev. Aaron Manderbach performed the ceremony in St. Stephens Episcopal Church.

Policemen are much in evidence in the Times Square area on warm summer nights, but despite their welcome presence, a solitary stroller was accosted repeatedly during an hour-long walk one night recently.

LONDON, July 3 (UPI) Carlos-Maria Velazquez, Uruguayan Ambassador to the Soviet Union and former head of the Uruguay mission to the United Nations, collapsed and died of a heart attack today in a hotel here. He was 52 years old. An embassy spokesman said Dr. Velazquez, his wife and seven children were en route to Spain for a vacation.
ROME, July 3 As this country gets ready for a comfortable summer vacation, Italians are hearing authoritative warnings of economic recession and a tight-money crisis.

CAIRO, July 3 The United Arab Republic reported today that its antiaircraft troops had "hit" two more Israeli fighterbombers in the Suez Canal combat zone and along the western shore of the Gulf of Suez.
BONN, July 3 The Volkswagen Company announced today a clear break with tradition a new model car equipped with a front-wheel drive and water-cooled engine.
Daniel Patrick Moynihan, counselor to President Nixon, has suggested that Negro-white relations are "getting better."
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3 (UPI) President Nixon nominated Malcolm R. Lovell Jr. today for promotion to Assistant Secretary of Labor for Manpower.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) A San Diego psychiatrist made $176,000 on a military health insurance program in l968, a House subcommittee reported today, and the Pentagon did not look into the payments until questioned by Congress.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 3 President Nixon's chief adviser on domestic affairs said today that a major theme of Republican campaigns next fall would be what he called the refusal of the Democratic leadership in the House and Senate to help make government more responsive to the nation's needs.
DETROIT, July 3 There'll be fewer bangs in Fourth of July celebrations tomorrow, the makers of fireworks say.

The Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N. Y., which was sued in May by a 27-year-old mother of three because she was denied a sterilization operation, changed its rules this week and agreed to perform the operation.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The Council of State Chambers of Commerce said today that the 1971 Federal deficit could rise to $12.5-billion, nearly 10 times the Nixon Administration's estimate of $1.3-billion.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, July 3 (AP) Charles (Chuck) Kocsis, 57 years old, won the fifth international amateur senior golf championship today by 21 strokes over his nearest challenger in the field of nearly 200 from 16 countries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 (AP) Forty-six South Vietnamese civilians were killed today when a passenger river boat struck a floating mine south of the demilitarized zone. Local officials said it was the highest toll from such an incident in memory.

The New England Electric System reported yesterday consolidated net income of $14,435,018, equal to 98 cents a share for the five months ended May 31, compared with $13,571,274, or 92 cents a share, for the like 1969 period.

Miss Judith Ellen Adams and Daniel Andrew Anderson, graduates of the Northwestern School of Music were married here yesterday in a Judeo-Christian ceremony performed antiphonally at the Riverside Church by the Rev. Dr. Jesse Lyons of the church and Rabbi Samuel Halevi Baron of Forest Hills.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 3 Mr. and Mrs. Peter Callan Reynolds have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Callan Reynolds, to William Felton Barrett 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barrett Jr. of Great Barrington, Mass. A wedding next January is planned.

MOSCOW, July 3 The Central Committee of the Communist party approved a report today condemning mismanagement in Soviet agriculture, admitting food supplies were inadequate and promising increased production of grains, meat, vegetables and other foods.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 3 (UPI) A campaign to recall Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, ended today when his opponents' petition fell 4,500 signatures short.

A bomb that the police said could have caused "extensive damage" was found outside the apartment door of Supreme Court Justice Jawn A. Sandifer yesterday at 2255 Fifth Avenue. Justice Sandifer and his family were said to be vacationing in New Jersey at the time.

LONDON, July 3 The Rev. Ian Paisley, Ulster's militant Protestant leader, charged today in his maiden speech as a member of the House of Commons that "men and women are being slaughtered on the streets of Belfast" because British soldiers stationed there had failed to protect them.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 3 (Agence France-Presse) Laotian Government forces have reoccupied Phou Kate, a mountain that was seized by the North Vietnamese June 19, an official spokesman of the Laotian Defense Ministry announced today.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 3 (AP) Clyde (Skeeter) Wright, a 27-year-old left-hander who had a dismal 1-8 won-lost record last season, hurled the first American League no-hitter of the year tonight, pitching the California Angels to a 4-0 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

WASHINGTON, July 3 President Nixon received recommendations today that Philadelphia be the site of an international exposition during the nation's bicentennial in 1976 and that other major observances be held at Boston, Miami and Washington.

LEE, Mass., July 3 Pauline Koner's dance "The Farewell," conceived as a tribute to the late Doris Humphrey, with whom Miss Koner was associated, is one that does not lose the magic I always associate with the first time I saw it.

The Administration has announced its endorsement of a proposed Voyageurs National Park to preserve part of the famed forested lake region along Minnesota's northern border. This highly inspirational and historic route of the French-Canadian voyageurs of the Seventeenth and eighteenth centuries is one of the few remaining places in the country that really deserve addition to the national park system.
To the roar of fireworks on this Fourth of July, add one sweet sound of trumpet: it is Louis Armstrong's 70th birthday.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 (AP) A fast lightweight crew from Yale University and a pair of strong scullers from California advanced today to the last day of the Henley Royal Regatta. The Yale eight beat a crew of Irish policemen, Garda Sciochana of Dublin, a length and a third over the 1-mile550-yard River Thames course. The Elis will meet England's crack Leander crew in the semifinals of the Thames Cup tomorrow.

Paul Boutelle opened his campaign as the Socialist Workers party candidate for Congress in the 18th Congressional District, in Harlem, yesterday with a street rally at 125th Street and Seventh Avenue.

The Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien, president of Fordham Preparatory School in the Bronx, announced this week that the school had been granted its own charter and had been legally separated from Fordham University.

One of the first major dents in France's dominant commercial position in her former African possessions has been made with new tariff cuts by four Central African countries.

TOKYO, July 3 (AP) The Bank of Japan reported today that there were clear signs in June indicating a halt in the sustained climb of Japan's wholesale prices.

DENVER, July 4, (UPI) The Denver organizing committee for the 1976 Olympic Winter Games urges everyone to hold off on requests for tickets. Sales will not begin for at least two years, a spokesman says.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., July 4 Donna Caponi, bidding for her second straight United States women's open golf championship, took a four-stroke lead today as Carol Mann, who shared the lead after two rounds, faltered and no other serious challengers emerged.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4 Although Keystone Aaron and Carbine Hanover finished one, two in the first semifinal and Counsel Hill took the second tonight at Roosevelt, the Billy Haughton Stable will be represented by only two starters in next Friday night's $25,000 final of the late-closing series for 3-year-old pacers.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 4 (Canadian Press) The favored Soviet Union and highly-rated Rumania emerged undefeated today in the preliminary rounds of Greco-Roman competition at the world amateur wrestling championships.

Mayor Lindsay led New Yorkers yesterday in celebrating Honor America Day by calling for Americans to support the troops in Vietnam but challenging "the wisdom of the political policy which keeps them there."
RYE, N.Y., July 4 The Rev. Dr. Deane Edwards, president emeritus of the Hymn Society of America, died at his home here yesterday. He was 85 years old.

On the theory that a rich vocablulary is the prerequisite of a meaningful education and a better job, the Manpower Education Institute in cooperation with the State University of New York will start a television program series in color beginning tomorrow called "For the Love of Words."

LOS ANGELES, July 4 For the second successive day, the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn lowered its own world record in the one-mile relay today at the United States women's track and field championships at the University of California, Los Angeles.

NEWARK, July 4 Kenneth A. Gibson, Newark's new Mayor, will begin his first full week of work on Monday and among the reports he will have to review is an exhaustive study of the New Jersey tax structure proposing tax changes that could benefit this financially troubled city.

LONDON Imagine the United States Government two weeks after the 1968 election: The new Republican Administration has taken over, filling every Cabinet and sub-Cabinet office. President Nixon has delivered his first State of the Union address.

Miss Gwynedd Anne Gowen and Guy Felix were married yesterday in the tiny Church of St. Christophe and St. Jacques built in 1501 in Villiers-sur-Marne, France.

ALBANY, July 4 Mr. and Mrs. Newton Briggs Van Derzee Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clara Bates Van Derzee, to Gordon Lang Jr., son of Mr. Lang of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mrs. Harriet Kendig Lang.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.-The Hollywood studio in which Richard Nixon conducted his one-hour "conversation" with three television reporters last Wednesday night is regularly given over to a show called "Let's Make a Deal."

Purchasing agents, who are especially sensitive to inflationary trends, find that the rate at which prices of industrial commodities has been rising slowed noticeably in June, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management.

DETROIT, July 4 Citizens in Michigan may soon be the first to benefit from a nationwide drive by conservationists and legislators to guarantee the right of individuals to go to court against any public agency or private industry that they think is damaging the environment.
ROME, July 4 Henry Cabot Lodge, in his capacity as President Nixon's envoy to the Vatican, had his first audience with Pope Paul VI today.

DETROIT, July 4 Mrs. Lillian M. Bradshaw, the new president of the American Library Association, said last night that librarians must consider the relevance of their work to human problems in a changing society and become more responsive to the demands of the young.

AUGUSTA, Ga., July 4 Dr. Abraham W. Miller, an obstetrician and gynecologist, and Mrs. Miller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Barbara Miller, to Steven Perlmutter. His parents are Dr. Martin Perlmutter, an endocrinologist, and Mrs. Perlmutter of Brooklyn.
MONTREAL July 4 (UPI) Bob Bailey and Rusty Staub blasted two-run homers tonight as the Montreal Expos trounced the St. Louis Cardinals, 8-0, behind the six-hit pitching of Steve Renko.

WEST POINT, N.Y. EARLIER this year, Dr. Edward Teller visited the United States Military Academy at West Point to give a lecture in which he urged continuing research on new weapons systems. When his talk was over, Dr. Teller, the father of the H-bomb, invited questions from the audience.

HAMPTON, Va., July 4 Miss Nancy Sayer Holt, a candidate for a master's degree in classical archeology at the University of Pennsylvania, and Richard Hinman Stowell, who received an M.B.A. degree from the university's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce will be married here Sept. 12 in historic St. John's Episcopal Church.
DEAL, England, Sunday, July 5 (AP) A Greek ship and a German ship collided in the English Channel early today and 17 Greek sailors were reported missing.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, asked Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe today to include designs for lowering repair costs in the $7-million in contracts for development of an experimental safety vehicle.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 4 The engagement of Miss Elaine Solari to Conant Atwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Atwood 2d of Salt Lake City, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Solari. A fall wedding is planned.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 4 (AP) The Chicago White Sox scored two runs in the 12th inning today on a walk, a threebase throwing error and a sacrifice fly to beat the Twins, 5-3. The loss ended Minnesota's five-game winning streak.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 4 Two Californians, Tom McKibbon and John Van Blom, and Ridley College of Canada salvaged victories for North America today in final events as the Henley Royal Regatta was dominated for the second successive year by Europeans.

WHEN, on June 19 the House of Representatives approved a program to revamp the postal service established by Benjamin Franklin (who had been Britain's colonial postmaster before 1776), it set into motion a long-felt need for change in the processing of the mails.

ROME, July 4 A series of criminal cases in which defendants were held in prison on what later turned out to be flimsy grounds have shaken the Italians' trust in their judicial system during the last few weeks.

SANTA PAULA, Calif., July 4-Mr. and Mrs. George I. Wilde have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Delphine Wilde, a 1969 graduate of Stanford University, to Richard E. Anderson, a second-year student at the Stanford School of Medicine.
SAN FRANCISCO July 4 (AP) Bill Sudakis and Tom Haller batted in Los Angeles' first five runs today to pace the Dodgers to a 7-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 Tom Seaver survived a rocky first inning, then settled down to business and posted his 13th victory of the season tonight as the New York Mets protected their slim National League Eastern Division lead with a 7-2 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.
WASHINGTON, July 4 Dr. Thomas B. Symons, agriculturist and educator, died today at Prince George's General Hospital in Cheverly, Md. He was 89 years old and lived at College Park, Md.

If you heard that Needham, Harper Steers, which is not a public company, was issuing its first annual report and you assumed that was because they did particularly well, you would have assumed correctly.

ON ROUTE 5, Cambodia, July 3 The South Vietnamese soldiers crouched in the grass on the side of the road, aiming their rifles and a machine gun at the Cambodians clustered at a checkpoint only a few feet from them. For more than 10 minutes, the Vietnamese kept their guns trained on the other men.

MUSKOGEE, Okla., July 5 (AP) Donna Caponi's fourfoot putt on the final hole gave her a second straight United States women's open folf championship by one stroke over Sandra Spuzich and Sandra Haynie today.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 5 Enemy forces were reported today to have seized most of the district capital of Saang, 26 miles south of Pnompenh, but were said to have begun pulling out late today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 6 Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky said during the weekend that anti-Communists in South Vietnam would accept a coalition government with the Communists if it were the result of free elections.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 5 A tug-of-war here today between 300 men from two suburban towns designed to settle a 150-year-old argument dramatized by an undisputed fact of modern life; the Mohawk River needs cleaning up.
GENEVA, July 5 Trade between the member nations of the European Free Trade Association in April exceeded the monthly total of $1-billion for the first time.

A Federal specialist on new urban mass transportation systems has been appointed by the City Planning Commission to the newly created post of director of transportation and regional planning. He is 33year-old Dick G. Lam.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 5 Bailey Brown of Bronxville, the defending champion, and Bill Tully of Pelham reached the final of the annual Paul Martin Memorial tennis tournament at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club today.

PARIS, July 5 Winston F.C. Guest's Gyr won the $273,000 Grand Prix de Saint-Cloud in majestic style today. Gyr covered the 12 -furlong distance at the Val D'Or racetrack in 2:36.8, the fastest time here in 20 years.

BALBOA HEIGHTS, C. Z., July 5 Increasing coal shipments from Hampton Roads, Va., to Japan helped set new records in tolls, cargo tonnage and ship transits through the Panama Canal during the year ended June 30.
BALTIMORE, July 5 David Saperton, a concert pianist and teacher, died today at Johns Hopkins Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 344 West 72d Street in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 The Litchfield Rowing Association of Connecticut, coached by Bill Stowe of Columbia University, scored five victories today in the fifth annual Philadelphia youth championship regatta on the Schuylkill River.
Morton S. Bailey Jr., publisher of Better Homes Gardens, is a second generation space peddler, and loves it.

WASHINGTON, July 5 In his new book, "The Hidden Crisis in American Politics," published last week, Samuel Lubell argues that the key to President Nixon's Southern strategy that is, the key to persuading Southerners to vote for him and not for George C. Wallace ...
CAIRO, July 5 Cairo's military spokesman reported that two more Israeli Phantom fighter-bombers were shot down today over the central sector of the Suez Canal and that two crewmen were captured.
WALDEN, N. Y., July 5 A 5-year-old blue roan English cocker spaniel, Ch. Ancram's Simon, the top-winning representative of his breed last year, keeps right on the victorious trail.

TOKYO, July 5 (Reuters) Typhoon Olga, with winds up to 90 miles an hour, battered western Japan today. The high winds caused cancellation of night entertainment programs at the world exposition in Osaka.

LENOX, Mass., July 5 Brooding skies that threatened rain but did not deliver it did little to discourage attendance at the opening weekend of the annual music festival at Tanglewood in the Berkshire Hills. The paid admissions were 22,489, about 1,650 over last year's total.
DURBAN, South Africa, July 3 Athol Fugard does not agree with the theater world's boycott against South Africa. He believes that it has achieved nothing, except to keep out badly needed ideas.
WASHINGTON, July 5 The Federal Trade Commission has quietly taken the first step toward promulgating a regulation requiring the listing of tar and nicotine ratings in cigarette advertisements.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 Steel producers report sluggish summer demand but the promise of a busy winter.

That bunk trundle bed in bright red lacquer, which dramatizes a mirrored room on Bloomingdale's fifth floor, offers handsome sleeping accommodations for three one each in the upper and lower sections and one in the trundle that pulls out like a drawer at the base.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) Two more yachts crossed the finish line today in the Los Angeles-to-Tahiti sailing race.

The Waterfront Commission sharply criticized the shipping industry yesterday for "deplorably inadequate" efforts to prevent theft and pilferage from the $20-billion in general cargo handled annually on the piers of New York harbor.
A 24-year-old security guard was arrested yesterday and charged with setting a fire that blazed for five hours in crowded Times Square on Saturday night, injured three firemen, and snarled traffic.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 5 A fading westerly stranded 109 boats of the Yacht Racing Association's record fleet of 156 on Long Island Sound today. The 47 finishers represented three of the 12 classes that sailed under the Orienta Beach and Yacht Club.
BERLIN, July 5 (Reuters) The Berlin Film Festival was broken off today following a dispute over the jury's opposition to a film showing the rape and murder of a Vietnamese girl by American soldiers.

Leo Durocher gave away six inches and 37 years to Dock Ellis yesterday, but Durocher had his equalizer his lip. A fervent argument between the pair started a two-team free-for-all as Durocher's Cubs bowed at Chicago to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-2, and sank to fourth place in the National League's Eastern Division.
Everybody talks about inflation, but very few people know exactly what to do about it.
ROME, July 5 Pressure on Premier Mariano Rumor's Government increased over the weekend to a point where Italian politicians spoke of the possibility of a Cabinet crisis.
Drug abuse in the business world has increased to a "startling extent" and has become an "ominously growing problem," the New York Chamber of Commerce said in a report released yesterday.

TRIPOLI, Libya, July 5 (AP) The Libyan revolutionary Government nationalized all four oil-distributing companies in the country last night. But oil production, controlled by some 30 big foreign companies, was not affected.

At one time I am full of arcane but useless information Brandon Thomas's "Charley's Aunt" was running simultaneously in 48 theaters in 22 languages, including Esperanto, Chinese, Zulu and Afrikaans. On Saturday night it returned to New York, In English.

BRAINERD, Minn., July 5 A Trans American race ended here today with a swinging of fists, a great deal of pushing by participants and peacemakers and a formal protest by the runner-up, George Follmer of Arcadia, Calif.
The Ford Foundation announced grants of $2.2-million yesterday to combat environmental problems ranging from garbage disposal to noise abatement.

Mrs. Cora Mantel Segal, editor of American Fabrics, a textile publication, died Saturday night at Bay Shore (L.I.) Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street. Her husband, William C. Segal, is the publisher of the publication.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 5 Dr. Mario Schteingart, former president of B'nai B'rith in Argentina, died today at the University of Michigan Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Buenos Aires.

ATHENS, July 5 Nea Politeia, an Athens newspaper that often reflects the thinking of the military-backed Government, today sharply criticized a recent editorial in The New York Times on United States arms aid to Greece.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that Vice President Agnew inspired some people to radical actions, and he called Mr. Agnew "'an upstart man."

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) Senator William Proxmire asserted today that the Pentagon has spent more than $2-billion so far for a still secret electronic detection system that cannot tell the difference between enemy soldiers and innocent civilians.

A manufacturing company with difficulty integrating its labor force, a life insurance company anxious to sell to the Negro market and a book publisher with a desire to involve its younger employes in the operation of training programs have all turned to a new consulting concern in recent months for assistance in dealing with these situations.

Reform of the American mail service survived one more ordeal last week when the Senate passed its version of the Post Office reorganization bill. Two, possibly three, barriers remain to be hurdled before the country can hope to have a postal system efficient enough to get letters regularly from New York to Philadelphia overnight.
A 16-year-old boy was fatally injured Saturday night while setting off fireworks near his home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

Dennis Kocjan studies at the Columbia University School of Pharmacy and works in the drugstore in St. Clare's Hospital. But pharmacy is not what lured this strapping, 21-year-old youth here last year from Campbell, Calif.
The Sydney County Council and the Victorian State Electricity Commission in Australia wish Theodore E. Maynard had never founded the National Utility Services International Pty., Ltd., down under.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) John Newcombe won the men's tennis title at Wimbledon yesterday, but that wasn't good enough to get him into the traditional Wimbledon Ball last night.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 5 Sandpaper and hoses were the busiest pieces of equipment on the America's Cup scene today.
GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 5 The mayor, a squareshouldered man in a dark suit, spoke firmly into the microphones that captured his voice and amplified it to the level of the thunder of doom.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 5 A Cambodian military tribunal, trying Prince Norodom Sihanouk in absentia on charges of treason and corruption, today condemned the deposed Chief of State to death by firing squad.

New York Theological Seminary, faced with financial disaster, has decided to suspend its traditional degree-granting curriculums in favor of oneyear specialized training programs for the inner city ministry.
WASHINGTON, July 5 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.

Newark's city departments face an investigation for corruption and financial mismanagement and Newark's residents face higher taxes if there is not a substantial increase in state and Federal aid. Kenneth A. Gibson, who took office as Mayor six days ago, said yesterday.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 5 (UPI) Chris Taylor, the 19year-old giant from Muskegon Junior College in Michigan, took only 25 seconds to pin Art Frechette, of Hamilton, Ontario, today in the heavyweight division of the world amateur wrestling championships.

NEWBURY, Mass., July 5 Sherry Greenberg's I'm Nasty from the Rock Bottom Farms of Lagrangeville, N. Y., was a double winner today as the Ould Newbury horse show wound up four days of competition here.

The president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association charged yesterday that the Fire Deparement was endangering "vast areas of Queens, Staten Island and lower Manhattan" by taking firemen and equipment from them "to supply high-hazard ghetto neighborhoods like Brownsville and Harlem."

Gary Barnes, 21 years old, came east from Ball State University in Indiana to discover "what this New York life is all about," but after two weeks of sampling the city's rents and prices he is going home, with regrets, to Indianapolis.

Early last week, the General Assembly of the Organization of American States agreed on modest first steps toward collective action against various kinds of terrorism in the Americas. Only one day later, the need for such action was underscored by two airliner hijackings one of them abortive and the firebombing of four Latin-American embassies in Washington.

It is July, 1970, and according to its latest promotional calculations, baseball considers itself 101 years old, because the first team, comprised entirely of professionals signed to full-season contracts, played in 1869.
NEWARK, July 5 Jerry Nusbaum, a long-time columnist for The Newark Star-Ledger, died today. He was 86 years old.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., July 5 Miss Stephanie Lucy Ryan, a stewardess with United Airlines, and Paul Francis Malvey, who expects to receive a Ph. D. in economics from the University of Notre Dame next May, plan to be married here next month.

SENDAI, Japan, July 5 (AP) Shozo Saijo of Japan recovered from a first-round knockdown and scored a majority 15-round decision over Frankie Crawford of Los Angeles tonight. Saijo retained his World Boxing Association featherweight crown.

LOS ANGELES, July 5 A 38-year-old engineer at the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation here planned to use his profit from his 300 shares of Lockheed stock as a stake to open a law practice. But the 19-monthlong bear market has ruined his plan.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 5 A British Army spokesman said that all searches for arms had been completed in the predominantly Roman Catholic area of Lower Falls Road here today. The security forces also lifted a 36-hour curfew.
STOCKHOLM, July 5 The world pair championship that finished here last night was, like both its predecessors, an exciting contest that was in doubt until the last deal was played.
F. I. duPont, Glore Forgan Co., one of the nation's largest investment houses, will open for business officially for the first time today and all of Wall Street will be monitoring its performance.
Molotov cocktails were found under five police radio cars in a fenced-in parking area at Cunningham Park, near Grand Central Parkway in Hollis, Queens, early yesterday.

Miss Barbara Kelly was married here last evening to Ira A. Lipman, president and chief executive officer of Guardsmark, Inc., a security and protection company here. The ceremony was performed in the ballroom at the Regency by Rabbi Sanford Seltzer, director of the Northeast Council of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

The city's Housing Authority, concerned about the relations between its staff and its tenants and about vandalism in housing projects, recently sought the advice of Dr. Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, and now plans to distribute Dr. Mead's comments among staff members.

TORONTO, July 5 An Air Canada DC-8 plane crashed while trying to land at Toronto International Airport this morning after two of its four jet engines had fallen off. All 108 persons aboard were killed.
Just when the New York Yankees hoped to be at their best, they were at their worst.

BOSTON, July 5 Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia received a rousing ovation today from 800 John Birch Society members and other ultraconservatives at the eighth annual New England rally for God, Family and Country.

The marriage of Miss Robin Bonnie Striar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Striar of South Orange, N. J., to Neil Steven Rollnick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Rollnick of Miami, took place at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

ALBANY, July 5 Local government taxes and assessments more than doubled in New York State from 1958 to 1968, State Controller Arthur Levitt reported today. The decade's rise was from $2.3-billion to $4.99-billion, or 111.5 per cent.

The Labor Department has reported a drop in the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate from 5 per cent in May to 4.7 per cent in June but has emphasized that this implies no essential change in the underlying employment situation. In fact, there are reasons for concern that the job market actually worsened in June rather than improved.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 5 Dr. Felton G. Clark, retired president of Southern University, one of the nation's leading black educators and a controversial figure in early efforts to integrate lunch counters in Louisiana, died today at the Ochsner Foundation Hospital in New Orleans. He was 66 years old.
YONKERS, N.Y., July 5 Four Bronx youths were arrested today in connection with the shooting of a 58-year-old Yonkers widow at a bus stop here this morning.

SOUTHFIELD, Mich., July 5 Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Cline have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eva Susan Cline, to Paul Harvey Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Freeman of Miami, formerly of New Hyde Park, L. I. The wedding will take place here Aug. 15.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 5 Colombia will become the first Latin-American country to join the new Caribbean development bank in a move to expand her trade and help the struggling islands of the West Indies. The official announcement will be made tomorrow, according to high Government officials working on the final details over the weekend.

Otto Preminger and Frank Sinatra have joined forces after a 15-year interval to coproduce the film version of "Where the Dark Streets Go," the novel by Dorothy Salisbury Davis published by Scribner's last November. They last cooperated in 1955 to make the controversial but successful "The Man With the Golden Arm." Mr. Preminger produced and directed the film and Mr. Sinatra as the Chicago narcotics addict and gambler of the title.
LONGVIEW, Tex., July 5 (UPI) Two dozen bombs exploded simultaneously in a school district maintenance yard late last night, damaging 36 school buses parked there for the summer.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) The Government is planning to build a superhighway through a soggy bayou land owned by Carlos Marcello, a reputed Mafia leader, and pay his business empire about $153,000.
WASHINGTON, July 5 J. Willard Marriott, chairman of the executive committee that organized Honor America Day yesterday, said today that he thought it should become an annual event.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 The Mets, protecting a precarious lead in the National League's Eastern Division, wobbled to a 5-4 victory over the Phillies today at Connie Mack Stadium. It was their third straight triumph in a five-game series after losing two games to the Phils on Thursday night.

BALTIMORE, July 5 (AP) Boog Powell drove in two runs with a bad-hop single and a sacrifice fly as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Detroit Tigers and Denny McLain, 2-0, today. Jim Palmer pitched a three-hitter for the victory.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 5 The United States and South Vietnam joined today in appealing to their allies in the Indochina war to provide urgent aid to Cambodia.

NEW ORLEANS, July 5 Miss Mary Ellis Carrere a computer programer with the Shell Oil Company here, and George Howard Hasseltine, a geologist with the Mobile Oil Company, also in New Orleans, have made plans to be married here Aug. 29.

SPARTA, N. J., July 5 Fran's Image, owned by the Lotus Farms of Spring Valley, N. Y., and handled by Holly McBride, won the regular working hunter championship in a hackoff with Mrs. A. Woithe's Winsomeore at the Northwest Jersey horse show today.

DUBLIN, N.H., July 5 Robb Sagendorph, owner and publisher of The Old Farmer's Almanac and Yankee magazine, died yesterday at Monadnock Community Hospital in nearby Peterborough following a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Dublin.
Assemblyman Charles B. Rangel termed President Nixon and Vice President Agnew as "one of the most honest Presidents and Vice Presidents probably in the history of the United States."
WASHINGTON, July 5 "When the smog covers the sun," said Representative Ken Hechler of West Virginia the other day, "you have one way Of telling it's morning the birds start coughing."
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 5 As President Nixon pointed out on television the other night, only history can judge the effectiveness of what he has done in Cambodia.

HONG KONG, July 5 The photographs accompanying an article in a recent issue of a Peking magazine, China Reconstructs, looked as if they had been taken in an earlier century.
LA BAULE, France, July 5 (Reuters) Frank Chapot of the United States won the Prix d'Honneur duPrefet today in a horse show preceding the world equestrian championships.

RUSSELLS POINT, Ohio, July 5 (AP) Scores of young people were in jail or out on bond today after a night in which the police fought youths who rampaged through this resort town, smashing windows and looting shops.

MEXICO CITY, Monday, July 6 Mexicans voted for a new President and Chamber of Deputies yesterday and Luis Echeverria Alvarez, the candidate of the governing Revolutionary Institutional party, claimed victory three and a half hours after the polls closed.
FROBISHER BAY, Northwest Territories, July 5 Queen Elizabeth II greeted her Eskimo subjects here today at the beginning of the first royal tour of the Canadian Arctic.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 5 Ruch Churzow, the second best soccer team in Poland this year, routed the New York All-Stars, 7-1, at Hostra Stadium tonight before 3,427 fans who paid about $9,000. The proceeds will go to Rudy Lamonica, a young soccer player who lost his right leg last April as a result of cancer.

ROME, July 5 Anyone who sees this country's congested cities and highways would think there is no space for more cars, but every day now 4,000 Italians buy new automobiles. Every fourth car is of foreign make.
Fifteen more taxi drivers reported being held up yesterday, making a total of 28 throughout the city since Friday night. Two men were killed in the robberies.
Three Americans who played in the 1969 Netanya International in Israel finished with much of the spoils.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 5 Challenge, a new Cal-43 sloop co-owned by Bruce Lockwood, Allen Berrien and Barrows Peale, won the Commodore Blattmann Trophy today by placing first in the Riverside Yacht Club's 39th annual Stratford Shoal overnight race on Long Island Sound.
OTTAWA A baby born on a Canadian Indian Reserve has less than half the chance for survival that a typical white Canadian baby has.

EDMONTON, Alberta This year's laurels for political precocity may go to Harold Cardinal, the principal author of a "red paper" submitted to the federal Government last month by Canada's Indian chiefs.

WHITTIER, Calif. An Egyptian pharaoh had his pyramid and an American President has his memorial library and museum. Whittier is campaigning to give its hometown boy who made it to the top Richard Milhous Nixon whatever immortality concrete and steel can provide.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 5 A dog Show, a white elephant booth, book stalls and antique shops will be part of the program for Saturday's fair at Christ Episcopal Church here.
MADISON, Ind., July 25 (AP) Dean Chenoweth won the Indiana Governor's Cup race for unlimited hydroplanes today for the second straight year, but in a different boat.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 5 (Reuters) Charlie Greene and Joy Silvester, world record holders from the United States, Sparkled today at an international invitation track and field meet.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 6 (AP) Live Oak Plantation's Peaceful Union outlasted her rivals today after gaining the lead leaving the backstretch and won the $7,000 Smart Deb Purse at Monmouth Park.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 6 (UPI) Charles O. Finley, the P.T. Barnum of professional athletics, told his first news conference here as owner of the Oakland Seals today that "I know absolutely nothing about hockey."

HANCOCK, N. H., July 6 Mrs. Ann English Anable and T. Gordon Hutchinson were married here this morning. The Rev. George Stewart performed the Presbyterian. ceremony at the home of the bride's father, State Senator Robert English. The bride is the daughter also of Mrs. A. Grew English of Greenwich, Conn., and the granddaughter of the late Joseph C. Grew, the United States Ambassador to Japan.

While the pickets circled out side in the sun on Park Avenue Mrs. Annette Forman stood frowning in the cool, elegant lobby, holding a pillowcase ful of the Monday wash.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) Savings-bond redemption exceeded sales by $30-million last month as savers continued to withdraw their funds, apparently in search of a better return on their money.

The Saratoga PerformingArts Ball will move outdoors for the first time this year. Five hundred guests from New York, Philadelphia and Washington gather on the lawn of the amphitheater on Aug. 7 for the sixth annual benefit for the Saratoga Performining Arts Center.
WASHINGTON, July 6 Seven affluent young wome have come to Washington from Farmington, Conn., to challeng the practices and concepts followed in nursing homes for the aged.

BRUSSELS, July 6 The United States and its allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization intend to explore vigorously the Warsaw Pact nations' recent offer to discuss the reduction of armed forces on foreign soil in Europe.
LONDON, July 6 Sir Alec Douglas-Home, Foreign Secretary in the new Conservative Government, warned today against the growth of Soviet power at sea and in the Middle East.

NEW ORLEANS, July 6 (UPI) A Federal grand jury indicted Attorney General Jack P.F. Gremillion of Louisiana today on five counts of perjury. It said he lied last January when he denied having interests in a bankrupt loan company.
WASHINGTON, July 6 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
MEXICO CITY, July 6 A sizable victory for Luis Echeverria Alvarez, presidential candidate of the governing party, emerged today in returns from Mexico's national election.
PARIS, July 6 The resignation of Premier Mario Rumor against the background of new social unrest in Italy touched off further selling of the lira in foreign exchange markets today.

LIMA, Peru, July 6 (Reuters) Peruvian authorities today were preparing for the expected arrival tomorrow of 65 Soviet transport planes with relief supplies for earthquakestricken areas of northern Peru.

OHRID, Yugoslavia, June 25 Relations between Albania and Yugoslavia, which have ranged in the postwar years from camaraderie to hostility to cautious cooperation, have now reached the point where officials of this dazzling little resort openly express the hope that tourists will someday visit them by traveling over Albanian roads.

The shy ones stayed close to their mothers' knees and, fingers in mouths, eyes enormous, looked longingly into the playroom of Mount Sinai Hospital's pediatric clinic where bolder children were actually enjoying the inevitable wait for the doctor.
NEW ORLEANS, July 6 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit today upheld the draft-evasion conviction of Cassius Clay, the former heavyweight boxing champion.

HONOLULU, July 6 (UPI) A five-day conference to work out the details of the withdrawal of 50,000 more American troops from Vietnam opened today at the headquarters of Adm. John S. McCain Jr., commander of United States forces in the Pacific.

BONN, July 6 The West German Government announced today a seven-month suspension of degressive depreciation allowances for industry as a means to assist the central bank in its fight against inflation.

JERUSALEM, July 6 Israel's chief of staff said today that in the last six days Israeli planes had been in intensive combat involving ground-to-air missile sites along the Suez Canal and that the missiles had been installed and were partly operated by Soviet personnel.
A new administration building is to be added to the Middletown State Hospital in Middletown, Orange County, which serves 3,000 mentally ill patients from Orange, Sullivan and Ulster Counties.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Tuesday, July 7-The police arrested scores of persons last night and early this morning as this seaside community suffered its third straight night of violence, vandalism and looting. For the first time, a 7 P.M.-to-6 A.M. curfew was in effect.

HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 6 Wilson Hicks, former executive editor of Life magazine and a lecturer on photo-journalism at the University of Miami, died at his home here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old.

LONDON, July 6 The pound, continuing a two-month slide in foreign-exchange markets, tumbled 14 more points today to $2,3914. This is the lowest level since last October, when the revaluation of the West German mark helped spark sterling's strong recovery.

WASHINGTON, July 6 A two-year, $2.3-million contract to establish and operate a Job Corps training center at Fort Totten in Queens has been granted to the RCA Service Company, a division of the RCA Corporation, the Labor Department announced today.

Film rights to "The Effect of Gamma Rays on Man-in-theMoon Marigolds," the off Broadway hit by Paul Zindel, have been acquired by the independent Newman-Foreman Company, headed by Paul Newman, the actor-director, and John Foreman, the producer. The comedy-drama about a bitter mother and her two troubled daughters opened last April at the Mercer-O'Casey Theater, 340 Mercer Street.

The New York Yankees, with eight losses in their last 10 games, inconsistent fielding of late by their shortstop, a hitting slump by their top batter and three consecutive defeats pinned on their former No. 1 hurler, open a three-game series against the Orioles, the Eastern Division leaders, at Baltimore tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, was awarded today the Bernard M. Baruch Conservation Prize for 1969 for his work in behalf of environmental legislation during the 1960's.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that the commission had been "maybe hyperactive" during his nine months as its head and may be due for a leveline off.
BOSTON, July 6 The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit ruled unconstitutional today the Massachusetts law designed to withhold contraceptive devices from unmarried persons.
WASHINGTON, July 6 The career of William Matthew Byrne Sr. is a tough act to follow.

A dancer's debut in one of the two leading roles in "Giselle" is both a trial and an initiation. The tension is frightening, simply because the dancer is dancing something his or her predecessors have been dancing for about 130 years now. There is a sheer accumulation of tradition here that must lie heavy on any dancer rash and brave enough to dance the ballet.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 6 Competition in the America's Cup observation trials will begin here tomorrow, almost but not quite on schedule.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 An American who visited South Vietnam's largest civilian prison last Thursday reported here today on what he described as the inhuman conditions and intimidation existing there.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., July 6 (AP) A military policeman testified today that he had seen no foot tracks in the house where Capt. Jeffrey MacDonald of the Green Berets is accused of slaying his pregnant wife and two children last Feb. 17.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 6 Prime Minister John Gorton announced tonight that Australia would grant the territory of Papua and New Guinea control of many of its internal affairs.

ATLANTA, July 6 (AP) The Army announced today that it would go ahead with a pretrial proceeding in the court-martial of Sgt. Esequiel Torres, 22 years old, of Brownsville, Tex., charged with murder in the alleged Songny massacre.
