Harry Lightstone, a Pennsylvania lawyer who was once District Attorney of Schuylkill County and General Counsel of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, was sentenced yesterday to a year in prison for soliciting a bribe.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 6 (AP) Two lions that killed a youth at the Portland Zoo Saturday night were dead today, victims of a nighttime rifleman.

The idea that mutual funds can best be managed by hiring several portfolio managers to compete against one another suffered a sharp setback yesterday when the Competitive Capital Corporation discharged all eight of its managers in an effort "to improve performance."

WASHINGTON, July 6 Do you have a right not to be stored in a computer, where you can be called up for instant investigation by any bureaucrat or law officer who considers you a "person of interest" or who may want to provide someone else maybe your employer with "facts" about you? If you haven't thought about that, it's high time you did.

BERLIN, July 6 (UPI) Berlin Film Festival officials ruled today that movies still scheduled to be shown would be, even though a dispute over one about Vietnam ended the festival competition yesterday two days early.
Joan Bird, one of 13 Black Panthers awaiting trial here on bomb-conspiracy charges, was released from the Women's House of Detention yesterday on $100,000 bail.

DUBLIN, July 6 Dr. Patrick J. Hillery, the Irish Republic's Foreign Minister, disclosed here tonight that he went to Northern Ireland unannounced today to talk with residents in the riot-torn Lower Falls Road area of Belfast.

WASHINGTON, July 6 The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously for a policy of "moderate growth in money and bank credit over the months ahead" at its meeting of April 7, a report of the meeting disclosed today.
TORONTO, July 6 The Air Canada DC-8 that crashed yesterday killing all 108 persons aboard had first made "a hard landing" at Toronto International Airport, a senior Government official said today.
The city's Department of Social Services is preparing to implement a new system of grants to welfare recipients now living in hotels so they can buy enough furniture to set up their own households.

RICHMOND, July 6 Mr. and Mrs. John R. Talbott Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Ann Talbott to Anthony Zinsser, son of Mr. and Mrs. August Zinsser Jr. of Glen Cove, L.I. A September wedding is planned here.

NEWNAN, Ga., July 6 (AP) Lorenzo Edward Ervin Jr., 25 years old, was sentenced today to life imprisonment on two counts of aircraft hijacking. The sentence was imposed here by Federal District Judge Albert Henderson.

The commission investigating charges of corruption in the New York Police Department went to work yesterday despite a plea from the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association that the commission defer action until its legality had been decided.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 6 American discussions with Thailand over the possible dispatch of Thai troops to Cambodia are reported to have bogged down over Thai demands that the United States underwrite a large share of the cost.

Mayor Lindsay had encouraging words for the Police Athletic League's summer play street program yesterday at opening ceremonies on 114th Street in Harlem. But several local residents were skeptical about the kind of play that usually takes place on the block between Seventh and Eighth Avenues.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) The Senate narrowly defeated today the first of several attempts to cut the $3.3-billion space budget.

A portrait of the United States as a nation bubbling with ferment and industry, dedicated to freedom, independence, individualism and equality but with a tendency for tyranny that it barely kept in check was drawn 135 years ago, in 1835 by a 30year-old French aristocrat. Count Alexis de Tocqueville, ville.

WASHINGTON, July 6 A special House committee that just returned from two weeks in Southeast Asia recommended today that the withdrawal of United States ground troops continue "at least as fast as now scheduled."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 The Cambodian Foreign Minister, Koun Wick, flew to Saigon from Pnompenh for a hastily arranged visit today at the invitation of Secretary of State William P. Rogers, During his five-hour stay he sought to explain his Government's political, military and economic problems to allied leaders here.

The dean of Teachers College, Columbia University, said yesterday that American education colleges were not doing an adequate job because, among other failings, they were out of touch with school classrooms.
PARIS The shrine of French bread is a modest bakery at 8 Rue du Cherche Midi, whose owner, Pierre Poilane, has been called the patron saint of bakers.

GARLAND, Tex., July 6 (UPI) Hugo T. Speck, a World War II correspondent, died here yesterday. He was 64 years old. Mr. Speck was born in Lone Grove, Tex., and went to work for the Chicago Tribune while attending Northwestern University.

Trading in silver futures on the Commodity Exchange of New York reached a record of 3,218,000,000 ounces in the first half of this year, it was announced yesterday by Matthew S. Fox, president of the exchange.

FORT MOHAVE, Nev. Here in the southern tip of the Nevada desert, a brand new black and white striped smokestack juts 500 feet above tie sagebrush. It symbolizes an important aspect of a nationwide struggle Power vs. Environment.
Preliminary figures from regional census bureaus around New York State have indicated a sharp decline in the population of upstate cities that may mean the loss of financial aid to urban areas.

Morgan Stanley Co. announced yesterday that six new general partners have been admitted to the firm. The new partners, who bring the firm's total to 34, have also been elected managing directors of Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., a separate entity.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 The National Education Association, at its 108th annual convention here, has called on Federal and state governments to withhold new aid for private schools and to withdraw the help such schools now receive from tax funds.

CHICAGO, July 6 (UPI) Judge Joseph A. Power denied today the Black Panther party's request that a black co-prosecutor be appointed to investigate the Dec. 4 police raid on a Panther apartment. The raid left two party leaders dead.

A strike against 2,500 apartment buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and Richmond was called at 10 A.M. yesterday by Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union. The buildings, mainly rent-controlled, house about half a million people.

For a man with only token opposition, Luis Echeverria Alvarez campaigned strenuously for the Presidency of Mexico. He traveled 30,000 miles, visited 850 towns and villages in 221 days and was seen by more than a fifth of Mexico's 48 million people. He won about 80 per cent of the votes in a turnout that was fairly heavy despite a "don't-vote" drive by young dissidents.

Four private secondary schools here announced agreement yesterday to merge some of their academic and business operations in an effort to reduce costs, to eliminate duplication and to provide enriched academic offerings.
PAPEETE, Tahiti, July 6 (UPI) The 48-foot cutter Jubilation crossed the finish line of the Los Angeles-to-Tahiti race late yesterday, the sixth yacht to finish.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 6 (UPI) Joseph Rhodes Jr., a member of the Presidential Commission on Campus Unrest, says he is disturbed that President Nixon has not been able to control Vice President Agnew's rhetoric.

Take a guess. How many games do you think the Dodgers have played is Los Angeles since Walter O'Malley packed his carpet bag in Ebbets Field and started his private California Gold Rush? Some diehard Brooklyn fans, still carrying the torch, might sigh deeply and mutter in despairing tones, "It seems only like yesterday." It's later than they think.

WASHINGTON, July 6 American officials reported today that Egypt's Soviet-built missile defense system had been improved recently but they differed with Israel's assessment of the extent of the build-up.

BUCHAREST, July 6 Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin received a coolly correct reception here today at the beginning of a visit centered on the long-deferred signing of a new Soviet-Rumanian friendship and mutual assistance treaty.
For the 10th consecutive trading session, prices on the American Stock Exchange slumped yesterday. The average dropped to 19.75, down 0.20. This was the lowest level since May 26, when it was 19.36.
ROME, July 6 The fourparty coalition Government of Premier Mariano Rumor resigned today in a dispute over the Socialists' cooperation with Communists.

A company headed by Andrew P. Kerr received $212,000 in city management-consultant contracts while Mr. Kerr served as the unpaid director of the project management staff of the city's Policy Planning Council.
MIAMI, July 6 Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba replaced his Ministers of the Sugar Industry and Education today.
WASHINGTON, July 6 The President's new Commission on Campus Unrest, despite urgent time pressure, will conduct public hearings, probably starting within two weeks.

William R. McAlpin Jr., a 39year-old Rockefeller heir who fell to his death early this year from a Florida hotel, bequeathed $1.5-million, a record, to the National Association for Mental Health for study of hereditary factors of mental illness, the organization disclosed yesterday.

The nation's major commercial banks, rallying together to head off what they freely concede could have been a serious financial panic, assembled a loan package of more than $400-million for the Chrysler Financial Corporation in just five business days.

WASHINGTON, July 6(AP) Charles A. Lindbergh, who made aviation history with his solo flight across the Atlantic Ocean 43 years ago, says that it is time to take a critical look at technology and its side effects.
Corporate bond prices climbed exuberantly yesterday in a performance that dealers described, as the strongest yet in the markey's advance that began three weeks ago.

Richie Allen of the St. Louis Cardinals beat out Willie McCovey of the San Francisco Giants, the National League's most valuable player of 1969, in the final voting for the 1970 All-Star team, and Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves led the fans' poll with 1,394,847 votes.

WASHINGTON, July 6 Dr. Curtis W. Tarr, the Director of Selective Service, told local draft boards today that the primary criterion for a conscientious objector was whether his beliefs were sincere and deeply held and not whether they were comprehensible to board members.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) The nation's interstate highways are cracking up from heavy truck traffic that may force many hundreds of millions of dollars in repairs, Government investigators reported today.
ST. JOHN, Virgin Islands, July 6 (AP) Five women scientists plunged into the warm waters off this tiny island today to live and work for two weeks at the bottom of the sea.
COLUMBIA, S. C., July 6 (UPI) Gov. Robert E. McNair said today that officials of the BASF Chemical Corporation had delayed plans to construct facilities in Beaufort County until at least 1972.

On April 20 an old contract expired for 25,000 doormen, porters and elevator operators in 5,000 apartment buildings here. The landlords said they could not meet wage demands without rent increases, which were prohibited by the city rent-control law.

JACKSON, Miss., July 6 A state judge told the Hinds County Grand Jury today that its investigation of violence at Jackson State College must be guided by state law, which permits a peace officer to kill a human being "in lawfully suppressing any riot."
A dispute continued yesterday over control of the eight schools in what was formerly the Ocean Hill Brownsville Demonstration School District.
LONDON, July 6 British officials appeared flabbergasted late tonight by Dr. Hillery's trip to Belfast. They spoke guardedly, awaiting reaction's from their political leaders.
CHICAGO, July 6 Tom Gorman, recovering in Wesley Memorial Hospital following his first injury in 20 years as a major league umpire, learned today that he would be on the sidelines at least a month.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 6 Mason Welch Gross, presi dent of Rutgers, the State Uni versity, for the last 11 years, today announced his retirement from that post effective Sept. 1, 1971.
Two employes at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx were arrested yesterday on charges of selling dangerous drugs to undercover agents of the office of Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.
ATLANTA, July 6 (Reuters) Gov. Lester G. Maddox announced today that he would seek legislation to prohibit pop music festivals such as the one held in Georgia last weekend for 250,000 young people.
The stock market fell sharply yesterday as glamour issues, where enchantment has turned into disenchantment on Wall Street, proved especially vulnerable.
STOCKHOLM, July 6 The world pair championship played here last week confirmed the reputation of Jeff Westheimer of New York and Ira Rubin of Paramus, N. J., as one of the world's best partnerships.
The London stock market closed mixed yesterday as traders, awaited today's official statement on the economy.
PARIS, July 6 (UPI) Juan D. Peron called today for a violent revolution in Argentina like that in Cuba and said he would return when the time was ripe.

PARIS, July 6 (AP) United States Embassy officials said today that several thousand American students apparently were stranded in Paris, Rome, Geneva and Vienna by financial difficulties of the United States tour organization through which their trips had been booked.

ZZYZX, Calif. One evening 27 years ago, Dr. Curtis Springer went out for a walk near his home in Hollywood. Passing a second-hand book store, he spied a volume about the "mineral springs of the Pacific Coast" on sale for 25 cents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 "If the Government is willing to give land to the peasants, why should it not give houses to disabled war veterans?" the former South Vietnamese paratrooper asked bitterly.

The Federal Government should shut down 42d Street and other skid row commercial blood banks before hepatitis-carrying blood donors cause a national health crisis, the New York Council on Civic Affairs said yesterday.

Premier Kosygin and other Soviet dignitaries received a correct if cool reception on their arrival in Bucharest yesterday. The visitors from Moscow, well aware that the Rumanians are reluctant allies, could hardly have been surprised. Leonid I. Brezhnev decided not even to come to Bucharest, showing his displeasure by hiding behind a diplomatic illness.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 6 Ada L. Cole, a public school school teacher here for 46 years, died yesterday at Elizabeth General Hospital after a brief illness. She was 87 years old and lived at 404 Westminster Avenue. She retired in 1948.

Until they can get offtrack betting parlors into operation, city officials will rely heavily on telephoned bets. The city hopes to raise about $50-million during the first year of offtrack betting. EDMONTON, Alberta, July 6 (Canadian Press) Janos Varga of Hungary won the world Greco-Roman amateur wrestling title in the 125 -pound division today when he battled to a 2-2 draw with Rustem Kazakov of the Soviet Union, the defending champion.
A borscht circuit or rock music festivals that seemed to be developing in the Catskills after last August's Woodstock Festival suffered a new setback yesterday.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 6 (UPI) The moderate Unified party, whose platform rejects union with Greece, has emerged as the strongest political party in Cyprus following elections to the House of Representatives yesterday. The Akel, or Communist party, almost doubled its strength, unofficial returns showed tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 6 The film starts with a slow pan of an airplane. It looks as if it's going to be a movie about airplanes one of those shiny documentaries that trace flight backward in color from a sparking jet lumbering out of its hanger to Icarus's wax wings.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 Koun Wick, Cambodia's Foreign Minister, conferred with Secretary of State William P. Rogers here today on the unresolved problem of Thai military assistance to Cambodia.
WASHINGTON, July 6 Dr. Walter Francis Colby, a physicist and professor emeritus at the University of Michigan, died at his home here today. He suffered a heart attack last May. He was 89 years old.

PARIS, July 6 Andre Philip, the economist who was several times a Finance Minister and one of the stanchest proponents of European unity in the Socialist party, died here last night. He was 68 years old.

The defense opened and closed its case yesterday in the conspiracy-perjury trial here of Dr. Martin Sweig, suspended chief administrative aide of House Speaker John W. McCormack, after calling only seven witnesses. The Government had called 46.

A request by a City Councilman for a court hearing on conflict-of-interest charges against Bruce A. Gimbel, president of the department store chain and a former member of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, was denied yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Isidore Dollinger.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 6 (AP) Cambodian troops recaptured the river town of Saang today while other forces beat off an enemy threat against the important highway town of Kompong Thom, 100 miles north, with the aid of South Vietnamese warplanes, the Cambodian command reported.
Sales in New York's largest department stores in June showed an evident worsening of already sluggish consumer buying

Creative Management Associates, one of the country's largest talent agencies, has joined forces with G.H.V. Packages Productions, Inc., to present Off Broadway works in the growing college theater market.

The New York City Opera's fourth annual Los Angeles season, scheduled to open Nov. 16, was canceled yesterday by the Music Center Opera Association. Lawrence E. Deutsch, vice president of the West Coast association, attributed the decision to call off the three-week season to "spiraling costs and increasingly unmanageable deficits."

CLEVELAND, July 6 Mayor Carl B. Stokes will meet tomorrow with representatives of the Cleveland Transit System and union officials in an attempt to end a six-day wildcat transit strike that has crippled Cleveland's public transportation.

HONG KONG, July 6 The discovery of two old Chinese cannon in the Kowloon Walled City has focused new public attention on this crowded, cramped quarter of Hong Kong with its reputation as a haunt of drug addicts and criminals and its history as a sensitive issue in Chinese-British relations.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced yesterday that it would raise prices by 2 per cent, effective Aug. 8, on tetraethyl lead, an antiknock additive for gasoline. The move followed an announcement last week by the Houston Chemical Company that it would increase its prices for the product by about 3.6 per cent, effective Aug. 6.

OLD BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 6 George Ostrowski, a 17year-old from the Glen Cove High School golf team, scored a 37, 37 74 to win the medal in the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Brookville Country Club today. Par for the 6,447-yard course is 36, 36 72.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (UPI) Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo said today that the riot Saturday at Holmesburg Prison in which 103 persons were injured was caused by "barbarians" and had "definite racial patterns."

The USLIFE Corporation has acquired more than 85 per cent of the stock of the Sterling Savings and Loan Association of Riverside, Calif., through an exchange of shares. The exchange offer has been extended subject to termination without notice to the remaining stockholders of Sterling.
LA BAULE, France, July 6 (UPI) Harvey Smith of Britain led the world jumping horse championships today after two of three qualifying trials.

The nation's railroads are talking again about seeking another freight rate increase. Meanwhile, five big lines in the East have applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase their basic one-way coach and first class passenger fares by 10 per cent.
The two Democratic Congressmen told yesterday of seeing men kept in "tiger cages" on their tour of the South Vietnamese prison island.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, second in size to Sears, Roebuck Co. among American retailers, reported level earnings yesterday for the first fiscal quarter, ended May 30, on a 3.6 per cent increase in sales.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 6 Prime Minister James D. Chichester-Clark issued the following statement late tonight:

Not all adolescents are all churned up inside. Yvette Williams, who is 18 years old, is quite serene. Oh, she's a bit nervous about going to live in Denmark for a year in September, but then her mother has promised to go with her for a week and get her settled.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) The Democrats announced today the format of their free time broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System tomorrow night amid demands by the Republicans for equal time to reply.

ROCHESTER, July 6 On the site of an old hospital in this city's predominantly black Third Ward, most of the foundation has been poured for a grass-roots housing project that will provide new living quarters for 149 low-income families.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 6 William W. Farley, former freestyle Olympian was appointed head coach of swimming at Princeton University today.
Union mailers seeking to win contract gains from The New York Post prevented the newspaper from distributing most of its editions yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Welst of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Harriet Weist, to Philip Simmons Douthit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Claude Douthit Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla., and Watch Hill, R. I.
The Uniformed Firemen's Association with 28,000 members will publicly announce today its endorsement of James Y. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator.
BOSTON July 6 (AP) Mr. Baird said today that the deci sion vindicated him of the accusation of being a "sexual pied piper."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 6 David's Island, where soldiers formerly were stationed at Fort Slocum and where the Consolidated Edison Company hopes to build four nuclear generators, today became an unusual summer day camp.

The first results of a federally supported survey of Americans' educational achievement confirm that the knowledge and learning skills of students and young adults are greater when "textbook" information is reinforced by practical experience.

HAMDEN, Conn., July 7 (UPI) Dr. C.N. Hugh Long, former dean of the Yale University school of medicine and Sterling Professor Emeritus of Physiology, died yesterday at Pemaquid Beach, Me., apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

Jed Harris, the 70-yearold producer-director who has become a legend in his own time, is returning to Broadway after an absence of 14 years. In late September, he plans to produce and direct a comedy called "Great Day for the Race" by Angus Dalrymple.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., July 7 (AP) Marjorie Rambeau, whose stage and screen career spanned almost 70 years and who was twice nominated for Academy Awards, died at her home here yesterday at the age of 80.
ZIGUINCHOR, Senegal, July 7 (AP) Senegal supports the efforts of nationalist guerrillas to free Portuguese Guinea from Lisbon's rule, but she has clamped down on some of the guerrillas' activities.

The New Haven Railroad's trustee, Richard Joyce Smith, has asked the Federal Court in New Haven to permit him to intervene in the reorganization proceedings of the Penn Central Transportation Company.

The flow of favorable bankearnings reports continued yesterday. The First National City Corporation, J.P. Morgan Co., Inc. and the Franklin New York Corporation the parent companies, respectively, of the largest, and fourth-largest bank in New York City and the largest bank based on Long Island generally reported higher profits, in some cases sharply so.
CHICAGO, July 7 (UPI) National trucking industry officials have approved a new contract with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The truckers predicted sharp, quick rate increases.

ROME, July 7-Some 50 members of the Italian Divorce League picketed the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate this afternoon to protest against the resignation of Premier Mario Rumor's Cabinet. They said the action would delay passage of a bill legalizing divorce.

BUCHAREST, July 7 (AP) Diplomats said the Rumanians had resisted Soviet efforts to insert in the treaty the socalled Brezhnev Doctrine of limited sovereignty that was used to justify the Soviet-led military intervention in Czechoslovakia in 1968. The doctrine is named for Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party leader.

POINTE AUX TREMBLES, Quebec, July 7 Fresh Yankee, a familiar figure in international trotting circles, captured the Canadian Trotting Championship at Richelieu Park tonight. The victory automatically moved Fresh Yankee at Roosevelt Raceway on the night of July 18.
LA BAULE, France, July 7 (AP) Two British riders, a German and an Italian qualified today for Friday's fourman final of the world jumping championship.
WASHINGTON, July 7James F. Kelly, Assistant Secretary, Controller, of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, announced his resignation today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 A dozen Senators, spanning the political spectrum, introduced a bill today that would end the military draft and establish an all-volunteer Army by next July 1.

Alwyn Lee, a contributing editor of Time magazine, died in Rome Monday after a short illness. He was 58 years old and in recent years lived at a villa near Rome. Formerly he lived at the Finney Farm in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

TRENTON, July 7 The ex tortion conspiracy trial of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defendants here was adjourned tonight until Thursday after defense lawyers told the court they were not yet ready to present their cases.

A new policy statement that details the rights and responsibilities of the city's 275,000 high school students and declares that "no student has the right to interfere with the education of his fellow students" has been approved by the Board of Education.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 8 The Soviet delegation to the World Youth Assembly, sounding like Moscow's regular diplomatic team, today demanded the exclusion of representatives from the "puppet" nations of South Korea, South Vietnam and Nationalist China.
ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 7 (Reuters) After winning the United States Open, Tony Jacklin tucked away the prize money in a suit and got taken to the cleaners.

LOS ANGELES The Company Theater, the off Off Broadway theater of Los Angeles, was founded in 1967 by a group of students, most of them dropouts from the University of Southern California. Despite many adversities, and with no advertisements, the group persisted until word-of-mouth, national recognition, offers to tour (so far, all rejected), and small foundation grants caught up with it.
BUCHAREST, July 7 Rumania and the Soviet Union signed a new treaty of friendship here today, extending a 20-year pact concluded in 1948.
Opponents of New York City's plan to negotiate future cable television agreements by competitive bidding are preparing arguments for public hearings before the Board of Estimate on July 23.
PITTSBURGH, July 7 (AP) The Pittsburgh Pioneers traded Warren Davis, a forward, to the Miami Floridians today for Simmie Hill, a former Midland (Pa.) high school star.
Many years ago (perhaps after he made Greta Garbo the slouch hat that became her trademark) Mr. John, who scorns modesty in any form, crowned himself "Emperor of Fashion."
LONDON, July 7 Britain's economic squeeze will be continued by the Conservative Government for the time being, Iain MacLeod, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today.
Commissioner Pete Rozelle moved yesterday to avoid a strike in pro football. He sought to prolong the negotiations betweea the Players Association and an owners' committee.

A New York subcontractor testified yesterday that he had heard Nathan M. Voloshen and Dr. Martin Sweig say "This is Speaker McCormack" to telephone callers in the Washington office of House Speaker John W. McCormack.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 7 (AP) Communist troops who have pulled out of part of the ancient temple ruins at Angkor have left them undamaged after an occupation of more than a month, authoritative sources reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 7-The House Banking Committee approved today a further contribution of more than $1-billion over the next three years by the United States to the InterAmerican Development Bank.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 7 Violence broke out anew this afternoon in the streets of this resort city, which has already been shaken by two nights of noting in the predominantly black West Side ghetto.
GENEVA, July 7 Investors Overseas Services announced today another internal shakeup with the ousting of Erich Mende, former West German Vice Chancellor, from the Mutual-fund empire.
WASHINGTON, July 7 The House Ways and Means Committee began detailed consideration of trade legislation today and tentatively decided to give President Nixon modest tariff-cutting authority.
LONDON, July 7 Sir Allen Lane, founder and head of Penguin Books, died tonight of cancer in the hospital at Northwood, Middlesex. His age was 67.

SEOUL, South Korean, July 7 The Government announced tonight that South Korean troops killed two North Korean agents in a gunfight this afternoon on a mountain six miles west of Kimpo International Airport. The airport is 15 miles west of the center of Seoul.

About 300 youths from around the world learned yesterday that New York City has five boroughs, that city dog licenses cost more than marriage licenses and that taxi drivers often make obscene gestures at other drivers.

The strike of the United Transportation Union against three railroads over the elimination of thousands of firemen's jobs could scarcely have come at a worse time from the standpoint of the financially beleaguered railroad industry.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 7 Gov. Ronald Reagan today angrily described as "ridiculous" a statement by a fellow Republican, Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, that the party might turn to Mr. Reagan for its Presidential nominee in 1972 and deny renomination to President Nixon unless economic conditions improved and the Vietnam War ended.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 On the empty storefronts around the Black Panther headquarters here the posters of Huey P. Newton are worn and tattered now.

In case you haven't noticed it, the growth stocks have taken an awful pounding in the first six months of 1970. By contrast, the growth stocks were notable for their buoyancy in the bear market of 1969.

Negotiators for the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Workers, sought last night to avert a strike set for 6 A.M. today that would affect 1,800 employes and 1,550 patients at two city hospitals.

BOSTON, July 7 A largescale experimental project to recover sulphur dioxide pollutant from power plant smoke and convert it into resalable commercial chemicals will begin in 15 months under a plan announced here today.
MOSCOW, July 7, (AP) A new Soviet history of Siberia accuses Communist China of "trying to create a territorial problem" over large stretches of Siberian lands.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) A bill to establish an 18,000acre Gulf Islands National Seashore off the coasts of Florida and Mississippi was approved today by a House Interior subcommittee.
John O'Hara's scorn for his critics lives again in a memorial exhibition of the writer's work which opened yesterday at the University Libraries of Pennsylvania State University.
Appropriations. President Nixon signed a bill providing more than $6-billion in new appropriations for the fiscal year 1970. More than half the money is for increased civilian and military pay.

Stock prices drifted lower yesterday after a rally attempt at mid-session failed to generate buying enthusiasm. The DowJones industrial average, finishing once again at its lowest level of the day, dropped 6.30 points to 699.36.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) A Senate-passed bill to limit broadcast spending by candidates for Federal offices in general elections was expanded by a House Commerce subcommittee today to cover races for Governor and primaries.
LISBON, July 7 (Reuters) Premier Marcello Caetano of Portugal said today that the Pope's controversial audience last week with three anti-Portugese guerrilla leaders had been clarified.

DETROIT, July 7 The Ford Motor Company today was ordered to sell its big spark plug plant and give up the spark plug business for 10 years, dispose of a battery plant and give up the name Autolite, the trade name Ford used to build its replacement parts business.
ATHENS, July 7 A Turkish porduction of "Fiddler on the Roof" before a Greek audience may sound like Babel, but here it is spelling success.

TOKYO, Wednesday, July 8 (Reuters) Secretary of State William P. Rogers promised Japan today that the Nixon Administration would do everything possible for the early removal of nerve gas from the island of Okinawa, the Japanese Foreign Minister, Kiichi Aichi, said today.
LONDON, July 7 The surprise visit to Belfast by the Irish Republic's Minister for External Affairs, Dr. Patrick Hillery, was officially deplored in Britain today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 The Senate narrowly rejected today two attempts by liberals to cut the nation's space budget as part of a campaign to reorient Government priorities toward everyday human needs.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 7 A new threat to the Florida Everglades has been created by the people who had original claim to the two million acres of virgin wilderness, the Seminole and Miccosukee Indians.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 (AP) Butcher Sherrerd, one of Pennsylvania's largest brokerage firms, plans to reduce spending, cut some salaries and trim its staff by 20 per cent.
GENEVA, July 7 The Swiss Government announced formally today that it would move to transfer to it the authority now reserved to Parliament to alter the value of the Swiss franc.

The scientist who recently reported that whales sing songs of haunting beauty disclosed yesterday that strong efforts were being made to remove whales from the list of protected animals included in the newly enacted Federal endangered species act.

When you walk into a news conference and they hand you a Stetson along with the press kit, you've got to figure something's up. Then when you realize that the three long-haired guys lounging indolently against the wall are none other than Lois (George), Holland (Ron), Callaway (Jim), you're sure of it.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 7 A sparkling scene of unlimited visibility was dulled by some very limited competition today in the opening round of the America's Cup observation trials.

The corporation that talked the Federal Government out of extra overseas bomber bases has helped to talk the New York City government into a revision of rent controls, slippery water for its fire engines and a reassignment of police detectives in a sharp break with tradition.
To help curb the harassment of firefighters, Mayor Lindsay promised yesterday steps to improve public appreciation of the firefighter's job.
TENAFLY, N.J. What was it like to be alive in the Middle Ages? Drs. Bard and Madeleine Cosman may not know exactly, but they can certainly make a good guess.
CAIRO, July 7 An Israeli Skyhawk fighter-bomber was reported to have been hit by antiaircraft fire today during a raid on Egyptian positions in the central sector of the Suez Canal.

WHITE PLAINS, July 7 A special Westchester County grand jury has blamed "poor planning and mismanagement by city officials on all levels of responsibility" for the difficulties surrounding snow removal in Yonkers after the big snowstorn of Feb. 9, 1969.

WASHINGTON, July 7 An investment analyst who said he was speaking in the name of a newly created National Shareholders Association told Congress today that stockbrokers should be required to make the same disclosures about the operation of their own firms as publicly held corporations were.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Democratic National Committee, opening a novel television assault on President Nixon, laid down the political theme tonight that the Republican Administration was developing a "performance gap" between its promises and its deeds.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark charged today that the Nixon Administration acted sluggishly against traditional school segregation, failed to act at all against new segregation techniques and then misled the public on the extent of actual desegregation.

A decision on the fate of Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., was postponed in Federal District Court yesterday. Judge Edward C. McLean gave interested parties until Friday to file any further papers relating to the validity of proxies cast at the annual-meeting June 15.
TRENTON, July 7 (UPI)The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a homeowner's liability insurance policy covered a case in which he shot his neighbor.
Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic candidate for Governor, was loudly cheered yesterday at a meeting of his party when he attacked Republican policies and Governor Rockefeller's support of them.

The U.S.I.A.'s investment of $80,000 in a split-screen color film about Spiro T. Agnew for overseas audiences was doubtless justified both by world interest and by the need to explain the Vice President to puzzled friends of this country abroad. The United States has few public relations problems of greater magnitude.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 7 (AP)--The Soviet Union added to its gold-medal total at the world amateur Greco-Roman wrestling championships last night, winning five individual titles and taking the over-all team trophy for the second successive year. The Russians won last year in Argentina.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7-President Nixon has promised the South Vietnamese Government $100-million to build badly needed housing for its soldiers and their families, President Nguyen Van Thieu disclosed today.
A new study has raised the question of whether premature babies receive adequate nourishment from standard formulas.

In its last desperate efforts to avoid bankruptcy by seeking a $225-million short-term loan guarantee from the Department of Defense, the Penn Central submitted a confidential financial plan and forecast. This plan indicated that Penn Central's management expected to lose $271 million this year. Next year, however, it would have done better: management foresaw losses of only $221 million!
Smith, Barney Co., Inc., announced yesterday that seven vice presidents have been elected to the board of directors.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Eckhaus of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Eckhaus, to Mortimer J. Altshuler Jr., son of the late Mr. Altshuler and the late Mrs. Rita Louise Alstone.

GENEVA, July 7 Secretary General Thant said at a news conference here today that he and Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, his special representative for the Middle East, had agreed not to reactivate Dr. Jarring's peace mission "for the moment."
Dick Barnett, ad man, will be working right next door to Dick Barnett, basketball star. Terribly convenient.

WASHINGTON, July 7 In a gesture designed to convey his continuing interest in LatinAmerican relations, President Nizon tonight praised the political, social and economic work of the Organization of American States as an example of regional cooperation for the world.
Marjorie Bartholomew Paradis, author and widow of Adrian Frederick Paradis, died last Thursday at LeRoy Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Brooklyn and in Pleasantville, N.Y.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 7 The pilot of a chartered DC-9 jetliner that ran out of fuel and ditched in the Caribbean on May 2 testified today that he could not warn his passengers before the ditching because the plane's public address system was out of order.

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Senate Banking Committee approved the one-bank holding company bill today in a version that is not only considerably less restrictive than the one passed by the House but also less restrictive than that orignally proposed by the Administration.
Why does a five-room rentcontrolled apartment on Riverside Drive cost $500 a month when an apartment identical in size and layout on the floor below cost only $240?
People close to the Pittsburgh Pirates say Roberto Ctemente is a new man this year, He frequently smiles, he jokes with his teammates, he doesn't talk about retiring.
BUCHAREST, July 7 (UPI) The first official appearance in Rumania by an American rock band Blood, Sweat and Tears broke up in a near-riot, witnesses said today.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 7 A little more than two years ago, Thomas Sydney Smith, the black Chief of Police of Asbury Park, told members of the Asbury Park Kiwanis Club:

WASHINGTON, July 7 The Nixon Administration is drafting plans for a $50-million program of military aid for Cambodia in the coming year as part of its continuing effort to bolster Premier Lon Nol's Government against Communist forces.
WASHINGTON, July 7 The House passed today a $98.8million authorization bill for the Peace Corps by a vote of 316 to 46. The measure now goes to conference with the Senate.

There was something quite right about the curtain calls at the Moiseyev Dance Company's opening last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The performers in their Ukrainian costumes were taking a bow on stage and waving at the public in the traditional Russian way. Several hundred feet in front of them, across the darkened rows of seats, several standees waved back.

For the 11th consecutive session, prices on the American Stock Exchange slumped yesterday. Its index closed at 19.63, down 0.12 points from the previous day. It was the lowest level since May 26 when it stood at 19.36.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 7 (AP) Harold S. Vanderbilt, the racing yacht skipper and inventor of contract bridge, was eulogized today at a memorial service at Trinity Episcopal Church. He died Saturday at the age of 86.
The fireman was trying to explain the frustration of struggling to turn on a hydrant as neighborhood children stand around and jeer, and his audience of youngsters looked more or less sympathetic.
The bond market's robust rally moved into its fourth week yesterday, gaining strength as prices continued to advance and interest rates kept moving downward.

WASHINGTON, July 7-A detailed proposal for comprehensive national health insurance was made public today by a private group of influential persons in medicine, philanthropy, civil rights and the Congress.

NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., July 7 Mr. and Mrs. John Monks Starr Hutchinson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Wynne Starr Hutchinson, to John Hugh Phelan of New York, son of the late John Phelan and the late Mrs. Margaret Courtney Phelan.
BELLPORT, L.I. July 7 William E. Richards, chairman of the board of the Peoples National Bank of Long Island, died today in Brookhaven Hospital after a short illness.

The National Bank of North America, an affiliate of CIT Financial Corporation, announced yesterday its previously proposed consolidation with the Trade Bank Trust Company, New York, had been consummated.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -The Federal Trade Commission ordered today an investigation into the breakfast cereal industry to determine whether sugar coatings and cartoon commercials were hiding puffed-up prices and a lack of vigorous competition.
In 1924, America's first diesel-powered locomotive was built for the New York Central Railroad.
LIMA, Peru, July 7 (Reuters) An immense Soviet airlift of supplies to earthquake-stricken northern Peru scheduled for today has been postponed.
An attempted purse-snatching on the upper West Side last night turned into a melee in which at least four persons, including two policemen, were injured and 14 shots were fired.

In the Congressional clamor over major issues like the war in Indochina and the troubled economy, it has gone almost unnoticed that Congress has agreed with the President that the arts and humanities should have substantially increased Federal support.

Just when the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup needs a shot in the arm, along comes Jim Hall to the rescue with a radically new race car based on the groundeffect principle. In esthetic terms the Chaparral 2J is boxy and homely; but aerodynamically it is beautiful ...
BERLIN, July 7 (Reuters) A Swedish and a French film shown at the Berlin International Film Festival, which collapsed Sunday, won international Critics Union prizes here today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 Retail sales declined 1 per cent in May after a sizable increase in April, the Commerce Department reported today.

NEW HAVEN, July 7 Lawyers for Lonnie McLucas, a Black Panther on trial here in the slaying of a party member suspected of being an informer, asked today that a psychiatrist of their choice be allowed to examine a key prosecution witness.

OLD BROOKVILLE L.I., July 7 George Ostrowski, Glen Cove High School, and Ed Franciewicz, Huntington High, will meet tomorrow in the semifinal round of the top half of the draw in the Long Island Golf Association junior championship. Play will continue over the 6,447-yard, par 36, 36-72 Brookville Country Club course.

Miss Celia Juliana Menendez, a research associate in the Columbia University department of biological sciences, will be married Aug. 29 in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church to Joseph Stephen Chamer, who is working for a Ph.D in biochemistry at the New York Medical College.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today grants to projects in certain model cities to conduct a wide variety of antijuvenile delinquency programs.

Cynthia Hill of South Haven, Mich., low amateur in the recent United States women's open golf tournament, was one oP eight golfers invited yesterday by the United States Golf Association to represent the (United States against Britain and Ireland in the Curtis Cup matches at the Brae Burn Country Club in West Newton, Mass., Aug. 7 and 8.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 7 (UPI) A general practitioner has been selling Spiro Agnew wristwatches here for the last few weeks.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 7 Joseph McBride and his son, Michael, of the Arcola Country Club, posted a 34, 34 68 and won the Metropolitan Golf Association father-and-son championship today. McBride had won in 1964, '65 and '66 with an older son, Terry. Play was over the 6,516-yard, par-71 Piping Rock Club course.
Three New York City cultural and educational organizations have received matching grants totaling $700,000 from the National Endowment for the Arts, it was learned yesterday.
Three persons were injured yesterday when a pipe bomb exploded at the Haitian Consulate here. A short time later, explosive devices were found at Portuguese and South African Government offices here.
SAANG, Cambodia, July 7 No one lives in this onceflourishing market town any more, and there is hardly a place left to live.

The chief negotiator of a union that represents 120,000 city employes said yesterday that he expected to reach agreement tomorrow on a new contract with the city that would provide retirement with full pay after 40 years of service and half pay after 20 years.
WASHINGTON, July (AP) An official of the General Elec tric Company said yesterday that the company believed it had good prospects of regaining a $50-million space cotract withdrawn from it last week.
Mrs. Andrew Kerr of Toronto has announced the engagesnent of her daughter, Miss Mary Kerr, to James G. Wallach. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ira D. Wallach of Scarsdale, N.Y.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July For many years a prestige title to be seized by some interloper from abroad, the British Open starts tomorrow with a native son, Tony Jacklin, as the firm favorite in the cast of 134.

Charles Tobias, who with his brothers Harry and Henry wrote hundreds of songs for Broadway shows, films and individual singers, died yesterday of a liver ailment at North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old.

In each high school there should be established an elective and representative student government with offices open to all students. The student government will establish reasonable standards for candidates for office. All students should be allowed to vote in annual elections designed to promote careful consideration of the issues and candidates.
LOUISVILLE, July 7 The Louisville "Black Six" were acquitted today of conspiracy charges filed in connection with racial disorders here in May, 1968.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7 The Lebanese penal court of appeals acquitted a Syrian writer, Dr. Sadiq Galal al-Azm, on a charge of having criticized Islam and fomented strife among religious factions. The decision was widely regarded as a milestone in the struggle for freedom of thought and expression in Arab lands.

The Lindsay administration threatened yesterday to order rent cuts in buildings that have been struck by maintenance and service workers. The strike, which began early Monday in Manhattan, was expected to spread to Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island today.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 7 Irving H. DuFine, president of DuFine Co., Inc., a New York advertising agency, died at his home here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame asked the city's Board of Ethics yesterday to investigate the roles of three city officials involved in two consultant contracts totaling $1.7million.
A graduate of the United States Naval Academy and two natives of Hungary carried the New York Athletic Club to its sixth straight national saber team championship at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.
Bankers don't like it and retailers don't like it, but the consumer seems to love it. It's as if you were getting something for nothing almost.

BALTIMORE, July 7 A grand slam home run by Brooks Robinson with nobody out in the 10th inning gave the Baltimore Orioles a 6-2 victory tonight in the start of the first "important" series played by the New York Yankees in five years.

PARIS, July 7 (AP) Hundreds of young Americans flew home from Europe today in an emergency airlift arranged for 3,500 students temporarily stranded by the financial collapse of a travel agency in Cincinnati, Ohio.

Some plays are so spectacular and improbable that it is hard to imagine them occurring in real life. The defensive play required by the diagramed deal was described in a recent issue of the Bridge World by Robert Ewen, a talented young New York bridge writer. One suspects that he was employing the art of the novelist rather than that of a reporter.
FAYETTE, Miss., July 7 One year as Mayor has not changed Charles Evers, but this tiny town will never be the same.

The Northrop Corporation and the Gates Rubber Company have begun preliminary discussions on a possible purchase by Northrop of Gates's majority holding of the Gates Learjet Corporation. A spokesman indicated the talks were of such a preliminary nature that no actual dollar value could be set at this time.

The New York Mets pieced together another baseball game like a far-fetched jigsaw puzzle last night when they defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, on a two-out walk to Ron Swoboda with the bases loaded in the ninth inning.

Big league ballplayers ordinarily don't have a high opinion of the intelligence quotients of the fans-except when those fans say nice things about them. But now that the balloting has been completed for the starting line-ups for the All-Star game at Cincinnati next Tuesday, the flanneled heroes should make grudging admission that not all fans are dopes.

A shouting crowd of black youngsters invaded the Brooklyn office of Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright yesterday after he announced the appointment of a district school superintendent by the new local governing board of District 23, which in cludes the Ocean Hill-Brownsville section.
WARSAW, July 7 (UPI) West Germany and Poland opened talks today on establishing consular relations.

The American Stock Exchange has laid off nearly 100 more employes, a spokesman confirmed yesterday. The reduction follows the dismissal of 100 workers last May 1 and reduces the current staff to about 850.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 7 Economics Minister Pham Kim Ngoc said today that the Government planned to carry out a devaluation of the piaster this summer "in deed, if not in name."

"The rapid deployment and support of a force of over one quarter of a million men to an area 10,000 miles from our shores clearly demonstrates that our logistics system has that capability. Never before has this country been able to field and support in combat so large a force in so short a time over so great a distance."

While most of the jockeys were struggling to keep their horses from bearnig out on the final turn, Bob Woodhouse made his move aboard Arachne and the filly went on to capture the $15,000 feature at Aqueduct yesterday.

Bowing to a court's temporary restraining order, about 40 mailers yesterday suspended a chapel or union, meeting during working hours at The New York Post that would have crippled production and halted distribution of the papers.

LUANDA, Angola The majestic fortress that dominates the bay of this bustling capital of Portuguese Angola was once a museum, but it has served as headquarters for the Portuguese Army since the nationalist guerrilla offensive began in 1961. Now there is a campaign under way to turn the 17th century Sao Miguel Fortress back into a museum.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) President Nixon signed today legislation to prevent Social Security beneficiaries from being short-changed despite this year's across-the-board increase.

WASHINGTON, July 7-Despite some internal argument about specific Soviet deployments and long-term Soviet intentions, the Nixon Administration is now negotiating on the Middle East with a new sense of urgency and anxiety.

CLARION, Pa., July 7 Miss Terril Lynn Wein, a marketing research field director of N.T. Fouriezos Associates, Inc., in New York, and Paul B. Lichtman, theatrical lawyer with the International Famous Agency, Inc., in New York, plan to be married on July 26 at the Pittsburgh Hilton.

PARIS, July 7 The United States has reaffirmed its position in favor of greater exchange-rate flexibility in the face of opposition by France and by the staff of the International Monetary Fund in Washington.
In the latest of a series of Wall Street merger announcements, Thomson McKinnon Auchincloss, Inc., said yesterday that it would acquire at least 15 branches of Blair Co., Inc.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7 A four-man committee representing the United Arab Republic, the Sudan, Libya and Algeria has worked out a formula that it believes will insure future good relations between the Palestinian commandos and the Jordanian Government.

WASHINGTON, July 7-Despite some internal argument about specific Soviet deployments and long-term Soviet intentions, the Nixon Administration is now negotiating on the Middle East with a new sense of urgency and anxiety.

CLARION, Pa., July 7 Miss Terril Lynn Wein, a marketing research field director of N.T. Fouriezos Associates, Inc., in New York, and Paul B. Lichtman, theatrical lawyer with the International Famous Agency, Inc., in New York, plan to be married on July 26 at the Pittsburgh Hilton.

PARIS, July 7 The United States has reaffirmed its position in favor of greater exchange-rate flexibility in the face of opposition by France and by the staff of the International Monetary Fund in Washington.
In the latest of a series of Wall Street merger announcements, Thomson McKinnon Auchincloss, Inc., said yesterday that it would acquire at least 15 branches of Blair Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) The Atomic Energy Commission denied today published charges quoting two of its scientists as saying they had been persecuted by the commission for having publicly criticized A.E.C. radiation safety policies.

PARIS, July 7 Miss Gustava E. de Rothschild, daughter of Baron and the Baroness Elie de Rothschild, was married today in a religious ceremony to Marc E. Leland, general counsel for the Peace Corps in Washington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Leland of San Francisco.
Four process-servers were indicted in the Bronx yesterday for swearing that they had personally served summonses when, it was alleged, they had not actually done so.

The McDonnell Douglas Corporation received yesterday a Navy contract totaling $247.9-million. Included in the award is a $121.6-million award for RF-4E reconnaissance aircraft and $59.5-million for the TA-4J trainer jet.

The Center-Left Government of Premier Mariano Rumor, Rome's 31st since World War II, took office only three months ago after a seven-week crisis, the longest since 1945. Its resignation and the increasing frequency and duration of political crises in Italy the current one is the fifth in two years stem from factional feuding within the governing Christian Democratic and Socialist parties over two inter-related issues: social reform and cooperation with the Communists.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, predicted yesterday that accountability of teachers for their performance might replace economic issues as the major point of conflict in New York's public school system.
PARIS, July 7 On a quiet suburban campus some played Ping-Pong, some washed clothes, while others stood around wondering what their parents were thinking.
Eli Lilly Co. achieved record sales and earnings in the first half of this year, it reported yesterday, despite a smaller second-quarter gain than in the first three months.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 7 (AP) Fred W. Hooper's Patzier charged from next-to-last today under Garth Patterson and won the $10,000 Summer Scandal Purse at Monmouth Park.
The latest shareholder census by the New York Stock Exchange shows there are 30.85 million American investors. Behind the statistics are some very real political considerations ...
WASHINGTON, July 7 Vice President Agnew said today that there were too few policymaking officials in the Federal Government who had a SpanishAmerican heritage.
MINNEAPOLIS, Wednesday, July 8 (AP) A national strike by clerical workers of Northwest Airlines began at 2 this morning despite the company's offer of a 33.4 per cent pay increase over three years.

WASHINGTON, July 7 Railroad firemen and their union allies struck three of the nation's largest railroads today, disrupting freight and commuter traffic in 16 states. This evening, President Nixon invoked his emergency powers and ordered that the strike be halted.
WASHINGTON, July 7 A staff member of a special House committee that toured the war zone in Indochina today termed its report a "whitewash" and said the panel had suppressed significant findings.

TOLEDO, Ohio, July 7 John T. French, executive vice president of the Toledo Area Convention Bureau, died of a heart attack last night while attending a meeting of Masonic officers as potentate of Toledo's Zenobia Shrine. He was 54 years old.
The Subway Supervisors Association voted 635 to 14 last night to authorize a strike against the Transit Authority to back its wage demands in a contract to replace the one that expired June 30.

Miss Lauren Taylor Levy, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hyman Levy of New York, was married at the Registry Office in Oxford, England, yesterday to Simon. Lester Adams, who is doing research for his doctoral thesis in English history at Balliol College. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper Bernard Adams of New York. His father is president of Windsor Newton, Inc., British artists' supplies maaufactur ers. Dr. Levy is a cardiologist.
The London stock market eased slightly yesterday as lack of buying interest brought a mark down in prices by dealers.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that despite preliminary census figures indicating a sharp decline in urban populations the state's cities would actually receive more unrestricted financial aid in the 1971-72 fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Government announced today a new regulation requiring drivers of commercial trucks and buses in interstate commerce to wear seat belts beginning next year.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 7 The Mayor of this embattled city stood at the corner of Main Street and Springwood Avenue this afternoon and gave his evaluation of the cause of two days of rioting and looting here.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 7 The American Yacht Club crew of Rye, N.Y., with Mrs. Rudolph J. Schaefer 3d, as skipper, and the Larchmont Y.C., Mrs. Susan Houdingas helmswoman, tied for the lead for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound today after four races in the 37th annual Syce Cup regatta were held off the Belle Haven Club.
The Daily News announced yesterday that, starting tomorrow, the price of its paper would be increased from 8 to 10 cents in the city and suburban areas.
An experiment in interracial living is taking place in the woods of the Fresh Air Fund's camping center in Dutchess County.
PARIS, July 7 The first United States track team to visit Paris since 1936 begins a three-meet European series tomorrow night against France.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 Miss Emily Anne MacDonald, daughter of Mrs. Percy MacDonald of Elkins Park, Pa., and the late Mr. MacDonald, was married here today to Dr. Francis Heed Adler, professor emeritus of ophthalmology at the University of Pennsylvania and immediate past president of the American Academy of Ophthalmology. The Rev. Tom Turney Edwards, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony in the garden at Cleve Gate, Dr. Adler's home in Chestnut Hill.
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia To an aging monk, the lonely custodian of a famous 13th-century Serbian Orthodox church near there, the gently rolling plain of Kosovo is "the Serbian Siberia."

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -Trans Caribbean Airways has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to borrow an additional $2-million from American Airlines to meet debts on which T.C.A. is in default and can no longer postpope payments.
Following Monday's sharp break, futures prices of soybeans and wheat closed irregularly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

LONDON The persistent vitality of Britain's Parliamentary system is in a sense symbolically reaffirmed by the new House of Commons which for the first time in its history includes the fourth successive generation of one family, albeit a rather unusual family named Churchill.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The General Assembly of the Organization of American States ended a two-week meeting here today with a call for urgent action on a convention to declare that acts of terrorism, including kidnappings of foreign diplomats, constitute international crimes.

The threat of a truckers' embargo on deliveries in New York City was renewed yesterday after representatives of Teamsters Joint Council No. 16 and of management failed to get Mayor Lindsay's personal attention to their demands for police protection.
The trial of 13 Black Panthers for an alleged bomb conspiracy here will not begin until September, members of the prosecution and defense said yesterday.
The Greek composer Mikis Theodorakis flew in from Paris yesterday to adress the World Youth Assembly at the United Nations saying of his native land that "a dark age is ruling the country now."
NEW ORLEANS, July 8 Government investigators have found potentially dangerous levels of mercury in lakes and streams in 14 Eastern states.
MEXICO CITY, July 8 A new campaign began in Mexico's universities today for the acquittal of Mexican political prisoners, particularly students jailed in 1968.

The General Electric Company previewed yesterday via closed-circuit television in Chicago, Detroit and the Hotel Biltmore here the forerunner of a permanent, closed-circuit custom color TV network. G.E. spokesmen said the new service, called the Command Performance Network, will be available for use in 21 cities next Oct. 1. It will be expanded in 1971 to 35 cities.
The Securities and Exchange Commission and a securities industry task force apparently reached agreement yesterday on a proposed insurance plan for investors at a special meeting in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The so-called family assistance program is a legislative Janus that probably could have emerged only from a conservative Administration. On the one hand, it provides for putting ablebodied welfare recipients to work and allows them to keep a percentage of what they earn. Thus it holds out, to those who regard welfare recipients as deadbeats, the possibility of people working themselves off the rolls.

DUBLIN, July 8 On Monday afternoon in Belfast, women and old men stood in the doorways of their tight row houses in the Roman Catholic Falls Road area and talked of the British Army raid of the weekend, of the curfew and of the battles between Catholics and soldiers.
TOKYO, July 8 (Reuters) Japan's export-import bank signed an agreement here today to supply Mexico with a $20million loan for hydro and thermal power projects.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) A Government technical committee recommended today a Federal tax or a subsidy to make it cheaper for motorists to use gasoline free of lead, which is considered a prime cause of air pollution.
LONDON, July 8 Roy Jenkins was elected deputy leader of the Labor Party today. In the opinion of many he thus becomes Harold Wilson's heir presumptive.

NORWALK, Conn., July 8 Some polluted beaches in Connecticut are being deliberately kept open illegally by health officials to avoid possible rioting in the slums, a witness charged at a hearing today.

John C. Duncan has been elected senior vice president, effective Oct. 1 of St. Joe Minerals Corporation. He formerly was executive vice president and a director of W.R. Grace Co. He will continue as a director of that company.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Douglas Toms, the Nixon Administration's automotive safety chief, is considering private employment after less than six months in office and may leave Washington by the end of this year.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 8 A crewman who survived the ditching of a DC-9 jetliner in the Caribbean May 2 leveled sharp criticism today at many of the airline industry's standard emergency ocean ditching procedures.
BONN, July 8 The West German Government announced today a six-point program to dampen the overheated economy through temporary tax increases and advance payments on income taxes.

MOSCOW, July 8 (Reuters) Natalya Gorbanevskaya, a 33-year-old Russian poet, has been declared insane after being investigated for alleged anti-Soviet slander, sources close to dissident circles said today.

SOMEWHERE IN SOUTH VIETNAM, July 5 An American general and his civilian and military intelligence specialists filed into the austere living room of a young American who is the chief adviser to the local South Vietnamese province chief.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The United States Bureau of Mines will hire more than 100 new coal mine inspectors over the next two months to bring its inspection force to almost 500, its highest level ever.
DETROIT, July 8 The United Automobile Workers said today that its contract demands could be met from the profits of the automobile industry.
Is it possible that some major mutual funds are doing a far worse job of investing their shareholders' money over the long term than is generally believed?

PARIS, July 8 President Nixon has appointed a diplomat of stature to head the American delegation at a time when the Vietnam peace talks have reached the lowest point since they began as a four-sided negotiation in January, 1969.

The commercial paper market, which has been the center of the financial storm that has swept through Wall Street since the default of the Penn Central Transportation Company appears to have passed through the worst of its crisis.
To be effective, any cease-fire agreement for the explosive Suez front must encompass a number of essential elements.
LOS ANGELES, July 8 (Reuters) A courtroom sketch led today to a further delay in the trial of four defendants accused in the murder of Sharon Tate, the actress and others.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP)--The Justice Department confirmed today that it had been asked for a ruling on conflict-of-interest questions involving four board members of the Federal National Mortgage Association. Fanny May, as it is called, is a privately owned corporation chartered by the Government to deal in the secondary mortgage market. The Department of Housing and Urban Development made the request.

SYRACUSE, July 8 The United Automobile Workers of New York State endorsed Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor today, and the candidate, flying here to accept the endorsement, said the Democratic party could learn a needed lesson from labor.

A merger of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific and the Union Pacific Railroads, to be followed by purchase of almost half of the Rock Island's trackage by the Southern Pacific Company, was recommended to the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday by its examiner, Nathan Klitenic.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 8 "Who Cares?" is a ballet about boys and girls intoxicated with the sparkle of their own champagne spirits, and none tingles the palate so piquantly as Jacques d'Amboise. He is a tiger of sophisticated and yet innocent energy as he bounds after his three loves, winsome Marnee Morris, confident Karin von Aroldingen and glittering Patricia McBride.

RICHMOND, July 8 (AP) The Olin Corporation told the State Water Control Board yesterday that it was being forced to shut down production of soda ash at its Saltville plant because there was no way to treat the stream-killing wastes from the plant.

The surreptitious visit by Ireland's Foreign Minister to Catholic areas of Belfast constitutes an unfortunate escalation of the explosive Protestant-Catholic confrontation. As Sir Alec Douglas-Home says, it magnifies the difficulties for those who are working to restore peace in Northern Ireland. It will further endanger those very Catholic communities with whom Dr. Hillery was trying to demonstrate Eire's solidarity.
New York City's municipal hospitals reported yesterday that during the first week that the new abortion law has been in effect 207 pregnancies had been terminated.
TAMPA, Fla., July 8 (AP) A Federal judge has forbidden the city of Clearwater to levy a special tax on theaters showing X-and R-rated movies.

TOKYO, July 8 (AP) Secretary of State William F. Rogers told Premier Eisaku Sato today that the breakdown in the textile negotiations between the two Governments last month would not affect the agreement on the Okinawa to Japanese rule in 1972, a high United States official said.

NEWTON, Mass., July 8 The engagement of Miss Roslyn Beth Weinstein to Stuart Holland Orkin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lazarus A. Orkin of New York, has been announced by the future bride's mother, Mrs. Jacob Weinstein.

Senator Margaret Chase Smith underwent a three-hour operation at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center yesterday in which her right hip was replaced, according to a hospital spokesman, who added that the 72-year-old Maine Republican "came through in fine Shape."
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) A bipartisan group including liberals and conservatives joined today in an effort to take the secrecy out of House votes. and won the support of the leaders of both parties.
BONN, July 8 Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that he had "reason to hope" for ultimate success in efforts to conclude a nonaggression treaty with the Soviet Union.
Jim Davenport did a lot for the San Francisco Giants in 13 seasons, but he never made a more beneficial move for them than he did Monday.
The stock market turned around yesterday after absorbing a pounding earlier this week and produced a brisk rally that was going strong at the final bell with the tape one minute late.

The American Courier Corporation of Lake Success, L.I., has filed suit against the Wachovia Corporation and three of its subsidiaries in Winston-Salem, N.C., charging violations of the antitrust laws and the Federal banking laws.

PRAGUE, July 8 (Reuters) The Czechoslovak Federal Assembly today unanimously approved the dismissal of Alexander Dubcek, former party leader, as a deputy and accepted the resignation of former Premier Oldrich Cernik.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) House leaders decided late today to schedule for tomorrow the first test of the Senate imposed limitation on Presidential action in Cambodia.

One thing that's been missing in department stores is the thrift shop. That breach has been filled by Altman's with a Cozy, lamp-lighted room on the sixth floor called Yesterday's News. While Connie Boswell, Jimmy Dorsey, Glen Gray and Bing Crosby perform venerable ...

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands In the Netherlands, where the put-on has been developed into weapon of nonviolent resistance, foes of the automobile and the wrecker have come up with a new one. They are painting "zebras" pedestrian crossings that give the walker the right of way where none are supposed to be.
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 8 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Essex County, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association champion, took a big step toward another title today.

FORT LEE, N.J.; July 8 Mr. and Mrs. Orlando Gargiulo of Fort Lee, and Capri, Italy, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Josephine Joan Gargiulo, to Dr. John M. Templeton Jr., son of Mr. Templeton of Nassau, the Bahamas, and the late Mrs. Judith Dudley Templeton of Nashville.

A Queens County grand jury said yesterday that the May 20 subway collision that killed two persons and injured about 70 others was caused by a series of "grossly negligent" human errors and several "inherently dangerous" and "defective" aspects of the subway system itself.

DETROIT, July 8 Henry Ford 2d called today a Federal Court decision to strip the Ford Motor Company of its spark plug business and make it give up the name Autolite "wholly unwarranted." He said the company was undecided whether it would appeal.

The 45-member American Waterways Wind Orchestra, conducted by Robert Boudreau, will give the first concert in a tour of Hudson River communities on July 19 in Yonkers. The two-week trip is sponsored by the Hudson River Valley Commission.

Several major producers of lead reduced their prices yesterday by 1 cent a pound to 15.5 cents a pound, but the company that started the action and one of its biggest competitors disagreed on the need for the cut.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 8 A 28-man patrol of black residents walked the streets in this seaside resort city's black community tonight to calm bitter residents and to halt the racial disturbances that have raged off and on since Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, July 8 President Nixon spoke tonight to the Women's National Press Club 50th Anniversary Dinner, but 83-yearold Alice Roosevelt Longworth, whose father was in the White House before the club was organized, got the biggest standing ovation without saying a word.
Mrs. Irving Kolodin, wife of the music critic and associate editor of Saturday Review, died Tuesday night of a heart attack at the age of 63.
COLOMBES, France, July 8 The French were saying they would be more than happy with five victories in two days.

TOKYO, July 8 South Vietnam and Cambodia, and South Korea, Thailand and Philippines as well, have told Secretary of State William P. Rogers that the United States must not reduce its military, political and economic commitments in the Pacific region in any serious way.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) The American viewing public got less than a whole movie in 84 per cent of the films broadcast by the major television network during a sixmonth period last year, the Federal Trade Commission said today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 A bipartisan group of 14 Senators filed a complaint today against the three television networks, charging that they were being denied an opportunity to present their views against the Administration's policy in Vietnam.

A creeping escalation by both sides in the embattled Suez Canal zone adds urgency to Secretary of State Rogers's proposal for a limited cease-fire to facilitate negotiations for an Arab-Israeli peace settlement.
DETROIT, July 8 (UPI) Edgar M. Branigin, former newspaperman, politician and Wayne County Clerk, since 1947, died at Jennings Memorial Hospital yesterday. He was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 8--The Air Force announced today the selection of the Boeing Company of Seattle to carry out the first phase of a $2-billion program to improve the nation's defense against invading aircraft.

STOCKTON, Calif., July 8 (AP) The Rev. Tillman Sherron Jackson, president of the Baptist Foundation of America Inc., is free on $5,000 bail on three indictments charging him with theft and taking part in bribes.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Senate unexpectedly approved today a $20,000 limit on the amount of money the Government would pay to any individual farmer under Federal crop control programs in the next year.

In a review of business conditions during May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York cited yesterday declines in major economic categories industrial output, employment, working hours, private wages and salaries.
WASHINGTON, July 8 President Nixon denounced today "centuries of injustice" to the American Indians and proposed a comprehensive program to give them dignity and control over their destiny.

Every day is a dog day in this the Chinese Year of the Dog. And to the astronomically minded, these are the days when Sirius, the dog star, rises and sets with the sun. It is also the period when canine discomfort is at its peak. The dog owner can help his pet get through the ...

BALTIMORE, July 8 The most inspiring sort of victory for the Baltimore Orioles, and the most dispiriting sort of defeat for the New York Yankees, was the story in a spectacular ball game before 35,000 persons here tonight, the largest crowd of the season in Memorial Stadium.
A jury of four women and eight men began deliberating the fate of Dr. Martin Sweig, suspended chief administrative assistant of House Speaker John W. McCormack, last night.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 8 Intrepid and Valiant won again today in the America's Cup observation trials, setting the stage for a confrontation tomorrow.

The Conservative party's candidate for United States Senator, James L. Buckley, said yesterday that he would back both President Nixon's efforts to win peace in the Middle East and Southeast Asia and his foreign policy in general.
BOSTON, July 8 (AP) A Federal court panel ruled unconstitutional today a Massachusetts law that requires a year's residency before a person can be registered to vote.
ROME, July 8 President Giuseppe Saragat opened formal consultations with political leaders today in a search for a successor to Premier Mariano Rumor, who resigned with his Cabinet on Monday.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 8 Rain delayed the completion today of what looked to be the finest round ever shot in the British Open golf tournament. Tony Jacklin was eight under par for 13 holes when thunder and lightning struck and the course was deluged.

The Flying Tiger Corporation, formed July 1 as a holding company that owns the Flying Tiger Line, purchased yesterday 520, figures shares of common stock of the North American Car Corporation. This is 16.6 per cent of the outstanding stock.
