WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) President Nixon ordered today the creation of a Vice-Presidential Service Badge to be awarded to military personnel who have been assigned to duty in the office of the Vice President.

After their rise slowed perceptibly in the previous two days prices of wheat and soybean futures continued their rather rapid climb yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Other grain futures prices, except for those of rye, followed the example set by the wheat contracts.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 The Seawanhaka-Corinthian Yacht Club crew from Oyster Bay. L.I., with Mrs. W. Perry Neff as helmswoman, won the 37th annual women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound for the Syce Cup today.

An audience estimated at 40,000 people serenaded Dorothy Kirsten Tuesday night, singing "Happy Birthday" to the soprano at Crocheron Park in Queens. The occasion was the Metropolitan Opera's first concert-in-the-park version of "La Boheme" this summer.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange reversed the long downward trend yesterday and moved up as measured by the exchange's index. It closed at 19.76, up 0.13.
ST. PAUL, July 8 (AP) One of four companies suing the International Business Machines Corporation in a complicated antitrust case was granted a qualified temporary restraining order today.

The Communist party offered yesterday to "reconsider" running a candidate in the 18th Congressional District in Harlem and to join an independent coalition behind Adam Clayton Powell if the independents backed the party on foreign and domestic policy.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Peace Corps announced today a pilot program designed to place returned volunteers in urban jobs where their skills and experience will benefit society.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 8 The Democratic party, by a 44to-29 per cent margin, is seen by a sample of the nation's voters as the party that will do the better job of keeping the country prosperous for the next few years, the Gallup Poll reported today.

JERUSALEM, July 8 There is a growing feeling here among Israelis that their Government will have to make some sharp response to the threat posed by the Soviet antiaircraft missile system now operating on the Egyptian side of the Suez Canal.
Nature abhors a vacuum, according to the old axiom. For a while there has been an empty space, a kind of noman's-land, in the securities business with regard to the small investor. But not any more.

Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, yachtsman, originator of contract bridge and railroad financier, has left $41-million to Vanderbilt University and $9-million to other educational or charitable institutions in six states.
NEW HAVEN, July 8 Jury selection in the first of a series of trials of Black Panthers here was completed today with the seating of a third alternate juror.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 Miss Mildred La Verne Sharpe, a lawyer with the Office for Civil Rights of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, plans to be married Aug. 15 in Washington to Dr. Oliver Morse, professor of law at Howard University Law School.

DARIEN, Conn., July 8 Mrs. William Granniss Tankoos of Darien has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lindsay Tankoos, to Gregory James Geelhood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth L. Geelhood of Northbrook, Ill. The wedding is planned for Aug. 15 at St. Luke's Episcopal Church here.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The State Department said today that the United States had officially informed the Government of South Korea of its intention to withdraw some of the 60,000 American troops in that country.

LOS ANGELES, July 8?Chester Stratton, an actor whose career included the theater, radio, television and motion pictures, died at his home here yesterday apparently of a heart attack or a stroke. He was 57 years old.

Charles O. Finley, the owner of baseball's Oakland Athletics, failed to meet the $4.5-million purchase price for the National Hockey League's Oakland Seals, Trans National Communications Inc., announced late last night.

Activities. The President met with eight leaders of the Taos Pueblo Indian tribe, two officers of the National Congress of American Indians, Vice President Agnew, Interior Secretary Hickel, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Richardson, and two advisers, Donald Rumsfeld and Leonard Garment, before sending a message to Congress on Indian affairs. Later, the President conferred with Defense Secretary Laird and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, counselor to the President.

ATHENS, July 8 An Athens military tribunal sent 10 persons to prison on sedition charges today with sentences ranging from two years to life. It also sentenced one of their attorneys to a year in jail for contempt of court.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) Service resumed on three major rail lines today as a Presidential panel prepared to in vestigate the cause of a brief selective walkout by the United Transportation Union.
ROSWELL, N.M. From World War II until three years ago, the Air Force was Roswell's biggest cash crop. Then, with little warning, there was blight.
Most interest rates continued to march briskly toward lower levels yesterday, but Government securities limped behind the parade.

Larry Sawyer said he was a tight end; Brian Waters identified himself as a defensive back; Dominick LaVacca as a quarterback and a flanker; Al Chandler as a cornerback, and Greg Akula as a split end. But it was not the names that were important to Alan Webb, coach of the Long Island Bulls.

WASHINGTON, July 8? Walter J. Hickel, the Secretary of the Interior, has had a less than placid relationship with the White House since writing that letter to President Nixon. And today he was forgotten by Vice President Agnew, whom he criticized in the letter.
Prices on the London stock market closed steady to firm yesterday after an earlier extension of their recent decline Trading remained light.

Two weeks ago, Myrta Hargen O'Dwyer was a happy bride, posing for photographers with her husband, Rory O'Dwyer, and his father, Paul O'Dwyer, who two days before had been defeated in his race for the Democratic nomination for the Senate.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The Federal Trade Commission, in a step it described as "innovative" in the consumer field, is trying to force the Coca-Cola Company to pay $100 each to thousands of unsuccessful contestants in a promotional game called "Big Name Bingo."

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 8 (AP) The Thai Government announced today the capture of the highest ranking Thai Communist and said that the arrest would severely cripple the clandestine Communist movement in Thailand.

Miss Katherine Alice Mooney, a 1969 graduate of William Penn College, and Frank Martucci, who received a Bachelor of Arts degree this May from William Penn, will be married Aug. 8 in Forest Hills, Queens.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The second quarter of this year showed the first really significant rise in unemployment and easing of the labor market during the current economic slowdown, according to a new measure of unemployment developed outside the government.
The city obtained an injunction last night barring landlords, in effect, from further organized resistance to a proposed new contract with striking building maintenance and service workers.

Oceanographers from the Navy and Princeton University believe discoveries on the Pacific Ocean floor southwest of Central America support the view that the earth's crust is formed of gigantic plates that push and pull at one another.
News Summary and Index

The city's Corporation Counsel, J. Lee Rankin, asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to reject a legal move by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association that seeks to block an investigation of allegations of police corruption.
ST. JOHN, Virgin Islands, July 8 (AP) The first allfemale team of American aquanauts were in their underwater chamber today when an earthquake shook the Virgin Islands and surrounding Caribbean area.
Joseph Elliott of the Mori Fencing Academy in Beverly Hills, Calif., won the national epee title last night on the strips of the Hotel Commodore's grand ballroom.
LONDON, July 8 Penguin Books, the great paperback house, is to be taken over by S. Pearson Son, a British holding company with major publishing interests.

BUCHAREST, July 8 The 48-hour visit of the Soviet Premier, Aleksi N. Kosygin, ended in cordiality today, and Government spokesmen declared that the new friendship treaty signed during his stay represented an encouraging improvement in relations between the two Communist nations.
The Advertising Council yesterday unveiled the new five-pronged campaign against drug abuse that might well turn out to be the biggest volunteer advertising effort in its history.
TRW, Inc., set records for sales and earnings in the second quarter and first half, H.A. Shepard, chairman, reported from the company's Cleveland headquarters yesterday.

The Bankers Trust New York Corporation a $9.78-billion registered bank holding, company, reported yesterday that income before security transactions edged up slightly in the second quarter from the corresponding 1969 period, though it was not enough to raise the per-share earnings above $1.34.
ROME, July 8 Bernard Cardinal Alfrink, Roman Catholic primate of the Netherlands, arrived today for talks with Pope Paul VI on the celibacy of priests.

Having survived strikes, riots, demonstrations, counterdemonstrations and decentralization, the city public school system is now summoned in the summer lull to prove that it can survive satire, too. A satirist has risen from its own ranks.
LONDON, July 8 The Irish Foreign Minister, Dr. Patrick J. Hillery, tonight rejected official British criticism of his secret tour of a riot-torn Roman Catholic neighborhood in Belfast on Monday.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 Arthur Daley, sports columnist for The New York Times, and Mrs. Daley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Blake Daley, to Paul Francis Fennelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl L. Fennelly of Frackville, Pa.

RABAT, Morocco, July 8 King Hassan II announced tonight that a new Moroccan constitution would be submitted to a national referendum July 24 and that if it was approved, Morocco would return to parliamentary democracy with legislative elections next month.

WASHINGTON, July 8 The House of Representatives approved today legislation immunizing from attack under the antitrust laws all existing joint operations of separately owned newspapers and most future arrangements of the same kind.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 8 When Herve Filion left here June 27, he was harness racing's last angry man. That was after the $94,335,42 Realization Trot had been staged at Roosevelt Raceway and Filion had stormed out in a huff after Harness Racing Commission officials had declined to take an additional test of Crain Hanover.
WOLFEBORO, N.H., July 8 John Heathcote, a retired detective who has been fishing the waters of Lake Winnipesaukee for 30 years, has only one complaint about it. It's too large.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 8 (AP) Northwest Airlines operated at 35 to 40 per cent of normal in its nationwide system today after clerical workers had gone on strike and mechanics and some pilots honored their picket lines.

WASHINGTON, July 8 Dr. G. Alexander Heard, President Nixon's special adviser on campus problems, denied today that he was preparing a report for the President saying that student unrest had destroyed Columbia University and the University of California at Berkeley as great academic institutions.

NEW HAVEN, July 8 A conservation group disclosed today that it had filed a formal protest with the Federal Power Commission to block plans to study the feasibility of building a huge hydroelectric plant in either Northwestern Connecticut or Southwestern Massachusetts.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 8 (Reuters) Frank Sinatra, a lifelong Democrat who campaigned hard for the Kennedy Brothers, today joined the campaign to re-elect Gov. Ronald Reagan, a conservative Republican.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 8 Morris Markin, founder and president of the Checker Motors Corporation died yesterday at Bronson Hospital after having suffered a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, Conn. "This is one of the oddest pasta dishes," Jack Denton Scott was saying, "but one of the best for summer."

MADRID, July 8 (Reuters) Rabbi Chaim U. Lipschitz of Brooklyn today met Generalissimo Francisco Franco, the man he credits with having intervened to save more than 60,000 Jews from the Nazis in the World War II.

A tentative contract agreement between the Albert Einstein Medical College of Yeshiwa University and the Drug and Hospital Union last night ended a one-day work stoppage by union members at the college and Lincoln Hospital and the Municipal Hospitals Center in the Bronx.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (Reuters) The South Vietnamese military command announced the start of a new operation in southeastern Cam bodia today.

One of the best collections of bridge deals ever published, and almost certainly the biggest, appeared last month. It is a series of four paperbound books by Alfred Sheinwold published by Pocket Books at 75 cents.

There is particular irony in the outbreak of racial hostility and violence in Asbury Park, an aging holiday resort of the white middle class. Asbury owes its origin to the fact that a New York businessman visited the Ocean Grove camp meeting in 1870 and was inspired to develop a large summering place nearby for temperance advocates, so that no wicked influences might encroach on the adjoining camp meeting.
PARIS, July 8 The major industrialized nations decided today to go slow on introducing greater flexibility to the monetary system.
WASHINGTON, July 8 The President's Science Advisory Committee is considering the merits of setting up a new organization to help guide national science policy.
CARSON CITY, Nev., July 8 (AP) Twenty-five judges are spending the night sleeping on prison cots behind barred doors at the Nevada State Prison.

SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, June 26 The air of this riverside city is soft with the fragrance of linden blossoms and harsh with the weight of plaster dust. Only at night can one hear the rush of water through the Vardar River's rocky bed. By daylight the clang of girders and the clash of piledrivers overwhelm all other sounds.
A state appeals court ruled yesterday that a regulatory agency as well as law enforcement bodies had the right to inspect grand jury transcripts for use in civil matters.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 8 (AP) Victor Mosca's Double Ripple left the gate first, drew off to a seven length lead on the backstretch and outlasted What A Dream to win the $44,750 Molly Pitcher Handicap by three-quarters of a length today at Monmouth Park.
LONDON, July 8 Dame Laura Knight, the painter of circus, theater and race track scenes, died today at her London home. She was 92 years old.

A spokesman for the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade said yesterday that the board would ask fleet owners to pull their cabs off the street from midnight until 6 A.M. until the city provided more police protection in high-crime areas.
LONDON, July 8 The gardeners and fishermen of England have been warned that a vegetable menace has escaped from captivity. It is called the giant hogweed.
LONDON, July 8 (AP) Britain called on 11 nations today to help reactivate the International Control Commission for Laos as a first step toward restoring peace there.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8 Gen. Emilio G. Medici, the President of Brazil, today named the last three of 22 candidates for state gubernatorial elections in all of Brazil's states next Oct. 3.

Top Round proved to be of prime quality in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. James Cox Brady's 4-year-old filly scored an impressive victory over C.V. Whitney's Watch Fob in the 11-16-mile turf event for fillies and mares, with the favored Princess Pout winding up third in the field of seven.

The Mets are doing their thing early this season, all right. They defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 7-5, yesterday before an afternoon Shea Stadium crowd of 48,999, swept the three-game series and extended their best winning streak of the year to six games.
A book of interest to all American chess buffs is the "1969 United States Chess Championship and World Championship Zonal Qualifier" by Morton Siegel, a national master.

"Alimony junkie" (n.) A woman who lives on alimony from her ex-husband, Usually content to sit around the house, over-eating, drinking heavily, and watching television all day long. Loathe to take a job, or remarry. Major goal in life: Making life miserable for her former spouse.
A hearing on a petition by The New York Post for an injunction to prevent Mailers Union No. 6 from holding union meetings at the paper during working time was adjourned yesterday until next Thursday.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (Reuters) The State Department said today that the United States Government was very concerned about reported prison conditions at Con Son, an island in South Vietnam.

BALTIMORE, July 8 Federal District Judge Roszel C. Thomsen decided today to drop his attempt to get The New York Times to divulge the source of information for its articles concerning a secret grand jury report.

The Minister of Mines for Indonesia said here yesterday that some of his nation's 120 million citizens eventually and inevitably would look with envy at the hundreds of millions of dollars in foreign capital that was expected to be invested in the country's mining and petroleum development.

CAIRO, July 8 Cairo's official spokesman said today that despite denunciations by Arabs of the latest United States peace proposals on the Middle East, Egyptian officials were studying them, "even between the lines," in the hope of finding something to discuss.
Balked in his attempt to abolish the city marshal system, Mayor Lindsay named a screening committee yesterday to suggest nominees for the jobs.
Federal authorities have informed New York City officials that they can expect $33.3-million in additional funds for urban renewal housing planned in nine neighborhoods.

In a continuing controversy over the city's use of outside consultants, Mayor Lindsay and Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday challenged each other's figures on the pace of the city's construction program.

Mounting garbage in apartment hallways, basements and on doorsteps is a nuisance to tenants of buildings struck by maintenance and service workers here, but city and health officials said yesterday that the situation was still far from critical.

WASHINGTON, July 8 A spokesman for the mutual fund industry asked the Congress today to exempt from the coverage and costs of the proposed broker-dealer insurance plan those small brokers who sell only mutual funds and fund underwriters who do not do a general securities business.

Gerrie Sue Jacobson, a group leader of the Metropolitan New York Council of American Youth Hostels, died of head injuries yesterday in the Bangor (Me.) Medical Center after being thrown from her bicycle. She was 22 years old and lived at 110-45 71st Road, Forest Hills, Queens.
HOUSTON, July 8 (Reuters) The United States may celebrate its 200th anniversary in 1976 with a big international venture in space, informed sources at the spacecraft center here say.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's 1970 earnings will be substantially above last year's, the chairman and president, Harold S. Geneen, said yesterday.
Several major retail chains, including two in the supermarket field, reported yesterday increased sales in June compared with year-earlier levels.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 8 There's a rhythm in land's end here, not only of surf and seasons, but also of spirits and labors.
DENVER, July 8 (AP) Vice President Agnew said today he did not think anything he had said had any "monumental significance" in campus disorders.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 8 The command post for the police control of the racial disturbances here was abruptly moved late today from a cluttered Police Department office on the second floor of the Municipal Building on downtown Bangs Street to the high school on Sunset Avenue.
The pace of monetary expansion is continuing gradually to slow, banking data published yesterday showed.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Small Business Administration apparently can recognize a trend when it sees one. It has published in the Federal Register the following notice:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 9 (Reuters) Republican party leaders said today that they would offer no candidate to oppose George C. Wallace in the Nov. 3 general election for Governor, leaving him only token opposition.
MIAMI, July 9 (AP) Frank Smathers Sr., father of former Senator George A. Smathers, Democrat of Florida, died yesterday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 88 years old.
Remember the good old pre-1969 days when every weekend seemed to bring news of another massive take-over attempt?
A jury of four women and eight men last night found Dr. Martin Sweig guilty of one count of perjury and acquitted him on six other counts after deliberating last night and all day yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP) Bob Menne turned in a sixunder-par 66 today and took the first-round lead in the $110,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.

Members of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospitals Union yesterday overwhelmingly approved a new two-year contract, ending a one-day work stoppage at institutions run by the Albert Einstein Medical College, the Bronx.

SAN JUAN, P. R., July 9 The co-pilot of a jetliner that ran out of fuel and ditched at sea May 2 said today that he had never flown the route before and that his employer had repeatedly denied requests for training to prepare him for the flight.
Stock prices advanced briskly yesterday for the second straight day as an increase in institutional activity sent trading volume higher.

William Harvey Reeves, a lawyer who specialized in international law, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 273 Harbor Road in Southport, Conn., and at 200 East 66th Street.

Men in their prime employment years who live in one of the city's four major poverty areas are three times as likely to be unemployed as men in the same age bracket elsewhere in the nation, according to a survey released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Israel was understood today to have informed the United States that she intended to step up sharply raids against Soviet missile installations in the United Arab Republic, but not to resume her "deep penetration" attacks against the Egyptian heartland.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 9 (AP) The state police arrested three members of the town of Providence's volunteer fire company late yesterday and charged them with setting more than 20 fires in their area in the last 18 months.

For the last two years, New Yorkers have come to identify the Preservation Hall Jazz Band as the six-piece group led by Billie and DeDe Pierce. But while this band has visited New York several times, another Preservation Hall Jazz Band, led by Kid Thomas Valentine, has also been on tour.

WEST PAWLET, Vt., July 9 Mr. and Mrs. James McClenahan Mertz of West Pawlet, and Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Allegra Standing Mertz to Owen Cates Torrey Jr. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mrs. Owen C. Torrey of New York and the late Mr. Torrey.

A son was born on June 30 to Mr. and Mrs. John Jermaine Slocum Jr. of New York in Doctors Hospital. The child has been named for his father, who is with the private banking house of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 The World Youth Assembly opened today with a plea from Secretary General Thant for idealistic youth to lead the world away from tension an appeal that was quickly lost under a blanket.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Senate passed today an $8-billion Agriculture Department appropriations bill that includes a $20,000 annual limit

Red Reality won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday as a 1-to-2 favorite. But even the most devoted of his adherents among the 27,861 spectators were willing to concede that the Cragwood Stable's gelding did not win like a 1-to-2 shot.

Edwin S. Friendly, a former president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association whose newspaper management career spannd more then 50 years, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old on June 15.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Supporters of President Nixon's welfare reform program were encouraged today when the Senate Finance Committee announced that it would resume suspended hearings on the legislation later this month.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (Reuters) Huey Newton's chance of being released from jail were put further in doubt today by a request from the State Attorney General's office that the manslaughter conviction against the Black Panther party leader be confirmed.
Sears, Roebuck Co. and the J. C. Penney Company, the country's two largest retailers of general merchandise, reported yesterday their lowest monthly sales for the year in June.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 The United States Command reported today that 61 Americans were killed in action in the Indochina war last week, the lowest toll in more than three and a half years.

LONDON, July 9 (Reuters) Bernard Cornfeld, who founded the Investors Overseas Services mutual-fund empire, announced tonight he was forming a new company. His announcement came one week after he was voted off the I. O. S. board of directors.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The United States is trying to persuade the South Vietnamese Government to do away with the so-called "tiger cages" at its island prison on Con Son, 140 miles southeast of Saigon.

MANILA, July 9 The church hierarchy of this predominantly Roman Catholic nation denounced yesterday what it termed Government abuses, and urged public vigilance to promote governmental responsibility.

"King: A Filmed Record From Montgomery to Memphis," the three-hour documentary about the civil rights work of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., which had a one-day benefit showing on March 24 in 300 cities throughout the country, will be released for theatrical engagements in the fall. It has been booked for its initial run at the Astor Theater, Broadway on 45th Street, to open July 29.

BALTIMORE, July 9 The New York Yankees finally got out of Baltimore tonight with a victory to their credit but it was a long, hard, wet struggle that didn't last quite eight innings. The game was called because of rain, as a 7-5 Yankee decision with one out and a man on second in the home half of the eighth.
A band of youths scuffled with the police, mauled passersby and shouted obscenities in City Hall Park yesterday. Two boys were arrested.
BRUSSELS, July 9 Authoritative Western military sources contend that the Soviet Union is at "flood tide" in a vast expansion of conventional and nuclear military strength.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Corporate shareholders have broad rights to participate in corporate decisions that have social impact and any denial of those rights has to be based on clearly stated reasons, the United States Court of Appeals here has held.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 9 (AP) Francis X. Mancuso, a former judge of New York's Court of General Sessions who was also a leader in Tammany Hall, died here yesterday after being stricken in his oceanside apartment. He was 82 years, old.

The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Secor D. Browne, says he thinks the nation's major scheduled airlines are safe for at least a year from cash shortages that could produce an airline crisis similar to the Penn Central railroad difficulties.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 9 Gov. Ronald Reagan said today the Federal effort to make California raise benefits to families with needy children would add $70-million to the costs of an "already too expensive program."
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 9 (UPI) June Darling, making the first start of her career, captured the $70,625 Lassie Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Hollywood Park today by nearly three lengths.

LUANDA, Angola The new affluence in this Portuguese territory fostered by a 10-yearold war with nationalists has led many here to criticize the nature of its relationship with Portugal. Lisbon's Ministry for Overseas Provinces is accused of viewing Angola with "a colonial mentality."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 9 The United States Army disclosed today that Maj. Gen. George W. Casey, who directed the withdrawal of the last American ground troops from Cambodia on June 29, has been missing since Tuesday when he took off in his helicopter. An intensive search is under way, an Army spokesman said.

CHICHESTER, England, July 9 Chichester this year is evidently an unhealthy place for stars. Pneumonia first struck Christopher Plummer out of the cast of "Peer Gynt" and now Lawrence Harvey has retired from "Arms and the Man" with a broken leg.

WASHINGTON, July 9 The Congressional Joint Economic Committee received today a generally reassuring picture of the nation's financial markets, the future of interest rates and even the problem of "liquidity."

The New York Mets will pay tribute tomorrow to the man who invented them, Charles Dillon Stengel. What's that? He didn't invent them? Oh, well, it certainly seems that way. He presided as a midwife of sorts at the birth of the Mets, then nurtured this puniest offspring through the harrowing underprivileged years and finally stepped aside to watch this creature of his imagination become champions of the world.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 A novel method was introduced today to vanquish that old golfing bugaboo slow play.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Following is a list of existing agencies that would be regrouped under an independent Environmental Protection Agency and the new National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration of the Departrnent of Commerce if Congress does not object to President Nixon's reorganization plans:
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee neared agreement today on a controversial bill that would impose quotas on imports of shoes and non-cotton textiles.
WASHINGTON, D. C. People who sit near Mrs. Richard Helms at dinner parties are very likely to find themselves worrying about the percentage of phosphates in detergents.

CAIRO, Friday, July 10 Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, editor of Al Ahram and Minister of National Guidance, disclosed today that two Egyptian attempts to move antiaircraft missiles to the Suez Canal zone had been "suicidal" because of Israeli air attacks. But the third attempt, completed recently, was a startling success, he wrote.

VIENTIANE, Laos, July 9 (Agence France-Presse) The three members of the International Control Commission on Indochina Poland, India and Canada have just signed their first joint statement on Laos in the eight-year existence of the commission.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 9 (AP) All available local policemen were called to the predominantly black West End section tonight when 300 persons took to the streets, throwing rocks and bottles.

The Commercial Credit Company of Baltimore and its parent company, the Control Data Corporation of Minneapolis, announced yesterday that Commercial Credit had obtained substantial additional bank financing to bolster its present $1.1billion in lines of credit at the banks. Negotiations for the financing were reported in yesterday's editions of The New York Times.

The Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton, for three decades pastor of one of New York's largest churches, died yesterday morning, apparently of a heartattack, in his home at 750 East 18th Street, Brooklyn. He was 82 years old.
Gary G. Renaud, a freelance photographer, was killed Sunday when he fell from a motor cycle near Woodbridge, N. J. He was 35 years old and lived at 22 Cornelia Street.

FAIRFAX, Va., July 9 (AP) A personnel specialist with the Xerox Corporation in Washington and his wife were shot to death early today in their plush home in Fairfax County. Their 15-year-old son was later charged with murder.

PARIS, July 9 Nixon Administration officials sought today to convince skeptical officials of other developed nations that the political climate is changing in the United States in favor of larger foreign aid spending.

KINGSTON, N. Y., July 9 (UPI) Counsel for promoters of a series of rock festivals said yesterday he had withdrawn an Appellate Division motion to vacate a stay against the programs, since those planned for the next two weekends had been canceled.
DENVER, July 9 Vice President Agnew promised today that his rhetoric would be calm when he spoke to 700 persons at a meeting of the Education Commission of the States.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Census Bureau counts the population once every 10 years and then prepares itself for angry shrieks. It is hearing them now.
TORONTO, July 9 (AP) Lady Eaton, widow of Sir John Craig Eaton of the Canadian merchandising chain, died at her home today after a short illness. Her family said she was 91 years old.

Philip Darlington Haab, a senior partner in Thomas, Haab Botts, stock-option brokers and dealers, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after an illness of three months. He was 72 years old and lived at 860 Fifth Avenue and at Tuthill Road, Shelter Island, L.I.

There were times when he got roaches on his raincoat visiting a Bowery shelter, when the wrote out his resignation and the Mayor tore up up, when he stayed awake nights worrying about how crowded the children's shelter was.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Guest Wiener of Rio de Janeiro have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Margaret Wiener, to John Walker Richmond 3d, son of Commander Richmond, executive officer of the Naval Station in Brooklyn, and Mrs. Richmond.
LONDON, July 9 (Reuters) Britain's 47,000 longshoremen today voted to start a national strike Tuesday.

BOSTON, July 9 (AP) Presidents of state colleges throughout the Northeastern states were told at a conference tonight that public reactions to campus turmoil may hurt financing for colleges and universities far more "than even pessimistic educators now acknowledge."
COLOMBES, France, July 9 The United States track team held a little meeting last night after falling behind France, 5650, on the first day of their dual meet. The discussions paid dividends.

Soybean and grain futures again opened higher on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday but profit taking sent prices tumbling. Soybeans closed sharply lower while the grains were off slightly from the previous session.
LEMONT, Ill., July 9 (AP) Ted Meier of Joliet, Ill., 19 years old, shot a 73 today for a 2-under-par 142 and a twostroke lead midway in the National Public Links golf tournament.

One could put a fence around the East 53d Street block between Second and Third Avenues and package it as a small city. It's the block that has almost everything including an easygoing air where shopkeepers buy things from each other or sit on the stoops and chat.
Millard Price Wear, for 38 years on the editorial staff of Variety, the theatrical trade weekly, died yesterday of a heart ailment and emphysema. He was 73 years old and lived at 2 Horatio Street.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia invalidated today a Civil Aeronautics Board ordened last September granting domestic airlines a 6 per cent fare increase. The order becomes effective in 21 days.
Harriet King, a brown-eyed brunette from San Francisco, won the women's national foil fencing title last night for the third time.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 9 (Reuters) By a margin of only one vote, the Government turned back a move in Parliament today to condemn a decree under which import and sales taxes have already been increased.

TRENTON, July 9 Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, took the stand in his own defense here today at his trial on charges of conspiracy and extortion. He denied all charges of wrongdoing and said repeatedly that the prosecution's key witness against him had "lied."
In 57 seconds, the Board of Estimate yesterday gave Mayor Lindsay permission to spend the entire capital budget of $1.32-billion for the current fiscal year.
