AREA A Off Manasquan the blues have been consistently good, according to Jack Kennell at Ken's Landing in Point Pleasant. Boats traveling about two hours in a 60-degree direction have used butterfish and bunkers with success.

Andy Livingston, the New Orleans Saints leading runner, is the first casualty of the pro football season Working out on Tuesday at the Saints practice field in Metairie, La., Livingston went down when his knee collapsed nine days before the scheduled opening of training camp.
Miss Angela M. Hill and Henry L. Weldon plan to marry next winter.
Tom Seaver pitched a threehitter and even hit a home run last night as the New York Mets won their seventh straight game by defeating the Montreal Expos, 7-1.

In many ways duplicate play for match points is more exciting than rubber bridge. The tournament player knows that he must sometimes crawl out on a tempting limb, seeking a juicy score that may become a zero if he crashes.
Regular Brooklyn Democratic and Republican organization leaders withstood challenges to their leadership in stormy county Committee meetings yesterday and last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 Lars Christensen enjoys jazz and F. Scott Fitzgerald, speaks four languages, has some doubts about the institution of marriage and likes international conferences.
On July 20, jury trials will be available for the first time to defendants in New York City's Criminal Court.

PEKING, July 9 Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he felt tempted to call in North Korean troops to help liberate his country. He said premier Kim Il Sung urged him recently to accept volunteers.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 9 Score one for fog in the America's Cup observation trials. It was the only winner here today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The bill to restore to the Taos Pueblo Indians of New Mexico their small, sacred Blue Lake and all its 48,000-acre watershed ran into strong opposition

For a few short weeks, Amalia Rodrigues has left her private life as Senhora Cesar Seabra, wife of a wealthy Brazilian and mistress of an 18th-century house near Lisbon, to sing for New Yorkers the fados that have brought her international acclaim. Accompanied by three highly accomplished guitarists, she is offering her bittersweet songs of love lost, love betrayed, love unrequited at the Chateau Madrid through July 15.

Once upon a time in The Nation magazine, commenting on Henry James, Kenneth Rexroth defined a snob as someone who imitates the manners of the class above him, leading at least one reader to wonder whether a Bohemian might be similarly defined as someone who imitates the manners of the class belong him.
ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 9 Mrs. William Tracy and her daughter, Mrs. John Sheik of Essex Fells, won the 43d annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-daughter championship today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indicated.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., July 9 Gov. William T. Cahill announced today that he would ask President Nixon to declare this seaside resort "a major disaster area."

ST. ANDREW'S, Scotland, July 9 That's more like it. Lee Trevino had a pair of 68's for 136 in the wind and rain after blowing his top and took the lead halfway through the British Open golf tournament today.

The Citizens Union said yesterday that it was "deeply troubled" that Mayor Lindsay let city officials hold positions in political parties, and it called on him to obtain a ruling on the practice from the Board of Ethics.

A management reorganization at Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., begun in May was completed yesterday, leaving the founder of the conglomerate, James J. Ling, out of active participation in the affairs of the company.
BRUNEI TOWN, Brunei, July 8 (UPI) Prince Mohamed Bolkiah, 21 years old, the heir apparent to the throne of this British protectorate on Borneo, married today in a festive ceremony.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Soviet Union was continuing to deploy intercontinental ballistic missiles at a rate that would dramatically increase its offensive nuclear-striking force.

CEDARHURST, L. I., July 9 Miss Elayne Lubarr and David M. Dobin, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Rubin R. Dobin of Lawrence and Herzliya, Israel, were married this evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst by the bridegroom's father, who is chairman of special projects for the Jewish National Fund of America and chairman of the Far Rockaway Jewish Community Council.
Tatham-Laird Kudner Advertising apparently has become the first ad agency to purchase an advertising medium since the American Association of Advertising Agencies relaxed its rules last April.
The chairman of the new Community School District 23 in Brooklyn said yesterday that the three-year-old Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration project would no longer have any special status.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 9 A 24-year-old man who was questioned and then released after the bombing of Manhattan Police Headquarters last month was arrested today on a Federal warrant charging him with threatening the lives of President Nixon and Vice President Agnew.

LONDON, July 9 On Feb. 5, 1969, Natalya Gorbanevskaya the Soviet poet who recently was committed to a mental hospital for a second time and declared insane after being accused of anti-Soviet slander sent a letter signed by 170 people to the Soviet leaders, theSupreme Court and the Prosecutor General. It protested against the trials of dissident intellectuals.

TOKYO, July 9 Secretary of State William P. Rogers described Communist China today as the key to the future of Indochina and said that a peace settlement could be worked out "very quickly" if Peking showed enough interest.
Three more of New York's giant bank holding companies reported second-quarter earnings yesterday showing small gains for two of them and a small decline for the other.
Johnny Johnson, a vicepresident of the New York Yankees and a member of their organization since 1947, will move to Commisioner Bowie Kuhn's staff as administrative officer of baseball on Aug. 1.
A Waterfront Commission hearing examiner has recommended that the CC Lumber Company, the port's largest marine carpentry concern, be denied a license to stay in business.

ACTIVITIES. President Nixon sent to Congress a plan for establishing an environmental protection agency and a national oceanic and atmospheric administration. He presente d the Defense Distinguished Service Medal to Gen. Earle G...

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Senate voted unanimously today to bar President Nixon from helping the Penn Central Railroad or other businesses by big Government-backed loans without prior Congressional approval.

City Council leaders announced yesterday an investigation of the city's use of outside consultants and at the same time proposed two revisions in the city Charter that were designed to put checks on the awarding of consultant contracts.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) President Nixon today awarded a newly created military honor, to be known as the Defense Distinguished Service Medal, to Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, who has retired as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
GENEVA, July 9 There is a little corner of Switzerland that is fast being annexed by the New York City ballet in general and by George Balanchine in particular. The place is the Geneva Opera House.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP) Widgeon, the 54-foot sloop owned and sailed by G. Norman Bacon of Santa Barbara, Calif., was officially designated yesterday as the winner of the Los Angeles-to-Tahiti yacht race.

DUBLIN All week the Irish Government has been warning foreign ambassadors that "a civil war situation" is possible in the northern six counties of Ulster, which are attached to Britain, unless London takes pacifying steps.
The London stock market closed easier yesterday following news that British dock workers would strike next Tuesday. Word of Government intervention in the dispute came after the close of business.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 9 Marlu Pride, parked out in a 1:01 1-5 half-mile, shrugged off the extra distance and, with Herve Filion sitting nonchalantly in the sulky, easily captured the 21st edition of the United States Harness Writers' Association Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 9 With the Nixon Administration's support, the House leadership thwarted an attempt by antiwar Representatives today to force an immediate vote on the Senate's Cooper-Church amendment restricting future military operations in Cambodia.

Gail Robinson, a 24-yearold soprano who had sung only bit parts at the Metropolitan Opera, substituted this summer on tour in Detroit in the title role of "Lucia di Lammermoor." She did so well, by all reports, that her New York debut in the role Wednesday night aroused more than ordinary anticipation.

The General Electric Company made a recovery in the second quarter with an 8 per cent increase in earnings and a 2 per cent rise in sales, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Fred J. Borch, chairman.
The Leo Burnett Company will be getting together a proposal for "an informational and educational advertising program" at the request of the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Republican National Chairman has threatened to sue if the Columbia Broadcasting System does not answer promptly his demand for free air time to reply to Democratic broadcasts.
WHITE PLAINS, July 8 (UPI) Ralph Sharp, former news editor of The Daily News in New York, died today in White Plains Hospital at the age of 77. He lived at 40 Barker Avenue here.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 9 On a recent workday morning, the 7:37 did not arrive because, as Frank Bonagiuso, the cheerful ticket-seller, explained, "the engine caught fire."
The first section of a 32inch-high steel median barrier, designed to prevent head-on collisions on the eight-lane upper level of the George Washington Bridge, was lowered into place yesterday.
The city promised yesterday an "all-out drive to protect the taxi driver" from holdup men, thereby forestalling a daily midnight-to-6 A.M, shutdown threatened by owners of 6,900 fleet taxis.

Roy Jenkins was the best possible choice for deputy leader of the British Labor party. His election by an overwhelming margin not only augurs well for the future of a party recovering from unexpected election defeat; it is good news on a crucial issue for Prime Minister Heath's Conservative Government.
DALLAS, July 9 (AP) A Federal court evaluator says that personal property left by Lee Harvey Oswald, assassin of President Kennedy, is worth $17,654.

Miss Peggy Warshavsky, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Warshavsky of Neponsit, Queens, was married here last evening to Joseph Seton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Seton of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Cyrus Arfa of Central Synagogue in the Grand Ballroom of the Pierre, where a reception was also given.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP) Dick Stockton of Garden City, L.I., F. D. Robbins of Salt Lake City and Paul Gerken of East Norwalk, Conn., are the only holdover members on the 1970 Junior Davis Cup squad named today by the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 9 (AP) Don Bohm of Lansing, Mich., was one of seven Americans who won their first-round matches in the world amateur pre-style wrestling championships that opened today. Three Americans were beaten.

UNION CITY, N. J., July 9 A family of three and a fireman died here early this morning in a blaze that destroyed a four-story apartment house at Kennedy Boulevard and 41st Street, near the North Bergen police headquarters across the town line.
YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., July 9 (AP) The National Park Service today banned automobile traffic from the east end of Yosemite Valley.

One year after its completion and seven months after its dedication by Mayor Lindsay, the Delacorte Fountain at the southern tip of Welfare Island began spewing a plume of water into the air on a regular basis yesterday, under a hazy sky.

F. Clifton White, the Republican strategist usually credited with engineering Barry Goldwater's Presidential nomination in 1964, was named yesterday to manage the campaign of James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate.
A bright red 65-foot sculpture called "Endless Column," the tallest ever placed outdoors in the city, was lifted into the air by an outsize crane and set in place in Central Park yesterday afternoon.

A two-hour union meeting of mailers at The New York Times during a working period last night delayed and reduced the distribution of the City Edition, the first, which normally consists of up to 240,000 copies.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) The Nixon administration threatened California and three other states today with a loss of Federal welfare aid and told some 35 other states to remedy similar failings in their welfare systems.
WASHINGTON, July 9 President Nixon called today for a major reshuffling of Government agencies to coordinate efforts to understand, protect and enhance the nation's environment.
WASHIGTON, July 9 (UPI) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today more jobs for blacks must be opened in the construction trades this summer or Federal quotas may be enforced in 73 cities.

A 14-year-old Harlem youth, whose body was found late Tuesday evening on the roof landing of a tenement across the street from his home at 71 West 112th Street, was reported yesterday to have died of an overdose of heroin.
MONZA, Italy, July 9 (AP) Carmelo Bossi of Italy outpointed 34-year-old Freddie Little of the United States in a close 15-round decision tonight and won the world junior middleweight boxing title.

Among a spate of broadsides, leaflets and ultraconservative books distributed at the New England Rally for God, Family and Country, which ended earlier this week in Boston, was a stack of flyers labeled "Communist Rules for Revolution."

DUBLIN, July 9 (Reuters) Rod Laver, the dethroned Wimbledon champion regained some of his shattered confidence today by overaking Tom Okker of the Netherlands and winning, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, in the Irish open tennis tournament.
Wind South to southeast, 10-20 knots today and tonight, south to southwest, 1015 knots tomorrow and variable, 10 knots or less, tomorrow night and Sunday.

Can anyone really believe that the only suitable target area in the entire Atlantic Ocean for testing a new generation of guided missiles and glide bombs is a 7,000-acre island off Puerto Rico which 726 American citizens call home? So says the United States Navy, which already owns a third of the island of Culebra and now intends to lease and eventually buy another third.

Francis Vandeveer Kughler, a painter and former president of the Salmagundi Club for artists, died Saturday at Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old. He lived at 2870 Heath Avenue, the Bronx, and maintained a studio at the Hotel des Artistes, 1 West 67th Street.

WASHINGTON, July 9 The Administration began a fight today against Congressional efforts to scrap the Cuban refugee program and divert its funds, about $120-million a year, to help povertystricken Americans.
A royal Iranian decoration, the Order of Merit, has been conferred on Ladislav J. Skaloud, chief of protocol of Pan American World Airways.

UTICA, N.Y., July 9 Arthur J. Goldberg discovered today that although the most liberal abortion law in the nation wen into effect in New York State on July 1, the issue of abortion can still be explosive.

The Board of Education's policy statement on the rights and responsibilities of high school students is a much needed, if incomplete, effort to clarify issues that have been neglected for too long here and in school systems throughout the nation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 The World Youth Assembly is meeting here, but some of its participants do not appear to be very youthful. Nor are they exactily amateurs in the business of internaional conferences.

A possible turning point in the city's current strike of building service workers takes place today. It will be the public hearing on the City Council's rent-control bill, a hearing the Mayor is required to hold before he can sign the measure.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., July 9 Miss Martha Gale Sanson, whose grandfather, the late Benjamin P. DeWitt, was president of the Lawyers Club of New York, plans to be married here Aug. 22 to Alan Lynn Antik of Atlanta, where he is account executive with the Marschalk Company, advertising agency.

WASHINGTON, July 9 A special additional charge on all stock transactions, amounting to 20 cents per $1,000 may ultimately be imposed on investors to finance the proposed new program of insurance against brokerage firm failures.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday the appointment of Sterling Johnson Jr, as executive director of the Civilian Complaint Review Board. He succeeds Benjamin Ward, who was appointed deputy commissioner in charge of departmental trials last month.

MIAMI, July 9 Jack O'Brine, a former correspondent for The New York Herald Tribune and staff writer for the information department of the Radio Corporation of America, died of cancer today in a hospital here. He was 64 years old.
If East Third Street stays cool for the next month, some of the credit must go to four water sculptures.

The Senate has again showed some determination to shift national priorities to urgent domestic needs by passing an $18.6-billion appropriations bill that exceeded Administration requests by $1.2 billion. The most significant increases were in urban renewal assistance ($400 million) and water and sewage grants ($300 million), both areas in which the need for additional Federal effort is self-evident.
LONDON, July 9 Pollution of British coastal waters threatens the existence of two sea birds, the black guillemot and the razor-billed auk, the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds warned today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) The Senate has approved a $9-billion appropriation for the veterans Administration that includes $1.8-billion for medical care. This is $105-million more than President Nixon requested and the House approved.

MOSCOW, July 9 The president of the Soviet Academy of Sciences said today that the Soviet Union would give "maximum attention" to specific proposals from the United States for cooperation in space exploration.
BONN, July 9 (AP) West Germany's 1971 budget, approved by the Cabinet today exceeds 100 billion marks of $27-billion, for the first time.

The second-largest block of stock ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange changed hands yesterday when a whopping 1.02 million-share trade of Northwest Airlines, Inc. crossed the tape at 14 , down .
TORONTO, July 9 The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company has agreed to pay $27-million to settle a $400-million claim against its $2-billion basemetals Kidd Creek Mine at Timmins, in northern Ontario.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
The bond market contiuned to travel yesterday toward lower interest rates, but the road became a little less of the superhighway it had been since mid-June.

Mayor Lindsay made it clear yesterday that he would sign into law a rent-control bill passed by the City Council. Landlords who have opposed the measure, the Mayor said precipitated the strike of apartment-house workers.

The United States Treasury, at last running short of the silver it can sell to industrial consumers, has informed these users and the producers of the metal that its last weekly auction of silver will be the session of Nov. 10.
Denny McLain was the starting pitcher, so he wasn't able to thrill the Detroit fans with another dazzling display of hitting baseballs into the stands.
WASHINGTON, July 9 The Justice Department, carrying out a threat it made last month, began today a legal push to require recalcitrant Southern school districts to desegregate by September.
DALLAS, July 9 (AP) The National Football League Players Association sent special delivery letters to its members today ordering them not to report to training camps until further notice.

WASHINGTON, July 9 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, citing budgetary pressures and the Nixon doctrine, said today that plans had been approved for the removal of some American troops from South Korea.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 10 (AP) Justice Russell Hunt of the State Supreme Court reserved decision today on an injunction motion, effectively blocking plans for a rock music festival this weekend at Mountaindale, in the Catskills.

LANSING, Mich., July 10 (UPI) The police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched today for the 16-yearold blonde daughter of a former Mayor and the man who kidnappde her yesterday during a robbery.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department estimated today that the 1970 corn crop would amount to 4,819,999,000 bushels, 5 per cent more than last year's output of 4,577,864 bushels.

LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived here tonight for a two-day official visit and said his talks with Britain's new Conservative leaders would center on the Middle East, Indochina and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
LONDON, July 10 Ian Grimble, a Scottish historian, has made a marvelously reassuring discovery: Macbeth was innocent. Even better, so was Lady Macbeth.
Does the stock market measure intrinsic value? It certainly does not, as many people who had forgotten have again begun to realize.

TRENTON, July 10 The partner of the procecution's key witness testified for the defense today that he was "unaware" of kickbacks allegedly paid by his companies to Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defendants on trial here for extortion and conspiracy.
LA BAULE, France, July 10 (AP) David Broome of Britain won the world horse jumping championship today, riding his horse, Beethoven, and then those of his three opponents.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 10 Maj. James Chichester-Clark, Prime Minister of Northern Ireland, tonight appealed for restraint during Monday's parades of the Protestant Orange Order in 18 towns throughout the province.
WASHINGTON, July 10 Government scientists say that they can find no valid evidence that nuclear explosions trigger distant earthquakes, despite the contention of other scientists that they may do so.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 10 (AP) Norton Simon, the Los Angeles industrialist, reported today that he had spent nearly $2-million, in his losing campaign for the Republican Senate nomination in California and that all but $100,000 of it had been is own.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Vince Lombardi, head coach of the Washington Redskins, left Georgetown University Hospital today and went to his Potomac, Md., home to rest.
ROME, July 10 President Giuseppe Saragat announced today that he would name a premier-designate tomorrow.
PORTO VELHO, Brazil As Brazilians intensify their colonization of the Amazon Basin, the army is the cutting edge of the advance.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A top Justice Department official said today that a onebank holding company bill now before the Senate contained substantial loopholes for conglomerates.

Self-styled vigilantes now patrol the broad, high-ceilinged corridors of the Ansonia Hotel, where in better days elegantly gowned ladies and formally attired gentlemen thronged on their way to post-opera parties in the suites of Enrico Caruso, Geraldine Farrar and Feodor Chaliapin.

LOS ANGELES, July 10 (Reuters) The prosecution, in a bid to cut short the drawn-out jury selection in the Sharon Tate murder trial, told Judge Charles Older today that it would probably accept the jury as presently constituted, according to defense sources.

WASHINGTON, July 10 Two women have received the patent rights to an electrically heated garment that they call the Hotcoat. Having worn models of the coat with comfort, they plan to manufacture it themselves or license a raincoat maker. Patent 3,519,791 was granted.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia The three girls held hands and giggled quietly among themselves as they walked with the graceful glide of Southeast Asian women.
Daniel Pollock, an investment broker, died at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday. He was 74 years old and had formerly lived at 11 Riverside Drive here.

When the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, unshaven and dressed in faded khaki trousers and an old checked shirt, crossed into Hong Kong yesterday, he left behind four Americans still detained in Communist China's prisons.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The Senate passed by a vote of 39 to 21 today a bill authorizing a $20-million grant toward the expansion of the United Nations Headquarters over the protests of some Senators that the United States was paying a disproportionate share of the cost.
The city and the state are in a dispute over which will get the more than $500,000 in fines collected from public employe unions for illegal strikes here in the last three years.
WASHINGTON, July 10 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended July 7, 1970:

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 10 (Agence France-Presse) A "new partnership" between the Kenyan Government and National and Grindlays Bank was announced here today by Finance Minister Mwai Kibaki "as part of our efforts to have greater control of the economic side of the country."

WASHINGTON, July 10 The tax-exempt status of private schools that continue to practice racial discrimination in admissions will be revoked under a new policy announced today by the Internal Revenue Service.
MOSCOW, July 10 (Reuters) Seven Comecon countries signed an agreement here to set up an international investment bank in Moscow, it was announced today.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) Perle Mesta threw her first party in London in 17 years last night, and everything was the way it used to be.

Miss Randy Lyn Kalikow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Kalikow of New York and Atlantic Beach, L.I., will be married here in September to Samuel G. Ketive. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ketive of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 10 (UPI) Glendinning Companies, Inc., which set up and operated the Coca-Cola Company's "Big Name Bingo" contest, denied today tentative charges by the Federal Trade Commission that the contest was unfair. Glendinning said that the number of winners was proof that the contest was on the level.

BOSTON, July 10 (AP) Brooks Robinson, third baseman of the Baltimore Orioles, and Tony Olives, outfielder of the Minnesota Twins, were added to the American League All-Star squad today as the 28player roster was filled for the annual mid-season game with the National League next Tuesday.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) United States car production faltered this week because of plant-changeover activities but still managed to maintain a lead over the comparable 1969 figures.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 10 (UPI) S. Sgt. David Mitchell of the Army filed suit today in Federal Court to block the Army from trying him on 31 counts of assault to commit murder in connection with the alleged Songmy massacre and to have charges against him transferred to a civilian court.

J. Lloyd Langdon has been appointed president of Pet Incorporated's dairy division, succeeding Thomas K. Happel, who died on June 16. Mr. Langdon formerly was executive vice president and general manager of the division.
ST. HELIER, Jersey, July 10 (UPI) The Government of this Channel Island off France declared a state of emergency today as 1,000 Government workers went on strike for a wage increase.
The first comprehensive biographical reference work covering science exclusively has just made its debut with publication Of the initial two of a 13-volume Dictionary of Scientific Biography.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 10 Premier Bjarni Benediktsson, his wife and their 4-year-old grandson died early today in a fire that destroyed the Government's summer cottage about 35 miles outside this capital.
AUSTIN, Tex., July 10 (AP) Dr. Charles A. LeMaistre, 46year-old physician, was named chancellor of the University of Texas system today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 11 The United States command announced yesterday that searchers had found the wreckage of the helicopter of Maj. Gen. George W. Casey, the commander of the First Cavalry Division (Airmobile), but withheld most details pending the completion of recovery operations.

WASHINGTON, July 10 LaDonna Crawford Harris has never been the tea party sort of Senate wife. "When she gets ahold of a cause she's like a terrier," says one friend, "she just won't let it go." This week, the White House spoke on the cause that Mrs. Harris most fiercely champions

Marine Midland Banks, Inc., a statewide $7-billion bank holding company based in Buffalo, announced yesterday that its income before security transactions in the second quarter declined 1.5 per cent to $10.3million, or 85 cents a share, from $10.5-million or 89 cents a share in 1969.
Casey Stengel, who arrived in the major leagues as an outfielder 58 years ago, arrived back in town yesterday for his 80th birthday celebration, which will be held tonight in Shea Stadium.

HANOI, North Vietnam, July 10 (Agence France-Presse) A young man introduced as a United States marine said at a news conference here today that he had left his unit in South Vietnam in February, 1969, and had been with the Vietcong until this month.
Mitchum, Jones Templeton, a major regional brokerage house based in Los Angeles, will acquire nine West Coast branches of DempseyTegeler Co. under an agreement announced yesterday.

A Queens County Supreme Court Justice issued arrest warrants yesterday for two black militants, Herman B. Ferguson and Arthur Harris, who had been convicted of conspiring to murder Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and Whitney Young Jr., executive director of the Urban League, in 1968.

BONN, July 10 East German authorities tonight released three American tourists who were seized after they accidentally crossed the border at Schlutup yesterday, the United States Embassy in Bonn reported.

The chairman of Columbia University's nuclear engineering division yesterday unreservedly defended safety measures outlined by the university in its petition to operate a 250kilowatt nuclear reactor on its Morningside Heights campus.

MOSCOW, July 10 The United States Ambassador, Jacob D. Beam, met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko here today as Moscow published a cautious first evaluation of American peace proposals for the Middle East.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 10 Frank P. Greco, president of Comet Industries, Inc., manufacturers of industrial sewing machines in Paterson, died at Valley Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived in Wyckoff.

A wait-and-see attitude dominated the trading in soybean futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a Department of Agriculture crop report due after the close was awaited. It forecast a 5 per cent rise in the 1970 corn crop and a dip for wheat.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 10 (UPI) President Chung Hee Park said today that the United States should not unilaterally cut back its forces in Korea.
Morris Chalfen, president of Holiday on Ice, has reached an agreement in principle to buy the Vienna Eis Revue for an undisclosed amount.
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that it was endorsing a Conservative, James L. Buckley, for United States Senator.

GENEVA, July 8 Hans Habe, the Hungarian-born novelist, has filed suit for libel against Friedrich Durrenmatt, the Swiss playwright. The story of the suit has its genesis in Mr. Habe's attack on Harry Buckwitz, the new director of the Schauspielhaus, the Zurich municipal theater.

HONG KONG, July 10 Frank Coe and Sol Adler, two aging former officials of the United States Treasury Department, appear to be filling the social niche formerly occupied in Peking by Anna Louise Strong, the 84-year-old American leftist who died last March after years of service in the cause of Chinese Communism.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., July 10 Paul Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, tonight accused Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic candidate, of blocking discussion of important state isues by centering his campaign on the war in Vietnam and the sending of planes to Israel.
Indian chintz, the fabric whose popularity almost caused a recession in Western Europe in the 1680's, is the subject of an attractive exhibition at the CooperHewitt Museum.

For the second night in a row, the distribution of the first edition of The New York Times was delayed last night because of a union meeting held by the mailers. However, they returned to work after The Times served their president with a restraining order barring disruption of "normal procedures."

Miss Judith Elen Bob and Robert Marc Bronstein plan to marry on Sept. 12 in Lebanon, Conn. The announcement of their engagement has been made known by the parents of the prospective bride, Dr. and Mrs. Murray Bob of St. Albans, Queens.
A guard and three truck drivers for The Daily News were indicted yesterday and charged with stealing $3,500 worth of Sunday newspapers and selling them on their own.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) A Federal judge ordered the United Mine Workers of America today to produce records and documents for inspection and copying by the Departments of Justice and Labor.

Philipp Brothers, a major New York metals broker, charging that shipments of American steel often are stalled in foreign ports while unscrupulous traders seek to change or wriggle out of their purchase contracts, is circulating a memorandum among producers and other brokers in an effort to create some orderly trading rules.

A pair of razor-edge finishes in succession thrilled the 29,510 fans at Aqueduct yesterday. One of these occurred in the feature race, in which Reginald Webster's Dark Emerald beat the favored Roman Consort by a nose.
The last time Al Oliver saw Bob Gibson, the St. Louis pitcher was struggling to regain the brilliance that had brought him four 20-victory seasons in the previous five.
The Treasury announced yesterday plans to sell $2.25-billion of tax-anticipation bills next Thursday.

MONTREAL, July 10 (AP) The Montreal Stock Exchange and Canadian Stock Exchange are installing an additional $3million worth of computing systems to triple their capabilities to handle mounting workloads.
Erwin H. Amick, chairman of the Department of Chemical Engineering at Columbia University, died of a heart attack Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 59 years old.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 10 (AP) A former Foreign Minister of Colombia, Fernando Londono y Londono, was kidnapped by Castroite guerrillas yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 10 A sound horse-player never forgets. Therefore, those who sent $84,330 down the drain when they backed Dayan in his last outing at Roosevelt Raceway may use less money and more caution while gambling on the outcome of tomorrow night's $50,000 American Trotting Championship at the Nassau County oval.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters) The South Vietnamese Government promised today to abolish the "tiger cage" punishment cells in Con Son Prison if an investigation confirmed the criticism of two United States Representatives and press reports of the mistreatment of prisoners.

After an inauspicious beginning, the U.N.'s World Youth Assembly appears to be settling down to serious business with at least some prospect that a new generation can bring fresh perspectives to a tired old world's perplexing problems.
Fanny Farmer Candy Shops, Inc., announced yesterday in Boston that G. Edward Brooking Jr. had resigned as president, chief executive officer, director and chairman of the executive committee.

The cruising yachts entered in the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week sailing numbered 61, but fewer were expected to start for one reason or another, Donald B. King, the race committee chairman, said yesterday.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 10 Rain and a thunderstorm marred play, but at the end of the day diamond-studded medals for the winners must have seemed like rainbows to the low qualifying team in the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 10 Steve Kline, a 22-year-old rookie right-hander, made his major league pitching debut for the New York Yankees tonight, displaying natural talent and surprising poise.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Aroused by the stranding of 3,000 students in Europe, Senator John J. Williams demanded today a Congressional investigation into travel agencies.

CHICAGO, July 10 The Commonwealth Edison Company was granted a 4.5 per cent increase in its electrical rates today provided that the company spends an estimated $200million for air and water pollution controls.

TUCSON, Ariz., July 10 Two Phoenix youths were arraigned yesterday in Tucson on two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder following the gunshot slayings on Wednesday of two New York men and the wounding of a third.

Michael Lehmann, 18 years old, was returning home from the post office yesterday with a stack of mail is hand when he ran into Felipe Sanchez, the superintendent of 473 West End Avenue, a rent-controlled building on the corner of 82d Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 (Reuters) After an extraordinary conference of South Vietnam's top military and political leaders, President Nguyen Van Thieu called on dissident war veterans today to halt their protests and give the Government time to solve their problems.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10 Fifty-two Harlem school children disturbed at the possibility that delegates to the World Youth Assembly might have no opportunity to visit their community came here today "to bring a little Harlem to them," as one child put it.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 10 United States sources said today that Thailand had assured the Cambodians of her willingness to come to their defense if necessary.
An obscure area of the game that gets no attention at all in textbooks concerns how best to take advantage of a penalty situation.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 Jazz is once again the focal point of the Newport Jazz Festival. Last year, George Wein, producer of the festival, put together a mixture of jazz and rock, which brought criticism from jazz purists and from Newport city officials who were alarmed by the efforts of rock fans to break into Festival Field, where the concerts are held.

WASHINGTON, July 10 President Nixon appointed 23 persons today to the new National Commission on Productivity and challenged them to help the nation "achieve a balance between costs and productivity that will lead to more stable prices."
Efforts to reassert the authority of Congress in vital decisions concerning war and peace have in the last few days received a double blow in the House of Representatives.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10 (Reuters) Defense Minister Pieter Willem Botha called today for revision of South Africa's Simonstown defense agreement with Britain.

NEW HAVEN Last April, Yale University's president Kingman Brewster Jr., aroused the wrath of Vice President Agnew, numerous judges and not a few Yale alumni by saying he was "skeptical of the ability of black revolutionaries to achieve a fair trial anywhere in the United States." Obviously

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 10 Led by Lars Thalen, a strong-willed Swede wielding a swift gavel, the World Youth Assembly stopped a leftist group's drive today to exclude young participants from Nationalist China, South Korea and South Vietnam.
The American Can Company has purchased from Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., its 75 per cent interest in the Wilson Pharmaceutical and Chemical Corporation, whose sales last year were $48-million.

HADDONFIELD, N.J., July 10 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Huston Ellis Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Atkinson Ellis, to Bryant Wynkoop Bozarth, grandson of Mr. and Mrs. Norman O. Wynkoop of Pleasantville, N.Y.
The two top leaders of Orthodox Judaism in this country issued a joint statement yesterday condemning "indiscriminate and blanket" abortions.
ATLANTA Hair of all shapes, hair of all colors, hair falling over ears, creeping over collars, reaching for the shoulders: the individual coiffure is the new fascination of the middle-American male.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 10 Miss Camilla Virginia Miner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glen B. Miner, was married this morning to George Dempster Smith, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Bronxville, N.Y.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., July 10 An 18-year-old scholarship winner apparently went berserk in his home here today and committee suicide by inhaling ether after allegedly stabbing his mother and brother, the police said.
Miss Ellen Barbara Kramer and Robert Zaplin, graduates of Adelphi University, plan to be married next June.
WASHINGTON, July 10 The Justice Department revealed today that it had restricted the antipollution actions United States Attorneys may take under the Refuse Act of 1899.

DETROIT, July 10 The engine that has powered American cars for more than half a century is coming under increasingly harsh attack as a dangerous anachronism that will have to be scrapped before the nation can clean up its air.
JERUSALEM, July 10 A military spokesman announced today that Israeli planes shot down three Egyptian MIG-21's this morning in a brief but intense dogfight over the Suez Canal.
Mayor Lindsay signed into law a major revision of the city's 27-year-old rent control law yesterday after a raucous four-and-a-half-hour public hearing.
Not everyone knows how to paint their own supergraphics on walls, nor do they necessarily want to keep the same design on view all the time. Or so Joe Grimaldi, an artist, believes.

Seattle Fraser Scott, Seattle, knocked out Denny Moyer, Portland, Ore., 8, middleweights; Boone Kirkman, Seattle, knocked out Amos Lincoln, Los Angeles, 2, heavyweights; Andy Kendall, Portland, Ore., outpointed Roger Rouse, Anaconda, Mont., 10, light heavyweights.

The Dayco Corporation an nounced yesterday that it would increase prices by about 8 per cent for latex foam rubber furniture cushioning, effective July 31. The rises were attributed to higher costs of labor, raw material, packing and freight.

The New York Mets came to the end of their seven-game winning streak last night when they were defeated, 9-7, by the Montreal Expos and a rookie pitcher from Kansas who reads books like "The Art of Thinking Big."

WASHINGTON, July 10 Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic leader of the Senate, predicted today that President Nixon would win re-election in 1972, as things now appear, despite foreign and domestic problems.
Bruno Sammartino pinned Crusher Verdu of Spain last night in a return exhibition at Madison Square Garden before 20,982 fans, a record for wrestline at the Garden.
HERSHEY, Pa., July 10 The diversion of motorist toll revenues to the New York City Transit Authority was criticized today by a spokesman for motorists.

WASHINGTON, July 10 Senator Jacob K. Javits has told colleagues on the Foreign Relations Committee that he is prepared to hold up indefinitely the creation of the multi billion-dollar Overseas Private Investment Corporation if President Nixon insists on his slate of officers for the new agency.
William T. Dentzer Jr., New York State Superintendent of Banks, has disapproved a proposed merger of the Dime Banking and Loan Association, Rochester, into the Community Savings Bank of Rochester.
A red-haired subway conductor's one-man experiment in giving riders on the West Side IRT "a little more information and a little more courtesy" is getting a response that makes him very happy.
PARIS, July 10 The airport was there first; the builders followed. Are the airlines, then, responsible for the noise that plagues their new neighbors?

Dr. Jacob Halpern, attending physician in internal medicine and head of the endocrine clinic at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn died at the hospital Thursday after a brief illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 403 East 19th Street, Brooklyn, where he also maintained a private practice.
WASHINGTON, July 10 The Court of Military Appeals reversed today the convictions of two Negro members of the Marine Corps accused of dislovalty.

WHITE PLAINS, July 10 A power failure in west central Westchester County knocked out electrical service to 18,000 homes early this morning in White Plains, Elmsford, Ardsley, Dobbs Ferry, Hartsdale and Scarsdale.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and its subsidiaries were awarded about $200-million in Defense Department contracts, it was announced yesterday.

Any hope the Administration may have entertained for pursuing a strong proxy fight against the Communists in Cambodia must have been dashed by the responses Secretary of State Rogers has met during his extended Asian tour.

Prices on the London stock market closed narrowly irregular yesterday as uncertainties on the threatened strike by British dock workers offset the favorable influences of the Wall Street upturn on Thursday.

Two major dance companies, the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company, have separated permanently from the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, their longtime base on the Lower East Side.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The Justice Department has opened a new study aimed at uncovering evidence of pricefixing on products that are usually handled by local processors and distributors, such as bread, beer and fuel oil.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 10 Two 25-foot putts for birdie 3's on the first and last holes gave Lee Trevino a par round of 72 today, 208 for 54 holes and a two-stroke lead in the British Open golf championship with one day to go.
WASHINGTON, July 10 The White House said today that President Nixon would meet in Louisyille, Ky., on Tuesday with 13 Governors to discuss development of the Appalachian regions of their states.

AUGUSTA, Ga., July 10 (UPI) Mrs. Cornelia Oatman, the mother of a 16-year-old Negro boy whose death touched off riots here in May, has filed a $4-million suit against Richmond County Sheriff E.R. Atkins and other officials.
RED BANK, N.J., July 10 Dr. Harold B. Allen, former edu cational director of the Near East Foundation, died today after being struck by a car yesterday. He was 79 years old.

History, or at least the reading of history, can be a consolation. Jon Kimche's review of events in the Middle East from the end of World War I to the present puts the daily reports of bloodletting in that area into perspective. It puts a distance between these daily accounts and the reader. The intensity is lessened.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) The big pro-America rally here July 4 cost taxpayers $68,770, about $14,000 less than November's antiwar demonstration, the National Park Service said today.
The chorus of anguish grows louder every year but seldom is heard an encouraging word. "I want to work, but part-time," cry the housewives of city and suburb.
HONG KONG, July 10 The Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, a 79-year-old Roman Catholic bishop from Maryland, arrived in Hong Kong today after 12 years of imprisonment in Communist China.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 10 Arthur J. Goldberg earned stripes today as a campaigner and labor man as he ran up a 42-foot ladder to meet with construction men on the job.
The Jim Walter Corporation showed lower earnings in the fiscal third quarter and nine months ended May 31 although sales, and revenues continued to climb over the prior year's levels:
TOKYO, July 10 (AP) Japan, after the United States, is the second largest user of electronic computers in the world, the Japan Electronic Computer Company said today.
Once again stock prices were nudged ahead on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The index closed at 19.93, up 0.04.
WASHINGTON, July 10 Congressional trips abroad known as "junkets" to many American taxpayers cost more than $500,000 in 1969.
NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 10 (AP) Sporadic violence broke out again tonight in two black sections of New Bedford, with scattered reports of window smashing and looting of small stores.

MILWAUKEE, July 10 (AP) Don Massengale, a non-winner since 1966, shot his way out of the pack with a four-under-par 68 today and moved into the lead after the second round of the $110,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, July 10 President Nixon has intervened at a crucial stage of consideration by the House Ways and Means Committee of trade legislation in an effort to limit any mandatory import quotas to textiles.

JERSEY CITY, July 10 The sudden illness of a juror tonight resulted in a mistrial for three Black Panther members being tried on charges of machinegunning a Jersey City police station in November, 1968.

LIGNANO SABBIADORO, Italy, July 10 (AP) Bruno Arcari of Italy retained the World Boxing Council version of the world junior welterweight boxing title tonight after the French challenger, Rene Roque, was disqualified for butting in the sixth round. The Frenchman, who scaled 139 pounds, had opened cuts above both of Arcari's eyebrows. Arcari weighed 139 .

MOSCOW, July 10 (Reuters) Seven Communist countries signed an agreement here today to set up an international investment bank in Moscow, it was officially announced. Rumania, the eighth member of the Communist economic organization, refused to join the bank at a meeting in Warsaw in May.

Nearly two years ago, Michael Smuin choreographed a charming, well-constructed, plotless ballet to Mozart's Cassation No. 1 in G for American Ballet Theater. Last night at the State Theater, in the first of its two performances this season, that ballet, "Gartenfest," proved as charming, well-constructed and plotless as ever.

A short bit of Dr. Martin Sweig's own handwriting on Government Exhibit No. 5 in evidence persuaded the jury to convict him of one of the seven counts against him, a poll of the jurors disclosed yesterday.

OVERLAND PARK, Kan., July 6 As the prairie sun swings to the west, still high but slumping behind the wispy afterthoughts of clouds in the all-consuming sky, the dusty cars start peeling off the highway.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 10 (AP) Fred Fozzard of Stillwater, Okla., stayed in the running today for a second straight championship in the 180 pound class at the world amateur free-style wrestling championships. Seven other Americans also advanced.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) The trucking industry denied today that heavy truck traffic was responsible for the cracking of interstate highways and said that a Government investigator's charges "just won't hold water."

For seven hours today, starting at 10 A.M., a 15-block midtown stretch of Fifth Avenue will be closed to all traffic except seven minitrains that will snake their way amid the Saturday shopping crowds.
LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) Frank Sinatra, Bob Hope and Sir Noel Coward will give two concerts here to raise funds for an organization that seeks to set up multiracial schools all over the world.

The New York Athletic Club trio of George Masin, Steve Netburn and Paul Pesthy gained a narrow victory over the New York Fencers Club last night and won the national epee team fencing championship at the Hotel Commodore.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 10 (Reuters) Jordan said today that eight Arabs, all expelled by Israel, had been found in poor condition in the southern desert and had been brought to Amman for medical treatment.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 The authority of the King Hussein's Government within his kingdom was reasserted tonight in an agreement with Palestinian guerrillas sponsored by Egypt, The Sudan, Libya and Algeria.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 10 Four Porsches and two Ferraris qualified this afternoon for this first six positions in tomorrow's running of the Watkins Glen Six Hours of Endurance, part of the world manufacturers championship.

WASHINGTON, July 10 The Senate placed on record today, for the second time in less than a month, its wish to repeal the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin Resolution, which was cited by President Lyndon B. Johnson as Congressional authorization for the war in Vietnam.

SANTA CLARA, Calif., July 10 (UPI) Dave Edgar turned loose a powerful kick down the stretch today to upset Mark Spitz, Olympian and Indiana University star, an the 100meter free-style at the Santa Clara international swim carnival.
The stock market closed higher yesterday for the third consecutive day, with many issues reaching their best levels near the closing bell.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 10 Mayor Joseph F. Mattice announced an end today to the 11 P.M. curfew in this riotdamaged city, but some black leaders immediately protested, saying they favored a 6 P.M. curfew.

ROME, July 10 Pope Paul VI received the Roman Catholic Primate of the Netherlands, Bernard Cardinal Alfrink, in private audience today amid unconfirmed reports that the Vatican might make minor concession on issues involving priestly celibacy.

The Environmental Pollution Research Corporation made the first highly successful initial public stock offering in several weeks Thursday, but the newissue market as a whole continued in its long-depressed state this week.

Mr. and Mrs. Phillippe Mottu of Pully, Switzerland, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Marie Mottu, to Jeffrey Hall Dobken. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Dobken of Ridgefield Park, N.J.
CAMDEN, N.J., July 10 A former junkyard worker confessed yesterday that he murdered six women and a man during an eight-month period last year.
More and more frequently, the charge is being made that, because of the actions and attitudes of the Vice President, the Nixon Administration is "dividing the country."

A funeral service was held yesterday at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, for Mrs. Melly Loeb Simon, a psychiatric social worker who was head of the Payne-Whitney Psychiatric Clinic for 18 years.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) Eighty-seven Senators put aside differences on the Indochina war today to demand that Hanoi end "inhumane treatment" of American war prisoners.
TRENTON, July 10 In two 4-to-3 decisions, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled to day that members of families may sue one another in automobile accident cases.
William B. Emerson, a retired New York City real estate salesman, died of a heart attack yesterday in East Hampton, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived at Tervell Lane, East Hampton.

WASHTNGTON, July 10 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission accused the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company today of making deceptive statements on the safety and wear of its tires and of falsely advertising price savings that did not exist.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 10 Mr. and Mrs. George W. McKinney Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth Ann McKinney, to Ens. Ronald W. Gerbe, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Gerbe Jr. of North Merrick, L.I.

PARIS, July 10 The French Employers Association and four unions have signed a nationwide agreement to set up a job-training fund under which wage earners could improve their skills or learn new ones. The fund would be financed by private employers and the Government.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 10 A conservation group initiated legal action in three Federal courts today against 214 Alabama manufacturers, businesses and municipalities, charging them with pollution of streams in violation of the Refuse Act of 1899.
TOKYO, July 10 (UPI) Japan appointed a new ambassador to the United States today to conduct diplomacy during a critical period in trade relations.

DUBLIN, July 10 (Reuters) Tony Roche beat Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., today and set up an all-Australian men's singles final in the Irish open tennis championships. He will meet Rod Laver tomorrow.
ROME, July 10 One of the summer pleasures of Rome used to be the nearness of the beaches. No longer.

The associate general counsel of the Selective Service System explained yesterday to nearly 200 lawyers active in defending draft registrants the new rules defining those entitled to the status of conscientious objector.
BONN, July 10 (AP) Economics Minister Karl Schiller told the Bundestag Parliament today the Government's program to combat inflation was necessary to restore equilibrium in the West German economy.
John Lee Hooker has an easygoing, casual attitude as he sits down to murmur his blues and stroke out a guitar accompaniment, But his seeming casualness masks a highly alert and disciplined performer.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 10 Fog continued to frustrate the America's Cup fleet today, and this time it was coming from the Pacific as well as the Atlantic.
HARTFORD, July 11 The Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut has called on its member parishes to refuse to participate in a fund drive to support student antiwar strikes.

LONDON, July 11 Secretary of State William P. Rogers said at a news conference today that the United States hoped that the Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic would provide a comprehensive response to the American peace plan for the Middle East after President Gamal Abdel Nasser completed his current visit to Moscow.
DARIEN, Conn., July 11 Miss Bonnie Ann McNell and Stewart Marshall Anderson, both of San Francisco, plan to be married here Aug. 15 at St. John's Roman Catholic Church.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 11 The Maurer family was worried that the towering plant pressing against the back-porch screen might be a rash-inducing giant hogweed, so the county agricultural agent looked at it this morning and said judiciously:

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 7 The policy of racial separation, designed to preserve white privileges, is stirring among blacks a new consciousness of their identity that represents a challenge to the Nationalist Government's plan for separate but harmonious racial development.

BARRE, Vt., July 11 Miss Lauren Kay Rossi was married this afternoon to Specialist 4 John Franklin Van Deren 3d, U.S.A. The Rev. Roland Rivard performed the ceremony in St. Monica's Roman Catholic Church.
SAN DIEGO, July 11 (AP) Clarence Gaston hammered a leadoff ninth-inning homer tonight as the San Diego Padres beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 11-Miss Pauline Ellen Price was married here today in the Congregational Church to Tadas Uskuraitis, a graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design who is director of the design department of J.C. Penney, Inc. in New York.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 11 Miss Carol Ann Craft and C. Barry Schaefer were married here this afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary by the Right Rev. Msgr. John J. Caldwell, assisted by the Rev. Kenneth Walter of the Linden Presbyterian Church. A reception was given at the Shenorock Shore Club in Rye.
A 4,500-seat auditorium capable of seating the entire cadet corps at West Point will be the main feature of a new $16.8-million Cadet Union building for the United States Military Academy.
Vice President Agnew has acknowledged that his political role in the Administration sometimes forces him into a "hardline" stance, but he has disavowed Presidential ambitions for himself.
The Internal Revenue Service has prosecuted 24 local and state law-enforcement officers in the last few years, many for failing to report bribes on their income-tax returns.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 11 Imagine a classroom pitched alongside a rippling stream that gurgles soothingly. Overhead spread oaks and maples providing dappled shade. And all around robins, thrush and redwinged blackbirds seem to be chirping "Come and get it."
THE Administration's game plan for controlling the economy and curbing inflation seems to be working fairly well now at least in the eyes of the investment community.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 11 Doug Sanders, who had to qualify to enter, and Jack Nicklaus have tied for first at 283 in the British Open golf championship that neither seemed able to win. They meet in an 18-hole playoff tomorrow.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y. A remarkable increase in the number of "lost" children is expected at the 11th annual Yankee Peddler Day here on Saturday, July 25. Children who report themselves lost during this event are given a ride on a mounted policeman's horse so that they can spot their parents in the crowd.

NEXT Tuesday night the jazz lovers of this city will find themselves bending to the south with the religious instincts of good Mos lems turning to the east. The pull on their pieties will be exerted by the Half Note, that Shrine of High Schrei on Spring and Hudson Streets, where the resident jinn, tenorman Zoot Sims, will he uncapping his horn for a very long playing engagement.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) J. Richard Lucas, nominated to direct the Bureau of Mines, has asked President Nixon to withdraw his name from consideration.
The pedestrian was king along midtown Fifth Avenue yesterday, but some merchant princes were not so sure this was good for business.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 11 (Reuters) An antigovernment newspaper said today that a South African Radio Corporation decision to ban nonwhites from a Beethoven music competition was sick racialism.

SIASCONSET, Mass., July 11 Miss Daryl Acheson, daughter of William G.H. Acheson of New York and Siasconset and the late Mrs. Acheson, was married here this afternoon to Robert Stanley Westbrook of New York, son of Mrs. Novie Westbrook of St. Louis, and the late Mr. Westbrook.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 11 Miss Nancy Adams Sweet and Lawrence Lewis Master were married here this afternoon in St. Eustace Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Frederick C. McQuade Jr. The Rev. William D. Hayes assisted.
DUBLIN, July 11 (AP) Tony Roche trounced Rod Laver, 6-3, 6-1, in the all-Australian final of the Irish open tennis championship today.
ARLINGTON, Ore., July 11 The State Board of Health has finally signed a license for storage of radioactive waste on a desolate mesa near Arlington.
A new warning system enabling a motorist to be a Good Samaritan and alert highway patrols to a fellow driver in trouble is being tested in Florida.

A Federal judge in Brooklyn has ruled that a Hicksville, L.I., youth cannot remain seated as a protest while his classmates rise to recite the Pledge of Allegiance because the youth's action has disrupted the classroom.
How times change! That most monopolistic of all monopolies the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is finally faced with the threat of competition.

The rates that physicians pay for malpractice insurance are rising sharply around the country, sometimes doubling in cost. A 65 per cent increase will go into effect for doctors practicing in New York on Sept. 1.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, July 10 Queen Elizabeth of Canada traveled 5,000 miles across the Arctic this week impressing on Canadians that their big, rich northland is their inheritance to develop and protect.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 11 (UPI) When 57-year-old Antonio Carrozzi goes to court Thursday, his wife will accompany him with a pot of soup for the judge.

TOM PAXTON 6: Tom Paxton (Elektra EKS74066). Tom Paxton, folk singer, poet and veteran of the McDougal Street music wars of the early sixties, has hung in there, content to stick with the bare tones of his talent, unseduced by the rich fleshiness of electronic gimmickry.
The latest word from the shopper's front is that the consumer is still being difficult, recalcitrant and downat-the-mouth.
Metallurgists seeking new high-temperature alloys are shooting for the biggest breakthrough in aerospace materials since aluminum.

CLUJ, Rumania, July 5 Heavy summer rainstorms, which added inches of water to low-lying areas and muddy streams in this already soggy corner of Rumania, have failed to dampen a remarkable national effort to recoup the vast losses suffered during a month of repeated flooding from midMay to mid-June.

RAVENNA, Ohio, July 11 The Portage County prosecuting attorney, Ronald J. Kane, is seeking state funds for a grand jury investigation into the Kent State University disturbances in May that resulted in the fatal shootings of four students by Ohio National Guardsmen.

NEWARK, July 11 In the winter of 1937, when Edward J. Simmons was an 18-year-old graduate of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn, he landed a job as a shorthand stenographer with the Triangle Conduit and Cable Company over in Manhattan. The starting salary was only $18 a week, but Mr. Simmons did not remain at that level for long.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 11 Pleasure Seeker, scoring his first major stakes victory, won the $62,100 Hollywood Gold Cup today by 3 lengths at Hollywood Park.

PARIS, July 11 With Charles de Gaulle out of office, American tourists are back in record numbers the young in more or less hippie costume, toting knapsacks and guitars, the older in gaudy sportswear, carrying cameras. But they are not spending the way they used to do.

NORWALK, Conn., July 11 Miss Stephanie Alice Dell'Agnese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fioravanti Dell'Agnese of Rowayton, was married here this morning to David Michael Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Brown Jr. of Wilton. The Rev. Stanley Koziol performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church and a reception was held at the Silvermine Inn.

DURHAM, N.C., July 11 Career Ambassador George V. Allen, who held key information posts in the State Department during some of most critical periods in the nineteen-fifties and served in some of the world's most sensitive areas, died today of an apparent heart attack at his farm in nearby Bahama. He was 66 years old.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 (AP) Richard Williams is a black tennis player living in Watts. Last summer he thought what had been good for him just might be good for his "brothers and sisters."
WASHINGTON In recent years there has been a rising chorus of voices, individually and in concert from expert panels, saying that the American health care system is in trouble and needs to be changed.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) Pattee Canyon, carrying high weight of 129 pounds, posted a six-length victory today in the $53,400 Matron Stakes at Arlington Park.

WASHINGTON As the unseen voter shakes money out of his cookie jar and stuffs it into an envelope to send to the Democratic party in Washington, a voice observes: "You don't have to wait until 1972 to vote against Richard Nixon."
ROME July 11 President Giuseppe Saragat today asked Giulio Andreotti, a moderate Christian Democrat with close ties to the Vatican, to form a new government.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 11 New Zealand is one of the few comparatively advanced countries in the world where big cities are still free from smog, where even in midwinter urban dwellers can still enjoy clear days. Yet even in New Zealand pollution is becoming a major issue.

The city's new Health and Hospitals Corporation will be billed for hundreds of thousands of dollars a year in added utility charges because of the separation of the municipal hospitals from the regular city government, a high official said yesterday.

Group medical practice on a prepayment basis geared to preventive medicine would be emphasized and encouraged. Hospitals and other facilities would be paid not on a cost-plus basis, but on a level worked out in advance. The intention would be to reward economy and efficiency and to penalize waste.

EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa. The old, wooden 19th-century railroad station which once was the hub of summer activity in this busy Poconos community has made a temporary comeback. It has been dressed in bunting and flags and is serving as the headquarters for the town's 100th anniversary celebration.

MARLBORO, Vt., July 11 Officially the 20th Marlboro Music Festival opens tonight, though without any special observances. Special observances are not in the Marlboro style. Unofficially the festival opened last night with a concert in the dining room before a highly critical audience made up largely of members of the music staff.

WAYNE, Pa., July 11 Donna Marie Sandmaier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Sandmaier Jr. of Radnor, was married here this noon to Lieut. Charles Buford Carden, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Buford W. Carden of Tulsa, Okla.
CHICAGO, July 11(AP) Tony Taylor's tie-breaking triple in the ninth inning capped a sevenrun explosion that gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 10-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
STANTON, Del., July 11 (AP) Christians Stables' unbeaten Unity Hall decisively defeated Deceit, her rival for the 2-yearold filly title, today in the $24,850 Blue Hen Stakes at Delaware Park.
Arnaud Cartwright Marts, a former president of Bucknell University and a professional fund raiser, died yesterday at Doctor's Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 41 Park Avenue.

The subway and bus operating budget for the city for the next fiscal year is up 20 per cent over the previous year, but the 30-cent fare is safe, at least "through 1971," the Metropolitan Transportation Authority reported yesterday.
BOSTON, July 11 (AP)-Gov. Francis W. Sargent vetoed a bill this week that would have empowered the state's 300 Registry of Motor Vehicles inspectors to carry weapons and exercise other police powers.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, July 12 (Reuters) British troops tonight sealed off roads leading to Roman Catholic areas of Belfast following an explosion in a Protestant district.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 11 Manuel Fishman registered a three-second triumph over George Wrage for Mariner Class honors today as the Unqua Corinthian Yacht Club's weekend invitation regatta got under way.

LA BAULE, France, July 11 (Reuters) Alvin Schockemoehle of West Germany piloted Wimpel to victory today in the Remy Martin Prix d'Honneur at the international horse show. Wimpel had a time advantage of 6.2 seconds in winning in 1 minute 15.3 seconds.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11 Four revolutionary groups in Oman, the interior province of the Sultanate of Muscat and Oman, in the southeastern sector of the Arabian peninsula, are reported to have merged and proclaimed a new revolt against Sultan Said Ibn Taimur.

The Senate has voted to set a $20,000 limit on the subsidy payments that the Federal Government can make next year to an individual farmer or farm-operating corporation. While that limit is still too high and may be circumvented by farm splitting the Senate's move is important in demonstrating that the influence of wealthy farm proprietors in Congress may be running out.

WHAT happens when architects build for themselves? All hell breaks loose for eight years. From 1962 to 1970, the American Institute of Archi tects has been trying to build a new headquarters in Washington, and its role has been a paradigmatic example of the client nightmare. The process offers some shaky illumination of institutions and esthetics.
LONDON, July 11 The supersonic airliner Concorde begins a fight for survival next week as crucial tests get under way.

AFTER THREE years of intensive work all around the world supporting the development of tourism as a key industry and economic hope for developing nations, the United Nations Inter-Regional Adviser on Tourism went out of business on July 1 in anticipation of a major change, probably by mid-autumn, in the U.N.'s handling of tourism projects.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., July 11 Trinity Episcopal Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Judith Pierreppont Grape, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley H. Grape of Fairfield, Conn. and Charles Ebbert Barnett 3d. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Barnett of Detroit.

Benjamin C. Davis Jr., has been promoted to president and general manager of the international division of the Canada Dry Corporation. He will report directly to James D.W. Blyth, president and chief executive officer.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 11 Miss Nancy Elizabeth Cohn and James Schaap Weinberg were married here this morning in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Patrick J. Zacarra, assistant executive director of the New York Mission Society, performed the ceremony.

VENICE. THE 35th Venice Biennale opened with the gusto of a soggy Opera Buffa. On preview day, in the lovely garden area which houses the Biennale, critics in search of art works made their way among wheelbarrows, masons mixing plaster, and carpenters pounding boards.

HOUSTON, July 11 (UPI) The Apollo 14 commander, Capt. Alan B. Shepard, expressed concern that cutbacks and layoffs in the space program may cause low morale among engineers and technicians preparing his moonship for launching in January.

Today the United States Soccer Football Association concludes, in Chicago, its three-day annual meeting, one which might be the most important in its history. PORT ALLEGANY, Pa., July 11 Miss Nancy Patricia Herger and A. Wilbur Duryee Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Duryee of New York and Pawling, N.Y., were married here this morning.

MAHON, Island of Minorca, Spain Like a pile of sugar cubes, the village of Binibeca huddles above a cove sheltering a mini-sandbeach on the rocky south coast of this, the most northerly of the Balearic Islands. Tile roofs topping a folk-art jumble of irregular houses leaning against each other and boats, nets and lobster pots scattered in front of massive boathouse doors recall old fishing villages on small harbors all around the Mediterranean.
