ASBURY PARK, N.J. The sign on the door of the Monmouth Community Action Program here says "No jobs available." For 40 places in the program's neighborhood center, there were 700 applicants. There are 246 jobs in the Neighborhood Youth Corps, compared with twice that number last year.
NEWTON, Conn., July 11 Miss Susan Mary Mudd was married today to Stephen Richard Kerbs just four weeks after her brother, Kyle Christian Mudd, and the bridegroom's sister, Joanne, were married.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 (UPI) A motorist has been held liable in a $21,500 damage suit on the ground that he invited the theft of his automobile, which later figured in an accident, by leaving the keys in the car.
PARIS, July 11 The body of Felix Gaillard, 50 years old, a former Premier of France, was found today in the English Channel near the island of Jersey following a yachting accident.
CLEVELAND, July 11 Three major strikes, two of them wildcats, have left Cleveland without public bus service, garbage collections and construction of new homes, schools and commercial buildings.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 11 For years airline crews have dutifully gone through elaborate drills in swimming pools and huge aircraft markups practicing how to evacuate a jetliner forced down at sea.
The Hennessy Grand Prix will be held Wednesday, but if anyone tells you that this world championship ocean race was once the Around Long Island Marathon, don't laugh. It's true.
LONDON, July 9 Locusts damaging food crops in Asia and Africa have an unwitting helper man.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 11 "If you don't love him," Mahalia Jackson declared last night as she dedicated the final selection in her portion of the opening program of the Newport Jazz Festival to Louis Armstrong, "then I don't think you know how to love."

RYE, N.Y., July 11 Miss Linda Davis Simonton and Yeoman 3d Cl. James Anderson Stainaker, U.S.N., were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony in the Rye Presbyterian Church. A reception was held at the American Yacht Club.

Dr. Carol T. Simon of New York and George M. Simon of Albany have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Esme Simon, to Brian Leslie Berger. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Berger of Elizabeth, N.J. The wedding is planned for Aug. 23 at the Plaza Hotel.

SEATTLE, July 11-It seemed to be a ray of hope after a long time when hope was scarce. Gov. Daniel J. Evans of Washington called it "a psychological boost." Local economists predicted that its immediate impact on a serious unemployment situation in metropolitan Seattle would be minimal.
Over a period of about a month and a half Al Hampel then copy chief at Young Rubicam, had some six or so clandestine meetings with Victor Bloede, who had been president of Benton Bowles for a year.

BEIRUT, Lebanan, July 11 The central miiltary office of the Palestinian commando movement has issued statistics purport to show a rapidly increasing level of operations against Israel in 1969 and the first half of 1970.

WASHINGTON, July 10 President Nixon had good reason to be "elated," as was reported. when he heard that the House had supported him in preliminary votes on the CooperChurch amendment to restrict future military operations in Cambodia. But there may have been some side effects that will not be so welcome, to him or to those Democratic leaders who apparently worked closely with him to achieve the victory.
KANSAS CITY, July 11 (UPI) Bill Butler hurled a three-hit shutout and drove in a run with his second hit of the season tonight as the Kansas City Royals defeated the Chicago White Sox, 4-0.

CHUGIAK, Alaska, July 11 Miss Susan Townley of Girdwood, Alaska, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Beardsley Townley of Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N.J., was married here this afternoon to George Charles Keppel, Jr. of Anchorage. He is the son of Mr. Keppel of Keokuk, Iowa, and the late Mrs. Keppel.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 11 (UPI) Ben Hogan, forced to curtail tournament participation because of a knee injury, notified sponsors of the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic yesterday he would compete in the event July 30 to Aug. 2 over the Westchester County Club's West Course.

WASHINGTON The heat of summer is enveloping the nation's capital, and with it has come the annual resurgence of a problem residents have come increasingly to dread: A stomach-turning miasma rising from the Potomac River.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. July 11 For one of the few times in his career, Jackie Stewart is "high" on a new race car in this case the Chaparral 23 but he acknowledges he has a great deal to do before he feels completely at ease with Jim Hall's radical design.

WASHINGTON, July 11 Knowledgable military sources here believe that the Nixon Administration's Vietnam strategy may require it to keep a large American military contingent in South Vietnam, roughly 150,000 to 200,000 men, as late as 1972.

Fourteen-year-old Michael D'Orleans attends school in an area below 59th Street and west of Fifth Avenue that the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission has cited as one of the worst drug addiction areas in the city.
OAKLAND, July 11 (AP) The Oakland Athletics poured across 11 runs in the first two innings as they ended a batting slump with an 11-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today.

From medical studies on American Indians, two researchers have "elaborated a radical proposal" that a common type of gallstone affecting many other Americans as well as Indians may result from a disorder of the liver, not the gall bladder.

RYE, N.Y., July 11 Christ's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Perry Thayer to Roy Bertram Remmert Jr., who expects to receive a master's degree in finance next month from the University of Oklahoma. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips, was followed by a reception at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter N. Thayer, parents of the bride.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 While many of their fellows are soaking up the summer sun, students at dozens of colleges across the country are already hard at work preparing for political campaigns next fall.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 11 Miss Molly Ann Tarkington was married here this afternoon to William Richard Moller Jr., son of Mrs. Moller of New York and the late Mr. Moller. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Andrew W. Tarkington of Greenwich.

BUENOS AIRES, July 11 (AP)-Two leftist students, one killed in a gunbattle and another still being sought, were identified by Argentine police today as the kidnappers of former President Pedro E. Aramburu.

Last December in Alamagordo, N. M., three children in a family of 10 an 8-yearold girl, 13-year-old boy and their 20-year-old sister fell seriously ill and were rushed to the hospital. Although the older girl improved slowly, the two younger children lapsed into a coma from which they have yet to emerge.
MILLBROOK, N.Y., July 11 Miss Cynthia Alley and Wodbury H. Andrews were married here this afternoon. The Rev. John G. Beaven performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.

The Consultation on Church Union, an organization designed to plan the uniting of nine major Protestant denominations into one church with 25 million members, has decided to reveal the details of its plan early next fall.

CHICAGO, July 11 (UPI) Jervis Langdon Jr., Chairman and President of the Rock Island Lines, expressed belief this week that an Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's report on the merger of the Rock Island with the Union Pacific could pave the way to a general settlement of realignment problems of the Western railroads.

DENVER, July 11 Miss Charlotte Margaret Wallace, niece of Mrs. Harry S. Truman of Independence, Mo., will be married here on Aug. 2 in the Evans Chapel of the University of Denver to Lieut. Jerome Barry Rich man, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Richman of Odenton, Md.

SOUTHPORT, Conn. July 11 Trinity Episcopal Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Gay Hadden and Alexander Edward Richard Woodcock. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Francis X. Cheney, assisted by the Rev. Richard A. Watson of St. Joseph's College in North Windham, Me., who is the bride's uncle.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 11 Miss Margaret Gorman Smith and Allen David Mitchell were married this morning at the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception by the Rev. John J. Gorman, a cousin of the bride, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (UPI) Matty Alou tripled home the tying run and scored the winning run on a fielder's choice in the ninth inning tonight as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored an 8-7 victory over the Cardian 8-7 victory over the Cardinals.

WHITE PLAINS, July 11 For the second successive night, communities in central Westchester County were without electricity as Consolidated Edison technicians and officials tried in vain to trace the mysterious malfunction that cut off lights, air-conditioners and electric clocks of more than 18,000 families.
For the first time in a quarter century, a borough of New York has seen its over-all property values decline. The unhappy distinction belongs to the blight stricken Bronx.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 11 This picture-book village of sculpted hedges, shaded avenues, sandy beaches, spacious lawns, saltboxes and windmill sails has been an artists' mecca for almost a cenutry.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., July 11 Nancy Baroody thought she was finished with small ponies when she sold Midget to Sindy Paul six months ago. The 14year-old Miss Baroody had ridden the talented gray mare to the national high-point championship four years in a row.

ROCHESTER, July 11 Miss Susan Reynolds Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Rafter Williams of Buffalo, was married here this afternoon to William Earl Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Hart of Pittsford. The Rev. William P. Jenkins performed the ceremony in the First Unitarian Church.

When a slight earthquake shook the Virgin Islands one night last week, five women aquanauts were sleeping in a steel underwater chamber on the bottom of a secluded bay. Awakened by the tremor, they quickly checked their habitat, Tektite 2, and telephoned to the control center topside that no damage had been done.
PARIS, July 11 Raymond Laporte, a French career diplomat who was Consul General in New York City from 1958 to 1963, died here Thursday of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.

WASHINGTON Senator James O. Eastland has been braced for some time for bad news from the House of Representatives. Legislation that would reduce the subsidies paid to farmers by the Federal Government has been under study by the House Agriculture Committee, and the Senator would stand to lose much of the $146,000 in subsidies he receives for his Mississippi cotton plantation.

TOKYO, (Reuters) July 11 The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development will open a Tokyo office early in November, to maintain close contact with the Japanese Government and financial circles, the Finance Ministry said this week.

TO MOST North Americans, Latin America, which is always coming up in the news, means Mexico and South America. What has been missed is the isthmus that bridges North and South America, sometimes known as Middle America.

MARTINSVILLE, Va., July 11 (AP) Thomas Bahnson Stanley, Governor of Virginia when the United States Supreme Court ruled in 1954 that Prince Edward County must desegregate its public schools, died today. He was 79 years old.

A group of Dartmouth College sociology students who became interested in hunger and welfare after reading a state report spent nine weeks investigating the problem in Lebanon, N.H., and helped obtain Federal surplus food for 80 families who did not know they were eligible.

Three of the nation's major railroads the Baltimore Ohio, the Southern Pacific and the Louisville Nashville were struck by the United Transportation Union last week as the result of a long-standing dispute over the elimination of firemen's jobs.

SHERMAN, Conn., July 11 Charles Halliwell Duell, founder and former president of the New York book publishing firm of Duell, Sloan Pearce, died after a heart attack here last night while attending a meeting of the Nairomi Land Trust, a conservation organization. He was 64 years old and lived on Cozier Hill Road here.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 11 Miss Annalise Marie Evenson, daughter of Herbert W. Evenson of Greenwich and Mrs. Helene Belange Evenson of Riverside, was married here this evening to Hubert Milton Greist 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Griest Jr. of New Haven and Pine Orchard.
WASHINGTON In a nation starved for good news, a heartening development has been taking place in the last three weeks: The bond market has gone up.

Casey Stengel made his first appearance on the New York scene in 1912 as a rookie player on the Brooklyn Superbas. He later was an outfielder for the New York Giants, manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers, manager of the Boston Braves, manager of the Yankees and manager of the Mets. He has tasted success and failure. He prefers success.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 11 (AP) James H. Weaver, commissioner of the Atlantic Coast Conference, a collegiate sports organization, died here today of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived in Greensboro, N.C.

GREENFIELD, Mass., July 11 Miss Phyllis Ann Ruggeri and Richard Austin Whiting 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whiting Jr. of Bedford Village, N.Y., were married here this morning. The bride's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Sebastian J. Ruggeri of Greenfield.

MILWAUKEE, July 11 (AP) Deane Beman got birdies on the last two holes today for a 68 and moved into a tie with Don Massengale for the thirdround lead in the $110,000 Milwaukee oven golf tournament.

TOYKO July 11 (UPI) A Japanese man who said he had guarded United States prisoners at Hiroshima during World War II asserted today that 23 American prisoners of war had been killed or fatally injured in the atomic-bomb blast that ravaged the city nine days before the war ended.

NEW HAVEN, July 11 The United States District Court in Connecticut has ruled that students of Rippowam High School in Stamford may publish independent newspapers without having the contents screened by school officials in advance.

HYDERABAD, India, July 11 (Reuters) The police have killed the founder of the Maoist Naxalite movement in Andhra State in southern India and one of his top aides, it was announced today.

BLAIRSTOWN, Iowa, July 11 (AP) Representatives of the Air Force Academy Swim Club took first place in both the men's and women's divisions of the Amateur Athletic Union national junior long distance swimming championships in Hannen Lake yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (AP) A head-on collision on a Golden Gate Bridge approach ramp killed nine young people early today and injured three others.

CATCHER Johnny Bench, Cincinnati Reds, only 22 years old but in his third full season in the majors and his third All-Star game. A native of Oklahoma City, Johnny led the league with 18 passed balls in his 1968 debut season but had so much obvious class he won rookie-ofthe-year honors. Bats and throws righthanded.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 11 A West Highland white terrier, Ch. De-Go Hubert, owned by Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N.J., was best of 1,115 dogs at the 17th annual show of the Champlain Valley Kennel Club today.

MAHOPAC, N.Y., July 11 Mr. and Mrs. R. Walter Burghardt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie Pearsall Burghardt, to Peter Michael Hayes. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lind Hayes of New Rochelle, and Las Vegas Nev. Mr. Hayes and his wife, Mary Healy, are the stage, radio and television personalities.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) The United States Office of Education says it has dismissed a young summer intern on charges that he presented an obscene slide show, in a Government building.

SANTA FE, N.M. Among the bonuses for students and other enthusiasts who visit archeological excavation sites in New Mexico is the proximity of Indian pueblos to many of the "digs." Several universities hold field sessions in archeology in the state each summer, and the "dig" sites are visited, too, by tourists brushing up on their knowledge of this region's heritage.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 27 (AP) Another sharp downward trend has developed for domestic oil and gas drilling operations.

On April 2, 1969, 13 members of the Black Panther party in New York were rounded up by police and charged with conspiracy to bomb public places. Since that day, almost all of them have been locked in jail cells, released only for brief court appearances, awaiting trial that is now likely to begin sometime late in September.

Commissioner Neal L. Moylan of the New York State Department of Commerce will be the principal speaker when the 25th annual convention on the National Secretaries Association opens at the Americana Hotel Wednesday.
CHICAGO, July 11 (UPI) Chicagoans began paying the second-highest urban transit fares in the nation this week.

HEADING the summer vacation best seller list of events is the fair country, county and state. Exhibits, starheadlined shows, contests, prizes, good eating and rides make the fair a popular attraction for the entire family. Among the fairs scheduled in the Northeast and Canada this season are:

PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 Statements by Negro leaders that President Nixon has little support among the nation's Negro population are borne out by survey results compiled in six consecutive measurements over the last four months, the Gallup Poll reported today.
DETROIT, July 11 A rookie Terry Crowley, belted a two run homer in the eight inning that sent the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-5 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 11-Miss Nancy Ferris Cook and William C. Brooks Jr., were married at 5:30 A.M. today on the dock of her parents' home on Long Island Sound.
Humid weather, severe head wind and curious pleasure boaters did not deter the rowing races in the Pelham Bay Park regatta yesterday.
WASHINGTON To the 25 intense young attorneys responsible for school desegregation problems in the Department of Justice, it was one of their best weeks in the Nixon Administration.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 11 Princeton University students, in a course to be offered next fall by the department of Aerospace and mechanical sciences, will be investigating Government projects dealing with technology, including weapons systems.

NIAGARA FALLS And still the newlyweds pour in, as they have for more than 100 years, to watch the falls fall. Some are older but most are under 30 and they stroll arm-in-arm alongside the two roaring cataracts, squealing like children when the mist soaks their hair and their honeymoon clothes.

LIGNANO SABBIABORO Italy Bruno Arcari, 139 pounds, Genoa, Italy, declared winner over Rene Roque, 139 Lyon, France. Roque disqualified in sixth round for butting Arcari retained his World Boxing Council junior welter weight title.
HOUSTON, July 11 (UPI) Johnny Edwards hit a sacrifice fly in the bottom of the 14th inning tonight to score Cesar Cedeno and give the Houston Astros a 5-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. The town that gave you Miss America, salt-water taffy, the diving horse and the stops on a Monopoly board now gives you a centennial. The arches overhead acclaim the venerability of the institution underfoot: the Boardwalk at Atlantic City is 100 years old this year.
FARMVILLE, Va., July 9 "I had to quit," the Rev. Francis Griffin said yesterday, "because I feel I was a part of a terrible hoax being played on black and on all poor people."
BOSTON, July 11 (AP) Approximately 10,000 persons mostly children were injured by fireworks during the Fourth of July weekend this year, according to the National Fire Protection Association.

PERHAPS the most useful aspect of our three major classic ballet companies, the New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theater and City Center Joffrey Ballet (the Harkness Ballet can no longer be taken seriously, not until we see what happens to that oddly Byzantine organization), is quite simply how different each is from the others. They are so different that it doesn't even pay to have favorites, or even to make too many comparisons.

President Nixon's proposed reorganization of environmental agencies is a statesmanlike move which could prove to be almost as historic in its own way as the great alphabetical upheavals of the early Roosevelt Administration.
DETROIT, July 11 (AP) Peace Movement, a 36-1 choice, won the $46,350 Milette Handicap for fillies and mares today at the Detroit Race Course.

If revolutions were fought with books instead of bullets our cities would already be in ruins. And blood would be pouring through their gutters. Book racks everywhere are beginning to creak under an ever-inceasing number of works devoted to the destruction of the existing order, well-packaged handbooks on how to annihilate the Establishment distributed by such giants of American capitalism as Random House and McGraw-Hill, in fact by almost all of commercial publishing.

STEAMBATH, a play by Bruce Jay Friedman, divided the ten critics evenly. Clive Barnes: "There is much to admire in the quality of Mr. Friedman's writing, but the basic idea is trite (it recalls SuttonVane's 'Outward Bound') and moreover not capable of much dramatic development.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) More Americans complain about their automobiles than any other consumer item.
New York City's apartment strike drifted through its sixth day yesterday, with any major turn appearing to await the outcome of court hearings scheduled for tomorrow.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 11 (AP) Hawkeye, owned by William Hawkins of Evansville, Ind., was the upset winner today in the $15,000 Junior Derby at Miles Park.
MIAMI, July 11 (UPI) The population of Florida, paced by the "gold coast" counties of Dade and Broward, grew by 1,721,538 people in the last decade and now has a population of 6,673,098.

Jonathan O'Herron had the opportunity two weeks ago to speak up for the nation's railroads in one way that would be sure to get him a hearing to rub Washington's nose in the fact that the railroads are the targets of repressive regulation not applied to most other industries.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 11 The Green Berets, troops of the United States Special Forces, who were the first American fighting men in this country early in the nineteen sixties, will be phased out of South Vietnam by the end of this year, according to reliable military sources.
For the first time since the Korean War, enrollment at college and university summer sessions around the country has apparently failed to grow this year. In some cases, it has dropped sharply.

WASHINGTON It took a quarter of a century, but Richard M. Nikon began to make good last week on a pledge to his Whittier College football coach. In the process, he may have given American Indians their only real cause for optimism since the United States signed the first Indian treaty in 1778.

ATHENS, July 11 Archbishop Iakovos, the Greek Orthodox Archbishop of North and South America, warned today that unless his Church kept up with changing times, it would forfeit the trust of the new generation of Greek-Americans.
ITHACA, N.Y., July 11 Clinton L. Rossiter 3d, historian, political scientist and professor at Cornell University, was found dead today of a heart attack in the basement of his home here.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 11 Leaders of the black community in this seaside resort appealed today for residents to contribute clothing and household goods to families burned out of their apartments during disturbances earlier in the week in which more than 100 people were arrested and 165 injured.

THESE are difficult times for newsmen. Journalism, especially tele vision journalism, is under attack for presenting a one-sided view of the news. But, as I found during a six-week visit to central Florida for the filming of "Migrant An NBC White Paper," a show investigating the living conditions of migrant workers, some of television's severest critics are the very people who make it difficult for journalists to present a balanced story.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 11 In a resumption of major military action, the Vietnamese Communists were reported this morning to have entered the strategically situated mountaintop resort of Kirirom, about 60 miles southwest of Pnompenh.

EVER since John Banister began presenting the first public concerts in London in 1672, impresarios have probably complained of poor attendance, audiences of unsatisfactory programs and less than great performers, artists of insensitive listeners, composers of not getting played. The complaints seem louder than ever today, so much so that the entire concept of concerts as we know them is being questioned.

LONDON, July 11 (UPI) Britian's largest industrial complex, Imperial Chemical Industries, said this week its exports of plastic film material would set a record $28.8-million this year up 20 per cent from the 1969 total.

PELHAM, N.Y., July 11-Miss Jane Adair Shattuck, a great-granddaughter of Frank G. Shattuck, founder of the Schrafft's restaurant chain, and Robert Otto Lepple plan to be married Oct. 3 in the Community Church of Pelham.

THREE recently published books complete a panorama of Amer ican and European chess play at the highest level. Of immediate interest to ardent buffs is the "1969 United States Chess Championship and World Championship Zonal Qualifier," by the U.S. master, Morton Siegel. Published by the United States Chess Federation, 479 Broadway, Newburgh, New York, it sells for $2.50.

LEMONT, Ill., July 11 (AP) Bob Risch of Gardena, Calif., withstood a closing charge by Mike Zimmerman of Kettering, Ohio, today to win the national public links championship by three strokes. Risch shot a 76 for a 5-over-par 293.

LAST Wednesday, on the eve of the opening of the 1970 British Commonwealth Games, an intercommonwealth sports festival similar to the worldwide Olympic Games, Britain issued three multicolored horizontal stamps depicting ac tion of participating athletes. They were printed by Thomas de la Rue, the British Stamp printer, by their Delacryl process.

MILOS FORMAN, the Czechoslovak film director, is eating chunks of watermelon in the breakfast nook of a tidy, one family home in Beechhurst, Queens, looking every inch the American suburbanite in his wheat jeans and striped body shirt. In fact, he's taking a lunch break on the set of his first American movie, which is being shot in this house and at other locations around New York.

The complaints seem louder than ever today, so much so that the entire concept of concerts as we know them is being questioned.

PELHAM, N.Y., July 11-Miss Jane Adair Shattuck, a great-granddaughter of Frank G. Shattuck, founder of the Schrafft's restaurant chain, and Robert Otto Lepple plan to be married Oct. 3 in the Community Church of Pelham.

Published by the United States Chess Federation, 479 Broadway, Newburgh, New York, it sells for $2.50.

Can a large investing real estate company and a local community find happiness together? Yes, but it takes 14 months of mutual negotiation, the exercise of rational expertise on the part of the community and enlightened self-interest from the developer. Can it happen in New York? It has, with the Murray Hill Association and Planning Board No. 6 and Laird Properties, Inc.

As noted here briefly last week, a 6-cent Dwight David Eisenhower definitive stamp will be issued at Washington next month. It will replace the Franklin Delano Roosevelt 6cent stamp (1966) which, with the current 6-cent Flag stamp (1968), have been the normal definitive stamps for the carriage of first-class domestic mail (in addition to various commemorative stamps of similar denomination).
SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 11 Andy Lawrence's Sonata II won Star Class honors today in the second race of the Sea Cliff Yacht Club's three-weekend Commodore series on Hempstead Harbor.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 11 Miss Susan Secor, daughter of Mrs. Thomas LeBoutillier of Old Westbury, and the late Jay K. Secor of Perrysburg, Ohio, was married here this afternoon to John Portner Humes Jr., son of Mr. Humes, Ambassador to Austria, and Mrs. Humes of Vienna and Locust Valley.
FORT DIX, N.J. In the "educational center" here were 15 soldiers newly enrolled in an unorthodox City University of New York program that aims to lead them directly from the service into college.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass, July 11 (AP) A Negro youth was killed and three black youths were injured tonight when occupants of two cars driven through a Negro neighborhood fired into a crowd on a corner, police said.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 11 United States and South Korean military officials opened preliminary talks here today on the United States plan to withdraw some of the 64,000 American troops and airmen from Korea, while South Korean Government leaders began softening their opposition to the troop cutback.

A 2 -year-old boy was admitted to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital in critical condition yesterday morning after his mother told authorities that he had swallowed an LSD tablet. The mother was arrested on a charge of endangering the child's life.

SMOKE RISE, N.J., July 11 Miss Merrill Isabel Adickes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert John Adickes, was married at home here this afternoon to David N. Rich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nelson B. Rich of Mirror Lake, N.H., and Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. John Luttrell, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

CETINJE, Yugoslavia, June 28 Prince-Bishop Peter II, who ruled here from 1830 to 1851 as Montenegro's temporal and ecclesiastical head, was a poet, a philosopher, a crack shot who enjoyed blasting lemons thrown in the air and a billiard addict who had mules carry his own table to his mountainous realm.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Monday, July 13 (AP) Gov. Edgar D. Whitcomb ordered 150 Nation Guard troops into Michigan City early today following a second night of disorders in the predominantly Negro North Side.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 12 The Bostwick brothers, Pete and Jimmy of Long Island's Meadow Brook Club, play a sport in every season. Today they captured the John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament with a 5-under-par bestball team score in the final at Winged Foot Golf Club. They beat Fred Kask, the Connecticut amateur champion, and Bill Brew of Weathersfield, 4 and 3.
RIXENSTRT, Belgium, July 12 At an unusual forum in this serene Walloon village, five students from Europe's oldest graduate school of business judged the modern corporation and found it lacking.

In the unlikely setting of the rolling Jamaica campus of St. John's University, a host of college graduates and undergraduates of various political attachments gathered over the weekend to play war games.

NEWPORT, R.L, July 12 Emil (Bus) Mosbacher has become a "contributor" to the Intrepid cause in the America's Cup defense campaign, ending rumors that he might be called upon to skipper Valiant if the need arose.
Albert Thomas and Tony Colon won 5,000-meter runs yesterday in competition conducted by the Road Runners Club of New York at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

The question of whether allegations of widespread corruption within the New York City Police Department should be investigated by a special five-man commission is scheduled to be argued today before State Supreme Court Justice Harry B. Frank.
[Earlier Mr. Brewster had referred to a society that is "tempted to give up on taking the risk of freedom generally." He was asked at this point to elaborate on the reference.]

The State Division of Human Rights has found that the New York Stock Exchange refused to hire a black man as an employe solely because of his race. It has ordered the exchange to recruit minority group workers and submit periodic reports to the commission for the next two years of the results of this effort.

WASHINGTON, July 12 The Federal auto safety program, despite acknowledged shortcomings, has earned credit even from its critics for curbing the incessant rise in highway deaths. While the number of fatalities has continued to grow, the rate of increase has declined.
Selective Service Director Curtis W. Tarr has made life somewhat easier for some potential draftees but not for their draft boards with his memorandum defining criteria for conscientious objection.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, July 12 The trial of seven leading Tanzanian political figures on charges of treason will enter its third week tomorrow, and lawyers expect it to continue for four more weeks.

In naming the members of his new National Commission on Productivity, President Nixon appears to have employed the commission device for one of its most anciet and least worthy purposes; to simulate action while in fact delaying or preventing it.
POCANTICO HILLS, N.Y., July 12 Miss Nancy Lee Dorfman and William Laurens Pressly Jr. were married here this afternoon in the Union Church by the Rev. Marshall L. Smith.
In this day and age, what should a university be, what do you regard as its mission?

Housewives, grandmothers, teachers and singers troop out of a dressing room in their leotards and bare feet, and then, facing a wall of mirrors, get to work on relaxation, a pretty strenuous undertaking.

Two community planning boards have protested a nearly $10,000 deduction that is being made from a $50,000 grant awarded to a private consultant to study Queensboro Bridge traffic. The amount being cut is to reimburse the city for rent, furniture, equipment and other overhead, because the study will be conducted in office space of the City Planning Commission.
JACKSON, Miss., July 12 A strike by black municipal workers here has turned into a racial dispute that appeared today to raise the prospect of a violent confrontation.
Bond prices are going to continue to rise, but not as fast as they have for the last four weeks.

LA JOLLA, Calif., July 12 The National Association of Laymen, an organization of 12,000 Roman Catholics, has decided that one of its prime activities this year will be opposition to state aid to parochial schools.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Cyrus S. Eaton, the Cleveland industrialist and longtime advocate of closer ties with the Soviet Union, said today that the famed British soldier, Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery believed "a political end to the war in Vietnam is the only possible way to end that war."
The kind of baseball that made the New York Mets famous long before they became glorious cost them another defeat at the hands of the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium yesterday.
MULLENS, W. Va., Monday, July 13 (AP) A dissident group of coal miners seeking liberalized pension benefits set up picket lines early today at mines in West Virginia.

This week Madison Square Garden severs itself from the mass of sports fans. The ticket applications are coming in and piling high as those well-known Knick and Ranger fans, the giant corporations, shovel their money into the round brown building.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 12 The United States military officers' clubs in Taiwan have discontinued the memberships of American business executives, lower-ranking foreign diplomats, and some Chinese national. The privileges of missionaries may be removed later.

BONN, July 12?A leading West German engineering company has signed a contract for delivery of 30 diesel-hydraulic locomotives worth 80-million marks (about $22-million) to Communist China, a spokesman for the company said today.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (UPI) The police tonight arrested a suspect in the bludgeon deaths of three members of a Los Angeles area family. The suspect was identified as Gerard Trent Jr., 24 years old, of Los Angeles.

TEL AVIV, Monday, July 13 An Israeli commando force crossed into Jordan during the night and blew up a Jordanian Army fortification, killing at least four Jordanian soldiers, a military spokesman said here today.

SHORT HILLS, N.J. Juy 12 A bird dog who is flying high on the dog show circuit added another piece of silverware to her owners' collection today. She was named best in a field of 1,348 dogs at the Twin Brooks Kennel Club fixture on The Mall. She is Ch. Canberra's Legend, an English setter owned by Dr. and Mrs. George N. Rosen of Commack, L.I.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan, declaring that political terrorists have begun guerrilla warfare on a national scale, announced today the opening of hearings into bombings this year.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 12 (AP) Business on the beaches and boardwalk of Asbury Park was near normal today. The resort city was nearly deserted at the start of the weekend because of four days of rioting, burning and looting in which 165 people were injured, more than 100 people were arrested and more than $4-million worth damage was done.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 12 (Agence France-Presse) A three-man French television team was captured by a Vietcong patrol near the historic ruins of Angkor Wat in northeastern Cambodia last week, bringing to 23 the number of newsmen missing in the Cambodian war.

LONDON, July 12 Secretary of State William P. Rogers, in talks with Prime Minister Heath today, said that the increased identification of American Negroes with black African causes was a factor in the United States opposition to British plans to resume the sale of arms to South Africa.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 12 (AP) Two corporations and six men connected with them, including Albert B. Chandler, former Senator from Kentucky, are being sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Alice Crimmins is to be arraigned in Queens Criminal Court today on new charges of first-degree murder and firstdegree manslaughter in the deaths of her two young children in 1965.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 12 Nearly 18,000 soldiers and policemen moved into tactical positions in rain-swept Northern Ireland tonight, the eve of big parades celebrating Protestant domination of the, torn country.
PARIS, July 12 (AP) Mrs. Golda Meir, the Israeli Premier, says her Government proposed secret negotiations to the United Arab Republic "two weeks ago" but never received an answer.
PLYMOUTH, England, July 12 (AP) A 44-year-old American yachtsman slipped into Plymouth yesterday after a lone voyage across the Atlantic. He didn't tell anyone here about it until today.
TRENTON, July 12 (AP) Richard Petty of Randalman, N.C., drove his blue, 1970 Plymouth Superbird to victory today in the Schaefer 300-mile NASCAR Grand National race at Trenton Speedway.
An unorganized but extensive movement is under way in coastal areas to save the nation's salt marshes.
The rate of infectious syphilis, which has been steadily decreasing during recent years, increased in the last year by 8.5 per cent, a national health society reported yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 12 George Harrold Carswell's first official day on the political stump in Florida began last week just as his nomination to the United States Supreme Court last winter had started out: sunny and clear with no signs of disturbance on the horizon.

The Chicago Cubs appear well again and ready to do battle for the top spot in the National League Eastern Di vision. Since their late June tailspin, in which they lost 12 straight games, one short of the club record set by the 1944 wartime team, the Cubs have won six of their last eight games, including a 10-2 victory yesterday over the Philadelphia Phillies in Chi cago.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 12 (AP) One of three United States newsmen arrested yesterday during a student demonstration here said today that they had been seized because they were taking pictures of police activities.

Castling kingside is usually normal procedure for both players in the majority of chess games. Castling on the queen wing has a suspicious look. It seems left-handed and needlessly provocative. Instinctively, many buffs believe that a king, on the queen flank, is sulking in unhealthly terrain.

Chet Huntley, who will retire Aug. 1 after 14 years as the New York half of the National Broadcasting Company's Huntley-Brinkley team of newscasters, has told a Life magazine interviewer that he is "overwhelmed" by what he regards as the shallowness of President Nixon and "frightened" by the fact that he is President.

KOMPONG THOM, Cambodia, July 12 Sok Khieu went into the battle line today in this most beleaguered of Cambodian towns, 80 miles north of Pnompenh, trying manfully not to look like a child. For a soldier who insists he is 14 but looks younger he did not do badly.
WINTERHAVEN, Calif., July 12 (AP) The bodies of two marines presumed to have died of carbon monoxide poisoning while exploring an abandoned gold mine were sighted today by rescue teams.

WASHINGTON, July 12 An innovative master plan designed to counter the "academic retardation" of students in the city's nearly all-black school system will be considered by the District of Columbia's board of education tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, July 12 The United States appears to have accelerated its shipments of F-4 Phantom fighter-bombers to Israel, but at the rate that officials here refused to discuss.
BAASTAD, Sweden, July 12 (UPI) Dick Crealy of Australia crushed Georges Goven of France, 6-3, 6-1, 6-1, today in the final of the $33,000 Baastad Grand Prix tournament.

We hear a lot about the financial plight of the university, but there is hardly an area where people aren't now talking about financial stringency. Just how critical is the financial stringency of colleges and universities and what can be done about it?

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., July 12 Col. Clayton E. Wheat, former chaplain and head of the English department at the United States Military Academy at West Point, died yesterday here, where he had resided in recent years. He was 88 years old.

GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., July 12 Mrs. Essie Jeffers Best, widow of Frank Best, was married here this afternoon to Representative Wayne N. Aspinall, Democrat of Colorado. The Rev. Glenn Brown performed the ceremony in the Crossroads Methodist Church.
Sly and the Family Stone, the San Francisco soul band, helped the Forest Hills Music Festival start its 10th season Saturday.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey, which had to get financial assistance from the Norfolk Western and Chesapeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio Railroads to meet its $1.2-million July 3 payroll, expects to be able to meet this Friday's payroll on its own, according to Clarence Jackman, the line's chief operating officer.

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 12 Jack Nicklaus won the British Open by a stroke from Doug Sanders in their 18-hole playoff today. It took an eightfoot downhill putt under almost intolerable pressure on the home hole for a birdie 3 to stave off Sanders's stirring challenge down the stretch.

DELANO, Calif., July 12 Cesar Chavez's five-year campaign to organize farm workers took a major step forward last week when the big vineyards indicated for the first time that they were interested in negotiating union contracts.

A quick canvass of agency executives (at least among those who found the need to work on a Friday afternoon in July) showed that almost to a man they were opposed to their creative people "moonlighting."
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12 For a while there, it looked as if parties for minority underdogs of one sort or another would come to a screeching halt.
NEWPORT, R.L, July 12 It's a little early to start calling Heritage a Southern Belle, but at least she's not an absolute wall flower anymore.

ITHACA, N.Y., July 12 (AP) A funeral service is scheduled Tuesday at Cornell University for Clinton L. Rossiter 3d, political scientist and expert on the American Presidency who died yesterday at the age of 52. The noon service will be conducted at Sage Chapel.
FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 12 (AP) Four Pennsylvanians died today when their light plane crashed into a wooded area north of Route 40 in this Gloucester County community.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 12 The Mayor of this troubled city today imposed a 9 P.M. to 5 A.M. curfew until further notice after attempts to develop a black and white dialogue were engulfed in Negro anger.
LA BAULE, France, July 12 (Reuters) Canada won the cup of Nations the final event at the Internaional horse and jumping show tonight after a jumpoff with France.
The publisher and managing editor of Jock, New York the local sports magazine that was recently suspended and sold will soon be coming out with an altogether new magazine called Sports Guide.

Miss Rita Jeanne Haggerty and Charles William Metz 3d were married yesterday afternoon in the Church of St. Bernard on West 14th Street, founded in 1868 by the Rev. Gabriel A. Healy, a maternal great-great-granduncle of the bride.

WASHINGTON, July 12 Eleven months after the President submitted an occupational safety and health message, saying, "With the advent of a new workplace technology, we must now give similar attention to workplace safety and health." Congress seems ready to act.

The Pan-Helienic Followship, dedicated to the preservation and protection of the Greek language, staged a protest demonstration yesterday across the street from the headquarters of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America at 10 East 79th Street.

A partnership that has a four-four fit in both spades and hearts might be forgiven for assuming that either can be selected as the trump suit. But some such fits are more equal than others, as George Orwell might have said. The relative strength of the suit became a factor on the diagramed deal, which was played in the world team championship in Stockholm last month.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP) Al Oliver snapped a 4-4 tie with a lead-off homer in the 10th inning today and the firstplace Pittsburgh Pirates gained a 7-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.
LONDON, July 12 Is Morag fact or fiction?
Mrs. Johanna Bass, wife of John Bass, a retired sugar executive and philanthropist, died here Saturday night. She was 69 years old and lived at 200 Central Park South and Miami Beach.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 12 A comprehensive plan for Long Island proposes major changes in housing and transportation patterns, "aggressive" park acquisition and the review of zoning at the county level to combat "deterioration and obsolescence."
SANTA CLARA, Calif., July 12 (AP) Debbie Meyer won the 800-meter free-style event today for her third victory in the finale of the annual Santa Clara invitation swimming meet.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 (Reuters) A Saudi Arabian Boeing-707 jet airliner with more than 140 people aboard was brought here tonight after having been hijacked at gunpoint to Damascus, Syria. It returned later to Jidda, Saudi Arabia.

Most people who happen to visit the South Bronx only see the garbage-strewn streets, the burned-out decaying buildings and the hundreds of people who have crossed the border into despair. They think of the high crime rate, of the welfare roll and of drug addiction, which is rampant in the area.

The Washington Darts of the North American Soccer League posted two triumphs within 24 hours over the weekend. The Darts, newcomers to the sixteam pro league, blanked the Kansas City Spurs, 2-0, in Washington yesterday, after they had defeated the Dallas Tornado, 2-0, in Dallas Saturday night.

MONTE CARLO, Monaco, July 12 Ballet is almost as at home at Monte Carlo as gambling, and in fact they have much in common. It was between World War I and World War II that ballet knew its finest days in Monte Carlo, for it was then, first under Serge Diaghilev and later his successors, that the old Ballet Russe used the town, and the Principality of Monaco, as its working base.
TEL AVIV, July 12 (Reuters) The most wanted guerrilla in Israeli-held territory was killed Friday after more than two years at the top of wanted lists, it was announced today.
WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., July 12 Denis Hulme won the third Can-Am race of the season today, making it the McLaren team's third consecutive victory of the season and the 16th straight since 1968.

WASHINGTON, July 12 A "low-profile" Government mission to the countries of Eastern Europe the first of its kind has returned with the conclusion that in at least two of these countries it may be possible for United States companies to establish profit-making joint ventures.
DURBAN, South Africa, July 2 The new chief of the Zulus has forcefully challenged the South African Government to put into effect its policy of black self-rule.
One of the top-ranking Biblical scholars in the Englishspeaking world has accepted the first joint professorship offered by a Protestant divinity school and a Roman Catholic seminary.
A couple of exuberant young people sat in the middle of Fifth Avenue Saturday afternoon, smiling at the passers-by. Passers-by smiled back.

Henry Crown, the Chicago financier who has been moving to regain control of the General Dynamics Corporation, has taken full charge of the company's profitable subsidiary, the Material Service Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
MSCOW, July 12 Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, today attacked as "ideologically vicious and artistically weak" two novels that had stirred the indignation of liberal Soviet intellectuals.

TORONTO, July 12 In the United States, economists and business analysts have talked wistfully for years about getting one comprehensive, monthly figure on the strength of the economy. They still must settle for Washington's quarterly data on the gross national product.
Could you elaborate, Mr. Brewster, on the points you made about disenchantment with the political process, the rigidity of education, and what is required to cope with this.
MUNICH, West Germany, July 12 (AP) Chi Cheng of Taiwan set a world record in the women's 200-meter dash today with a time of 22.4 seconds.
MILWAUKEE, July 12 (AP) Deane Beman shot a threeunder-par 69 today and posted a three-stroke victory in the $110,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.
An easy and thoughtful gesture a parent or grandparent can make for a child's future is a gift of securities to be held in a custody account.

MARLBORO, Vt., July 12 There was a great deal of good music at the two opening concerts of the Marlboro Music Festival. Indeed, there was nothing but good music. Nevertheless, as is inevitable when so glamorous a veteran as Pablo Casals participates in a program, there was one sentimental favorite over the weekend, and that was, of course, Mr. Casals.

STOWE, Vt., July 12 Mrs. Cheever Porter's Ch. Legend of Gael, C.D., a Gordon setter gained his seventh best-in-show award today at the Green Mountain Dog Club competition. It was the 23d group victory for the 5 -year-old dog.

LONDON, July 12 Secretary of State William P. Rogers has concluded during his twoweek journey in Asia and to Britain that the Communists have no immediate interest in negotiating a peace settlement in Vietnam.

TUBAYONG, the Philippines, July 12 The unequal contest between pagan hill tribesmen and Christian lowlanders that has cast a pall of violence and fear in this frontier area of the Southern Philippines has now been put before President Ferdinand E. Marcos.
MIAMI BEACH, July 12 (UPI)-The new Miss Universe, Marisol Malaret Contreras, said today that she was excited about the prospect of traveling around the world.
A girl whose body was found late Saturday on a lot in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn was identified by her mother yesterday as Wendy Abramson, 17 years old.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 12 A group of nonwhite students has broken away from the National Union of South African Students, the largest student organization in South Africa, and formed their own exclusively nonwhite South African Students Organization.
BRIDGETOWN, Barbados July 12 (Reuters) The papyrus reed boat Ra II with its captain, the Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl, arrived today in Bridgetown after a 57-day voyage from Morocco.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 L. Wolfe Gilbert, composer of more than 250 songs, including "Ramona," the first motion picture theme song, died today of a stroke. He was 83 years old.
When Paul Mayen sends out his Christmas greetings, they are small metallic puzzles that recipients are likely to save as art objects once they have put them together.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he expected President Nixon to come here this fall to campaign for them Republican ticket headed by Governor Rockefeller and Senator Charles E. Goodell.

A Navy doctor, the Coast Guard and the cardiac-arrest unit of Peninsula General Hospital teamed up yesterday afternoon to save the life of a Brooklyn youth who was thought to have drowned at Bergen Beach on Jamaica Bay.

LONDON, July 12 (UPI) Representatives of British dockworkers and their employers resumed talks today amid apparently waning prospects, that the country's first total port shutdown in 44 years could be averted.
NEW LONDON, Conn., July 12 The 23d season of the American Dance Festival began with particularly strong performances here last night in a program by the Lucas Hoving Dance Company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 13 A United States helicopter-borne assault and a B-52 raid that followed were reported today to have killed at least 384 North Vietnamese soldiers and to have wounded many more. American officials termed the action the sharpest setback in months for enemy forces in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 12 The Federal Trade Commission has proposed new guidelines that would establish significantly tighter standards for the nation's correspondence schools and private vocational institutions.
WASHINGTON, July 12 A member of the Federal Reserve Board said over the weekend he doubts that a higher unemployment level than now would bring any faster progress against inflation.
The city is considering a plan under which apartment house strikers would return to operate essential services, and the city would collect rents to pay them.
Dismay and even a touch of panic has been set off in France's Gaullist party by its defeat in a single parliamentary by-election in a distant province far from Paris.

BRUSSELS, July 12 Japanese mining interests, which moved into the former Belgian Congo when its relations with Belgium were at a freezing point, have struck it rich and by October, 1972, hope to extract 54,000 tons of copper per year from their new concessions in Katanga Province.

PITTSBURGH, July 12 Steel producers are anxiously awaiting word of the buying plans of automobile companies. Mill officials are hoping the auto companies will provide a general lift when they place orders for late August and for September.

An acute financial crisis is threatening the solvency or growth of many institutions of higher learning as they seek to rebuild public confidence and resist any encroachment on their freedom, according to presidents of major colleges and universities in this area.

WASHINGTON, July 12 Mel Stottlemyre, one of three Yankee players on the American League All-Star team, hardly looked the part today as he was battered by the Senators on their way to a 7-3 triumph at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.
LONDON, July 12 Traditionalists in the City are aflutter over the prospect of "a financial supermarket" crowding into their narrow streets.

A new study asserts that the pattern in New York City's voting for Mayor last year indicates that the "polarization of racial feeling has become probably the strongest political force agitating New York City's voters."

An item titled "HelloGoodbye" looks and sounds like something that Francoise Sagan might have thought up during a lunch hour at the Cannes Film Festival, scribbled on a small table napkin and peddled to a desperate moviemaker.

ST. LOUIS, July 12 (UPI) Mayor Alfonso J. Cervantes said today that he could not wait "a year or more" for his lawsuit to prove that the recent article in Life magazine linking him with the underworld was untrue so he has issued an article.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 12 The time-limit rule in yacht racing says that if one yacht finishes within the prescribed period, it is an official race for all the yachts in that class.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 12 (Canadian Press) The Soviet Union remained the master in the world amateur wrestling championships, which ended last night. Soviet grapplers, who dominated the Greco-Roman events, captured their second straight team title with brilliant performances in the free-style, taking four gold medals all in the heavyweight classes.

ROME, July 12 Pope Paul VI expressed joy today that Communist China had freed the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, an American missionary bishop, from prison and said he would like to see in this decision "a sign of better days."
WASHINGTON, July 12 The United States is pressing a drive to persuade Latin-American countries not to relax the diplomatic and economic boycott against the Castro Government in Cuba.

The nationwide unemployment rate, now approximately 5 per cent, is expected to increase to 5 per cent by the end of this year, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional director here of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Senator Jacob K. Javits and Arthur Ashe combined sagacity and a delicate touch at the net yesterday to outfinesse Jim Brown and Herb FitzGibbon in a good-humored exhibition tennis match in Central Park.

A sharp drop in theater business in the early days of July killed two show last week. "Charley's Aunt" with Louis Nye and Maureen O'Sullivan and "Room Service" with Dick Shawn, both revivals, closed Saturday night.
What do you consider to be some of the most basic problems confronting your university or college?
DAYTON, Ohio, July 12 On Wednesday morning, Dayton is scheduled to become the nation's fourth largest city with a black Mayor.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 12 This state capital, nestled in the narrow green Kanawha Valley of the Appalachian Mountains, has become a testing ground for the Nixon Administration's policy of financing highways only after adequate replacement housing is fully ready for people living in the highway's right-of-way.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 After paying tribute to Louis Armstrong on Friday night, the Newport Jazz Festival yesterday turned to a wide variety of jazz styles and jazz groups, but once again a trumpeter turned out to be the key to the day's programing.

Jefrey Arlen, M.D., does not have an answering service, but he sleeps on a mattress on the floor in the back of his office. His head is usually off the pillow at the first ringing of the doorbell by a patient on a bad trip.
MADRID, July 12 (AP) Van Campen Heilner, author, explorer and protege of the late author Zane Grey, died here today. He was 71 years old.

NORWALK, Conn., July 12 William Salzman, former president of the Standard Bag Corporation and a founder of institutions concerning Hebrew studies, died at Norwalk Hospital yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 1120 Park Avenue.
ROME, July 12 At the age of 51, Premier-designate Giulio Andreotti is still young by the standards of Italian politics.

With most other American institutions being subjected to rebellious scrutiny, it was unlikely that certain venerable practices of Congress would long escape critical attention. The improbable vehicle for such examination is one of those Legislative Reorganization bills which periodically allow Congress to study itself in a mirror specially designed to reassure it that, in spite of a few minor flaws, it is still the fairest one of all.

The American Ballet Theater, justifiably proud of its new production of "Petrouchka," presented two performances of it yesterday at the close of the company's season at the State heater. In the evening, Royes Fernandez danced "Petrouchka" for the first time this season. Diana Weber and Han Ebbelaar were the "Dancer" and "Blackamoor," respectively, at the matinee.

Gil Hodges, manager of the National League All-Stars, said yesterday that Joe Morgan, Houston Astro second baseman, would replace Felix Millan of Atlanta on the squad for tomorrow night's game at Cincinnati.
PARIS, July 12 Yves SaintMartin, the French champion jockey, yesterday signed a three-year contract to ride for the 300-horse stable of Daniel Wildenstein, are dealer and philanthropist.

Off-duty policemen carrying placards and an American flag picketed the station of the 19th Precinct on East 67th Street yesterday to protest the use of city policemen for guard duty in front of consulates and United Nations missions in the area.
WASHINGTON, July 13 A sharp dispute over charges that a Senator had made public highly classified information on the Army's "electronic battlefield" project broke out on the Senate floor today.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 13 The Rev. John N. Warren, rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Oyster Bay, L.I. for 27 years, died here today after a long illness.

President Nixon has ordered Federal Bureau of Investigation protection for Mrs. John N. Mitchell, wife of the Attorney General, but she believes that the families of Cabinet members would be safer living in a protected compound, it was reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) The three top-ranked Americans, led by Stan Smith of Los Angeles, registered victories today in the first round of the $35,000 Washington Star international tennis tournament.

BOSTON, July 13 (AP) Massachusetts motorists will have to pay an estimated total of $23-million in additional insurance premiums this year as the result of a ruling today by the State Supreme Judicial Court.

NEWARK, July 13 (AP) Dominick A. Spina, former Newark Police Director, who lost his job when Kenneth A. Gibson was elected Mayor last month, was appointed today as "staff assistant" to the Chief of Police.

ROME, July 13 On the way to the showings in the couture salons one passes furniture shops with gleaming white plastic wares that turn up in the most traditional homes in the form of globular lamps or translucent ice buckets. But the fashion people have turned their backs on the ugly, polluted, overpopulated modern world.

Mrs. Alice Crimmins collapsed and fell to the floor in a faint in the Fresh Meadows, Queens, police station yesterday as she was booked on new charges of murder and manslaughter in the deaths of her son and daughter five years ago.

MONTREAL, July 13 (Canadian Press) The International Air Transport Association today reported an 11.5 per cent increase in total scheduled passenger traffic by member airlines in 1969. The Montrealbased organization has 104 member airlines 91 active and 13 associate in 85 countries.
ATHENS, July 13 Greece's military-backed Government announced the formation of a 13-man board of advisers today to help Premier George Papadopoulos administer the country.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The White House choice for director of Volunteers in Service to America is reported to have rejected the appointment because of sharp disagreement with President Nixon's Indochina and domestic policies.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Senator John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, charged the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission today with harrassment of businesses and exceeding Congressional intent in using its authority.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 13 Miss Susan Annan Guernsey and Duke Nordlinger Stern were married here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Thomas Fuller. A reception was held at the Edgartown Yacht Club.

The case for increased exchange rate flexibility has been brought home to the United States over the past three years. The political onus traditionally attached to devaluation or even upward revaluation of currencies led Britain, France and West Germany into overlong delays in making needed adjustments. As it became increasingly evident that larger adjustments would be necessary, massive waves of speculation shook the West's monetary stability.

Georgie Soloway has a private Cessna and lives in a penthouse on top of the General Motors Building. He is 40ish, an enormously successful rock composer. Suddenly, someone named Harry Kellerman begins to destroy systematically all of his personal and professional relationships by telling everyone what a rat he is.

HOUSTON, July 13 The Nixon Administration began prosecuting today an 18month-old suit charging the International Longshoremen's Association with illegally maintaining 37 segregated union locals in Texas.
Following a Government crop report, issued late Friday, some, soybean futures prices rose the daily limit yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

CINCINNATI, July 13 (UPI) Earl Weaver, the Baltimore manager who is handling the American League players in tomorrow's All-Star Game, has an idea for "screening" those excused from playing because of injuries.

CEDARHURST, L. I., July 13 Jimmy Wright of Inwood, began his quest today for the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association 54-hole medal play championship with a 34, 35 69 over the par 35.35 70 Rockaway Hunting Club layout that measures 6,304 yards.
LOS ANGELES, July 13 (UPI) The selection of 12 permanent jurors was apparently completed today at the murder trial of Charles Manson and three young women members of his "family."

HONG KONG, July 13 (AP) The Most Rev. James E. Walsh, a Roman Catholic bishop freed by Communist China three days ago after 12 years in prison, may be flown to Rome for a meeting with Pope Paul VI when the doctors decide he is fit to travel.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) President Nixon described himself today as a "student radical" and failed to recognize at a White House reunion of the Whittier College class of 1934 a girl he once dated. His old classmates called him "Mr. President" instead of Dick.
The United Funds and Council of America announced here yesterday that it had changed its name to the United Way of America.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13 The opening round of the 18th annual Ike golf tournament today belonged almost exclusively to a group of 1970 college graduates and undergraduates led by Greg Powers of stamford, Conn., and Paul Samanchik of Wavne, N. J.

FIRE SUPPORT BASE VEGHEL, South Vietnam, July 13 Gen. William C. Westmoreland, back in Vietnam for the first time since he left two years ago to be Army Chief of Staff, dropped in today at this post near Hue and voiced optimism about the war.

OAK RIDGE, July 13 Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California who is chairman of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy, joined Senator Albert Gore. Democrat of Tennessee, tonight in denouncing what they said was the Nixon Administration's proposal to sell the nation's only nuclear fuel plants.
The Liberal party in Queens re-elected J. Stanley Shaw as its county chairman last night at a turbulent meeting marked by charges of "boss control" at the state level.
WASHINGTON, July 13 President Nixon will throw out two "first balls" at the annual All-Star Game in Cincinnati tomorrow night one each for the American and National Leagues.

LINDEN, N.J., July 13 Dr. Samuel B. Harris, a dentist here for many years and a leader in the Jewish community, died yesterday at Rahway Memorial Hospital, after a heart attack. He was 58 years old and lived at 5 Raritan Road.
New financing for the $300-million Robe River ironore mining project in Australia was announced yesterday by officials of American concerns participating in the multinational development.

WASHINGTON, July 13 A House watchdog committee today demanded a prompt and thorough Federal investigation of conditions at South Vietnam's Con Son Prison, where "titer-cage imprisonment and savage mistreatment of human beings" was charged last week by two Representatives who visited the scene.
The SCM Corporation said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had completed a review of SCM's office copier marketing practices by upholding a provisional order issued in April.

"From the beginning," writes Fredrick W. Turner 3d in his superb introduction to Geronimo's autobiography, "the Chiricahua raised their males to be strong, swift, deep-chested runners, rustlers of stock and raiders of pack trains, good hiders and dodgers, and implacable haters of nontribal neighbors.
RYE, N. Y., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. Armand M. Morrell have announced the engagement of Mrs. Morrell's daughter, Miss Anne Dolores Davis, to Richard Alden Ray Pinkham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Pinkham.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 13 Noccalula, beaten 6 lengths by Dayan last Saturday night in the $50,000 American Trotting championship at Roosevelt Raceway, today was designated...

TRENTON, July A defense witness said under cross-examination here today that Anthony P. LaMorte, former Director of Public Works of Newark, who is on trial for extortion conspiracy with former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, accepted a gift of airplane tickets to Florida and free lodging there from a contractor doing business with the city.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 The United States command reported today that the number of American troops in South Vietnam had dropped to 411,500, the lowest in more than three years.

Corporations with medium-grade credit ratings are finding it increasingly difficult to borrow money. This trend, which started when the Penn Central Transportation Com pany filed for reorganization on June 21, became more evident yesterday.

In February, 1969, a mildmannered Reform Democrat from the Bronx named Benjamin Altman rose on the floor of the Assembly to rebuke Mayor Lindsay for "pussy-footing around" with rent control for uncontrolled apartments.

WASHINGTON, July 13 For years scientists have assumed that the master chemical called DNA always dictated the pattern for transmission of hereditary characteristics. Now it appears that this master chemical of life is sometimes produced on orders from another chemical.

The Lindsay administration declared yesterday that emergencies existed in 14 strikebound East and West Side buildings. It said the buildings were heaped with garbage and lacked elevator service and hot water.
NEW TOWN, N.D., July 7 In a sudden reversal of roles, the white homesteaders of this region are living in fear that the Indians will run them off the land.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 13 Pounding drums and waving orange banners, nearly 100,000 matchers trooped past barbed-wire barriers in Northern Ireland today to celebrate Protestant control of this tortured state.
Predictable of the Wheatley Stable redeemed herself, after a fashion, by winning the featured six-furlong race at Aqueduct yesterday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 13 (UPI) Baffle, winner of the California and Inglewood Handicaps at Hollywood Park this season, was retired to stud today because of a leg injury, Johnny Longden, his trainer, announced.

MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Tuesday, July 14 The streets of this city's North Side black neighborhood were deserted this morning as National Guard troops and the state and local police enforced a 9 P.M.-to-6 A.M. curfew.

CINCINNATI, July 13 In a setting so brand new it isn't really completed, though functional, the outstanding baseball players of today will square off tomorrow evening in the 41st major league AllStar Game on the artifical surface of Riverfront Stadium.

Benjamin Altman, the city's Commissioner of Rent and Housing Maintenance, charged yesterday that the apartmenthouse workers strike had been provoked by 22 "hard-core, greedy and irresponsible landlords" whom he identified by name.

R. Kenneth Davis, general manager of the offtrack betting system for the State of Victoria in Australia, predicted yesterday that New York City would net $2-billion in the next decade from offtrack betting.
The Last four of the nation's top 10 banking organizations to disclose their profits for the first half of 1970 reported yesterday.
ROME, July, 13 Premierdesignate Giulio Andreotti received the formal endorsement of his own party, the Christian Democrats, today for an attempt to rebuild a governing coalition.

President Nixon was praised yesterday the chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations for leaving "no ground for miscalculation" to "a potential aggressor" in the Middle East.

PITTSBURGH, July 13 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Steelers said that Terry Bradshaw, their rookie quarterback, suffered a minor injury today in a workout for the College All-Star Game at Chicago and would be brought back here for an examination.

MADRID, July 13 (AP) Prince Juan Carlos presided in place of Generalissimo Francisco Franco today at the funeral of Capt. Gen Agustin Muflos Grandes, Spanish war hero and a friend of the Chief of State.

On the green Uni-Turf court in the Felt Forum yesterday, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales yelled across the net to Francisco (Pancho) Segura as two 15-year-old high school tennis champions joined them for a practice session.

SEASIDE PARK, N.J., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Wynne Jr. of North Haven, Conn., and Seaside Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Fielding Wynne, to John Robert Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Lewis of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The wedding is planned for November in Hamden.

After a good number of years with a succession of New York ad agencies, Braniff International of Dallas is taking its advertising account West. Starting Oct. 15 its agency will be Clinton E. Frank, Inc., Chicago. The airline said yesterday that its advertising and promotional budget is $8-million a year.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 13 American intelligence officials have turned up evidence of a movement toward South Vietnam by some North Vietnamese regiments well north of the demilitarized zone.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 13 Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Davies Wingebach have announced the engagement of Mrs. Wingebach's daughter, Miss June Wood Alling, to Samuel Hunter Richey, son of Mrs. C. Buff Scott of Rye and John M. Richey of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for September.
SAN DIEGO, July 13 The United States gave Mexico $1million in aircraft and financial aid today for control of drug traffic across the border.
Records in sales and earnings were posted by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the quarter and six months ended June 30, the Company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 13 Pettiffogery has hampered American conduct of international negotiations over the years, an authority on the art of negotiating has told the Senate.

The International Business Machines Corporation continued its revenue and earnings growth in the second quarter with the highest results of any quarter in its history. It also lifted its figures for the first half to records, according to the company's midyear report issued yesterday.

MANILA, July 13 In an extraordinary trial in his palace office, President Ferdinand E. Marcos today suspended murder charges against the chief of a pagan hill tribe accused of killing two members of the Philippine national police.

The producers of this weekend's three-day rock festival on Randalls Island said yesterday that an undisclosed portion of the profit would be contributed to the Young Lords, the White Panthers and other groups for their community projects.

For the first time since 1962 the Russians will compete at Forest Hills. Two men and two women will play in the $160,000 United States Open tennis championships starting Sept. 2 at the West Side Tennis Club in Queens.

If Japanese influence prevails, as now seems likely, the continued existence of the most fabulous creature on earth is in gravest jeopardy. Supported by the representatives of Russia and Norway, the Japanese members of the International Whaling Commission have flatly rejected a scientifically based proposal that whale quotas be drastically reduced in the Antarctic, where some two-fifths of the world's whaling is now done.

The engagement of Miss Anna-Dietlinde Skazel to Stephen Edward Gilhuley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward John Gilhuley Jr. of Upper Nyack, N.Y., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hans Dieter Skazel of Vienna.

WASHINGTON, July 13 A Senate-House conference committee reported out today a tough anticrime bill for the District of Columbia that contains provisions permitting the preventive detention of certain suspected criminals and "noknock" entry by the police.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 13 (AP) The 12-Meter sloop American Eagle was the first across the finish line today in the annual Port Huron-toMackinac race, but on corrected times Charisma of Chicago was the over-all winner in Class A.

CINCINNATI, July 13 More than three decades ago a couple of Cincinnati pitchers, Lee Grissom and Gene Schott, made an unforgettable contribution to photographic history. For the benefit of enterprising cameramen whose pictures were irresistible to newspapers throughout the country, the two prankish players stepped into a rowboat at the old Red Leg park, Crosley Field, and rowed the boat over the center-field fence.

Robed (Sonny) Wood, a detective in the New York City Police Department and a former professional basketball player, died of a cerebral hemmorhage Saturday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 47 Years old and lived at 22-23 98th Street, East Elmhurst in Queens.

Judge Edward C. McLean of the Federal District Court here yesterday ordered a hearing Thursday on a proposed settlement of condemnation proceedings involving Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc.
Several more major companies announced yesterday that they were reducing prices for copper and brass mill products by three cents a pound of copper content and by one cent a pound lead content.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 13 Reports of fires and of confrontations between the police and Negroes circulated through the Negro community in the West End here this afternoon while Negro residents and elected officials held long sessions on ways to head off further violence.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 Jordanian and Lebanese military spokesmen reported repulsing Israeli thrusts today.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The New York Stock Exchange, in calculating the earnings of its member firms to make its case for an extension of the special surcharge on small orders, did not include a major item of income for member firms that its own economic consultants said should have been included.

BONN, July 13 Foreign Minister Walter Scheel of West Germany is expected to fly to London and Washington later this week to discuss the forthcoming negotiations between Bonn and Moscow for a treaty on renunciation of force.

It is a great relief that the Orange Day celebrations in Northern Ireland have been carried off apparently without bloodshed and with only minor acts of lawlessness. There is no cause even for temporary complacency, however; an uneasy truce was maintained by the largest British peacekeeping force deployed in the North since the partition of Ireland in 1921, by a virtual state of siege, and by sealing off Catholic areas in the cities.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) A citizens committee was set up today to organize grassroots support for a bill to require United States withdrawal from Indochina.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, July 14 (Reuters) Cambodian troops were reported today to have fought their way into the beleaguered resort of Kirirom, but to have arrived too late to save many of the 400man garrison in the town.
BINHSON HAMLET, South Vietnam, July 10 The trouble in Binhson hamlet is all the missing men. They left to join the Vietcong.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Two university presidents and two student leaders will be among the first witnesses Wednesday when the new President's Commission on Campus Unrest begins three days of televised public hearings.
