UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 13-Youthful participants from South Vietnam and Nationalist China were denied the right to speak at the World Youth Assembly today, prompting 30 delegates from 19 countries to walk out in protest.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 12 Nick Monte, proprietor of Gurney's Inn, who started angling as a 4-year-old in Brooklyn's Gowanus Canal with a piece of string and a diaper pin, wasn't surprised yesterday by unexpected news.

FORT BRAGG, N. C., July 13 (UPI) An Army hearing officer was told today that hair found on a hairbrush in the apartment of Capt. Jeffrey MacDonald, who is accused of slaying his wife and daughters, did not belong to any member of the MacDonald family.

NEW LONDON, Conn. July 13 Connecticut College's American Dance Festival, for more than two decades the hallowed ground upon which the giants of modern-dance have created some of their best work, is breaking ground as well as sanctifying it this year.

Psychic bids are rarely attempted in serious tournament play, but there were a few examples in the recent world pair championship in Stockholm. The diagramed deal was perhaps the only case in which both pairs tried to steal from each other, and the result was distinctly comical.

TRENTON, July 13 (AP) The New Jersey Clean Air Council recommended today that the state place limitations on the use of automobiles, trucks and buses to alleviate what it called a highly dangerous air-pollution condition.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The Federal Bureau of Investigation today branded the Black Panther party as the country's "most dangerous and violenceprone of all extremist groups."

In junior and senior high schools throughout the country, the initials "FHA" do not usually bring to mind the Federal body in Washington that makes loans to prospective home owners. Instead, they refer to the Future Homemakers of America, an organization of 600,000 teenage girls who hope someday to be the wives and mothers of America.

LONDON, July 13 (UPI) Britain's longshoremen canceled a call for the first nationwide dock strike in 44 years tonight four hours before it was to begin and agreed to consider a revised contract offered by port managers.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., July 13 William Hoeferlin, who mapped out and maintained over 50 trails in New York State and New Jersey died yesterday, apparently after a heart attack while leading his hiking group, the Wanderbirds, near the Hudson River here. He was 72 years old and lived at 556 Fairview Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens.
The Rolling Crepe has come to Broadway, and it's not a singing group but a Volkswagen microbus parked at 115th Street offering crepes filled with chicken and sherry or ratatouille or spiced apple.

Federal Judge John P. Fullam of the District Court in Philadelphia directed the Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday to segregate and hold in escrow, subject to further court orders, the $1.50-a-share dividend payable tomorrow on the common stock of the Pittsburgh Lake Erie Railroad.
PHOENIX, South Africa, July 1 The multiracial Mahatma Gandhi Memorial Center here stands as a challege to the increasingly segregated society around it.
LOS ANGELES, July 13 He is not happy to be interviewed, this gray-haired, florid-faced multimillionaire pacing the rug in a parlor of his mansion in West Los Angeles. He does not like publicity.

LONDON, July 13 (UPI) Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery said today that the United States industrialist, Cyrus S. Eaton, had broken a confidence in making public a letter saying President Nixon was "totally unfit to be Commander in Chief of the United States armed forces."

JERUSALEM, July 13 Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel proposed today, that Israeli and Egyptian representatives meet informally "without prejudice to their respective positions" to start breaking the diplomatic deadlock on the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) The Justice Department ruled today that Gen. Lucius D. Clay, board chairman, and three other directors of the Federal National Mortgage Association had not violated conflict-of-interest laws even though they were associated with concerns doing business with Fanny May.

Right now the odds are that at least one of every 10 outdoor pay phones in Manhattan is out of order and probably is swallowing customers' dimes without yielding so much as a penny's worth of service.
A $50,000 study of Queensboro Bridge traffic is the fifth such study since 1968, the eighth since 1963 and the 10th since 1948.

LARCHMONT, N.J., July 13 Blaine Wise and Creighton Condon, both of the Larchmont Yacht Club, and Wally Corwin of the American Yacht Club came out of the harrowing sailing that began the three-day teen-aged portion of Larchmont Race Week as winners today.

Arguing that "police corruption occasionally reaches endemic conditions here, a lawyer for the city said yesterday that the special investigating commission appointed by the Mayor was needed to develop methods to prevent such graft.
Cinerama, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation's 50.5 per cent stock interest in Plume Atwood Industries, Inc.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 13 (AP) A small group of miners' widows and disabled miners, including a man who lost both legs in a mine accident, closed down at least 16 mines in three states today to dramatize their demands for liberalized pension benefits.

In a lackluster day, stocks on the American Stock Exchange managed to inch upward to 19.96 as measured by the exchange's index. The increase was 0.03 above the close on Friday. Volume was a dull 1,674,940 shares in the slowest day since May 11, when just over 1,600,000 shares changed hands.

Under belated pressure from the United States Embassy, the South Vietnamese Government has promised provisionally to abolish the inhuman "tiger cage" punishment cells uncovered by two unorthodox Congressional investigators, Representatives Augustus F. Hawkins of California, and William R. Anderson of Tennessee. The two Congressmen departed from an otherwise routine "fact-finding" junket to visit the prison and expose the "tiger cages" which had been described to them by a former prisoner.

The Public Service Commission ordered the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday to reduce "the ever-present hazard" of underground explosions by setting up a more effective system of detecting and repairing natural-gas leaks.

About 150 Italian-Americans picketed the offices of the National Broadcasting Company at 49 West 49th Street, for three hours yesterday evening to protest alleged defamation of Italians by a program shown on Channel 4 Sunday evening.

WASHINGTON, July 13 President Nixon has decided to step up diplomatic relations with the new Cambodian Government of Premier Lon Nol by naming Emory C. Swank, a senior diplomat, as the first United States Ambassador to Cambodia since 1965.

PENSACOLA, Fla., July 13 Vice Adm. Austin K. Doyle, former Chief of Naval Air Training, died today at the Pensacola Naval Air Station Hospital after a short illness. Admiral Doyle, who has lived here ever since he retired from the Navy 12 years ago, was 72 years old.

Mayor Lindsay broke ground yesterday in a block-square vacant lot on East 143d Street to begin construction of the first Model Cities housing project in the South Bronx a 309apartment public housing project.

The new position of provost at the University of Notre Dame has been filled by the Rev. James T. Burtchaell, the 36-year-old chairman of the university's department of theology. His appointment is effective Sept. 1.
WASHINGTON, July 13 In a heated confrontation in an echoing Senate hearing room today, the Nixon Administration argued that it was pursuing the only legally permissible school desegregation policy.
For thousands of tenants in struck apartment houses here, a major problem is garbage disposal.

A policeman's vote is as free as any other citizen's. As an individual, he has the right that anyone else has to endorse a candidate for public office and to make known his choice. While these are his privileges as a citizen, it is essential that they be kept separate from his status as an officer of the law. Certainly they ought not to be exercised on his behalf by a professional policemen's organization.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell was rebuffed yesterday in his legal effort to force a new primary election in the 18th Congressional District, where he was narrowly defeated for the Democratic nomination by Charles B. Rangel in the June 23 primary.
LUSAKA, Zambia Hopes have been raised for development of a big new Zambian copper mine 100 miles north of Lusaka on old workings.

RICHMOND, July 13 (AP) Virginia Democrats will pick a nominee for the Senate from three candidates, rated moderate to liberal, in a primary election tomorrow. The winner will run against Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., an independent, and Ray L. Garland, a Republican in November.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit ruled yesterday that two umpires fighting their discharge by the American League were not victims of an antitrust violation.

The Queens County Democratic Committee designated its first black chairman last night, elevating Assemblyman Guy R. Brewer from vice chairman to the post formerly held by Ralph De Marco, Mr. De Marco will seek election later this week as Queens County Democratic leader.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) Any city or town in New York State can demand and get a census recheck, Representative Daniel E. Button, Republican of New York, said today.

CINCINNATI, July 13 As All-Star players gathered for one of baseball's two major annual shows, officials displayed today some of the promotional gimmicks they hope will attract additional attention to the game.

In 1761, some burghers living on a spindle-shaped island in what is now Long Island Sound devised an ambitious plan to develop the place as a booming seaport that could compete with and someday overshadow the then burgeoning city of New York. The scheme failed, but the name chosen for the envisioned metropolis City Island lingers.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 13 (AP) This seashore community returned closer to normal today, following racial disturbances, with the withdrawal of the last of the State Police troopers called to help quell the disorders.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 13(AP) Premier Chung II Kwon said today he and all 19 members of his Cabinet would resign if the United States carried out a plan for a reduction of 20,000 troops in South Korea.
Bucherer, a Swiss concern that makes and sells watches and fine jewelry, has opened its first shop in this country with an exhibition of jewelry that looks like the cache of a mermaid.

DETROIT, July 13 The four car makers today reported that their dealers delivered 181,491 new United States-type automobiles July 1-10, down 1 per cent from sales of 183,123 in the year-earlier period.
The 26 National Football League teams have agreed to prohibit experienced players from reporting to training camp, pending a settlement in continuing negotiations with the N.F.L. Players Association.
MOSCOW, July 13 The Communist party's Central Committee announced today that the 24th party congress would be postponed to next March.

LONDON, July 13 (Reuters) Five British sailors aboard a minesweeper, the Iveston, were charged with mutiny today over a sitdown protest they allegedly made because they considered their ship had been too long at sea.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 13 Intrepid's second promotional button in the Americ's Cup trials has already been programmed: Catch 22.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 13 Miss Anne Purvis Bailey and Stephen Hapgood Watters, June graduates of Denison University, plan to be married on Aug. 29.

At least 45,000 Westchester County and Connecticut commuters were delayed up to two hours yesterday morning by a fire on the Penn Central's Harlem River drawbridge. Railroad officials said it was the worst tie-up on the line in at least two years.
It may well be that the best thing the economy and the stock market have going for them is the prohibitively costly burden of waging war in Indochina.

HONG KONG, July 13 A rash of murders by gangs of youths whose favored weapons are triangular files, knives, iron bars and meat cleavers, and the disclosure of official statistics showing a 28 per cent increase in crime over five years have aroused public concern.

PARIS, July 13 The warning is being heard with increasing frequency, almost as if the forces have irreversibly been set in motion: The United States and the European Economic Community are on the brink of a trade war.
Robert Lightbourne, Jamaica's Minister of Trade and Industry, yesterday sharply criticized a recommendation for the nationalization of banks and mining and other enterprises in the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The House Ways and Means Committee rejected today a major provision of the Nixon Administration's trade bill the provision to repeal the "American Selling Price" system of customs valuation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13 Richard Christian Hemingway, president and director of Newsrad, Inc., an electronic concern in New York, died at his home here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

SAN GABRIEL, Calif., July 13 (AP) Siegfried Fred Senff, a 38-year-old, German-born father of two, was charged today with murder, attempted murder and arson in the claw-hammer attack on his family and subsequent house fire, the police said.
The stock market moved upward yesterday for the fourth consecutive day, but the enthusiasm of the three previous sessions seemed to have disappeared.
NORWALK, Conn., July 13 Peter J. Collins, architect and engineer, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 61 Years old and lived at 68 Canterbury Lane in Walton.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., July 13 Dr. Jacob M. Ross, former principal of Midwood High School in Brooklyn, New York, died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived at 3001 South Ocean Drive.

Herbert J. Grubb has been elected executive vice president of Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company. Prior to joining Colonial Penn in 1968, he was assistant vice-president-group division, Continental Casaulty Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 13 Lawrence T. Ellis, dean of boys and coach of track and cross-country at Jamaica High School in Queens was named today as Princeton University's as head coach of track and cross-country.

JACKSON, Miss., July 13 In the hot, stuffy meeting hall of this city's striking refuse collectors, two young Mississippi lawyers one black and one white have taken 15 legal cases from low-salaried black workmen to help them avoid evictions and foreclosures on household item loans.
The Black Academy of Arts and Letters announced yesterday that three prominent black Americans will be enrolled in its newly established Hall of Fame.

The City Health and Hospitals Corporation reported yesterday that 64 abortions had been performed in municipal hospitals over the weekend that 679 women were awaiting abortions and that 1,324 were awaiting screening for abortion appointments.

ITHACA, N. Y., July 13-- Perry T. Egbert, retired chairman of the board and president of Alco Products, Inc., manufacturers of locomotives and other machines, died yesterday at his home here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.

The Fifth Avenue Peace Parade Committee has filed a suit in Federal Court charging that the Federal Bureau of Investigation used confidential bank records to obtain information about opponents of the war in Indochina.
The Nature Conservancy has announced that it has made a $75,000 down payment on a 22-square-mile "ecological gem"-in Arizona that will be preserved as a nature sanctuary.

WYCOMB, Pa., July 13 Robert E. Patterson, a marketing executive with Dun Bradstreet, Inc., in New York, died after a heart attack while playing tennis Saturday at the Buckingham Racquet Club. He was 54 years old and lived here for 19 years. Mr. Patterson, who had been with Dun Bradstreet since 1935, was director of research and development.

A hearing in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on an application for an injunction to bar Mailers Union No. 6 from interfering with normal production at The New York Times was put over yesterday to Thursday.

WASHINGTON, July 13 The Government announced today an investigation into the possible adverse effects on United States exports of the special trade agreements negotiated by the European Economic Community with Morocco and Tunisia.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the giant chemical producer, said today that it was reversing a decision taken only last week that would have cut off supplies of a drug to researchers who think it may prove effective in the treatment of heroin addicts.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 13 Percy Sledge, an American Negro soul singer whose popularity on tour here won him special Government permission to appear before white audiences, has come up against the curtain of apartheid in Bloemfontein, capital of the Orange Free State.
WASHINGTON, July 13 The House embarked today on what could stretch into weeks of angry debate over changing age-old Congressional procedures.

WASHINGTON, July 13--The Government announced today that it was proposing new regulations to limit the size of demonstrations in front of the White House but to allow unlimited public gatherings on the Ellipse and the grounds of the Washington Monument behind the White House.

Robert Patrick Hamilton, professor emeritus of law at the Columbia University Law School, where he taught for 36 years, died here yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Hamilton, who lived at 39 Claremont Avenue, was 73 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 13 Donald H. Elliott, chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, urged Congress today to give local governments a greater voice in the planning of Federal highway projects.

ORONO, Me., July 13 The Maine election campaign probably will do little to change Senator Mike Mansfield's view that the Democrats do not as yet have an agreed challenger or a winner for the Presidential campaign of 1972. A really smashing victory, sweeping the whole Democratic state ticket into office, could give this state's Senator Edmund S. Muskie an important lift; but such a victory may not be in the cards this year.

ROME, July 13 Chancellor Willy Brandt had an audience with Pope Paul VI today and was reported to have received encouragement for West Germany's policy of seeking improved relations with Poland and ether Eastern European states.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that he fully expected to reach by next year an annual goal of producing 600,000 federally assisted lowincome housing units.

The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that the buckling of a welded steel rail was the probable cause of a high-speed passenger train derailment at Glenn Dale, Md., on June 28, 1969.
The Office of Education and the National Endowment for the Arts will make grants totaling $900,000 for professional artists to perform and teach in elementary and high schools.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Two former Government economists urged today that the Federal Reserve Board permit a somewhat greater increase in the money supply than was the case in the first half of this year, partly in order to help restore "liquidity" in the economy.

Prices on the London stock market closed moderately higher yesterday on the strength of Wall Street's firmness on Friday and cautious optimism for avoiding a threatened strike by British dock workers.

CEDARHURST, L.I., July 14 Jimmy Wright of Inwood shot a final round of 34, 33 67 to post a five-under-par total of 205 and win the Long Island Professional Golfers' Association 54-hole medal play championship by a stroke at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.
PEKING, July 14 (Agence France-Press) Premier Chou En-lai today attended a French Embassy reception marking France's National Day, the first time he has attended such a reception since 1964.
On Aug. 25, 1968, a handful of Russians demonstrated for two or three minutes in Red Square against Soviet aggression in Czechoslovakia before being arrested.

ROME, July 14 Princess Irene Galitzine denied that there was anything remarkable about her prints at the dinner party for a few hundred close friends and fashion followers held in her apartment after her fashion showing Monday evening.
Magazine publishers just love high readership figures. (That's because advertisers do). They are not at all fond, however, of the high cost of production and subscription solicitation.

A stockholder suit has been filed against the General Dynamics Corporation; its auditor, Arthur Andersen Co., and a group of its present and former directors charging that false statements were made in the company's annual and quarterly reports for 1969.
A small group of modern furnishings designers, and a few friends, picketed the Dione Lucas Gourmet Center yesterday afternoon for engaging in "design piracy."

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, said today that President Nixon makes a mistake "every time he names a Democrat or a leftist Republican" to an Administration job.

MANHASSET, L.I. July 14 Miss Pamela Carol Reeves, a senior at Villanova University, plans to be married next spring to Lieut. (jg.) Richard A. Kennedy, U.S.N., a Villanova graduate and flight officer stationed in Oceana, Va.
MALTAVERNE [Un adolescent d'autrefois]. By Francois Mauriac. Translated by Jean Stewart, 195 pages. Farrar, Straus Giroux. $5.95.

GENEVA, July 14 Red Cross inspectors have found in two visits that conditions at the South Vietnamese prison at Con Son were "not too bad" and that a vast majority of the inmates were held as common criminals, reliable sources disclosed today.
Dick Tiger of Nigeria and Emile Griffith of the Virgin Islands, two of professional boxing's most durable men, will battle in a scheduled 10round bout tonight in Madison Square Garden.
CINCINNATI, July 14 President Nixon threw out two "first balls" before the All-Star Game tonight, then tossed three balls the other way to fans seated in the stand.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 14 (AP) Mike Miceli brought Interaction between horses in a daring move near the finish and held off a threat by Persister to win the Rockland County Association Purse at Monmouth Park today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today he was giving the states until Aug. 3 to pledge full compliance with the new Voting Rights Act that lowered the voting age to 18 years.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The District of Columbia school board has voted to devote the curriculum of the city's grade schools and junior high schools next year to teaching children to read.

NEW ORLEANS, July 14 The Department of the Interior was told today that its suspension of oil leases in the Gulf of Mexico offshore area was causing an economic depression in Southern Louisiana and will cause a shortage of natural gas this winter to heat Northern homes.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 14 (AP) Manuel Santana and Manuel Orantes scored singles victories today and gave Spain a 2-0 lead over Yugoslavia in the European Zone A final of the Davis Cup tennis competition.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) A spokesman for the nation's Governors called on Congress today to create a "national community development policy" to embrace almost all domestic affairs, from population growth to a national housing policy.
It was another listless day on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, so much so that, had there not been a big block trade, the volume would have been the smallest in four years.
NEWARK, July 14 A major shake-up in the top levels of the Newark Police Department was announced today by its new director, John L. Redden.
Miss Judith R. Fischman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Fischman of New York and Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Harmer F. Johnson, who is...

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 One hundred eighty candidates will vie for 30 of the 60 seats in South Vietnam's Senate, in elections Aug. 30. The central election committee announced the names of the candidates and the tickets on which they are running today, after the filing deadline of midnight last night.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Three junior naval officers have met a setback in efforts to block their early discharge that the Navy acknowledged stemmed in part from their antiwar activities.
ATHENS, July 14 The United Arab Republic's embassy here accused an Israeli singer today of having "penetrated" a cocktail party given by Ambassador Hassan Ahmed Kamel.
A small, but loud, chorus of booing that greeted Angel Cordero Jr., before each early appearance at Aqueduct yesterday turned into a mass of disapproval after the feature race.
LONDON, July 14 Britain's trade position took an unexpected turn for the worse last month.

The Caterpillar Tractor Company's earnings fell 24.7 per cent in the second quarter and 18.3 per cent in the first half of this year, according to the company's semi-annual report issued yesterday from its Peoria, Ill., headquarters.

"I am the boss" has a sometimes false ring for Irving Levites, part owner of the Nustyle Knitting Company in the Bronx. The word "boss" conjures up visions of big cigars, ease and contentment, but these emoluments do not apply to Mr. Levites.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill calling for a massive program to bring family planning services to all American women who cannot afford them.
POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 14 Ed Wukowitz will not win tomorrow's Hennessy Grand Prix ocean race.

CINCINNATI, July 14 If there was an undercurrent of grateful affection in the voice of Bowie Kuhn when the commissioner introduced Rico Carty of the Atlanta Braves at an All-Star luncheon yesterday it was understandable. Rico is the guy who rescued Bowie's computerized fan vote from becoming a gigantic boo-boo.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The United States took a skeptical view today toward reports from India that the Soviet Union was trying to promote an international conference on Indochina.
Jule M. Sugarman was sworn in yesterday as the city's Human Resources Administrator, succeeding Mitchell I. Ginsberg.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 More than 500 prisoners have been flown on American military planes from the Con Son Prison to Saigon and are awaiting release, a South Vietnamese Government spokesman said here today.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Warren Armstrong, the American Basketball Association's rookie of the year the season before last, was traded by the Washington Capitals to Kentucky today for cash and the right to the Colonels' firstround draft pick next season.

LA JOLLA, Calif. July 14 (AP) Preston Foster, who played heroes and villains for more than two decades in movies and then became a television star died here today after a long illness. He was 69 years old.
The Giants and the Jets didn't plan it this way, but their football seasons will open today with extremely personalized inspection for 50 young players.

With promises to persist in the course that he has taken independent of the Lindsay administration, City Council President Sanford D. Garelik is eliminating the positions held by three of his top assistants.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 A case of flagrant vote-rigging has discouraged officials and reinforced the cynicism of villagers in a small province along South Vietnam's coastline.

Lieut. Gen. Leslie R. Groves, director of the World War II Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb and ushered in the nuclear age, died Monday night at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. The retired general, who was 73 years old, had suffered a heart attack at his home earlier in the evening.
GENEVA, July 14 The United States urged the United Nations today to convene its narcotic drugs commission in special session to map plans to combat the "disastrous spread of drug addiction."

There is a racing adage that "you can't beat the inches." The 430-cubic-inch engine of a Group 7 sportsracing car churns out more horsepower than a 299-inch engine in a Group 5 sports car, right? So when you have a Can-Am race that mixes Groups 5 and 7, it makes an...

A 23-year-old policeman was arrested early yesterday after he allegedly broke into the apartment of a young woman on the Lower East Side. After he was charged with burglary and assault, he was suspended from the force.
MOSCOW, July 14 The newly elected Supreme Soviet, the national legislature, today opened a session that will endorse a new government and adopt a labor code designed to tighten worker discipline.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Top-seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania, playing without practice after a 13-hour plane ride from Athens, defeated Steve Krulevitz of Baltimore, 6-2, 7-5, in the first round of the $35,000 Washington Star international clay-court tennis tournament today.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 14 Mrs. Cutting Cushing of Meadow Brook and Laura Leonard of Piping Rock posted a two-over-par 35, 39 74 today to lead the women's Long Island Golf Association's 36-hole better-ball-of-partners tournament over the 5,643-yard Maidstone Club layout.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The only American manufacturer of an industrial chemical called PCB has decided to restrict sales of the chemical because of mounting evidence that it can induce birth defects in animals.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 14 "Bravo," half-shouted Jean Mary, who will drive Tidalium Pelo of France in Saturday night's $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The newest and most anxious student of South Vietnam's, economic problems here is Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, whose interest is aroused by fears of a precipitate decline in the morale and effectiveness of Saigon's army.

Six inspectors in the city's Department of Air Resources were charged in State Supreme Court yesterday with falsely denying that they had told a fellow inspector about opportunities for bribery in their jobs.
A policeman was injured and four youths arrested last night after 400 Negro and white youths clashed in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 15 While the wealthy players and wealthier owners of the National Football League jockeyed for position in their labor dispute, the real working class of football went into action at Nassau Community College today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 Critics of Congressional secrecy lost a crucial round today as the House voted to oppose a move designed to open most committee meetings to the public.

CINCINNATI, July 14 It's only an exhibition game, every hardened baseball man knows that, and it's an honor to participate and no disgrace to lose but the American Leaguers acted just as disappointed after their 12-inning loss to the National League tonight as if they had lost a game that hurt them in the league standing and in the pocketbook.
The Parks Departanent has started using chains and shackles to keep thieves from digging up newly planted trees and shrubs and carting them away.

NEW HAVEN, July 14 The jury hearing the case of a Black Panther charged in the kidnapping and murder of a fellow party member saw a series of color slides today that showed the victim with his wrists bound with a clothesline and with a wire hanger around his neck.
OAK BLUFFS, Mass., July 14 (AP) Thomas Hart Benton suffered a heart attack July 5 but is recovering at Matha's Vineyard Hospital, his wife, Rita, said tonight, Tuesday night.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 14 Miss Janet Sue Gage and Thomas Peter Scheweitzer will be married here Aug. 15 in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, July 14 When Emory Coblentz Swank first heard that he would be named by President Nixon as United States Ambassador to Cambodia he reacted in the low key that has always marked his career as a Foreign Service officer.
terday as trading activity on the New York Stock Exchange continued to move at the slowest pace in a month.
LONDON, July 14 For years, the National Gallery's portrait of Pope Julius II, dulled by the dirt of centuries, had been considered no more than a good copy.

Norton Simon, Inc., the billion-dollar conglomerate, and Simon Schuster, Inc., the 46year-old publishing house, announced jointly yesterday that negotiations for the acquisition of the book publisher by the conglomerate "have been terminated."

MAGNOLIA, Mass., July 14 Miss Karyl-Lynn Kopelman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Kopelman, plans to be married Aug. 16 to Dr. Neil J. Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Stone of Highland Park, Ill.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 4 There is a new billboard at Seventh Avenue and 22d Street here that subtly advertises a service that until recently was only whispered about in tradition-bound Colombia family planning.
Shuji Terayama has been praised as Japan's leading avant-garde playwright, and his work, "La Marie Vison" ("Mink Marie"), which he wrote and directed, has been praised as a masterpiece.

Show magazine, a majority of whose stock is owned by Huntington Hartford, the A. P. heir, filed a $2-million damage suit against the New York Telephone Company yesterday for assertedly listing magazine phone numbers incorrectly in the telephone book.

Today is the day that four agencies in three cities officially pull off a merger. And yesterday, even before it was official, switchboard operators at Bishopric/Green/Fielden, Miami; Lieberman Associates, Allentown, Pa.; and Bishopric/ Lieberman and Lester Harrison Advertising, New York, were already getting in practice by answering calls with, "Bishopric, Lieberman, Harrison Fielden."
MOSCOW, July 14 Three groups of Soviet Jews have issued demands to the Supreme Soviet that they be permitted to emigrate to Israel, according to documents circulating here.
CINCINNATI, July 14 Pete Rose walked into the National League clubhouse, smiling and limping. One after the other, the other players grabbed his hand.

SCRANTON, Pa., July 14 Miss Nancy Jane Friedmann and Thomas David Pincus, both of whom received A.B. degrees with honors last month from the University of Wisconsin, will be married here Aug. 12 at the home of the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Elihu Friedmann, who have made known the engagement of the couple.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 (UPI) A jury of seven men and five women was sworn in today at the Sharon Tate murder trial after each promised to give the defendants an "impartial and fair hearing."
TOULOUSE, France, July 13 "Bravo!" and "Allez!" The cheers are ringing along the turnpikes again as the great annual bicycle race, the Tour de France, snakes its way through the countryside.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 14 Sailors 13 to 17 years of age nursed 279 boats round triangular courses in a wavering southerly breeze today at the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week. The second of three regattas set aside for juniors was thus gratefully completed as the wind held up a lot better than it did yesterday when conditions were abysmal.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) The Justice Department has disclosed that its main witness in a conspiracy case involving $43-million in stocks and securities stolen, from the United States mails was found shot to death two days after a grand jury returned a sealed indictment in a secret session.

WASHINGTON, July 14 A spokesman for the member firms of the New York Stock Exchange said today that they should have tried to raise their sales commissions on stock transactions back in the early nineteen-sixties.
New York Mailers Union No. 6 announced yesterday that its 500 members at The Daily News would go on strike at 12:01 A.M. Friday because their contract negotiations had reached an impasse.
Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the largest securities concern, disclosed yesterday that its profit in the first half of 1970 had declined 23 per cent to $13.9-million.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday in Pittsburgh that it would add substantially to the basic steelmaking capacity of its Fairless Works, one of the company's major integrated mills.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 14 Erwin Wedemann, president of Wedemann Godknecht, Inc., freight forwarders and custom house brokers, in New York, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 314 Hamilton Road. He was 63 years old.
Six persons, three of them 15-year-olds, were arrested on charges of arson early yesterday morning following five suspicious fires in the South Bronx area during the night.

Film or videotape records of Broadway and Off Broadway shows, to be used primarily for research, educational and historical purposes, are being planned by the film library of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

NORTH CONWAY, N.H., July 14 Ch. Legend of Gael, C.D., a Gordon setter owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York, gained his second best in show on the scenic circuit, when he was chosen today, in a field of 936, at the Carroll County fixture on the skimobile grounds. Two days ago, at Stowe, Vt., he took the top prize at the Green Mountain Dog Club show.

Oscar Heyman, founder and head of Oscar Heyman Brothers, Inc., a New York jewelry manufacturing concern, died Monday at Beth Israel Hospital after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 1165 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Elliot L. Richardson, urged the Senate not to raise the latest Social Security benefit increase above the 5 per cent voted by the House in May.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 14 The heavyweights of the America's Cup defense trials resumed their slugfest today, and again it was Intrepid that floored Valiant.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, July 14 (Reuters) Thor Heyerdahl, leader of the transAtlantic expedition on the papyrus reed boat Ra II said today that on some days he and his crew had been reluctant to wash because of pollution in the ocean.

DALTON, Ga., July 14 Former United States Representative Harian Erwin Mitchell of Georgia and Mrs. Mitchell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marilyn Helen Mitchell, to Lieut. Chester Logan Davidson Jr. of the Army, son of Dr. and Mrs. Davidson of Chapel Hill. N.C., formerly of New York.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The Soviet Union was understood to have informed the United States officially today of the interest of Warsaw Pact powers in exploring with the North Atlantic alliance the reduction of outside forces in Central Europe.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 4 (UPI) Prime Minister James Chichester-Clark thanked British troops, Northern Ireland's security forces and the people of the province today for having maintained the peace during yesterday's Orange Day celebrations by Protestants.

At the annual stockholders' meeting yesterday of Roosevelt Raceway, Inc., in Westbury, L.I., minority stockholders met the Raceway's new management now controlled by Irving Mitchell Felt's Madison Square Garden Corporation and Philip J. Levin's Tansnation Development Corporation and some expressed doubt ...

In a retaliatory move following the National Football League club owners' decision to bar experienced players from training camps, the N.F.L. Players Association will request members of the College AllStar squad to desert their Evanston, Ill., headquarters today.
TEL AVIV, July 14 A military spokesman announced here today that Israeli troops routed an Egypitan commando force that landed on the eastern bank of the Suez Canal last night.
PARIS, July 14 France celebrated a noisy Bastille Day today as leftists rioted and rightists cheered a parade that brought Foreign Legionnaires and nuclear-missile trucks into the heart of Paris.

COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, July 14 Dr. Daniel A. Mulvihill, assistant director of the American College of Surgeons, died here Saturday after attending a meeting of the college. He was 67 years old and lived in Chicago.

TRENTON, July 14 A minor excavating contractor, testifying today at the extortion conspiracy trial of former Newark Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and four other defendants, said he did a $1,600 job at the request of a major contractor on a Newark city project, received a check from the city for $20,000 in 1968, and kicked back the difference $18,400 to the major contractor.

A Federal judge has substantially rejected a claim by the United States Steel Corporation for a tax refund of $35-million. The 125-page ruling here yesterday by District Judge Richard H. Levet would allow the nation's largest steel company to recover only about $950,000 of the original claim.
The World Bank, which has not borrowed money in the American capital market for almost two years, plans to sell a $200-million bond issue here July 23.

WHITE PLAINS, July 14 The engagement of Miss Eilecn Theresa Bingham to Paul Gregory Tuttle of Lynchburg, Va., son of Mrs. Mavis Beryl Tuttle of Denver and Ronald A. Tuttle of Oakland. Calif., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Bingham.

When Europeans first arrived on this continent and spread into its interior, they found a people whose ancestors had come from Asia 25,000 years earlier and had long since mastered the North American environment as hunters, agriculturalists, or fishermen. The various Indian tribes boasted complex cultures and religious systems, technologies adequate to their needs, and proud traditions.
NEW DELHI, July 14 Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, left this morning after having conferred with Indian officials about the prospects of a new Indochina conference.
A drop in sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30 was announced yesterday by the RCA Corporation.

Dr. Harry C. Laidler, an author, economist and a founder of the League for Industrial Democracy, died yesterday at Adelhpi Hospital atfer a short illness. He was 86 years old and lived at 292 Garfield Place, Brooklyn.
"It's like the whole city is coming together, like a kibbutz we almost like it better running the building by ourselves," said Miss Roberta Fishman.

Rudolf Orthwine, businessman, inventor and printer, who was publisher of Dance Magazine, died Monday at University Hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived at the New York Athletic Club, Seventh Avenue at 59th Street.
A group of 22 American Jewish organizations accused Japan Air Lines, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company yesterday of participation in an economic boycott of Israel.
Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio intervened yesterday in the nine-day-old apartment strike, calling about 30 landlords to City Hall to warn them not to expect further changes in the rent control law.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel ordered Federal experts today to find the sources of newly discovered mercury pollution in the nation's waterways. He called the pollution "an intolerable threat to the health and safety of Americans."

PENN YAN, N.Y., July 14 Petitions went into circulation across the state today to get an extra line on the ballot for two of Arthur Goldberg's running mates on the Democratic ticket who now are on that line only.

LONDON Stalin saw no difference between the policies of either major party that won an American or British election because, for Moscow, the basic attitude was always the same. Likewise, when Washington and...

Rolf Liebermann believes there may be life in the old opera house yet, and that films and television can be used to interest new young audiences. "In Germany we have found that television promotion of opera is quite a success 3 to 5 million may see an opera that perhaps 2,000 could see in the opera house."

A letter sent to Mayor Lindsay and other public officials on the stationery of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Community Education Center in Brooklyn has warned that "we'll burn down Ocean Hill-Brownsville" unless Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright is removed from the area" by Aug. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 13 Israel, a country that has won acclaim for its relatively smal but effective technical coopera tion programs in Asia and Afri ca, is expanding similar activi ties in Latin America.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company, which was acquired in a tender offer last month by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, increased its 14-man board to 16 members yesterday with the election of Harold S. Geneen and Eugene R. Black.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 14 Jerry Courville's Eagle 3 on the narrow, 480-yard 17th hole at Bonnie Briar during the second of today's two 18-hole rounds enabled the Connecticut amateur to gain a one-stroke margin for his sixth Ike golf tournament victory. It was also his second triumph in a row in the event.
An explosive device went off at 2:33 A.M. today, damaging the front door of the Chase Manhattan Bank branch at 599 Broadway at East Houston Street.

PINE RIDGE, S.D., July 10 On top of Sheep Mountain, a lonely butte in the Badlands, an angry group of Oglala Sioux is protesting what they call the latest piece of treachery and bad faith by the Government.

William Alfred (Al) Douglas, a realtor, owner, of the Red Rooster cafe in Harlem and a former fight promoter, died Saturday after a brief illness while vacationing at St. Croix, Virgin Islands. He was 74 years old and lived in Englewood Cliffs, N.J.
The old Marxist charge that capitalist economies depend on war to provide prosperity and full employment dies hard. Not only orthodox Communists but radicals of the New Left...

A group of 150 persons led by members of the Young Lords occupied the old Lincoln Hospital School of Nursing in the Bronx for 12 hours yesterday and presented a set of demands that the hospital's administrator called valid.

Bache Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, incurred a $10-million capital decline in the four months ended May 31, but it has apparently turned the corner to profitability after more than a year of financial distress.

The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, Pittsburgh, the largest bank in Pennsylvania, reported yesterday consolidated net income for the first half, before securities transactions, of $24,601,000, or $2.46 a share, up 3.2 per cent from the year-earlier $23,837,000, or $2.38 a share.
After two years of supervising New York City's efforts to collect its garbage, clean its streets and plow its winter snows, Griswold L. Moeller submitted his resignation yesterday.
In the shadow of the worst bear market in modern history, observers are questioning some basic Wall Street tenets.
WASHINGTON, July 14-- Total business inventories declined by $275-million in May, the second largest drop in nine years.
LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) Nearly half of Britain's 47,000 longshoremen staged an unofficial strike today, defying their union's appeal to carry on work while a wage offer was being considered.

City Planning Commission officials said yesterday that they were reconsidering the status of a key aide who was scheduled to resign his $24,500-ayear post to take a job with a consulting concern that has received $8.4-million in contracts from the commission.

When passers-by businessmen, shoppers, women pushing strollers stopped one day recently to peer at the activity in the store window on Third Avenue near 61st Street, Mrs. Kenneth Ziegel paid no attention.
CINCINNATI, July 14 The National League won its eighth straight All-Star Game tonight by scoring three runs in the ninth inning and one in the 12th to defeat the American League, 5-4.

Joan Manley, who served as director of sales for Time-Life Books, has been appointed publisher of the sales division of Time Inc., it was announced yesterday by Rhett Austell, executive vice president.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 14 Gov. Raymond P. Shafer is expected to sign a bill sent to him by the Legislature yesterday to raise the interest rate on conventional home mortgages to 9 per cent the next two years.

RICHMOND, Wednesday, July 15 In a primary election marked by massive voter indifference, George C. Rawlings Jr., one of Virginia's most liberal Democrats, apparently squeaked to victory yesterday in his bid to be his party's candidate for the United States Senate this fall.

The Republican leader of the Town of Brookhaven, Richard D. Zeidler, was "guilty of misconduct" as chairman of the Suffolk County Water Authority, the Appellate Division, Second Department, ruled yesterday.

DETROIT, July 14 The Chrysler Corporation's financing arm, the Chrysler Financial Corporation, has used $500 million to $600-million of its bank credit lines, Lynn Townsend, the automaker's chairman, said today. He said the company had $800-million in such bank lines.

WASHINGTON. July 14 Apparently yielding to White House pressure, Richard Blumenthal said today that his decision to decline appointment as director of Volunteers in Service to America VISTA had not been based on disagreement with Administration policies dealing with the poor.
WASHINGTON, July 14 The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a manysided trade bill that would substantially alter the nation's 35-year-old policy of gradual reduction of trade barriers.

One of the biggest swings against the Dallas Aces in the qualifying play for the world championship in Stockholm last month occurred on the diagramed deal against Brazil. The Aces, of course, survived the setback and went on to win the world title.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The Office of Economic Opportunity said today that it would go ahead with a major test of a new educational system despite disclosures that the first pilot project had been "contaminated" by irregularities.

The Federal District Court in Philadelphia has decided to defer for another week its dessignation of the trustee, or trustees, of the Penn Central Transportation Company. Two stockholders of the Financially troubled Villager industries, Inc., filed a class action in United States District Court charging the company and former officers and directors with fraud in the sale of common stock between Jan. 1 1968, and Dec. 31, 1969.
Changes, some permanent others undertaken as trials, are taking place among the city's television and radio news organizations.
LONDON, July 14 In his time, Alec Guinness has played many a saintly part, but none more bizarre than his role in Bridget Boland's new play "Time Out of Mind" at the Yvonne Arnaud Theater here.
DETROIT, July 14 The United Automobile Workers and the car makers will open their new contract talks tomorrow in an atmosphere of crisis.
Prices on the London stock market lost earlier firmness yesterday as most slipped moderately following news of an increased June deficit in British trade.
Buddy Jacobson, who had been unsuccessful in getting stall space at Aqueduct after sitting out a 45-day suspension, learned yesterday he would not be able to race any horses at Saratoga either.
Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union is making plans to pay benefits to its members if the apartment strike, now in its ninth day, continues through Monday.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 14 A battle raged tonight about 55 miles from Pnompenh on the highway linking the capital with the port of Kompong Som, the former Sihanoukville.

A month ago a hill on the southern end of Mount Morris Park in Harlem was strewn with bottles and trash, and weeds grew in abundance. Now its sloping face is terraced, shored with weathered boards and dotted with marigolds, petunias and geraniums and a weeping willow tree.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 14 (Reuters) The Italian entry, "Ondata di Calore" ("Heat Wave"), starring Jean Seberg and directed by Nelo Risi, won the best-film award tonight at the San Sebastian International Cinema Festival.
ROME, July 14 (Reuters) Representatives of three of Italy's four traditional government partners met today with Premier-designate Giulio Andreotti for talks on a new coalition government.

WASHINGTON, July 14 A House panel that investigated the alleged killing of Vietnamese civilians at Songmy recommended today that the jurisdiction of the Federal courts be expanded to deal with military offenders who have become civilians.

Early this month Leonid I. Brezhnev told the Soviet Communist party Central Committee that "the year 1970 will be memorable for our party and the entire Soviet people because this year there will take place the 24th Congress of the Communist party of the Soviet Union."

The complete correspondence between Dr. Sigmund Freud and Dr. Carl G. Jung his most famous pupil and, eventualy, his fiercest opponent will be published as the result of an agreement between their sons to lift a 60-year embargo on the letters.
Silver futures prices rose here yesterday in line with the prices received at the Government's weekly auction sale of fine silver in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 14 The Senate Armed Services Committee has adopted restrictive language intended to keep the Administration from using Defense Department funds for indirect support of the Cambodian Government.
EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 14 Dr. David Abraham Rosenberg, a pediatrician, died today at Montefiore Hospital Medical Center, the Bronx, after a stroke. He was 52 years old and lived at 37 Claudet Way.

MASSENA, N.Y., July 14 The Canadian lake freighter Eastcliffe Hall, bound from Quebec to Michigan with a cargo of pig iron, sank after going on a shoal in the St. Lawrence Seaway early today. Nine of the 21 persons aboard lost their lives.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 14--A burly City College senior invited the World Youth Assembly today, in the name of black American youth, to make a bus tour of Harlem to prove that the United States has colonies.

BRIELLE, N.J., July 15 "My great-grandfather is the greeter and boat dispatcher," said 13-year-old Johnny Bogan 4th today. "My grandfather is the buyer and office manager. My father is the captain of one of our fishing boats. Me? I'm a salesman in the tackle shop."

The effort to politicize American higher education, along with the demonstrations of student unrest, have dominated public thinking about the nation's universities and colleges. But for those responsible for the operation of these institutions, the much less publicized financial squeeze on the campus is now an even more intense preoccupation.

There is growing danger that the protectionist drive in Congress will ensnarl the United States in a trade war with the European Common Market and create grave problems for future relations between the world's two most important trading areas. Even more broadly, if protectionism takes command in this country, it could initiate a world-wide disruption of trade capable of threatening prosperity in many countries.
Defiantly dropping his guard, or taunting Dick Tiger with mincing steps and the "Ali Shuffle," Emile Griffith streaked to a unanimous 10-round decision at Madison Square Garden last night.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., July 15 Three days after winning the British Open title, Jack Nicklaus was back on the American pro tour today. Happy but tired, he teamed in the pro-amateur preliminary to tomorrow's $150,000 Philadelphia Classic at the Whitemarsh Valley Country Club with three amateur partners he had not met previously.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, July 15 (AP) A Vatican Cardinal proposed today that Lutheran leaders join with the Roman Catholic Church in new efforts toward achieving Christian unity.

The boy-office treasurer at the Eden Theater, where "Oh! Calcutta!" is playing, has been accused by New York State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, of exacting "ice" or payments over the listed price for tickets to the Off Broadway hit.
A 30-year-old city patrolman was arrested yesterday on a charge of growing marijuana in a vegetable garden in the backyard of his Suffolk County home.

The board of trustees of the City Club of New York has adopted a resolution that the club take whatever legal action is possible to support the right of civilian authorities to investigate corruption in the Police Department.
DEARBORN, Mich., July 15 The Rouge automobile complex rises here like a gray mirage. The colors of...

The start of the vacation season does little to inhibit the tournament enthusiast. Many New York experts will be competing tonight at the New York Hilton, where the first round of a knockout team championship signals the beginning of the Fun City regionals. Some of the players were competing last weekend in the Suffolk championships at Patchogue, L.I.
Ship buffs here will be able to board five warships, flying the flags of the United States, Portugal, Britain, Canada and West Germany, this weekend.

ROCHESTER, July 15 Joseph Chamberlain Wilson, board chairman of the Xerox Corporation and Mrs. Wilson have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Deirdre Wilson, to Joseph Walter Garton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Garton of Sheboygan. Wis.

A commercial complex in Brooklyn's downtown area including three towers and a covered pedestrian mall above Fulton Street was started toward almost certain approval by the City Planning Commission yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 15 A young reporter from a black weekly asked James H. McGee today to react to a charge by militants that he "does not take a stand" on issues involving the black community.

ATLANTA, July 15 A three-judge Federal court was told today that Sgt. Esequiel Torres, accused of murder in Songmy, South Vietnam, could not receive a fair trial in any American military court becuase President Nixon had already declared him guilty.

GENEVA, July 15 The Fund of Funds, operated by Investors Overseas Services, said today in its annual report that its total net assets had slid to $402,430,000 on July 1 from $623,004,300 at the close of 1969 and from $797,202,500 at the end of 1968.

CHATTANOOGA, July 15 (AP) The Chattanooga NewsFree Press, an evening newspaper, filed a motion in United States District Court today seeking the dismissal of a $21million antitrust countersuit filed by the publisher of the paper's morning rival, The Chattanooga Times.
CINCINNATI, July 15 Dr. Nelson Glueck will retire from the presidency of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion July 1, 1972. He will retain the title of chancellor.

WASHINGTON, July 15 The Nixon Administration announced today that it would send to Congress next week a bill to regulate the explosives industry in an attempt to keep dynamite and other high explosives out of the hands of terrorists.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 14 Mr. and Mrs. Thatcher Payne Luquer of Cambridge and Holderness, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Brenda Payne Luquer, to George Edward Iselin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Iselin of Jackson, N.H. A fall wedding is planned.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (UPI) Philip A. Ray, former Under Secretary of Commerce and a prominent lawyer here, died today after a short illness. He was 58 years old.
The Greenwich Hotel had room for Anthony Cortez one recent night, his first outside the walls of Rikers Island prison in a year, but he chose to sleep in the park.
CARLISLE, Pa., July 15 (UPI) Without Coach Vince Lombardi or the old hands, the Washington Redskins opened their football training camp today with 39 rookies.
Creamy Delicious: Eat My Words (In Other Words), by Steve Katz, illustrated by Richard Tum Suden (Random House, $5.95). A collection of short stories.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it had found no indication of sabotage to explain the jet air taxi crash that killed Walter P. Reuther, his wife and four other persons May 9.
ATHENS, July 15 Eight Greeks were honored in Athens today for having helped rescue thousands of Jews from Nazi camps, where 62,000 Greek Jews perished during World War II.

Rudy Turcotte included the Great American Stakes among his three successes at Aqueduct yesterday. The 20-year-old jockey from Grand Falls, New Brunswick, steered Edward Sawyer's Three Martinis to a decisive victory in the $29,350 feature, a 5 -furlong event for 2-year-olds.
The Continental Can Company reported record earnings yesterday and increased the dividend.

New American Review, the latest literary quarterly to be left out in the cold, may have found a foster home in Simon Schuster, Inc., the 46-yearold publishing house that just terminated merger negotiations with Norton Simon, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) A compromise version of the Administration's anticrime bill for the nation's capital cleared the House today. It includes controversial "no-knock" and preventive detention provisions.

"But Never Jam Today," Vinnette Carroll's Afro-American adaptation of Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland," will begin a citywide summer tour tomorrow at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx.
STUTTGART, Germany, July 15 (AP) The United States men's track and field team built a slim 58-48 lead over West Germany tonight.

NEW HAVEN, July 15 A young woman who wanted to qualify for membership in the Black Panther party testified today that she saw Alex Rackley led from the party's headquarters here with a wire hanger wound around his neck on the night he was murdered.
A tall, well-dressed man with long blond hair, held up the Chemical Bank at 303 West 42d Street at Eighth Avenue yesterday and escaped with more than $30,000.

The chief executive of one of West Germany's largest chemical concerns said here yesterday that Congressional refusal to eliminate tariff barriers would have little impact on companies like his because of the accelerating shift from imports to production in the United States.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July l5 Deprived of their experienced quarterbacks by the pro football labor dispute, the New York Jets signed Bill Kushner, a 23-year-old product of the Continental League, today in order to facilitate practice sessions.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Mexico's Joaquin Loyo-Mayo upset Clark Graebner of New York, 6-4, 6-3, in the second round of the $35,000 Washington Star clay-court tennis tournament today.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 15 (AP) Manuel Santana and Juan Gisbert defeated Yugoslavia's Zeljko Franulovic and Nicola Spear in doubles today to give Spain an unbeatable 3-0 lead in the European Zone A Davis Cup tennis final.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 Federal Judge John P. Fullam set today a hearing for July 23 at which nine banks that are depositories of the Penn Central Transportation Company have been ordered to show cause why they should not be held in contempt of the court's orders for refusing to release $4,512,000 of the railroad's deposits.
ALBANY, July 15 The Department of Motor Vehicles has ordered its issuing offices to introduce a series of innovations to speed service and reduce the time citizens must spend on vehicle transactions.
JACKSON, Miss., July 15 The Nixon Administration's latest actions on school desegregation in the South have aroused anger on one side and suspicion on the other.
WASHINGTON, July 15 The Federal Reserve Board's Index of Industrial Production declined again in June, though by somewhat less than in each of the preceding two months, the board announced today.

Col. Martin J. Brennan, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Brennan of Parkchester, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Judge Brennan, to Paul Elliott Van Hook of New York, son of Mrs. Elliott Boyd Van Hook of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mr. Van Hook.
Rob Roy Buckingham, editor and general manager of The New York Times News Service, announced three staff promotions yesterday.

The reason most people who stop smoking gain weight is not necessarily that they eat more, a new scientific study has found, but that their bodies, in adjusting to the new smokeless routine, undergo changes that make gaining weight difficult to avoid.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Justice Department awarded grants totaling $11million today to help finance college courses for law enforcement personnel.
Zoe Caldwell will withdraw from the title role in "Colette" after the Aug. 2 performance to fulfill a prior commitment on the London stage.
DETROIT, July 15 (AP) The Detroit Tigers sold Earl Wilson to the San Diego Padres today for the $20,000 waiver price.

Dr. Carl F. Prutton, an educator, inventor and industrial leader in the field of chemistry, died yesterday at the Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Key Biscayne, Fla.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Just before Robert B. Anderson became Treasury Secretary in 1957. The Washington Post said tonight, he completed a deal with oilmen designed to pay him nearly $1-million.

DENVER, July 15 For the first time since the beginning of the nuclear age 25 years ago tomorrow, the powerful and once-unquestioned interests that have grown up around this nation's atomic technology are being forced onto the defensive by a rising public clamor for reform.

BONN, July 15 Swiftly responding to Government action against inflation, West Germany's central bank eased its brakes on the economy today, lowering the bank discount rate from 7 per cent to 7 per cent, effective tomorrow. This is the basic rate at which commercial banks can borrow from the central bank.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 The Nassau-Suffolk Committee of Boys' Towns of Italy will hold its 13th annual International Summer Ball on July 26 at the Cloud Casino at Roosevelt Raceway here.
Soybean futures prices fell sharply in early trading on the Chicago Board of Trade but rallied in the last hour and set new highs for the season.
New York City rejected the two bids it received yesterday for $170.18-million of bonds because of a clerical mistake, and it rescheduled the sale July 28.

The city returned yesterday to a familiar task searching for a new Sanitation Commissioner. After trying politicians, managers and engineers in the post, top officials of the Lindsay administration are uncertain now who can handle it.

GILFORD, N.H., July 15 Ch. De-Go Hubert, a West Highland white terrier owned by Jane Esther Henderson of Stockton, N.J., was named best in show today in an entry of 958 dogs at the Lakes Region Kennel Club fixture.

HOWELL TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 15 Three gunmen robbed a branch office of the Monmouth County National Bank on a busy seashore highway today and made off with $229,000 in cash scooped from tellers' tills.

Like all proper babies, Christabelle Nita Arndt wore a long white dress at her christening and cried when the water was poured on her head. But that was all that was usual about her christening on Tuesday evening.

CORINTH, Miss., July 15 An official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development today called this northeastern Mississippi town of 14,000 "the national pace-setter" in the providing of new low income housing.

ARMONK, N.Y., July 15 Residents of the sparsely populated town of North Castle, with its tree-covered hills and winding country roads, are bitterly debating a proposal that could bring six corporate headquarters and more than 4,000 cars in peak hours to a residential neighborhood on its border with Greenwich, Conn.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) House Democrats contended today that they had achieved a productive legislative record in the 91st Congress despite "delaying tactics and lack of full cooperation" on the part of President Nixon.

LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) Sir Colin Crowe, a career diplomat who is now High Commissioner in Ottawa, is expected to be appointed Britain's new chief delegate to the United Nations, informed sources said today.

DETROIT, July 15 Meyer L. Prentis, who retired in 1951 as treasurer of General Motors Corporation, after helping guide the concern through its formative years, died today on his 84th birthday, after a long illness.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) About 1.1 million Americans were taken off the poverty rolls at least by official Government definition last year, the Census Bureau reported today.

SANTA ANA, Calif. Robert Lawrence Balzer, a fine cook who was ordained as a Buddhist monk and has been a pilot, painter, writer, foreign correspondent, restaurateur, and the operator of a famous specialty food market, is fondest of describing himself as a professional wine expert.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., July 15 Joseph Stewart, chairman of Project SEED, a program of the American Chemical Society to train disadvantaged persons for professions in chemistry, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 2107 Gallagher Avenue. He was 52 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 15 The pattern of President Nixon's recent successful ventures out of his self-described "isolation booth" is instructive. Knoxville, St. Louis, Louisville, Cincinnati the mere names evoke the idea of that "heartland" of which Mr. Nixon so often speaks. And the big crowds that have greeted him seem in large part drawn from the "Middle America" to which he most directly appeals.
WESTFIELD, N.J., July 15 The Echo Lake Country Club, a 6,692-yard, par-72 layout, has narrow fairways and a twoinch growth of rough.
Members of the Young Lords and administrators of Lincoln Hospital yesterday discussed some of the demands made by the group during its occupation of part of the Bronx hospital on Tuesday.
A new bus service that would have provided easy access to public medical facilities in Nassau County has been blocked by the Public Service Commission.
OLD LYME, Conn., July 15 Miss Carol Andrews Johnston and Amos Galpin will marry here Aug. 11.
MIAMI, July 15 (AP) The Havana radio said today that Cuba's sugar harvest is nearing an end a million and a half tons short of its goal of 10 million tons but still a record.
Gen. Sheng Shih-tsai, a warlord who controlled the vast, strategic province of Sinkiang in western China during the 1930's and 1940's, died on Tuesday in Taiwan. He was 75 years old.
The eight interlocked weapons production plants of the Atomic Energy Commission, scattered from Colorado to Florida, are currently undergoing a $314-million expansion.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 15 (AP) Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman suggested today that the United States was on the verge of a national mental breakdown that had affected its reliability as an ally.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 15 The engagement of Miss Susan Vartanian, an investment officer at Standard Poor's counseling corporation, Intercapital, Inc., in New York, to J. William Barba, a member of the law firm of Shanley Fisher in Newark and Washington, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Andranik Vartanian.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 15 (Reuters) Misael Pastrana Borrero, a 46-year-old lawyer and economist, was named President-elect of Colombia today by the Supreme Electoral Court.

WASHINGTON, July 15 Members of a House panel that investigated the alleged mass killing of Vietnamese civilians at Songmy stepped up their criticism of the Army today, contending that it had hampered their investigation.

Earnings of the International Paper Company fell 3.5 per cent in the second quarter and 5.59 per cent in the first half, reflecting the depressed condition of the residential building-materials market, the company reported yesterday.
The stock market moved back into the winning column yesterday as prices advanced on a broad front in more active trading.

Hindley Taylor, a former opera and concert singer in Britain, hit a high note in the dog show world when one of his Pekingese, Ch. Beau of Kyratown, recently became the Briton's 300th winner of a challenge certificate. That made Taylor the first exhibitor of any breed in his...

Miss Rosaria Vignolo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paolo Vignolo of Genoa, Italy, was married there yesterday to Eric Mallory Munson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul English Munson of Scarborough, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in the Church of the Cappuccini.

WASHINGTON, July 15 The House Ways and Means Com- mittee completed action today on major trade legislation by voting to prevent the President from ever substituting a tariff on oil for the present system of oil import quotas.

WASHINGTON, July 15 Secretary of State William P. Rogers, in an apparent effort to move his position on Vietnam closer to that of the White House, said today that there were "reasonable pros- pects" for the peace negotia- tions in the long run but that the short-run prospects were not bright.
PARIS, July 13 The great iron sheds and the streets around them that constituted Les Halles, one of the world's most famous central markets, are mostly dark and silent these nights.
GENEVA, July 15 A new pattern for a soft approach to international trade problems may be set here at informal talks to be held by key officials of the United States and its major trading partners.

A proposed $2.5-billion gas pipeline stretching 2,500 miles from the North Slope of Alaska to the American Midwest will be studied by a consortium of six major United States and Canadian companies, the group announced yesterday.

QUINCY, Mass., July 15 At a shipyard that has produced over $200-million in losses for the General Dynamics Corporation, the keel was laid today for a mammoth, boldly designed ship that the company is counting on to reverse its fortunes.

WASHINGTON, July 15 The Senate overwhelmingly passed today a bill granting the native peoples of Alaska Indians, Eskimos and Aleuts 10 million acres and $1-billion cash compensation in settlement of a century-old claim. The vote was 76 to 8.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 15 With a Dramamine sou'wester kicking up white caps, the America's Cup committee made a logical decision today.
DETROIT, July 15 Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers, said today that a "noninflationary, equitable" settlement could be reached in the industry without a strike.

RICHMOND, Va., July 15 The possibility of a run-off election to determine the Virginia Democratic nominee for the United States Senate loomed here today after George C. Rawlings Jr., one of the state's most liberal Democrats, won a slim plurality in balloting yesterday.

Representatives of the city's four major newspapers and the New York Mailers Union No. 6 failed last night to settle a contract impasse that has led the mailers to threaten to strike The Daily News at 12.01 A.M. tomorrow.

Have you ever wondered about pop singer-composer teams? Which one really does the creative work, and, even, what are their sexual proclivities? Having talked to five major agencies as a replacement for Young Rubicam, BeechNut, Inc., announced early yesterday afternoon that it was switching its confections division to Dancer-FitzgeraldSample.

ROCHESTER, July 15 Arthur J. Goldberg charged today that what he characterized as a frightening increase in water pollution in New York State could be traced to a breakdown in the enforcement of pure-water standards.
Not everybody thinks that Jim Bouton has achieved insight or even accuracy in his controversial book, "Ball Four," a series of spy reports from roof and locker room.

ROME, July 15 Two of their girls have made it and the Italian fashion world is blissful. Mila Sch n's collection has boosted local pride and stimulated descriptive powers. Everybody is shouting brava and meravigliosa (marvelous) and lauding her technical brilliance and architectural style.

As the audience arrived for last night's performance of the Broadway play "Borstal Boy" at the Lyceum Theater, Peter Hock, one of the actors, stood backstage and told why the cast is nervous when the curtain goes down these nights.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger spent more than $l.8 million in his successful campaign for the Democratic nomination for United States Sen ator, with $1.7-million of the total coming in loans from his mother, according to reports filed yesterday in Albany.
PARIS, July 15 The Foreign Ministers of Britain and France agreed here today that the United Nations should make a fresh peacemaking drive in the Middle East, highly placed diplomats reported.
A 3-year-old Bronx child was fatally shot in his crib early this morning in an apartment at 375 East 159th Street in the... Morrisania section of the Bronx.
Two multiple-alarm fires in the Brownsville and Williamsburg section of Brooklyn were put under control just before last midnight.
The Congress of African People will meet Sept. 3 to 7 in Atlanta, where, according to its sponsors, institutions will be developed to bring about the liberation of black people.
The innovative City National Bank of Columbus, Ohio, is firmly convinced that women of all ages particularly those of banking age love Paul Newman, the actor.
MOSCOW, July 15 Diplomatic sources said today that Communist China had agreed to send a new ambassador to Moscow.

TEL AVIV, Thursday, July 16 (Reuters) A military spokesman said here early today that Israeli commandos had struck into Lebanon during the night and had blown up three buildings in the village of Kafr Kala in retaliation for recent guerrilla attacks from Lebanese territory. The village is west of Metulla, the northernmost Israeli town.
