Aircraft Door Implants and Gorilla Goals, George Malko pauses to observe, "Of course all this struck me as being insane garbage." Of course. Up to this point, Mr.

SIEMREAP, Cambodia, July 15 This besieged town near the Angkor temples has become an armed camp, with mortar and rocket fire likely to strike by day and by night. Civilian life has become an incongruity among the gun positions, entrenchments and soldiers, and amid the recurrent sound of small-arms fire.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Siegfried H. Reiger, vice president-technical of the Communications Satellite Corporation, died at his home here yesterday. He was 50 years old.

WILMINGTON, Del. E.I. du Pons de Nemours Co., Inc., expects to report that second-quarter earnings were about the same as in the first quarter, when they reached $1.93 a share, and that secondquarter sales were slightly below the $937-million of the first period.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 15 Nothing succeeds like excess, and of all the world's avant-garde classic ballet companies the Netherlands Dance Theater is the most gloriously and conspicuously excessive. It is clearly ready to try anything more than once, and its performances are free, vigorous and exciting.

MONTEREY, Calif., July 15 (AP) Dr. Eric Berre, the psychiatrist who wrote the bestselling book "Games People Play," died in a hospital here today after having suffered a heart attack two weeks ago. He was 60 years old.

CINCINNATI, July 15 A violent collision at home plate on the final and deciding play; the enthusiastic attendance of the President of the United States; a 12-inning victory for the National League made possible by a three-run rally in the home half of the ninth; a four-hour national television show that used up all the prime time in the eastern part of the country and a good share in the western half; a...
WASHINGTON, July 15 There can be no peace on the nation's campuses until there is peace in Vietnam, witness after witness told the President's Commission on Campus Unrest today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 The Federal Communications Commission suggested today that the fertile new field of specialized communications services such things as data networks and private-line phone hookups for businesses will develop best through open competition.

WASHINGTON, July 15--The Nixon Administration strongly urged Congress today to drop the Senate's Cooper-Church amendment restricting military action in Cambodia, on the ground that, if enacted, it would infringe on the President's "lawful responsibilities" as Commander in Chief.

The Monsanto Company's earnings fell 25 per cent in the second quarter, Edward J. Bock, president, reported yesterday. He attributed the decline to the economic slowdown, which has depressed manmade-fiber markets in the last year amid rising costs.

The French Defense, 1 P-K4, P-K3, is based on action against White's king pawn to force overt and committing counteraction. Thus 2 P-Q4, P-Q4 allows three obvious continuations: 3 N-QB3 or 3 N-Q2, defending the king pawn by a piece, or 3 PxP, exchanging the king pawn, or 3 P-K5 advancing into Black's territory.

Lawrence Cowen, former chairman and president of the Lional Corporation, manufacturer of model trains and electro-mechanical devices, died yesterday of a coronary thrombosis in his home at 2 Sutton Place South. He was 63 years old.
BUENOS AIRES, July 15 (UPI) The Argentine police said today that the first violinist of the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra, Naum Fruman, had asked for political asylum.

WASHINGTON, July 15 Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator from New York, announced plans today to sue the Federal government to compel the Justice Department to enforce an 1899 antipollution law.

RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 15 A new program in communications at Fairleigh Dickinson University, with radio, television and newspaper workshops and a course on the philosophy and practice of journalism, was announced here today by J. Osborn Fuller, president of the university.

MEXICO CITY, July 15-The Mexican Congress was called into special session today to consider a proposed national security law that would sharply increase penalties for terrorism and political kidnapping.
CINCINNATI, July 14 Joseph A. Meyer, former head football coach at Xavier University and at the University of Cincinnati, died here at his home Monday night at the age of 75.

OAK LAWN, Ill., July 15 (AP) James T. Mangan, an industrial designer and promotion consultant, who once laid claim to all the universe except the earth because nobody else had claimed it, died last night in a convalescent home. He was 73 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 President Nguyen Van Thieu vowed today to "beat to death" these of his countrymen who called for "immediate peace, in surrender to the Communists."

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) The Senate completed Congressional action today on a bill that would exempt financially unstable newspapers from antitrust laws and permit them to pool their noneditorial operations with other newspapers to prevent collapse.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 15 Seven children were killed and 52 other persons injured today when a chartered bus carrying youngsters and counselors from a day camp in Lawrence, L.I., skidded off a rain-slick highway near here.

LONDON, July 15 Prince Charles and his younger sister, Princess Anne, make their first visit to the United States tomorrow in a style that reflects their increased freedom to do and say what they like.

A hastily arranged meeting between Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary and taxicab fleet owners has once again forestalled a daily midnight- to - 6 A.M. shutdown threatened by owners of 6,900 fleet taxis.

POINT PLEASANT, N.J., July 15 A pair of New Yorkers outclassed the rest of the fleet today in the Hennessy Grand Prix ocean race but failed to outlast a race committee that penalized both drivers and two others for failing to pass a checkpoint properly.

The Board of Education has taken legal measures and tightened security at its headquarters to prevent new disruptions by supporters of the now-defunct governing board of the former Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district in Brooklyn.

It is likely that a Ford Foundation-funded "Newsroom" is in Channel 13's near future. The nightly news program, once established, could become the focus of an interconnected public television news network.

ATHENS, July 15 A spokesman for Stavros Niarchos said tonight that the Greek Government had lifted the travel restriction imposed on the Greek shipping millionaire after the death on May 4 of his 42-yearold wife.
WASHINGTON, July 15?The International Monetary Fund announced today a combined drawing and debt repayment that will provide $463-million to Italy.

Because of its long military history, the Atomic Energy Commission has traditionally cited national security and operated in secret, holding the public at arm's length and supplying only those facts it chose to release.

MOSCOW, July 15 The Supreme Soviet today reappointed Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and President Nikolai V. Podgorny, keeping intact the collective leadership structure... established after Nikita S. Khrushchev was deposed in October, 1964.
CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, July 12 The divorce mills of Chihuahua State grind fast, and that is good for the economy of this Mexican border city.
PARIS Danielle Darrieux, the piquant, titian-blonde star of the French cinema, arrived in New York recently to begin rehearsals for the title role of "Coco."

OTTAWA, July 14 (Canadian Press) Transport Minister Don Jamieson announced today that improper prelanding procedure in the cockpit of the Air Canada DC-8 that crashed in Toronto on July 5 caused the initial runway impact that led to the death of 109 persons moments later.

CHICAGO, July 15 The Board of Governors of the American Bar Association approved in principle tonight President Nixon's organized crime control legislation but suggested that several sections be amended.
LONDON, July 15 Dr. Francis A. Freeth, a British industrial scientist, died today at Church Crookham, Hampshire. He was 86 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15 The five South Vietnamese delegates to the World Youth Assembly, who have been prevented from speaking by leftist-led hecklers, withdrew from the conference today and charged that they were victims of "fascist maneuvers."

DETROIT, July 15 (UPI) A suspended auto worker ran shooting through an axle plant of the Chrysler Corporation today and killed three workers in his search for the foremen he felt were responsible for his dismissal.

City officials, physicians and leaders of what used to be the abortion-repeal movement warned the Board of Health yesterday that its proposed amendment to the City Health Code would cancel the very benefits the state's new abortion law was designed to bring.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 15 Seventy-five fans and one New York Giant stared wistfully over a fence today as the football training season began.
Rod Laver says he is human after all.
The appointment of Dr. Stephen J. Wright, former president of the United Negro College Fund, as vice president of the College Entrance Examination Board was announced yesterday.

The commercial paper market, where corporations sell their unsecured i.o.u.'s to investors, dropped more than $2-billion in the final three weeks of June, figures published... yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.
The Japanese, widely regarded as imitators since their closed culture was opened to Western ideas by Commodore Perry in 1854, are now challenging the world with their innovative products.
LONDON, July 15 Britain's ports were shut tonight by the first national dock strike since 1926.

BOSTON, July 15 Andrew Wyeth, America's favorite painter as well as its most expensive, has never looked more appealing or more nearly worth the money than he does in the retrospective opening to members tomorrow and to the public on Friday at the Museum of Fine Arts.

In the first combined operation by the Federal joint strike force on organized crime since its creation here a year ago, eight men were arrested yesterday on charges of bookmaking, loan-sharking and criminal contempt.

WASHINGTON, July 15 There are six member firms of the New York Stock Exchange that are currently in liquidation, in addition to the four whose failure had previously... been announced, it was officially disclosed today. The

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia July 11 The slow but significant improvement in relations between Yugoslavia and Communist China, nations that scorned each other for a dozen years, is being delayed by China's unexplained failure to name an Ambassador to Belgrade.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 The $125,000 International Trot, which is supposed to enhance international relations, may hurt them. That's how it appeared to some observers this morning when they heard JeanRene Gougeon, the French reinsman who will drive Une de Mai in next Saturday night's classic at Roosevelt Raceway, criticize Dayan, the main American hope in the 1 -mile race.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 15 (AP) The Department of Water Resources plans to ask the Attorney General of Maryland, Francis B. Burch, to initiate criminal proceedings against the companies responsible for Sunday's 67,200-gallon oil spill in the Baltimore harbor.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 15 (Reuters) A Communist guerrilla force of unknown size was reported today to have struck at Bat Rokar, 28 miles south of Pnompenh, yesterday in an apparent move toward the southern provincial capital of Takeo.
After its decline on Tuesday, the American Stock Exchange Index moved ahead yesterday. It closed at 19.99, up 6 points from what the Exchange called an adjusted figure of 19.93 for Tuesday.

ALBANY, July 15 (AP) The defending champion, Lancy Smith of Buffalo, and the tourney medalist, Gail Sykes of Schenectady, won their matches today in the New York State women's amateur golf championship at the Colonie Country Club.

HONG KONG, Thursday, July Still shaky from the effects of 12 years' imprisonment in Communist China, the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh told newsmen here today of his ordeal, including a grueling year and a half of interrogation and trial that ended in his sentencing to a 20-year-jail term in Shanghai.

TRENTON, July 15 Lawyers defending Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other men on trial here for extortion and conspiracy, said today that they would recall Paul Rigo, the prosecution's key witness tomorrow to authenticate accounting records and other documents.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 15 Leon M. Jordan, one of Missouri's leading Negro politicians, was killed early today by three shotgun blasts fired from a car.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) The College All-Stars will return to organized practice tomorrow after a one-day strike in sympathy with players locked out of National Football League training camps.
Dean Witter Co. and Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis, two of the nation's largest brokerage houses, are discussing a possible merger.

Three one-hour programs, condensing the day's testimony from the public hearings of the President's Commission on Student Unrest, will be broadcast by National Educational Television tonight, tomorrow and Friday at 10 P.M. on the public television network. In New York, the programs will be carried on WNDT, Channel 13, at 10:30 P.M.

GLEN RIDGE, Pa., July 15 Joseph H. Spring, a director of the Foley Dog Show Organization, Inc., of Philadelphia, died yesterday in Misericordia Hospital, Philadelphia, of emphysema. He was 62 years old. The Foley organization superintends dog shows nationally.
Prices on the London stock market declined over a wide range yesterday.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 Ralph Whipple, a 15-year-old from Manhasset, L.I., whose father is a stinkpot advocate, emerged as the big winner today as the Larchmont Yacht Club's three-day regatta for junior sailors ended.

Mayor Lindsay's administration called on landlords yesterday to reject their leadership in the 10-day-old apartment strike. The statement came after a meeting between the... landlord group and union leaders failed to make any progress toward agreement.

"The Revolutionary" is a young philosophy student, identified only as "A," who lives in a major city in a country "somewhere in the free world," but which looks very much like contemporary England (where the movie was made) and whose students, housewives, policemen, soldiers, rebels and politicians all have purposeful American accents.

MADRID, July 15 Spain's Supreme Court has voted to indict two dismissed Cabinet ministers in a financial scandal and has asked Parliament to lift the immunity of the head of the Bank of Spain so that he, too, may be prosecuted, reliable sources disclosed today.
Two policemen were arrested here yesterday in the alleged theft of $100,000 that was said to have been turned over to them in a brown paper bag by a man who said he found the money hidden in his car.

Marion Harper Jr. has resigned as president of sixmonth-old Harper Rosenfeld Sirowitz "because of the pressures of his other business activities." That was the announcement made yesterday by Ron Rosenfeld and Len Sirowitz, the new president.

Abbie Hoffman, the Yippie leader, pleaded guilty in Criminal Court yesterday to resisting arrest during a Black Panther rally here in the spring of 1969. He was sentenced by Judge Arthur Braun to the maximum term a year in jail or a $1,000 fine.

After hard negotiating in London, Ghana has obtained agreement of fifteen creditor governments for reservicing part of the billion-dollar debt that was one of many legacies of Kwame Nkrumah's profligate dictatorship. Ghana's negotiators had to settle for much less than they had asked for, but they will urge Prime Minister Busia to accept the package.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 The Security Council will meet in urgent session at 3:30 P.M. tomorrow at the request of 41 nations concerned that Britain's new Conservative Government will resume the sale of aircraft and arms to South Africa.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., July 16 Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Siska have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Mary Siska, to Bernard Francis Walters, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Walters of Manhasset, L.I.

An impressive performance by C.V. Whitney's Bid High was one of the more noteworthy occurrences at Aqueduct yesterday. Competing in a 5 -furlong sprint for 2-yearold fillies, Bid High registered a 3 -length triumph over Meadowhill's Green Princess.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 The New York Mets rang up the curtain on Act Two tonight the second half of their title defense and were immediately defeated by the Los Angeles Dodgers, 3-1.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 16 Black community leaders have begun to organize a boycott of merchants in the downtown shopping area of this seaside resort town that was shaken by racial disturbances last week.
Adolf Knul, Joseph P. McCarthy Jr., and Leighton H. McIlvaine Jr. have been promoted to vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

The American Stock Exchange index continued its upward march yesterday, closing at 20.07, a gain of 0.08. One of the upward factors was a large number of blocks of stocks crossing the tape at strong prices, an indicator of some renewed interest by institutional buyers.
ALBANY, July 16 (AP) A State Supreme Court justice granted continuation today of a temporary court order blocking a music festival at Mountain Dale, in the Catskill Mountains.
A suspended detective testified yesterday at his Police Department trial that he never requested or received a reward for the recovery of stolen property from Montgomery Ward.
PHILADELPHIA, July 16 Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo told a Congressional committee today that the city was in desperate need of outside funds to combat the juvenile gang problem.

BUDAPEST, July 11 At 8:30 P.M. last Monday all over downtown Budapest the sound of laughter was competing with the clatter of the yellow streetcars and the rumble of the big, fume-trailing city buses.

BOSTON, July 16 Dr. Avery Allen Ashdown, who retired in 1957 as a professor of organic chemistry at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but served later as a lecturer, died yesterday at the age of 78.
STUTTGART, West Germany, July 16 (UPI) West Germany, led by its women's team, upset the United tSates tonight in a two-day track and field meet, 182-175.
The statistics became people last night on N.B.C.'s documentary white paper, "Migrant:"
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (AP) Delegates to the national convention of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks voted today to retain the lodge's whites-only membership requirement.

WASHINGTON, July 16 The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that, so far as he knew, the New York Stock Exchange had adequate resources to prevent financial loss to the customers of any exchange members that were going to have to be liquidated in the near future.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 16 Fernando Dahmen Jr., a director of the Chilean Nitrate Sales Corporation and a member of the Chilean delegation to the United Nations, died yesterday of a pulmonary embolism at St. Fancis Hospital in Roslyn. He was 57 years old and lived at 24 Revere Road.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 16 Gov. Marvin Mandel of Maryland and Mrs. Mandel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Marsha Mandel, to Jack Victor Kahn, who owns and operates a gift shop in the Georgetown section of Washington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Kahn of New York, where Mr. Kahn is vice president of the M A Wares Company, a toy manufacturer.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 16 The South Korean Government approved today a $50million investment and loan project of the Gulf Oil Corporation for South Korea's oil refinery and petrochemical industries.
TEHERAN, Iran (AP) There is a new feeling of hope and pride in Iran, and it is evident in this sprawling capital with its new office buildings, supermarkets, freeways and modern factories.
After the first five meetings this season between last season's American League division winners, the Minnesota Twins held a 3-2 edge over the Baltimore Orioles.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 16 Barclay Harding Warburton 3d, great-grandson of John Wanamaker of Philadelphia and a well-known resident here, married this afternoon Mrs. Lore Maria Faught, who has been conducting Yoga classes here.

Mayor Lindsay's administration was stopped in State Supreme Court yesterday from taking over services, cutting rents or otherwise acting against landlords of struck buildings, pending a trial on city powers in that court starting Monday.
NEW ORLEANS, July 16 (AP) A spokesman for the national Sierra Club asked the Interior Department today to call a halt to all offshore drilling.
LONDON, July 16 (AP) Prince William of Gloucester, the 28-year-old first cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, has resigned from the diplomatic service, the Foreign Office announced today.

DETROIT, July 16 The Chrysler Corporation reported today earnings of $8.1-million, or 17 cents a share, in the second quarter. This was about a fifth of the $41.4-million, or 88 cents a share, earned the year before on matching secondquarter sales of $1.9-billion in both years.

Contract negotiations between The Daily News and the Mailers Union continued past a strike deadline this morning as Theodore W. Kheel, chief mediator in the dispute, sought to head off a strike that would shut down both The News and The New York Times today.
The Public Service Commission ordered the New York Telephone Company yesterday to cut its rates on coin telephone calls in the New York Metropolitan area by $2.68million a year.

Stanley W. Hesse, a general partner in H. Hentz Co., and its floor partner on the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 1085 Park Avenue. He was 59 years old.
PARIS, July 16 The precious landscape of the Riviera has been scarred this week by vast forest fires fanned by the mistral, the dry wind of southern France.

Four narcotics cases in which six policemen refused to take bribes totaling close to $10,000 were cited yesterday by District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx as evidence that the "overwhelming majority of New York policemen are honest."
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The House decided today not to expand the United States Travel Service.

Announcement has been made by Irving Zeldman of Boston and Mrs. Lois Zeldman of Beachwood, Ohio, of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Arlyn Joy Zeldman, to Joel William Greenbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Morton Greenbaum of Yonkers.
After advancing sharply, soybean futures prices dropped on profit taking and closed lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a rather active session.

The State University's board of trustees decided yesterday that a special investigation of the university's College at New Paltz was unnecessary because a regular evaluation of the school will be made this fall by the Middle States Association the regional accrediting agency.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 16 A year ago today, as 700,000 people watched Apollo 11 thunder off toward man's first landing on the moon, an enterprising aerospace engineer rushed through the motel parking lots along the beach here slapping copies of his job resume on every windshield in sight.

Some 50 participants in the United Nations World Youth Assembly took an unofficial tour of Harlem yesterday that was designed by its organizer, an American black militant, to show them "how this country exploits and oppresses its own people."
NEWPORT, R.I., July 16 They finally discovered a way today to keep Intrepid from winning in the America's Cup defense trials. They called off the races.

The Southern California Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the June quarter and the first half. Jack K. Norton, chairman and chief executive officer, placed second-quarter revenues at $172,935,000 against $150,055,000 a year earlier. Net income increased to $29,276,000, or 61 cents a share, from $24,052,000, or 51 cents, in the 1969 period.
Last Saturday's traffic ban on a 15-block midtown stretch of Fifth Avenue was "a success from virtually every point of view," Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.

LONDON The basic problem of defense planning under Britain's new Conservative Government is how to adjust a smallpower role to great-power commitments in a world where U.S. overseas strength is steadily shrinking.
DETROIT, July 16 The Ford Motor Company labeled as inflationary today a demand of the United Automobile Workers that the union calls a key to halting inflationary wage increases.

SAN SALVADOR, July 16 (UPI) A two-mile, wide noman's land was established today along the Honduras-El Salvador border. The two nations fought a brief but bloody war in July, 1969, over territorial and economic issues.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 16 Ralph E. Ward, president and chief executive of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc., and Mrs. Ward have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Elizabeth Ward to William Lawrence Hogan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Hogan of Warren, Pa. An October wedding is planned.

Dr. John Herbert Pearson, for many years a director of research for the General Chemical Company, now the Industrial Products Division of the Allied Chemical Company, died Wednesday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 63 Central Avenue, Glen Rock, N.J.

The coincidence of two centennial celebrations this year those of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has brought to New York an extraordinary loan exhibition of 100 masterpieces of painting from Boston's permanent collection. The exhibition, which includes pictures by Rogier van der Weyden, Rembrandt, Titian, El Greco, Zurburan, Turner, Monet, Degas and Gauguin, is currently on view in the Metropolitan's special exhibition galleries.

ORANGE, N.J., July 16 Msgr. John A. Weisbrod, pastor of Our Lady of Counsel Roman Catholic Church in Newark, died in a hopsital here yesterday as a result of a fall in the rectory. He was 74 years old.
Led by a group of traditional blue-chip favorites, the stock market continued to rally in active trading yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, July 16 (AP) A former Yonkers City Councilman pleaded not guilty today to conflict-of-interest charges in an indictment growing out of last year's investigation of municipal corruption by the State Investigation Commission.
SEOUL, South Korea, July 16 The South Korean National Assembly unanimously voted a resolution today voicing objection to United States plans for troop cutbacks in Korea.
TRENTON, July 16 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill's son-inlaw, hired by the state two months ago, is in line for a promotion.
Following is an excerpt from a speech by Mayor Lindsay at the Lotos Club Public Affairs luncheon on the city's use of consultants:
BONN, July 16 The Soviet Union and West Germany have agreed to start formal negotiations on a nonaggression treaty in Moscow on July 27, it was announced here.
J. Ross MacLennan, thought by many to be the heir apparent at Ted Bates Co., the world's fourth-largest ad agency, has quit.
TEL AVIV, July 16 A United Nations observer was killed and another wounded this afternoon by Egyptian fire across the Suez Canal.
Former Chief Justice Earl Warren, who led the United States Supreme Court during 16 years of bold reforms, is completing a book on the meaning and responsibilities of American citizenship.

The sun was fitful and the wind a damp sigh, but there was diversion for the determined beach-sitters of Coney Island yesterday a New York City deputy commissioner in a nice blue suit sprinting along the damp sands trailing a gaggle of chil- dren and 102 feet of silvery foil.

BALTIMORE, July 16 Mrs. Robert Haysham Sayre 4th of Whitehall has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Elizabeth Underwood, to John Dillon Hay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Hay of Old Brookville, L.I. An October wedding is planned.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 16 (UPI) Seventy-two Americans were killed in Indochina last week, raising United States battle deaths for 1970 beyond 3,000, the United States com- mand reported today.

LONDON, July 16 A state of emergency was proclaimed in Britain today as a strike by 47,000 dock workers virtually paralyzed the movement of food, raw materials and other goods through the nation's ports.
WASHINGTON, July 16 An appeals court reversed today a lower court judgment that ordered the induction of a 21year-old Los Angeles man with dual United States and Argentine citizenship.

WASHINGTON. July 16 (UPI)-The Nixon Administration announced today a program to develop by 1975 at least two low-pollution alternatives to the regular gasoline auto engine, which is estimated to cause at least half of the nation's air pollution.

WASHINGTON, July 16 Besides dealing with Russians, Arabs, Israelis and Vietnamese, Secretary of State William P. Rogers is now engaged in periodic negotiations with the White House and, on occasion, even with himself.
THE CHALLENGE OF WORLD POVERTY. A World Anti-Poverty Program in Outline. By Gunnar Myrdal. 518 Pages. Pantheon. $8.95.

CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) A 900-pound bronze casting of Rodin's statue "The Thinker," damaged by a bomb outside the Cleveland Musem of Art March 24, will not be repaired, museum officials said yesterday.

The stalemate in the pro football labor negotiations will go into its fourth day today with no further meetings scheduled. The committees of the National Football League Players Association and the owners remained here, however, each awaiting a compromising move on money issues by the other.
The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter totaled $32,411,000, or $l.17 a share, including extraordinary gains of $20,805,000, or 75 cents a share.

The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, reported yesterday moderate declines in earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30. A sharp reduction in taxes this year helped to keep the drop in earnings at a moderate level, according to the midyear statement.

Two men, one with a criminal record dating back to the early nineteen-twenties, have been indicted on charges of criminal contempt. The indictments were handed up by a Manhattan grand jury that has been investigating police corruption.

AT AN ISRAELI AIR FORCE BASE, July 16 Israel graduated a new class of air force pilots today. Pinning on their wings, Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned that they, rather than the diplomats, would determine the nation's future security.
The London stock market closed quietly mixed yesterday as most traders took to the sidelines to await a clearer indication of the effects of the strike by British dock workers.
D. Vincent Redding, advertising acceptability manager of The New York Times, died yesterday at his home, 1507 Old Country Road, Elmsford, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., July 16 (AP) United States Representative Gerald R. Ford said tonight that the Nixon Administration was committed to the kind of orderly progress through reform that would lead the nation out of what he called the "violent sixties" into a decade of "human betterment."

Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia continued yesterday a restraining order he issued last Friday preventing the Provident National Bank from trying to collect rental payments from tenants of Madison Square Garden.
NOTTINGHAM, England, July 16 (Reuters) The clash of steel is ringing through Sherwood Forest as this medieval city stages Britain's first full-scale jousting tournament in 400 years.

LONDON, July 16 If everyone had his own, no doubt Dostoyevsky would belong to the stage, but the National Theater has hardly strengthened this claim with Simon Gray's adaptation of "The Idiot." It is the saddest piece of butchery I have seen at this address.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 A denunciation of the United States for its role in Vietnam and what was termed its "rapacious" policy in Latin America was rammed through a World Youth Assembly panel today by a vote of 181 to 73.

Angry tenants in six large apartment buildings on an Upper East Side block threatened yesterday to set fire to their garbage in the street because the city's sanitationmen have refused to collect refuse while the buildings are being struck by service employes.

Such difference of opinion as may exist between Secretary of State Rogers and Presidential assistant Henry A. Kissinger over the effect of the Cambodian "incursion" on the prospects for peace in Vietnam is less important than need for agreement on a White House policy to get the Paris peace talks moving again.
Local 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union announced yesterday that its 39,000 members would go on strike at 12:01 A.M. Tuesday unless the city takes immediate action to protect taxi drivers.

BONN, July 16 Dr. Erhard Eppler, Economic Cooperation Minister, said today that, in 1969, West Germany spent a larger share of its gross national income on aid to developing countries than any other nation.
The counsel to the city's Youth Service Agency was suspended yesterday after charges that, against orders, he gave some of the agency's insurance business to a friend.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 16 (UPI) Dean Martin, an active fund-raiser for the Democrats, has joined the reelection campaign of Gov. Ronald Reagan.
WASHINGTON, July 16 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume of the yearearlier week.

ROME, July 16 In the Rome of the politicians it is an outright disgrace these days to have a tan. It indicates that one really does not count for much and has plenty of time to loll on the seaside rather than being engaged from morning until late at night in the ritual of crisis consultations.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 16 (Reuters) The ninth Commonwealth Games opened today with a bomb scare, a noisy demonstration and Scottish highland pageantry to welcome 1,900 competitors from 41 countries.

Stan Bahnsen, seemingly refreshed after a three-day break for the All-Star game, hurled seven strong innings yesterday at Yankee Stadium to gain a 4-1 triumph and a split for the Yankees in a double-header with the Oakland Athletics.
The New York Stock ExExchange and the American Stock Exchange have issued their latest reports on changes in share ownership by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed corporations.

A modification of the world's largest radio telescope that would, in effect, bring Venus as close to the earth as the moon seems likly in view of provisional approval of the project by a House committee.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 16 (Reuters) Mark Cox of Britain, seeded No. 8 lost to Ray Moore of South Africa, 6-3, 7-5, today in the second round of the Swiss international clay court tennis championships. Moore was not seeded.

The Neuwirth Fund, Inc., which has been closed to new investors for the last 15 months, has announced that it has begun selling its shares to all investors on a no-load basis until Oct. 30 and then will begin making sales charges of up to 8 per cent.

Until three years ago there was only one tournament in the metropolitan area the Eastern regionals at which enthusiasts could earn the red points needed for life master rank. The Long Island regionals in the fall improved the situation, and now there is a third tournament the Fun City regionals now being played at the New York Hilton.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Vice President Agnew's favorite charities received $25,- 000 in donations today as royalties from watches and T shirts bearing caricatures of him.

LONDON, July 16 Anthony Barber, making his first public address as British negotiator for membership in the European Economic Community, said today that Britain was not playing hard to get but she could not accept membership that imposed "intolerable burdens."

CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) July 16 Douglas Clyde (Peahead) Walker, former Wake Forest football coach and recently a scout for the New York Giants of the National Football League, died today at a Charlotte hospital. His age was 71.

WASHINGTON, July 16 Representative Rogers C. B. Morton, the Republican National Chairman, accused the Democrats today of "trying to destroy" the country and President Nixon by demanding equal television time to answer Mr. Nixon's reports to the nation.
The city lost a court decision yesterday, and the result could cost it at least $200-million a year in wage increases for policemen, firemen and oth- er municipal employes.

ROME, July 16 Valentino's fall collection is not apt to cause riots in the streets, and the closest it comes to the mysterious East is the Russian steppes, but it's very pretty anyway. Being king of the Roman couture is an awesome responsibility, and this one doesn't pull his rank.

Dr. Virgil Foster, former editor of The International Journal of Religious Education, a publication of the World Council of Churches, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 501 West 123d Street. He was 68 years old.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 16 The Holland Festival is the most dependably surprising of all European festivals. Each year it manages to produce works that not only are off the beaten track but also worth the diversion. This year it was the staging of a new ballet by the Netherlands Dance Theater, "Mutations."
Even if the pro football labor dispute is settled soon, Joe Namath has been granted permission by the New York Jets to report to training camp a week from Sunday.
WESTFIELD, N.J., July 16 Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair stole the play from his younger colleagues today in the second round of the New Jersey State Golf Association's 50th open championship.

Federal Reserve member banks appear to be responding strongly to reminders by the central bank that it stands ready to lend them money through the discount window should they come under pressure from their customers, banking statistics published yesterday showed.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The House Appropriations Committee approved nearly $207-million today for hospital and health research this fiscal year, the same prograims President Nixon tried to veto last month.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) Campus violence will continue as long as "snobbish, arrogant" students regard the American people as an enemy in their efforts to solve social problems, Harvard graduate-author Steven Kelman said today.
NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 16 (UPI) A village justice here dismissed charges today against a man who grew marijuana plants in the backyard of his home and then used the plant's seeds to make soup.
Doyle Dane Bernbach, which has had its share of firsts in this business, might well have another if no other ad agency has a nun on the payroll. Ex-nuns do not qualify.

WHITE PLAINS, July 15 For nearly a decade, the Westchester Art Society has held classes and exhibitions for its 700 members in a converted sweatshop on the third floor above a General Electric repair store here.
TRENTON, July 16 The defense rested today in the trial of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other men charged with extortion and conspiracy.

R.J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., in its first statement since its formation as a holding company for the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company and other diversified operations, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

Short-term interest rates declined for the fourth consecutive day this week helped along by the Federal Re- serve in spite of a heavy volume of Treasury financing this month, including $2.25billion yesterday. The emphasis on higher-quality corporate bonds intensified, and a lower medium grade issue yielding 11 per cent did not sell out completely after it was offered to investors.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 16 (UPI) Residents of rustic Middlefield, and promoters of the Powder Ridge Rock Festival resumed legal skirmishes in Superior Court as preparations were under way for a threeday rock festival expected to attract 50,000 youths from July 30 through Aug. 1.

Two suspects in the slaying of the manager of an East Side A. P. were arraigned in State Supreme Court yesterday on murder charges. Both men Louis Overton and Donald Tanner were held without bail by Justice Harold Baer.
The Suburban Companies announced yesterday in Pomona, Calif., that its board had approved a merger agreement with the Williams Brothers Company of Tulsa, Okla.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 16 (Reuters) The Government said today that it would declare a state of siege if there was any trouble during the opening of Congress on Monday or during the inauguration Aug. 7 of President-elect Misael Pastrana Borrero.
Dempsey-Tegeler Co., until recently one of Wall Street's major brokerage houses, disclosed yesterday that it planned to suspend operations and reorganize, perhaps as a much smaller entity.

ALLENTOWN. Pa., July 16 Investigators found almost treadleas tires today on the left rear wheels of the chartered busi chat skidded off a highway yesterday, carrying seven children to their death and injuring 52 other persons.
LISBON, July 16 (AP) Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, the 81-year-old former Premier of Portugal, suffered a relapse and is critically ill, his doctor said today.
Doris Freedman, who helped set up the Department of Cultural Affairs of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration, resigned yesterday "for personal reasons" effective next Friday.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 16 (AP) Herbert Marcuse, the Marxist philosopher, will remain at the University of California at San Diego even though his contract expired July 1, his department chairman said today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16 The Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week, devoted the last three days to sailing among the young, started what amounted to a stretch run to the finish for the older helmsmen today and not even the losers had much to grumble about. The wind conditions weren't perfect, but they were close.

The stormy stock market could not have come at a worse time from a tax viewpoint. Here we are still trying to limit losses in one of the worst bear markets in history while favorable taxes on capital gains are being whittled.

BALTIMORE There are few cities in America albeit a precious few worth visiting simply because of their restaurants. They would include San Francisco, New Orleans, Cincinnati, New York and Chicago. And Baltimore, where good food, particularly good sea food, is of great importance. Following are six of the best restaurants here, rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
TEL AVIV, July 16 Moshe Haim Shapiro, the Israeli Minister of Interior, died tonight. He was 68 years old.
Employes in the computer and business divisions of the Control Data Corporation will be required to take 10 days off without pay between Aug. 1 and Dec. 31, 1970, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, July 16 Three Rivers Stadium, major league baseball's newest magnificent ballpark, had a gala opening tonight even though the Pittsburgh Pirates, attired in natty new uniforms, lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2.
Mayor Lindsay pledged yesterday to pursue the city's policy of expanded use of outside consultants, who, he said, "point the way to the future."

The Germans have always taken their opera seriously, and when they present opera on films it is with equal seriousness. On Wednesday night in Philharmonic Hall a series of filmed operas, most of them the product of Rolf Liebermann, got under way with the world film premiere of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger." The series, which takes in 12 operas, will continue until July 27.

ROME, July 16 A city magistrate closed the beaches around Genoa this morning because of pollution but he was overruled this afternoon. A higher official said the pollution danger was so great that local authorities lacked jurisdiction.

MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and the Soviet leaders concluded crucial talks on the Middle East today. A communique is expected tomorrow after the Egyptian leader leaves.

Rod Laver, who says he plays better "when I'm nervous," beat Ken Rosewall in straight sets last night and won $35,000, the biggest single prize in tennis, in 85 minutes.

WASHINGTON, July 16 Congressional approval to expand the anti-crime jurisdiction of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to the major airports in the metropolitan area was sought today by most members of Congress from New York and New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, July 16 The House passed today a compromise $4.4-billion education appropriation bill that provides $453-million more than President Nixon requested.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) One of the two Representatives who drew attention to the tiger-cage cells at Con Son Prison in South Vietnam made public today a letter charging that inmates were tortured and subjected to other "inhuman practices" at a second prison in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 16 The nation's total output of goods and services stabilized in the second quarter after having declined for six months, the Commerce Department reported today.

A neighbor was arrested yesterday in the death of a 3-yearold boy who was shot as he lay in his crib. The neighbor admitted that he had accidentally fired the weapon while sitting on a fire escape across the street from the building in which the baby lived, the police said.

The National Broadcasting Company, following an angry meeting with representatives of the Coca-Cola Company, altered its documentary on migrant farm workers before the program was broadcast over the N.B.C. television last night.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 16 An explosion extensively damaged a bank here today and injured 31 persons. Nine of them were hospitalized, four with severe facial and internal injuries.
One of the hallmarks of Dr. Harvey B. Scribner's tenure as Vermont's Commissioner of Education has been his small staff. "You've got to wipe out the bureaucracy," he has been quoted as saying.

General Motors, Ford, and Chrysler have opened their new contract talks with the United Auto Workers in an atmosphere clouded with concern over inflation, the threat of increasing loss of sales to foreign cars, and criticism of the auto industry for its record on safety, performance standards, and pollution.

PALOMAR MOUNTAIN, Calif., July 16 (AP) A oneton mirror, the optical heart of the first telescope to be added at the mile-high Mount Palomar Observatory in 22 years, is being installed this week and should be operational by next Monday.

After three months of consideration, a Senate-House conference committee has reported out an anti-crime bill for the District of Columbia which has been variously characterized as violative of no less than five Constitutional amendments and as "a blueprint for a police state." Twenty former Federal prosecutors have found the bill's chief provisions of "doubtful constitutionality, questionable necessity and demonstrable ineffectiveness."

The 1,800 Jicarilla Apaches of New Mexico, who are setting a precedent as the first Indians to back a movie by totally financing a $2-million Western starring Kirk Douglas and Johnny Cash, the folk singer, are now sure of some returns on their investment. Paramount Pictures announced that it has just acquired rights to distribute the movie, "A Gunfight," both in this country and in Canada.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today increases averaging 15.2 per cent in rates for mailing fourth-class parcel post and catalogues.

ALBANY, July 18 Budgets in 82 school districts of New York State were defeated this year as compared with the record 137 budgets defeated in 1969, the State Education Department announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, JULY, 18 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service said today that it had granted income tax exemptions to six Southern private schools that had promied not to discriminate on the basis of race.

REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy, July 18 (AP) Youths hurling gasoline bombs set fire today to the central police station in this town on the southern tip of Italy, where civic rivalry has touched off six days of rioting, leaving one dead and 300 injured.
After a five-hour meeting at City Hall, landlord leaders agreed yesterday to recommend a settlement of the apartment strike to their members, aiming at a return of maintenance employes on Tuesday.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 18 One of the state's five racing commissioners suggested today that information on New Jersey races be withheld from New York City bettors in offtrack betting parlors.

The Virginia Boat Club of Richmond, returning to club rowing competition after a lapse of several years, was outclassed by the New York Athletic Club's more experienced oarsmen yesterday on the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, July 18 The president of the University of Connecticut, an educator who was once a close associate of Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Elliot L. Richardson, is under "serious consideration" to head a two-man team that would replace James E. Allen Jr. as Assistant Secretary and Commissioner of Education, a department official said today.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 (UPI) The police have asked the United States Attorney General's office and the District Attorney's office to enter an investigation into the police slaying of two unarmed Mexicas who did not speak English.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 18 The driver of the chartered bus that crashed 10 miles west of here last Wednesday, killing seven children and injuring 52 other persons, suffered a heart attack last night while undergoing treatment for injuries at Allentown General Hospital.

THAT William Blake, the visionary poet and painter of the late 18th and early 19th century, was a man at odds with his time will not be readily apparent from the splendid exhibition of his illustrations for the story of Job now on view at the Pierpont Morgan Library. The 21 watercolor drawings beautifully rendered and radiant in coloring are drawn from the Library's collection and will be on view until July 31.

WITHOUT any great array of favorable economic, political or international news to propel them, the finan cial markets nevertheless continued to advance last week as a more confident mood enveloped investors and Wall Street.

THREE classic stamps are due from Britain on September 18 for Philympia, the international stamp exhibition opening in Olympia Hall, London, that day. Each stamp will reproduce a historic 19th century British stamp, each with a portrait of Queen Victoria. The designs are by David Gentleman, creator of a number of British stamp designs. The printing will be by Harrison Sons, in photogravure at their High Wycombe plant.

FLIN FLON, Manitoba South of this mining town, highway engineers and the province's Department of Natural Resources have developed a sports-fishing attraction that has more shades of James Bond than of Flintabatty Flonatin, the story-book character for whom the town was named.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 18 Jean Mary, driving Tidalium Pelo, and Jean-Rene Gougeon, steering Une de Mai, paid so much attention to each other in the $125,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, they virtually ignored Joe O'Brien and Fresh Yankee, the Canadian champion.

TORONTO Strung out along the northwestern shore of Lake Ontario and home to more than two million inhabitants, Toronto is like a respectable dowager who has had a remarkably successful face lifting. Its aura of conservatism and tradition is blended now with slightly incredulous delight at the transformation. The dowager is swinging in an air permeated with confidence, wellbeing, pride and vitality.
Within the last few days City Controller Abraham D. Beame has quietly begun a multimillion-dollar shift of investments in the city's five pension systems.

Steve Katz, guitarist with Blood, Sweat Tears, is describing the group's recent State Department-sponsored tour to Poland, Yugoslavia and Rumania. His primary emotion still is amazement that the Eastern European countries were so different from his expectations.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 18 In what amounted to a handicap event, Valiant finally managed to beat Intrepid here today.
LANSING, Mich., July 18 (UP) The Michigan Supreme Court ruled yesterday that all public schools in Michigan must provide free textbooks and school supplies to their students.
The Chagrin Valley Professional Horsemen's Association horse show starting tomorrow will offer a whopping $25,000 in prize money for the open jumper division.

E. Raymond Sheerin, a former vice president, treasurer and director of the IngersollRand Company, machinery manufacturers, died Friday in Beekman-Downtown Hospital, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 17 As the tempo of terrorist bombings increases from Canada to Argentina, many Venezuelans are wondering what happened to their anti-Government guerrilla groups.

BUFFALO, July 18 Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Heussler have announced the engagement of Mrs. Heussler's daughter, Miss Lisa Gallatin Rogers, to Ronald Edward Bornstein, who will teach at the University of Dakar in the fall as a visiting Fulbright professor of law and economics.

SETAUKET, L.I., July 18 Miss Lila Jane Romans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McDowell Romans of New York and Old Fields, was married here this afternoon to Alan Bartlett Hooper. He is the son of Mrs. Robert Alan Hooper of Brooklyn and Sparta, N.J., and the late Mr. Hooper.

Richard Lewisohn, one of a handful of high officials who has been with the Lindsay administration since it started, was appointed Finance Administrator yesterday.

The communique concluding a nineteen-day Moscow visit by President Nasser leaves the world still awaiting Cairo's response to the recent peace initiatives of the United States, the Soviet Union and Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 18 With surprising ease, Cliff Richey turned back top-seeded Ilie Nastase, 6-3, 6-2, today and reached the final of the $35,000 Washington international tennis championship.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 18 The Powell brothers of the host club dominated two classes today in the opening race of the weekend invitation regatta of the Wet Pants Association. The fleet encountered heavy seas whipped by a 20-knot southwest wind.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 Willie Mays's 3,000th major league hit a second-inning single off Mike Wegener overshadowed Gaylord Perry's fourhit pitching today as the San Francisco Giants posted a 10-1 victory over the Montreal Expos. The 39-year-old Mays also singled in the sixth before leaving the game and receiving a standing ovation from a Ball Day crowd of 28,879.

Steve Kline, a 22 year old rookie pitcher who was working in his second major league game, raised both his pitching and batting averages from zero to .500 yesterday as the dominant force in a 7-2 triumph by the Yankees over the Oakland Athletics at Yankee Stadium.
The roar of diesel-electric machinery, the splash of a grab bucket and the creaking of dredging gear are being heard in New York harbor's "death alley."

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. It may not be long before matadors and picadors in their gold brocade will be swaggering down Collins Avenue in Miami Beach, giving a practice twirl to their capes now and then. Florida has just become the first state in the Union to legalize bullfighting the bloodless, ceremonial type.

ERIE, Pa., July 18 The engagement of Miss Kathe Mary Weschler to Nicholas Michael Epple of Cleveland, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick N. Epple, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Weschler. A wedding in November is planned.

PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 18 Miss Carolyn Jean Sprague and Lieut. (jg.) William Frederick Kracke, U.S.N., were married here this afternoon in the United Methodist Church by the Rev. William A. Studwell, assisted by the Rev. Harold E. Beliveau, an Episcopal minister.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., July 18 (AP) Two American records were surpassed today in an event added to the Amateur Athletic Union junior pentathlon competition.

HARTFORD, July 18 Anyone planning a trout expedition in Connecticut's streams this year has no need to hurry. A new regulation that becomes effective on Sept. 1 extends the season in streams from Oct. 31 to Feb. 28.

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Power have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rosemary Power, to Christopher Sparks Dorment, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Dorment of Montclair, N.J. An October wedding is planned.
MIAMI, July 18 "Do you Know, Father," a Cuban woman said recently to a Roman Catholic prelate here, "I simply must confess with a Spanishspeaking priest."

NEW ORLEANS. SITTING on the edge of her bed in a bleached smock stamped "Charity Hospital," her hair in pigtails tied with faded red ribbon, she might easily have been taken for a child only knocking at the door of puberty. But Bonnie Higgins, a frail and unmarried, 18-year-old, black high-school senior, had awakened that morning in the maternity ward, six hours after giving birth to a prema ture-infant son.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 Allied forces established a new combat base today at Khamduc, an abandoned United States Special Forces camp 13 miles from the Laotian border in northern South Vietnam.

The city's "builder incentive" program, under which developers of luxury housing can build to high R-10 densities in lower density zones, is expensive for the city, socially disastrous and doesn't help solve our housing problems. A basic point is that we don't need more luxury that is, nonsubsidized housing, especially at currently projected rentals of $125 to $150 per room.
The 1942 St. Louis Cardinals edged the 1955 Brooklyn Dodgers, 3-2, on Johnny Hopp's eighth-inning single in a computerized baseball game presented over NBC-TV network yesterday.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 18 Miss Deborah Owen Hyson and Michael Terry Hertz were married today in a garden ceremony at the home of the bride. Nassau County Judge Alexander Vitale officiated.

VIRGIL THOMSON, gazing down from the aerie of his 73 years and his dizzying critical eminence, ticked off Charles Ives the other day in The New York Review of Books, finding Ives, at last, only an inspired dabbler in composition, and even something of a bore. About all Thomson could find to like in Ives work, he said, were a few impressionistic pieces such as "The Housatonic at Stockbridge."
The widow of Soviet Yiddish poet and her daughter joined eight other signers last week in an unusual appeal to the Supreme Soviet.

A bomb shattered a glass doorway at the Broadway Savings Bank at 5 Park Place last night. The police said the blast went off at 7:50 P.M. The bank was closed and a superintendent was the only person in the building. He was not injured.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 18 Alan Burtis's Guacharo beat John Siljander's Valkyrie for Star Class honors this afternoon in the fourth of five races in the Sea Cliff Yacht Club's Commodore series.
Each year sees more allbreed and specialty shows. In 1969, there were 1,103, an increase of 46 over the previous year. The figure will be higher in 1970.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) The police maintained a close watch today on Ranko Carol Yamada, 17 years old, as she recovered from attacks by a razor-wielding assailant who raped and murdered her roommate in a downtown hotel room.

ALBANY, July 18 Miss Katherine Ellen McManus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. McManus, was married here to William Stephen Bruin Jr. this afternoon at her parents' home. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruin of Warwick Neck, R.I.
Free Fresh Air Fund vacations received by two New York City children 20 years ago are being "paid back" by their mother who now serves the organization as its representative in New Jersey.

In an unusual election ploy, New York voters are being urged to support a "coalition, ticket" made up of the Conservative candidate for United. States Senator, the Republican candidate for Governor and the Democratic candidate for Controller.
WASHINGTON, July 18 Prince Charles and President Nixon today spent an hour and 20 minutes alone in uninterrupted conversation at the White House.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 18 (AP) Juan G. Hernandez, the actor who appeared in more than 30 movies under the stage name Juano, died in a suburban clinic here yesterday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 74 years old.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 18 An analysis by the Tennessee Valley Authority of fish samples collected from 10 lakes on its reservoir system has shown no significant levels of mercury in fish except at Pickwick Lake near Florence, Ala.
VERSAILLES, France, July 18 (AP) Jean-Pierre Danguillaume of France won the 22d leg of the 57th Tour de France bicycle race today.

BROOKLYN, Conn., July 18 Miss Susan Williams Lodge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Dearnley Lodge of Brooklyn and Quonochontaug, R.I., was married here this noon to Arthur John Peck Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peck of Lawrenceville, N.J.

THERE ARE a few magic hours left in Rome when the visitor can revel in the grandeur of its ancient ruins and baroque architecture and take some snapshots without being run over by a Vespa motorscooter or choked by exhaust furnes filling the narrow, twisting streets.

KENT, Conn., July 18 The Litchfield Rowing Association of Kent and the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia dominated the national youth rowing championships on Lake Waramaug today. The winners earn the right to represent the United States in the world youth championships in Greece Aug. 4 to 8.
Two weeks ago TathamLaird Kudner, of Chicago and New York, diversified by buying a trade-magazine publishing company.

PITTSBURGH, July 18 (AP) Woody Woodward doubled home the tie-breaking run with two out in the 10th inning and scored on Bernie Carbo's pinch single, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in a rainprolonged struggle tonight.
William H. Borst's Sparton was second to finish and first over all in the 22d annual Sappho Trophy race for cruising boats yesterday on Long Island Sound.
Persons seeking to buy explosives in New York State will be subject to more stringent licensing rules starting today in an effort to prevent such sales to those who might use them illegally.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (UPI) Superior Court Judge Lawrence Mana has held that television news film not broadcast may not be subpoenaed in a murder trial. He ruled Thursday to do so would violate the 1st and 14th Amendments.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 (AP) Two masked men, one armed with a pistol, held up a miniature train at a city park today.

BALITMORE, July 18 (UPI) Harmon Killebrew and Frank Quilici hit two-run homers to produce a four-run, sixth-inning rally today that enabled the Minnesota Twins to a post 6-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in a battle of American League division leaders.
William S. Porter, who wrote under the name of O. Henry, looked on life at the turn of the century and tied up his findings in pretty ribbons.
PHILADELPHIA, July 17 The Nixon Administration's approach to the Model Cities program suffered a major setback in the courts this week.

SOPHISTICATED buffs hold with Dr. Emanuel Lasker, world chess champion, mathematician and philosopher, that chess is neither a science nor an art. From the first move to the end, it is a struggle for victory.
PARIS, July 18 An oldFrench Communist whose career dates from a Black Sea mutiny of 1919 has caused his party embarrassment by open dissidence before several million television viewers.

The temper of Congress in the summer of 1970 may have been conveyed accurately enough last week by two apparently disparate actions. One was the House Ways and Means Committee's approval of the most protectionist trade legislation in the last forty years. The other was the agreement of House and Senate conferees on a District of Columbia crime bill introducing into American law for the first time the idea of preventive detention of criminal suspects.

MEXICO CITY, July 18 At least 187 United States citizens are in prison in Mexico on narcotics charges among them at least a dozen young students or vacationers who were arrested with small amounts of marijuana in their possession.
ROME, July 18 A dozen young Americans, caught in an intensified police drive against drug offenders, are now in Italian jails. Many of them were unaware of the severity of Italy's antinarcotics laws.

PARIS, July 18 The French coastal authorities, aghast at the mounting pollution of the Mediterranean, have decided to crack down on local polluters and to press Italy to keep her own seaborne filth from drifting over to the French Riviera.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 18 In a bitter defeat for conservationists, Bald Head Island, a semitropical wilderness that lies at the mouth of the Cape Fear River, has been sold to a private corporation for development as a posh, multimilliondollar resort.
The Continental Oil Company has become the latest large concern to move its headquarters away from Manhattan.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP) Ron Hunt of the San Francisco Giants established a National League record today when he was hit by a pitch for the 119th time in his career.
The Russelsheim judo team of West Germany, one of the best squads in Europe, will arrive in New York City for a three-week tour against Metropolitan area clubs.

JEROME HELLMAN has discovered some delightful drop-outs. Producer Hellman will make his directorial debut with the film, which will be shot in New York later this year.

HOUSTON, July 18 (Reuters) Col. Edwin E. Aidrin, who was on his way to man's first landing, on the moon this time last year, believes that the event changed mankind's perspective forever.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18 (AP) Alabama Republicans, their spirits lifted by a leading Republican Senator and a Cabinet member, started a drive today to make the G.O.P. a formidable party in Alabama.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, July 18 A leading South Vietnamese general charged today that the leaders of Thailand were shirking their responsibility to help defend Cambodia because the United States would not pay them enough money.
Miss Margaret Swearingen Dearing, yacht charter manager for the Rubodor Corporation, and Spencer William George Hooker, who is with the IBM World Trade Corporation here, plan to be married in August.

WOODSTOCK, Vt., July 18 Miss Alice Ann Kany and Edward Macksoud Jr. were married here today in a ceremony that moved from Our Lady of the Snows Roman Catholic Church to a hilltop meadow at Old Bailey Farm, the Macksoud's summer home.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 18 Pat Stewart of New York captured the New Jersey State women's tennis championship today by defeating Sylvia Hooks of Newark in the final, 6-4, 6-3, at the East Orange Tennis Club. Miss Stewart, winning the title for the fifth time, was steadier and scored with deep forehand placements.

The new-order index of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers' Assocciation, a sensitive economic indicator, declined, 3.3 points, or 1.9 per cent, to 172.7 in May from 176 in April. It also was 17.1 points or 9 per cent below the index of 189.8 for May, 1969.

MINEOLA, L.I. July 18 A study by the Nassau County Probation Department shows that a group of people arrested in the county for drug-related offenses in 1968 were young-, er, more often full-time students, more intelligent, better educated and had higher incomes and better jobs than those involved in a previous study.

The new apartments that are coming onto the market in Manhattan at a rate no faster than a trickle are renting at price levels higher than ever in the city's history, but are offering something less than what was once considered luxury.

Governor Rockefeller opened his formal campaign for re-election yesterday in as informal a fashion as possible.

KINNELON, N.J., July 18 Prosperity suddenly struck Mrs. Diana Coe today after having eluded her for more than two years.

PHILADELPHIA The bright yellow and blue liquids simmering in the pots on the little stove in the noisy market of Head House Square in Philadelphia's Society Hill section should not be tasted. They are molten wax, ready to be poured into a hole in some sand in a box.

Carl Schreyer, 22 years old, and Angela Maher, 19, were arrested yesterday while harvesting marijuana from a concrete planter in the divider mall of Park Avenue South near 25th Street, the police said.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 18 Mr. and Mrs. William McIntosh Crouse Jr. have announced the engagement of Mrs. Crouse's daughter, Miss Judith Robins Leslie, to Jonathan Gardiner Wallick, a former Marine sergeant. He is the son of Mrs. Cornelius H. Van Vlaanderen of Palm Beach, Fla., and the late L. Duane Wallick.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., July 14 Pennsylvania's economy weakened considerably during the second quarter, according to business analysts at the Pennsylvania State University.
ONE of the most striking aspects of the pho tographic scene in California is that, diverse and widespread though it may be, it centers almost exclusively around the schools.
Journeymen mailers at The Daily News have won a wage increase of $72 a week over a three-year period under terms of a tentative new contract made public yesterday.

Public school superintendents in much of the country, preparing for the coming academic year, are being swamped by applications from thousands of qualified teachers unable to find positions in a tightening market.

With Del Insko, Herve Filion and Carmine Abbatiello thus far enjoying their best harness racing seasons ever, new driver records in both race and money-winnings could be established before 1970 runs its course.
VIENNA, July 18 (AP) Chi Cheng of Formosa tied the women's world record in the 100-meter dash today in clocking 11 seconds at a track and field meet near here.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP) C.V. Whitney's Chompion and J. Lieberman's Gaybrook Swan finished in a dead heat in record time in the $27,750 Getaway Day Special today as Suffolk Downs ended its 90-day race meeting.

MIDHURST, England, July 18 (AP) An American team, Boca Raton of Tulsa, Okla., plays today in the final of the Cowdray Park Gold Cup, the English polo championship.

DARIEN, Conn., July 18 Harry Francis Cooke, president and treasurer of Cooke Photoengraving Company of Stamford, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. His age was 56, and he lived at 19 Bittersweet Lane here.

LOVE VALLEY, N.C., July 18 (UPI) One youth died today from an overdose of drugs and another was wounded by a shotgun blast fired by a deputy sheriff, shattering the relative calm of the Love Valley Rock Music Festival.

In a small segment of the Bronx north of Hunts Point, upwardly mobile minority groups are finding a better way of life as first-time homeowners, willingly accepting what for many is a heavy financial strain.

WASHINGTON, July 18 Five conservation, consumer and social organizations have asked the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit to reverse the refusal of Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin to suspend the use of the herbicide 2,4,5-T on food crops.

JERUSALEM, July 18 Israel resumed her bombardment of Soviet-Egyptian missile batteries in the Central Sector of the Suez canal Zone today, scoring what the lsraeli military Spokesman termed satisfactory hits on the designated targets, but losing one aircraft.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 18 The Giants made their first cut of the summer today, a modest two-man severance that dropped the squad to 18 rookies.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 18 In the early days of a pro football training camp, the "look" of a rookie is important his physique, the set of his jaw, even his stride.
OTTAWA, July 18(AP) A four-engine Soviet cargo plane carrying earthquake relief supplies to Peru is missing over the North Atlantic, a spokesman for the Canadian armed forces said today.

ANAHEIM, July 18 (UPI) Bob Feller, Allie Reynolds and Don Larsen will pitch for Casey Stengel's American League AllStar team in the second Oldtimers' game at Anaheim Stadium on Aug. 16. Stengel's team will meet Fred Haney's National League All-Stars in a three-inning contest.

The National Basketball Association expansion to Buffalo, Cleveland and Portland, Ore., and the realignment of the 17 teams into four divisions, has created some odd situations with the New York Knicks' 41game home schedule released yesterday. The 16 other teams all will appear at Madison Square Garden but their appearances will be few and far between.

FOR all the hard times and tragedy that were the constant companions of Bessie Smith from her birth to her death, she did have two lucky breaks although the luck is actually ours rather than hers.
WASHINGTON, July 18 A White House study on national goals has reached the conclusion that the White House cannot set goals for America.

Strong colors mark the roadsides and old meadows now, wild flowers almost tropical in their look. Spring flowers ran to the lighter shades, but now we get the deep hues, the heavy ones, that we think of as strong sun colors.

Country music is definitely "in" at the moment: Johnny Cash and Glen Campbell are superstars; Dennis Hopper and Tony Richardson are using country music on the soundtracks of their new movies; and rock groups such as The Band have manufactured yet another hybrid, country rock. The Nashville sound is so popular that even Dylan has been recording there.
MINEOLA. L.I., July 18 (AP) The first of 14 unions ratified a new contract with the Long Island Railroad today extending through 1971. The other unions are expected to follow suit.

Scientists who grew up in a world where their profession was revered are finding, to their dismay, that there is today a widespread hostility to science. It is evident in broad sectors of the public, particularly the young, and is reflected in the attitudes of legislators who control funds for university and laboratory research.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 Miss Margaret Raymonde Langan and John Chester Moore Jr. were married here this noon in an almost completely homemade wedding, starting with the ceremony, which they wrote and which the Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed in the St. Timothy Roman Catholic Chapel.

Frederick Mathias, a Presbyterian minister.

BRANDS HATCH, England, July 18 Two and a half hours after he was disqualified for the use of illegal aerofoils on his Lotus 72, Jochen Rindt of Austria was declared the winner of today's British Grand Prix to move him far in front in the race for the world drivers' championship.
MT. HOLLY, N.J., July 18 The Board of Freeholders of Burlington County voted yesterday to return 200 American flag decals donated by a local Elks lodge.
SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA, July 4 Australia's Acting Minister for Trade, Ian Sinclair, says growing protectionism in the United States is causing concern in Australian trade circles.

HOUSEBOATING has come a long way since Noah's Ark. And except for the likes of Cleopatra's sumptuous barge, it has had a history of utility, not glamour. Only in the last few years have houseboats moved into the world of pleasure boating; as recently as 1968 the largest manufacturer of pleasure boats had not added them to its line. Now that they have, according to a spokesman for the company, sales are "very strong."
Three private fishing boats participating in a marlin fishing tournametn in the Atlantic off Fire Island reported being fired upon by an unidentified military vessel yesterday afternoon.
Two young Brooklyn men were arrested yesterday morning in connection with the death of a teen-aged girl last week from a narcotics overdose.

WASHINGTON, July 18 President Nixon warned Congress today of "difficult and painful measures" ahead if it persists in running up a budget deficit.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 18 A 44,000-gallon railroad tank car of liquid propane gas that exploded here last night continued to burn until 4 P.M. today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 18 Miss Laura Breckinridge Ten Eyck, a descendant of John Cabell Breckinridge, who was Vice President under President James Buchanan and later a United States senator, was married here this afternoon to Nicholas John Nichols in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

YONKERS, July 18 Miss Daphne Doreen Fodor, daughter of Mrs. Anthony Romeo of Yonkers, was married here this afternoon to Carl Edward Hetherington, son of Mrs. James V. Hetherington of Boston and the late Mr. Hetherington. The Rev. Albert J. Bichanan performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the brides's mother and stepfather, Mr. Romeo, who owns the Carriage Inn restaurant in Larchmont, N.Y.

Dr. Jonathan Serxner, a psychiatrist who had served as a medical officer on Polaris nuclear submarines, died Thursday at his home of injuries suffered earlier in the day in an automobile accident in Brooklyn. He was 32 years old and lived at 108 West 15th Street.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 18 A California-bred colt, Fast Fellow from the Gem State Stable, won the $163.900 Hollywood Juvenile Championship today as the 3-5 favorite. Moonsplash, ran third in the field of 14 2-year-olds.

Two Army veterans, double amputees who lost their legs while serving in Vietnam 18 months ago, were arrested yesterday along with another man and a woman when six detectives raided a Brooklyn apartment and seized 21 kilos of heroin having an estimated retail value of $5-million.

RYE. N.Y., July 18 Miss Andree Phillips and J. Peter Doherty were married here this afternoon in Christ's Episcopal Church, where the Rev. Dr. Wendell Phillips, the rector, who is the father of the bride, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Wendell R. Phillips, brother of the bride.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., July 18 (AP) It's the beginning of a long haul back for the St. Louis Cardinals, who open camp with a three-day routine for rookies Monday in preparation for the National Football League season.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 18 (AP) Army First Lieut. Charles Richards of Tacoma, Wash., won, the United States modern pentathlon national championship today after a tension-packed second round of shooting.

One day early in 1968, Bobby G. Seale, the chairman of the Black Panthers, stood "rapping, really rapping" on a Harlem street corner and won for his party the loyalty and admiration of at least one rapt listener.

Demuth of Bethesda, was married hare this afternoon to Petty Officer 3d Class William Wade Thompson, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel T. Thompson of Lynchburg, Va. The Rev. Orville S. Chadsey performed the ceremony in the Chevy Chase Presbyterian Church.
Fragmented and splintered organizations of the New Left last week held a meeting described by one of its sponsors as "more or less historic."
ELMIRA, N.Y., July 18 (AP) The New York Athletic Club swept to an impressive victory today in the 10th annual New York State Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Parker Field.
