RHINEBECK, N.Y., July 18 Liberty Award, owned and ridden by Bill Morrin of Albany, swept to victory in all three classes today to score 15 points and win the green working hunter championship at the Springbrook Park horse show.
AUGUSTA, Mc., July 18(AP) A shortage of dentists has placed Maine in an emergency dental situation, according to the director of the state's dental health division.
The cast of the off-Broadway show "Joy" helped celebrate the formal opening yesterday of the Bronx River Food Co-op in the East Bronx.

PARIS For fateful anniversaries, this was the week that was On July 17, 1936, the twentieth century's first truly ideological conflict, the Spanish Civil War, began. And on July 16, 1945, the first atomic device was exploded at Alamogordo. Einstein remarked that the world would never again be the same.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., July 18 "I never knew what was going to happen next," associated Billy Casper after his third round of 71 brought him a twostroke lead and a 54-hole aggregate of 206 today in the $150,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 18 The marriage of Miss Christine Louise Smith to Charles Merrill Ambler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambler of Jenkintown, Pa., took place here today. The Rev. William T. Bryant of the Greens Farms Congressional Church performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julian C. Smith.

ROSLYN, L.I., July 18 Miss Lynda Pat Gunther and Coulby James Dunn were married here this morning in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church by the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. William Mar rin of the Huntington Theological Seminary.

OCEANPORT, N.J. Monmouth Park dubbed the "resort track" because of its many amenities for visitors, especially family groups with children 12 and over will mark the 100th anniversary of its first racing program with a weeklong round of events beginning Saturday.

It is bad luck for the Conservative Government that, hardly a month in office, it must grapple with Britain's first national dock strike in 44 years. Political justice would have required the late Labor Government to deal with this intractable dispute that could quickly dissipate Britain's hard-won economic gains and balance-of-payments surplus.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 18 (AP) Turkey, citing "security reasons." has forbidden a United States expedition seeking Noah's Ark tc climb Mount Ararat.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Boyd Burke to Brian James Madden took place in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here yesterday. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Rudolf Harvey, was followed by a reception at the Colony Club.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 18 A construction strike that has crippled the metropolitan area entered its 110th day this weekend with no visible indication that the two sides were any closer together now than they were when the work stoppage was called April 1. It is the third major construction tie-up in Kansas City in the last four years.

EDINBURGH, July 18 (AP) Karen Moras, a 16-year-old Australian girl splashed to a world-record clocking tonight in the 800-meter free-style swimming final of the Commonwealth Games. Earlier Ian Stewart shattered a dream of Ron Clarke of Australia by winning the 10,000-meter run.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 18 (UPI) The South Vietnamese Government confiscated today's editions of five newspapers, four of them for articles dealing with prison conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 18 Rarely if ever does a member of Congress or any other politician have to face a clear-cut choice between going down in flames for virtue or going to bed with the devil. Few choices are ever that simple for anyone, and one of the classic examples of recent times is the District of Columbia crime bill now before the Senate.

WASHINGTON, July 18 Top economists in the Nixon Administration have concluded that the economy is in process of sagging sufficiently below the capacity of its men and machines to warrant a somewhat stimulative economic policy next year.

STANTON, Del., July 18 (AP) Saddle Rock Farm's Twice Worthy outran 11 other 3-yearolds in the $30,700 Rosemont Stakes at Delaware Park today and equaled the mile-and-a-sixteenth track record of 1:41 4/5.

Martin Hamer, the adviser for multi-ethnic services at McGraw-Hill, told a group of educators last week that because textbook publishers had to produce books that dealt with all students, they turned out books "that appeal to no students."
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in unlisted issues registered a small gain last week. The index closed Friday at 20.19, compared with 19.93 a week before.

Samuel B. Casey Jr. has been elected president and chief executive officer of Pullman, Inc., effective Sept. 15. He will succeed W. Irving Osborne Jr., 65 years old, who will continue as chairman of the board of the diversified manufacturing, engineering and construction company.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association schedules a variety of events early in the season. However for one reason or another it becomes more difficult each season to get young players to take part in the events.
Frederick V. Lett has been named coach of Massachusetts Institute of Technology's freshman baseball and wrestling squads.

BISLEY, England, July 18 (Reuters) Sgt. Burl Branham of the United States Army marksmanship training unit at Fort Benning, Ga., finished in a three-way tie for first place in the Donegall Cup competition at the National Rifle Association meeting today.

WHEN the Robert E. Lee family lived at Arlington House about 110 years ago, their Virginia hillside estate overlooked the nation's capital. The house had an oldfashioned greenhouse that was the proud domain of Mrs. Lee, an astute and dedicated gardener.

"No Parachute" is the finest personal account of World War I air fighting I have ever read. The text is a series of letters written in 1917 by a 22-year-old lieutenant to a very new, very much loved wife named Gwyneth-Ann. Arthur Gould Lee eventually became an Air Vice-Marshal, but except for an appendix on the lack of parachutes and an evaluation of Trenchard as a commander, he has not given in to hindsight.

OLD CHATHAM, N.Y., July 18 An exhibition of "Carriages of Yesteryear" will be included in this year's Shaker Museum Festival, to be held on the museum grounds here from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Aug. 1. Mrs. Frederic L. Simmons is chairman of the annual event, instituted in the summer of 1956 as a benefit for the museum.

BOSTON, July 18 (AP) The Boston Red Sox suffered a crippling blow today when X-rays disclosed that their hard-hitting third baseman, George Scott, had a broken right hand and would be lost three to four weeks.

YORK, Pa., July 18 The wonderful world of drag racing, a kaleidoscope of exotic sights, sounds and odors, invaded this agricultural and industrial area of central Pennsylvania today. By midafternoon, temperatures at the York U.S. 30 Dragway had soared into the 90's, but drag fans are so dedicated that they are never fazed by a triviality like broiling sun.
BIDDEFORD, Me., July 18 Volunteers by the thousands converged today on the 120mile-long Saco River to answer an S.O.S. call Save Our Saco.

The head of the sanitationmen's union warned yesterday that there might be a snow emergency this winter because the city was not preparing for such a contingency.
Like the spot on Lady Macbeth's hand, the stain on the conscience of the United States that was left by the slaughter of civilians in Mylai hamlet, South Vietnam, on March 16, 1968, will not go away.
Union taxi drivers decided last night to postpone a work stoppage that they had planned for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow as a protest against the increase in assaults and other crimes against cabbies.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 19 (AP) Mrs. Judy Rankin, aided by an eagle 3 on the 17th hole, posted a closing five-under-par 68 for 209 and won the $20,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Jaycee open golf tournament by one shot today.

BUDAPEST A young Hungarian escorting an American acquaintance around this spring's big Budapest trade fair proudly showed as the most significant domestic product on display a new "third-generation" digital computer that had been built in Hungary with the aid of a French electronic firm.

Sponsors of what they called the city's first politically oriented rock-music festival, plagued for two nights by gatecrashing, threw down the barriers for the final program last night and admitted all comers free.

LONDON, July 19 (AP) Prince Charles and Princess Anne returned home today from a visit to Washington that was criticized here as mishandled by the White House and Buckingham Palace. Some British papers also came to the defense of the 19-year-old Princess Anne.

From the time men first walked on the moon a year ago today, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been struggling to define and win public support for an ambitious range of post-Apollo projects and goals. The struggle is now reaching a critical time of decision.
ATHENS, July 19 Panayotis Pipinelis, Foreign Minister and once Premier of Greece, died in a hospital here early this morning following a heart attack. He was 71 years old.
CHICHESTER, England, July 19 In a comparatively few years the Chichester Festival has established itself as one of the three or four most important drama festivals in the English-speaking world.

At Temple Emanu-El here yesterday afternoon Miss Irene Helen Schwarzschild, a graduate student in education at New York University, was married to Robert Alan Schwartz, who is an associate professor of economics and finance at N.Y.U's Graduate School of Business Administration. Rabbi Mark N. Goldman performed the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Lee Maye's bases-loaded single with one out in the ninth inning scored Paul Casanova and brought the Washington Senators a 4-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today.
The man who burned himself to death in Times Square Saturday was tentatively identified yesterday as Hin Chi Yeung, 21 years old, of 41-86 Gleane Street, Elmhurst, Queens.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 (AP) Jim Hutto walloped a pinchhit, grand-slam homer in the ninth inning of the opener and Mike Ryan delivered a two-run shot in the ninth of the second game as the Philadelphia Phillies swept a double-header from the Los Angeles Dodgers, 9-4 and 4-2, today.

CUTCHOGUE, L.I., July 19 Three black men and a teenaged girl were arrested here this morning and semiautomatic weapons, pistols, ammunition and Black Panther literature were seized after residents near a migrant labor camp reported hearing weapons being fired.

SAN DIEGO, July 19 (AP) The Montreal Expos scored one run on Dave Roberas's error in the ninth inning and a second on a single by Jim Fairey to gain a 6-5 victory today over San Diego after the Padres had won the opener of a twin bill, 6-5.

Lloyd Morgan, an architect and teacher, died at his home in Tarrytown of a heart attack yesterday. He was 78 years old. Mr. Morgan, a 1911 graduate in architecture from Pratt Institute, taught the subject at Yale University and New York University from 1925 to 1936. He then returned to private practice.

PENTICTON, B.C., July 19 (CP) The United States will be short 50 billion to 100 billion gallons of water a year by 1980 if new sources are not found, the annual meeting of the Canadian Water Resources Association was told during the weekend.

TORONTO, July 19 Canadians are playing a new guessing game this summer: will the postman ring even once? The game starts anew each morning as individuals and campanies wonder whether it's their neighborhood's day to go without mail service.

WASHINGTON, July 19 William M. Magruder, the Government's chief salesman for the supersonic transport before an increasingly skeptical Congress, is a former test pilot and engineer who accepts part of the blame for the aircraft industry's present problems but calls the SST crucial to the industry's recovery.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 19 At 10:25 this morning 6-yearold Alicia Ann Finch was studying the Sunday school lesson, "In the Image of God," while the Rev. James Thomas Crutcher reviewed his morning's sermon. "The Task Before Us," in his study.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 Not since Nikita S. Khrushchev banged his shoe had the decorous halls of the United Nations reverberated to such goings on.
DOVER, Del., July 19 (AP) A. J. Foyt led on four occasions for a total of 179 laps to win the Dover 200 United States Auto Club stock race at Dover Downs today in a 1970 Ford Torino.

PITTSBURGH, July 19 (UPI) Matty Alou, scored, the tiebreaking run from first base on Richie Hebner's single and an unusual error in the sixth inning, then the Pittsburgh Pirates added three runs in the eighth for a 7-3 victory over the Cincinnati Reds today. The triumph gave the Eastern Division leaders a split of their four-game series with the Western pace-setters.

BLACK LAKE, Mich., July 19 The internal combustion engine emerged as a major symbol and target as environmental activists met here this weekend to seek new postEarth Day strategies.
NEW ORLEANS, July 19 A family of four left here yesterday in a 31-foot sailboat bound for Africa.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 19 Tax collection, propaganda lectures and military recruitment have become features of life in a Cambodian village controlled by the Vietcong and North Vietnamese, according to a youth who has just escaped.
ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 19 (AP) Mark Donohue of Media, Pa., drove his red, white and blue Javelin to victory today in a Trans-American championship series race at the Road America track.

ALLAGASH, Me., July 19 A 92-mile-long watery corridor through the forests of northern Maine became today the first state-administered recreation area added to the National Wild and Scenic River System.
SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, July 19--More than 700 passengers and crewmen abandoned a burning cruise ship, the Fulvia, in the Atlantic Ocean today after an explosion in the engine room.

MEDELLIN, Colombia, July 19 A plant for assembling Renault automobiles has been opened here on terms that leading United States automobile makers are said to have scored, but which some observers consider to represent the pattern of future private foreign investment in developing countries.

Miss Barbara Lynn Bernstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Bernstein of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Dr. Steven Philip Taubkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Taubkin of Roslyn Heights, L.I. Rabbi Isadore Fine performed the ceremony in the Tree of Life Center of Flatbush.

The final stages of major New York knockout team championships are usually a masculine preserve, but the final match played yesterday in the Fun City Regionals at the New York Hilton was an exception. Both groups of finalists included two women experts.

Vincent Trotta Sr., an artist who sketched 2,000 portraits of military personnel, from privates to three-star generals, during World War II and the Korean war, died Saturday at his home, 143-24 41st Avenue, Flushing, Queens. His age was 84.
"Houston. Tranquility Base here. The Eagle has landed."

MANHASSET, L.I., July 19 Clare W. Sabin, who retired as manager of the Connecticut General Life Insurance office at 90 John Street, New York in 1963, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn. He was 67 years old and lived at 631 Hunt Lane.
PITTSBURGH, July 19 There is still no pickup in demand for steel. With mills approaching the time when any fall improvement should start showing up in orders, new business continues to lag.

BRISTOL, Tenn., July 19 (AP) Bobby Allison of Hueytown, Ala., with relief assistance from Dave Marcis, won the $32,000 Volunteer 500 NASCAR Grand National race today at Bristol International Speedway.

HOUSTON, July 19 (AP) The Justice Department has asked the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit to order the Houston School. District to pair and group 101 schools to achieve greater desegregation.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Robert H. Finch, White House counselor, predicted today that student disorders had peaked and said President Nixon's special advisers on campus unrest would turn in a basically optimistic forecast this week.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 18 Under intense pressure from conservative army and business elements, Bolivia's military Government has moved significantly away from the militantly leftist stance it adopted after seizing power 10 months ago.

WASHINGTON, July 19 The State Department is encouraging an American aircraft company to try to interest Israel in a shipment of modernized F-8 Crusader jets to replace the F-4 Phantom fighter-bombers that Israel has lost, according to reliable sources.
MILLBROOK, N.Y., July 19 Dr. Henry Chase, a New York dentist, has owned Signed Piece for a year, but never had ridden the mount to a championship until today.
PARIS, July 19 (AP) Eddy Merckx of Belgium won the Tour de France bicycle race today for the second year in succession.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said today that he expected the war in his country to last at least another year but that by the end of 1971 United States troops would be needed only in supporting poles. He said the supporting pole would require more than 50,000 United States soldiers.
YORK, Pa., July 19 (AP) Larry Brown of Vandalia, Ohio; Gene Snow of Fort Worth, and Pete Robinson of Atlanta won titles today in the $175,000 National Hot Rod Association summer nationals drag meet.
Brooklyn is presenting the city with some of its "most formidable and urgent social and economic challenges," according to a report published yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WELLSVILLE, Pa., July 19 Ch. Black Hawk of Kasan, a 4-year-old smooth collie, was William L. Kendrick's choice for best in show today over an entry of 1,500 at the York Kennel Club's first show.

NEW DELHI, July 19, (Reuters) Dr. Howard K. Hyde, an American management adviser for the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was killed today when he fell from a tree in his garden. Dr. Hyde, formerly of Washington, had climbed a eucalyptus tree to saw off a branch when he fell, his family said.
In Manhattan, the Silent Majority Mobilization Committee is handing out "Rockefeller-Buckley" buttons and literature.

One of the city's summer festival events died over the weekend while another held to a thin thread of life. The New York Shakespeare Festival will survive its July 26 cutoff date and run at least through Aug. 2. But four concerts of the Harlem Cultural Festival were canceled because of insufficient funds.

Julio Kaplan, Puerto Rico's chess prodigy who is attending the University of California in Berkeley, was invited by chess buffs in the San Francisco Bay area to participate in the recent 1970 Berkeley international students' tournament.
FORT COLLINS, Colo. Twenty-eight men from industry and Government came last June 13 and 14 to the beautiful Colorado State University campus here at the foot of the Northern Colorado Rockies.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Now Arthur Ashe knows how the weekend hackers feel trying to solve their ground strokes: He couldn't hit a forehand well enough to win a set off Cliff Richey today in the final of the $35,000 Washington International Tennis Tournament.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 18 (AP) Juan G. Hernandez, the actor who appeared in more than 30 movies under the stage name Juano, died in a suburban clinic here Friday after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 74 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) The Democratic party said today that it had established a special committee to deal with environmental problems and accused the Nixon Administration of foot-dragging on attemps to clear up the environment.
Ron Mathis had problems, pride and the undirected energy typical of many youths who live in the city's blighted areas.
HELENA, Mont., July 19 (UPI) Kathy Huppe, the dark-haired beauty queen who gave up her Miss Montana title rather than keep her antiwar views quiet, said today she was glad her short reign was over.
PASCO, Wash., July 19 (AP) Lil' Buzzard captured the Atomic Cup hydroplane race today, giving Tommy Fults, the driver, his first trophy since 1968.

WASHINGTON, July 19 To domestic industries other than textiles and shoes, and to the greatly varied importing community, the crucial element in the trade bill approved last week by bhe House Ways and Means Committee is the new version of the "escape clause" of the trade law, Government officials and other trade experts agreed this weekend.

Four grants totaling $18,500 have been awarded to the New York Free Theater, which provides workshops for teachers, students and social workers and operates under the sponsorship of the School of Arts at New York University.

LONDON, July 19 (AP) Prime Minister Heath's Government today declared its determination to keep perishables moving in the four-day-old dock strike. The statement followed warnings by union leaders and port officials against using troops to move cargoes on strikebound ships.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 19 The South Africa Iron and Steel Corporation is negotiating with Japanese concerns for development of an iron ore export harbor at Saldanha Bay near Capetown. The project is estimated to cost about $420-million.
BOSTON, July 19 (UPI) Rico Petrocelli knocked in five runs in the first two innings today with a home run and a double, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 9-4 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

MAINZ, West Germany, July 19 (UPI) Lee Evans of the United States, the Olympic 400meter champion, won the 200and 400-meter dashes today and Charlie Greene and Marty Liquori, fellow Americans, took their specialties at the Mainz invitation track and field meet.
STOCKHOLM July 19 (AP) A fire bomb was thrown into the Spanish Tourist Agency here today. A resulting fire destroyed the lower floor and filled an upper office with smoke.
ALBANY, July 19 John L. Loeb Jr., a New York City investment banker, was designated today by Governor Rockefeller as chairman of the recently established State Council of Environmental Advisers.
SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 19 (AP) Brazil's Davis Cup tennis team defeated Canada today in doubles and took a 2-1 lead in the finals of America, Zone play.
In October of 1939, when baseball's clarion cry was, "Break Up the Yankees," an unidentified Cincinnati player said, "I'd be satisfied if they'd just break up Keller."

HAWTHORNE, N.Y., July 19 -Msgr. James A. Quinn, who retired as pastor of Ascension Roman Catholic Church, 221 West 107th Street, New York, in 1968, died yesterday in Rosary Hill Home. He was 79 years old and lived at 63 De Vries Avenue in North Tarrytown.
The Navy said yesterday that it would conduct a formal investigation into the firing upon three private fishing boats by four destroyers in the Atlantic off Fire Island Saturday.

NEWARK, July 19 The annual Puerto Rican Day parade here today was disrupted by clashes between the Young Lords and the police. Five persons were arrested and two policemen were reported slightly injured by thrown bricks in the disturbance, which centered around a City Hall reviewing stand.
White-collar unionization is widely regarded as on the upswing. But a survey just completed by the National Industrial Conference Board indicates that the pace is well short of breathtaking.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 19 Lullaby Kennels' and Tom Foy Jr.'s 15-inch beagle, Ch. kings Creek Triple Threat, gained his sixth best-in-show award today at the Holyoke Kennel Club's 21st annual dog show and obedience trials on the Northampton Fairgrounds.

While some landlords were reported already signing new union contracts yesterday, the Metropolitan Fair Rent Commitee called a meeting for tonight to act on recommendations worked out at City Hall late Saturday for setling the apartment strike.
LONGVEK, Cambodia, July 18 The sprawling Cambodian military supply base here, which once nourished the entire army but now looks more like an auto graveyard, was attacked by the Vietcong and
LOVE VALLEY, N.C., July 19 (AP) A three-day rock festival marked by one death and one shooting, drew to a close here tonight.

ST. LOUIS, July 19 (AP) Light-hitting Dal Maxvill singled in the tie-breaking run with two out in the eighth inning and Lou Brock doubled in another, sending the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-1 victory over the Atlanta Braves today.
James D. Washington, senior vice president and a director of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., the real estate company, died Friday at his home, 20 East 68th Street. He was 61 years old.
HALIFAX, N.S. July 19 (UPI) Aircraft from three countries continued to search the North Atlantic today for a Soviet cargo plane with 23 persons aboard.
WHITEMARSH, Pa., July 19 Billy Casper won the $150,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic by three strokes today and further entrenched himself as one of the game's notable players.
Harold Howe 2d, a former United States Commissioner of Education, has been named a vice president of the Ford Foundation in charge of its education and research division.
TORONTO, July 19 A parliamentary committee as expected to recommend shortly that the Government create an agency to oversee acquisitions of Canadian companies by foreign corporations.

CHICAGO, July 19 (UPI) Duane Josephson collected four straight hits and drove in two runs today to help the Chicago White Sox beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7-3, in the second game after the Orioles had whipped the White Sox, 8-2, in the opener of a twin bill.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UPI) Eleven persons were injured, none seriously, when a United Air Lines Boeing 737 jetliner aborted a take-off from Philadelphia International Airport tonight and skidded 300 yards off a runway before halting in a field.
MIAMI, July 19 (AP) Jim Merten of Oshkosh. Wis., won the 225-mile Gold Coast invitation marathon boat race today at a record average speed of 72,373 miles an hour at the Miami Marine Stadium.

TEL AVIV, July 19 Israeli warplanes were reported to have attacked Arab targets on three fronts today, striking the Egyptians in the Suez Canal sector and guerrilla positions in Jordan and Lebanon. All the jets returned safely, the Israeli military spokesman reported.
It is obvious that where blacks are concerned, the [Nixon] Administration faces a credibility gap of enormous proportions.
BUDAPEST, July 11 Sooner or later, all conversations with Hungarian Communists turn to the two-and-a-half-year-old economic reform.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, July 19 A rugged wall of coral rock and limestone surrounds Fox Hill Prison where five young Americans are serving sentences meted out by the Bahamian courts for possession of drugs.

WASHINGTON, July 19 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Nixon Administration appear to have pushed the securities industry as far as they intend to on the issue of safeguards for the public funds that will be committed to the new plan for insurance against brokerage firm failures.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, July 20 Enemy forces fired two 100-pound rockets into the heart of Saigon early today, setting off explosions that reverberated throughout the downtown area.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 19 (UPI) Merlin Olsen, player representative for the Los Angeles Rams, said a prolonged strike by the National Football League players would tend to turn the fans against the players.

GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 19 (AP) Tony Roche of Australia defeated Tom Okker of the Netherlands, 6-3, 7-5, 6-3, today in the men's singles final of the Swiss open tennis championships. Roche won the top prize of $4,640.
SEATTLE, July 17 A classic police shakedown and bribery scandal has been exposed here in the Federal court conviction on perjury charges of an assistant chief of Police.

Rudy May and Tom Murphy, two young pitchers for the California Angels, made a weekend trip of 6,000 miles to appear in yesterday's Bat Day doubleheader at Yankee Stadium. On a two-day leave-of-absence from reserve military duty in California, the pair hurled superbly as the Angels swept two from the Yankees, 5-2 and 3-1.

A miscellany of jazz acts appeared at Madison Square Garden on Friday and Saturday nights billed as "The Newport Jazz Festival." Some of them had played at the Newport Festival on the preceding weekend. The rest had been there at one time or another.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 19 The Governments of Colombia and Venezuela are struggling to prevent a long- simmering dispute over illegal immigration from breaking into serious violence.
The credit markets are entering a critical period that should go a long way toward determining whether the drop in interest rates over the last four and a half weeks is long-lasting.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 19 For the last 41 summers, Mrs. Rose Meadoff has studied the styles of generations of college students who have come to her employment agency here to look for high-paying jobs in Catskill Mountain resort hotels.

Whitney M. Young Jr. said yesterday that the Nixon Administration was not consciously antiblack and that the time had come for a coalition of black groups to negotiate with white leaders to accomplish social change.
LONDON, July 19 The Mayor of Meursault grumbled about the wine. The Mayor of Offenbach complained about the beer and the bread. And the Lord Mayor of Sirmione said the skirts were shocking.
Controller Abraham D. Beame telegraphed Govenor Rockefeller yesterday asking him to call a special session of the Legislature to return the subways to city control.

Nineteen months ago, as he was leaving Washington to join the Ford Foundation as an adviser in India, Harold Howe 2d lamented the difficulty of getting the nation's schools and colleges to adapt to changing conditions.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) Itzhak Rabin, Israel's Am bassador to the United States, said today his country opposed a limited cease-fire in the Middle East such as the 90-day halt of hostilities reported proposed by the United States. But he did not reject the suggestion completely.

This is one of the most varied and troubled districts in the city. Residents whose ancestors fled Europe have resisted the latest influx of newcomers, creating serious tensions. DETROIT, July 19 (UPI) The General Motors Corporation will publish the net horsepower of engines installed in automobiles, as well as the horsepower of the stripped engines, beginning with the 1971 models.
MIDHURST, England, July 19 (AP) Boca Raton became the first American polo squad to win the English championship, posting a 13-10 victory today over Prince Philip's Windsor Park team.
NEWPORT, R.I, July 19 While the America's Cup Defense forces broke camp today, the French got a major psychological lift.

Dr. Samuel J. Konefsky, professor of political science at Brooklyn College and the author of books on Justices of the Supreme Court, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 1225 East 23d Street, Brooklyn.

For the first time in five years, the city has had to dip into its so-called "rainy-day fund," taking out $35.1-million of the $84-million cash in the fund to balance the expense budget for the year that ended last June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Ten former, present and future presidents of the American Economic Association made public today a statement expressing alarm at the "serious threat to United States trade policy" posed by protectionist moves in Congress.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 19 Ceylon took the first step today toward severing all constitutional links with the British Crown and Parliament.
The Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday that New York City was being shortchanged by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development on funds for the leasing of public housing units.

WATERFORD, Conn. It was a misty, sodden day at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center, damp enough to depress anyone's spirits, except, apparently, the enthusiastic playwrights, directors, and actors at this year's Playwrights Conference here.

Leo Burnett, Chicago, the country's fifth largest agency, has announced a move that might well shake the business to its foundations. It has resigned from competition in all advertising awards contests and will turn the "tens of thousands of dollars" needed to enter them toward educational purposes.

Light months after the Nixon Administration announced a "phasing out" of DDT, American farmers and gardeners are using less of the persistent pesticide than at any time in the last two decades but not because of Federal restrictions.

WASHINGTON, July 19 Nearly a year after the Nixon Administration began trying to put significant numbers of Negroes on construction jobs across the country, the program is still struggling to get off the ground.

Like it or not and she doesn't Kate Millett is being called the Karl Marx of the women's liberation movement. "Sexual Politics," the dissertation that gained her a Ph.D. in English and comparative literature from Columbia University last month and that Doubleday is rushing into capitalist bookstores this week, is the movement's first above-ground political analysis.
JACKSON, Miss., July 19 Black municipal workers here reversed themselves last night and decided to continue their strike against the city of Jackson.

MACY, Neb. The normally docile and undemonstrative Omaha and Winnebago Indians, whose small reservations are on the west bank of the Missouri 70 miles north of Omaha, have warned the surrounding whites that the Indians will no longer tolerate "prejudice, bigotry and discrimination."

Preliminary Government data indicate that the nation's total output of goods and services stopped declining in the second quarter. Administration spokesmen promptly announced that the downswing has bottomed out and expressed their confidence that total output will start growing in the current quarter.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 In an afternoon of cliff-hanging on both sides, the New York Mets divided a double-header with the San Francisco Giants today and slipped two games behind the first-place Pittsburgh Pirates in the National League East.

Dr. Oswald R. Jones, a specialist in internal medicine who founded and was first director of the Cardio-Respiratory Laboratory at St. Luke's Hospital, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 850 Park Avenue and East Hampton, L.I.

Miss Joan Mayer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ludwig Mayer of Belle Harbor, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Lonnie Wollin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wollin of Brooklyn. Rabbi Allan Blaine performed the ceremony at the Washington Hotel in Rockaway Beach, Queens.
LONDON, July 19 The strategy of the Labor party's opposition in the House of Commons is expected to take shape this week with the assignment by Harold Wilson, the party leader, of shadow portfolios.

A disturbance broke out in the Federal House of Detention at 427 West Street late last night as inmates broke windows on the second floor of the overcrowded facility and threw light bulbs and rolls of toilet paper to the street.
Maria de Kammerer, a portrait artist and teacher of portraiture, died of cancer yesterday morning at Roosevelt Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at 22 East 60th Street.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 19 New Mexico has reported its fourth case of bubonic plague this year, and Dr. Paul Pierce, state epidemiologist, is urging campers in the state's wilderness areas to use insect repellants and keep their pets restrained and free of fleas.
MOSCOW, July 19 The Soviet Union has initiated a broad program to put more meat and daily products on the tables of this country's 240 million consumers.
Boeing, which makes the giant 747 jet, ran full-page ads last Thursday in 85 newspapers in 46 cities throughout the world, headlined, "Take one today and be one in a million."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 19 (AP) Sam McDowell yielded two hits and a run in the first inning, then retired 24 straight batters today in pitching the Cleveland Indians to a 3-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

The Internal Revenue Service has quietly started to tighten up the tax rules it applies to holders of scholarships and fellowships. The Government's new restrictive stance toward student taxpayers began without fanfare on July 1, when it discarded an informal ruling based on a case known as Evans v. I.R.S.
Middle-class elements of the West Side are banding together to oppose what they regard as a threat to reduce their neighborhood to "a racially segregated slum."
STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 20 (AP) The United States wheelchair basketball team defeated the Netherlands, 64-23, today in its first game of the 1970 Wheelchair Olympics.

WASHINGTON, July 20 Attorney General John N. Mitchell told a House committee today that the "no knock" authority Federal agents are seeking to strengthen their search powers had become a widely misunderstood "catchword."
Kremlin disagreements over the old guns-vs.-butter issue appear to have played an important role in forcing the postponement of the next congress of the Soviet Communist party to March, 1971.

BONN, July 20 West Germany's powerful conservative Opposition in Parliament broke the last thread of foreign-policy accord with the Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt today. It refused to send a delegate with Foreign Minister Walter Scheel to Moscow for treaty negotiations next week.
Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, was endorsed yesterday by Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon's chief economic adviser told Congress today that the task of Government policy now was to promote expansion of the economy. He strongly implied that this would require a more rapid growth of money and credit than was the case in the first half of this year.
ORLANDO, Fla., July 20 (AP) Orlando's professional football team is negotiating to sign a woman player. Pat Palinkas, who measures 3525-34, would hold the ball for her place-kicker husband.
WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon threatened today to veto trade legislation if it imposes mandatory quotas on any imports other than textiles.

LANSING, Mich., July 20 (UPI) Police Chief Derold Husby announced tonight that the body of Laurie Muringhan, 16 years old, who was kidnapped during a holdup 11 days ago, had been found in a remote area 22 miles south of here.

Thirteen community organizations from slums throughout the city charged yesterday that the power of the poor to influence urban renewal efforts in their neighborhoods was being undercut by The City Council president, Sanford D. Garelik.

The owners of the National Football League's 26 teams must accept or reject today the proposal of the Players Association to submit their current contract dispute to Federal mediation. If mediation is agreed upon, the College AllStar game scheduled for Chicago on July 31 seems certain to be canceled.

Miss Mary-Elene Canellakis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Canellakis of Sydney, Australia, formerly of Peking, China, was married here yesterday to Elmer Gethyn Rees, son of Mrs. William Rees of Llanelli, Wales, and the late Mr. Rees. The ceremony in Christ Chapel at the Riverside Church was performed by the Rev. James H. Holmes.
GREAT LAMESHUR BAY, St. John, Virgin Islands, July 20 (AP) The world's first team of female aquanauts came to the surface today after two weeks of living under water. They were 25 minutes early.

About 200 persons, some throwing debris and other objects, gathered in front of a Brooklyn police station last night after two teen-aged girls were taken there for questioning following a family disturbance nearby.

NEW DELHI, July 20 (UPI) Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, Foreign Minister of the provisional revolutionary government of South Vietnam, said today that she was willing to return to the Vietnam peace talks in Paris now that President Nixon has named David K.E. Bruce the United States chief negotiator.
CHICAGO, July 20 (UPI) A fourth suspect in the killings of two Chicago policemen surrendered today, two days after a murder warrant had been issued.

NEW ORLEANS, July 20 In a decision hailed by conservationists, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has ruled that ecology should be considered along with other factors in the filling and dredging of coastal wetlands.
A strange combination of circumstances cost the Pittsburgh Pirates a game as they fell to the Houston Astros, 5-4, last night in 12 innings.

For a nation that is urgently in need of a clear and forceful redefinition of goals and priorities, the report of President Nixon's National Goals Research Staff comes as a disappointing evasion of responsibility.

A 53-hour occupation of a Chelsea tenement was ended early yesterday when the Police Department's Special Events Squad evicted more than 50 men, women and children from the four-story building at 233 West 15th Street.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 20 (UPI) Lieut. Gen. Odd Bull of Norway paid a farewell visit today to the Jordanian Foreign Minister, Anton Atalla, and said later that he was concluding his work as Chief of Staff of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in the Middle East.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 20 Off to a shaky start, Mike Ballo, the handsome 1969 Connecticut open golf champion from Woodway, stormed back to post a four-under-par 68 and lead the qualifiers in the Westchester open today.
Leonard Sillman, who usually discovers talent to people revues (he has produced 13 "New Faces" since 1933), is planning a Broadway revival of a comedy in the fall with tried and proven artists.

DETROIT, July 20 The United Auto Workers presented their new economic demands to General Motors Corporation today, and Earl Bramblett, G.M.'s top negotiator, said: "On their face, the economic demands are more extensive and even more far reaching than had been indicated by anything we had heard or read about."

FORT BRAGG, N.C., July 20 (AP) Military policemen scuffled with Capt. Jeffrey R. MacDonald's civilian lawyers today, took the captain into "protective custody," then removed hair from his head and body, presumably to use as evidence in prosecuting murder charges against the Green Beret physician.

HOUSTON, July 20 Miss Margaret Moore, a teacher at the University of Hartford, plans to be married late next month in New York to Clyde William Henry Jr., manager of sales for the Esco Corporation in San Francisco.
Stock prices continued to advance yesterday although buying interest simmered down in the blue-chip issues that led fast week's upward move.
WASHINGTON, July 20 For the second time in three days, the White House gave emphasis today to the simple but radical idea that Congress impose a spending ceiling on itself.
Two taxi drivers were robbed yesterday, and one of them stabbed, in Queens and Brooklyn. The incidents occurred as the taxi industry continued to press for steps to curb such assaults.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The head of the Government office developing the supersonic transport announced today the formation of two advisory panels on the environmental problems that have threatened the further development of the aircraft.
DEER PARK, L.I., July 20 The United States Coast Guard has contracted for a new radar system that is expected to greatly increase its capabilities for small craft searches and rescues.
Paul W. Moseley, a wellKnown figure in advertising circles, has left Pepsico, where he was vice president, advertising.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon listed as "fair" today prospects for Congressional approval of his welfare reform program as White House agents began to put on the pressure for needed Republican votes.

VIENNA, July 20 A dispute over the allocations of costs is delaying the completion of the International Atomic Energy Agency's basic proposals for checking on violations of the treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons.
George Washington's expense account for the Revolutionary War, which was accepted by the Treasury and settled with hardly a glance in 1783, has at last come under exacting scrutiny.
LONDON, July 20 In the face of fierce criticism at home and abroad, the Conservative party Government declared today that it would consider the sale of arms to South Africa for maritime defense.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The House completed Congressional approval today on a bill to Generate 1.3 million new housing units, including a subsidy plan for middle-income home buyers. It went to the White House for President Nixon's signature.

MIAMI BEACH, July 20 Barry Wood, whose broadcast career ranged from acting as master of ceremonies on the old "Hit Parade" radio show to producing the "Bell Telephone Hour" on television, died at a hotel here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 63 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street, New York.
"Someone," Whitney Moore Young Jr. has told black audiences, "has to work within the system to try and change it."

The New York Philharmonic begins its sixth season of free parks concerts tonight in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park. Dean Dixon will conduct the program, with James Oliver Buswell 4th as soloist in the Sibelius Violin Concerto.

A cable television company, initiated action in State Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin the Board of Estimate from recommending exclusive 20year contracts for two other cable television companies in Manhattan.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 20 Drug abuse, a scourge of urban centers, has become a major problem for sparsely settled prairie states as well, Governors of the Middle West said today.
Prices on the London stock market drifted moderately lower yesterday in slack trading.
LIMA. Peru, July 20 Reuters) A Peruvian Air force spokesmen said today that only 12 of an expected fleet of 65 Soviet planes carrying relief supplies had arrived to date.
BRUSSELS, JulY 20 The European Economic Community decided today on tactics in the British membership talks aimed at getting the British unilaterally to give away their negotiating position.

WINDHOEK, South West Africa, July 20 (UPI) Chief Hosea M. Kutako, leader of the 40,000-man Herero tribe, died yesterday at his home 180 miles east of here after a brief illness. He was said to be 100 years old.

Guests at the Monmouth Turf Charity Ball and Carnival set for the Monmouth Park Race Track on Saturday are being urged to wear fashions of 1870. The Centennial Ball is the theme of the benefit, which coincides with the track's 100th anniversary. The ball is only 23 years old.
The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in net income for the three, six and 12 months ended June 30 and for the month of June.
JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., July 20 (UPI) The Apollo 11 astronauts celebrated today the first anniversary of man's first landing on the moon.
WASHINGTON, July 20 Two New York City housing officials asked a Senate subcommittee today to defer action on the Nixon Administrator's housing program.
CHICAGO, July 18 A new chart is posted these days over the detergent section in most of the 220 supermarkets operated by Jewel Food Stores in Chicago and its suburbs.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 20 At the snap, Jim Turner, the New York Jets placekicker, who was a college quarterback, retreated and looked for his receiver, but none was open. Instead of throwing a pass, he sheepishly held the ball.
Whitney M. Young Jr. announced yesterday that 25 United States Senators were ready to sponsor a plan for a multibillion dollar "domestic Marshall Plan" to help the country's poor people.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The Department of Justice sought today to obtain its first court order to stop alleged discrimination against women in job opportunities.

The New York Yankees, who saw both their starting pitchers routed by the California Angels in a double-header loss on Sunday, got their finest pitching performance of the season last night as Fritz Peterson set down the Angels on three hits and won, 6-1.
MARGATE, N.J., July 20 Lucy, this Jersey resort town's 89-year-old, 90-ton, wood-and-tin elephant, was moved today to new quarters in town amid murmurs of approval and rumblings of discontent.

BARCELONA, Spain, July 20 (UPI) A small plane and a West German jetliner collided over northeastern Spain today. All three persons aboard the light plane were killed, but the airliner, although badly damaged, landed safely.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 The two rockets that crashed into the center of Saigon early this morning made headlines round the world but barely made themselves felt in the minds of the people of this weary city.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The nation's manufacturing output fell further below capacity in the second quarter of this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The amount of money borrowed for home mortgages dropped by one-half during the first quarter of 1970, the Federal Home Loan Bank reported today.
A group of merchants proposed to Mayor Lindsay yesterday that Madison Avenue from 79th Street south to possibly 57th Street be made a pedestrian mall Tuesdays from 7 to 10 P.M.
Interest rates on tax-exempt local government bonds again moved downward yesterday, snaking off the hesitancy this sector of the credit markets exhibited last week.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 The New York Mets lost their third straight series tonight, and their seventh game in the Last nine, when the San Francisco Giants defeated them, 7-4.

Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey, wife of the former Governor of New York, died Sunday night in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, after a long illness. Mrs. Dewey, who was 67 years old, lived at 141 East 72d Street and at the family's country home in Pawling, N.Y.

LUSAKA, Zambia, July 20 Laying of track for the Pekingfinanced Zambia-Tanzania railway will begin from Dar es Salaam in October this year, Zambia's Development and Finance Minister, Elijah Mudenda, said here today on his return from Peking.

The discussion was friendly but a trifle strained at times. It took place last week in a posh and scenic Miami country club hotel following a reporter's speech to leading accounting professors and the members of a Big Eight accounting firm.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The House timidly moved into the electronic age today, inserting into a Congressional reform bill a provision to allow televising, broadcasting and photographing of committee hearings.

The Riker-Maxson Corporation said yesterday its lawyers had signed a stipulation to settle a class action suit filed by former stockholders concerning the amount paid them in the merger of Maxson and Riker on April 1, 1969. The settlement is subject to court approval, with a hearing scheduled for Sept. 3 in District Court.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (UPI) Ken Rosewall posted an easy 6-2, 6-3 victory over S. Sugiarto of Indonesia as play began today in the $25,000 Western tennis championship at the Cincinnati Tennis Club. The Australian was a surprise late entry.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that there would be no school-desegregation problem by the time of the 1972 elections.

WASHINGTON, July 20 The chief consulting economist for the New York Stock Exchange conceded today, under questioning, that no economic study had ever been made to justify the schedule of increases in Commission on stock transations that are currently being proposed.

Defense in Extortion Case Scorns U.S. Witness TRENTON, July 20 The lawyer defending Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark who is on trial here charged with extortion conspiracy, told the jury today that it must decide "whose word" should be believed, Mr. Addonizio's or that of the prosecution's key witness, who, he said, "lied."
Commuter hydrofoil service from the Upper East Side to Wall Street got off to a soggy, bumpy, and not too successful start yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The Chinese Nationalist Government is extending an airfield in Taiwan to handle United States B-52 strategic bombers but thus far Washington has not thought it proper to ask why.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 20 (UPI) A total of 2,900 American servicemen were withdrawn from South Vietnam last week, the United States command said today.

Yesterday, for the first time, the centuries-old system of trial by jury came to the New York City Criminal Court, but only one jury was selected and only one jury trial begun. It was the case of a man in Queens charged with "jostling," or pickpocketing, and though the witnesses were heard yesterday, the judge will not charge the jury until this morning.
The First Boston Corporation announced yesterday the election as a director of Roland Pierotti, formerly executive vice president and head of the international division of the Bank of America.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 21 Iain Macleod, Chancellor of the Exchequer, died of a heart attack tonight at his official residence, 11 Downing Street. He was 56 years old, and underwent an operation for acute appendicitis on July 8.
Major North Atlantic cargo ship operators stopped accepting British-bound cargoes yesterday as a result of the nationwide British dock strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 Secretary General Thant accepted today a fragment of lunar rock sent by President Nixon as a gift from "all the people of the United States." The fourounce specimen will remain on exhibition at the United Nations.
LAWRENCE, Kan., July 20 (UPI) A white youth was shot to death tonight and a Negro companion injured north of the University of Kansas campus in this racially tense city.
Mrs. Lilyan Goldman Stark, wife of Abe Stark, Brooklyn Borough President, died yesterday at Brookdale Hospital after a long illness. She was 72 years old and lived at 10 Plaza Street, Brooklyn.
The General Host Corporation reported yesterday that the Goldfield Corporation has filed new claims against General Host and other defendants.

Jack Biegeleisen, founder and partner of Biegeleisen Schour, fur manufacturers, died Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 321 West 78th Street.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 20 Violence marked the opening of Congress this evening as opposition members of the Senate and House fought and smashed furniture before being evicted by the police.
Two leading industrial giants the Xerox Corporation and the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company achieved record results for the second quarter and first six months this year.

LENOX, Mass., July 20 One of the most interesting aspects of the concerts given by the Boston Symphony at Tanglewood this weekend has been the way in which the artistic directors of the Berkshire Festival have dealt with a reduced orchestra. This is that part of the summer during which a sizable segment of the Boston Symphony has to be in Boston to play the Esplanade Concerts.

That fighting general from South Carolina, Strom Thurmond, who held the right wing in the great Nixon victory at the Battle of Miami Beach in 1968, has done the nation a service at last. By threatening that George Wallace will sweep the South in 1972 if the Administration continues its slight slip to the left on racial matters, General Thurmond has taught a pair of useful lessons.

LONDON, July 20 At 7 o'clock this morning the gulls fluttered over the silent, windy Royal Victoria Docks in East London. The dockmen sat quietly in the Connaught pub, sipping beer and peering out at the empty wharves.
Governor Rockefeller set up a new commission yesterday headed by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, to draft "the most up-to-date home-rule powers" for the localities of the state.

The impasse between the players and owners of the National Football League it could be a strike or a lockout or both has created complications of various descriptions. Not the least of these is the status of the game a week from Friday between the College All-Stars and the Kansas City Chiefs, the Super Bowl champions, in the annual Chicago showcase.

WASHINGTON, July 20 Four physicians who investigated health conditions of migrant farm workers attacked Congress, growers and the medical profession today for the disease, neglect and deprivation they told a Senate hearing they had found.

The nation's mutual funds scored a sharp and somewhat unexpected increase in net sales of new shares last month, but instead of buying stocks with this money they used it to help raise their cash reserves relative to total assets to another record.

A 15-piece orchestra that ranges, musically, from Renaissance to rock played at the Village Gate on Sunday. The band, called the Seventh Century ("because this is the seventh century, of organized, written instrumental music," explained Alan Raph, a bass trombonist, who leads the group), is one of a series of new, contemporary groups that will perform at the Village Gate on Sunday nights.

President Nixon's deepening quarrel with Congress over Federal spending is at least in part a result of the President's own failure to respond forthrightly to the rising public demand to reorder national priorities.

Four decades have now passed since Joseph Stalin dragooned Soviet Russia's unwilling peasants into the collective farms. For almost a quarter of a century thereafter the systematic exploitation of the collective farmers whose produce was annually taken from them at a small fraction of its real value provided vast amounts of capital needed for industrialization.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Urban Coalition announced today the start of a $2.9-million project to help black and other minority building contractors in four big cities compete for large construction jobs.
Fifty summers ago and now. A different world, a different city. Fifty summers ago and now. The same world, the same city.

Lou Anemone, an Atlantic Collegiate Baseball League allstar from the Staten Island Pilots had the kind of afternoon at Yankee Stadium yesterday that would make Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds only half satisfied.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 20 (AP) A band of guerrillas occupied the small town of Teoponte, 200 miles from La Paz, for several hours yesterday, burned the offices of a United States company and took two Germans as hostages, the Government said today.
BAYONNE, N.J., July 20 Former Mayor Alfred V. Brady died yesterday in Bayonne Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 74 West 34th Street.

PARIS, July 20 Even the taxi drivers and the concierge ask you how do you like the showings. Fashion, like wine, is a source of national pride here. So far, there's nothing to be ashamed of Philippe Venet and Louis Feraud outdid themselves. Capt. Edward Molyneux stumbled, but then he's British.

The Mayor's Subway Service Watchdog Commission and the chairman of the Joint Legislature Committee on Transportation yesterday criticized the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for its procedures for investigating the IND subway accident in Brooklyn that injured 37 persons on Friday.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 20 (AP) Karen Moras of Australia won her second gold medal in the Commonwealth Games today by taking the 400meter free-style swimming race.
LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP) Bill Singer, using a blazing fast ball in the smoggy late afternoon, hurled a no-hitter as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Phillies, 5-0, today.
